name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the “Clean Energy for All” package.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, distinguished Members, as you will remember, on the previous occasions when we have met over the past two years I was always telling you about our plans, objectives and our future path for creating the Energy Union, one which serves Europe’s citizens, boosts our industries and preserves our environment. But at this point in time as we are meeting in December 2016, I would like to say to you that our internal work in the Commission is now almost entirely complete. We have presented to you over the past two years the strategy, the legislation and the enabling environment for turning the Energy Union from a catchy buzzword to the reality we live in.  With last week’s package we are 90% done with what we have promised, and now we very much need the European Parliament to make sure that the Energy Union also becomes a legal reality. We need to work together to make sure that we start the co-legislative process as early as possible. Of course, last week’s package was rather a big one. It has eight legislative proposals and some important political communications and reports, so I shall just focus on the three main goals: how to put energy efficiency first; how to achieve global leadership in renewables; and what we can do to provide a really fair deal for our consumers.  As you will have already noticed, this package is bound to have a huge impact on jobs and growth. It could generate around a 1% increase in GDP in the next 10 years. It could spur investment of EUR 177 billion and it would directly improve the life and quality of our citizens. On this last aspect it was very important for us to have a particular social component in the package, particularly for those who have difficulties in paying their energy bills, and to make sure that the transition we are starting will be a transition which we can call socially fair.  As you can imagine, because of the time constraints I will not be able to go into the details of the overall package, so I will just focus on some elements of the new governance systems we are proposing. When we discussed it the last time, in December 2015, you were very much inviting the Commission to present a legislative proposal on the governance. We listened very carefully to you and we proposed such a proposal. It serves three objectives.  First, it streamlines the different planning and reporting obligations, and we are making sure that we will really get rid of overlapping reporting obligations, we will align the reporting in terms of frequency and timing, and I believe that what we are putting on the table is in full accordance with the reporting and planning of the Paris Agreement. So it will allow us to continue to play a leading role in the Paris Agreement implementation. Secondly, you have been very much calling for increased transparency and more predictability, which we introduced into the system as well because we see them as two essential conditions to attract investments and indeed to fundamentally transform and modernise our economies. Thirdly, we are proposing a mechanism that is solid and robust so we can collectively reach all the Energy Union’s objectives, in particular the 2030 targets, and to put Europe firmly on the road to a low-carbon economy and society. How do we want to achieve it? The key instrument will be the national energy and climate plans, plans that have a long-term perspective of 2030 or even 2050. The plans will cover all five dimensions of the Energy Union and will be the result of consultations with other neighbouring Member States because we know how important regional cooperation in this aspect is.  We would like to make sure that the work on these plans will start swiftly because we would like to see the final form by the beginning of 2019, and this will be an important goal of my second Energy Union which I would like to start in February next year and where I hope some of you, as we did the last time, could join me.  Then we will have a system of biannual reports and every year we will also issue a report on the Energy Union, where we will analyse the overall situation in Europe and where we will also if needed issue the necessary recommendations. I see that time is flying by. Therefore, Madam President, I would like to pass the floor, if you will allow, also to Commissioner Arias Cañete so that he can go into more detail on the concrete legislative proposals.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as explained by Vice-President Šefčovič, the main building blocks of the legislative proposals cover energy efficiency, renewable energy, the design of the electricity market and governance rules for the Energy Union. Let me start with energy efficiency first. We are proposing, as we promised, a European Union binding target of 30% for 2030, up from the current target of at least 27%. A 30% target is the most cost-effective option by 2030. It will create about 400 000 more new jobs, reduce gas imports by 12% and save EUR 70 billion in fossil fuel import bills. For buildings, a sector which accounts for 40% of Europe’s energy consumption, we are proposing to speed up the renovation rate and promote the use of innovative and smart technologies. This will boost activity and revive employment in the construction and engineering sectors. As examples of concrete measures we propose prolonging the savings obligations in order to contribute to the energy efficiency target, deploying about five million electric vehicle recharging points, and encouraging greater use of renewable energy in buildings, which is currently just 16%. With this set of measures, our proposal will speed up investment in the renovation of buildings, create a building renovation market with a value between EUR 80 and 120 billion in 2030, lower energy bills for consumers, and take up to 3.2 million households out of energy poverty. Last, but not least: for products, the Commission has adopted a new Ecodesign Working Plan. On renewable energy, our aim is to be world leaders, maximising the use of renewable energy in buildings, transport and industry. Our new rules will ensure that the renewable energy target of at least 27% by 2030 is reached. First, we are putting the investment framework right by consolidating several core principles for support for renewable energy in European Union legislation. We move away from national schemes and propose a progressive Europeanisation through cross-border opening of support. We want to put an end to retroactive changes in support, and we call for simplified administrative procedures to get the projects up and running. Second, we propose measures for the sectors which have the highest potential for the deployment of renewable energy: transport, heating and cooling, and electricity. In transport the proposed measures will boost the use of advanced biofuels, electricity and renewable synthetic fuels. We have proposed an ambitious mandate of 6.8% by 2030, with a strong component of 3.6% of advanced biofuels. On bioenergy in particular, after many years of uncertainty, we are introducing strengthened sustainability criteria for biomass. Also, in line with our earlier position, we propose to progressively reduce the contribution of food-based biofuels to meet the European Union’s renewable target: from 7% in 2021 to 3.8% by 2030. This is both realistic and proportionate. The Renewables Directive also includes a number of options for Member States to increase their share of renewable energy in heating and cooling supply by one percentage point per year until 2030. Furthermore, our proposal opens access rights to local district heating and cooling systems for producers of renewable heating and cooling and waste from industry, and third parties acting on their behalf. This takes me to the third area: renewable electricity. Our target of at least 27% also means a 50% share of renewables in our electricity mix. Here the proposed Renewables Directive and the new market design proposals work hand in hand. We are overhauling the electricity market, and we do so mainly in two ways. First, by changing the rules of the market. The new market rules will promote a more flexible market. Sharper price signals will prompt investment in demand response, storage and quickly reacting generation. Our proposals will make trading easier by better integrating short-term markets. Second, by fostering regional cooperation. We will create Regional Operational Centres where transmission system operators will cooperate to ensure optimal use of the European electricity grid and better security of supply. And we will set up a Europe-wide DSO entity to coordinate the operation and planning of the transmission and distribution networks. Third, by giving a European dimension to security of supply. We will develop common rules on crisis prevention and tools to ensure cross-border cooperation to confront new threats to security of supply, such as cyber-attacks. And we will establish a common framework for capacity remuneration mechanisms. This framework will build on a wider European adequacy assessment. All available capacities, including in neighbouring States, will be taken into account and this will make sure that the right amount of capacity is identified. We provide rules the rules to ensure cross-border participation. This is a big change compared with today, and it will keep costs to consumers to a minimum and preserve the functioning of the internal market. But I want to be very clear on one more point. Capacity mechanisms will not be used as a backdoor subsidy for high-polluting fossil fuels. That would go against our climate objectives. That is why we have set a limit of 550 grams of carbon dioxide per kilowatt-hour for new plants, and existing capacity mechanisms also have to adapt to the new rules in due time. In all of this, our European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) will ensure the proper regulatory oversight. We propose therefore to reinforce ACER’s powers to meet these tasks. Finally, allow me to underline one of the essential elements of the package, namely putting consumers at the centre. The new rules will enable them not only to be more informed or to change their provider more easily, but to be able, if they want, to produce their own renewable electricity and be paid for electricity they feed into the grid. In that case, their contribution to the grid costs should be fair and cost-reflective while they continue to benefit from facilitated access to the market – the so-called priority dispatch. I expect this complete set of proposals will be adopted by the co-legislators as quickly as possible.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: On behalf of the EPP Group. — Chairman! Commissioners! The initiative that the European Commission comes with is perhaps the biggest policy initiative in the last decade. Its importance can not be underestimated. Specifically, what has driven our energy policy so far — for the last fifteen, maybe even twenty years? It's been climate policy. The surface is to reduce harmful emissions — CO2 gases — or reduce climate change — what we as humanity do. And thanks to this policy, we have subsidized renewables and these technologies have evolved in a way that we have wind farms, solar generators and so on today that we have a real alternative to fossil fuels. With this initiative, in fact, we will replenish our policy arsenal by introducing another principle that could be quietly translated as price competition. We will now also be thinking about how to ensure that prices are as low as possible for the consumer and industry, and its response and the way we will do that is by putting in more competition, allowing the market to determine what capacity should be in place. We know that subsidies have been necessary so far, but now we have to look at where and how we can maybe move away from that and let the market take over what the subsidies have launched because the market is mature for it.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (NL) Thank you, Commissioner, not only for being here, but also for having approved your winter package in good time at the appointment and sent it to Parliament. There is a huge package of dossiers, legislative and non-legislative, and I can assure you that our group is ready to go ahead and, together with other groups, to ensure that this package gets through Parliament quickly and well. It's a good base to leave. But - and there is always a but - the level of ambition should be even higher in our group. We are one day after one year after the Paris Agreement, and for us this agreement, the COP 21, is the one to which all other initiatives should be covered. In that respect, it is important to strengthen the level of ambition. We are delighted with the binding energy efficiency targets. We think that is great, but as you know, this Parliament has already voted for a binding target of 40%. That is feasible, it is good for climate policy, but also for employment and also for energy poverty in Europe. I'll come back to that later. Two, renewable energy. Good, but not good enough. In fact, you have abandoned the ambition to impose binding targets at Member State level, which have worked so terribly well in the past. We therefore need better targets for renewable energy. I am also linking the priority dispatching to that. There is no point in focusing on renewable energy and giving priority to fossil fuels, which are easier or more expensive to disconnect. Finally, our group is very much in favour of the initiatives presented on energy poverty. We want to support and strengthen them. In addition to climate policy, it is an extremely important challenge. In any case, dear Commissioners, we are ready and we hope for very good and constructive cooperation to get this package through Parliament and to put it forward ambitious.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Indeed, the package presented by the Commission is very extensive, with a dozen legislative projects and hundreds of pages, so there is a lot of work waiting for us. But therefore it should not be considered hastily or under pressure and the treaty allocation of powers between the Member States of the Community should be maintained, mindful of the right of States to establish their own energy mix, the right to choose ways to achieve Community objectives, e.g. decarbonisation. Moreover, the balance between the two objectives of the Union's energy policy, climate protection and energy security must be remembered. Some proposals in this respect raise doubts, for example, contrary to the Union's push for increasing energy independence is the Commission's proposal for the formation of power markets in the Member States, above all the proposed emissivity limit. In practice, it means allowing only gas units to create capacity markets. Similarly, the exclusion of biomass as a source of RES is at odds with the technological neutrality guaranteed to date in increasing renewable energy production. Concerns are also raised by the concept of a financial platform, centrally managed by the European Commission. There may also be doubts about the proposal to establish a legally binding energy efficiency target of 30 per cent. This remains at odds with the December 2014 climate summit findings. But we will work on all this and I hope we will reach a compromise on these matters.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President! Thank you very much the Commissioners, too, for being here and preferring the bills we have at hand. This represents perhaps the biggest energy policy bill we had in the history of Europe and is important from very many perspectives. Partly to ensure that we cope with the geopolitical challenges and security threats that energy policy actually poses when we are unable to ensure that our industry and our consumers can be supplied with their own energy, but we depend on a third power to ensure that we cope with the heat in winter, industrial production and low energy prices for our citizens. At the same time, this energy package also places in a larger climate policy challenge. And it is important to remember that the summer package also forms part of the big picture of this, and also the ETs that we are right now in at a stage of trying to finalise. It also gives at hand that we need to have a discussion about what are subsidies and what are not subsidies. It always strikes me in the debate, as one of those who advocate renewable, that as soon as there is a push for renewable energy, then we get a debate about it being massive subsidies. But all the billions of euros ploughed into coal, into gas projects, they are seen all the time as ventures and as something that matters to industry. I think both will fill their function in the European energy market for the foreseeable period. But it is to ensure that we meet the climate targets we have set, low prices for energy so that we cope with electric intensive industrial production in Europe, that we cope with low prices for consumers and that we do so in an environmentally sound way. We can see in several parts in Europe that it can be done, and together with a proper functioning market, we will also resolve this. Thank you!

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, Commissioners, we as GUE/NGL will not support an energy package that completely subordinates energy to the needs of the market, making it a tool for the benefit of multinationals and monopolies. Unfortunately, the Commission is promoting complete liberalisation of the electricity market, which will give suppliers the right to treasure and thus impose as high prices as they want. They have been calling from 2012 to supervise the energy plans of states and to have overpowers, thereby circumventing the sovereign rights of states. Although some progress is being made in promoting energy efficiency, the target set for a 30% increase by 2030 is a serious reduction compared to the 40% set by the European Parliament. So is the target of 27% consumption of renewable energy sources, instead of the 30% or more requested by the European Parliament. It is also a bad thing that the priority of entry into the networks of renewable energy sources is put to an end. Once again the Commission recognises the problem of energy poverty, but fails to propose a comprehensive action plan to combat it. It has also failed to provide solutions to serious energy problems, such as that of lifting the energy isolation of states and regions of Europe. It has also failed to provide a comprehensive and proper framework for tackling climate change. It seems to us that once again the environment and the energy needs of the peoples have been sacrificed in order to satisfy the interests of multinationals and the needs of the market.

name: Claude TURMES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, allow me to thank Mr Juncker for having stuck to the 30% energy efficiency he promised us, Mr Šefčovič for promoting energy for citizens, Mr Arias Cañete for banning new coal, Mr Timmermans for recognising that eco-design is a big measure for Europe, Mr Katainen for all the work he does on improving financing around energy efficiency, and Mr  Moedas for preparing the energy business in Europe for disruptive change.  But - and of course there are good elements in this package - there is a lack of vision. Why do you call this package ‘clean energy’? Why do you not call it green energy? Because the future can only be renewables. Look at the costs. 50% renewable electricity in 2030, with full electrification of transport, bringing more heat and electricity: that is too low, sorry; get up your numbers.  If there is one thing which is unacceptable in this package it is your costs on renewables. How is it possible that the Commission suggests that an offshore wind park costs EUR 90 [per MWh] in 2050 when we have seen one last week which cost EUR 49 in 2016? You need a reality check when it comes to the cost reductions of renewables, and you need a reality check when it comes to ETS and how well or badly it functions. This is not building trust.  The second thing is that this package is not building trust for the market. Yes, Krišjānis, let the market take over, but not only for renewables. What is a market where coal pollution costs EUR 4 per tonne? What is a market where German power companies have to pay for the decommissioning, while France is organising a EUR 100-billion-plus tax subsidy for decommissioning? I want the market to take over, but it must be a market which is fair not only for renewables but also has to address coal and nuclear costs.  And it is not building trust with governments. Governments are not happy. Why? Because you cannot coerce governments by forcing them to open their support schemes. That is not building trust: forcing them to split, or suggesting that they split countries up into two or more zones, forcing them to open cross-border lines without any security margins. That is not building trust. We need to go beyond borders, but therefore we need concrete plans. For the Baltic Sea, how do we link desynchronisation, which is a political must, with offshore wind farms? For south-east Europe, how do we reduce capital costs in non-euro countries like Bulgaria and Romania, and help Greece? How do we get 100% renewable fast-charging stations between Germany, France, Italy, Benelux? Concrete projects: why do we not have a financing scheme to help citizens’ cooperatives. Let us make concrete projects to bring this Energy Union closer to citizens and closer also to the governments.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one hundred, two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, five hundred, six hundred... These six hundred euros, colleagues, are effectively buried on page twelve of the second annex of the Communication “Clean Energy for All”. True is that inefficient subsidies to the fossil, I quote, are in the main text, but as the penultimate argument of the penultimate paragraph, en passant, and without quantifying. Almost they had escaped us. I refer to data from the International Monetary Fund and direct and indirect subsidies in the EU to fossil sources, in the year of the Lord 2015amounting to three hundred billion euros per year, quantification reported by Yourself, I am sure, therefore, with your authoritative endorsement. Quantification? Yes, we are 500 million citizens, as a matter of fact I do not know how long, the year-per-capita subsidy for infants and the elderly is therefore equal to these six hundred euros. In the face of this scandal everything else pales, it is a disgrace, five hundred million times shame. I genuinely appreciate the work of those who have drafted four thousand and over pages of professional documents, precise and interlinked, but they lack a capital thing: dirty and lethal fossil energy, climatically, sanitarily and geopolitically it doesn't have to be subsidized more than what you call clean yourselves: I find it immoral, obscene and anachronistic, in fact suicidal. Stability, budget balance, denial of conditions and actual laws governing planet, life, universe. Climate stability, circularity, thermodynamic balance, only certain and eternal rules such as death, to which we must respond. So for the sake of justice and science, if you do not want to eliminate fossil subsidies, that put at least on the plate, print at least three hundred billion per year of green money, of real money at least green energy. Enough with the teases of ragged liberism, we put order in the common house. Oikonomy!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Šefčovič, Commissioner Cañete Following the Paris Agreement and the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, the Commission presented its proposal for an accelerated transition to a low-carbon economy this summer, and now the winter package, a clean energy package for all. Commissioner Šefčovič, you said that 90% of the work is done with this. And it is certainly also possible to establish and ensure that the EU can play a leading role in the field of environmentally friendly energy systems globally. The current package has three main priorities, namely increasing energy efficiency, the EU's global market leadership in the field of renewable energy, and a particular focus on consumers. There are opportunities for consumers in that they have been ensured a much more active and vital participation in the energy markets. They have a wider choice of providers, access to more reliable price comparison tools and the ability to generate and sell their own electricity, which will lead to a significant reduction in electricity prices. The ecodesign measures alone will deliver annual energy savings by 2020 in line with Italy's energy consumption, and households can save up to €500 per year. Similarly, ecodesign alone opens up great opportunities for businesses and an additional revenue potential of €55 billion. There are also great opportunities for industry as clean energy has attracted global investment of €300 billion last year alone. In order to achieve the 2020 targets, it will be another 379 000, notably for the construction industry by amending the Directive on the energy performance of buildings, and a market of €120 billion, in particular for SMEs. However, let me briefly make criticisms: I think it is better to strengthen and better network national regulators, rather than a pan-European regulator. I am also opposed to the collection of European charges, and the capacity mechanisms must also be defined in detail once again.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, 'Clean Energy for All', the title is sonorous, its purpose is beautiful. But some questions need to be answered. Can we realistically imagine what percentage of the energy to be produced from pure energy? When we talk about green energy, do we take the limits into account? The barriers are of natural origin, systematic origin, and there are also barriers to support. And do we expect the same from all Member States? In Hungary, the built-in electricity power is 9 thousand megawatts. By 2030 this will be 13 thousand. The power park park has grown old, we need 8,000 megawatts of new capacity. It is unthinkable that a significant part of this should be made from green energy. And one more question: the title is not renewable energy for everyone, clean energy. Let us note that nuclear energy does qualify as clean energy from the point of view of climate change. And so far, I have not heard a single positive reference from ten speakers.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: — Madam President, Commissioners, it is true that energy policy and economic policy are the two sides of the same coin that must be dealt with together. The Union energy package you are proposing provides solutions to the enormous challenges facing the European Union. This must indeed enable us to develop the cleanest technologies. I am very interested in the announcements you have made to us, on the one hand on energy efficiency, on the other, on ecodesign; this will lead to a lot of investment, so a lot of jobs and, therefore, growth. However, as far as energy efficiency is concerned, it is also important to know what kind of financing can be offered. Renewables are an important factor, but complementarity with other current energy sources, be it nuclear, geothermal installations, hydropower plants or biogas produced by methanization. Of course, coal is not the panacea, quite the contrary, and it will be necessary to gradually replace it, perhaps by gas, before leading to a greater development of renewables. However, in this area, we need research — as we have said — and I wonder, because we had pilot projects to capture and store carbon. Today, out of four pilot projects in Europe, only one has been implemented in Norway. Finally, the Energy Union will gradually be achieved, first at local level in local authorities, through better networks that are more connected by interconnections which will create a much denser mesh of European territory. I am confident that this Energy Union is a key strategic vehicle for the success of the European Union, and we will support you to that end.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted, before entering the matter, to thank the Commission and the Commissioners for this great effort of legislative proposal. It is a commitment that comes from afar, announced a few months ago and that we have been following very carefully since then as a group and that today, on time, becomes an articulate proposal for the government of energy challenges. In this spirit, and therefore with a positive eye, I examined the package, I fully understand the sense of the proposed general orientation: opening energy markets to the challenges of modernity, to intercept and to govern deep changes already taking place, aiming for clean energy and competitive costs. It is still early, I think, to grasp all the implications of this package and I agree with what Mr Van Brempt said on this, and, however, some aspects seem to me already obvious: on the one hand, Paris commitments on the containment of global temperatures lead us all to do more than is now proposed, I am thinking in particular of the targets on generation from renewable sources, to the full integration of renewable sources into markets also through a thoughtful discipline of priority access. On the other hand, the package also gives us another message, which we cannot underestimate: the Commission proposes a path of decarbonisation that is too phased, we must invent new systems to accelerate this process. From here we start, the work of these months and these years has been that of the report Gróbarczyk, Griffin, Langen and others, and they tell us that more advanced balances can be obtained.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioners for being with us here today. I welcome this ‘Clean Energy for All’ package, and I am glad it is called clean rather than green because I want to concentrate on the word clean. I am not talking about clean in terms of radical reductions in carbon, although I know that is the main focus for most people today, and that is very important. I am talking as the recent rapporteur for the National Emission Ceilings Directive about being clean of pollutants other than carbon – that is NOx, PM, etc.  I particularly welcome the focus of this package on consumers, which is important as it is ultimately by adapting consumption patterns in energy and much more generally in the way we live that we can truly transition to a clean, low-carbon economy rather than a low-energy one. I would like to see very specific measures to tackle the problems associated with outdated carbon-heavy district heating schemes in some parts of the EU. On the theme of changing consumption patterns, we must look at ways of dealing with the issue of individual household log-burning – currently being overlooked as a major health issue because of our focus on diesel transport. I know these are fairly minor issues this morning, but I think that they should be considered.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Madam President. I would like to start by thanking the Commission for this tsunami of legislation that may be the most important for decades. We now have a unique chance to push Europe's transition from black to green energy while creating hundreds of thousands of jobs, investing massively in research and innovation and doing something unique for climate. There are many things at once, and the winter pack also fills several thousand pages. Now the Commission has played out, and now it is up to us in the European Parliament and in the Member States to provide as ambitious reform as possible. We have a unique opportunity to put an imprint in the story's mole. An imprint that will also make Europe safer and more independent of Putin's gas and sheiks' oil. We need to have green power in the sockets all over Europe. As long as we are not at 100%, it must be our objective to get all the way up there. I would like the European Parliament's approach to be even more progressive and even more ambitious than the Commission's. We must move something, thus also said that the play out, seen with radical glasses, is not ambitious enough. We both can and must go further yet! We must take global leadership in renewable energy and energy efficiency and ensure that legislation here is optimised and implemented for the benefit of all citizens of Europe, and not least the climate.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: e (GUE/NGL). — Madam President, this package is one of a series of legislative measures that we have been through in the last year and a half, which fundamentally changes the face of current energy The European Union. However, it is critically important that we successfully relate this megabalique to the already pending legislative texts relating to ETS, Effort Sharing and land use, land-use change and forestry (LULUCF). There was only a target for energy savings, which was slightly increased. However, there is little to talk about some big ambition here, because this summer we demanded more from the Commission in the European Parliament. We will still have to work on this, for the old familiar cliché that the best is the energy we do not need to produce. Increased energy savings can save thousands of human lives and bring in billions of euros extra if they get a right grip. But here I come to the biggest weakness of the text, which is intended to provide clean energy for all Europeans. The heightened ambition does not yet go hand in hand with protecting the weakest. The Commission promises that the consumer is to be at the centre of its new concept, while the package lacks concrete steps to combat energy poverty. In the case of increased energy efficiency, the enormous costs imposed on energy suppliers threaten to be paid by the consumer, and this will be the most socially weakest. We still have a huge amount of work to do, and we should return to the basic thing that available energy must be the right of every citizen of the European Union, and we should just build it on that.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, a recent study from the Westminster Parliament indicates that current green policies will cost UK energy users as much as GBP 300 billion by 2030. This will do huge economic damage, yet both the National Grid and our energy regulator Ofgem are warning that over-reliance on intermittent renewables, coupled with the closure of baseload capacity forced by the Large Combustion Plant Directive, threaten power outages this winter. The National Grid has responded by doing deals with the owners of diesel generators. Madam President, you could not make it up. We are going to save the planet and cut CO2 emissions by relying on diesel generators for backup. They are also looking at what they call ‘demand management’. I call it supply failure. It is getting factories to agree to close at peak demand times. In medieval times, folk who could not afford candles went to bed at sunset. They ground their corn in windmills which stood idle on calm days. By contrast, we are accustomed to secure supplies of energy available at the flick of a switch, but now these green policies threaten to send us back to the dark ages where our own power supplies are vulnerable to the vagaries of wind and weather, with dire social and economic consequences. In my party we demand secure and affordable energy for homes, for pensioners, for industry. We want an end to fuel poverty. For these reasons, we oppose the Commission’s energy package and we oppose its obsession with renewable energy.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to do something good in these luxurious buildings which, I recall, cost €166 billion a year, we need to do one simple thing, which is to listen and do what our peoples ask of us. And with this logic of listening to act I have put the energy package these days to families, businesses, young people, the elderly and, during this listening phase, what emerges? The need to reduce the cost of energy. The cry of pain of many families who cannot afford a basic necessity that is precisely the use of energy, the cry of pain that comes even from citizens who present me bills of hundred euros per month just to afford light, then electricity. It is crazy that, in fact, there is a cost of one hundred euros per month for our families, consisting of twenty-five euros to produce electricity, from twenty-five euros to transport it and fifty euros instead are additional costs and charges. If we think that in Italy we have come to the madness of inserting the RAI fee, we add this. I conclude by saying that we must absolutely fight for the fact that we do not agree to put further costs into your electricity bills.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). — (EL) Madam President, fierce energy competitions are regenerating wars, fugitions and misery, and on the other hand the culprits (the European Union, the United States and governments) pretending to be concerned about the really dangerous climate change! They cheat. Clean energy and green growth is the cloak of exploiting accumulated capital in investments of guaranteed highest profits, subsidised by billions from the European Union and governments paid by the peoples with more expensive current. In an energy union of privatized energy-commodity, where the Syriza-ANEL government is also distinguished in Greece, the people's energy poverty is rising, while prices for industrialists are falling. Decisions of conferences such as Paris have not prevented thirst, hunger, epidemics, natural disasters, consequences of imperialist wars. It sharpens the opposition of popular interests with a system that kills people and the environment for profits. Only socializing wealth and natural resources, the central planning to satisfy popular needs can ensure cheap energy for all, balanced development of man and the environment.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Madam President! I congratulate the European Commission, the Commissioners responsible for energy, for this package. This is exactly the approach that we need — in the form of a package, because all these elements related to the energy union are linked, and we already have almost ninety percent of the legislation necessary in our Union. Five short notes: The energy union management system contains an indicator of dependence on energy imports — that's a good thing. That's what we wanted in our report on the energy union. Second point: it enjoys a common objective at Union level on RES — 27% by 2030, but on this occasion it would be necessary to guarantee energy neutrality, which we have said many times and emphasised. Third: if we stand guard for this neutrality, then undoubtedly setting the emissivity on the capacity market at 550 kilograms per megawatt-hour is some denial of point 194 of our treaty, where Member States” choice of the energy mix is guaranteed. Point four: financial platform for supporting RES. After all, we want to trade renewable energy, this platform should be in the main act, not delegated acts. And point five: it enjoys an ambitious EU energy efficiency target of 30%, because the ITRE committee has always advocated a high energy efficiency target.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Madam President, Commissioners! With the Clean Energy for all bundle, the Commission is taking a really big leap, and that is a good thing. Nevertheless, I would like to mention a few places where I think the Commission is a little too short. A binding efficiency target of 40% — as Parliament has called for — is achievable by 2030. However, it must also be broken down to the Member States. The same applies to renewables. Without any additional measure, a share of 24% would be achieved by 2030. That is why I believe that the Commission's target of 27% is simply too low. Ambitious targets stimulate innovation and provide impetus for growth and employment. They help the craft startups and they create industrial jobs. And it is long overdue to make the electricity market fit for renewables throughout Europe. This includes, of course, priority for renewables. I would like to see concrete European frameworks for national support systems so as not to produce a patchwork in Europe. Capacity mechanisms — if at all — must not be used to artificially keep old nuclear dividers alive through the back door, for example. One final point: I believe that the Commission's approach is right to put consumers at the heart of the energy transition. In the future, consumers will become more and more prosumers. In doing so, we need to pay particular attention to poorer people. They must be given the opportunity to participate equally actively in the energy transition. If we properly shape the Energy Union now, citizens will immediately feel the benefit. So let's work together on a successful implementation!

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Commissioner, I am pleased to be able to congratulate you today on the proposals you have made. The Commission's proposals show that it sees where the energy and climate challenges lie today. We must indeed set ambitious targets first, but they must remain realistic. Unrealistically high targets pass their goal. I would like to explain three things. Firstly, the emphasis on efficiency is rightly at the heart of the Commission's proposals. However, where the Commission is aiming at 30% on energy efficiency, I propose that we stick to the 27% as agreed in the Council. If necessary, we can re-evaluate in 2023, then the second element, renewable energy. The Commission is right to propose a binding European target of 27%. The Commission demonstrates that, within a single energy market, there is no point in setting nationally binding targets for renewable energy. Finally, with regard to plans for a new market model for energy, I will see to it that the market barriers that still exist are removed as far as possible. I think that the Commission is just short of something in this area.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Madam President, this winter package is about shaping European energy policy for a decade to come, and even longer, so this requires some forward-thinking. The Commission got it right in clearly stating in its proposals that we are moving away from centralised generation towards decentralised production, with renewables and technology at the core, but all of this package needs to deliver on the statement and provide the right initiatives for the energy sector and consumers to move forward with this change.  One key element is connectivity – connectivity between countries, connectivity between smart buildings, appliances inside homes and the grids, connectivity between car and home, connectivity to integrate more renewables to the grid. To deliver on connectivity, grids need to get smarter and we do need smart meters which are, as one expert says, the brain of the grids. So before we talk about more ambition in our renewables policy, we need to make sure that we get these key principles right.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: — I think that the clean energy package is a good document. I hope that it will be properly implemented. Measures to promote the renovation of buildings can really significantly reduce energy consumption, and that is why renovation should be one of the most important pillars of these measures. Secondly, the European Union must speak with one voice on the energy security of each particular member of the Community. Also for the safety of nuclear energy production. In this package, I wasted due attention to the issues of a nuclear power plant built alongside the external border of the European Union in Belarus. Apparently, one should not forget the elementary truth that a single radioactive cloud can bury all the clean energy packages and the entire energy strategy of the European Union. In view of the alarming reports on the construction site in Astrave, it is the international focus on the safety of this power plant that should be significantly higher. Third, energy prices for home consumers. There are countries in the Community where the population is forced to surrender almost a third of their income for energy resources. In energy, monopolists have entered into. The prices dictated by them impoverish the consumers of the Community countries. It is from them that energy companies with not always correct taxation are charging huge profits.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Madam President, Commissioners, what is a policy? A policy is what, indeed, requires voluntary action and is not based solely on market instruments. You know that! If we had wanted to make an ambitious policy on energy efficiency and new energy, the only possibility, given the amounts that would have to be invested in order to go beyond the market, to have a proactive policy, would have been to use monetary creation — the so-called quantitative easing — in agreement with the Central Bank, to make a program of 500 billion new investments in energy conservation and new energy. If you have an ambition, that's what you need to do, you know. Secondly, you need to rely on states, state investment agencies and national state-owned enterprises. That is not what you did, and you destroyed the instruments, in large part, which we put ourselves after the Second World War to effectively build an energy policy. We are therefore at risk of insecurity and we are confronted with energy precariousness.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! When I listened to Mr. Cañeta, I got the impression — sorry very much — that I was listening to a lunatic. There is no talk of profit at all, which is in any economic activity, only here twenty percent, here expelled from the finger thirty percent, here forty-seven, there fifty-two. I wanted to make Mr. Cañeta aware, who was asleep at school, that carbon dioxide is not waste, this is not poison — this is a priceless building block from which plants build their matter. Carbon dioxide is priceless. Thanks to him, the earth is going green at the moment — that's what I say to the Greens. Please, at the moment, most scholars are already saying that global warming, if it exists at all, has nothing to do with human activity. And I swear to God, I swear on my children's head that I won't rest until the people who banged out huge money to fight this global warming land prisons. Because your place, Mr. Cañete, is in prison, not on this bench. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. The Commission's proposals on future energy policy are ambitious, but they must be created. I am well pleased with the obvious references of the individual proposals to the other legislation. For the most part, it goes hand in hand, which is also reflected in the future integrated reporting system of the Member States. Nevertheless, two points of criticism. Firstly, I still believe that the impact of this package on emissions trading is insufficiently taken into account. What effect do the requirements for renewables work? What is the effect of the compulsion to save energy? But what effect do ecodesign labelling, structural requirements also work? How does all this have a concrete impact on CO2 emissions and thus on certificate prices? We must not get back to a situation where we use any corrective mechanisms to undercut the markets and unsettle the economy. We need an assessment of the overall impact of European and national energy legislation on emissions trading. Secondly, I believe that compulsion to save energy is no longer up to date. Everything will go much faster than we think today — green energies also in the heating market. Secondly, the structural change to electromobility: we will need more electricity in the future, not less. Yes, dear Claude Turmes, this electricity will then be green, and we should not block the way to the green electricity age with a compulsion to save money. In summary, the package is okay. However, we also need an assessment of the impact of our actions on emissions trading, and we should work with indicative targets instead of coercion in the field of energy saving.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: — Commissioner, Madam President, the 'winter energy package' should have been a major turning point in energy policy, and I still believe it could have been. But it remains a question whether it will live up to the expectations that are placed in it. The result will also depend on how we manage in the European Parliament to push through the set of measures we proposed in the report on the implementation of the Energy Efficiency Directive and in many other reports we have taken in the past two years. I'm glad the proposals are on the table, whether they seem less ambitious or more ambitious to someone, but in my opinion they are realistic. I would like to focus specifically on the field of energy efficiency, which I consider to be one of the absolutely fundamental aspects of the future setting of the entire energy market. I don't suppose anyone would be found to question the importance of energy savings. Reducing consumption can reduce our dependence on imports, strengthen our energy security, and help households at risk of energy poverty.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I consider the 'winter energy package' to be one of the most fundamental but also very risk materials for future decades. Energy has become an essential part of people's lives, they all need to shine and drown at kidnapping market prices, undeformed, not auctioned by various political interests. However much I agree with many in the text, I consider the setting of binding targets for energy efficiency at 30% as an administrative decision. If we overdrive the targets, the impact on security, investment costs and ecology can be quite the opposite and destructive. Any increase above 27% must be supported by a comprehensive impact study that objectively justifies the proposed level of increase. The Energy Union must provide an incentive for an open energy market that will help the competitiveness of Member States and industry.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, such a proposal will always provoke reactions – it is too ambitious, lacking ambition, and so on. What I am looking forward to seeing is whether this is complex proposal which will do away with distortions of the market and we will have an Energy Union and a functioning internal market.  We always speak in favour of completion of the internal market, but then with the proposals and the deliberations in Parliament we gradually dilute it. For me, the absolutely key issue is whether a company will find it viable to invest in the energy market. That is key. Once that happens, we will have the functionality of the internal market, so issues like the design of the energy market, issues of price zones, issues of capacity mechanisms and so on, these have to be assessed in a complex way and then we might find out whether the target XY is ambitious or realistic or not, but as I say, the functionality is the absolute key issue and we will assess it on the basis of the impact assessments, for sure.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, Commissioner Cañete. Congratulations on the Clean Energy package. It shows that the European Union is on its way to investing more in production again. Ultimately, we should also set up a binding target that we want to have 30% of gross national product in production again by 2030. If we see that France is currently at 11%, then this is a huge chance that this Clean Energy package will create new employment here, and of course investment. I believe, however, that the traffic issue could be solved more efficiently, using sensor technology and the new 5G system, if we use 5G for continuous driving. I went to Parliament today, you stand some red lights for three minutes. There are heavy trucks that accelerate back to 50 kilometers per hour, and this is a huge challenge, because of course this creates an enormous amount of particulate matter from braking. The abrasion of the tires, the brake pads, the engines are in the worst condition. So: take care of continuous driving, please, so that the cities can be driven at a continuous speed. This also increases the lifespan of batteries in e-mobility. Ultimately, it is also necessary to thermally renovate 140 million houses in Europe. With vocational training, i.e. with appropriate training, one could create many new jobs that could relieve citizens' purse and additionally guarantee new jobs with good incomes. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Rübig, you are a specialist on energy: would you not consider that we must raise the level of ambition for renewables and energy efficiency and develop further provisions on energy poverty, whilst avoiding hidden subsidies for mature technologies?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Thank you very much for this question. I believe that we could easily solve the problem by making it easier to invest. Namely, in particular, investments for consumers, in the appropriate thermal protection of homes from cold or heat. My proposal would be to make the emission trading system, the proceeds generated by the national finance ministers, available to the European Investment Bank, thereby launching an investment programme that will allow these energy efficiency measures to keep the money in their pockets. Thank you for this question.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I would like to inform you that I will not be taking any more blue cards, because we still have many speakers on the list.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, just like the customs union and the single market, the UK Government is being incredibly silent on the issue of the internal energy market. Today’s Clean Energy Package highlights that the EU is leading the way when it comes to promoting renewable energy, making our buildings more energy efficient, decarbonising our economy and fighting energy poverty. However, I believe that we can be more ambitious, especially in terms of energy efficiency. It is paramount that the UK remains within the internal energy market, and that we don’t listen to the usual climate change denial claptrap of UKIP. Outside the internal energy market, the UK will lag behind its 27 neighbours. Not only is that bad for the environment, but it is bad for our industries and the sustainable green jobs of the future. Energy is not a commodity. It is a  basic social right. So what is your vision, Theresa May? Is it a United Kingdom that turns its back on the climate, or a leader promoting jobs alongside our neighbours?

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Madam President! Messrs. Commissioners! When taking the floor in this debate, I want to draw attention to a very important issue from the point of view of my country, Poland. According to the criteria proposed by the Commission, countries using coal as an energy carrier will not be able to launch so-called power markets, and the EU treaties state that individual Member States determine their energy mix themselves. Unfortunately, such effects result in a last-minute solution to the draft regulation that only power plants emitting less than 550 kilograms of CO2 per megawatt-hour will be able to participate in the capacity market. In a situation where state-of-the-art units now emit about 700 kilograms of CO2, such a provision basically eliminates coal-fired power plants and the 5-year transition period proposed here for older power plants not meeting this standard changes little. Describing such a solution to the regulation at the last minute (because in earlier versions it was not) without assessing the effects of such a regulation shows that it was a political decision by the Commissioners without seeing what economic effects would entail on Member States, including such a country like Poland, which has carbon-based energy.

name: Herbert REUL
text: — Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen. This is a very interesting proposal that the Commission is presenting. A huge package that probably won't be able to accurately assess all the details yet. But it's an attempt to approach the question a little more pragmatic. If we want to have favourable prices because we see energy poverty as a problem, then we must not just continue to gas. If we want to ensure that security of supply is increased and that the impact on the climate is reasonable, then we need an overall approach and must take into account — and I find this interesting in the concept — that the different measures are also related to each other. If emissions trading is to be such a central element, then — as Mr Pieper has rightly said — more attention should also be paid here to the impact we actually have with the other measures. There are interesting indications, including the question of how we deal with the feed-in priority for renewables, that this should no longer exist in the future. But even there is the devil in the details. There are points that need to be talked about even more intensively. I don't understand why ACER needs to be built and expanded like this. Why do we need such a centralist European unit with additional competences? It is quite enough to improve the cooperation of the existing national institutions that we have. Rather, it is about practical questions about how to speed up the network expansion. I do not see a clear answer here. And, last but not least, what is always happening here in Parliament and what I fear again: more and more, ever higher, ever faster objectives — this competition does not take us any further. We need practical solutions to move forward.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: - Madam President! Priority in dynamic, optimal realization of the optimal energy union paradigm is energy security, the fight against energy poverty, the modernization of production and transmission infrastructure and the green use of available energy sources. Energy, including clean coal, when not enough other sources are available. This is necessary to reduce the energy dependence on imports. It should not be forgotten that an important element of the energy union is the full thermomodernization of residential, commercial and public buildings. Support also requires the development of efficient production of mains heat in CHP plants, also in coal-fired green ones. Decarbonisation cannot be achieved by artificial administrative constraints and unrealistic limits imposed, but by real efficiency increases.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! The Clean Energy Package raises reservations. The first note concerns the criteria that Member States will have to meet in order to start the power market. According to the treaty provisions, Commissioner, each state has the right to decide on its own shape of the energy mix. Unfortunately, the Commission's proposal excludes the possibility of coal when building a power market, and this will weaken Poland's energy security. Secondly, the Commission, having entered into the role of the wizard of energy policy, assigns itself the competence of the Council. In October 2014, heads of government agreed that the union would seek to reduce energy consumption by 27% by 2030. Without any legal basis, the Commission changes the ambition targets to a legally binding target and raises it to 30%. I hope that further work on the Clean Energy Package will remove these objections.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, having had the privilege of representing Parliament in Paris and in Marrakech at the two COPs, I welcome the introductory  remarks by the Commissioners and look forward to working with them as we move towards our ambition of a low-carbon economy. I want to use my time to focus on the proposal on the energy performance of buildings, which is an area which I have a keen interest in and in which I see significant potential. Big improvements are needed in numerous buildings, 75% of which are currently considered to be inefficient. Buildings account for 40% of final energy consumption in Europe. An enormous amount of this is wasted due to buildings not performing efficiently. Our work in the coming months needs to ensure that we set the right framework to make investment into energy-efficient projects in buildings happen; I look forward to that challenge. I welcome the mandatory minimum requirements for renewable energy in new buildings, and in buildings undergoing major renovations. This, along with a more ambitious energy efficient target of 30%, will help to ensure real improvements in terms of energy use in our buildings. Efficient homes mean less energy consumption, lower bills and a lower carbon footprint. It is a true no-brainer, and I look forward to work in the proposal in the coming months.  I feel that the key challenge in making the required improvements is mobilising the investment to bring about the required changes. The new initiative to unlock EUR 10 billion in public and private funding for energy efficiency and renewable energy in buildings, as announced in this package, is welcome and will be a crucial part of this. I also welcome the EUR 400 million under the EIB FC fund for France, that could be emulated elsewhere.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: — I join in congratulations on the Commission's ambitious document, for the first time we have a fully linked plan, which has used digital technologies and innovation to create a modern, efficient energy market that meets the realities of today's life. A historic agreement on climate change has been reached in Paris, so we must be leaders in this area and continue to maintain the initiative. Renewable and clean energy is one of the most effective ways in the long term. We have too many untapped opportunities in the area of renovation of buildings, so the proposals put forward by the Commission will speed up this process and ensure much more efficient energy savings and the transition to a low-polluting economy. This will also reduce energy bills, which is very relevant for the most socially vulnerable consumers. It is important that the creation of the Energy Union contributes to the reduction of energy poverty, which in the long term brings real benefits to our consumers and businesses.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! In energy policy, the context of a country, the source, the raw materials it uses and the standard of living must always be taken into account. Only such a policy is an expression of solidarity, not socialism, which wants to use public power to eliminate competition or limit the possibility of it. Elimination of coal as a source of energy will only lead to increased dependence not only of Poland, but of the entire European Union on Russia. Who doesn't understand this at all should not exercise any public authority. Please, sir, I would like to recall the present Article 98 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the In this article in Maastricht, you enshrined Germany's special right to public aid for that part of Germany that was under Soviet domination, which experienced the woes of communism, and today it uses the supposed pretext of public aid even where it is not at all, that limit the development of most countries that have experienced the same.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Madam President! I believe that the overall package is ambitious enough, it is balanced and fair, and excessive demands, as some of which have been made here, do not have a realistic background, because in the end we also have to deal with the responsibility of the Member States over the energy mix. Therefore, it's no use if we throw out the baby with the bathwater. The positive and negative points have been mentioned. I want to name a few. With the proposal for a new electricity market design, the Commission is setting the right course for a strengthened flexible internal electricity market. However, the necessary network expansion is missing, as has already been pointed out. The Commission is proposing an electricity market with clear price signals. However, this also provides for the shift to supranational authorities and institutions, and the issue of responsibility and liability may be very complicated. The issue of capacity markets: Capacity markets should only be allowed as a transitional solution. We shall see what the Member States make of it. As far as coal is concerned, the benchmark is 550 mg CO2 for new power plants. Commissioner Cañete, this is such a high benchmark that it cannot be met and practically means the economic disadvantage of all these power plants. Finally, the Commission prefers a significant increase of ACER competence. There too, the question is whether the problem of overcapacity in the electricity market can be tackled correctly here.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, we are facing a great opportunity. The transition to clean energy is an environmental need and an opportunity for economic growth and job creation. We need a single energy market, a more integrated, more transparent market capable of providing affordable prices and meeting our climate objectives. In addition, overcome the isolation like the one that suffers the Iberian Peninsula. We need to push the transition towards a model that pivots renewable energies, that drives self-consumption and that undeniably bets on improving energy efficiency. And as socialists, but also as people, we demand definitive action against energy poverty. Fifty million Europeans and 5 million Spaniards await a response to the challenge. The citizens, Commissioners, must be the centre and reason for the European Union's new energy policy.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Madam President. Thank you to the Commission for presenting the winter package now. This is a huge piece of legislation and it is probably the most important piece of legislation in this Parliament in the current period. Energy policy has a direct impact on our security policy and our security of supply, as we are unfortunately becoming increasingly dependent on gas from Putin's Russia and oil from the Middle East. In addition, our decisions affect both our environment and our climate. By making better use of European energy, we reduce dependence on imported energy and are less affected by geopolitical unrest. Now let's live up to the “Clean Energy for All” headline! It's good to see that energy efficiency is being put in high seat. That 30% should be no problem at all! There are plenty of jobs and employment in this policy, especially in energy efficiency and energy refurbishment. It's within different jobs — there are also jobs for people in the blue boiler suits in energy renovation! But from a broader perspective around digitization, education, etc., we also keep a lot of money at home in Europe and spend the money in Europe rather than sending the money to Russia and to the Middle East.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, let me start by thanking Vice-President Šefčovič and Commissioner Arias Cañete for delivering this winter package as promised. As representatives of our citizens across the EU, we need to answer our constituents’ calls when they ask us for policies that will deliver better air quality and cleaner energy. I believe that this package introduces significant improvements in energy efficiency, which, if properly carried out, can lift people out of energy poverty, cut greenhouse gas emissions and create jobs. Energy efficiency comes first, and rightly so. On the other hand, we need to make sure that renewable targets can actually deliver the results we want and do not slow down the momentum reached during COP21. The shift away from coal power plants needs to be concretely encouraged, and no loopholes should remain open to subsidise the use of coal for power generation or high-polluting fossil fuels. The technology and the solutions are there, and we need to make sure that we deliver a package that will seriously tackle climate change in the decades to come. This is once again our opportunity to rise to the occasion and move away from fancy words to concrete action which continues to build on the Paris Agreement.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President! I would like to congratulate the Commission on the winter package and, above all, on the part of energy efficiency. The Commission has really put energy efficiency first. This is not just in some theoretical paper, but that is agreed in the legislative proposal, and I very much welcome that. Energy efficiency is the low-cost part of climate protection policy. I would like to take up what Bendt Bendtsen said: if we invest in energy efficiency, we can save a lot of money on fossil fuels. In recent years, we have transferred EUR 1 billion a day to Russia, to the Arab states. If we can at least partly invest this money in European industry and in the craft sector, which will help us to bring energy efficiency forward, it will certainly be better spent there. I have a question about the proposal on renewables, and I would like us to work together to resolve this issue: we have a binding target of 27%. The path is not as clear to me as we are achieving this goal. In terms of energy efficiency, the path is described relatively clearly, and not so for renewables. Above all, I would like countries investing in renewable energy to be recognised in the event that we fail to meet the binding target. So reward pioneers, not punish pioneers. And I would be delighted if we could work together with the Commission on this path across the political groups.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, this proposal will limit the overall cost of our decarbonisation challenge, which is very important. We can read this in particular in energy efficiency. It is the best example of how actions will soon be paid back. The Commission also aims to eliminate artificial bottlenecks, which will facilitate investments and lead to the better functioning of the regional and European electricity markets. Decarbonisation of the transport sector is strongly prescient. In the long run, electric vehicles will be in the mainstream of personal transport, so it is important to lay down the foundations of this transition today. But we will need to deliver right away too. I thank the Commission for coming forward with the proposal to substitute fossil fuels with sustainable biofuels. Many Europeans will drive using liquid fuels for decades, but this proposal is not coherent and we will need to look at the coherence of the policies on biofuels in the future months.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Madam President! Messrs. Commissioners! I understand the intentions of the European Commission — this is an attempt to find a solution to make the economy of the European Union competitive in a situation of imminent technological transition in energy, and these reimagining must move towards clean energy. And indeed the strong point of this proposal is to try to captivate green energy. Renewables lose priority in access to the grid, but the initial assumption that this assumption is overly optimistic, namely the assumption that this package will be possible to achieve one percent GDP growth on the scale of the European Union. Therefore, it actually abstracts from the differences between the countries, the perfectly familiar conditions of the respective countries of the two commissioners. This is not a technologically neutral proposition, as you gentlemen know. Thus interferes with the energy mix, which should be a sovereign decision of the Member States. From the point of view of a country like Poland, of course, the limits that virtually exclude coal from the capacity market look most worryingly. This limit, which the Commission proposes of 550 grams of CO2 per kilowatt-hour, prevents public support, but worse, prevents public support in energy that goes towards clean coal, and this is for countries such as Poland the only possibility of achieving the objectives climatic and should not be punished for it.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as your communication says, the least expensive energy is that which we do not consume. The key to this apparent paradox is energy efficiency, which I consider a top priority together with renewables. It is an opportunity for citizens, for the energy bill, for environmental improvement, for the health of the citizens, yes I say clean air as you say, if I think about what happens in some cities of Europe, where today the air is unbreathable. And it is a great opportunity, formidable for industry too, but we need to act in a collegial and integrated way. I therefore call on the Commission, formally, to work in a more coordinated way with the Commissioners on Industry, Innovation and Budget, because energy efficiency means, first, support for the research in the technological and environmental field, for housing, transport and industries themselves; supporting new businesses, startups that are born with these innovative projects; to have a more flexible finance and smarter precisely for these products, for their creation and distribution in the market; prepare the necessary skills and professions. We are all aware that in Europe, in this area, Europe could have strong competitive capacity and industrial leadership.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Madam President! A European energy market must be based on healthy and free, open competition. It must be based on good conditions for renewable forms of energy, it must ensure, through the price mechanism, that different forms of energy and new energy teams can compete fully and emerge and play the role that in future they must be able to play. A European energy market must also be based on a close relationship between countries, with the development of transfers between countries, across the Baltic Sea, in Europe, on the continent, so as to create a market. And here the Commission has to take the lead on proposals that involve opening up what is a market. But at the same time, I would also like to say that this is not possible to achieve if you allow Nord Stream 2 Nord Stream 2 is a project that, for its political purpose, is to undermine European independence and European security of supply. It has no commercial functioning purposes, but the political purpose of dividing Europe. The Commission has a responsibility to maintain European security and European security of supply, and you have a responsibility to ensure that no one achieves dominance in the European energy market, which is contrary to competition and the opportunity to make this market strong. Thank you!

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Madam President, in recent years the price of gas on the world market has decreased by 40%, but the Hungarian government has reduced the price of residential gas by only 10%. The difference was either absorbed by the state or this extraprofit was put in the pockets of businesses close to the government. The Hungarian authority's gas price, in connection with which the Hungarian Prime Minister is imagining another attack on Hungary in Brussels, serves to keep gas prices high in Hungary precisely through official prices. In Hungary, the official gas price does not reduce, but, on the contrary, increases the retail gas price. That is why, Commissioners, the problem in Hungary is not the institution of official price. We even support that. The real problem is that, with a pronounced corruption objective, the Hungarian government gives gas to the population much more expensive than it costs on the world market. On the other hand, we must act together.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, my fellow Members have already had the opportunity to call on you for more ambition, with higher binding targets on the three essential parameters of your package: greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and renewables, and I agree with them. But who says ambition also means coherence and completeness. There are concerns that capacity mechanisms subsidize fossil fuels. How, therefore, can we reconcile the essential energy security with our commitments to emit less CO2? What are you proposing to relaunch energy efficiency investments in the electro-intensive industries that your own services recently noted as stalled? You took a step on energy precariousness by acknowledging that this is a truly European subject. But this evolution does not disappear with a magic wand the millions of Europeans who are victims of it. Much remains to be done. Finally, since you seem to be inspired by the European Semester for your governance component, how do you intend to transform what is now a somewhat undergoing technocratic procedure into a genuine democratic exercise of positive debate on common energy options?

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: — Madam President, the step forward in the implementation of the Energy Union must also give impetus to save the European project. It's agendas like this one that the Union needs — agendas that allow us to lead the design of the future and erase the ghosts of the past. The targets are ambitious: 50% clean electricity by 2030, emission-free electricity production in 2050, additional net investment of €177 billion per year between 2021 and 2030, and 900,000 new jobs. It is important, however, that these figures come true, but we cannot be dazzled by them. We must seize this opportunity to modernise the market, make it more transparent, efficient and fair, improve interconnections and regulation, develop production processes and create even smarter networks, combat regional asymmetries, ensure the competitiveness of industry and services, ensure universal access to electricity and reduce energy poverty. Clean energy is a good choice for the planet and for people. Today it is also part of the energy needed for the European project to survive. So this is an agenda on which the European Union must not fail, on which we must not fail.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, let me start by congratulating you, and indeed the whole Commission, on this very impressive winter package with real European value. It is a good starting point, but I also think that we need to raise our ambitions. Let me give a few brief examples. When I read the Commission proposal on ACER, I see words such as ‘may’ and ‘recommend’, but if we want a truly interconnected and sustainable European energy market that effectively does away with transmission bottlenecks, those words must be changed to ‘shall’ and ‘decide’ in a number of places. Europe needs an energy regulator. We need a much stronger ACER with real powers. On renewables, we remain embarrassingly close to the Commission’s own ‘doing nothing’ scenario.
