I will once again quote Commission President Juncker, who said that Europe should be number one in renewables, so let us beef up our ambitions as well on that point. We are ready to work with you, we have a good starting point, but we need more ambition.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposals put forward all respond to the desire to achieve the transition to a sustainable system that holds together low carbon emissions, safety supply, the active role of consumers, benefits for the environment, the health of citizens and also, it is good to say, the competitiveness of our system. One given: in 2015 alone, renewables attracted more than 300 billion euros of worldwide investment and stimulate new technologies in which Europe enjoys competitive advantages. If I welcome the priorities given to energy efficiency, however, I would like to stress the concern about the measures envisaged for renewable. The target has remained at 27 per cent and a number of pro-renewable measures are being eliminated, while we still have subsidies to fossil sources, and in particular coal, standing. Here, let's figure out where we want to go and where we put resources is an essential indicator of the way to go. I say this clearly: we cannot afford shyness now, we avoid not only not moving forward, but even slowing down compared to what we have done up to now.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: — Mr President, I understand that wind turbines are generating such enthusiasm among our ruling elites, who love both brewing air and distributing subsidies. But we must realize the disastrous impact of these 21st century windmills on our ecosystem. I am thinking in particular of the growing use of rare earths, the extraction and processing of which is particularly polluting. So go and ask our fishermen what they think about offshore wind, whose maintenance costs are, on the other hand, terribly high. But all this is not even really beneficial to our economies, as the wind turbine construction market is increasingly being captured by Chinese companies. But there's worse! Wind turbines disfigure our landscapes shaped for centuries by the generations that preceded us. It is this same badly thought out ecology that wants to systematize isolation from the outside, seriously jeopardizing our built heritage. However, from January 2017, in France, obtaining a building permit will no longer even be necessary for the construction of wind turbines. They should therefore logically multiply everywhere in an anarchic manner, depending on the subsidies. That is why I think it is time to reinvest in other renewable energies, such as the marine hydroenergy, such as Normandie Hydro, which has been neglected in recent years. Hydropower remains by far the largest source of renewable electricity. We must also encourage the solar. (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr. President, gentlemen, the Commission's proposals on clean energy for all Europeans reflect the fact that the transition to clean energy is a sector of future growth and an opportunity for smart investors. Under this package, which will mobilise public and private investment amounting to €177 billion per year by 2021, gross national income can increase up to 1% over the next ten years and create 900,000 new jobs. Europe imports €1 billion worth of energy per day. Investing in energy efficiency reduces the need for energy production. By investing in it, we invest in the European economy, we invest in our homes, invest in our production, in our small businesses rebuilding our homes. It is better to invest 1 billion euros a day in our economy than paying for energy from imports. It is also necessary to make better use of the potential of biomass and biofuels based on sustainable management of these resources. Europe and Croatia do well in this.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, in the biofuels part of the package, I naturally understand that we are encouraging the production of modernised technologies, but first generation biofuels also make sense. The target of the latter reduction from 7% to 3.8% is indeed exaggerated in the grain or, more specifically, in the maize zone in Europe. It should be remembered that the transport of grain and maize by land over 500 km already represents significant energy costs and causes significant environmental damage. Therefore, it is worth processing them locally. Furthermore, it should be borne in mind that a significant amount of feed and other useful products are produced when biofuel is produced. I therefore propose the introduction of a specific target number for the countries of the grain or maize zone.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, Mr Arias Cañete, Mr Šefčovič. It is good that you come to this House to discuss this winter package, because you are talking about putting citizens at the centre of energy, but what you are putting at the centre is fossil fuels. By their deeds we know them and not by their beautiful words. It would be nice to explain why they are proposing contradictory measures in this package. Capacity mechanisms, first of all. Undercover subsidies for fossil fuels. According to estimates, 95% of the Union's coal plants will receive money; they will receive millions for continued contamination until 2026. Secondly, a clearly insufficient goal of efficiency and energy saving. We should reach 40% binding and without legal loopholes, facilitating public investment to reduce consumption and eradicate energy poverty. Insufficient objectives to comply with the Paris Agreement and contradictory measures: this is what we see in this package designed to continue to slow down the democratization of the sector and maintain the power of fossil fuel lobbies.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commission on this energy package, which is broadly a very good and balanced entity. We are committed in Europe to reducing emissions and it is important that it is done as cost-effectively as possible and also at arm's length. This is where energy efficiency plays a big role. We know that in many Member States we can significantly and very cost-effectively increase energy efficiency. But two things I want to raise about this package in particular. The other relates to renewable energy and subsidizing it. It is natural that, in the early stages, renewable energy must have been strongly supported, but it must now gradually reach an arms-length situation as well. A form of energy based on permanent production support cannot be on an economically sustainable basis. Another issue relates to cutting emissions from transport. It is good that the Commission has taken steps in this direction, but we still have a lot of opportunities to cut transport emissions more ambitiously, and this is where Europe can also be a pioneer in the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — (EL) Mr President, the liberalisation of the energy market in the European Union must be combined with the introduction of stricter safety conditions, particularly as a result of frequent accidents involving the supply of natural gas. Mr Vice-President, Mr Šefčovič, the Commission should check the safety regulations for gas installations from the network of providers to households, apartment buildings and apartments in the various Member States of the Union. In addition, the Union must develop renewable energy sources, strengthening the energy policy of the Member States, while taking measures at the same time to strike energy poverty. In Greece, due to mercelic austerity and memorandum, 70% of households are unable to keep their homes warm due to excessive taxation on heating oil. The Commission acknowledged, however, that Greece could reduce tax rates on heating oil. So why is the Greek Government not doing so? Why does he let the Greek people freeze?

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank all of you for your thoughts and comments on the Clean Energy for All European package. The Commission has been very attentive to the proposals made by this House when preparing the legislative measures included in the package. Many of the views suggested over the months by this House have been incorporated in the package and are reflected in the pages of the legislative proposal. I am aware that on some issues this House has advocated slightly different positions from the ones put forward by the Commission in its proposal, so allow me to emphasise this: the Commission proposals are in themselves no easy targets. They will require considerable efforts by Member States to meet their international and domestic obligations, and to get them right we have assessed our proposals along several dimensions, including energy system impacts, macroeconomic impacts, environmental effects, social impacts, including affordability issues, energy-related investments, and, finally, energy system costs. And of course our proposal fully respects the right of Member States to choose their energy means as stated in Article 194 of the Treaties. Many of you have referred to renewable energy. The proposal revising the Renewable Energy Directive is ambitious and improves upon the previous directive, in particular by putting an end to retroactive measures and launching a Europeanisation process. But the measures favouring renewables go beyond this text: the market design, energy efficiency, the energy performance of buildings and the governance of the Union all contribute to reaching our policy goals and targets in a cost-effective way, paving the way for further deployment of renewables in buildings, transport and industry.  The revised proposal also goes beyond reaching the 27% target. It is about bringing sustainable jobs to the market, creating local added value, locking in investment potential, and fostering innovation. The target – at least 27% –represents the cost-optimal contribution of renewables in 2030 towards meeting the European Union’s long-term decarbonisation objectives, and it reflects the European Union’s fair and ambitious contribution to the Paris Agreement.  For the first time; the package is proposing a clear framework on cell consumption and production, energy communities and demand response, and this will help drive the energy transition by unlocking private capital for investment in renewables and make the electricity system more flexible in order to help renewable integration. The European Union’s binding 30% energy efficiency target for 2030 is ambitious but balanced and consistent with other targets of the 2030 framework for energy and climate. It is also the target which Vice-President Šefčovič and myself promised the European Parliament at our hearings two years ago: this is what we have delivered. We are going beyond what strictly speaking would be necessary to ensure that the target of at least 40% for production is met, and any claim that our targets and proposal are insufficient to honour our commitment under the Paris Agreement is simply wrong. With this package we will take the decisive step forward to ensure that the energy transition will continue and that the targets agreed upon will be met. For sure, a lot of real political engagement will be needed in both Parliament and the Council to reach a compromise, and I am counting on you to improve them and make them a reality soon for the benefit of all our citizens.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for what I feel was general support for the package. I would like to assure you that we listened carefully to the critical remarks and the calls to be more ambitious and are ready to work very closely with you on this package. Just to complement Miguel’s remark about energy poverty, I think it is very important that we clearly recognise energy poverty as an important challenge in our package. We recognise it as a very important challenge which we have to tackle together with the Member States but we want to do our utmost at European level. We are addressing the energy poverty issue in our governance system. We want to make sure that renovations, issues of social housing, and long—term innovation plans clearly factor in the issue of energy poverty. Miguel elaborated on the importance of energy efficiency and we see it as a very strong instrument in tackling energy poverty as well. In electricity market design we are proposing a clear procedure which would prevent people from being unfairly disconnected, not to mention eco-design and energy labelling where already today our citizens are saving hundreds of euros thanks to our efficient electric appliances.  I would also like to respond to one remark and express the support of the Commission for all those who are pushing for the completion of the internal energy market in a prompt and smart way. I think a lot of positive things are happening in the Baltic and Nordic countries. We are seeing positive developments in South—East Europe through our CESEC initiative, and I would like to assure you that we are bringing new dynamism to managing our projects of common interest. We are also encouraging the Member States to present more projects in the area of smart grids. To conclude, I would like to thank all Members who recognised the high level of ambition in this proposal. Its truly transformational nature should deliver the most significant modernisation of our energy systems since they were built in Europe. So I welcome your readiness to work hard on this package. It is on the priority action list for next year so I believe that we can move from the year of delivery to the year of implementation.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing. — (NL) This broad and far-reaching package of measures is a crucial step towards achieving the objectives agreed in Paris. The Commission is committed on many fronts at the same time to enable the transition to a clean and energy-efficient economy. That is the right approach. We must use the strength of the Union and better connect our energy markets so that we can exchange renewable energy more easily. Increasing the energy efficiency target from 27% to 30% of final energy consumption is crucial. We can achieve this through the new financing opportunities for more insulated buildings, better energy labels and more efficient appliances through the ecodesign regulation. We all need to make a move together. Member States need to quickly introduce the obligations related to renewable energy for heating and build in incentives to set up energy cooperatives. Consumers should also receive clearer information on the share of renewable energy in their total energy consumption through their electricity bills. At the same time, they must be better protected against disconnection from the grid. The crucial simplification that Member States submit one national climate and energy plan each year and one progress report, rather than the hundreds of reports now, should be decisive.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The transition to clean energy is an environmental necessity and an opportunity for economic growth and job creation. We need a single, more integrated, more transparent energy market that meets our climate goals and is able to deliver energy at affordable prices. We must move towards a model that pivots on renewable energies and that is committed to improving energy efficiency. Socialists also demand definitive action against energy poverty. Fifty million Europeans and five million Spaniards await a response to the height. In addition to reducing CO2 emissions by at least 40% by 2030, we are committed to a binding target of at least 30% on renewables, as well as energy efficiency, thereby reducing our dependence on energy imports. The Union is well placed to turn this transition into an opportunity and generate an increase of up to 1% of GDP and 900 000 new jobs over the next decade. In addition, European consumers must have a greater supply supply, price comparison tools and the possibility to produce and sell their own energy.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. — The Commission proposal seems to place Europe at the helm of a transition process that could lead to rapid abandonment of dependence on fossil sources. This is done by focusing on energy efficiency, renewables, research and innovation, connected and automated mobility, low impact, but also — and finally stated in clear letters — on the new role attributed to the citizen for self-production and self-consumption. There remain some concerns about the use of financial instruments that may prove to be at too high risk and I admit a strong disappointment at the malalcelated support for fossil sources. There also remain huge doubts about the added value of EFSI, but the optics of support for renewables and energy efficiency are positive. However, it will become even more so when not a penny of European money goes to support fossil oil, coal and fuels, or to finance waste burning (or nuclear). When European money is intended to ensure widespread production among citizens, sustainability, really renewable sources and fully within the perspective of a circular economy near-zero impact on the environment, only then can we see realized the energy revolution able to secure our future.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. — Commissioners, I, too, support the need for a clean energy package. It's not the goal that worries me, but how you want to implement it. I am speaking from the perspective of my country, which, although it has low per capita income, ranks first in the percentage of renewable energy used! You stated that you want to put the consumer in the center and I am glad, but do you know that the price of green certificates was included in the consumer bill? The energy mix is a matter of subsidiarity under the treaty, and countries have different energy resources and you need to take this into account! Why is the Strategic Investment Fund not attached to this important objective? Why use the first-come, first-served criterion and not the goal criterion? As a former industrialist I know that when I wanted to save energy I had to invest. My country still produces energy from solid fuel! Do you know what it means to close tens of thousands of jobs without putting anything in place? Why is money not allocated for switching from one power generation system to another? We cannot set ourselves good goals, but we should not allocate money for investments so that we can achieve them without bringing negative social effects.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - We have reached another important step on the way to the Energy Union. Initially, we created a framework that could serve as the basis for the Energy Union. After that, we moved one further and developed several sub-strategies and regulations on natural gas within the framework of last year's winter package. This year's winter package is now in front of us, which aims to integrate the electricity market deeper. We have seen a lot of integration efforts in the electricity market from the interconnection of markets through the measures of the third energy package, yet we have not yet managed to develop a system that really serves the interests of consumers. Some of the problems are natural, as technological progress is constantly presenting us with new challenges. I think it is time to rethink the whole regulation of the electricity market and develop a system that meets the challenges of the era. It is extremely important that we do not lose sight of our goals during the recalculation phase, even during the deepening of the details. As the Commission has put it, the main objective of the current and current reform package is to support consumers. All other aspects and expectations can only be secondary. I wish that, with the work we are beginning, we will be able to create a system that will provide consumers with more accessible, reliable and affordable energy, thereby improving the competitiveness of the Union.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. — The European Commission is claiming an ambitious target to reduce CO2 emissions by at least 40% by 2030. It assumes that this can be achieved by engaging three programs. Firstly, it is an increase in energy efficiency, secondly a leadership position in the development of renewable energy sources, and thirdly it is a new relationship to the customer. The goals are very ambitious. In the field of science and research — especially for photovoltaics and hydrogen economy — we have a rapid fundamental turn in the immediate period. In photovoltaics, basic research shows the possibility of finding new chromophores. Their efficiency could jump to the energy produced by photovoltaic panels from the current approximately 11% to about 22%. If the European Commission's 2020 EP-confirmed target of 1% energy in hydrogen is met, we can expect rapid expansion of the hydrogen economy. Currently, electric and hydrogen cell buses are in test operation of several major EU cities. In a number of places, it is being worked to improve the possibility of hydrogen storage. It will also be a very challenging task to achieve the connection of small producers to the grid, not only as consumers, but also as suppliers of electricity. Another of the effective steps may then represent an increase in power generation from the core. Let's keep our fingers crossed that these ambitious goals are urgently supported by concrete steps at all levels.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Energy efficiency, use of renewable energy sources and inclusion of consumers in production are the basis of the new energy package. This new package encourages innovative solutions, new technologies and better connectivity between different sectors. We are the first in the world in the circular economy, and the new energy package is an additional incentive to stay. However, these goals are not accompanied by sufficient flexibility of regulation or by the speed of investment in innovative solutions. We still have major problems across Europe with pollutants that threaten human health and we should not passively observe these examples. Talking about the new package, while not addressing pollution cases such as the one in Slavonski Brod caused by production in Bosanski Brod means being inconsistent. According to data from the European Environment Office, some pollutants are transformed in the air and become particles that can affect countries located far from sources of pollution. Published graphs show that 63% of all air pollution in the Netherlands comes outside its borders. In the case of the Czech Republic, this percentage moves around 70%, and the pollution emitted by the Czech Republic is as much as 80%. Given that pollution knows no borders, it is necessary to develop awareness of the need for cross-border cooperation and the implementation of joint projects with countries outside the EU.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — The clean energy proposal promises a 1% increase in GDP over the next ten years and the creation of 900 000 jobs. However, the Commission must put on the table the necessary legislation to ensure the necessary transition to sustainable energy. This transition should focus on energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart infrastructure and Europe-wide solutions for interconnections, LNG terminals and energy storage capacities. However, it should not be ignored that the production of energy from renewable sources requires the continuity of conventional energy production. The exploitation of hydraulic energy in Romania, of high-efficiency gas and coal-fired power plants, benefiting from the latest technologies, can make an essential contribution to unlocking the European energy market. The development of renewable energy involves the creation of a new energy market design that ensures a level playing field for all market participants. Legislative proposals must enable consumers to control energy costs and have access to the full real costs of electricity delivered, including those associated with transmission and distribution.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. –  Solidarity and fairness are at the core of European values. Europe must deliver to business and to citizens clean energy at a fair price. I welcome the proposed ‘Clean Energy for All’ package and I believe we must be even more ambitious if we are to be at the forefront of the low-carbon economy. We must also abide by the historic COP21 agreement. I call on the two co-legislators to ensure the swift negotiation and implementation of the proposals; only in this way will we deliver security of the energy supply. By making the energy market more flexible, I believe it will bring about more resilience and adaptability of the energy sector.  Working together is crucial. We must provide and strengthen the rules to ensure cross-border participation and that no country is left behind. Europe must work towards greater fairness of the cost of energy in order to increase consumers’ trust. I look forward to working on this package here in the European Parliament.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing. - I congratulate the Commission on presenting a comprehensive energy package aimed at implementing a competitive, sustainable, citizen-oriented EU energy policy. This is one of the most important legislative proposals in this term, which will affect not only the energy sector, but also the European industry as a whole and its competitiveness. The Commission's main highlights are correctly identified: energy efficiency, leadership in renewable energy sources, promotion of the consumer as an active and key player in the energy market. However, as I have said repeatedly, a properly interconnected network and an efficient internal energy market are the cornerstone of the Energy Union, without which we will not be able to optimally take advantage of the benefits of renewable energy sources and ensure affordable prices for the consumer. I am also pleased that the Commission has also noted cyber security in the electricity market. I think that with the increasing development of smart networks, ensuring their safety is extremely important.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The production of renewable energy cannot contradict other activities that are essential to the life of peoples, such as food production. In this context, it is necessary to demand the preservation and priority of the use of agricultural land to produce food. In Galiza we are at risk with the law on fiscal and administrative measures, annexed to the draft budgets for 2017 (which opens the doors to the creation of biomass megaplants) to increase pressure on the production of energy crops, including afforestation of agricultural land; ultimately becoming a real desert green and mortgaging the future of our small and medium-sized farms, rural areas and our food sovereignty and security for generations. We urge the Commission to avoid such situations and to put in place effective measures to preserve land use for food production.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the package, which has been celebrated here as a great toast, goes by the matter. It's fighting a phantom. Man-made climate change is not assured knowledge, but a scientific hypothesis. There is much evidence that he is an invention of lobbying interests and scientists interested in research funding. My party is therefore completely opposed to any plans aimed at reducing so-called greenhouse gases. We do not need an energy transition, not green energy, but rather a rational energy policy that is geared to consumers and is based on market economy. Anyone who talks about a market design, who believes that you know the best energies of tomorrow and for tomorrow, is subject to a blatant mistake. As legislators, we cannot afford to do that. It is indicated a humility before the future and the individual rationality of the acting demand. Let us not presume to have a knowledge that will lift us above it. That is why we should immediately remoth these projects. The Commission's winter package is on ice. Immediately.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — Energy and Energy Union are one of the 10 policy priorities of the Juncker Commission with very ambitious objectives: taking global leadership in the use of renewable energy, providing fair conditions for consumers and enabling energy efficiency. The European Union is currently the largest importer of energy in the world, with an estimated 53% of the total energy consumed at an annual cost of around 400 billion euros. For this reason, improving the interconnectivity of energy grids between Member States and modernising infrastructure would help reduce disruption and energy dependence to the lowest possible level. Efficient management of energy consumption as well as clean energy are sectors of future growth and opportunity for smart investors. Proof this is the Paris Agreement, which committed the European Union to reduce CO2 emissions by at least 40% by 2030, allowing at the same time to modernise the economy, securing jobs in the green sector thanks to increased use of renewable energy sources and growth for all European citizens. According to the Commission's announcement, this set of laws should lead to the investment of up to 177 billion euros of public and private money a year from 2021, which would increase GDP by 1% over the next decade and create 900,000 new jobs.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Written. — The European Commission presented a new package of measures under the heading “Clean Energy for All Europeans” at the end of November this year. The Commission wants Europe not only to adapt to the clean energy transition, but to take the lead in this area, but unfortunately, given the content of the package, this seems anything but achievable. What we may be very concerned about is the fact that the package is unfortunately very far from commitments made under the Paris climate agreement, which is also pointed out by many NGOs and environmentalists. Raising the target for improving energy efficiency from 27 to 30% is far too little and also well below the request of the European Parliament, which has already called for a binding target of 40% by 2030. The package is also weak on renewable energy sources, with maintaining the 27% renewable energy consumption target under-ambitious and does not include binding national targets. The extension of fossil fuel subsidies is also worrying. The package thus far short of the Commission's promises, on the contrary, could even undermine EU action to combat climate change. I hope this will not be another lost opportunity to step towards a greener, sustainable and environmentally friendly future we owe to our planet and future generations.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. — Honourable Members, I congratulate the Commission, which has presented a comprehensive legislative package for the European Energy Union in just two years. This Clean Energy for All Europeans package outlines the future of European energy by 2030 in an ambitious and realistic way to achieve. Energy efficiency is put first as a universal means of reducing energy consumption, energy dependence, energy poverty and harmful greenhouse discharges into the atmosphere. The proposed target of 30% energy saving by 2030 will allow the current pace to improve energy efficiency. The package adopts the principle of technological neutrality in energy support policies, which provides the necessary flexibility for Member States to seek the most cost-effective solutions for achieving greenhouse emission reduction targets and ensuring a reliable supply of clean and affordable energy, including of nuclear origin. I welcome the restriction of excess privileges for renewable energy. After their technological development and entry into energy, it is time to transition to the market mechanisms of their participation in energy supply. The prospect of the declining role of fossil fuels in energy is also clear, but setting the unyielded target of 550 GSO2/kWh emissions from new coal plants represents in practice an end to investment in new capacities under existing coal technologies.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — These are one of those sounding words that look good in any room. The problem lies in the strategy chosen to achieve such a goal. The route chosen by the European Union was the market path, or rather the illusion of the market. All public energy production and distribution systems have been privatized over the past decades. Huge private energy groups have been created that run political power and rely on this supremacy to ensure more power and more profits for their businesses. There is no summit however festive, or however ambitious its goals may be, that conceals this reality. The only way to have a sustainable world, with a clean and accessible energy policy to all can only be achieved through public policies and with public control over energy production and distribution. Everything else is pure illusions.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda — which was put on the agenda on Monday at the request of the plenary session is the debate on the report by Richard Corbett, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the general review of Parliament's Rules of Procedure (2016/2114 (REG) (A8-0344/2016).

name: Richard CORBETT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, this overhaul of our Rules of Procedure is intended to make them better in terms of efficiency, transparency and clarity. It is the result of a year-and-a-half’s work by a working group with a representative of every political group, helped by a task force at secretariat level that involved every parliamentary committee secretariat and the Legal Service of Parliament. It is therefore very much a consensual report and I pay tribute to the role played by Mr Rainer Wieland who chaired the working group, and indeed all the members of the working group. The bulk of what I propose to you today is very much consensual. It is an evolution, not a revolution. Nonetheless, although many of the rule changes are technical, there are quite a few that are of political significance. Let me list just a few very quickly.  We have rewritten the procedure for first reading agreements with the other institutions, to make them more transparent and to introduce safeguards. We have put into our rules the consequences of the Interinstitutional Agreement with the other institutions on Better Law-Making. We have put into our rules the changes to the procedure for hearings with Commissioners that we agreed in the context of my own report of last year. We have put together a considerable package on transparency, building on the work that Mr Giegold had done in preparation of a different report, and steering a course between what is desirable and what is legally possible to do through changes to the Rules of Procedure, rather than through legislation and, of course, bearing in mind that we have to get an absolute majority in this House to approve any such changes.  We have looked at the rules concerning the conduct of Members; we are prohibiting racist and xenophobic language in this Parliament. We have increased the penalties that can be imposed on Members who transgress our rules in this Parliament. We have rationalised the numerous thresholds in our Rules of Procedure for triggering different procedures, rationalising them to just three different thresholds. We have not raised the thresholds, by the way, and the most common threshold is the lower threshold. Nonetheless, we have brought greater clarity here. We have also made provision concerning membership of parliamentary committees such that when a Member leaves a political group and joins another one, which happens occasionally, the Group that he or she belongs to can replace that Member on the parliamentary committee that they left. This is particularly important, I think, for smaller groups who may only have one member of a committee and if that member leaves they are bereft of representation on that committee. So, overall, it is a wide package which I have the great honour to commend to the House.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate concerns largely matters which are the internal business of the Parliament. While we have been following the full work of Mr Corbett’s report with interest, I will comment only on those aspects which would affect the cooperation between our two institutions as defined by the Treaties and the Framework Agreement between us. Allow me to highlight Article 21 of the Framework Agreement, which states: Parliament will seek the opinion of the Commission when it comes forward with its revision of its Rules of Procedure concerning relations with the Commission. I regret that Parliament did not respect this commitment in a meaningful way and requested the Commission’s view only at the very last moment, leaving less than 48 working hours before the vote. This does not allow the Commission to provide a considered response or even discuss the matter in the College, which will meet only later today. I will make some preliminary comments nevertheless. At first glance there are a number of proposed changes which the Commission can warmly welcome. The incorporation of elements from the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making is a positive step. The changes to your approach to the recast procedure should make it more effective and reliable. The Commission looks forward to having a regular opportunity to present the key political decisions taken in the College directly to the Parliament. And we hope that the idea of topical debates will add liveliness and diversity to the European Parliament sessions, while remaining focused on the areas of EU competence and of general interest. However, some other proposed changes, in particular those relating to a proposed hearing in the case of the appointment of a new commissioner during the Commission’s mandate or modifications in a portfolio of serving commissioners, as well as those relating to possible conflict of interest of the Commission, represent a modification to the current legal framework that cannot be introduced unilaterally by the European Parliament. It must be borne in mind that those changes, if introduced unilaterally by the European Parliament in its Rules of Procedure, cannot create a role for the European Parliament which is neither provided for in the Treaties nor in the Framework Agreement and which would affect the institutional position and functioning of the Commission. I would also like to recall that President Juncker has himself proposed changes to the obligations for the commissioners to avoid any conflict of interest, and, in line with our commitment taken in the Framework Agreement, he has, by letter to President Schulz on 23 November 2016, asked Parliament’s opinion on these changes. It is for this reason that the first Vice-President Timmermans yesterday wrote to President Schulz to ask, on the basis of the principle of loyal and sincere cooperation between our institutions, to ensure the Commission is given enough time to express its opinion and for the Parliament to take it duly into account before voting on the proposed changes to the Rules of Procedure. The Commission underlines in this regard that you apply the Treaties and continue to respect the terms of the Framework Agreement, and the Commission expects that the European Parliament will do the same.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. — Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Corbett and everyone. It was a lot of work, and we struggled with each other occasionally. I would like to thank you for taking up the suggestion of the Committee on Budgetary Control — the one we had. There are many good things in it, including the publication of the annexes containing the Commission's replies. This is really a milestone. They've been pushed on it for many years now. I would like to tell you that there are some things in hand that would really have needed a deeper observation. The point that the Commission representative, Vice-President Šefčovič, has just raised, is a very important issue, namely the issue of portfolio changes. I believe that the Rules of Procedure cannot overtake the Treaty or ignore the IIA. I find it extremely unfortunate that any portfolio change here in the House will be subject to a business match in the future. We are not doing ourselves and Europe any favors. I would urge us to bring our rules at least into line with those we have in the IIA and the Treaty. I would like to thank you once again, Mr Corbett, and pay tribute to the great work!

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote is important in many respects, given that the report is important in many respects. Corbett governs the democratic life of this institution, which is the home of European citizens. I am speaking as chairman of the ENVI Committee on the contribution made by the Environment Committee to this dossier: as you know, in ENVI we have a long and extensive legislative experience, we have carried out hundreds of trilogists and therefore we have, on the basis of this experience, intervened with regard to Parliament's second reading aspects, finding an excellent report with the AFCO Committee, with rapporteur Corbett, whom I thank for the long work done in recent months. Our speech, contained in Amendment 88 to Article 73c, concerns the case where the Council's position covers elements which are not covered by Parliament's position at first reading: We have provided with this text that the committee responsible can adopt guidelines for the negotiating team. Of course, I would like to thank my fellow Members who would like to support this amendment and call for the report to be adopted as a whole.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: draftsman of the Committee on Legal Affairs. — Mr President, Commissioner, I support the proposal to revise the Rules of Procedure because I believe that this is a good outcome for work in particular the colleagues of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, who I would like to thank for working with the Committee on Legal Affairs. Our Committee provided its opinion for the revision of the Rules of Procedure, in which it mainly affected those institutes which it uses within its competencies, such as the discussion of immunities or application of the principle of subsidiarity. I can conclude that in fundamental matters, meaningful and effective changes have been proposed in these areas. However, I think ultimately the concern of all of us is to use the institutes and the Rules of Procedure on a substantive basis. Therefore, I would like to call here that we leave the consideration of compliance with the principle of subsidiarity only to the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. We are voting on this report this afternoon, and we will note that we are still discussing a few minor issues, although some colleagues will complain this afternoon that the vote is going on for so long. We have many hundreds of amendments because we are regulating many technical matters with this reorganisation. And, as I said, we still have a few things we disagree on. This is due to the fact that the process itself has been very broad-based. A technical working group was on board, and all the groups were on board with appropriate relineforce. And, Commissioner Šefčovič, your Commission was also present as an observer at AFCO. So there can be no talk of having been informed 48 hours in advance. They have been re-sent the entire bouquet of all these amendments 48 hours in advance, so to speak, at a time when Members have received it. That was when they came from the translation. We agree on a lot of progress. I believe that we have found a clear agreement on first reading. Secondly, I believe that we have answered the issue of handling in the committees with a convincing proposal. Thirdly, we have introduced a topical debate. We have some serious differences, but they are less party-political. In other words, the question of how the President of the Commission should be elected in the future — by secret ballot or possibly by a roll-call vote — has to do with political culture. In Germany, one cannot imagine choosing the chancellor in an open election, because this has a lot to do with a free mandate. So, there will also be votes today that are beyond party politics. Finally, let me turn to a point which, in particular, Commissioner Šefčovič. The House is under tremble pressure because there are reviews outside of Members who have to deal with a lot — number of speeches, number of applications, number of questions and more. And I know that the House is suffering from the fact that we are asking tens of thousands of questions to the Commission. I know that the Commission is also suffering from this. We want to have to limit the possibilities of individual Members to a certain extent. But if we succeed through the Rules of Procedure or otherwise, Commissioner, then, on the other hand, we also expect you to have the answers to the questions to be somewhat more meaningful. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: João FERREIRA
text: Question under the blue card procedure. — (PT) Mr President, Mr Wieland, both you and Mr Corbett were concerned to come here and say that this is a transparent and consensual process. In fact, it's not. It is not, and the best demonstration of this is that it has been arguing for two years, and this is the first time the matter has been discussed in plenary. And it would not even be, because it was only yesterday that, on our proposal, an amendment was made to the agenda allowing this matter to be discussed. Do you think it is a sign of transparency not to discuss a matter of this magnitude in plenary? Secondly, if this is such a consensual issue, why have we reached the vote in plenary with more than four hundred and sixty amendments? Is it customary for such consensual subjects to come with four hundred and sixty amendments to the plenary?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. There are, of course, our own ideas on all the parliamentary matters that are going on here, and we have had all the group representatives on board, including your group representative. I know that he has given feedback to your group on several occasions. You have explicitly not mentioned the things that are close to your heart now. But there would also have been answers to this at an early stage. Lack of transparency is not. The vast majority of the things that are going on in the committees come to plenary only at the end of the committee's work, and so has been here.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, real changes are generally made by small steps and proposals for revision of the regulation by Richard Corbett and the whole group of work that has worked with him and Mr Wieland in this long period are of this kind, they propose a number of ambitious changes necessary for our democracy: more transparency, more responsibility, a better functioning of this Parliament in favour of our citizens. These are the watchwords that make up the work produced by Richard Corbett and, as AFCO coordinator of our S&D Group, I agree with the aim of rationalising the activities of the Chamber and a regulation of written statements, questions to the Commission, for example, are necessary measures. I think it is really time to close an absurd competition between Members to write more about it than the others, and that is the direction towards which this report is moving and these changes. I ask you to vote for it.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I want to name an absurdity as vice president. Every time I give the floor to a colleague here, this is statistically taken as a point of order in plenary. Of the same importance as the speeches given by Mr Wieland, Mr Bresso and others here. This shows that there is an urgent need to change the statistics.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Colleagues and Colleagues! I would also like to thank Mr Corbett and other shadow rapporteur colleagues for their work together. This is a very good effect. The report stands for synthesis. The European Parliament will be able to act effectively and political groups retain political rights and freedom of expression of their beliefs. I want to emphasize the need for transparency, which is something very important from the point of view of policy accountability, from the point of view of the trust of citizens in the institutions of the European Union. I am the author of this amendment, which presupposes the election of the head of the European Commission by a This is precisely the accountability of policy, and the traditions of more than 20 Member States of the European Union are in favour of this. I understand that Germany has other traditions, but that is a reaction to the experience of Nazi dictatorship; the European Parliament doesn't necessarily have to consider them. Finally, this is about the consistency of this process, since European political families are urged to submit candidates for the head of the European Commission during the elections to the European Parliament, the choice of the head of the European Commission by the European Parliament should be overt, as overt is the political process at the election. I therefore persuade you to vote for the overt election of the head of the European Commission

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, at first glance there is a tendency to pay little attention to the internal rules of the European Parliament. However, taking a closer look at it, one quickly becomes clear that many of these provisions are of political importance. Rules of procedure are part of the parliamentarian's toolkit. To simplify them is to make its parliamentary activity more expeditious. Our colleague Richard Corbett summarized the reflections presented to him by representatives of political groups over the last 30 months. The number of Members required to initiate a parliamentary decision varied according to the requests made by our colleagues. It had become a real labyrinth. We have succeeded in putting order in this way, although we have not succeeded in revaluing the function of the political groups further, which I regret. Let us put to the credit of our work the strengthening of sanctions against our colleagues tempted by particularly hurtful and irresponsible remarks. Candidates for the presidency of the Commission state, in principle, before their approval in the European Parliament, that they do not want to be elected by Members from extremist parties. With the election of the President of the Commission with an open ballot — as proposed in our report — we will now have the opportunity to verify it. If the proposal is accepted, Parliament will, in future, be informed of the decisions taken by the College of Commissioners before the press, in plenary sitting on the same day. Finally, the new proposals for a regulation will allow the European Parliament, provided that it will, of course, put an end to the ranking of the performance of Members and, in this way, one of the greatest absurdities — as my colleague, Mercedes Bresso has already said — in the parliamentary world. Indeed, the quality of parliamentary activity is not measured in number interventions or reports. To give a report which simply endorses a Commission proposal and does not require in-depth research the same importance as the report on the European Union budget, for example, is simply to disregard the work of the budget rapporteur. This ranking, which is supposed to encourage Members of the European Parliament to step up their work, only records the number of parliamentary acts without being able to give any indication of the quality of their action. This form of stakhanovism has the effect of producing larigot amendments, resulting in inflation of deliberative votes. The means and costs generated by the activism of some of our colleagues are inversely proportional to the results achieved. Certainly, statistics rhymes with politics, but in order to move Europe forward, there are more sensible logic than that of recording simple noise. I therefore call on you to be responsible when voting on our proposal to revise the Rules of Procedure. Two and a half years of reflection, hard work and exemplary commitment by our rapporteur, Richard Corbett, and our President, Rainer Wieland, deserve the support of our Assembly. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr President, I, too, appreciate the workload and the need for this report, and I congratulate my colleague, but I have a concrete question: it seems natural to you that there is an amendment in Article 11 where the Member is sanctioned if a person employed by him and who has access to equipment violates parliamentary conduct? Because the deputy does not have the opportunity to sanction the employee at hand, instead, the deputy is sanctioned. Do you agree with this amendment?

name: Charles GOERENS
text: the answer “blue cardboard”. — A body in the European Parliament empowered to decide this kind of question.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I requested this debate because I cannot politically understand that the result of a good two years of work in the working group — I thank all the members of this working group for this — and is being waved through here in plenary at the end of more than 1 400amendments without discussion. The number of amendments tabled in committee and, ultimately, again here in plenary, shows that such a process is best achieved when it is inclusive in development and openly in the result. The result before us, however, is clearly controversial by many parts of Parliament. Despite the great openness with which the working group has come to work — with its rather early return to the groups, I am dissatisfied at the end. Not because I was unable to prevail with my own views and proposals, but because, unfortunately, the work on important issues finally became a matter of power between large and small groups. The Rules of Procedure should be our constitution, which governs our internal democracy, within which we fulfil our duties as Parliament, as the Commission's supervisory body and as co-legislator alongside the Council. The fathers of the great constitutions in our Member States have not been so petty, but have been driven by creating spaces and not restricting them. Democracy thrives on breathing, and we all learn every day: nothing lasts and can be secured forever. Of course, efficiency and acceleration are something we face every day, including in Parliament. But if they are made the primary goals for our internal rules, this ultimately leads to breathing and change. That is why we refuse, for example, to curtail the rights of individual Members, and that smaller fractions should be squeezed into stronger rules. I would have liked, for example, to try not only to reduce the number of questions to the Commission or the Council arithmetically, but also to consider together how to strengthen Parliament's competence in this area and how, of course, to negotiate this with the institutions. This is how we strengthen Parliament, the work of our plenary, the political groups and committees, as well as the role and responsibility of each Member for the EU and not the other way round.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, (the words of commencement were not taken)... on Parliament's Rules of Procedure. This is the conclusion of a two-year process of hard work in which we have gone through the Rules of Procedure paragraph by paragraph. Parliament's Rules of Procedure is a very important document because it regulates the balance of power in this House between large groups, between small groups, between group leaders, between individual members. It is a complicated document and anyone who reads the Rules of Procedure closely gets an important tool to push their policies. It is therefore good that we make the Rules of Procedure easier and something easier to understand. There are also things that are good improvements. Parliament's board will no longer be able to stop suggestions that we should have a vote on setting up a committee of inquiry to investigate malfeasance. The President of Parliament will no longer be able to prevent the advisory group investigating whether a member has committed breaches of the rules of ethics from investigating this. That veto has the President of Parliament today and it is good for it to be removed, except in cases that are quite obvious. There are some other things that are actually good for the small groups. On the whole, although the report is not as we Greens would like it to be, it is a good report. But there are some things that I want to talk about, which we are fighting to improve. One applies to Application 222 on the composition of committees, the composition of the committee, which is that we change the principle of who should sit on which committee. Today, the member is the one who owns his committee seat. With the proposal drawn up by the Group, it is the party groups that own the committee seat, and will thus be able to punish a member who votes against the will of the group management by taking away from the member its committee seat. If you want a Parliament of strong members who can represent their constituents, it would be very good if we keep the principle that the Member own their own place. I notice my speaking time is already up, I just want to say it: please do so for the green professions for better control of lobbyism as well. Thank you!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur Corbett and all my colleagues for their work. We have spent about two years reviewing what constitutes the fundamental act of democracy in this institution. I would have expected the reform of the Rules of Procedure to take place with the widest possible debate and not with the usual agreement of the broad agreements, which depreciates the democratic life of this Parliament. Too many points have remained unresolved: it is a reform that betrays respect for minority rights and betrays the demand of European citizens for greater transparency and greater ethics in politics. It is surreal for Parliament to ask the Commission for new rules to limit Commissioners' conflicts of interests and refuses to change their own. Those who vote positively for this reform will assume all the responsibilities of the case, even in the face of the citizens, explaining why it was decided to defend the privileges of the caste. We in the 5 Star Movement will always be here to remind you that to bring European citizens closer to the institutions we need a radical change of course from ethics.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) We, as a group, have cooperated in a positive and hopeful way for over a year in the clearing and updating of our Rules of Procedure. In general, as a lawyer, I remain of the opinion that such a document should be shorter and less complex. More specifically, we continue to object to a number of provisions and adjustments which, in our view, discriminate against small groups or non-aligned Members and make them dependent on the arbitrariness of the large so-called majority groups in this Parliament. The further restriction of parliamentary control, the number of motions for resolutions and so on are also difficult points for us. Finally, we are very much lifting the introduction of a new punishment regime. Without wishing to defend racist or xenophobic language or behaviour, our group is concerned about the abuse which majorities in this House generally use these concepts in a hysterical way. simply to further discriminate against people with a different, non-politically correct opinion.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Mr President, let us go back to the beginning: why reform the Rules of Procedure at all? If we ask this question, the answer is, or should be, clear: to make the work of Parliament more effective; to improve it. If nothing else we owe this to the citizens whom we represent, and it follows. This is very much in the interest of Parliament itself. Does anyone actually want to be a Member of a badly-functioning Parliament? A great deal of work has gone into the preparation of the new Rules of Procedure. Some of it is technical – necessarily so; the outcome is that they are a more coherent, more cogent set of rules by which Parliament operates. But this reform also means innovation, meaning that some of the rules to which we had become accustomed will change. While we all subscribe to change in theory, there are those who dislike it in practice. Restructuring the Rules of Procedure was a complex and lengthy task involving high levels of experience. In other words, we are looking at expertise in action. To reject this expertise would be tantamount to the worst kind of populism, the kind that in other contexts we denounce every day of the week. With the new Rules of Procedure, the work of Parliament will become more accountable and more focused. It will undergo a modernisation to bring it into line as co-legislator under the Lisbon Treaty. One particular innovation should be universally welcome. MEP ranking has been generally deleterious to the work of Parliament, and other colleagues have said the same thing. Under the new rules, these excesses that MEP ranking has induced should be curbed. So, as EPP coordinator, my congratulations to Mr Corbett and the other members of the working group. This reform should be supported unreservedly.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Mr President, I think that there is no strong Parliament if there is no efficient regulation. I think this is an efficient regulation. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mr Wieland and Mr Corbett, who have done an extraordinary job, two words that are important in this matter: what transparency and exemplarity mean. Transparency, because I think we need to be much more transparent than we are. That is why our group will support many of the amendments which we need to make, in terms of improving transparency and informing citizens. I am against an amendment which presents the possibility that Members can also defend lobbies. It is not possible to defend all citizens and defend lobbies. We defend citizens, we do not defend particular interests. And I am also in favour of a reform of the Statute which would allow us to establish the criterion that our activity is exclusive. We can't work here and elsewhere. I think that change must also be done.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think we must be aware of the importance of the report we are voting for here today, because, depending on the rules we give ourselves, an idea of democracy will emerge. In the name of efficiency and speed, these new rules narrow the individual rights of Members, their possibility of control, intervention and scrutiny on legislative activity, as well as limit the powers of smaller groups, raising and creating new barrages. I believe that the freedom to be protected is primarily the freedom of those who think otherwise and I believe that this Parliament has not learned the lesson of the Italian referendum. The peoples of Europe say no to those who intend the parliamentary institutions only as a place of ratification of the executive or the grand coalitions, that is, the majority of this Parliament who wrote austerity policies. We need more democracy, not less democracy, to open the windows of our Parliament, to be able to hear the questions of citizens and society. To deny time for debates, limiting times is to do exactly the opposite. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue card issue. — Mr President, many questions have been raised here that this motion would be undemocratic, although I personally see this as a proposal that strengthens democracy with small steps, as the rapporteur, Richard Corbett. In my own Parliament, the Finnish Parliament, we looked at this house for a long time from the outside and wanted many things to be brought into the light of day already in the negotiation phase, from committees to plenary, and I see that taking things further to negotiation through plenary will increase a huge amount of time. democracy. Here in the plenary session, all groups are fully engaged. Do you give value to this motion for more democracy, which is included in this motion? In other words, the plenary session deals with matters at an earlier stage, rather than only being dealt with by committees in a smaller configuration.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: answer to a “blue card” question. — Firstly I want to remember that if we are having a debate here in plenary it is to the merit of a minority group that has called for a plenary debate, it is about the My parliamentary group, the GUE/NGL Group, which called for a plenary debate because, say, the majority of the European Parliament did not anticipate that on such an important element, namely what rules We give ourselves to decide, there was a parliamentary debate. I recall that we had difficulty in having parliamentary debates here. A few weeks ago we were denied the possibility of an appeal to the European Court of Justice on CETA. What's the point? That on the rules of the functioning of the European Parliament cannot decide a majority, the rules of the European Parliament are democratic if they primarily protect the individual rights of MEPs and rights of minorities, which this report absolutely does not.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, Mr Corbett, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, we believe that this report contains many improvements and modernisations. Unfortunately, some things were not achieved either. We have not made any relevant progress in the transparency of lobbying here in the House. Unfortunately, we have not been able to make a legislative footprint mandatory. The President can continue to throw sanctions proposed in the trash in the event of breach of our Code of Conduct in the event of conflicts of interest without public justification, and unfortunately the trilogues also remain non-transparent. Further progress is needed for greater integrity and transparency. However, I would also like to make one thing clear: what has been said here about restricting minority rights is being inflated like a popanz here. Parliament is protecting itself against obstruction. It is not a question of restricting the real rights of Members or groups, here too we must praise the work of Mr Corbett and say that this is an improvement

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, what has been preparing for the last two years in relation to the operation of this Parliament is a coup. This is a blow which seeks to seriously limit the individual initiative of Members, the initiative of the smaller political groups and to concentrate even more power on the large political groups. It is not just a question of limiting the number of questions Members can put, thereby reducing the power of scrutiny over other institutions, reducing the number of resolutions, reducing the possibility of tabling amendments in committee or eliminating written statements. This alone would be serious, but there is more: the aim is to limit and set up rapid legislative procedures, so-called fast track, which limit Members' intervention and make it more difficult for them to vote; it is intended to create conditions for the general lack of registration of the individual vote of Members. , hindering requests for nominal votes, which is essential to an effective scrutiny of the work of the elected. It's a case to say: they know what they're doing here and they want to hide it. Less democracy, less pluralism, less transparency — this is what they want to impose. (The speaker agrees to answer two Blue Card questions tabled pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I notice that Mr Ferreira has quite an impressive MEP ranking score with 322 questions to the Commission and an impressive 882 plenary speeches, but I would like to ask him: how many of those speeches are real speeches? Are you aware of that?

name: João FERREIRA
text: Answer according to the blue card procedure. — (PT) Mr Max, everyone will judge your work, what I can assure you is that if you look at the questions we have tabled and the speeches that are being made here... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Ferreira, I have two questions. The first question is, as the number three of the quantitative secemrantions, you are not a lobbyist on your own behalf with the things you are doing here? Secondly, can you tell me any measure in the Spanish, Portuguese or Italian Parliament where a single Member has more rights than here in the House?

name: João FERREIRA
text: Answer according to the “blue card” procedure. — As I said a moment ago, everyone will know of his work. The questions we ask and the speeches we make here show a deep link to those in our countries who follow the work we are doing here — a deep link to their problems, their aspirations and their concerns about what is decided here. What you are doing is to prevent this possibility of speaking, either through written questions, written statements or through speeches. If you don't want to do it, you're free not to. But don't stop those who want to do it from doing so. You see, I am not a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, but this is a matter which concerns us all and which concerns us all. I was able to speak during the debate in committee by tabling more than fifty amendments to what you have been discussing. If the rules you want to adopt were in force, it would be impossible for a Member who is not a member of that committee to be able to take part in this debate. You think that's okay? Are you comfortable with this imposition? For, from our point of view here, in this group, no one is comfortable, and that is why we appeal, it is still time, still go in time, stop to reflect and suspend this process.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, congratulate Mr Corbett for his excellent work. The general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure arises from the need to ensure a better functioning of Parliament and to clarify the interpretation of certain rules, taking particular care not to narrow the scope of action of Members. I fully agree with the rigor and transparency introduced which requires, for example, the obligation for former Members to inform Parliament if they undertake a new lobbying activity and the anticipation of withdrawal the access licences of registered lobbyists who do not comply with the regulation. I believe that the introduction of the power granted to a committee to speed up a legislative procedure and the obligation to respond by the committee will bring greater efficiency to the legislative activity itself within three months to requests for initiatives submitted by Parliament and, in the event of failure to respond, the obligation of it to appear before the committee responsible. Finally, also the provision which provides, in the event of withdrawal of legislative proposals, the obligation for the Commission to discuss first with the relevant committee of the European Parliament and then, in the absence, of an agreement in plenary.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). — Mr President, the revision of the Rules of Procedure is a very important step, because it results in the smooth functioning of Parliament. However, some of the proposed changes significantly affect and restrict the freedom of thought and the activity of MEPs to an extent that is unacceptable. For example, we need to reduce the number of questions we are going to ask the Commission. But how will a Member of the European Parliament be able to raise issues and get answers on serious issues affecting his country, including his constituents? Another unacceptable proposal for me is to prosecute a Member of the European Parliament for expressing, they say, xenophobic speech. Who and by what criteria will judge this thing? In fact, this is an attempt to silence the opposite voices, because unfortunately many and many of you are not accustomed to hearing these opposing voices.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: (ECR). — Mr President, first of all it is good that we are discussing the Rules of Procedure, a matter which concerns us and must express our views. Secondly, I, along with other colleagues, will protest that it is unacceptable to limit the parliamentary activity of Members, the main aspect of which is the question. We ask questions to highlight issues, to check the Commission, to say what is happening in our countries, to express citizens' concerns. Therefore, limiting the number of questions to us is unacceptable. Secondly, there is also a system within Parliament which controls the alleged correctness of our questions and prevents us from asking them. A moment ago, the services sent me a message saying “we would suggest that you redraft your actual question”, that is, they don't like the questions we ask. We will ask the questions, and if there is no competence for questions, the Commission will say so, and Parliament's services will not say so. We cannot be under the control of Parliament's services. We must exercise our rights.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would also like to thank Mr Corbett and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs for their enormous work on this file. From my previous work, I fully understand its complexity, and I would therefore highlight the need for practical solutions. Just to give you an example from my own experience, some of you will probably remember that I had to take over, rather abruptly, the health portfolio. A few months later, the former President of the Commission had to take over mine because I was on electoral leave. After I came back from the elections, I assumed the portfolio of Viviane Reding, who became a Member of the European Parliament. These were very real situations which occur in political life and which we have to be able to resolve promptly. In response to the remarks made by Mr Wieland: the Commission was indeed participating in the work of the AFCO Committee as observers, and we have signalled the Commission’s interest in being properly consulted in accordance with the framework agreement. Nevertheless, the Commission stands ready to work with the European Parliament on practical ways to implement the provisions of this important reform in respect of our respective institutional prerogatives. The Commission will issue a written statement in the minutes of their votes in the event that the European Parliament decides to proceed with its vote on the Corbett report.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am delighted that there is, in general, a very broad level of support for what we propose to review our Rules of Procedure, even if there are still some misgivings on one point or another. Let me just respond to four or five of the key issues that have been raised. First, the complaint from my good friend Mr Šefčovič on behalf of the Commission. Indeed, the Commission was present at all our committee meetings discussing this. I did not once hear the Commission ask for any extra consultation beyond that, though of course, nonetheless, our President has written to you to inform you of all the amendments tabled at plenary stage after we had finished our work in the Committee. But what we are doing in relation to the Commission is largely about how we organise what we already do as a Parliament, notably in terms of the Commission hearings. Some of them, other ones, actually respond to concerns of the Commission, such as on the volume of parliamentary questions tabled in writing to the Commission. But I am sure that after the vote we can explore any issues that you may feel perhaps are still there and we can look at practical solutions to that. Second, on the question of thresholds. I repeat, we have rationalised not raised the thresholds. The lower threshold is actually lower than it is in our present Rules because it means 38 Members instead of 40 Members can trigger a whole range of parliamentary procedures. The medium and the higher thresholds are rarely used, but they are used in cases which already now have a threshold that is as high, if not actually higher. So I do not think we have made any of these procedures more difficult for smaller groups or small numbers of Members. Third, on the issue of transparency. We have introduced legislative footprints. We have toughened up the declaration of Members’ financial interests. We are proposing to ban second jobs and lobbying of Parliament or the institutions. We are tightening up on the use of badges by outside people. We are bringing more transparency to first reading agreements and to trialogues. What we have not done on transparency are either things that are illegal, that we cannot do via the Rules of Procedure but where we need to change the primary legislation such as the Members’ Statute; or things where we need to reach agreement with the other institutions. That is true, but those issues are still open. We can revisit them and I am sure we will. And finally, may I address Mr Ferreira’s notion that this is a coup. A coup. If you really think that a working group composed of representatives from every single political group in the European Parliament reporting back to public meetings of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs is a coup, then I really am astonished. As I said, this also lowers many of the thresholds. It introduces a new procedure for topical debates where every Group in turn can choose a debate on a subject of its choice. It introduces a number of other safeguards for individual Members. This is not a coup. And if you were implying that as an individual Member you find it difficult to make your political points within the wide, very wide, range of possibilities that this Parliament offers to individual Members, then I suggest that you may have some difficulty actually doing your job as an MEP.
