Let me finish, however, by commending this package to the House. It is reasonable, it is balanced. Even on the points that are still subject to some contention I am confident that a large majority will back what the working group and I, as rapporteur, have put before this House today.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Tuesday, 13 December 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — During the work which led to the text tabled in plenary, introducing amendments to Parliament's Rules of Procedure, they were not implemented by the groups collaborative attitudes towards small groups. The demands of the latter for the safeguarding of their rights in the different bodies and bodies have not been accepted and, on the contrary, rules limiting the autonomy of individual Members have been inserted and groups. In addition, during the reform process the issue of transparency was completely ignored, which should have been dealt with in an ad hoc report that was blocked in committee, so that amendments introduced by it could not affect the revision of the current regulation. Some slightest hint in this regard was inserted at the last moment, but definitely not to a sufficient extent.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. It is a special honour for me to welcome Mrs Nadija Murad and Mrs Lamija Aji Bashar, the winners of this year's Sakharov Prize, to the European Parliament, two extraordinary, two remarkable young women who are fighting for their community, the Yazidis, and who are responsible for this today with the Sakharov Prize be awarded. (Applause) I would like to ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to take your seats and invite you first to watch a short video. (The video will play.) Dear Mrs. Nadija Murad and Mrs. Lamija Aji Bashar! We are very proud to welcome you today and we bow to the people of the Yazidis, one of the oldest religious communities in human history. But we don't just welcome you. We also welcome your families and friends who have taken their seats in the grandstand. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen! (Applause) It is also an honour to welcome this year's two finalists of the Sakharov Prize, Mr Can Dündar and Mr Mustafa Cemilev, to our award ceremony. (Applause) Can Dündar was the editor-in-chief of the Turkish newspaper Cumhuriyet, a leading and independent newspaper that won the Alternative Nobel Peace Prize this year. Mr Dündar was accused of espionage and imprisoned just because he was engaged in his free journalistic work. Mustafa Cemilev, who is now elected Member of the Ukrainian Parliament, has dedicated his life to the non-violent struggle to protect minorities, and especially the Tatars in Ukraine. He is the former president of the Crimean Tatar Parliament and has the privilege of being a friend of Andrei Sakharov, who paid for his belief in freedom of expression with his life and who gave his name to the award today. Today's award ceremony is not just a reason to welcome our two finalists. Today's award ceremony is also an occasion for us to recall the situation of last year's prize-winner, Raif Badawi, who is still in prison, and I take this opportunity to appeal once again to the government and the King of Saudi Arabia to release Raif Badawi immediately. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, the two women sitting up here — Nadija Murad and Lamija Aji Bashar — are heroines. They have suffered indescribable atrocities, survived captivity, and they have fled and found exile. They have overcome fear and suffering and finally found refuge and protection with us in Europe. Both Nadija Murad and Lamija Aji Bashar are fighting today with commitment to those who are left behind, fighting against impunity and for justice. Nadija, you once said, “To tell my story and relive the horror is not an easy task, but the world needs to know.” Ladies and gentlemen, Nadija and Lamija lived in the quiet rural village of Kocho, Iraq, where Christians, Muslims and Yazidis lived together peacefully as neighbours. On 15 August 2014, the Daesh, the so-called “Islamic State”, killed all the men in their village and enslaved all women and children. In November 2014, Nadija Murad managed to escape to Germany. Lamija Aji Bashar risked her life. She escaped the war and was seriously injured by the explosion of a landmine. Today, Nadija and Lamija draw our attention to the suffering of the Yazidis, stand up for the rights of women and minorities and are launching a campaign against human trafficking and for the Recognition of the genocide of their people. And this, ladies and gentlemen, is a matter of direct concern to us in Europe. We took the “never again” vow after the European Holocaust. “Never again” does not only commemorate the past, but also means the duty for the present and future to protect people from persecution and puniny. We see cities in ruins and children buried under the scree of war. We see whole peoples, we see whole regions, we see entire cities and villages disappearing from the map. We see men being killed, children abducted, and women enslaved and kidnapped. However, we, the democratic communities, in the wealthest parts of the world, sometimes refuse to give protection to these people. This, ladies and gentlemen, is shameful and unbearable. (Applause) The two women Nadija and Lamija remind us of our duty by telling us their story. Nadija, you once said, “The world needs to know.” Yeah, I think so too. The world needs to know. And let me add, the world needs to act too. The European Parliament supports their call to the United Nations Security Council. No offender has been tried for the crimes committed against the Yazidis so far. The International Criminal Court must investigate the crimes committed by the so-called “Islamic State”. Crimes against humanity committed by this terrorist organisation must be prosecuted before the International Criminal Court. (Applause) Nadija and Lamija, your fight is also our fight, and we are proud to honour you, on behalf of all colleagues, on behalf of the European Parliament, and I believe on behalf of the entire European Union, today with the 2016 Sakharov Prize. Congrats! (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Lamiya Haji Bajar
text: Winner of the Sakharov Prize (The following is a transcription of the interpretation of the original speech from Kurdish into English). – Mr President, President of the European Parliament, distinguished guests, Members of the European Parliament, I would like to thank all of you for this very valuable prize and I feel that this prize is a prize for every woman and girl that has been sexually enslaved by Daesh and for every Yazidi woman that has been a victim of Daesh and for everybody around the world that has been a victim of terrorism, everybody, all and every one of them, each and every one of them deserves this prize. I am a Yazidi girl. My real age is 18 years old. I loved school very, very much when I was little and my father decided to increase my age by a year so that I would be able to go to school. And when Daesh attacked my village I was 15 years old. They killed all the men in the village, including my brother, my father, relatives, young and old. And then they took us to another place and they separated us between older and younger women. They killed the older women and then they divided the younger girls up and we were then traded on the slave trade market. I myself was sold four times by Daesh and every single time I was sold I tried to escape. They tortured me, they beat me and they insulted me and captured me again.  And one of the individuals made explosive devices and bombs and forced me to help him, forced me to make these bombs. The last person who bought me was an Iraqi doctor called Doctor Eslam. He was the director of the Houwaja Hospital. He used to torture me. He used to torture all the Yazidi women and he would even rape girls who were only nine or ten years old. Together with a friend of mine called Kathrin and a nine year old girl, all of us were raped by Dr Eslam. The three of us did actually manage to escape but before we actually managed to arrive to safety Kathrin accidentally walked over a landmine and it exploded and the last thing I heard was her death screams and this was awful, absolutely awful and it was the worst thing that I have ever heard.  When I managed to pick myself up I knew that I would not be able to ever see again because the whole of my body was burnt, my body was burning and I did not think that I would actually be able to open my eyes ever again. And then I was taken to Germany and I was helped to travel from Iraq to Germany and I was helped, I was treated and I am now able to see through one eye. I can see now again and I would like to thank God for the possibility that I can see now, that I can be a voice to the victims. And the Sakharov prize gives me great strength.  And this is why I have taken a decision to become a voice for the voiceless. The Yazidis have been victims of extremism, of violence and terrorism, they have lost their lives but I very much ask you and urge you to promise me, to promise us, that never again, never again will you allow these kinds of things to happen. That you will listen to us and see that justice will be done so that the criminals can be brought to justice and held accountable.  It has been two-and-a half-years now since the tragedy that affected the Yazidi people and there are still more than 3 500 children and women held by Daesh as slaves and every day they die a thousand times over again. The bones in the Yazidi mass graves that remain untouched in the area of Singhar, and the Yazidi people, have no value in Iraq, whether dead or alive. Our village, ladies and gentlemen, has been a neighbour to Arab cities for hundreds of years and when people visited us, when an Arab or a Muslim visited us, they would not eat meat in our homes because this was prohibited under their religion. They were not allowed to eat this meat. And my father would tell our Muslim guests that they should slaughter the animal themselves so that they would then be able to eat halal meat when they visited us.  When Islamic State arrived and attacked us then it was our neighbours who actually attacked us first of all, before them. And they killed our men and they enslaved our women. As a result of this we have lost the social order in our own society and we have lost trust with these countries because they do not treat us as Yazidis as equal to other citizens. So today we need Europe so that we can go back to our country, so that we can build up our country again and so that we can experience peace again in our society. These criminals must be brought to justice, they must be held to account. The Yazidis and the Christians need international protection and they, both children and women that have been victims of Daesh, need some kind of psychological rehabilitation. We need programmes for that and they need to be resettled. And ladies and gentlemen I would like to thank you very much for this prize. I stand here before you and I would like to accept this prize on behalf of all the women and all the girls who are still in the camps in Kurdistan, who are living in those camps where the conditions are absolutely appalling and I very much hope that you will all help us. Thank you very much. (The House accorded the speaker a heartfelt standing ovation)

name: Nadia Murad Basee Taha
text: Winner of the Sakharov Prize (The following is a transcription of the interpretation of the original speech from Arabic into English). – Mr President, esteemed Members of Parliament, as I stand before you today, my heart is full of happiness, because you decided to stand by a Yazidi woman and the Yazidi community in the midst of a genocide. I am happy because not only did you stand by us as a community but you stood by millions of women and children in Iraq, Syria and in conflict zones where they face blind terrorism. Receiving the Sakharov Prize today is a great honour for us. Daesh wanted, by enslaving us, to take our honour, but they lost their honour, and here you have given us this honour.  Daesh and the extremists came on 3 August to erase the Yazidis from existence and they gave us one option: death or Islam. There is no doubt Daesh committed mass genocide. This genocide did not only consist of killings, but it also sought to enslave women in a systematic manner and to take the children away. Daesh wanted to break our will to live. They started by killing the disabled and the elders and the women that they did not desire for themselves. Then they destroyed places of worship and infrastructure so that we wouldn’t return. Daesh and other global radical groups do not want anyone to have a life. They target all those who stand against their ideology, including millions of Muslims. Terrorism and radicalism are the enemies of mankind. I was a girl in a big family. I was the closest to my mother among my sisters. I learned from my mother the meaning of goodness and mercy, and what it means to challenge poverty. I learned from my small community that when we pray every evening we pray for all the peoples of the world before we pray for ourselves. I learned from my religion that God is tolerant and noble and that the difference between religions and cultures is a difference chosen by the creation, and it ought to be respected as such. Daesh took my mother, who believed in the essence of humanity, along with 86 Yazidi women in Soulagh. They killed them all because they did not hold any value in the human sex trade. Today, my community has disintegrated under the weight of genocide. Half a million people do not know where their future is leading them. Will we return to our lands? How will we return to our lands under the same conditions that led to the genocide? Should we emigrate? This is what some 75 000 Yazidis did. They mostly emigrated to Germany, and I thank Germany with all my heart for taking in my community, and I also thank Germany also for taking in 1 000 Yazidi women to provide them with medical and psychological care.  Half a million Yazidis remain in Iraq and they are the last members of this community present in the Middle East. They are the few who remain after thousands, or perhaps millions, of Yazidis were exterminated throughout history. The harsh conditions forced them to emigrate from Turkey and Syria, especially under the Ottoman Empire.  We look up to Europe as a symbol of humanity, and Europe is indeed confirming today that it is such a symbol. Europe should remain a model for the world and a model for the coexistence of peoples and cultures. The world today faces two of its biggest threats – the danger of terrorism as well as the dangers of reactions to terrorism. We must fight terrorism and we must dry its source. We must also work with the Islamic community around the world so that they can change the teachings of Islam and make the mosques a place for mercy, love and peace, free of extremism. We must prevent radicalism and racism everywhere. Radicalism and extremism have become such dangers today. We must respect the individual, regardless of religion, creed, colour, sex or place of residence.  The religious communities in Iraq must be protected, and amongst them my community after this genocide. They can be protected through the establishment of a protected zone or zones under the aegis and protection of the international community in coordination with the Iraqi Government and the regional government of Kurdistan. If the world is unable to protect us in our lands, I invite Europe to open its doors to us to provide refuge to half a million Yazidis from Iraq, through an organised mass migration similar to what happened following the Holocaust. For we cannot afford to remain the fuel of genocide and slavery. There must also be an accountability system to hold those who committed these crimes accountable both at [local] level and in the international community. There are still thousands of terrorists in Iraq and Syria and they must be brought to justice.  Thank you again for giving us this great award. From here, I would like to say to Daesh, and all terrorists in the world, if you have chosen for yourself the path of no dignity, then Europe has chosen for itself the path of humanity and honour. (The House accorded the speaker a loud and sustained standing ovation)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Dear colleagues, The little young man you see right here is another guest of honor today. I will take the opportunity to explain this briefly from this. That's the little wad. Wad is Lamija's brother. He's been in a camp for the past 18 months. His mother, father and all siblings are dead — murdered. He found his sister with us yesterday, also on the occasion of our award ceremony. I think this is a great day for the European Parliament and for Wad and his sister. A warm welcome. (Loud and sustained applause) (The formal sitting was closed at 12.35 p.m.)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the round of voting. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, the fact that we are dealing with a report which currently has more than four hundred amendments shows that it is far from consensual and that this process is far from mature enough. It is a process that will have very profound political repercussions — it is far from a purely technical dossier — and this advised another process of maturation and reflection. If we add to this the fact that in recent days, within a few days, a public appeal that is available on the Internet has already been subscribed by many hundreds of citizens, all this would advise that this procedure should be suspended here and that there could be a deeper reflection on this report, than that reflection could continue in the specialized committee. We were therefore calling on your prerogative, Mr President, to be able to return the report to committee, to make use of it and that we should not vote here today on this report, not to force the adoption of a report which is far from consensual and which will have profound political repercussions on the operation of this report. Parliament. As far as political considerations are concerned, we have already made them during the debate, but it would be wise to postpone this.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Ferreira, are you asking the House to speak for or against your proposal or is it just an invitation? He asks for a vote? All right then, let us speak on the House, please.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, it is the President's prerogative to be able to send this report to committee. If you do not want to make use of it, then we would ask the plenary to speak.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: – Mr President, I wish to raise a point about Rule 170 of the Rules of Procedure. We have an amendment supported by more than 100 MEPs from five different groups, Amendment 320, which proposes that former MEPs who have a transitional allowance should not be engaged in lobbying. It was declared inadmissible on the fifth version of the voting list last night. We have not received a formal explanation why this pretty good amendment was declared inadmissible, and this we find strange and unacceptable. If possible, we would like the vote on Amendment 320 to go forward.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Andersson, I will immediately answer your question and then let us vote on Mr Ferreira's proposal. As regards the President's decision to declare the amendment to which you refer inadmissible, this is a final decision because, within the meaning of Article 232 of the Treaty on the the functioning of the European Union, Parliament has the power to establish its rules of procedure on the basis of case-law; this means that it can decide on its own internal organisation and take appropriate measures in order to ensure the proper functioning and conduct of its procedures. In this context, Parliament may regulate, in its Rules of Procedure, certain questions concerning its Members where this is necessary to ensure the proper functioning and performance of its own Members procedures. However, the rules of procedure cannot be used to regulate the activities of former Members. Hence the president's decision. As far as Mr Ferreira's proposal is concerned, I would like to know if there is any Member who wants to speak in favour, someone who wants to take action against it. (Parliament rejects the request for an adjournment)

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission, in writing. – The Commission takes note of the fact that the European Parliament has adopted today a revision of its Rules of Procedure which includes some changes concerning the relations with the Commission. Pursuant to point 21 of the Framework Agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission, the European Parliament has taken the commitment to seek the opinion of the Commission when it comes forward with such changes to its Rules of Procedure. By letter from President Schulz of 9 December 2016, the European Parliament transmitted for the Commission's opinion, where relevant, the envisaged amendments to its Rules of Procedure brought forward for consideration of the plenary on 13 December 2016. The Commission regrets that Parliament did not respect its commitment for consulting the Commission in a meaningful way, as the time left before the vote by the European Parliament has not allowed the Commission to provide a considered response or even discuss the matter in the College, and the Parliament to take a Commission opinion duly into account before voting on the proposed changes. The Commission regrets that the Parliament did not act in accordance with the principle of loyal and sincere cooperation and, despite its request, did not allow the Commission enough time to express its opinion before adopting the revision.  The Commission wishes to highlight some of Parliament's changes to its Rules of Procedure, in particular those relating to the proposed hearings in case of the appointment of a new Commissioner during the Commission's mandate or modifications in the portfolio of serving Commissioners, as well as those relating to a possible conflict of interest of a Commissioner. It must be borne in mind that those changes, if introduced unilaterally by the European Parliament in its Rules of Procedure, cannot create a role for the European Parliament which is neither provided for in the Treaties nor in the Framework Agreement and which would affect the institutional position and functioning of the Commission. The Commission underlines in this regard that it will apply the Treaties and continue to respect the terms of the Framework Agreement. The Commission expects that the Parliament will do the same.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: With this concludes the round of voting.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ The following report aims to lay down certain technical and financial rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. Although the report still remains very general, not indicating the specific programmes in which Algeria will be able to participate, I think it is important to involve the geographically neighbouring countries in order to cooperate with the aim of encouraging development and growth. For the reasons set out earlier I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. ‒ Algeria and the Union have been participating in a Euro-Mediterranean Agreement since 2005. In 2013, Algeria expressed its interest in expanding its participation in programmes to which it would have consequently access, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Today's report opens the door for such participation to become effective, in the terms freely negotiated by Algeria and the European Commission. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on a framework agreement between the EU and the Republic of Algeria establishing the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Algeria in European Union programmes. I voted in favour of the draft in support of its main provision on the conclusion of the protocol. I take this position on the basis of the Council's request for consent, the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and also in the light of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part , a draft protocol on a framework agreement between the EU and the Republic of Algeria establishing the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Community and its Member States The European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes, because within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy the gradual opening of Union programmes to neighbouring countries such as Algeria, aims to reform and modernise it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. — This report focuses on Algeria's participation in EU programmes. Considering that Brussels does not have to substitute for States in foreign relations, moreover, with their money, I opposed it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support this Agreement. As I do not believe that the United Kingdom should be a part of the European Union, I cannot support the participation of Algeria in European Union programmes whilst the UK remains a member.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text, which endorses the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the EU and Algeria. The latter is close to the European Union and its participation in its programmes is an essential condition for cooperation between the two entities in many areas.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria establishing the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. In the light of the request for consent submitted by the Council, I support the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. — I voted against this framework agreement because the European Union does not have to have its own foreign policy; it should not be in its power to integrate a third country into its internal programmes. Moreover, joining with Algeria seems dangerous in view of the country's instability, which is economically fragile and subject to President Bouteflika's shaky health.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. — I approved this report, which recommends approval of the Protocol, the objective of which is to lay down technical and financial rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes within the framework of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the Union and Algeria.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I agree with the possibility that Algeria can access the Union's programmes.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution establishing the possible participation of Algeria in cooperation programmes between the Union and neighbouring countries. The programmes in question should be agreed on a case-by-case basis. I considered that it should accept the resolution, as it was a request from the Algerian Government and not to determine in principle the nature of the programmes.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Panzeri for his work on this report on the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. Algeria is a strategic country with which the Union has a long-standing relationship and its participation in the Union's programmes will hope it will serve the development of the country and the region.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the framework agreement between the European Union and Algeria on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. The European Union does not have to substitute for sovereign States in establishing diplomatic or commercial relations with third countries. Especially in this particular case concerning Algeria, a country with which France has a long history and privileged relations. On the other hand, it is still comical that the EU funds its diplomacy with the money of the Member States that it stripped of their competences.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. ‒ I find the Panzeri report examining the Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria on the general principles of the participation of the Democratic and People's Republic of Algerian in programmes I have therefore not intended to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. ‒ The gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of the European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries represents one of many measures to promote the reform, modernisation and transition of the European Union's neighbouring countries. The Protocol contains a Framework Agreement on the General Principles of Algeria's Participation in Programmes. Algeria has already expressed its interest in participating in programmes open to partner countries. Algeria is also a key and very important partner of the Union. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Algeria laying down the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) gradually opens up the opportunity for partner countries to participate in certain Union programmes and agencies, one of a number of measures to promote reforms, modernisation and transition in the European Union's neighbourhood. This policy aspect was further defined by the Commission in its Communication of December 2006 on a common approach to enable ENP partner countries to participate in Community agencies and Community programmes. The Council endorsed this approach in its Conclusions of 5 March 2007. On 18 June 2007, the Council instructed the Commission to open negotiations with Algeria, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Egypt, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Moldova, Morocco, the Palestinian Administration, Tunisia and Ukraine on framework agreements establishing general principles for participation in Community programmes. February 2013 Algeria has expressed its willingness to participate in various programmes in which the European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries can participate. At the same time, the Commission shall submit a proposal for a Council decision on the This Protocol shall constitute a framework agreement establishing the general principles for Algeria's participation in Union programmes. The Framework Agreement sets out the standard conditions that should apply to all partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy with which such protocols will be concluded.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. —I support this Report. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies for participation with partner countries is one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in Algeria.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing. — I am opposed to the fact that the European Union is interfering with matters of foreign relations. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report. Whilst these frameworks for participation in EU programmes allow third countries to access EU funds, remove travel or visa restrictions and promote cultural awareness, they are for the most part neoliberal financial arrangements aimed at trade liberalisation. Furthermore, Algeria’s human rights record is poor. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: — Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Republic of Algeria, in particular, is one of the few countries in north Africa where the social and political system holds despite the huge problems to which it is exposed: an exceptional case for reception and tenacity which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite still serious structural shortcomings, its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with minorities and jihadist militias still active in many areas of the country. Altogether Europe can look to Algeria as a friendly reality, present in a key area, which we must support, ensuring its territorial integrity and political survival, and enabling it to stabilize under appropriate conditions, and to gradually become part of the area of common collaboration and comanagement of the Middle East crisis.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This is a codification report on Algeria's participation in European Union programmes. On the one hand, we consider that the European Union should not replace the Member States in its foreign relations with third countries. The Union should not have an external policy insofar as diplomatic policy falls exclusively within the competence of the Member States. On the other hand, it is not at all appropriate to integrate Algeria into Community programmes in view of its state of extreme fragility, particularly because of President Bouteflika's very uncertain succession. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - The European Union is one of the main promoters of reform measures, modernising the neighbouring countries of the Union. Thus, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the European Union aims to gradually open programmes and agencies for ENP partner states. Algeria is one of the states that has expressed its intention to engage in a series of programmes dedicated to the European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries. As a result, a draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, has been concluded. This Protocol laid down the financial and technical rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. I have expressed myself in favour of the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes because I believe that the European Neighbourhood Policy needs to be constantly strengthened, and this framework agreement is a strong instrument of cooperation economic, financial, but also technical, which proves to be appropriate.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this recommendation to establish the conditions for political, economic, social and cultural cooperation between the European Union and Algeria. I think that respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights is an essential element of the agreement in question. Furthermore, I think that the EU-Algeria Agreement should promote: a periodic dialogue on political and security matters; economic, trade and financial cooperation, especially aimed at progressive trade liberalisation, sustainable development of the Mediterranean region and investment; social, cultural and education cooperation, especially through dialogue intercultural, migration control, development of qualifications, the promotion of labour law and equality between women and men. Finally, I believe that this agreement can allow the participation of Algeria, a partner country of the European Neighbourhood Policy, in Community programmes, acting as a basis for the gradual liberalisation of exchanges in the Mediterranean space.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The good elements of the report include allowing Algeria to access EU programmes, access funding, remove travel and visa restrictions and promote cultural awareness. However the main part of the agreement is about promoting neo-liberal financial arrangements aimed at trade liberalisation. This, on top of the fact that Algeria currently has a poor human rights record, meant that I abstained on the final vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this consent procedure. So long as the UK continues to contribute to the EU central budget we will continue to oppose any legislation that would waste the money of the EU taxpayer. We do not support the transfer of EU money overseas or the continued development of an EU foreign policy through the European Neighbourhood. As this only sets out general principles the budgetary impact and value for money of British contributions is unknown.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the EU and Algeria on a Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes as part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), which allows for the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries. This helps to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: In writing. ‒ In Mr Panzeri's report, some technical and financial rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain European Union programmes are laid down. My vote was positive.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: In writing. ‒ The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was developed in 2004 to avoid the emergence of economic and cultural fractures between the European Union and its neighbouring states with the aim of promoting the stability and security of the whole region. The resolution, for which I voted in favour, gives approval to a Euro-Mediterranean framework agreement laying down the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). I think it is appropriate to give Algeria access to financial assistance programmes but not only, in order to reiterate the European Union's support for the country's delicate political and democratic transition. I firmly believe that a stable and democratic Algeria can be a key ally in countering terrorism in North Africa as well as being an important trading partner for the Union European as a whole.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the report on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes, as we consider it extremely important.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria and on the general principles governing the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. This is a useful effort to deepen and further develop the relations between the two parties. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: In writing. — Negative vote, the agreement covers Algeria's participation in certain European programmes such as economic, financial and technical cooperation. The report lacks a deepening of the contents of the programmes mentioned.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. ‒ In the current powder keg of the countries of North Africa, I cannot but guarantee my approval at the conclusion of the Protocol, since Algeria is the only successful case of the Arab Spring. It is undoubted how the former French colony is embarking on a path of reform in all state areas, but in pursuing these objectives it finds hostility, primarily from neighbouring countries and from the extremist cells. In addition to external pressures, the difficulties encountered by a country that is starting to adopt Western systems of democracy and the rule of law, therefore through the association between the Union European and the Algerian Republic are aimed at facilitating economic, financial and technical cooperation. Thus, openness to financial assistance will be achieved in pursuit of Union programmes, especially aimed at the progressive liberalisation of trade, the sustainable development of the region and to investments. In addition, a periodic dialogue on political and security matters is planned to foster mutual understanding, cooperation and joint initiatives, as well as social, cultural and cultural cooperation education, especially through intercultural dialogue, migration control, development of qualifications, the promotion of labour law or equality between women and men.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: The draft Euro-Mediterranean agreement aims to create an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Algeria of the other part. The objectives of this Framework Agreement are: to provide an appropriate framework for political dialogue between the Parties in order to enable the strengthening of their relations and cooperation in all areas they deem relevant; to develop trade and to ensure the development of economic relations and between the Parties and define the conditions for progressive liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital; promote human contacts, particularly in the context of administrative procedures; encourage Maghreb integration by promoting exchanges and cooperation in the region and between The latter and the European Communities and their Member States; promote cooperation in the economic, social, cultural and financial fields. Respect for democratic principles and fundamental human rights, as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is an essential element of this Agreement. I therefore support this Recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this consent procedure. So long as the UK continues to contribute to the EU central budget we will continue to oppose any legislation that would waste the money of the EU taxpayer. We do not support the transfer of EU money overseas or the continued development of an EU foreign policy through the European Neighbourhood. As this only sets out general principles the budgetary impact and value for money of British contributions is unknown.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that Algeria's participation in Union programmes is an important measure to promote reform and modernisation of this country within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Political Programme.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. ‒ Algeria and the Union have been participating in a Euro-Mediterranean Agreement since 2005. In 2013, Algeria expressed its interest in expanding its participation in programmes to which it would have consequently access, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Today's report opens the door for such participation to become effective, in the terms freely negotiated by Algeria and the European Commission. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, approving the conclusion of the Protocol of Agreement between the EU and Algeria. to allow Algeria to participate in the Community programmes envisaged by European neighbourhood policy. In fact, I believe that the conclusion of this Protocol represents not only an important opportunity for economic, financial and technical cooperation between the EU and Algeria, but also a strengthening of the framework of Euro-Mediterranean partnership.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Parliament agreeing to conclude a framework agreement on relations between the EU and Algeria and its participation in EU programmes. I believe that programmes should be supported to support Algeria's efforts to develop all areas of the economy. Relations between Algeria and the European Union are based on the Association Agreement signed under the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership in 2005, covering policy, economy, trade, technical and financial cooperation and humanitarian aid. A particular argument in favour of the legitimacy of supporting the agreement is economic cooperation with the participation of both parties. It is necessary to seek to ensure the widest possible agreement in the European Parliament on agreeing to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this recommendation as it provides for the gradual opening-up of certain union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries. Such protocols include standard clauses which are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood policy countries, promote reform, modernisation and transition in Algeria. This also strengthens the EU-Algeria relationship.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support the strengthening of relations with the countries of North Africa, including Algeria, in order to foster economic growth, reform, and cultural ties. This is of vital importance for future growth, opportunity and security.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This non-legislative report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament on the gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of the partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This framework agreement represents one of many measures aimed at promoting the reform, modernisation and transition of third countries in the neighbourhood of the European Union. Considering on the one hand the historical links between the Union and France with Algeria, and on the other hand that support for the stabilisation and development of third countries in the neighbourhood is of particular importance, particularly in terms of the stabilisation of the European external borders, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing. — The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Algeria, of the other part, concerns a framework agreement between the European Union and Algeria on the general principles of its participation in Union programmes. The objective of this protocol is to establish a general framework for Algeria's participation in European programmes. This protocol also makes it possible to deepen our relations with our nearby neighbourhood. While similar protocols have already been signed with Armenia, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Moldova, Morocco and Ukraine and Algeria indicated in February 2013 its wish to participate in these programmes, I therefore voted in favour of the conclusion of this protocol.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consent procedure. So long as the UK continues to contribute to the EU central budget we will continue to oppose any legislation that would waste the money of the EU taxpayer. We do not support the transfer of EU money overseas or the continued development of an EU foreign policy through the European Neighbourhood. As this only sets out general principles the budgetary impact and value for money of British contributions is unknown.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is a codification program that does not call for comment. Nevertheless, the question of principle concerns Algeria's participation in Community programmes. We are against it, both on principle and in view of the unstable situation in the country, caused in particular by the uncertain succession of President Bouteflika.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — Relations between Algeria and the EU are based on an association agreement signed as part of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership in 2005. They cover policy, economy, trade, technical and financial cooperation and humanitarian aid. Economic cooperation under the Association Agreement shall be carried out through several mechanisms involving both Parties. The EU also funds a number of programmes aimed at supporting Algeria's efforts in various areas of the economy. The first assessment of the benefits of the Association Agreement was carried out in 2009. A second assessment is currently underway. An agreement was signed in 2014 that established the general principles for Algeria's participation in EU programmes. I supported this report because it is technical and I believe that Algeria, as a country that has maintained its stability and showing good results, can benefit from EU programmes.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The conclusion of a framework agreement between the EU and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing the participation of Algeria in Union programmes is hereby approved. In other words, the EU is once again trying to intervene in the internal affairs of a third country in exchange for a trade agreement.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes, as agreed by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the European Parliament. Ensuring good relations around the globe and making agreements for co-operation is very important for the EU and for Wales.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: codification report on Algeria's participation in EU programmes. The EU does not have to substitute for states in foreign relations with their money in addition.

name: João FERREIRA
text: This recommendation aims to approve the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, establishing a set of general principles establishing the participation of Algeria in EU programmes. Algeria has been part of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement since 2005 and has now asked to be part of EU programmes. The programmes contained in the Protocol concern economic, financial and technical cooperation, which will enable Algeria to access assistance, in particular financial assistance. Algeria may participate in programmes open to its participation and should contribute to the EU budget in those specific programmes. The specific terms of the Protocol will be determined in a Memorandum of Understanding between the European Commission and the Algerian authorities. We have known reservations about the content of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which opens the door to free trade agreements. But that is not what we stand on in this report, but it is related to it. We do not block Algeria's request, an expression of its sovereign will, to join EU programmes. However, we reaffirm some doubts and reservations regarding the issues of financial assistance in the manner mentioned in the Council decision.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The European Union seeks through the European Neighbourhood Policy Agenda to strengthen the reforms and modernisation of partner countries involved in the programme. One of these countries is Algeria, which has shown an interest in engaging in many European Neighbourhood Policy programmes. The Protocol in question contains a framework agreement which overlays the general principles for Algeria's participation in European Union programmes. These are standard provisions for all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which protocols are concluded.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report as it represents a potential danger to the Italian economy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles for Algeria's participation in Union programmes, as the EU is once again attempting to intervene in the internal affairs of a third country in exchange for a trade agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Council issued directives to the Commission to negotiate Framework Agreements, among others, with Algeria on the general principles for their participation in Union programmes. Algeria expressed its interest in participating in the broad range of programmes open to partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This protocol contains a Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes. It contains standard clauses that are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which such protocols are concluded. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in Algeria.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. — The gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of the partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy represents a concrete possibility of bringing the two shores of the Mediterranean closer together. It is an indirect but effective way of promoting reforms, modernisation and transition in the European Union's neighbourhood. Algeria's participation in EU programmes will also promote economic growth as well as cooperation in the field of security. In addition, the agreement opens the possibility for Algerians, especially young people, to take part in programmes such as Erasmus +, Horizon 2020 or Creative Europe. Beyond economic and political benefits, it is a step towards a new history of relations between Algeria and the European continent, a step that brings peoples closer together by building new ties, which are not those of colonization or war. Algeria has expressed its keen interest in participating in European Union programmes a long time ago, and I am delighted that the European Parliament has given almost unanimous agreement to this Memorandum of Understanding as a concrete element of the Euro-Mediterranean partnership.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution concerning the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which establish an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Democratic and People's Republic of Algerian on the other hand, concerning a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria on general principles of the participation of the Algerian Republic in the Union programmes, because I believe that Algeria is a key country for peace keeping and in the balance of the North African area. This is an important decision and I call on the Commission and the Algerian authorities to define together the specific arrangements and conditions relating to Algeria's participation in each Union programme , on the basis of the criteria set out in the programmes concerned and equal conditions for the Member States. Participation in Community programmes is a bridge with Europe, enabling civil society, young students, researchers and workers, the enterprise system and humanitarian organisations to make a leap forward towards democratic and liberal development, which I consider the main weapon against fundamentalism and religious extremism. Duty action by the EU in support of democracy and the rule of law in Algeria.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: in writing. - The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria strengthens economic and cultural relations and aims to strengthen political dialogue.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this consent procedure. So long as the UK continues to contribute to the EU central budget, I will continue to oppose any legislation that would waste the money of the EU taxpayer. I do not support the transfer of EU money overseas or the continued development of an EU foreign policy through the European Neighbourhood, as this only sets out general principles the budgetary impact and value for money of British contributions is unknown.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood. On 18 June 2007, the Council issued directives to the Commission to negotiate Framework Agreements, among others, with Algeria, on the general principles for their participation in Community programmes. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. I voted in favour of this technical report, which contains standard clauses that are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which such protocols are concluded.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: In writing. ‒ The conclusion of this protocol is the successful conclusion of a continuous dialogue process, supported also with the fundamental contribution of the members of the two Parliaments, and for the adoption of which i voted for it. Political dialogue is open to more ideas and today's framework agreement is yet another confirmation of this. The rule of law and the role of civil society will only improve and foster better Euro-Mediterranean and regional relations, without considering good governance practices that mutually will benefit from trade in sectoral programmes. It is a strategic cooperation that has economic and political foundations, but which is aimed at promoting regional stability and security, paving the way and setting the foundation for an increase in harmony also to More complex issues such as migration and mobility or security policies and the fight against terrorism, with a focus on development. Finally, public diplomacy and cultural diplomacy are fertile areas where much can still be done, among the many measures of the European Neighbourhood Policy with Algeria as well as with others Euro-Mediterranean partners.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution establishing the possible participation of Algeria in cooperation programmes between the Union and neighbouring countries. The programmes in question should be agreed on a case-by-case basis. I considered that it should accept the resolution, as it was a request from the Algerian Government and not to determine in principle the nature of the programmes.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this protocol. The objective is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. This is a technical report, which contains standard clauses that are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which such protocols are concluded.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. — The agreement concerns the participation of Algeria in Union programmes. We do not disagree on this aspect, especially since it is the will of the Algerian Government. However, we disagree because this presupposes financial obligations and because these agreements in many cases lead to free trade agreements on which our position is negative. For these reasons we consider it appropriate to abstain.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the opening-up of certain European Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform and modernisation in Algeria. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. — I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Algeria People's Democratic Republic, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria The People's Democratic Republic on the general principles of participation of the Algerian People's Democratic Republic in Union programmes (16152/2014 — C8-0152/2015 — 2014/0195 (NLE)) in view of the situation in Algeria where assistance is needed to maintain stability, avoid radicalisation, to start the economy, reduced unemployment and continued construction of democratic institutions. Among other things, Algeria needs European assistance in the restructuring of the banking sector and financial institutions, preparing development programmes for small and medium-sized enterprises, the development of fisheries and agriculture and the development of telecommunications and new technology networks. Such an agreement connects economic cooperation with democratic processes and human rights and represents a new phase in relations with Algeria where the EU must be effective in the assistance it provides to end terrorism and violence and support Algerian citizens' aspirations to live in peace and stability.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — Whenever the European Union tries to assign itself to the management of Europe's external relations, I would point out that foreign policy must remain the prerogative of States alone. I voted against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation because I support a closer partnership between Algeria and the European Union. This agreement will help to deepen the cooperation built on the bases of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States from 2002 with common objectives of setting the appropriate framework for political dialogue and encouraging integration of the Maghreb countries by promoting trade and cooperation within the Maghreb group and between it and the EU. I believe that Algeria’s participation in Union programmes will lead to the expansion of harmonious economic and social relations and promote its trade in terms of establishing the conditions for the gradual liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital and facilitate human exchanges.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Pier Antonio Panzeri on the agreement between the European Union and Algeria. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, Algeria is one of the ten Mediterranean neighbours with whom the EU must maintain a political and strategic relationship. This procedure allows the EU to approve the Memorandum of Understanding between the two countries on financial rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain EU programmes. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which allows Algeria to participate and benefit from certain European programmes and from the activities of certain Union agencies within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This framework agreement has been part of the negotiations requested by the Commission by the Council since 2007. Algeria had expressed its interest in 2013. This text thus strengthens our links with this country that is essential for North Africa's stability.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. — I have rejected this report. This concerns the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in the programmes of the Union. The aim of this agreement is to give Algeria access to and finance European programmes. However, adequate compensation is not available.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The premise of the European Neighbourhood Policy is that the EU has a vital interest in building a much stronger and deeper relationship to its neighbours. This is why I voted in favour of this report as I believe that Algeria should be allowed to participate in the programmes of the Union, as well as contribute financially to the general budget, corresponding to the specific programmes in which Algeria participates.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. I support the recommendation for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and The People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles of participation of the Republic in Union programmes. This Protocol contains a framework agreement on the general principles for Algeria's participation in Union programmes. It contains standard clauses which are intended to be applied to all partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy with which such protocols are to be concluded. I believe that, as part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of partner countries in the European Neighbourhood Policy constitutes one of many measures aimed at providing support for the reform process, modernisation and transition in the neighbouring countries of the European Union. I believe that a deeper partnership between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria is needed in order to improve the situation in terms of stability, democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption, economic development and employment in the region.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Algeria in Union programmes (hereinafter referred to as ‘the Protocol’). The signing and provisional application of the Protocol will lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes which in a long term perspective will foster bilateral relations between Algeria and the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal under consideration concerns the EU-Algeria framework agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. Opening up to some EU programmes or agencies in the participation of partner countries in the neighbourhood policy is a further step in promoting reform, modernisation and transition in the area surrounding the EU. Directives were issued in 2007 aimed at negotiating framework agreements with several countries, including Algeria. The latter in 2013 expressed its interest in participating in several programmes which were opened to partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. In the light of these reasons, Parliament proposes the approval of the agreement by the Council, which authorises Algeria's participation in European Union programmes.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the framework agreement between the European Union and Algeria on the general principles of Algeria's participation in European Union programmes. Even if it is merely a codification report, the question is whether or not Algeria should be accepted in Community programmes. The answer must be no, for many reasons, the first and most important of which is that the European Union does not have to have foreign policy, and the second that Algeria is a country in a state of extreme fragility due to President Bouteflika's uncertain succession.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: This report makes it possible to codify Algeria's participation in European Union programmes through a framework agreement. I cannot accept this idea for two reasons: first of all, we are opposed to the EU having a foreign policy as such, since that prerogative must be the right of the Member States. Furthermore, Algeria is in a state of extreme fragility due to the uncertain succession of President Bouteflika, as well as the “Dutch syndrome” affecting the country's economic model. I voted against this report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. ‒ Algeria and the Union have been participating in a Euro-Mediterranean Agreement since 2005. In 2013, Algeria expressed its interest in expanding its participation in programmes to which it would have consequently access, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Today's report opens the door for such participation to become effective, in the terms freely negotiated by Algeria and the European Commission. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal allows the Council, on behalf of the European Union, to add a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement providing for the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. In particular, the Agreement seeks to define the technical and financial rules enabling Algeria to participate in these programmes. Thus, the Protocol establishes a mechanism for economic, financial and technical cooperation which will enable Algeria to access assistance, particularly financial, which will be transmitted by the Union as European programmes. I support the protocol because it is included within the European Neighbourhood Policy's objective of promoting the inclusion of the countries participating in the Union in EU programmes as a measure to promote reforms, modernisation and transition for the Union's neighbouring countries.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I voted against. I do not want Algeria to participate in European Union subsidy programmes at the expense of our taxpayers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the gradual opening of certain Union participation programmes for partner countries is one of many measures to promote reform and modernisation in neighbouring EU countries. In 2007, the Council issued guidelines for the Commission's work on negotiating framework agreements with a number of countries, including Algeria. In 2013, Algeria expressed interest in participating in most programmes that were open to partner countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy. Since the text of the negotiating protocol with Algeria is in accordance with Article 218. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of the Protocol is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol constitutes an economic, financial and technical cooperation measure, which gives access to Union financial assistance, pursuant to the Union programmes. I support this agreement.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a framework agreement between the The European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text is a codification report aimed at involving Algeria in EU Community programmes, which we disagree with. Moreover, the EU does not have to substitute for States in their external relations.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ The Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Algerian Republic on the general principles of the participation of the Republic of Algerian in the Union programmes is aimed at pursuing objectives established previously both by the Council and the draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement, which establishes an association between the Member States belonging to the European Union and the Democratic and People's Republic of Algerian, promoting the development of a charity and increasing cooperation between the countries that are part of it.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we voted on the proposal to grant consent to the framework agreement between the EU and the Democratic and People's Republic of Algeria on the general principles of Algiers participation in Union programmes. The Protocol aims to lay down financial and technical rules which would allow Algiers to participate in certain Union programmes. In particular, it is a horizontal framework for measures of economic, financial and technical cooperation which would give Algiers access to aid, in particular financial, provided by the Union under programmes Union. This framework would, of course, apply only to those Union programmes for which such participation by Algiers is allowed. I agree with such an option for Algiers, which is why I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the draft Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes.

name: Georg MAYER
text: in writing. - This is a Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association with regard to a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria. The agreements are intended to establish free trade in accordance with WTO rules, with a transitional period of up to 12 years for the tariff reduction of the industrial partners. These agreements, which already include provisions to liberalise trade in goods, are complemented by a number of additional negotiations to further liberalise trade in agricultural products, services and investment and to establish a dispute settlement procedure for trade issues. As this framework agreement, which is financed by EU direct investment, will lead to a wide market opening between Algeria and the Member States of the EU and the opening up of Algeria to EU programmes, I believe that this report should be rejected.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament resolution on a Framework Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Algeria laying down the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Algeria in European Union programmes.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which gives consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and a Framework agreement between the EU and Algeria.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: Algeria expressed its willingness to participate in certain European Union programmes open to third countries, such as Erasmus Monde but also Horizon 2020. Even if I oppose the terms of this agreement, which gives the Commission the power to negotiate its terms, I respect the sovereign choice of that country, hoping that Algerian youth will be able to benefit from it. I vote for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: This is a report codifying Algeria's participation in European Union programmes. I objected to this report considering that the European Union is not responsible for managing foreign policy affairs, which is solely the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Algeria is not only one of the biggest neighbours of the European Union but also one of the most important neighbours. The recommendation before us on the framework agreement between the EU and Algeria is another step towards strengthening our global and multidimensional relations. Our objective is to establish a horizontal framework for economic, financial and technical cooperation that will enable Algeria to participate in certain European Union programmes and the EU to provide financial assistance aimed at supporting the Algerian government's efforts to reform and economic and social adjustment. In this sense, this agreement, based on genuine dialogue, will help the development and modernisation of Algeria, a country with which the EU wishes to build a neighbourhood of prosperity and stability, helping to bring policies on both sides of the Mediterranean closer.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this agreement, which contains a Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes. It contains standard clauses that are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which such protocols are concluded.
