As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in Algeria.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — The Council drew up a draft decision on the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes the conclusion of a Protocol on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles governing its participation. In order to adopt the draft, the Council must obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Foreign Affairs called for Parliament to agree with the conclusion of the protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. — The Panzeri report is a codification report. It is a two-point report (acceptance and transmission to the Union authorities). So there is nothing to comment on. The only problem is whether or not Algeria participates in Community programmes. The answer must be no for many reasons, the first is that the EU does not have to have foreign policy and the second that Algeria is a country in a state of extreme fragility due to President Bouteflika's uncertain succession. Since decolonization had been completed, there was no need to return in the opposite direction. Unfavourable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - Codification report on Algeria's participation in EU programmes. The EU does not have to substitute for states in foreign relations, with their money in addition. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this technical report to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: I voted in favour of this legislative resolution on the conclusion of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part. Algeria concluded a Euro-Mediterranean agreement with the European Union, which entered into force in September 2005. The additional protocol approved by the European Parliament makes it possible to organise Algeria's participation in certain EU programmes. It states that Algeria contributes financially to the general budget of the Union for all the programmes in which it participates.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States on one side and the People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria on the other, regarding a framework agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in EU programmes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because the agreement is financed by EU direct investment and calls for extensive market opening between Algeria and the European Member States on European programmes.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. By concluding the Framework Agreement, Algeria will be able to participate in certain EU programmes and agencies under the European Neighbourhood Policy, which could contribute to reforms and innovations in the EU's immediate neighbour.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - In the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries is one of the numerous measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in its neighbouring countries European Union. In accordance with a Council Decision, partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy are allowed to participate in Community agencies and programmes on the basis of their performance and provided that the legal bases permit. Algeria expressed its wish to participate in a number of Union programmes. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the Framework Agreement on the general principles for Algeria's participation in Union programmes and which includes specific terms and conditions, in particular the financial contribution and reporting procedures, and evaluation of Algeria's participation in each specific programme.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the Community and the Member States should be concluded, of the one part, and the Algerian Republic on the other. The purpose of the Protocol is to establish financial and technical standards enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes and is within the most ambitious objective of building balances relations with a number of Mediterranean countries at economic, political, strategic and cultural levels according to the logic of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I believe that European security is not a zero-sum game and we need stability in our neighbouring countries. For this reason I supported this report, because it will promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood. In February 2013, Algeria expressed its interest in participating in the broad range of programmes open to partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Good relations of the European Union with its neighbours, while taking care of the interests of the Union and its citizens, are the best motivation for fruitful joint cooperation. The European Union and its members are therefore partnering with their neighbours to foster better understanding and improve mutual relations. In this spirit, I also observe the approval of this Protocol in addition to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing links between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria on the general principles of Algeria's participation in the programmes Union. The Protocol in question lays down financial and technical rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. These programmes aim to assist the public sector and governance, the exchange of technical assistance and knowledge in order to improve overall relations, reduce administrative barriers, and to facilitate the traffic of goods and services by better knowledge of each other's procedures. Not least, Algeria's participation in Union programmes also contributes to the implementation of assistance projects to efforts that support respect for children's rights, women and environmental protection, and the greater role of civil society, as well as better cultural cooperation and promotion of young talent. For all of the above, I have supported this Recommendation of the European Parliament.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. — In the east and south of the European Union there are sixteen countries whose hopes and future have a direct impact on us. Within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening of certain programmes and agencies of the European Union for the participation of ECJ partner countries is one of a number of measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in neighbouring countries of the European Union. With Algeria, the surface largest country in Africa, rich in resources and a population of 40 million, it is necessary to continuously develop relationships across all fields, from energy and education, to transport and security. Since its inception in 2004, our neighbourhood policy has promoted a number of important initiatives, especially in terms of trade and the economy, thus encouraging the creation of even stronger relations between the EU and its neighbours. Partnership with our neighbourhood therefore brings great benefits for both sides, it is undeniable. Sustainable economic development and job creation, with overall growth in respect of the rule of law and human rights in partner countries, is necessary to encourage.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: This recommendation aims to approve the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, establishing a set of general principles establishing the participation of Algeria in Union programmes. The programmes contained in the Protocol concern economic, financial and technical cooperation, which will enable Algeria to access assistance provided by the Union through its programmes. Algeria may participate in Union programmes open to its participation and should contribute to the Union budget in the specific programmes in which it will participate. Although it is part of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement which opens the door to free trade agreements, it is not an agreement of this nature that is involved in the conclusion of this Framework Agreement, but an instrument from which Algeria can benefit in its development.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. The Framework Agreement lays down financial and technical rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. Algeria is an important EU partner in the region of North Africa, which plays an important role in stabilising the situation of North Africa and the fight against terrorism. This framework agreement represents another step in the deepening of relations between the EU and Algeria. It is in the highest interest of Europe and its security and stability to continue to work closely with this country.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. — Relations between Algeria and the EU are based on the Association Agreement signed under the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership in 2005. They include policy, economy, trade, technical and financial cooperation and humanitarian aid. As part of the association agreement, economic cooperation takes place, through several mechanisms, involving both parties. The EU also funds a number of programmes to support Algeria's efforts in various areas of the economy. The first assessment of how the association agreement works was carried out in 2009 and the second evaluation procedure is currently underway. In 2014, the general rules for Algeria's participation in EU programmes were also established in the form of a separate agreement. I hereby supported the Framework Agreement on EU-Algeria relations and its participation in EU programmes.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Algeria has been participating in the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy since 2013. In this context, this North African partner can access certain European programmes. I voted in favour of the country's access to these programmes which will boost our political and economic relations.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The European Neighbourhood Policy aims to share the benefits of the European Union with neighbouring countries, thereby contributing to strengthening stability, security and well-being inside and outside the Union. In this context, this text refers to the protocol negotiated between Algeria and the EU, which aims at the participation of Algeria in certain Community programmes. Because the European Union cannot close itself to the world around it, and because Algeria's geographical proximity to the European area justifies the creation of synergies with that State, I approve this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this consent procedure. So long as the UK continues to contribute to the EU central budget we will continue to oppose any legislation that would waste the money of the EU taxpayer. We do not support the transfer of EU money overseas or the continued development of an EU foreign policy through the European Neighbourhood. As this only sets out general principles the budgetary impact and value for money of British contributions is unknown.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the progressive opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries is one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and democratic transition in the European Union's neighbouring countries. This agreement with Algeria is an example of this.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. ‒ The gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) partner countries represents one of many measures to promote the reform, modernisation and transition of the European Union's neighbouring countries. The protocol to be negotiated contains a Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in the programmes. Algeria has already expressed its interest in participating in programmes open to partner countries. Algeria is also a key and very important partner of the Union. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Yesterday, the European Parliament approved the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement which authorises Algeria's participation in Union programmes and determines the conditions for it. This agreement, signed jointly in Brussels on 4 June 2015, takes the form of a protocol annexed to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement EC/Algeria (in force since 2005). Parliament's green light will allow Algeria to take part in twenty EU programmes such as COSME (SMEs), Horizon 2020 (research) and Creative Europe (culture and media).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this agreement, which sets out the general principles for the participation of the Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. This agreement is an integral part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which is based on the principle of mutual benefit. On the one hand, the European Union opens up opportunities for Algeria to gradually participate in EU programmes, on the other hand, only through reforms within the country, thereby ensuring a secure neighbourhood.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The gradual opening of some European Union (EU) programmes and agencies to the participation of member countries in the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) is one of many measures to promote the EU in supporting reforms, modernisation and democratic transition processes in its neighbouring regions. In 2007, the European Council instructed the European Commission to negotiate Agreements with EU neighbouring countries, of which Algeria was a part. The Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, contains general principles for the participation of Algeria in EU programmes, which require the adoption of financial and technical rules for their integration. These programmes will establish economic, financial and technical cooperation measures with a view to facilitating, in particular financial assistance, to Algeria. I voted in favour of this report approving the protocol concluded between the EU and Algeria, given that all the legal and regulatory criteria inherent in this decision are met.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, for which I am shadow rapporteur for the EPP, which gives the approval of the European Parliament and invites the Council to approve the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Algeria, of the other part, on an agreement. framework between the EU and Algeria on the general principles of the country's participation in European programmes, on behalf of the Union. Within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies to ENP partner countries is one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the EU's neighbouring countries. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. The aim is to strengthen economic, financial and technical cooperation which allows access to assistance, particularly financial, to be provided by the Union under European programmes.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish for the EU to get involved in foreign affairs.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this protocol, the objective is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. This is a technical report, which contains standard clauses that are intended to be applied to all European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries with which such protocols are concluded.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. “I voted in favour of this resolution. Algeria is an important country for achieving the goal of curbing migration across the central Mediterranean, which is now a major migration route. In the Framework Partnership Agreement with third countries adopted in June this year, Algeria was identified as one of 16 “priority” countries with which the European Commission wants to conclude contracts. The EU wants to work with Algeria to prevent migration and reception of deportees. At the same time, the EU wants to provide various assistance to Algeria, such as development aid and trade with it, and participation in its programmes. Algeria had already shown an interest in participating in a wide range of programmes open to EU partner countries in 2013.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. — I supported the conclusion of the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement, as I am pleased with Algeria's interest in participating in Union programmes. Similar framework agreements have been concluded by the EU with several neighbouring countries. Algeria is joining the so-called European Neighbourhood Policy by this Framework Agreement. This will gradually open up space for cooperation with the Member States of the Union through European programmes and agencies. For the countries of the European Neighbourhood, this policy is one of the tools that allows them to implement reforms and modernise the country in their society. The protocol that we have approved with Algeria contains general principles on the basis of which Algeria's participation in Union programmes will be guided. Since it is a protocol containing standard clauses already used in other similar framework agreements, its implementation should be smooth. This horizontal agreement, which brings economic, financial and technical cooperation, should gradually make Algeria accessible to European citizens. The mutual exchange, which thus has the potential to arise, will certainly benefit both sides.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. — It is crucial for Europe's security that the region of North Africa is economically and politically stabilised. Thanks to the European Union's assistance, Morocco has managed to stabilise after the unrest. We are now offering the same assistance to Algeria, which is also an important partner for us in diversifying energy sources.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - The European Parliament resolution on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in the Union's programmes. The EU should not pursue foreign policy in its current state, should not associate itself with North African countries, nor should it lay the foundations for other States to participate in its programmes.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. — The Foreign Affairs Committee adopted a proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Algerian Republic, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria The Republic on the general principles of participation of the Algerian Republic in Union programmes. The aim is to establish financial and technical rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol represents a measure of economic, financial and technical cooperation and enables the receipt of assistance, in particular financial assistance, to be provided by the European Union in accordance with the programmes. This framework applies only to those Union programmes for which the relevant constituent legal acts provide for the possibility of participation of Algeria. The signing and interim application of the Protocol, therefore, does not imply the exercise of powers on the basis of the various sectoral policies exercised by the programmes which are exercised in the establishment of the programme. I support this Report because I believe this is one of a number of measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in neighbouring European Union countries.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EU and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. I support cooperation between the European Union and the countries in the EU neighbourhood, which, in my view, will contribute to promoting reform, modernisation and transition in countries. Algeria's participation in certain Union programmes will thus help modernise the country itself in all areas. Especially when we talk about programs that provide access to financial assistance.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - In February 2013, Algeria showed an interest in participating in the EU's general programmes open to the partner countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. As AKEL, we have strong concerns about these agreements, as through them the EU imposes economic obligations on states by imposing relationships of dependence in the context of neoliberal policies. It is for these reasons that we abstained.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament, on a proposal from the Council, giving its consent to the Protocol to the Convention in the framework of Euro-Mediterranean Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of Algeria a framework agreement which allows and regulates the participation of Algeria in the various programmes operated by the European Union and at the level of the principles. I have taken into account that this will not only fulfill the necessary legal adaptation as a result of the Treaty of Lisbon, but will also help the Algerian economy and society to make better use of the cooperation within the framework of EuroMed for the development and democratisation of the country opportunities with the EU and its Member States. In the current precarious political situation of the Maghreb countries and the EU's entire Mediterranean neighbourhood, I consider that closer links of this kind to be useful for the stability of the region and for the security of the EU.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - The European Union supports cooperation with the countries of North Africa, a very important area in its southern neighbourhood. Algeria is one of the countries of this region, which can play a significant role in the current conditions, both in the Mediterranean and in the wider Middle East. Through the Neighbourhood Policy, the EU has supported a close relationship with the country, which has made significant progress in respect of democratic standards and human rights, although it still has enough problems to deal with internally. However, in the context of the volatile situation in Libya and the migrant crisis at EU level, achieving an extensive partnership with Algeria, which is already an important economic partner of the Union, in particular in the field of energy, would be an important advantage. A first step in this direction is the signing of the framework agreement in order to allow the Algerian State access to Union programmes. This would encourage the progress of democratic reforms in Algeria, would benefit Algerian citizens and would also lead to a reduction in illegal immigration to EU Member States on the Algerian route. In these circumstances, I believe that this is an important step forward, which takes into account the immediate interests of the Union. For these reasons, I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, as regards a framework agreement between the European Union and People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles of the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. Mr. Panzeri's proposal is a good one.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes is a tool to strengthen the relationship between the EU and Algeria in areas including politics, the economy, trade, cooperation and humanitarian aid. I voted in favour of the report on the Association between the EU and Algeria, as Algeria represents a key strategic and economic partner for the EU and both parties will stand to largely benefit from closer and more comprehensive ties.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. — The EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Pier Antonio Panzeri Union programmes (A8-0367⁄2016) I support the Motion for a resolution on the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement on the general principles of Algeria's participation in Union programmes. That proposal is in accordance with Article 218. (6) The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union where consent is given to conclude the protocol. Back in 2007, the Council issued guidelines for agreements with a number of EP countries, and Algeria expressed its openness to European Neighbourhood Policy in February 2013. I believe that the achievement of the Framework Agreement represents the strategic interest of the European Union and that it is necessary to establish the general principles that will be guided by the Union in the integration of Algeria in Union programmes.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I supported the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Union and Algeria on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria laying down financial and technical rules allowing Algeria to participate in certain European Union programmes. This will define economic, financial and technical cooperation measures and allow the European Union humanitarian assistance to be provided to Algeria in accordance with the programmes envisaged. I believe that the conclusion of this Protocol is a good step towards improving relations between the European Union and Algeria and that this cooperation will affect the further progress of Algeria and the implementation of much-needed reforms. The conclusion of an agreement with Algeria is also one of a number of measures to promote modernisation and transition in neighbouring European Union countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - Draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and I supported the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP-European neighbourhood policy), the gradual opening of certain Union programmes and agencies for partner countries' cooperation is one of the tools to promote reform, modernisation and transition. In 2013, Algeria showed interest in participating in a wide range of programmes, to open up to European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In this report, the European Parliament allows itself to decide on how Algeria should participate financially in European Union programmes. The interference is complete, it is up to Algeria alone to decide whether or not it wishes to participate in European Union programmes, and to decide how it wishes to intervene with its own money and that of its citizens. The European Union cannot substitute for States in international relations with their extra money. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. — In my assessment, the existing relationship is sufficient and gives Algeria the opportunity to enjoy convenient economic cooperation with the EU. So I was against agreeing to a new deal.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. — According to the proposal, the European Parliament agrees with the conclusion of the Protocol and instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council, the Commission and to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria. I followed S&D's position by Voksom.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution establishing the possible participation of Algeria in cooperation programmes between the Union and neighbouring countries. The programmes in question should be agreed on a case-by-case basis. I considered that it should accept the resolution, as it was a request from the Algerian Government and not to determine in principle the nature of the programmes.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of  giving my consent for the EU-Algeria Framework Agreement to allow Algeria to participate in the Union programmes.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Algeria to participate in certain Union programmes. I voted in favour because I believe that the horizontal framework established by the Protocol constitutes an economic, financial and technical cooperation measure which gives Algeria access to assistance, in particular financial assistance, to be provided by the Union pursuant to the Union programmes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. ‒ As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the gradual opening of certain European programmes to the participation of countries entering the Union's area of influence represents one of many measures effectively employed to promote reforms, modernisation and transition in our environment immediate. Framework agreements were negotiated in 2007 with a number of neighbouring countries, including Algeria. Later, in 2013, Algeria expressed interest in participating in a wide range of NPA programmes. Wishing to help Community tools enable third party societies to advance and develop in regions as important to European stability and security as North Africa, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. ‒ Algeria and the Union have been participating in a Euro-Mediterranean Agreement since 2005. In 2013, Algeria expressed its interest in expanding its participation in programmes to which it would have consequently access, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Today's report opens the door for such participation to become effective, in the terms freely negotiated by Algeria and the European Commission. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. — The new European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) towards “a Changing Neighbourhood” was theoretically designed to provide more assistance to partners working to deepen and better guarantee democracy, the rule of law and human rights. The level of EU support to partners must change in line with progress made in “political reforms and deepening democracy”. Algeria has chosen to join the ENP and this protocol follows both for the Euro-Mediterranean agreement and for access to European programmes stricto sensu. It is therefore difficult to judge its relevance from both the EU and Algeria's point of view. However, I voted in favour, considering that this was a strictly technical agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This Recommendation sets out a set of general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes. Algeria has been part of the EU Mediterranean Agreement since 2005 and has now asked the European Union to be part of Union programmes. The programmes contained in the Protocol concern economic, financial and technical cooperation, which will enable Algeria to access assistance and in particular financial assistance to be provided by the Union through its programmes. Algeria may participate in Union programmes open to its participation and should contribute to the Union budget in the specific programmes in which Algeria will participate. The specific terms of the Protocol will be determined in a Memorandum of Understanding between the European Commission and the Algerian authorities. This is a request from Algeria. With doubts about the nature and implications of these agreements, the sovereign will of Algeria and its government prevails above all.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: in writing. - This is a Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an Association with regard to a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Algeria. The agreements are intended to establish free trade in accordance with WTO rules, with a transitional period of up to 12 years for the tariff reduction of the industrial partners. These agreements, which already include provisions to liberalise trade in goods, are complemented by a number of additional negotiations to further liberalise trade in agricultural products, services and investment and to establish a dispute settlement procedure for trade issues. As this framework agreement, which is financed by EU direct investment, will lead to a wide market opening between Algeria and the Member States of the EU and the opening up of Algeria to EU programmes, I believe that this report should be rejected.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. “The Association Agreement between the EU and Algeria was concluded in 2005 as part of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership which is the southern dimension of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Thanks to this agreement, the estimated EU aid for Algeria under the European Neighbourhood Instrument in 2014-2020 will be between 221 and 270 million euros. These measures are directed at EU programmes based on the following pillars: reform of the justice system and increasing the participation of citizens in public, economic affairs and labour market reform. First of all, however, the Union should take the first pillar as a priority given that the already so-called Arab Spring has shown unequivocal opposition by citizens to authoritarian leaders in the states of the region. As a result, it is crucial that, under the current agreement, the EU focuses on supporting democracy in Algeria, because in the long term, democratic countries are simply proving to be more stable countries. For it is important to remember that the civil wars in Libya and Syria are just under the civil protests of the Arab Spring. Given these conflicts taking place in our close vicinity, it is crucial for the Union's security that Algeria gradually becomes democratised and remains stable. I have therefore expressed my support for this recommendation in this vote.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the legislative proposal for the conclusion of the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the EU and Algeria. Algeria is a major regional player, particularly in energy production. That is why it is in the interest of the Union and its Member States to promote deeper cooperation through various programmes focusing on political and socioeconomic reforms and the fight against corruption. This agreement is part of the broader European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Already in 2007, the Council issued a regulation to the Commission to negotiate a legal framework for agreements with ENP countries, including Algeria. Subsequently, in February 2013, Algeria expressed an interest in actively participating in a wide range of programmes intended for these countries. Algeria will now join most southern partners who have already signed similar agreements with the EU. This will strengthen cooperation and the development of a democratic society, as well as promote economic integration and education.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I support the Framework Agreement presented on Algeria's participation in EU programmes. There is a need for African countries to strengthen their competitiveness, to improve the entrepreneurial middle and also the political culture in the country. Moreover, the European Union is Algeria's main trading partner, which is why Algeria should be able to participate in EU programmes. I am confident that this agreement will help improve both the economic and political situation in Algeria.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. — I supported the recommendation on the proposal for the conclusion of a protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part. This Protocol concerns the general principles for the participation of Algeria in Union programmes, the principles concerned in particular the technical and financial conditions for Algeria's participation in those programmes. I think that Algeria's participation in European Union programmes will help this country implement democratic reforms and modernise overall. And since all this is an objective of the European Neighbourhood Policy, I had no reservations about the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the effort, on the one hand, of the Algerian Democratic Republic to join the European Union programmes, and on the other hand certainly the European Union itself which has enabled it. It is therefore a recommendation from Pier Antonio Panzeri. It is understood that part of the European Neighbourhood Policy is the gradual opening of EU programmes and agencies to the possible participation of ENP-partner countries with the aim of promoting and ensuring reform, modernisation and transition in the neighbourhood of the European Union. Since Algeria has long shown, already in 2013, the interest of participating in the programs of the European Union, agreements began. Following the approval of the European Union Protocol itself, further objectives were to provide financial assistance, but also to set technical and financial rules. Algeria decided on an important move. We could conclude that this is a small but important step in the relationship both with the European Union itself and its Member States. By joining the Union's programmes, Algeria will thrive, both financially and politically and diplomatically. In this way, many doors open to him lightly.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the People's the democratic Republic of Algeria on the general principles for the participation of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in Union programmes. I support the approval of the conclusion of the Protocol as it is a continuation of the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This policy comprises political coordination and closer economic integration, increased mobility and interpersonal contacts. Promoting sustainable democracy and inclusive economic development prevents dividing lines between the EU and its neighbours and enhances prosperity, stability and security for all.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: — The seas are large and the oceans are deep. But the bottom has been reached. An estimated ten million species of plants and animals live in our oceans, and many of these species have not even been discovered yet. They live right on or right above the seabed, in the deep sea. This deep sea starts at 200 meters and contains beautiful coral reefs. Some of them are more than 35 meters high. The oldest are about 8500 years old and there are fish that can live up to 150 years old without human intervention. And these beautiful fish are ground into cheap fodder and fish oil. Where do we get the right to wipe these unique species out of this unique ecosystem with monstrously large towed nets in one fell swoop? That's not fishing, it's ocean vandalism! And international waters have hardly any rules. The fish have been declared outlaw and with difficulty, after years of discussions, there is now a half-hearted plan to combat this ecocide. But again, the law of the strongest outweighs the interests of the weakest. Europe considers its heavily subsidised fishing vessels to be more important than protecting vulnerable ecosystems and, contrary to scientific advice, this proposal also allows towed nets below or up to 800 metres deep. Only the deepest seabeds are slightly better protected and that is a cloth for bleeding. It is with pain in my heart that I shall vote in favour of this proposal because without this plan the seabed is completely at the mercy of the vandals of deep-sea fishing. I also believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, there is a multiple award-winning documentary by Richard O’Donnell called Atlantic that has been described as a wake-up call, as chilling as a bucket of ice-cold sea water over the head. Filmed through the eyes of small fishing communities in three countries, Ireland, Norway and Canada, it addresses exactly this issue, deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters. Every Member of this House should make it their business to learn of the situation with regard to Irish fishing waters from which much of that stock has been taken. Would the French government gift 75% of its wine production to the EU? Would the Netherlands gift 75% of its agricultural production? I doubt it. In 1973, when Ireland joined the EU, that is exactly what the Irish Government did. It gifted 75% of our stocks to the EU. And here is the rub. Ireland has never been credited for this value, estimated by Dr Karen Devine to be worth in excess of 200 billion from 1973 to 2012. As one of the fishermen said in the film, there is something wrong here. He could have said more. There is something really wrong here and it has got to change: otherwise we have got to get out of this rotten Union.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, of course comrade Flanagan is exactly right, both about the problem and the possible solution – as the United Kingdom is about to demonstrate – which makes me wonder why we are pushing through plans for the revision of the CFP in the North Sea when the area covered by it territorially is about to shrink by around half. Of course, when the United Kingdom resumes control of its maritime resources out to 200 miles of the median line, we will want in a phased way –with the agreement of our European partners – to move to a system of national control. We should not behave precipitately, but we can at least take back control in the way that Norway, Iceland and other countries that have pursued successful conservation take for granted. You will find that, instead of being constantly bickering tenants, we will become good and responsible neighbours.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, I seem to be following three in agreement, as Mr Flanagan, Mr Hannan and I all agree that it is best for the people of Britain and our fishing industries to leave the European Union, which has just taken our stocks, taken our jobs and in effect taken our income. And as Mr Hannan has said, and Mr Flanagan has repeated, one of the important parts of leaving the European Union in our referendum was that we could take control of our laws, take control of our borders, take control of our trade, but more importantly take control of our fishing industries. Go back to our 200-mile limit. Create jobs once more on the coastlines that desperately need it. Create income for our nation once more and ensure that in our new Brexit future at this Christmas we have a star above our people who have a fishing industry that becomes alive. And that is why we should continue to champion taking control of all our fisheries from this Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report in light of the specific and crucial regulation and that it clarifies in the sphere of fishing international waters. From an Irish perspective, I can appreciate that the advancement of the economic viability of the fishing sector has a profound effect on the livelihoods of fishing communities across the EU. Moreover, it is increasingly important that we identify species and ecosystems that are vulnerable to over-exploitation, thus establishing and clarifying a sustainable level of fishing for all Member States. Regular assessment, reinforcement of current and future sanctions, and promotion of greater transparency do prove vital to safeguarding of deep-sea stocks and regulation of fishing activities in the EU. I also urge colleagues, like my colleague Mr Flanagan, to look at the film The Atlantic, a wonderful production, but I would not draw the same conclusions. I do not think that we should be leaving the European Union, but I will let Members look at it and then come to their own conclusions because there are very important messages in it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ Despite a long time discussing deep sea, we have only come to the vote now. The dossier proposes lowering the limit within which trawling can be carried out, intensify controls on board vessels and increase transparency regulation. It is very important that institutions are committed to protecting and preserving our seas, so I voted negatively to the rejection amendment.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation for second reading as it ensures, to the greatest extent possible, the sustainable exploitation of deep-sea stocks while reducing the environmental impact of these fisheries. The agreement reached maintains the ban on trawling beyond 800 metres only for Community waters, an important aspect in ensuring equal opportunities for Community fishermen in external waters. On the other hand, one of the most controversial aspects of this dossier, the coverage of observers on board, has been resolved thanks to the fact that the European Parliament has lowered its request from 100% to 20% for vessels targeting deep species, both in Community waters and in the waters of NEAFC (North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission), including flexibilities when managing this coverage. Deepwater fisheries in the North-East Atlantic are dominated, in part, by traditional coastal fleets (Portugal) and partly by large roaders (France, Spain). While as a whole they account for approximately 1 per cent of landings from the North-East Atlantic, the economic viability of certain fishing communities depends to some extent on these fisheries.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I vote against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading, because I consider it positive that the deep-sea fishing footprint should be frozen and specific sanctions are stipulated for vessels that do not comply with the rules. Parliament and Council negotiating teams reached agreement on the Commission proposal on 30 June 2016, establishing a depth limit of 800 metres for trawling, which is intended to ensure the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. Also good news is the obligation of vessels to leave fishing areas over 400 metres deep when they are in vulnerable ecosystems. The new transparency rules on deep-sea fishing activity and its impact, as well as the introduction of scientific observers on board 20% of vessels should also serve to advance in this same direction. That is why I do not support the amendment which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted against the amendment of the European Group of Freedom and Direct Democracy, proposing to reject the Council's position submitted to Parliament. The amendment was rejected by a majority, and the Council's position was adopted without a separate vote. I support the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the deep-sea stocks and their fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic, paying attention to its positive aspects: the European Union will freeze the fishing impact indicator by identifying the zones in which the deep-sea fishing. This geographical limitation will apply to deep-sea vessels and specific sanctions will be imposed on vessels that violate the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation. Among other things, the report introduces new stricter transparency rules, including the obligation to publicly provide information on European vessels fishing for deep-sea fish and record all catches, i.e. fish and vulnerable ecosystems. Member States will also have to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessment), and the European Commission will assess these data each year and then adjust the area where fishing is allowed. I voted in favour of the provisions aimed at better protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems of the seabed.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is deep-sea fishing in the North-East Atlantic, which is mainly practised by traditional coastal fleets (Portugal) and large nomadic trawlers (France, Spain). It is practiced in Union waters and in international waters governed by agreements within the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). Measures taken so far have not resolved overfishing due to the high vulnerability of these stocks. Some of them can no longer withstand fishing pressure and their replenishment can be very long, if not impossible. Bottom trawls damage vulnerable and irreplaceable marine ecosystems, and trawling of deep-sea species leads to high levels of bycatch. The new regulation provides for more stringent regulations: a ban on trawling below 800 metres deep, freeze the footprint (mandatory for vessels to fish only in areas already operated between 2009 and 2011), strengthening on-board controls and penalties and greater transparency of activity. In favour of this regulation, I voted against the amendment rejecting it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the Council position on North East Atlantic arrangements because I believe the UK should have the sovereign right to govern its territorial waters without further EU interference.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on deep-sea stocks and their fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. We must strive for the success of the fisheries sector. I agree with the need to carry out regular assessments, to provide for appropriate sanctions and to ensure transparency in order to protect fisheries activities in the European Union.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — This proposal for a regulation aims to tighten the conditions of deep-sea and international fishing, since the current regulations do not guarantee sustainable and reasonable fishing capable of protecting extremely fragile ecosystems. French jobs will not be affected because it is a sector from which our companies are absent. I voted against rejecting the proposal.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which, at second reading, recommends approval of the Council's position at first reading without amendment. In accordance with this text, the Union will freeze the fishing footprint by defining the area in which deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised. This area covers the area where fishing took place between 2009 and 2011 in the European waters of the North-East Atlantic. Parliament has also secured specific penalties for vessels violating the deep-sea fishing regulation.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. ‒ Deep-sea fishing is a major challenge to the sustainability of our seas. I am fully in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: In writing. ‒ Technological development has greatly changed the methods and forms of fisheries, an activity that can now involve areas until a few years ago unthinkable and have a strong impact on the environment and on biodiversity. The Thomas report, which I supported today, sets out specific conditions for fishing for North East Atlantic deepwater stocks aimed at protecting marine ecosystems particularly vulnerable, characterized by the presence of longeve species, with slow growth and very advanced breeding periods over time. With this perspective, Member States will be asked to provide data on the location of vulnerable ecosystems which the Commission will then have to assess in order to define the authorised fishing areas. The central points of the report are transparency and data collection, the obligation of the presence of scientific observers on ships and the recording of catches. Several penalties are established and a new bathymetric limit of 800 meters is set. Deep fishing is allowed only in the area exploited by fishing vessels in the period 2009-2011.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I understand the Recommendation as positive, either because of increased levels of transparency, such as the control of high-impact fisheries, or because the depth limit above 800 metres is ensured, except for vulnerable marine ecosystems, where a limit should be placed 400 meters.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report and therefore against the rejection amendment concerning the regulation of deep-sea fishing, particularly in the North-East Atlantic. This fishery has been regulated since 2003, but the regulations in force do not solve the problems of overfishing due in particular to the high vulnerability of the stocks. In addition, bottom trawls damage vulnerable and irreplaceable marine ecosystems, and trawling of deep-sea species leads to high levels of bycatch. Finally, while previously we could worry about the impact on employment in France of the ban on deep-sea fishing, the problem does not arise in the same way since Scapêche, the only French operator in this sector, is gradually withdrawing from deep-sea fishing under pressure from environmental organisations.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: ‒ The measure is very technical and although it may be shared in general, it contains some prescriptions that may open to future critical issues at the application stage. For this reason I preferred to express myself with an abstention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal for a regulation is generally aimed at ensuring the sustainable exploitation of deep-sea stocks, reducing the environmental impact of these fisheries, and improving the information base for scientific assessments. This is the result of an intense negotiation with the Council, which comes from the previous legislature. The European Union shall freeze the 'fishing footprint 'in the area in accordance with a general bathymetric limit set at 800 metres, satisfactory to industry and which in turn ensures the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. In addition, more stringent standards are laid down on transparency, a fair sanctions system for non-compliance and ensuring the presence of scientific observers in 20 per cent of vessels. In short, this is a good regulation for fisheries sustainability in the deep waters of the North-East Atlantic, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation on deep-sea stocks and their fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The text of the Agreement was submitted to a vote in the Committee on Fisheries on 12 July 2016 and approved by a large majority. Since the position of the Council at first reading is in line with the agreement reached during the trialogue meetings, the rapporteur of the European Parliament proposes that the committee approve it without further amendments. The main aspects of this compromise would be that the European Union will freeze the fishing impact indicator by identifying the zones in which deep-sea fishing will be authorised. This zone covers the area where targeted fishing took place in the North-East Atlantic waters belonging to Europe between 2009 and 2011. This geographical limitation will apply to deep-sea vessels, i.e. vessels whose deep-sea catches represent more than 8% of their total catches during at least one fishing trip per year. In addition, the European Parliament has reached the introduction of specific sanctions on vessels that violate the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation and that a number of control rules are not exempted. The negotiators of the Parliament and the Council agreed to set a batimetric limit of 800 m. The aim of this new provision is to improve the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems of the seabed.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. - I support this Report which is a compromise text on fishing in the high seas in the north-east Atlantic. This Report provides conditions for preventing significant negative impacts on sensitive marine ecosystems: deep-sea fisheries will be restricted to the area from 2009 to 2011; vessels will be required to report encounters with sensitive marine ecosystems below 400 metres. Furthermore, scientific observation coverage increases by 20%, specific sanctions are being put in place, better conditions to improve data collection and transparency is strengthened.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — Protecting deep ecosystems and safeguarding fish stocks require us to take more and more stringent measures and more effective control. Since this report goes in this direction, and since the measures recommended will not harm employment in France, I voted in favour of this report and against the rejection amendment.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted against the proposal to reject the Council’s position. I supported this report because the European Parliament has secured a commitment to implement sanctions for vessels violating the regulation on deep-sea fishing and a stipulation that no exemptions will be granted to certain rules. There is agreement that there will be no bottom trawling below the depth of 800m. This new measure is intended to protect vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems more effectively. This is a positive step as bottom trawlers drag huge, weighted nets along the deep seafloor, devastating ecosystems, including corals and sponges that have flourished for thousands of years. Vessels found to be fishing in vulnerable marine ecosystems (VMEs) at a depth in excess of 400 metres will have to stop their operations and move. New, stricter transparency rules have also been introduced that include requirements to make information available to the public on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems).

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - Current regulations provide for restrictive technical measures against certain fishing gear and prohibits deep-sea fishing in certain areas. However, these restrictions are insufficient to ensure sustainable and protective fisheries for these particularly fragile ecosystems. This proposal for a regulation aims to tighten the current legislation, notably by prohibiting trawling below 800 metres deep and by strengthening controls and penalties. We believe that this report will contribute to protecting marine resources and limiting environmental damage without threatening employment in France, since Scapêche, the sole operator in this sector, is gradually withdrawing from deep-sea fishing. That is why I voted in favour of this text and objected to the rejection amendment.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - Deep fishing in the North-East Atlantic has developed at an accelerated pace, amid unsustainable practices and overfishing on the continental shelf. This rapid development has occurred without relying on comprehensive information on the state of deep-sea fish stocks, the level of discards or the effects on marine ecosystems caused by this fishing activity. As a result, this proposal aims to address the two main problems of this type of fishing, namely: high vulnerability of deep-sea fish stocks and lack of data on deep-sea fish stocks. It therefore envisages the collection of comprehensive data on the state of fish stocks and the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems at the seabed. I have spoken in favour of this proposal because I consider it essential to promote sustainable development in marine ecosystems, precisely in order to protect marine diversity and deep-sea species.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation for second reading as it ensures, to the greatest extent possible, the sustainable exploitation of deep-sea stocks while reducing the environmental impact of these fisheries. The agreement reached maintains the ban on trawling beyond 800 metres only for Community waters, an important aspect in ensuring equal opportunities for Community fishermen in external waters. On the other hand, one of the most controversial aspects of this dossier, the coverage of observers on board, has been resolved thanks to the fact that the European Parliament has lowered its request from 100% to 20% for vessels targeting deep species, both in Community waters and in the waters of NEAFC (North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission), including flexibilities when managing this coverage. Deepwater fisheries in the North-East Atlantic are dominated, in part, by traditional coastal fleets (Portugal) and partly by large roaders (France, Spain). While as a whole they account for approximately 1 per cent of landings from the North-East Atlantic, the economic viability of certain fishing communities depends to some extent on these fisheries.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this balanced report, which preserves both the marine environment and deep-water species, but also helps to strengthen the sustainability of fisheries. We have sought and obtained an economically and ecologically sustainable and deeply European agreement. I am delighted that incidental fishing is allowed up to 11.5 tonnes per year while being supervised and controlled. Fishing for deep-sea species is now prohibited beyond 800 metres deep and vessels must avoid vulnerable marine ecosystems between 0 and 400 metres deep. The presence of observers on board vessels allows the collection of data relevant to the knowledge of very slow-ripening species. The implementation of this text helps to reduce the impact of this fishery on the seabed while preserving the sustainable fishing activity necessary for our European market and for employment in coastal areas.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions relating to fishing in the international waters of Northeast Atlantic. It is essential to ensure the sustainable exploitation of deepwater stocks, reducing the environmental impact of this type of fisheries, and to improve the information base required for evaluation scientific. The adopted regulation goes precisely in this direction. The European Union will freeze the fishing footprint by defining the area where deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised. This area includes one where targeted fishing was carried out between 2009 and 2011 in European waters of the Northwest Atlantic. In addition, specific penalties have been introduced for vessels violating the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation and excluding derogations for control rules.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement reached over this file and therefore voted against an EFDD amendment to reject the text. My rationale for supporting this file was that the negotiations secured sanctions for vessels violating the Regulation on Deep-Sea Fishing and a stipulation that no exemptions would be granted to certain rules. Inter-institutional negotiations agreed that there should be no bottom trawling below the depth of 800m, which should ensure protection for vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems more effectively.  New transparency rules will also be introduced that include requirements to make information available to the public on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report all catches. This will result in enabling allowed fishing areas to be adapted.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – We supported rejection as these plans attempt to tie up arrangements in the North-East Atlantic in a manner which is damaging to the interests of the UK after we leave the European Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it bans bottom trawling targeting deep-water species at depths of more than 800 metres. This new provision will protect the vulnerable marine ecosystems of the deep sea bed. Provisions such as recording all catches are also included. This will improve monitoring of these fishing activities. Member States will also be required to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems and the Commission will assess this data annually and adapt the allowed fishing area accordingly.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: In writing. ‒ The text, which comes to approval at second reading after three years of negotiation, has important and positive elements. Among them: a ban on trawling under 800 metres (limit that passes to 400 meters in the case of areas with particularly sensitive ecosystems), increased controls and environmental protection, more Stringent rules of transparency. I undoubtedly voted for it.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: In writing. ‒ Ecosystems and deepwater species are very vulnerable to fishing and increasingly at risk: deep-sea species are characterized by weak biological productivity, the implying that they can only sustain low levels of exploitation. There are clear European obligations for the protection of such species and for the defence of the seabed, obligations that member countries are called upon to comply strictly. The report, for which I felt I voted in favour, has the merit of introducing specific penalties for vessels which violate the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation and the merit of dictating new provisions in order to better protect the seabed. In this regard, I believe that the new rules for the registration of all deepwater catches can provide a guarantee of transparency of the work on fishing vessels and that the involvement of Scientific observers on vessels can not only ensure a fruitful collection of scientific data, but also strengthen the link between research and fish companies.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are voting against the report, as it contains several points with which we disagree.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the proposal to reject the recommendation establishing special conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions concerning fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. As I believe that the recommendation contains positive elements that act in the interests of the environment and economic activities related to fisheries, I voted against the motion for rejection.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: In writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of a new regulation since it is necessary to establish effective measures to resolve the vulnerability of stocks and establish a level of fishing Sustainable habitat protection and reduction of unwanted bycatch throughout the North East Atlantic. In particular, I fully agree with the introduction of the absolute ban on fishing beyond the bathymetric limit of 800 metres by virtue of the fact that deep-sea fishing involves the scraping of the seabed. What is more, it has as its main objective of fish species with slow growth and high vulnerability, so I hope that such a provision can be decisive. Likewise, I approve the advertising requirement for deep fishery vessels, i.e. for which this activity accounts for more than 8% of the total catch in at least one exit during the course of the year. It is therefore essential not only to establish a catch register, but also the commitment of Member States to geographically delimit areas where deep fishing is permitted and to provide data and impact studies related to ecosystem vulnerability.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on North-East Atlantic: deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters. I support establishing specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. I support banning bottom trawling targeting deep-water species which are mainly slow-growing and at risk of over-exploitation. I rejected the proposal to reject the Council position.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We supported rejection as these plans attempt to tie up arrangements in the north east Atlantic in a manner which is damaging to the interests of the UK after we leave the European Union.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because the main purpose of the proposal is to establish specific conditions for fishing for stocks in the deep waters of the North East Atlantic and to regulate fisheries in international waters of the Northeast Atlantic through specific provisions. This new provision will be able to protect vulnerable marine ecosystems found at sea deep, ensuring more sustainable fishing and decreasing the catch of unwanted fish.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I vote against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading, because I consider it positive that the deep-sea fishing footprint should be frozen and specific sanctions are stipulated for vessels that do not comply with the rules. Parliament and Council negotiating teams reached agreement on the Commission proposal on 30 June 2016, establishing a depth limit of 800 metres for trawling, which is intended to ensure the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. Also good news is the obligation of vessels to leave fishing areas over 400 metres deep when they are in vulnerable ecosystems. The new transparency rules on deep-sea fishing activity and its impact, as well as the introduction of scientific observers on board 20% of vessels should also serve to advance in this same direction. That is why I do not support the amendment which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — The concern for the protection and inviolability of the riches of Atlantic waters is immeasurably close to me. The EU has a sizeable deep-sea fishing fleet fishing in the deep sea zone. In the course of research, deep-sea fisheries (particularly using bottom trawlers) have been shown to irreversibly destroy the seabed and organisms found there, among others, corals, sponges colonies and ecosystems of underwater mountains. The agreement reached between the EU and the main participants in the deep-sea fisheries market allows solutions to contribute to the protection of ocean wealth into the regulation. The Regulation introduces, inter alia, a ban on bottom-trawling fishing and establishing a geographical area of impact for vessels so that they can only fish in areas where they were previously fished. Implementation of the principle of distancing the vessel — if sensitive marine ecosystems are discovered, vessels are not allowed to use fishing equipment. I believe that the strengthening of control measures should be sought to ensure compliance with the rules by all parties. Nevertheless, I cannot agree with the EFFD's proposal in favour of rejecting the Council's position. I voted against the motion with a view to protecting the waters of the Atlantic.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Fishing stocks need to be conserved, and thus I am in favour of this recommendation as it enables the Union to freeze its fishing footprint by specifying areas that allow deep-sea fishing. This compromise is also in line with the CFP reform and thus ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this report ending deep sea trawling, which strikes the right balance between measures to conserve and protect the seabed whilst not imposing overly complex and expensive burdens on the fishing industry.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: This legislative report proposes to establish specific conditions for the fishing of deep-sea stocks in the international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The aim of this text is to ensure better management of fish stocks in this region, whose turnover rate is particularly vulnerable to overexploitation. As such, it prohibits bottom trawling at a depth of more than 800 metres. At the same time, although deep-sea fisheries account for only about 1% of Atlantic landings, many professionals rely on this type of fishery to maintain their activity. Considering that a balanced support for the positions defended by my group has been found, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ We supported rejection as these plans attempt to tie up arrangements in the north east Atlantic in a manner which is damaging to the interests of the UK after we leave the European Union.

name: Rachida DATI
text: I have approved the regulation laying down specific conditions for the fishing of deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic as well as provisions for fishing in the international waters of the North-East Atlantic. Deep-sea fishing, if uncontrolled, poses a significant risk to the sustainable management of fish stocks. That is why we have adopted this regulation which controls deep-sea fishing by subjecting it to authorizations, prohibiting fishing to more than 800 metres deep, delineating the areas in which it can be practised and by imposing an increased presence of scientific observers on board vessels.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Deep waters are the largest ecosystem on the planet, but also one of the most sensitive ecosystem. Deep trawling is a fishing method that destroys deep-sea waters. Equipped with metal plates, the nets plow the seabed, crushing and deteriorating ecosystems that take several thousand years to rebuild. To combat this scourge, the Union has just approved a total ban on fishing below 800 metres in European waters. This decision is a first at the global level. It is vital for the balance of the seas and for the very equilibrium of fishing — especially for small-scale, artisanal and coastal fishing — to allow the renewal of these resources. These are a common good, which must be preserved. This decision is therefore excellent news.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report and against the amendment to reject it. Deep sea fishing is carried out in European Union waters and international waters governed by agreements within the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). In the European Union, this fishery has been regulated since 2003. These regulations, which often include technical measures such as the ban on gillnets, have not resolved the issue of overfishing. In addition, bottom trawls damage ecosystems, with 20 -40% of incidental catches. The new regulatory proposal is therefore more stringent. It provides, inter alia, for the prohibition of trawling below 800 metres deep and the strengthening of on-board controls and penalties.
