Initially in favour of deep-sea fishing due to the jobs concerned, the National Front notes the gradual withdrawal of the only French company active in this sector of activity. We have no reason to support this practice, which causes certain environmental problems.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The text proposed by the Commission is the recommendation for second reading and concerns the European Union's intention to clarify in which area of the North-East Atlantic deep-sea fishing will be permitted. This geographical limit will apply to vessels whose more than 8% of the total catch on at least one fishing trip per year consists of deep-sea species. Member States will be invited to provide information on the geographical location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessments), and the Commission will evaluate these data annually and adjust the authorised fishing area accordingly. The EFDD amendment rejects this proposal. It is considered, however, that it was submitted purely in the interests of the United Kingdom and not in the protection of fish.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on deep sea stocks and fishing in international waters in the North-East Atlantic to protect vulnerable ecosystems from destructive fishing practices and overfishing. Wales has a unique and treasured coastline and protecting our natural assets is essential to our economy as well as our environment.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which puts clear and stringent stakes to limit the damage of trawling by banning it below 800 metres deep, a limit rising to 400 meters in the case of areas with particularly sensitive ecosystems. The protection of marine environments, due to their fragility and delicacy, is of particular importance especially for areas still little known as the seabed and the deep waters.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The proposal provides for new rules for the fishing of deep-sea species in the North-East Atlantic, which include a general ban on fishing with trawls below 800 metres deep and a system for protecting vulnerable marine ecosystems in areas where fishing under certain conditions still is allowed. The Regulation also provides for special protection measures for vulnerable marine ecosystems applicable to operations with bottom gear below 400 metres deep; the limitation of fishing directed to deep-sea species to the area in which this activity took place in 2009-2011 (the so-called “footprint of '); the introduction of two types of fishing authorisation, one for vessels landing more than 8% of deep-sea species at each fishing voyage and at least 10 tonnes in the calendar year concerned, and others for vessels catching these species as by-catches.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing. — For the report and against the rejection amendment: the current regulations provide for restrictive technical measures against certain fishing gear (gillnets ban) and prohibit deep-sea fishing in certain areas. But these restrictions are not sufficient to guarantee a sustainable and protective fishing of these particularly fragile ecosystems.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This is a complex dossier whose discussion has been going on for more than three years. The compromise that has finally been reached is reasonable from the point of view of the proposed objectives and the solutions outlined — which was not the case with the European Commission's initial proposal. The Regulation provides for the EU to freeze its 'fishing footprint'. The fishing depth limit is 800 metres in order to safeguard deep-sea ecosystems. Vessels fishing in vulnerable marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres will have to stop operations and travel at least five nautical miles from the fishing zone concerned. The Regulation provides for improvements in transparency, the provision of information and the collection of scientific data — aspects that we value. We argue that we should have gone further in the field of international waters (ICES zones), where fishing activities are carried out which would have to be subject to stricter regulation, thus benefiting the resources that evolve in the waters of the Azores and Madeira — regions where measures have long been adopted to protect vulnerable marine ecosystems, but eventually affected by fishing activities carried out by European fleets in northernmost areas.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ This compromise text represents a balanced legislation on deep-sea fisheries in the North-East Atlantic. The text is in line with the principles of the new basic Regulation and the reform, which provides conditions for preventing adverse effects on vulnerable marine ecosystems. Vessels will be required to report encounters with sensitive marine ecosystems at a depth of 400 metres and immediately stop operations and move to an area of at least 5 nautical miles from the meeting point. The reform in question should also increase the participation of scientific observers by 20%.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down special conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions as regards fishing in international waters of the north-east Atlantic and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002, as I am not satisfied with what it says. Member States will be invited to provide information on the geographical location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessments) and the Commission will evaluate these data annually and adjust the authorised fishing area accordingly. The EFDD amendment rejects this proposal. It is considered, however, that it was submitted purely in the interests of the United Kingdom and not in the protection of fish.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is an improvement in fishing policy which seeks to help preserve fish stocks and mitigate the damage being done by deep sea trawlers. I am especially pleased to see a tightening of control measures which will hopefully ensure that all fishermen, from all Member States, are following the same rules.  These new rules strike the right balance between protection methods, without adding an extra level of complexity and burdens on the industry.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this compromise text on deep-sea fishing in the North-East Atlantic. It is in line with the principles of the new Basic Regulation/CFP Reform and it ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems. Targeted deep-sea fishing will be limited to the area where it occurred in 2009-2011 (freezing the ‘footprint area’); fishing with bottom trawls below 800 metres will be prohibited; vessels will be obliged to report encounters with vulnerable marine ecosystems below a depth of 400 metres and to immediately stop operations and move to an area at least five nautical miles away from the area of encounter. Furthermore, it includes an increased scientific observer coverage of 20%, establishes specific sanctions, better conditions for improving data collection and stronger transparency rules. Member States will finally be required to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems and the Commission will assess this data annually and adapt the allowed fishing area accordingly.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported a rejection of this recommendation as these plans attempt to tie up arrangements in the north east Atlantic in a manner which is damaging to the interests of the UK after we leave the European Union.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it simplifies the system currently in place for managing deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters and allows us to take action to stop destructive impact of bottom trawls.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this compromise solution because I would like to see Parliament's intervention not to the detriment of those who work in this area and those who benefit and live from the induced fishing, especially artisanal fishing. As many times pointed out alongside trade associations, we must try to choose at the end of our debates the least penalising solutions for operators, such as the remodulation of Fishing gear, space-time closures and traceability systems. Applying the principles of blue economy in our interventions goes hand in hand with the contrast to illegal practices implemented by those who take vital resources from our seas. The depletion of the wealth of our seas and the limitation of marine resources must not always and by force translate into limitations without considering the economic nature of the sector, on which many depend families. The protection of marine resources is not at odds with these priorities.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I understand the Recommendation as positive, either because of increased levels of transparency, such as the control of high-impact fisheries, or because the depth limit above 800 metres is ensured, except for vulnerable marine ecosystems, where a limit should be placed 400 meters.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this compromise text on deep-sea fishing in the North-East Atlantic which is in line with the principles of the new Basic Regulation/CFP Reform. It also ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems, establishes specific sanctions, better conditions for improving data collection and stronger transparency rules.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation for second reading as it ensures, to the greatest extent possible, the sustainable exploitation of deep-sea stocks while reducing the environmental impact of these fisheries. The agreement reached maintains the ban on trawling beyond 800 metres only for Community waters, an important aspect in ensuring equal opportunities for Community fishermen in external waters. On the other hand, one of the most controversial aspects of this dossier, the coverage of observers on board, has been resolved thanks to the fact that the European Parliament has lowered its request from 100% to 20% for vessels targeting deep species, both in Community waters and in the waters of NEAFC (North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission), including flexibilities when managing this coverage. Deepwater fisheries in the North-East Atlantic are dominated, in part, by traditional coastal fleets (Portugal) and partly by large roaders (France, Spain). While as a whole they account for approximately 1 per cent of landings from the North-East Atlantic, the economic viability of certain fishing communities depends to some extent on these fisheries.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation on establishing new rules for fishing in the North-East Atlantic. When fish stocks on the continental shelf started declining at the end of the 1980s due to overfishing and unsustainable practices, the fishing industry started targeting deep-sea species. The development of industrial fisheries in the EU over the last four decades led to a critical stock depletion and destruction of marine habitat.  The new regulation strengthens the protection of deep-sea habitats by setting stricter conditions on deep-sea fisheries. The cornerstone measure is the ban on bottom trawling fisheries below 800 metres in EU waters, which entails an important precedent worldwide. I was also particularly happy to support a new effort to ensure the collection of scientific data; 20% of vessels will now be required to have a scientific observer on board.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems and establishes better conditions for improving data collection and stronger transparency rules.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for a Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and provisions for fishing in the international waters of the north-east Atlantic and on repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 138/2013 2347/2002 This Recommendation, which I voted for, draws attention to identifying areas where deep-sea fishing activities are permitted in EU and north-east Atlantic waters, for vessels whose total catch share of that fish is more than 8% in at least one fishing exit during the year. Specific sanctions will be imposed on vessels that violate the regulations, and at the same time, restrictions on the depth at which vessels can carry out fishing activities are also agreed in this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: I support this report, which is a satisfactory compromise between the total prohibition of deep-sea fishing and the protection of marine ecosystems. Damage from trawlers can be irreplaceable for both the environment and stocks due to the high rate of incidental catch. Nevertheless, the restrictions prescribed by the regulations in force seem to succeed in ensuring effective protection. The expertise of scientific observers will allow for certainty to determine the potential for a viable level of fishing. I voted against the Council's position.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation because I am in favour of higher standards of protection of the marine environment. I consider the total ban on bottom trawling below 800 metres a necessary measure in order to preserve the marine ecosystem in EU waters. I am glad that the European Parliament took a common step towards proper regulation and the development of industrial fisheries. I hope that this ban, together with the identification of fishing zones and mandatory impact assessments, will help to avoid further destruction of deep-sea marine life. The European Union should maintain its position of the key player leading by example in the area of environmental protection.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Isabelle Thomas's report on deep-sea fishing. This report aims to ensure the sustainable exploitation of deep-sea stocks while minimizing the environmental impact of this fishery. One of the main objectives of the text is thus to improve scientific knowledge about deep-sea species and their habitats. I supported this agreement, which I consider to be balanced because it allows for sustainable fishing of deep-sea species while ensuring the preservation of vulnerable ecosystems and the preservation of stocks of deep-sea species, characterized by their very slow growth. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. — I endorsed this report at second reading, which establishes specific conditions for the fishing of deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions for fishing in the international waters of the same ocean aimed at protecting the ecosystem. High seas fishing in the North-East Atlantic is targeting species that are slow-growing and particularly vulnerable due to overexploitation. This report prohibits bottom trawling of deep-sea species, which will protect vulnerable marine ecosystems.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is in line with the principles of the new Basic Regulation / CFP Reform and ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since we need to protect vulnerable deep-sea species and ecosystems from the harmful impact of bottom-fishing. As the current management regime of deep-sea fishing has led to the depletion of many deep-sea ecosystems, I consider reforming the regime and setting more specific conditions to be a necessary action.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it is our moral duty to reduce the destructive impact on the marine ecosystem that has been caused by the use of bottom trawls in international waters. As a matter of fact, deep sea stocks are very vulnerable to fishing, stock depletion can occur within a short period of time, and recovery might take very long or even fail. Therefore, I urge the EU to impose a ban on fishing below a depth of 800 metres in the North-East Atlantic in order to protect vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems more effectively. I encourage the EU to insert stronger transparency safeguards, by including obligations to provide public information on EU vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems). In general, I believe that the EU should lead global and regional efforts to promote more responsible deep-sea exploitation and to boost protection of deep-sea ecosystems.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — Under this agreement, the EU defines the area where deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised. The demarcated area provides for the application of a bathymetric limit, such as that of 800 metres, to vessels fishing directly to deep species, or at least one fishing exit during the year, with aim to better protect vulnerable marine ecosystems of the seabed. For vessels that violate existing deepwater fishing regulations, the EP has planned for specific sanctions to be introduced. It has been envisaged that over 400 metres and in case of catches in vulnerable ecosystems, deep-fishing vessels will have to cease operations and move at least 5 miles away from ecosystem capture zone. For these reasons, the EP envisaged the introduction of strict transparency rules, including the obligation to provide data on vessels fishing in the deep waters and the obligation of Member States to provide all data suitable for locating these vulnerable ecosystems.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In the vote on the report by the Socialist Isabelle Thomas, Parliament returned a December 2013 vote which allowed deep-sea trawling, but which could have catastrophic effects on the seabed and their ecosystem. This fishery will therefore be limited beyond 800 metres deep, and will be framed by scientific observations and the recording of catches made. It is therefore not a question of prohibiting ships with this type of equipment, they are 760, but to prohibit the use of these heavy equipment in fragile spaces -the big bottoms- which are still very little known to us. I therefore supported this report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: I am rather in favour of the report entitled 'North-East Atlantic: deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters' and therefore voted against the rejection amendment. I consider the report to be a good compromise. It works to protect marine ecosystems, without advocating a total ban on deep-sea fishing.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. — An amendment proposed to reject the text drawn up in the Fisheries Committee. This text proposes more restrictive regulations on deep-sea fishing to solve several problems: first, the vulnerability of deep-sea fish stocks; secondly, the damage to marine ecosystems generated by these large deep-sea trawls; and, finally, uncertainty about the sustainability of these fishing levels. To overcome these problems and preserve the future, I support the introduction of more restrictive measures and support this report. I therefore voted against the amendment which wanted to reject this text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I vote against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading, because I consider it positive that the deep-sea fishing footprint should be frozen and specific sanctions are stipulated for vessels that do not comply with the rules. Parliament and Council negotiating teams reached agreement on the Commission proposal on 30 June 2016, establishing a depth limit of 800 metres for trawling, which is intended to ensure the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. Also good news is the obligation of vessels to leave fishing areas over 400 metres deep when they are in vulnerable ecosystems. The new transparency rules on deep-sea fishing activity and its impact, as well as the introduction of scientific observers on board 20% of vessels should also serve to advance in this same direction. That is why I do not support the amendment which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — Parliament hereby approves the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down specific conditions applicable to fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions relating to fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions relating to fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic international waters of the North-East Atlantic, and Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002 is repealed. This proposal, which was adopted by the Committee on Fisheries with a very considerable majority, has taken place on a number of important points, such as the reception of new, more stringent transparency rules through, for example, the registration of all catches, the setting of a bathymetric limit of 800 metres to better protect ecosystems more closely. vulnerable to the seabed or the imposition of sanctions on vessels that violate these rules, without anyone going unpunished in the case of various control rules. These are just some of the new measures which, in my opinion, will contribute significantly to the goal of sustainable fisheries.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I abstained. Since the Czech Republic does not have a sea, I leave the decision on fisheries regulation to the Member States concerned.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — The European Union will freeze the fishing footprint by identifying the area in which deep-sea fishing activities are permitted, including a zone of targeted fishing activities undertaken between 2009 and 2011 in EU and north-east Atlantic waters. This geographical restriction will apply to vessels engaged in deep-sea species fishing, and special sanctions are imposed on vessels that violate deep-sea fishing regulations. A fishing depth limit of 800 metres has been agreed and the aim of that new measure is to protect sensitive marine ecosystems more effectively. Parliament also introduced new transparency rules that include commitments to inform the public about European vessels fishing for deep-sea species and notify all catches. Member States will also be obliged to provide information on the position of sensitive ecosystems, and the Commission will evaluate this data each year and adjust the area of fishing permitted. Given that the Council's position at first reading is consistent with the agreement reached in the framework of the trialoges, I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation must have the following aims: to prevent significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems and ensure the long-term conservation of deep sea fish stocks; to minimise and where possible prevent by-catches; to apply the precautionary and ecosystem approaches to fisheries management; and to ensure that the Union measures aimed at the sustainable management of deep-sea fish stocks are consistent with resolutions adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the amendment to the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down special conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in North-East Atlantic and provisions concerning fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002, as this recommendation for second reading is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Council proposal. The Council proposal aims to strengthen restrictive technical measures against certain deep-sea fishing gear in the North-East Atlantic. The current regulations already envisage certain restrictions, but they are not sufficient to protect the very fragile ecosystems and ensure sustainable fishing in these waters. We therefore support this regulation by considering it favourable to the protection of marine resources.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. - This recommendation for second reading aims to adopt a report on the regulation of fisheries in EU waters in the North-East Atlantic. One of the measures envisaged is the definition of the area where deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised, and concrete sanctions are proposed for vessels violating the provisions of the Regulation. Indeed, the proposed measures show a strong concern in safeguarding vulnerable marine ecosystems and biologically sensitive areas and ensuring the sustainability of the ecosystem. I voted in favour.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down special conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions concerning fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic and for the repeal of the Regulation. It is imperative that Parliament introduce new and stricter transparency rules, including obligations to publish information on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report on all catches in the ecosystem.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I agree with the Council's position put forward to Parliament on deep-sea fish stocks and their fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The Council proposal identifies the zones in which deep-sea fishing will be authorised. This geographical limitation will apply to deep-sea vessels. Vessels that violate the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation will be subject to specific sanctions. I hope that these amendments will ensure better protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems of the seabed.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. ‒ After the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading in plenary on 10 December 2013, the trialogue negotiations began to reach an agreement in July 2016. Deep sea trawl fishing is prohibited from 800 m and from 400m for areas known as “vulnerable marine environment”. In addition, the fishing footprint will be frozen and limited to areas in which the targeted fishery took place between 2009 and 2011. Finally Parliament introduced new rules on transparency by including the obligation to inform the public about European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems). I would have wanted more and better. The negotiated outcome limits predation on the marine ecosystem while contributing to the sustainability of the fisheries sector. I am voting for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: This report aims to strengthen the protection of stocks and regulation of deep-sea fishing in the north-east Atlantic. Since this type of fishing is no longer profitable, the last French operator concerned in this sector is gradually withdrawing. The damage to the environment and the marine ecosystem and the almost impossibility of replenishing stocks prompted me to vote for this report, which will not affect the French economic fabric and to vote against the rejection amendment.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: I welcome the position taken by the European Parliament on the regulation on fisheries in the North-East Atlantic. Concerning fishing in European waters, this Regulation includes, inter alia, the prohibition of bottom trawling below 800 metres and aims to protect seabed ecosystems. I am pleased that European fisheries policy is taking another step towards responsible management of resources and greater protection of marine environments, and in particular the most vulnerable ecosystems.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — Parliament adopted its first-reading position on 10 December 2013 on the Commission's specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and on fishing in international waters of the north-east Atlantic on its proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down provisions and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002. The Council subsequently discussed the proposal in detail between January 2014 and November 2015. As a result of the five-round trialogue held between 17 November 2015 and 30 June 2016, Parliament and Council negotiating groups reached agreement on the proposal. The text of the Agreement was adopted on 12 July 2016 by the Committee on Fisheries. The Council subsequently adopted its first-reading position confirming the Agreement. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries proposes that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading, given that it is in line with the agreement reached in the trialogue. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — The current regulations provide for restrictive technical measures against certain fishing gear (gillnet prohibition) and prohibit deep-sea fishing in certain areas. But these restrictions are not sufficient to guarantee sustainable fishing. Therefore, fishing opportunities have been constantly reduced since they began to regulate them. The text provides for more stringent regulations: prohibition of trawling below 800 metres deep, freeze the footprint (mandatory for vessels to fish only in areas already operated between 2009 and 2011), strengthening on-board controls and penalties, and greater transparency of activity. In addition, scientific data collection will be carried out by scientific observers who will have to board 20% of the vessels. Positioning in favour of the report, and against the rejection amendment.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The current regulations provide for restrictive technical measures against certain fishing gear (gillnet prohibition) and prohibit deep-sea fishing in certain areas. But these restrictions are not sufficient to guarantee a sustainable and protective fishing of these particularly fragile ecosystems. As a result, fishing opportunities have been constantly downward since they began to regulate them. In the Committee on Fisheries, on 12 July, the proposal for a regulation was adopted. It provides for more stringent regulations: a ban on trawling below 800 metres deep, freeze the footprint (mandatory for vessels to fish only in areas already operated between 2009 and 2011), increased controls on board and penalties and greater transparency of activity. In addition, scientific data collection will be carried out by scientific observers who will have to board 20% of the vessels. Overall, this text is a good compromise and I therefore reject this amendment rejecting the text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it simplifies the current management system, currently subject to a double instrument, and it is important we take action now to stop the destructive impact of bottom trawls.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text at second reading on the specific conditions for the fishing of deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and the provisions relating to fishing in the international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The legislative resolution endorses the Council's position and banishes deep-sea fishing beyond 800 m (400 m in vulnerable areas). Deep water trawling accounts for only 1% of European fisheries but causes serious environmental damage. That is why it was essential to impose restrictions on it. The adopted text strengthens the controls and penalties applicable to offenders.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report on deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. - I supported this recommendation in my vote because I believe that the final agreement negotiated with the Council representatives is a good one, which brings improvements to legislation on the protection of the deep-sea environment. Given the fragility of this type of marine environment and the fact that the diversity and quantity of deep-sea fish stocks are at risk caused by their slow regeneration, I believe that it was extremely important for the EU to adopt a full and firm regulation in this respect. I welcome that this agreement imposes high standards of environmental protection, protects biodiversity in deep waters, while respecting the Common Fisheries Policy and its objectives.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - Did not support, as I consider that the compromise reached must come into force. Deep sea stocks are at risk and further measures need to be taken to preserve them, such as identifying the area where deep-sea fishing is permitted, penalties for vessels that violate deep-sea fishing rules and more transparent rules for fishing vessels.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. Deep-sea fishing in the North-East Atlantic accounts for about 1% of landings from the North-East Atlantic. The economy of many fishing communities depends, to some extent, on deep-sea fishing. Deep-sea stocks are fish stocks caught in waters beyond the main fishlands of the continental shelf. I voted in favour of the report, which raises, among other things, the issue of sustainable management of stocks and the issue of preventing significant adverse effects on vulnerable marine ecosystems. The European Union will freeze its fishing footprint by specifying in which area deep-sea fishing will be permitted. The area includes the area where a targeted catch was carried out between 2009 and 2011 in EU waters in the North-East Atlantic. In addition, fishing was agreed for a depth limit of 800 metres. This new measure seeks to protect vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems more effectively. Similarly, it was agreed that vessels caught fishing in vulnerable marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres should stop their operations and move within at least five nautical miles of that fishing area.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which validates the trialogue agreement on deep-sea fishing. This agreement will protect vulnerable marine ecosystems while protecting employment and fishermen. The European Parliament has thus obtained specific sanctions for vessels violating the deep-sea fishing regulation and that a number of control rules are not exempted. Parliament and Council negotiators agreed to set a bathymetric limit of 800 metres. The objective of this new provision, which I support, is to better protect vulnerable marine ecosystems in the seabed.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against my colleague's recommendation on the adoption of the Regulation establishing specific conditions for fishing and deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters in the North-East Atlantic area since, while I agree with the principle of safeguarding the marine ecosystem, with particular reference to the most vulnerable species, I believe that introduction into the same regulation of more stringent rules may have a negative socio-economic impact. I am thinking of the ban on any trawling of the fund even exploratory over 800 metres, which has no scientific basis, and the difficulty of explaining to a bona fide industry operator that this activity, before legal, is now impracticable; as well as the rule enshrining the presence of observers on 20% of boats, which carries considerable charges. I welcome the progress made in drafting the new regulation, but I believe that there is a need for greater flexibility. Therefore, I voted down.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the proposal for a Regulation laying down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the Northeast Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the Northeast Atlantic. This Regulation will freeze the fishing footprint by identifying the area in which deep-sea fishing activities are permitted. This geographical restriction will apply to vessels engaged in deep-sea species fishing, and in particular will sanction ships that violate deep-sea fishing regulations. In order to more effectively protect sensitive marine ecosystems on the seabed, the Regulation offers a depth limit of 800 metres, and vessels caught fishing in sensitive marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres will have to stop their fishing activities and move away at least 5 nautical miles from the aforementioned area. I welcome new and stricter transparency rules, which include the obligation to inform the public about European vessels carrying out such fishing as well as notifying all catches. In order to ensure the collection of scientific data, scientific observers must be present on 20% of vessels. Member States will also be obliged to provide information on the position of sensitive ecosystems, and each year the European Commission will evaluate this data and adjust the fishing area in view of them.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - It is necessary to ensure all conditions for the successful prevention of negative consequences on vulnerable marine ecosystems and therefore I support the adoption of the text without further changes. In July, the Fisheries Committee voted on the text of the Parliament and Council agreement of June 2016 and approved it by a large majority of votes. On 18 October 2016, the Council adopted its position in a first reading endorsing the agreement. I am pleased that Parliament has achieved that special sanctions are imposed on ships that violate deep-sea fishing regulations. For the purpose of more efficient protection of sensitive marine ecosystems, depth limits of 800 metres have been agreed with the aim of protecting the ecosystem on the seabed and generally vessels caught fishing in sensitive ecosystems, at a depth of more than 400 metres, will have to discontinue their fishing activities and distance at least 5 nautical miles. Member States will also be obliged to provide information on the position of sensitive ecosystems, and the European Commission will evaluate this data each year and adjust the area of fishing permitted. Transparency is a principle that we encourage at all levels of our Union, citizens are welcome active participants in all our policies — therefore I welcome the introduction of new and stricter rules on transparency by including the obligation to inform the public about European fishing vessels deep-sea species.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. — (PT) This is a complex dossier whose discussion has been going on for more than three years. The compromise that has finally been reached is reasonable from the point of view of the proposed objectives and the solutions outlined — which was not the case with the European Commission's initial proposal. The Regulation provides for the EU to freeze its 'fishing footprint'. The fishing depth limit is 800 metres in order to safeguard deep-sea ecosystems. Vessels fishing in vulnerable marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres shall have to stop operations and travel at least five nautical miles from the fishing zone concerned. The Regulation provides for improvements in transparency, the provision of information and the collection of scientific data — aspects that we value. We argue that we should have gone further in the field of international waters (ICES zones), where fishing activities are carried out which would have to be subject to stricter regulation, thus benefiting the resources that evolve in the waters of the Azores and Madeira — regions where measures have long been adopted to protect vulnerable marine ecosystems, but eventually affected by fishing activities carried out by European fleets in northernmost areas.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — Deep sea fishing is another in a series of huge environmental problems associated with the pace at which mankind is depleting natural resources. Disrupting ecosystems by man results in unprecedented loss of biodiversity and loss of ecosystem services that are vital to us as humanity. Over the past few decades, the intensity of deep-sea fishing has grown exponentially, a technique of so-called bottom trawling, whereby bottom-trawling fishing boats drag nets often in size football field, makes the seabed essentially a desert. Deep-sea ecosystems have a major impact on life in the sea and therefore on the planet, and their uncontrolled plunding may very soon have very egregious consequences. Therefore, I am pleased that, after long negotiations, Parliament and the Council have managed to reach an agreement on this proposal, which envisages reducing the devastating impacts of fishing in international waters of the North East Atlantic, using the definition of the specific area in which deepwater fishing will take place. Furthermore, the agreement sets the limit of the depth at which it is possible to fish at 800 metres and presents the draft penalties for ships which the Deep Sea Fisheries Regulation violates. Some vessels will also be obliged to take on board scientific observers so that data collection and research on the effectiveness of the regulation can take place, which I personally consider very important.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which would limit bottom trawling in the North-East Atlantic which destroys seabed habitats. A depth limit of 800 metres beyond which fishing is prohibited has therefore been established which will help protect vulnerable and fragile marine ecosystems. In addition, States will now have an obligation to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems, on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report on all catches. Finally, the EU has defined the area in which deep-sea fishing activities will be allowed, as well as specific sanctions for vessels that do not comply with the relevant rules.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We supported rejection as these plans attempt to tie up arrangements in the North-East Atlantic in a manner which is damaging to the interests of the UK after we leave the European Union.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. — A heavily loaded vote this noon with the adoption by the European Parliament of a new regulation prohibiting fishing beyond a depth of 800 metres in the North-East Atlantic. This is the main fishing area for the Member States of the European Union, about 70% of total fish catches. This prohibition on high depth fishing will apply to bottom trawling, which often destroys seabed habitats, and will limit deep-sea fishing to the area where it took place between 2009 and 2011. Other important measures include the obligation for Member States to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems and stricter controls at sea: 20% of European vessels will need to have a (scientific) observer on board to ensure timely and accurate data collection. This text therefore responds to some of the problems raised by NGOs. But in the long run the EU will have to commit itself to do more if it really wants to protect its fisheries resources, for example through a planned elimination of bottom trawls and bottom gillnets in deep-sea fisheries. This was precisely what the European Commission had proposed in 2012.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: In writing. - This report is intended for the European Union to freeze the fishing footprint by defining the area where deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised. Parliament also succeeded in introducing new stricter transparency rules, including the obligation to provide information to the public about European vessels targeting the deep-sea species and record all catches (vulnerable fish and ecosystems).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. — I supported this recommendation to prohibit fishing beyond a depth of 800 metres in the North-East Atlantic. This prohibition will apply to bottom trawling, which often destroys seabed habitats, and will limit deep-sea fishing to the area where it took place between 2009 and 2011. In addition, stricter controls at sea and rules on transparency in data collection will also be applied. From now on, there will be more transparency guarantees, including, for example, obligations to provide public information on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report on all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I voted on this recommendation. The text of the Agreement was submitted to a vote in the Committee on Fisheries on 12 July 2016 and approved by a large majority. The agreement reflects several important aspects. It was agreed that a 800 m batimetric limit will be set. The aim of this new provision is to improve the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems of the seabed. It was also agreed that after reaching a depth of more than 400 m and touching vulnerable marine ecosystems, deep-sea fishing vessels will have to cease activities and move at least 5 nautical miles away from the fishing zone of that ecosystem.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Following the various trialogues that have taken place to reach a negotiating agreement on the adoption of a regulation establishing specific conditions for the fishing of deep-sea species in the North-East Atlantic and provisions applicable to fishing in waters in this region, it was possible to adopt its position at first reading. Thus, the compromise reached in this regard is the freezing of the 'fishing footprint' by defining the area where deep-sea fishing activities will be authorised, the application of specific sanctions on vessels violating the Regulation and the setting of a bathymetric limit of 800m, with to protect vulnerable seabed ecosystems. Through the adoption of these and other measures contained in the Regulation, it will be possible to improve scientific knowledge on deep-sea species and their habitats, implement technical fisheries management measures and, in this way, ensure a more sustainable exploitation of deep-sea species, at the same time minimising the impact of deep-sea fishing activities on the marine environment. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the agreement which lays down special conditions for fishing in deep-sea stocks and in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The reason for the agreement is that existing arrangements have not yet improved the vulnerability of fish stocks and the difficulty of establishing a sustainable fisheries sector. The agreement is now intended to remedy this situation and help to prevent overfishing in international waters of the North Atlantic.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I vote against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading, because I consider it positive that the deep-sea fishing footprint should be frozen and specific sanctions are stipulated for vessels that do not comply with the rules. Parliament and Council negotiating teams reached agreement on the Commission proposal on 30 June 2016, establishing a depth limit of 800 metres for trawling, which is intended to ensure the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. Also good news is the obligation of vessels to leave fishing areas over 400 metres deep when they are in vulnerable ecosystems. The new transparency rules on deep-sea fishing activity and its impact, as well as the introduction of scientific observers on board 20% of vessels should also serve to advance in this same direction. That is why I do not support the amendment which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: ‒ Deep-sea stocks and marine ecosystems have peculiar characteristics that make them particularly sensitive to human activities. Numerous species have slow growth, live long and breed late. Thanks to the new regulation, a number of specific measures will be taken to ensure sustainable deep-sea fishing and prevent damage to the seabed and their life forms, such as, for example, Cold water coral reefs, sponge gardens and the ecosystems of the underwater mountains. A ban on trawling at depths of more than 800 metres, or more than 400 metres in the presence of a vulnerable marine ecosystem will be introduced, and it will be called a “geographical footprint” in a way that vessels can only fish in areas already affected by fishing activities. Some control measures such as the presence of observers on board will ultimately help ensure compliance with the rules. I have decided to vote in favour of this regulation because the new proposal represents a fair balance between protecting the environment and responsible management of this type of fisheries.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the rejection amendment. We tabled this rejection amendment as the EU should not be involved in the North Sea. Without our amendment this would have passed without a vote.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this compromise text on deep-sea fishing in the North-East Atlantic which is in line with the principles of the new Basic Regulation/CFP Reform. It also ensures conditions for preventing significant adverse impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems, establishes specific sanctions, better conditions for improving data collection and stronger transparency rules.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. “I voted against the rejection of this resolution. Fisheries need to be regulated and protected in order to ensure long-term sustainable management. Within the framework of this regulation and conservation, it was necessary to review and establish specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea fish stocks in the North-East Atlantic. As a result of the agreement, for example, the European Union will freeze its fishing footprint by specifying the area in which deep-sea fishing will be allowed. Specific penalties will be introduced for vessels that violate the Deep Sea Fishing Regulation and there will be no exceptions for certain provisions. It also agreed a depth limit of 800 metres.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because I consider it right that, in accordance with the United Nations General Assembly Resolution, in particular Resolutions 61/105 and 64/72, the protection of sensitive deep-sea ecosystems against the impact of bottom fishing gear as well as of sustainable exploitation of deep-sea fish stocks. Although deep-sea fisheries have been regulated in the EU since 2003 through Total Allowable Catch (TAC), I think that it is only through other effective measures that we can prevent further adverse consequences of unregulated fishing and the destruction of deep-sea fish stocks. I regret that the stocks of some deep-sea fish are threatened by fishing activities outside the main fishing grounds. To ensure that deep-sea fish stocks are able to recover and can be exploited in a sustainable way even in the long term, it is essential to reduce some catches. I believe that it is in our interest to make further progress in this area, because it is a good investment not only in the health of our seas, but also in the future of our fishermen.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - I support a legislative resolution of the European Parliament confirming the Council's position at first reading. The agreement achieves a key objective, which is to ensure sustainable management and exploitation of deep-sea species while minimising the impact of deep-sea fishing activities on the marine environment which is highly sensitive. The key point is that the European Union will freeze its footprint of fishing activities by identifying the area where deep-sea fishing will be allowed. This area also contains an area in EU waters in the north-east Atlantic, where targeted fishing took place between 2009 and 2011. This territorial confinement will apply to vessels fishing for deep-sea species, i.e. those whose catches of deep-sea species account for more than 8% of all catches on at least one fishing trip per year. A depth limit of 800 metres is also set, which is important for the effective protection of sensitive deep-sea ecosystems. But it is also important to agree that vessels caught fishing in sensitive marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres will have to cease their activities and sail at least five nautical miles away from the fishing area concerned. To ensure the collection of scientific data, 20% of vessels will need to have on board a scientific observer. I hope that the content will now be followed by an effective implementation in practice.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - The European Parliament resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and rules for fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic, and I reject the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002. I voted in favour of the request for rejection. Environmental protection is close to my heart, but this report is pushed too far. The European Union freezes the fishing footprint by determining the area in which deep-sea fishing is permitted. Fishing shall be authorised only at or above a depth of 800 metres. In addition, the co-legislators have agreed that deep-sea fishing vessels caught from vulnerable marine ecosystems must cease fishing at depths of more than 400 metres and move away from the fishing area concerned at least five nautical metres. It is absurd that 20% of vessels must take scientific observers on board to ensure the collection of scientific data. There are doubts about the EU's competence in this project anyway.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted against the EFDD Group's proposal that the European Parliament reject the Council's first reading position on the setting of specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and the provisions on fishing in international waters of the north-east Atlantic and repealing the Council Regulation. I support the trade-offs reached in a trialogue such as that the European Union will freeze its footprint of fishing activities by identifying the area where deep-sea fishing will be allowed. I also support a compromise to impose specific penalties on vessels that will violate deep-sea fishing regulations and that there will be no exceptions under certain regulations.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - The EU must seek effective protection of vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on deep-sea stocks and fisheries, which has already been submitted to the European Parliament at second reading. Compared to the first conditions of three years ago, significant compromises have been achieved which make fishing sustainable in international waters. The Recommendation points out that the EU, as a first step, identifies the area in which deep-sea fishing is permitted, thereby freezing its fishing footprint. This geographical limit will apply to vessels fishing for deep-sea species, i.e. those whose catches of deep-sea species account for more than 8% of the total catch. It also emphasises that Parliament has foreseen concrete sanctions against those who violate the regulation. During the compromise, the parties agreed on a depth limit of 800 metres, which will more effectively protect the vulnerable deep-sea ecosystem. I think it is important to mention that new, stricter transparency rules will be introduced by introducing obligations to make information on vessels fishing for European deep-sea species available to the public and all catches must be taken to report. An important element is the need for Member States to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessment) and the Commission will assess these data annually and adapt the authorised fishing (by means of implementing acts) accordingly area.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. - In general, the promotion of sustainable development involves the inclusion of environmental protection requirements in the definition and implementation of EU policies and actions. Regarding deep-sea fishing, the need for regulation (in accordance with the precautionary and prevention principle) derives from the fact that long-term sustainable exploitation of these stocks is required, not only for the purpose of preventing significant harmful effects on ecosystems vulnerable marine, but also with a view to ensuring the conservation of the fishery resources concerned. In this respect, scientific advice is indispensable. Thus, fishing activities should be conditional on prior environmental impact assessment, adopting, where appropriate, measures to close areas with vulnerable systems, specific measures to prevent significant effects on vulnerable marine ecosystems, conservation measures aimed at protecting vulnerable marine ecosystems. Impact assessments of the application of the provisions shall be based on actual and relevant collection of data and information. For the purposes of environmental protection, it is welcomed to phase out fishing methods which are extremely harmful to vulnerable marine ecosystems, while presenting high levels of unwanted catches of deep-sea species.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - Fisheries is one of the essential economic activities for a significant part of the Member States of the European Union. A significant share of this activity is covered by fishing for deep-sea species stocks in the North-East Atlantic area. In order to protect the vulnerable marine ecosystem at the seabed, the European institutions have started a tighter regulatory process since January 2014. The agreement currently reached provides for a freezing of the footprint, defining the area where fishing activities are permitted. That area includes a region of European waters of the North-East Atlantic where directed fishing was practiced during the period 2009-2011 and where catches targeting deep-sea species are no longer allowed to account for more than 8% of total annual catches. The depth limit below which this provision applies shall be 400 m and ships which do not respect a distance of at least 5 miles from that area shall be subject to specific sanctions. Strict rules are also laid down for reporting all catches, as well as the provision of information by Member States and the presence of scientific observers on 20% of vessels entering the area. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. — I am totally in favour of this text. Parliament introduced new, more demanding transparency rules by including obligations to provide public information on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to record all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems). Member States will also be required to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessments) and the European Commission will evaluate this data annually and adapt the authorised fishing area accordingly (using implementing acts).

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The deep sea is the largest habitat on Earth, which hosts biologically significant ecosystems, playing an important role in the ocean ecosystem. Deep-sea species have become vulnerable as a result of overfishing and unsustainable practices, in conjunction with the development of industrial fisheries in the EU, which have led to the depletion and destruction of marine habitat.  I voted in favour of the report on the regulation establishing specific conditions for deep-sea fishing because it will strengthen the protection of deep-sea habitats through the imposition of stricter conditions for said fishing, protecting one of the EU’s most important natural resources.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. — As rapporteur, I have had the responsibility to negotiate with the Council the report to Parliament on deep-sea fisheries, and I am delighted that it received a very large majority with 634 votes in favour and 38 votes against. This vote rewards an in-depth work and 8 months of negotiation with the council. The agreement provides for a “footprint freeze”, i.e. the obligation for this fishery to be limited geographically to areas already exploited between 2009 and 2011. It also provides for a ban on trawling below 800 metres deep. Strengthens controls and penalties for offenders; It promotes better knowledge of the environment through the collection of vessel data and the publication of resource and ecosystem impact studies. This monitoring should make it possible to adjust the regulation to environmental realities. In 2012, a majority of MEPs refused the Commission's proposal to ban deep fishing. Together with the Council, we have built a regulation that takes into account both environmental and socio-economic issues. This balance is the key to sustainable development.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. : I supported the recommendation for second reading in the vote because it concerns serious regulations in deep-sea fisheries; without the extinction of these regulations, the protection of species covered by the threat would be limited. Parliament has introduced new, more stringent transparency rules covering the need to provide the public with information on European vessels targeting deep-sea fishing and the need to record all fisheries (fish stocks and ecosystems are vulnerable). Member States will also be required to provide information on the situation of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessment), and the Commission will have to evaluate these data annually. This is the right decision, worthy of approval.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. — Deep sea fishing accounts for about 1% of landings from the north-east Atlantic, and some of the fishing communities are to some extent economically dependent on deep-sea fisheries. Over time, it has been shown that the original rules for fishing for deep-sea stocks do not have sufficient restrictions and that they can no longer ensure sustainable management of stocks. In addition, they have not solved the problem of significant adverse effects on sensitive marine ecosystems. So I voted positively for this report that delivers significant improvements to the rules in deep-sea fishing of the Northeast Atlantic. This regulation was passed after four years of political negotiations and the new rules should begin to apply by the end of 2016. Some of these include a ban on fishing from trawling trawls below a depth of 800 metres, a rule that boats can only fish in areas where they have previously hunted to prevent new damage, an obligation for vessels to report encounters with sensitive marine ecosystems at a depth greater from 400m and then move to another fishing area, more rigorous control measures to make sure everyone adheres to the same rules, and to guarantee data collection, scientific observers will have to board 20% of vessels fishing in EU waters and those bordering the EU.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - Draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and provisions on fishing in international waters of the north-east I have not supported the Atlantic and the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002. The proposal seeks to set specific fishing conditions for deep-sea stocks in the Northeast Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the Northeast Atlantic. Deep sea hunting is dominated by traditional coastal countries such as Portugal and large vessels with networks of France and Spain. In total, they account for 1% of landings from the Northeast Atlantic. The most are hunted by species that are slowly growing and susceptible to overexploitation (sea sword, ling...). The European Union will freeze its footprint of fishing activities by identifying the area where deep-sea fishing will be allowed. This new measure aims to protect sensitive deep-sea ecosystems more effectively.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a clear effort to improve long-term sustainability of fishing. It is an acceptable compromise because: - The European Union is going to freeze its fishing footprint by specifying the area in which deep-sea fishing will be allowed. That area includes the area in which targeted fishing took place between 2009 and 2011 in EU waters in the North-East Atlantic. This geographical boundary will apply to vessels targeting deep-sea species, i.e. those whose deep-sea species catch makes up more than 8% of the total on at least one fishing trip during the year. - Parliament has secured specific penalties for vessels breaching the regulation on deep-sea fishing and a stipulation that no exemptions will be granted to certain rules. - The Parliament and Council negotiators have agreed on a depth limit of 800 metres. This new measure is intended to protect vulnerable deep-sea marine ecosystems more effectively. - In an effort to ensure that scientific data is collected, 20% of vessels will be required to have a scientific observer on board.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. — This report proposes to better regulate fisheries, particularly deep-sea fishing. This method is destructive to the environment for several reasons, bottom trawls damage vulnerable and irreplaceable marine ecosystems, trawling of deep-sea species leads to high levels of incidental catches and thus makes it impossible to replenish them. This text, if it limits fishing, will have no impact on employment in France, and allows better protection of the seabed. I therefore supported the adoption of this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. — Implemented restrictions could lead to a fundamental reduction in fish catches and consequently the collapse of many fisheries companies. The fight to stop the degradation of underwater flora should be supported, but it is important not at the expense of labour and people, so I voted against the report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. — Following Parliament's position at first reading in plenary on 10 December 2013, the Council discussed the proposal in detail between January 2014 and November 2015, which coincided with the Luxembourg presidency to achieve a second reading agreement with negotiations that have begun. In line with S&D practice, I voted against the EFDD proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I understand the Recommendation as positive, either because of increased levels of transparency, such as the control of high-impact fisheries, or because the depth limit above 800 metres is ensured, except for vulnerable marine ecosystems, where a limit should be placed 400 meters.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation for a second reading on the Council position regarding the North-East Atlantic: deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters regulation. I believe it is of extreme importance to protect deep sea species and environments, which are ecologically fragile. In addition we consider that the trilogue results were acceptable, although due to delicate and complex political agreements, the actual impact of this regulation may be less than we would expect.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing. — Parliament has introduced new stricter transparency rules, including an obligation to make public information on European vessels fishing for deep-sea fish and record all catches (fish and vulnerable ecosystems). Member States will also have to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems (impact assessment), and the European Commission will assess these data each year and then adjust the area where fishing is allowed (by means of implementing acts) accordingly.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading in view of the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002.  According to the regulation, the European Union is going to freeze its fishing footprint by specifying the area in which deep-sea fishing will be allowed. That area includes the area in which targeted fishing took place between 2009 and 2011 in EU waters in the North-East Atlantic. Parliament has secured specific penalties for vessels breaching the regulation on deep-sea fishing and a stipulation that no exemptions will be granted to certain rules. I voted in favour because I believe that, through this regulation, Parliament has introduced new, stricter transparency rules by including obligations to make information available to the public on European vessels targeting deep-sea species and to report all catches.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I vote against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading, because I consider it positive that the deep-sea fishing footprint should be frozen and specific sanctions are stipulated for vessels that do not comply with the rules. Parliament and Council negotiating teams reached agreement on the Commission proposal on 30 June 2016, establishing a depth limit of 800 metres for trawling, which is intended to ensure the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. Also good news is the obligation of vessels to leave fishing areas over 400 metres deep when they are in vulnerable ecosystems. The new transparency rules on deep-sea fishing activity and its impact, as well as the introduction of scientific observers on board 20% of vessels should also serve to advance in this same direction. That is why I do not support the amendment which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: in writing. — (NL) I voted against because Parliament has introduced new, more stringent transparency rules and the obligation to disclose information on European vessels engaged in deep-sea fishing activities and recording all catches.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: The protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems is fundamental to the future of our planet. Deep-sea species are particularly threatened by intensive fishing activities. The European Union has agreed on new delineations of fishing areas in the North-East Atlantic with a depth of 800 metres. Restrictions apply below the 400 metre depth bar where species at risk live. Vessels that violate the legislation will have to suspend their activities and move away by at least five thousand sailors from the area in question. This limit applies to all vessels whose deep-sea fishing stock is at least 8%. The European Parliament introduced new transparency rules, including the obligation to make public the names of deep-sea fishing vessels and the obligation to report all catches. Member States will have to inform about locations containing species at risk. Finally, the Commission will evaluate the data each year and adapt the authorised fishing areas accordingly. Finally, the European Union regulates deep-sea fishing and prohibits trawling. Of course I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The Regulation provides for improvements in transparency, the provision of information and the collection of scientific data - aspects that we value. The Regulation provides for the EU to freeze its 'fishing footprint'. The fishing depth limit is 800 metres in order to safeguard deep-sea ecosystems. Vessels fishing in vulnerable marine ecosystems at a depth of more than 400 metres shall have to stop operations and travel at least five nautical miles from the fishing zone concerned. We argue that we should have gone further in the field of international waters (ICES zones), where fishing activities have been carried out which should be subject to stricter regulation, thus benefiting the resources that evolve in the waters of the Azores and Madeira - regions where measures have long been adopted to protect vulnerable marine ecosystems, but eventually affected by fishing activities carried out by European fleets in northernmost areas.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which represents a fair and balanced compromise. It promotes the preservation of vulnerable seabeds, the protection of deep-sea species and the safeguarding of jobs that depend on this economic activity. With the introduction of the concept of footprint, deep-sea fisheries will now be restricted to areas already exploited in the past and prohibited under 800 metres of depth.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I did not support the amendment by the EFDD political faction rejecting the Council's position. I do not agree with this rejection, since, on the contrary, I support the Council proposal to adopt a regulation laying down special conditions for fishing for deep-sea fish stocks in the North-East Atlantic and the provisions on fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic. The proposal deals with the so-called high seas, where fishing takes place at a depth of 600 - 800 m. However, such fishing, especially when using certain types of gear, causes irreversible damage to the environment and damages deep-sea ecosystems. That is why the regulation introduces stricter measures against such damage to the seabed. In addition, fishing will be allowed only where there is already a so-called fishing footprint, it will not be possible to fish in areas whose ecosystems are identified as vulnerable and stricter controls will be put in place. I think that the environment needs to be protected as much as possible and, on the contrary, it is necessary to control the activities that lead to its, in this case irreversible, damage. I consider the rules introduced by the draft regulation to be proportionate and hope to prove their effectiveness.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support Isabelle Thomas's report on the Northeast Atlantic case: deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters. The EU has been given the task of establishing specific fishing conditions for both deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and fishing in international waters of the Northeast Atlantic. I believe that the protection of marine ecosystems, especially those that are severely endangered, is initially important. Furthermore, since this is about fishing for deep-sea stocks, it is necessary to create a list of deep-sea species because the goal is to work on conservation and further research related to this case. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate it. It is necessary to raise awareness of the need to prevent catches of endangered deep-sea stocks. Those ships, that is, persons who violate these rules will be sanctioned. The European Commission has decided to punish vessels that break the rules and that deep-sea fishing should be banned. The European Parliament has gone a step further in this case, which I find positive, in a way that it has introduced stricter rules and an obligation on European vessels to give information about what they are hunting and to record every catch. In this way, it can reduce and slightly reduce the catches of deep-sea species and preserve the fish stock.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and provisions on fishing in international waters the north-east Atlantic and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002 I support the adoption of the Council's position at first reading without further amendments as it is in line with the agreement reached in the trialogues. The proposal aims to lay down specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the north-east Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the Northeast Atlantic in order to enable sustainable fishing.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: — Mr President, we had two objectives here: to improve the efficiency of our work and to strengthen our rules of transparency. I would like to address the written questions. These questions, which we are asking the Commission, which must answer us within four weeks. A sound and democratic exercise in principle, which is now used, diverted, misguided by some, to such an extent that the Commission usually does not even take the time to respond on the substance. It was necessary to tighten, limit, allow one or two questions a month, only, actually impose a virtuous circle of real questions, to get real answers, and instead, what are we doing? We are cutting the ceiling, seven questions instead of five, that is incomprehensible, and I did not even mention the cost of inflation: at EUR 490 the question is EUR 30 million a year for an exercise which is parliamentary expression what Coca-Cola is in Brunello. It is indefensible, and I do not vote on this compromise. A word, on the other hand, about our code of conduct, which we are strengthening. It will now be forbidden to be a member of Parliament and paid consultant; no place here for influential trafficking is essential.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, I voted against these changes to our Rules of Procedure because, if we already had little powers, we are now going to reduce our decision-making power, limiting the number of questions we can ask the Commission, limiting the possibility of amending texts with which we do not agree and limiting the position of the Parliament vis-à-vis the Council in negotiations. At the same time, this is the reform of the grand coalition. A reform to address only the issues that interest them, and as they are interested in, the big political groups: the European People's Party and Social Democracy, which means blocking the work of the groups that are against austericide, against the loss of labour rights and against refugee policies.
