Today, in short, is a black day for democracy in the Union and bad news for citizens. It is their concept of democracy and respect for minorities that is clear today.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, I said 'no' because the Corbett report is an attack on pluralism, transparency and democracy that keeps this Parliament away from the European people. Large groups have agreed to censor critics' voices, limiting our right to amendments, questions and parliamentary participation. In order to leave no mark, they also reduce debates and transparency of votes. The new regulation formalises what many have been denouncing for a long time: that this Parliament is nothing more than a theatre where agreements between socialists and the right are represented before a gagged public who is astonished at the destruction of their social rights and freedoms in the name of the market. On this path, the European Union will not survive this democratic involution.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, the report states that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege for Members, but a guarantee for Parliament as a whole, and also a guarantee for Members of Parliament. I agree with this and that immunity should not be a shield from immoral deeds, to those who are not ethical or even to criminal facts. Many times, however, Parliament or national parliaments are a shield against criminal offences. The guarantee of our independence does not mean that we can afford anything, anytime, anyway. We are independent in decision-making, in votes, in expressing opinions, but we are not independent to break the law and then invoke immunity. We are not doing enough, in my opinion, for the transparency of our work. We also do not do enough for the protection of “whistleblowers” of those people who from inside the institution say outside, tell the press, tell society what goes wrong in the institution and reveal the illegalities that are committed. I hope to solve all this in a later report.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: — Mr President, one of the founding principles of the European Union is equality between all citizens and citizens. This means that all the votes of all citizens and citizens are equal, they are worth exactly the same and therefore the Members and the Members elected by them have the same rights and are also equal within this House. I repeat, they should all have the same rights. That, Mr President, is democracy. However, this report is the total disregard for democracy in the sense I have just described: it is the seamless legalisation of backstage policy in the worst sense, in all that this backstage policy has the worst. I never thought that the European Parliament was the only European institution directly elected by European citizens to help strengthen the democratic deficit. Don't talk about democratic deficit, you just legitimized it. I voted against it because I'm not an accomplice.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I did not support this report, I did not support amendments to the Rules of Procedure. First, I think that the rules of the game are not to change in the middle of the parliamentary term, that is, if the rules of procedure are to be changed, then for the next term, to be clear for future MPs, for on what terms the European Parliament works, and secondly, I do not agree with how the individual rights of Members have been restricted. By and large, I don't know the rational reasons for why the institute of oral explaining an MP's vote is to be restricted, for example, when it is one of the options an MP can to his constituent communicate the position he holds and why he votes in the European Parliament in a certain way. In my view, this will lead to Members doing worse in the future explaining their political positions and the European Parliament may move those rules of procedure away from its constituents and further complicate the relationship between Brussels institutions and citizens of the European Union. So I think some changes aren't good.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, although I largely agree with what my colleague Pospíšil said, in particular with regard to oral explanations, I finally decided to support this report. It is undoubtedly that there are violations of individual rights of MPs, there is simply a decline in these rights. To me, this circumstance is balanced to some extent only by the fact that this report introduces completely new, transparent institutes into the decision-making and negotiations of the European Parliament. After all, many of those individual rights are very illusory to some extent. Today, a non-member in the European Parliament, I think, has very few rights, it is far more advantageous and better to be a member of a faction. For various reasons, such as strengthening transparency and undoubtedly limiting the factory on issues, which were really overused by some Members, I decided to support the report in the end.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, students of liberty will tell you that, throughout our history, there has been the ebb and flow and battle between the people trying to regain power from those who wish to control the people. They will tell you that, where the power is concentrated too much in the hands of those who lead us, then there will be problems with the people and often abuse of their lives. We can see what happened in Cuba. We can see what happened in Cambodia or China or the Soviet Union.  Mr Corbyn’s party has a member here, from the Labour Party, who wants to institute his own constitutional manipulation of this House. Now he is not a communist and he does not come from those countries, but he comes from a party that supports Cuban leaders, supports people who were in the Soviet Union, and supported those who believed that the power of the people should be suppressed by the power of organisations. These changes to this House will ensure that this continues, but I believe that many more people will want to leave the European Union on the basis of it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, now in the past few months I have sat on the Committee that produced this report and I have witnessed the final stages of the work which has been done and which we voted on this morning, supposedly to make the Parliament function better for the States that wish to remain members of the European Union and be governed by the body in the years to come.  Now if the people of the United Kingdom had not voted to leave the European Union on 23 June there would have been a number of clauses that I would have voted against or wanted amended today. However, I chose to abstain almost constantly throughout and only voted against at the very end since I do not believe in more Europe, I do not believe in more EU control, and I felt the report was fundamentally flawed. There was a request right at the beginning to defer this report and to send it back to committee, and it is a very great shame that that request was ignored.

name: Seán KELLY
text: — Go raibh maith agat, to Uachtarain. The most important votail in Tuarascála seo cosúil the most ghrupa agus is right in tús: tá moladh mór tuillte ag an Uasal Corbett agus in feisirí eile a d'oibrigh ar an tuarascáil iontach fhada seo. I ndáiríre tá gaisce deanta acu agus dá bhri without ba chóir go mbeimid buioch doibh. You know ceart go ndeanaimid athbhreithniu ar in rialacha atá againn sa Pharlaimint anois is aris, agus ddoigh tábhachtach go dtuigfeadh in saoranaigh cada ar siúl againn, go dtuigfidh siad go bhfuilimid chomh hoscailte agus is there linn chun an tredhearcacht to chur chun cinn; agus sa tsli without beidh muinin ag in saoranaigh as Parlaimint in HeorPa. I know without thar a bheith tábhachtach. Caithfimid to myiu doibh cad to ar siúl againn, cé hiad on the crane to bhfuilimid ag bualadh leo, cada a la acu agus ansin cén fáth go dtagaimid ar chinneadh éigin ag deireadh in the day. It is right to go bhfuil without a tábhachtach agus cabhrodh an Tuarascáil without chun and without dhéanamh.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, I have voted against because I do not agree with the method by which changes are introduced. Especially I agree absolutely with you, Mr President, that the Rules cannot determine what the ex-deputies are doing after they stop being deputies. But they can lobby. But why can I not speak against the European Union and try to destroy the European Union and I am losing my benefits? It is incoherent. Moreover I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, may I start by thanking all colleagues for those comments. But let me also reiterate that this report was two years in preparation through a working group in which every single political group was present and participated constructively in this, before it even went for public discussion in the committee and public discussion and vote in this House.  Very high majorities – extremely high majorities – backed the key changes proposed in this report. So I sometimes wonder whether those who now claim that this is a great conspiracy, some sort of coup d'état – as one of our colleagues from over there claimed – or that this is some great manipulation, have actually read what is in the report or whether they are just posturing for some segment of public opinion back in their home country. Those who really do care, Mr Woolfe, about concentrations of power should stand up for an effective, efficient and transparent parliament, a pluralistic parliament that is able to stand up for pluralism in the European Union, for scrutiny of the executive, and for holding the other European institutions to account. That is what this report is about. It is about making our Parliament clearer, more transparent and more effective in doing its work. Let me finish with one thing, Mr President. If Britain does indeed go ahead and leave the European Union, then let it not be said that British Members have not contributed to making this Parliament an effective, vibrant Parliament able to act on behalf of the citizens that send us here.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you Mr Corbett and congratulations for your success.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ Richard Corbett's report is concerned with reforming the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. The whole procedure has been longer and more complicated than usual, just think that the working group has been working on this dossier for a year and a half. I have always felt it necessary to change the rules of the European Parliament, especially with regard to transparency rules. I have always fought myself to make the institutions of glass buildings such as to allow citizens to follow with complete confidence what is happening inside. We should be the members of the European Parliament who are committed to this happening. Unfortunately, the reality is very different and this report is a testament to this. That's why I decided to vote against it.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. - I think there is no strong Parliament if there is no efficient regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this revision of the Regulation which aims to improve its functioning, increase transparency and adapt its content to the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Improvement of Legislation. I welcome the fact that the reform adopted includes proposals to improve efficiency in practical issues such as question time, voting on legislative acts and roll-call votes, as well as to integrate a gender perspective and include current discussions at each partsession on the proposal of political groups. In addition, the new Regulation introduces improvements in the field of transparency by introducing legislative footprint on reports, limiting meetings to interest groups that are registered in the transparency register and prohibiting the development of paid interest representation activities directly related to the Union decision process. However, I regret that other reforms that were seeking Members to publish meetings with interest groups online or the prohibition on remunerated work during their term have been rejected by the conservative majority in the European Chamber.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this revision of Parliament's rules of procedure, because it will reduce the ability to influence the parliamentary work of small groups, leaving this House at the service of popular and socialists, who see their capacity to define working times and speed up the legislation of interest to them, blocking amendments and debates that they consider hostile. And the same will happen with other forms of initiative, such as questions and statements, that small groups have been using to influence the political agenda beyond agreements between the majority groups.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the joint review of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The European Parliament has regularly reviewed its Rules of Procedure, often after the adoption of new treaties that increase Parliament's powers. In the present case, the rules are being restructured mainly for internal reasons: making Parliament more functioning, clarifying the rules, improving transparency, protecting Parliament from political forces seeking to sabotage its work and potential disturbances in work. Only a few amendments have been made due to wider changes, such as 2006. In the context of an interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking or on the establishment of new bodies in the context of a banking union. Several changes have also been made, based on 2015. R. Corbetto's report on procedures and practices for hearings by the Commission. I welcome this in-depth review of the rules, while stressing that it was prepared in a working group that included all stakeholders in the discussion, which held regular meetings for 1.5 years and reached agreement on many points.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the general review of Parliament's Rules of Procedure because I believe that with the new regulations the European Parliament will become a more transparent, efficient, open and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In a democratic Parliament, the Rules of Procedure should play a vital role in ensuring transparency and fairness. It is important that these principles should exist across the European Parliament, and I therefore voted for any amendment that brought about more transparency and voted against any amendment that looked to remove it. Those amendments which would have provided greater fairness and balance between the political groups were also worthy of support.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I approved this general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I think it was important to clarify certain rules in order to make Parliament work better by protecting it from certain disruptive political elements. This agreement resulting in part from the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation should improve the efficiency and transparency of the work of parliamentarians.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the joint review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The European Parliament has regularly reviewed its Rules of Procedure, often after the adoption of new treaties which increased the powers of the European Parliament. However, in the present case, the rules are being restructured mainly for internal reasons: making Parliament more functioning, clarifying the rules, improving transparency, protecting Parliament from interference by political forces seeking to sabotage its work. The largest part of the work done is technical, legal and linguistic, and it improves the details of the rules. However, there are a number of changes, the importance of which is broader.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. — I voted against this revision of the rules because of the new restrictions it would impose on members of parliament: these limits would undercut the control function which the elected people have the right and the duty to exercise. In addition, the new rules would not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members of the minority. For example, all political groups would have the right to propose at least one topic for a current debate a year... except that if 80% of the groups at the Conference of Presidents oppose a proposed topic, it will not be accepted. This rule would serve to prevent patriot parties and groups, unfortunately minority at the moment, from speaking out.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I approved this revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which will, in particular, enhance its transparency. Thus, during their tenure, Members of Parliament will be prohibited from accepting paid lobbying. Once their term is over, they will lose their privileges as former MEPs — including free access to the European Parliament — if they become lobbyists. In addition, agreement had been reached to strengthen sanctions against perpetrators of defamatory or xenophobic statements in plenary.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: In writing. ‒ Throughout its history, the European Parliament has carried out several regular revisions to its regulation to better adapt its internal functioning mechanisms to changes in the institutional and political system. The Corbett report, which I supported with my vote today, is the result of a collegiate work that lasted 18 months and which was intended to define a general revision of the Rules of Procedure to respond to the new needs of the institution and to optimize the use of internal resources. The highly articulated and technical text introduces important innovations that aim to make Parliament even more transparent and efficient, strengthening its institutional image and its listening ability towards citizens. Notable measures include: an increase in penalties for MEPs using defamatory, xenophobic and racist language; the definition of statements of financial interests of MPs more detailed and regular; a strengthening of the Code of Conduct and an explicit prohibition for deputies from working as salaried lobbyists. Written questions, motions for resolutions and calls for a roll-call vote are also more limited. The regulation will enter into force on 16 January 2017.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. - I voted against the general review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as I believe that it is a very important text that implies greater centralisation of power in large political groups to the detriment of small political groups. The AFCO Working Group on the Rules of Procedure devoted more than two years to the revision of the Rules of Procedure. The mandate of the working group was “to identify possible inconsistencies, redundancies, overlapping standards and, as far as possible, simplify standards”. Much of the changes proposed by the Working Group were technical (simplification of the text, incorporation of interpretations, adaptation of the legal basis, regrouping of provisions into new chapters, etc.). These changes are positive as they improve the readability of the Regulation. However, a number of substantial proposals could hinder the expression of smaller groups, particularly at the Plenary level, while larger groups would be more likely to act both in the Committee and in the Whole. In general, this means greater centralisation of power in Parliament for the benefit of larger groups.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the general review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. After many negotiations today, we voted on a text that wants to simplify some rules, but I also voted in favour of the amendments which called for transparency when enumerating the groups we met during our parliamentary work.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. — I voted against Mr Corbett's report on Parliament's Rules of Procedure, because I believe that it undermines democracy by, in particular, greatly reducing the prerogatives of so-called minority groups to the detriment of the two major parties of the establishment, 'Republicans' and Socialists. The establishment of a new group in Parliament is made much more difficult, as is the representation of non-registered members who are forced to have an official coordinator without having a say. In addition to the denial of this necessary pluralism of political parties, which is obliterated, freedom of expression itself seems to be at risk in this Parliament with sanctions with all words considered out of the norm: if I obviously condemn violence, the very aim of political mandates and the protection of the immunity of Members is to be able to do so hear their voice, even dissonant. Finally, parliamentary work itself tends to be monitored, with limited possibilities in terms of legislative procedures such as reducing the number of resolutions to one per month.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: In writing. - I cannot agree with the amendments made to the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, because these greatly restrict the work of us Members of the least large groups. As I feared, the strong pressure of the large groups has had the better and this text is a missed opportunity: instead of improving the parliamentary system of work to allow all the representatives of the citizens to make their voices heard, this text penalizes our work in opposition to the crazy policies of Brussels. For these reasons I expressed myself with a down vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I think there is no strong Parliament if there is no efficient regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this revision of the Regulation which aims to improve its functioning, increase transparency and adapt its content to the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Improvement of Legislation. I welcome the fact that the reform adopted includes proposals to improve efficiency in practical issues such as question time, voting on legislative acts and roll-call votes, as well as to integrate a gender perspective and include current discussions at each partsession on the proposal of political groups. In addition, the new Regulation introduces improvements in the field of transparency by introducing legislative footprint on reports, limiting meetings to interest groups that are registered in the transparency register and prohibiting the development of paid interest representation activities directly related to the Union decision process. However, I regret that other reforms that were seeking Members to publish meetings with interest groups online or the prohibition on remunerated work during their term have been rejected by the conservative majority in the European Chamber.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the joint review of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The European Parliament has regularly reviewed its Rules of Procedure, often after the adoption of new treaties which increased the powers of the European Parliament. In the present case, the rules are being restructured mainly for internal reasons, such as making Parliament more functioning, clarifying the rules, improving transparency, protecting Parliament from interference by political forces seeking to sabotage its work. Only a few amendments have been made due to wider changes, such as 2006. In the context of an interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking or on the establishment of new bodies in the context of a banking union. The most part of the work is technical, legal and linguistic, and it improves the details of the rules.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing. — I voted against this revision of the rules because of the limitations it will impose on individual members. These limits will impede the control function that the elected representatives of the people have the right and duty to exercise. Moreover, the new regulation does not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members of the minority.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which is extremely alarming and represents a major step backwards for democracy in Europe. This vote has been described as representing merely technical changes that will improve efficiency in the European Parliament. But the truth is these changes will have a dramatic political impact, by undermining democratic oversight, transparency and political pluralism. My top concern is the empowerment in the legislative process of the so-called trilogue. Trilogues are an undemocratic and illegitimate means of forming legislation that give undue power to the unelected officials of the Commission. This vote not only attempts to legitimise them but also means that once an agreement has been reached in trilogue, MEPs will no longer be able to amend the proposal in the plenary of Parliament. The ability of MEPs to question the Commission, to propose motions for resolutions, and to table amendments to legislative proposals will all be restricted. This will harm both our ability to effectively represent our constituents and to hold the Commission accountable. The power of the two major political groups, the conservative Christian Democrats (EPP) and the social democrats (S&D), will be further entrenched by the raising of procedural ‘thresholds’.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: In writing. ‒ The European Parliament has carried out regular revisions to its regulation, often following the adoption of new Treaties which strengthened its powers. Improve the efficiency of the functioning of parliamentary work, periodically devote some sittings to topical debates of great interest to European Union policy and allow each group political to ask for at least one debate per year, in addition to more involving the FEMM Committee on gender equality issues are useful elements in making our institution more active, closer to citizens and more useful to Europe.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: This general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament is supposed to increase transparency regarding the activities of Members of Parliament and improve the efficiency of the functioning of Parliament. To achieve this, it advocates that Members of Parliament be formally prohibited from holding paid lobbyists and making the declaration of financial interests of Members more comprehensive. Nonetheless, other elements in this amendment to the rules will impede the parliamentary activity of Members of Parliament. Starting with the proposal to limit the number of written questions to twenty per quarter, while only one motion for a resolution per month can be tabled per Member. Moreover, this report will help to restrict the freedom of expression of MEPs who are elected by the European peoples by direct universal suffrage. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - The Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament have been constantly revised, most of the time as new treaties have been adopted which have strengthened the powers of the European Parliament. This general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure is based on internal reasoning, namely: to improve the functioning of Parliament, to clarify the rules, to improve transparency, to protect Parliament from the elements of disruptive policy aimed at sabotaging its work. A number of measures aimed at technical, legal and linguistic changes have been proposed to improve the level of detail of the Regulation. At the same time, there are new rules aimed at streamlining the work of the European Parliament, amending provisions on the voting order of legislative acts, in order to become clearer, but also certain limitations in terms of the number of motions for resolutions, declarations written and written questions. I have expressed myself in favour of this proposal for a general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure because it becomes essential that the work in the European Parliament is constantly streamlined in order to be able to respond to all European challenges.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. - I think there is no strong Parliament if there is no efficient regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this revision of the Regulation which aims to improve its functioning, increase transparency and adapt its content to the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Improvement of Legislation. I welcome the fact that the reform adopted includes proposals to improve efficiency in practical issues such as question time, voting on legislative acts and roll-call votes, as well as to integrate a gender perspective and include current discussions at each partsession on the proposal of political groups. In addition, the new Regulation introduces improvements in the field of transparency by introducing legislative footprint on reports, limiting meetings to interest groups that are registered in the transparency register and prohibiting the development of paid interest representation activities directly related to the Union decision process. However, I regret that other reforms that were seeking Members to publish meetings with interest groups online or the prohibition on remunerated work during their term have been rejected by the conservative majority in the European Chamber.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure because it introduces rules that will make it more democratic, more transparent and more transparent efficient parliamentary institution. In the area of transparency, important is the introduction of the obligation for former MEPs to inform Parliament of their lobbying activities and the provision for the withdrawal of their access badge in the event of violation of this norm. The report also offers major improvements in efficiency and participation. For example, the plenary will always have a say in authorizing or denying the opening of negotiations with the other institutions in order to reach agreements at first reading. Rules were then introduced to strengthen sanctions against MPs making inappropriate statements or attempting to disrupt parliamentary activity. In the event of serious misconduct, an MP may be banned from representing Parliament outside (in external delegations or interinstitutional meetings, for example) for up to one year.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which will be a major step backwards in democracy in Europe. The new Rules of Procedure adopted will restrict the rights of individual members and smaller political groups, further centralising parliamentary power in the hands of the ‘grand coalition’, the conservative EPP and Social Democrats.  This vote has been described as representing merely technical changes that will improve efficiency in the European Parliament. But the truth is these changes will have a dramatic political impact, by undermining democratic oversight, transparency and political pluralism. My top concern is the empowerment in the legislative process of the so-called trilogue, described by a journalist recently as being the place ‘where European democracy goes to die’. Trilogues are an undemocratic and illegitimate means of forming legislation that give undue power to the unelected officials of the Commission. This vote not only attempts to legitimise them but also means that once an agreement has been reached in trilogue, MEPs will no longer be able to amend the proposal in the plenary of Parliament. For these reasons I voted against.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP could not vote for this report.  There were elements of the report that did not allow for representation by all the groups of Parliament. Furthermore, we could not vote for a report that would allow legislation to be fast-tracked without following the due procedure for scrutiny.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which reviewed the European Parliament Rules of Procedure  in order to make Parliament work better, clarify certain rules, improve transparency, and efficiency in our daily work. Following inappropriate incidents in plenary, several rules have been redrafted in order to improve the conduct of the plenary sittings and avoid abuses. The changes propose enhanced powers for the President to intervene and increase potential sanctions against individual Members.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: In writing. ‒ The changes made do not take into account the need to give adequate representation and autonomy to small groups and the text is also very lacking in the transparency profile. I therefore voted definitely negative.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this European Parliament regulation aimed at improving transparency within it, although from my point of view we have not gone far enough. This revision provides for more detailed financial statements by MEPs and the strengthening of their code of conduct, so this is a good start to achieve greater transparency. I find it interesting that now a mandate from Parliament as a whole is needed in order to negotiate between MEPs and the Council with a view to concluding an agreement at first reading. Our legislative work will thus be better apprehended. Finally, and it is an excellent thing, from the next legislature, the groups themselves will be able to nominate their members to the posts of Presidents and Vice-Presidents of Committees.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the outcome reached today after a year and a half’s worth of hard work, but critical progress remains blocked by the usual conservative suspects. Candidates to the posts of EU Commissioners will in the future be much more tightly scrutinised for conflicts of interest, made all the more necessary by recent revolving door scandals. As far as our own House is concerned, we have enhanced the disclosure and updating requirements of MEPs’ parallel sources of income, banned Members from the outrageous practice of engaging in lobbying activities aimed at their own colleagues, and explicitly asked that MEPs refuse to meet unregistered lobbyists. I and other colleagues, and the staff in our offices, have personally abided by such practices for a long time, and have gone even beyond them in terms of the information we publish. I personally think that most second jobs are outright incompatible with the responsibilities of a parliamentarian and would like to see the legislation laying out our statute revisited to that end. Unfortunately, many colleagues held us hostage to what is literally business as usual to some of them, on pain of blocking any progress at all, but we must keep up the pressure.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are voting in favour of the report. The revision of the Rules of Procedure is mainly due to internal reasons, such as improving the functioning of Parliament, clarifying the rules and increasing transparency.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. Although it is commonly accepted that we need to revise and improve Parliament's Rules of Procedure, I think this report is an attempt to adopt conservative and restrictive rules which will work to the detriment of freedom of speech and the possibility of which is why I voted against it.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against. The proposed revision of this regulation further penalises small political groups and restricts all kinds of opposition activities.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: ‒ Few totems are comparable to the revision of the regulation in terms of complexity and regulatory acumen, as well as diplomatic skill in dealing with colleagues, but outside my support and full reliance on the result obtained. First, the freedom and independence of MEPs are reiterated. Among the changes made, I have shared in particular some of them, and among these is the simplification of the ordinary legislative procedure since Parliament will first vote on possible proposal for an immediate report of the draft legislative act submitted in writing. Where this is accepted, then the project would lapse, otherwise the conclusion of the procedure will be declared. With regard to the bureaucratic lightening, I welcome the facilitation in drafting the Commission's work programme. The latter, the result of cooperation between Parliament and the Commission as provided for in the Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better legislation', is then analysed by the Council and sets objectives and top priorities of organs. What's more, documentations reflecting the outcome of the trilogues will be made public. Together with these facilitations aimed at speeding up the entire EU decision-making process, there are limitations on the submission of written questions, an instrument of which some colleagues tend to abuse for mere statistical purposes. I hope that such a review will provide more ready and effective responses to citizens.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the general revision of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. However, I opposed abolishing written declarations as they allow MEPs to voice issues of concern to their constituents.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP could not vote for this report.  There were elements of the report that did not allow for representation by all the groups of Parliament. Furthermore, we could not vote for a report that would allow legislation to be fast-tracked without following the due procedure for scrutiny.

name: Lara COMI
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the General Review Decision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure as I agree with the changes proposed by the AFCO Committee, which highlight the simplification of voting thresholds in plenary and committee, the composition of committees and delegations, the simplification of the procedure for electing the Bureau, as well as a series of other measures relating to the functioning of Parliament.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted against this revision of Parliament's rules of procedure, because it will reduce the ability to influence the parliamentary work of small groups, leaving this House at the service of popular and socialists, who see their capacity to define working times and speed up the legislation of interest to them, blocking amendments and debates that they consider hostile. And the same will happen with other forms of initiative, such as questions and statements, that small groups have been using to influence the political agenda beyond agreements between the majority groups.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's Rules of Procedure have undergone several changes in recent years to generate better regulation. The European Union is always trying to become more transparent in decision-making, but also closer to every citizen of it. I voted for the revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure so that those procedural gaps are overcome and the results are seen as soon as possible in the life of every citizen in the bloc.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - As a result of several years of conciliation work, Parliament's Rules of Procedure have been amended, which will enter into force next year. The Parliament's session is being reformed by changes resulting from the revision, which also clarifies, inter alia, the part concerning the handling of petitions falling within the competence of the Committee on Petitions (Article 216). This includes a new section on fact-finding visits to the Member States, giving a precise description of the substance of the fact-finding visits and the work to be carried out by the Commission, as well as amendments and additions to the petition portal for accepted petitions also for information.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure of Parliament, which I believe will improve and improve the existing rules defining the working mode of Parliament and MPs. The report on the proposed amendments and new developments follows the 18-month work of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure Working Group, which included members of the AFCO committee and representatives of all groups represented in Parliament. The aim of the work was primarily to simplify the Rules of Finally, the report included proposals for changes to the Rules of Procedure, on which MPs gained broad consensus. Most proposals for amendments are technical, legal or linguistic in nature aimed at improving transparency in the Rules of Procedure.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as this new set of Rules aims at making the European Union more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens. I agree with the rapporteur that the overhaul of the [text] can help Parliament operate better, clarify rules, and improve transparency.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I was unable to vote in favour of a report that was seeking to abolish written declarations and limit the number of oral explanations of vote Members can make. These are both tools which offer a voice to backbenchers in the parliament and are an important part of the legitimate democracy of the European Parliament.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: In writing. ‒ With today's vote, the reform of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament was adopted, which aims to improve functioning and ensure greater rationalisation the work of the only European institution directly elected by its citizens. The changes that have been made and which I strongly supported are reasonable and balanced. I am convinced that these changes will help to make parliamentary work not only more efficient and transparent, but also better withstand possible interference from anti-political groups -Europeans, who often try to prevent the regular conduct of work. In the new regulation, which will enter into force as early as January 2017, discriminatory or racist languages will no longer be tolerated in any way, or conducted that harm the credibility of the European institutions. Specific provisions will also be made to avoid conflicts of interest or untransparent and clear relations between Members and the lobbies. A result that was achieved thanks to the political commitment and will of the Socialists and Democrats group.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: This legislative report deals with the general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which governs internal organisation and work within the institution. Among the flagship measures, the report proposes a package of measures to improve the transparency of legislative work and avoid conflicts of interest of Members by revising the Code of Conduct. This report also aims to strengthen democratic control, in the context of negotiations with the Council of Ministers, through a vote on the mandate of the Parliament's negotiator in plenary session and not in parliamentary committee. Political groups may also be able to request thematic debates in plenary sessions more easily. Considering that this reform aims to improve the democratic legitimacy and integrity of legislative work in the European Parliament, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP could not vote for this report. There were elements of the report that did not allow for representation by all the groups of Parliament. Furthermore, we could not vote for a report that would allow legislation to be fast-tracked without following the due procedure for scrutiny.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on a general review aimed at improving the functioning of Parliament and clarifying some of its regulations. I particularly support measures that will allow for greater transparency. For example, I voted in favour of the paragraph proposing the prohibition for MEPs who are directly related to the Union's decision-making process from engaging in paid lobbying activities. I also voted in favour of the paragraph calling for the deletion of written statements, in the interests of greater efficiency of parliamentary work.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted against this revision. There are some positive points in this general revision of the rules: the formal prohibition for Members of Parliament from holding paid lobbyists, more complete statements of financial interest by Members, and the prohibition for Members of Parliament to trade with lobbyists registered in the transparency register. Furthermore, the text strengthens sanctions against “defamatory, racist (s) or xenophobic (s)”: the defamatory, racist (s) or xenophobic (s)”: the deputy who is the author would be subject to a suspension of 2 to 30 days of the daily allowance and/or participation in Parliament's activities, in particular. Nevertheless, this revision results in further restricting the rights of the opposition. The main levers of MEPs are narrowly limited: a Member will only be able to ask a maximum of 20 written questions over a period of three consecutive months and issue a motion for a resolution per month. Written statements are deleted. Topical debates can be rejected by at least 80% of the groups at the Conference of Presidents.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. This report relates to the work of a working group whose task was to amend and amend the Rules of Procedure of the EP. In this working group there was one member from each political group. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the changes proposed by the working group will contribute to transparency and enhancing democracy in the European Parliament.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The revised regulation, as proposed in the report to be voted on, will have a major blow to the independence of Members in the performance of their duties and to the excessive limitation of the national (where applicable) competence of the judicial/tax authorities in the proceedings audit of these financial data. The vote in favour of this text will lead to an uncontrollable limitation of Members' ability to act by making their role a resounding decorative one.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe it will give my constituents in Wales more information on how Parliament works and will also make it more effective. I supported amendments by my Group to strengthen the transparency and gender mainstreaming proposals.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — The revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as desired and disappointing in its final result, is yet another testimony to the concentration of the management of power and the rules in the hands of large political groups with the usual agreement of broadsides intended to the detriment of minorities. The possibilities for expression and intervention by smaller political groups and individual Members are reduced, no update of the Code of Conduct and the rules on conflict of interest, no formal recognition of the d'Hondt method which will continue to be used instrumental for the use and consumption of large political groups, as has been the case on time during these two and a half years of Legislature. Finally, the call for more transparency from citizens is completely ignored, fuelling even more that enormous distance that separates them from institutions and fuels the sense of mistrust. For these reasons I voted against the report.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of rules that make our work even more transparent, while also ensuring that everyone, even small and not equally organised organisations, should have the opportunity to contact us. I have also voted to abolish the procedure with written declarations where its political importance is extremely small. My hope is that the new rules will contribute to more efficient and more transparent work in Parliament.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has regularly revised its Rules of Procedure, often following the adoption of new treaties which have strengthened the powers of the institution. The proposal makes it possible to provide Parliament with a better modus operandi, clarify the Rules of Procedure, increase transparency and defend Parliament from disturbances caused by political elements wished to sabotage its work.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing. — Vote against because of the limits it will impose on individual members of parliament. Moreover, the new regulation does not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members of the minority.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Faced with the profound and persistent crisis in which the EU is immersed, the reaction of the main forces that have determined its course - the right and social democracy - is to strengthen anti-democratic instruments. This is another example. These amendments, as a whole, severely limit the power of Members and smaller political groups, and further increase the power of the large groups. Amendments to reports and opinions, written questions to other institutions, resolutions, explanations of vote, participation in specialised committees - all this is severely limited. Written declarations - an instrument that has allowed important struggles to be expressed (two recent examples: renegotiation of debts or replenishment of milk quotas) - are abolished. Instruments for democratic control of the work carried out by Parliament and Members are weakened or eliminated, in particular by imposing accelerated procedures and reducing the possibilities of requesting 'roll-call votes'. It is a case to say that some are afraid or ashamed to assume the positions they take here. PS, PSD and CDS voted in favour. The CFP voted against and put forward many dozens of proposals that would strengthen democracy, pluralism and transparency in the functioning of the European Parliament.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision on the general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as it adequately clarifies and simplifies a number of rules, in particular with regard to the subsidiarity clause and the election of the President of the Commission.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report because it penalizes small groups and greatly restricts all kinds of opposition activities.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - The revised regulation will have a major blow to the independence of Members in the performance of their duties and to the excessive limitation of the national (where applicable) competence of the judicial/tax authorities in the process of verifying these financial data. The vote in favour of this text will lead to the uncontrollable limitation of Members' ability to act by making their role a resounding decorative, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament has regularly reviewed its Rules of Procedure, often following the adoption of new treaties that enhanced the powers of the European Parliament. On this occasion, the overhaul of the rules is largely due to internal reasons: to make Parliament operate better, to clarify the rules, to improve transparency, to protect Parliament from disruption by political elements intent on sabotaging its work.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: In writing. ‒ I thank my colleagues in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs for the impressive work of drafting and negotiating which led to the approval of the new Rules of Procedure of Parliament. We have an instrument that will enable us to better respond to the political challenges of the Union and make our legislative process more effective and democratic.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: in writing. — The revision of the Rules of Procedure is mainly for internal and technical reasons to enable Parliament to act more efficiently. The rules of the Rules of Procedure should be clarified and transparency improved.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I could not vote for this report. There were elements of the report that did not allow for representation by all the groups of Parliament. Furthermore, I could not vote for a report that would allow legislation to be fast-tracked without following the due procedure for scrutiny.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which includes important reforms to make the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens. This report crucially allows us to take significant steps forward on transparency: MEPs will be banned from taking a paid lobbying job during their mandate, and after they step down, their privileges as ex-MEPs – such as having free access to Parliament – will be denied if they become lobbyists after their mandate.  Another key measure is the imposition of stronger sanctions against anyone making defamatory or xenophobic statements in plenary.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. — I voted against the revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. Under the guise of efficiency, or adaptation, many of the provisions in it reduce the individual rights of MPs, reinforce the prerogatives of groups over their members (in contradiction with the necessary independence of MPs) and those of large groups over small groups. I mention in passing the new vexatious little measures against non-registered Members, to dubious legality. But it is worse: the possibility and even freedom of expression of elected officials and opposition groups are limited. Of course, I am thinking of the mirrobolising possibility of censorship within the Chamber itself, which will make it possible to punish any Member who fails to comply with the multiculturalist doxa. I am also thinking of the organisation of the legislative process, which aims to ensure that European laws are only the subject of a single vote, without debate, on the consensus reached in committee by a handful of shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs: restrictions on the tabling of amendments, separate or divided votes, etc. Paradoxically, while these laws govern the lives of 500 million citizens, the organization of lobbying favours large pressure groups. You are doing very hard: you invented Parliament where it is more difficult to speak every day.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - I voted against the general review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as I believe that it is a very important text that implies greater centralisation of power in large political groups to the detriment of small political groups. The AFCO Working Group on the Rules of Procedure devoted more than two years to the revision of the Rules of Procedure. The mandate of the working group was “to identify possible inconsistencies, redundancies, overlapping standards and, as far as possible, simplify standards”. Much of the changes proposed by the Working Group were technical (simplification of the text, incorporation of interpretations, adaptation of the legal basis, regrouping of provisions into new chapters, etc.). These changes are positive as they improve the readability of the Regulation. However, a number of substantial proposals could hinder the expression of smaller groups, particularly at the Plenary level, while larger groups would be more likely to act both in the Committee and in the Whole. In general, this means greater centralisation of power in Parliament for the benefit of larger groups.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: In the context of the general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, I wanted to defend a global logic, namely to ensure consistency between the elections to the posts of President, Vice-Presidents and Quaestors in the European Parliament and the posts of President and Commissioners for the European Commission. There must be an identical system for everyone, not secret ballot votes for one institution and roll-call votes for the other.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on the general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure because improving the functioning of Parliament is essential. It is important to have clear rules that improve transparency and ensure Parliament's protection against disruptive political elements aimed at sabotaging its work. Given that the European Parliament represents the interests of citizens, it is important that this institution is effective, transparent and trustworthy.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the General Revision of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure as this is a reform which makes the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In support of the report by Mr Richard Corbett, I voted in favour of improving the functioning and transparency of the European Parliament while preventing attempts to sabotage parliamentary activity. This amendment is also a means of putting an end to the tricks to “improve” the statistics of Members of Parliament, which are in no way true legislative work. Several provisions have also been adopted on the Code of Conduct for Members to strengthen ethics and transparency. Thus, deputies will automatically be punished in cases of defamatory, racist, xenophobic or actions disrupting parliamentary activity. The new rules confirm the establishment of a “legislative footprint”, which consists in documenting contacts with interest representatives as part of the preparation of their work. Above all, it will no longer be possible to have a paid lobbyist job. These new rules are really going in the right direction, to move our House towards greater ethics and efficiency.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. - I think there is no strong Parliament if there is no efficient regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this revision of the Regulation which aims to improve its functioning, increase transparency and adapt its content to the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Improvement of Legislation. I welcome the fact that the reform adopted includes proposals to improve efficiency in practical issues such as question time, voting on legislative acts and roll-call votes, as well as to integrate a gender perspective and include current discussions at each partsession on the proposal of political groups. In addition, the new Regulation introduces improvements in the field of transparency by introducing legislative footprint on reports, limiting meetings to interest groups that are registered in the transparency register and prohibiting the development of paid interest representation activities directly related to the Union decision process. However, I regret that other reforms that were seeking Members to publish meetings with interest groups online or the prohibition on remunerated work during their term have been rejected by the conservative majority in the European Chamber.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards its citizens, and with this modernisation, Parliament can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - We voted against the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, since this was an attempt by the large political groups to restrict the rights of small groups, as well as the rights of MEPs. Instead of expanding democracy and the possibility of highlighting issues and greater intervention, in fact, with the changes that have taken place, this possibility has been limited, which we are strongly opposed to. Similarly, the questions of transparency which we had proposed were unfortunately not accepted by the majority in plenary.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that amends the European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. This revision will make the overall operation of Parliament more transparent and counter disruptive parliamentary practices. For example, this new procedure now prohibits any paid lobbyist work for Members of Parliament, while former Members of Parliament must register for such activity. It also proposes a strengthening of sanctions that can be imposed on a Member of Parliament in the event of non-compliance with the rules of conduct.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This new set of rules will make the European Parliament more transparent, efficient, open and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favour of a proposal for a European Parliament decision on a general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament because I believe it is necessary to ensure greater transparency and improve the functioning of Parliament. A large part of the amendments made by this proposal concern technical and legal nature, however, there are also major changes that directly affect the work of this institution. I keep it essential that certain procedures are streamlined to make Parliament's business more efficient, faster and consistent, and I support the potentiation of gender-conscious politics and gender equality. More efficient implementation of the European Parliament's activities leads to greater trust of citizens and to an improvement of interinstitutional agreements.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — The very technical composition of this text is a threat because of the various limitations it imposes on Members of Parliament, first and foremost the obstacle that Members will encounter in their supervisory function. Similarly, the new regulation further violates the rights of minority MPs and, by its configuration, prevents the Patriot elected representatives from proposing topics for a current debate. I voted against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure in order to have a more streamlined and efficient working environment in which MEPs can represent their citizens in an even more transparent manner. In addition, we have strengthened the sanctions provisions in order to ensure Members cannot abuse their positions. For example if the Member is not complying with the rules of conduct the President can go so far as to withdraw one or more posts held by the Member concerned. I am of the view that these arrangements will lead to the European Parliament working in a more transparent manner.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Richard Corbett on the revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. The purpose of this procedure is to make Parliament's work more efficient and transparent by specifying certain operating rules. For example, the new regulation of the European Parliament will strengthen sanctions against Members who make racist or defamatory statements and disrupt parliamentary activity, which I welcome. I also supported several provisions on transparency consistent with my personal approach to the subject. Indeed, I am committed to publishing on my website every month the list of interest representatives that my team and I meet in the framework of my European mandate.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure because it will make it better to function by specifying certain rules.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. — I voted against this report. In addition to some necessary revisions of paragraphs and technical amendments, there are indeed successful and positive changes. The aim is to increase transparency by means of a “legislative footprint”. The assessment is negative from a political and strategic point of view. Smaller groups and non-attached Members are restricted by ceilings for written questions, motions for resolutions, amendments, etc. I also consider the restrictions on free speech in plenary and committees to be questionable. Equally critical can be taken of the provision that, when the 14 Vice-Presidents of the European Parliament are elected, at least seven names must be on the ballot for it to be valid. This is tentless compulsion to have to elect politically unloving candidates.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which makes the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — As representative of the EU's only directly elected body, I could not support in the vote the report on the overall revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure as it introduces so-called speed laws. I believe that issues such as the common asylum policy, the system of compulsory registration on entry to Schengen, the reform of the Juncker investment package, the common basis for calculating corporate tax or a contentious directive on the possession of firearms should not be addressed behind closed doors. This is how we will only strengthen the influence of the European lobby and reduce transparency, thereby only distancing ourselves to EU citizens.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. - I supported the adoption of the report on a thorough revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as I believe that this way the institution will work better, increase transparency, the EP will be protected from political attempts to block its work. More substantial changes to the regulations are dictated by the one adopted in 2016. An interinstitutional agreement on better law-making, as well as the creation of new bodies in the context of the banking union. The observations of the 2015 Corbot report on procedures and practices in relation to the hearings of Commissioners are also enshrined in the formation of the new rules. The amendments aimed at improving the efficiency of work are the order of voting on legislative acts, Question Time, Question Question Questions from the Commission, Motions for Resolutions, Named Votes and Written Declarations. Members will henceforth be sanctioned by the President if they use defamatory, racist or xenophobic language, or if they take action that disrupts parliamentary activity. In the rest, the amendments are predominantly dictated by technical, legal and linguistic considerations.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: In writing. — After two years of intense work, Parliament has succeeded by a great majority in reforming its rules of regulation. The reform takes a big step towards clarifying existing rules and allows for greater transparency within Parliament. I supported this report not only because I believe that it is positively in the direction of the greater effectiveness of parliamentary work, but also because it shows a clear signal of Parliament in comparisons of those members who use defamatory, racist and xenophobic language. Sanctions against members using this language, undermining the smooth conduct of parliamentary work, have been strengthened in the most serious cases and doubled in the event of recidivism with the loss the right to represent Parliament externally. Parliament has today taken a step forward by clarifying how the use of this language is incompatible with the exercise of the civil service.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — The report to the vote concerns the rules of the European Parliament. It achieves several objectives, such as simplifying current thresholds in plenary and committee, composition of committees whose members are appointed by political groups, composition members of interparliamentary delegations, the streamlining of the election of the EP Bureau, interinstitutional negotiations, voting procedures and verification of compliance with the principles of subsidiarity, proportionality and gender equality, among other points. I believe that the proposal has a clear simplification and transparency intent, ensuring a better functioning of the EP.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. — In order to enable the European Parliament to function better, to clarify the rules in force and to improve transparency in our House, we have embarked on a thorough revision of our rules of procedure. A highly technical vote, and without direct impact on the fate of our fellow citizens, it is of real importance since we have decided to change the rules of the game between the political groups in our House and to clarify certain rules in the direction of greater transparency. The major novelty of this revision is the creation of a session of topical debates organized at the initiative of the political groups. However, I wanted to express my opposition to a number of changes that I consider useless. In particular, I voted against the deletion of written statements, a mobilization tool that sometimes allowed members to bring to the attention of their colleagues a topic dear to our fellow citizens.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. — I voted against the general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament because of the limits it will impose on individual Members. These limits will impede the control function that the elected representatives of the people have the right and duty to exercise. Moreover, the new regulation does not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members of the minority. For example, all political groups will have the right to propose at least one topic for a current debate per year. However, if 80% of the groups at the Conference of Presidents oppose a proposed topic, it will not be accepted. This rule will serve to gag sovereignist and patriotic forces. In the area of censorship, we must also denounce the rule punishing “racist and xenophobic” statements. This should not concern me, except that these accusations are misused and through the EP.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. — I objected to this revision of the rules. Indeed, it restricts the freedom of action and expression of MEPs, who are representatives of the people's voice in the European Parliament. Moreover, this new regulation does not sufficiently protect the rights of members in minority positions (non-registered, small groups...). For example, all political groups will have the right to propose at least one topical debate per year. However, if 80% of the groups, at the conference of group presidents, oppose a proposed subject, then it will be dismissed. This rule is therefore a quick way to gag small groups, and therefore the most patriotic groups, so these abusive changes are inadmissible.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — As has happened regularly, Parliament revises and amend its Rules of Procedure with the intention of improving it and adapting it to the new powers that are being attributed to it. In this particular case, some amendments result from the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on the improvement of legislation or the creation of new bodies by the banking union. The new regulation includes amendments to agreements at first reading, whereby absolute majority approval in committees for the opening of negotiations with other institutions will be announced in the plenary, which will vote on it if one tenth of the Members of Parliament oppose. In addition, and, inter alia, current debates will be organised at each partsession, a more thorough monitoring of the declarations of economic interests of Members will be carried out, and in order to polish parliamentary activity, the thresholds for Parliament's various procedures are amended. I vote in favour because these measures will increase transparency as well as the functioning of Parliament. And there is no doubt that such an objective contributes to a stronger and better European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that updates Parliament’s Rules of Procedure.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I voted against. The Rules of Procedure determine the rules of voting, committee formation, interpellations, etc. The Rules of Procedure are to have stability and are to be changed only by choice. For them to work, they must be experienced. This is a large set of changes that do not mark an unequivocal shift for the better, so I favour the existing rules of procedure from the principle of caution. Nor do I agree with the new Article 47a, under which the committees will be able to agree “in coordination with the Council and the Commission to accelerate the legislative process.” That, I think, is an impermissible mixing of power by the legislative and executive.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — The objective of the general review of the Rules of Procedure is to improve the functioning of Parliament, clarify regulations, increase transparency and protect Parliament from political elements intended to sabotage its work. Most of the changes are technical, legal and linguistic nature and clarify the provisions of the Rules of Procedure. The new rules increase transparency, more clearly set out the order of voting on legislation, the double vote is lifted and sanctions for serious cases of misconduct are tighter. So I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament is taking several steps forward on transparency.  MEPs will be banned from taking a paid lobbying job during their mandate. After they step down, their privileges as ex-MEPs – such as having free access to the Parliament – will be denied if they become lobbyists after their mandate. Rapporteurs will be able to list the people they have met while writing their report. I think the formula is simple: more transparency – more trust.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. — I support the amendments to the EP's Rules of Procedure, which should contribute to a more efficient and flexible functioning of Parliament and better law-making. Reducing the maximum number of written questions for a single Member will increase the responsibility of Members for asking genuinely relevant questions, while reducing bureaucracy and the cost of processing answers. Similarly, increasing transparency and further procedural adjustments will help to understand the processes in the EP and the public more comprehensible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/12/2016, and because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The purpose of this text is to revise Parliament's Rules of Procedure and contains many positive elements aimed at, for example, greater transparency or the prohibition of the cumulation of the functions of paid MPs and lobbyists. On the other hand, certain limits are imposed on individual Members. The control function of Members of Parliament will be diminished and the new rules do not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members in a minority position.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: In writing. — My positive vote went to the report on the general revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The changes envisaged by this proposal, which take into account the provisions of the Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better legislation' of 2016, aim at improving equipment important for procedures MPs, like the IT. This proposal for a decision can also reveal its usefulness in pursuing ever greater clarity and transparency in the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament and its Members.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we voted on the report proposing an overall revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The report proposes a range of provisions that will reduce the already capped powers of smaller political factions and individual MPs. More demands are being made for voting with the help of a qualified majority, which will not be of any benefit to small political factions. This, in my opinion, reduces the democratism of this institution even further. For example, the abolition of written declarations, limiting the scope and possibilities of referring written questions to the Commission and other institutions, as well as limiting the possibility of submitting draft resolutions. This will lead to a narrowing of the possibilities of individual MPs to undertake parliamentary activities. I could not agree with the vast majority of the proposed changes, so I voted against the report in the final vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: in writing. - On Tuesday, the revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure was voted on, which also aims to increase transparency through a 'legislative footprint'. This will improve the understanding of the activities and influence of EU lobbyists and stakeholders and their relations with MEPs. The proposed amendments also include a stricter code of conduct for Members and tougher sanctions in the event of disruptions to Parliament's work. Negotiating mandates for compromise talks with the Council will also have to be adopted by the plenary at first reading from 2017.
