The declarations of Members' financial interests should also be described and examined in more detail under the new rules. The assessment is negative from a political point of view. In some areas, EPP and S&D have cleverly restricted the rights of smaller groups, non-attached and individual MEPs by means of ceilings on written questions, motions for resolutions and amendments. The restriction of free speech in plenary and in the committees is particularly drastic, where pointed speeches are likely to be classified as “xenophobic” or “xenophobic” in the future and thus prohibit them. The provision that the election of the 14 EP Vice-Presidents must also be considered absurd to include at least seven names on the ballot in order for it to be valid. This is tentless compulsion to have to elect politically unloving candidates. That is why I did not support this report.

name: Alex MAYER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the changes to the European Parliament’s rules of procedure, which was led by my Labour colleague Richard Corbett MEP, as it will make the European Parliament more transparent and clamps down on MEPs having second jobs as lobbyists.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - The review of Parliament's Rules of Procedure has worked for more than a year by a working group representing the various groups. Above 700 proposals have been submitted to change and improve Parliament's working order. The most part of the work is technical, legal and linguistic, and it improves the details of the rules. However, there are a number of amendments that are of greater importance and which not all political groups have succeeded in agreeing. The substantive changes concern procedural matters, the elections of Parliament, the President of the Commission, the appointment of MEPs to work in committees, the setting of thresholds for voting, etc. It is likely that, even with the adoption of the amendments, absolutely all bureaucratic, administrative failures, political disagreements on the procedural issues of the EP, but it must be hoped that this step will still help Parliament to work more transparently and smoothly than before.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament aims under the guise of 'simplification' to reduce the powers of parliamentarians. This includes restricting the possibilities of expression of “small” political groups to increase those of the “large”. Thus, the thresholds for amendment tabling, requests for votes (RCVs) and motions for resolutions have been reduced to three main thresholds (5%, 10%, 20%) which allow large groups (EPP and S&D) to act alone when small ones are prevented from doing so. In addition, the revision of the Rules increases the political power of the groups to the detriment of Members of Parliament. Thus, the seats of committees and delegations will belong to the political groups that will have the right to distribute them among their members. For the general purpose of limiting the expressions of Members, members will no longer be allowed to file written statements and will be able to make only one explanation of oral vote per day. The nickname evaluation agencies of elected officials will better wax the pumps of those who pay them. So much to reduce the already weak power of MEPs, as much as to suppress the European Parliament right away. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: This revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure leads to a tightening of the rules allowing the Member to exercise and will cut the minority or individual Members of Parliament from certain controls which they have the right and duty to exercise. Conversely, this revision does not sufficiently ensure the rights of minority MEPs thus reinforcing the limitation of the democratic functioning of the European institution. It is therefore for these reasons that I voted against this revision.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: I voted in favour of the report on the general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, which sets out in general the measures necessary to strengthen Parliament's powers. This approach is also part of an effort to make it work better, notably by improving a number of rules on transparency and accountability. In this way, for example, it will henceforth be prohibited from being both a member of Parliament and from serving as paid consultants. In addition, the Code of Conduct for Members will also be strengthened, harshly punishing those who engage in actions aimed at disrupting parliamentary activity, with the aim of strengthening the sense of responsibility of the members of our institution. In these periods of nationalist retreat, and the rise of racism and xenophobia, it was necessary to punish MEPs who take extreme postures, in total contradiction with European values.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on the European Parliament to adopt a new set of Rules that will make it more transparent, efficient, open and ready to listen to European citizens

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The European Parliament shall regularly review its Rules of Procedure. This amendment was proposed by an eighth working group after 18 months of consultation. The proposed recast was aimed at making Parliament more functional, clarifying the rules, increasing transparency and protecting Parliament's functioning from the political elements wishing to sabotage its work. In its report, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs proposed that Parliament amend its Rules of Procedure on 284 points on the basis of a proposal from the working group. However, the amendments that would have ensured greater transparency and publicity in Parliament's operation would have tightened the declaration of wealth, the majority, unlike me, did not vote for it. In my view, the most important objective of this review has become naught, and I have therefore voted against this amendment of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. — We voted against this revision of the rules because of the limits it will impose on individual members. These limits will impede the control function that the elected representatives of the people have the right and duty to exercise. Moreover, the new regulation does not sufficiently guarantee the rights of members of the minority. For example, all political groups will have the right to propose at least one topic for a current debate per year. However, if 80% of the groups at the Conference of Presidents oppose a proposed topic, it will not be accepted. This rule will serve to gag the patriotic forces. In the area of censorship, we must also denounce the rule punishing “racist and xenophobic” or defamatory statements. It leaves the administration and other elected officials the right to censor, under the guise of this rule, any comments that criticize, for example, the policy of reception of migrants. Of course, all this is done with the political aim of silencing the Eurosceptics.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The possibility is now offered to the Speaker of Parliament to erase entire passages of certain speeches that dislike him from the audiovisual archives. It looks like Stalin's idea! Moreover, the powers of questioning of MEPs are considerably reduced, which further diminishes the already limited interest of this a-democratic institution. I am voting against this aberrant report, which proves once again that the UERSS deserves this nickname.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome these reforms, which make the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, which governs the legislative procedure and more generally the functioning of our institution. This revision makes the organization of Parliament more transparent and efficient. It eliminates certain provisions that have become obsolete, and prohibits all paid lobbyist work for MEPs in order to avoid conflicts of interest.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament are regularly reviewed in order to be up to date following adoptions of new treaties that enhance the power of the European Parliament. I have voted for this report on the general revision of the European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the general revision of the Rules of Procedure because the level of debates in recent years in the European Parliament has reached a level that requires certain sanctions to be tightened. I refer to members of this respectable forum who have offensive behavior and use racist or xenophobic messages in public speeches. I support and have always held debates, I have encouraged in political work the expression of differences of views, as each of my colleagues represents the views and visions of a particular group of citizens of the European Union and must represent them. At the same time, I reject in all conditions extremist, defamatory, racist or xenophobic messages that, in my opinion, have no place in a democratic institution.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. — I supported the revision of the rules of procedure of the EP, which should lead to rationalisation and greater efficiency of the EP's work at all stages of the decision-making process. And this without preventing MPs from showing their views and positions. I also agree with the restriction of certain statistically recorded activities of MPs, which have either lost their justification in relation to strengthening the powers of the EP as a whole, or tend to be overused and trigger increased administrative costs.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: in writing. — I opposed the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure because I cannot support a number of points in the report. An example of this would be the restriction of free speech in plenary and in the committees, where in future, pointed speeches would be considered and will be prohibiting as xenophobic.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. The review of the rules of procedure is carried out regularly This aim is once again to enhance the work of the Parliament, to clarify the rules, to increase transparency and to prevent sabotage of Parliament. Among other things, various measures to increase efficiency will be reduced, for example, by limiting the number of proposals for a resolution, the number of questions to be answered in writing, and by proposing the abolition of written declarations. The possibility of punishing a Member of Parliament for defamatory, racist or xenophobic behaviour that disrupts Parliament's actions has yet to be brought in.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament is equipped with its own Rules of Procedure. This reform has aimed at updating the internal legislation, with two main objectives: improving operability and transparency, clarification of certain rules. These changes have been the result of extensive technical work, and a negotiation that has lasted almost two years. We have sought to reduce obstacles and simplify internal decision-making processes, in addition to adapting the legislation to the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Legislation that it wants to give, and we will see if so, more weight to Parliament. Finally, some of the new measures is the new debates on issues of particular relevance and topical in the Union, which will enable Parliament to assess what is urgent. We're slow. I am ashamed of helplessness in the face of the political and humanitarian crisis and this regulation is not a miraculous solution, but it is a little better.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. — The already deeply reactionary regulation is becoming more reactionary with its revision, which strengthens the structure and mechanism for promoting the EU's anti-grassroots policy. It aims to facilitate the political forces of capital in their anti-grassroots movements and compromises “behind closed doors” in order to avoid popular reactions in conditions of increased monopoly competition. It aims to further control the composition of parliamentary committees, to limit the right to speak and the possibility of MEPs to intervene (e.g. restriction of questions, oral explanations of vote, abolition of the possibility of debating an unanswered question in plenary). The new regulation, to an even greater extent than the previous one, serves the aspirations of the political forces who defend the capitalist system and those within its framework deceive the peoples with illusions of pro-popular management, by attempting to silence every case the voice of the Communists, who reveal capitalist barbarity and call to overthrow it. This is the “parliamentary democracy” of the chapter advertised by the bourgeoisie and its political representatives. The people can, through their struggle, put their mark on developments, questioning the sovereignty of monopolies and claiming the economic and political power that will serve their interests.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of these new rules: they must enable the European Parliament to function better and improve transparency.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because with the new regulation Parliament's work will be more coherent and accountable, thanks to the status of an organic and innovative body of norms. It is about fulfilling the duty of responsibility to the citizens of the European Union, supporting a reform that represents the happy epilogue of long and meticulous work. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Given the changing political landscape in the European Union and globally, I believe that it is necessary to adapt the Rules of Procedure of our House accordingly in order to be able to deliver quicker and better. For this reason I voted in favour of streamlining the current thresholds at plenary and committee level, also supporting the clarifications of some aspects of the legislative procedure and the inter-institutional negotiations and other provisions. The European Parliament must lead by example.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported the decision on a general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. As in all Member States, citizens also ask the European Parliament to work effectively and transparently by their representative bodies. The proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure aim to enable efficient performance of work through coherent and mutual communication with other EU bodies. I welcome the restriction whereby each MP will be able to ask a maximum of 20 questions over a three-month period. Deputies' issues are an important tool for MPs and representing the interests of citizens. This measure seeks to focus problems on the most important ones, but also to give sufficient space to the competent agencies of the services and bodies to answer questions competently, professionally, and comprehensively. I also welcome the simplification of the procedures for the adoption of legislative acts, but most of all I support amendments that further emphasize the role and importance of national parliaments through verifying compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Unfortunately, this article refers exclusively to legislative acts and opinions that it should be extended to non-legislative acts. Member States should be able, if anything, to object to frequent cases of European Parliament interference in cases falling within the exclusive competence of Member States.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - This revision of the Rules of Procedure has been given by the European Parliament a new set of rules that will make Parliament more transparent, efficient, open and willing to listen to European citizens. Particularly important are the transparency changes, which should point out the provision that European parliamentarians will no longer perform paid professional lobbying jobs directly related to the EU decision-making process. Other provisions on greater transparency relate to: a more detailed presentation of statements on the financial interests of MPs in Parliament; checking the update and accuracy of statements of financial interests; revocation of an access card for registered lobbyists who do not comply with regulations; seizure of a card for access to persons who do not respond to a summons to the Investigative Committee; prohibition of the use of escort IDs for lobbying purposes; allowing rapporteurs to attach a “legislative imprint” to their reports (in accordance with the decision of the Presidency on the legislative imprint). It was S&D that insisted on better transparency rules and I am pleased with the results of the vote because most colleagues recognised the importance of these changes and supported our proposal.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. — (PT) Faced with the profound and persistent crisis in which the EU is immersed, the reaction of the main forces that have determined its course — right and social democracy — is to strengthen anti-democratic instruments. This is another example. These amendments, as a whole, severely limit the power of Members and smaller political groups, and further increase the power of the large groups. The tabling of amendments to reports and opinions, written questions to other institutions, resolutions, explanations of vote and participation in specialised committees — all this is severely limited. Written declarations — an instrument that has allowed important struggles to be expressed (two recent examples: renegotiation of debts or replenishment of milk quotas) — are abolished. Instruments for democratic control of the work carried out by Parliament and Members are weakened or eliminated, in particular by imposing accelerated procedures and reducing the possibilities of requesting 'roll-call votes'. It is a case to say that some are afraid or ashamed to assume the positions they take here. PS, PSD and CDS voted in favour. The CFP voted against and put forward many dozens of proposals that would strengthen democracy, pluralism and transparency in the functioning of the European Parliament.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — I supported the report, the approval of which will have a significant impact on the European Parliament's own functioning. In the course of preparation, the report went through a very complex process in which not only the members of the responsible committee were involved, but also everyone else, as it relates to the factual organisation of our daily work, or how the European Parliament operates after the next European elections. The report is essential not only from a technical but primarily from a political point of view. I believe that, in its final form, the new Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament will also lead to far greater transparency and efficiency in the work of the European Parliament, with citizens will be able to follow the entire legislative course in passing specific legislative acts.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. ‒ Corbett's report is the result of an 18-month work by the Working Group on the EP Rules of Procedure. The aim of the work was primarily to simplify the Rules of Finally, Corbett's report included proposals for changes to the Rules of Procedure, on which MPs gained broad consensus. Most of the proposed amendments are technical, legal or linguistic in nature aimed at improving the transparency of the Rules of Procedure. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which aims to amend the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament in order to improve its functioning, to increase financial transparency and to strengthen the code of conduct for Members, particularly with regard to interest representatives. Moreover, these new rules will increase the protection of MPs and legislative work against defamatory attitudes and statements. It is important that no racist speech should be tolerated within our institution under penalty of sanctions. These provisions will also enhance the transparency of legislative work, particularly during the negotiation process, but also improve the efficiency of parliamentary work by limiting the number of written questions, motions for resolutions and requests for roll-call votes in plenary.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP could not vote for this report. There were elements of the report that did not allow for representation by all the groups of Parliament. Furthermore, we could not vote for a report that would allow legislation to be fast-tracked without following the due procedure for scrutiny.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament is continuous work. The Group of European Socialists is generally satisfied with the measures proposed in this agreement, which are aimed at greater efficiency and transparency.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of many procedural changes proposed in this general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, such as the measure prohibiting a Member from being paid to lobby the European institutions, which I think is obvious in terms of ethics. In the same spirit of respect for the function entrusted to us, I find it beneficial to strengthen the sanctions of Members who use defamatory, racist or xenophobic language, which should not be anywhere, let alone in a Parliament. Another step I would like to point out among others is the establishment of committees of inquiry, which will no longer necessarily have to obtain prior validation by the Conference of Presidents of Political Groups. This gives MEPs more power and opens the way for more rigorous scrutiny by the European Parliament.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report. It is clear that the internal rules of the European Parliament had to be changed. The corrections bring more transparency, such as the obligation for Members to declare other revenues in more detail. The procedure for asking parliamentary questions has also been changed. At present, each Member may ask them five per month. Under the new procedure, they will be able to be asked for 20 within a 3-month period. More openness is introduced during the vote on the President of the Commission, which will be open and not secret.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report amending Parliament's Rules of Procedure. First of all, it contains a series of measures to improve the efficiency of parliamentary work. In order to ensure that the latter is not unnecessarily slowed down and the statistics of MEPs are no longer artificially inflated at the end of the term, the number of questions written by parliamentarian, motions for resolutions and oral explanations of votes in plenary assembly has been framed. The report also suggests the abolition of written statements, or, at the very least, a limitation on the number of written statements. In addition, the report amends the Code of Conduct for Members of Parliament to strengthen the ethical and transparent obligations of parliamentarians. In particular, MEPs will now be subject to automatic sanctions for any defamatory, racist and xenophobic statements they may have made. A “legislative footprint”, forcing rapporteurs to record any appointments with lobbyists during the drafting of their reports, has been established. Finally, an absolute incompatibility between MPs and paid lobbyist employment has been created, and the operation of the Intergroups will now be more transparent.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Over time, there have been several revisions to the Rules of Procedure which often relate to the adoption of new Treaties. This review concerns, above all, internal reasons, in order to give greater operability, clarity and transparency to the internal operating rules, except for the cases of changes resulting from the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on the Better Law-Making programme and the creation of new bodies in the field of “Banking Union”. The working group set up in this context was able to reach agreement on a multitude of aspects, particularly technical, legal and linguistic aspects. As regards the substantive amendments, I would like to stress the new rules for maintaining agreements at first and second reading, the introduction of topical discussions on major issues and the introduction of new rules and procedures on transparency. On the question of the efficiency and effectiveness of parliamentary work, I would like to highlight as positive the measures relating to votes, the motions for resolutions and the amendments which I have endorsed for the introduction of two new types of written questions to the Commission/Council in order to give them greater political weight In this way, to obtain better answers and thus improve the quality of work and parliamentary debate.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which amends the rules of procedure of Parliament. The objective of this revision is to strengthen transparency in the European Parliament and the Code of Conduct for Members. I would also like to emphasise that the text calls for Members in office not to engage in paid lobbying activities directly related to the Union's decision-making process. Finally, it should be noted that the political groups may request the holding of topical debates in plenary session. I therefore voted in favour of this text, which aims to strengthen the transparency, efficiency and democratic character of the European Parliament.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the revised version of Parliament's Rules of Procedure because I consider the amendments to be correct and sensible, because they make work in Parliament more efficient and transparent.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. — Greater transparency of European institutions implies greater credibility in the public eye. This also applies to the European Parliament, which is why I supported a number of amendments to the Rules of Procedure to make the European Parliament even more transparent its role in the legislative process. The work of MEPs must be under constant public attention. Unfortunately, that can't be said of the Commission and the Council of the EU, whose decision-making takes place behind closed doors. I consider a step in the right direction, for example, the compulsory disclosure of newsletter meetings with lobbyists, and I am doing so voluntarily now. What was all the more striking was the failure of some colleagues in particular from right-wing factions to back a motion that an MP could not be simultaneously paid as a lobbyist. The MP lobbyist is a mockery and denial of the meaning of the whole report. I have also supported restrictions on certain actions by MPs that have no influence on decision-making and only lead to a media-grateful increase in activity statistics.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against this revision of Parliament's rules of procedure because it will reduce the ability to influence the parliamentary work of small groups, leaving this House at the service of popular and socialists, who see their capacity to define working times and speed up the legislation of interest to them, blocking amendments and debates that they consider hostile. And the same will happen with other forms of initiative, such as questions and statements, that small groups have been using to influence the political agenda beyond agreements between the majority groups.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This was a long report with lots of votes on individual amendments. I voted in favour of anything that increased transparency. However I voted against the report as a whole as I do not see most of this report as necessary.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the General Revision of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure as this is a reform which makes the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. — I supported the revision of the EP's Rules of Procedure because the amendments concerned better functioning of the European Parliament, clarifying the rules, improving transparency and protecting Parliament from disruption by deliberate elements of sabotage our work. The review was created during the meeting of the working group for 18 months, while achieving a high degree of consensus on a number of points. The Rules of Procedure increase transparency in the work of Members by prohibiting paid lobbying employment or imposing a more detailed declaration of their financial interests. We also adopted a number of proposals concerning measures to improve the efficiency of work in the EP. We have adjusted the voting order on the legislation, changed the rules for Question Time and, in order to reduce the excessive number of questions for the Commission, we have provided that each Member will be able to submit a maximum of 20 questions over a continuous period of three months. I also supported the proposal that Members should be sanctioned for using derogatory, racist and xenophobic statements or if they interfere with parliamentary activity.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. “I welcome the revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which also responds to the increasing number of cases where lobbyists who refused to comply with agreed rules have been disproportionately interfered in the EP's decision-making. We are also making legislation more efficient and clarifying some of the points of dispute of a technical nature.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The main parts of the Rules of Procedure serve to curtail the rights of smaller groups and individual Members. In the future, the respective parliamentary group will assign committee memberships by the type of lord, and in the event of a group change, a Member of Parliament will not be able to take his committee memberships with him. This will discipline and disenchute Members. The fact that the untold written declaration will be abolished is far from being able to make up for this.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. — In March, we voted the Interinstitutional Agreement on better lawmaking, which is an important step forward for more effective legislation. We laid the groundwork for better cooperation between the EU institutions and stressed the importance of openness and transparency in terms of improving EU law for the benefit of EU citizens. By reviewing the rules of procedure of the European Parliament, we are credibly going a step further towards transparency. I support this proposal because the proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament credibly introduce greater transparency as well as greater visibility of MEPs and their activities.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure to achieve better functioning of Parliament, clearer rules, greater transparency and protection of Parliament from disruptive political elements seeking to sabotage its work. I also support an amendment to the Rulebook towards tougher penalties on MPs for abusive, racist or xenophobic speaking or acts disrupting parliamentary activities. Likewise, in some cases, they may also be responsible for this kind of conduct by their staff.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - This report promotes a number of changes which lead to a strengthening of the action of the large political groups and to limiting the possibilities for action for small political groups, both in committees and in plenary. Some of the main changes, such as the limitation of the powers of MEPs, the reduction in the number of resolutions they are entitled to table and the way in which control of the legislative process will be exercised clearly pose serious problems. Attempting for a speedy legislative process greatly limits the possibilities of MEPs to intervene and to exercise effective control over procedures. For these reasons we have voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - The revised regulation, as proposed in the report to be voted on, will have a major blow to the independence of Members in the performance of their duties and to the excessive limitation of the national (where applicable) competence of the judicial/tax authorities in the proceedings audit of these financial data. The vote in favour of this text will lead to an excessive limitation of Members' ability to act by making their role a resounding decorative.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. -I supported the report on the revision of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure and the detailed package of proposals because I consider that the number of amendments envisaged are mainly aimed at greater transparency, greater efficiency, speeding up and political and serve its practical effectiveness. I myself have seen the justification of most of the changes in my daily parliamentary work, reflecting practical experiences — and unavoidable political compromises — while complying with the requirements as well. I think it is equally important and necessary to make corrections to the rules of electoral, conflict of interest and behaviour applicable to Members and to the observance of democratic standards, thereby contributing to the preservation and strengthening of the credibility of the European Parliament in the in front of European citizens. However, I have been forced to reject a number of amendments because I do not agree with the abolition of written statements, the scope of explanations of oral votes being unreasonably restricted or, for example, the right of Members to submit an amendment is restricted in the with regard to membership of the Committee.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - The European Parliament is the institution which ensures the direct representation of citizens' interests at Union level. Its operation is governed by the Rules of Procedure, which contains provisions relating to every aspect of current and regular activities. At certain intervals, the Regulation is subject to a general review, designed to correct the minor malfunctions observed or to bring up to date provisions whose application raises problems. The current amendment brings to the fore changes related to agreements after first and second reading — where the role of committees becomes more important, the thematic debates in the plenary session, simplifying the thresholds required for various legislative initiatives, changing the composition of committees — where political groups acquire more prerogatives, the order of voting legislation — by simplifying the voting on resolutions, limiting written questions, motions for resolutions, written questions and oral explanations for voting. Also, misconduct will be sanctioned, gender issues will be analysed by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality; the hearings of European Commissioners, the composition of inter-parliamentary delegations (for national diversity) and the growth of transparency of the work of MEPs. These are changes that contribute to making Parliament more efficient and more openness to European citizens. This is why I support the adoption of this necessary report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: The purpose of the text, and in particular its revision, is to achieve a more effective code of conduct and to play a much more transparent role. It's now done!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the general revision of the Parliament’s Rules of Procedure outlines several changes to be made regarding the Rules, which include a revision of rules on, inter alia, thresholds for votes, the election of officers of Parliament, the ordinary legislative procedure, questions for written answers, and composition of committees. I voted in favour of the report, which presents the proposed overhauling of the Rules of Procedure, ensuring greater transparency, efficiency and clarity in Parliament’s proceedings.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: In the short term, the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure will allow us to see real improvements in the management of our institution's day-to-day work. Significant changes will be made to encourage greater clarity of competence, better definition of the limits and areas of action of committees and individual Members and to increase the transparency of parliamentary activities. Secondly, Parliament's work can continue faster, thanks to a more streamlined and timely regulation. These changes will make it possible to respond promptly to the challenges posed to European society, with renewed attention to the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Among the points to be addressed most urgently include immigration through partnership with Africa to manage the phenomenon, reviving the economy and combating unemployment through e.g. the new digital agenda, the European Fund for Strategic Investment, Energy Policy.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. — The revision of the procedural rules can make the European Parliament even more effective, transparent and accountable towards citizens, and with this modernisation, the EP can become a real co-legislator in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why I voted in favour of the Corbett report.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the “Motion for a resolution on a general revision of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament” in the light of Articles 226 and 227. Rules of Procedure. It is necessary to simplify the current voting at the Plenary session, respect the principles of proportionality and gender equality, and reduce the reasoning of votes. MPs should perform a duty independent of potential party instructions, obey conflict of interest rules and a code of conduct from the beginning to the end of their term of office. In order for the Rules of Procedure to be respected and implemented by the Articles of Procedure, it is necessary to comply with the time and current situation in which the European Union and Parliament are located.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I supported the compromise on the new Rules of Procedure, which was put forward by a working group composed of one representative from all political groups in the European Parliament after 18 months of negotiations because it aimed to explain and simplify the rules so far. The compromise that is personally the most acceptable point of this agreement is the one that contains the subsidiarity clause because I keep the same principle a fundamental stone on which the European Union must necessarily build a healthy future. The rule that problems are addressed at the lowest level, or where they arise, if possible, and that legislative acts at Union level are adopted only if the same objective cannot be achieved in a more effective way by adopting acts at national or local level, conditio is sine qua non the survival of the European Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure The Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) set up a working group to continue its review of the Rules of Procedure. The group included 8 people from different political groups. Most of the proposed changes were adopted unanimously. Proposals vary from technical adjustments and simplifications to possible political amendments to the current Rules of Procedure. Amendments to the Rules of Procedure have consistently followed the provisions of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Legislation. All necessary measures should be taken to adapt the information systems of Parliament immediately to the revised Rules of Procedure and to establish appropriate electronic tools, inter alia, to monitor written questions to other Union institutions. Amendments to these Rules of Procedure will enter into force on the first day of the partial meeting following their adoption (except for the article on the composition of the delegation).

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ It is true that the Rules of Procedure needed to be updated on certain points. There were certain gaps and grey areas which had to be addressed and have been addressed in an appropriate way. Some of the proposed changes, however, went against democratic principles. The proposal, for instance, to limit the submission of amendments to only full members and substitute members of committees is unacceptable. This puts Members from small countries like Estonia at a disadvantage, as they are not represented in every committee. We should be working on strengthening the democratic practice in the European Parliament, not limiting the powers of single Members who have been elected and represent a part of the population.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it undermines the rights and activity of directly elected representatives of the people. This report does not improve but decreases transparency of the work of this House. The Conference of Presidents will continue to be the decisive non-transparent place for all important decisions in this House. It decides the agenda and topics to be discussed. Members should not be limited in the parliamentary questions, which are an essential element to raise issues important to their constituency. The actual system is over-bureaucratic and the parliamentary questions are filtered by non-elected bureaucrats.  I am in favour of the publication of the minutes of the trilogues and Conference of Presidents minutes; all citizens should have access to it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: The purpose of this revision of the regulation is to subtly gag those elected officials who are unfortunate to be a minority in the European Parliament. For this purpose it proposes, among other things, sanctions against “xenophobic, racist, and defamatory statements”, means which the European Parliament has used informally so far to blame the positions of our ENL Group, or a quorum of 80% to put on the agenda a topical debate proposed by a political group (figure skillfully chosen to prohibit any proposal from opposition groups). I strongly opposed this report by voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. — I spent eighteen months working on this report. Mr Corbett's report is the result of a consensus drawn up during meetings of the EP's constitutional committee working group of which I was a member. We have analysed and discussed basically the entire current Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament by ordering and reforming its shape. Among the changes proposed by the Working Group, there was also an amendment by me to elect the head of the European Commission by public vote (Article 117). It only ran out of a few votes for this amendment to be passed by the full chamber. Despite rejecting my amendment, I voted in a final vote in favour of the report because the other proposals for amendments are also important and needed.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. — I supported the functioning of the European Parliament and certain corrections to its general rules of procedure during the vote in order to ensure transparency, efficiency and credible citizenship representation.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. - I voted against the general review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, as I believe that it is a very important text that implies greater centralisation of power in large political groups to the detriment of small political groups. The AFCO Working Group on the Rules of Procedure devoted more than two years to the revision of the Rules of Procedure. The mandate of the working group was “to identify possible inconsistencies, redundancies, overlapping standards and, as far as possible, simplify standards”. Much of the changes proposed by the Working Group were technical (simplification of the text, incorporation of interpretations, adaptation of the legal basis, regrouping of provisions into new chapters, etc.). These changes are positive as they improve the readability of the Regulation. However, a number of substantial proposals could hinder the expression of smaller groups, particularly at the Plenary level, while larger groups would be more likely to act both in the Committee and in the Whole. In general, this means greater centralisation of power in Parliament for the benefit of larger groups.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing. - In the present case, the rules are being restructured mainly for internal reasons: making Parliament more functioning, clarifying the rules, improving transparency, protecting Parliament from interference by political forces seeking to sabotage its work. Only a few amendments have been made due to wider changes, such as 2006. In the context of an interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking or on the establishment of new bodies in the context of a banking union.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the general revision of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The report underlines that those amendments to the Rules have taken due account of the provisions of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 13 April 2016 on Better Law-Making. Moreover, it draws attention to the need to reorganise the Annexes to the Rules of Procedure so that they contain only texts that have the same legal value and are subject to the same procedural majority as the Rules themselves, and Annex VI which, although it requires a different procedure and a different majority for its adoption, consists of implementing measures of the Rules. I voted in favour because the report requests that the other existing annexes and any additional texts which could be relevant for the work of the Members, be re-grouped into a compendium which will accompany the Rules.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these reforms, which make the European Parliament more transparent, efficient and ready to listen to European citizens. The proposals, which were drawn up by a working group including all political Groups, will increase public visibility of important legislative votes, as they will ban committees from embarking on negotiations with other institutions without this being accepted by Parliament as a whole. The report also includes measures to enable Groups to propose current affairs debates, tougher penalties for racist and defamatory language or behaviour, and provisions for implementing the 13 April 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: — I voted in favour because these amendments to the Rules of Procedure take due account of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 13 April 2016 on Better Law-Making.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. - Improving the functioning and efficiency of the European Parliament is a concern shared by all. This report proposes a series of measures aimed at eliminating inconsistencies and redundancies in Parliament's Rules of Procedure, and some technical changes are indeed in this direction, such as the better distribution and consideration of gender or Member States or access by parliamentary committees to confidential information, European citizens' initiative or the supervision of lobbying activities. But these technical reforms do not conceal the main goal: that of the preeminence of major political groups and the limitation of the individual rights of parliamentarians - a way for groups to better hold their internal majority. The powers of the Speaker of Parliament are also strengthened. The expression of diversity of opinion is the foundation of any self-respecting democracy. It is not a luxury that is deprived of in order to better establish a majority and increasingly contested institutional choices. European citizens deserve better. I voted against this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: These amendments as a whole seriously limit the power of Members and smaller political groups and further increase the power of the large groups. Amendments to reports and opinions, written questions to other institutions, resolutions, explanations of vote, participation in specialised committees - all this is severely limited. Written declarations - an instrument that has allowed important struggles to be expressed (two recent examples: renegotiation of debts or replenishment of milk quotas) - are abolished. Instruments for democratic control of the work carried out by Parliament and Members are weakened or eliminated, in particular by imposing accelerated procedures and reducing the possibilities of requesting 'roll-call votes'. It is a case to say that some are afraid or ashamed to assume the positions they take here. CFP voted against the PSD, PS and CDS, and has put forward many dozens of proposals that would strengthen democracy, pluralism and transparency in the functioning of the European Parliament.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: in writing. - On Tuesday, the revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure was voted on, which also aims to increase transparency through a 'legislative footprint'. This will improve the understanding of the activities and influence of EU lobbyists and stakeholders and their relations with MEPs. The proposed amendments also include a stricter code of conduct for Members and tougher sanctions in the event of disruptions to Parliament's work. Negotiating mandates for compromise talks with the Council will also have to be adopted by the plenary at first reading from 2017. The declarations of Members' financial interests should also be described and examined in more detail under the new rules. The assessment is negative from a political point of view. In some areas, EPP and S&D have cleverly restricted the rights of smaller groups, non-attached and individual MEPs by means of ceilings on written questions, motions for resolutions and amendments. The restriction of free speech in plenary and in the committees is particularly drastic, where pointed speeches are likely to be classified as “xenophobic” or “xenophobic” in the future and thus prohibit them. The provision that the election of the 14 EP Vice-Presidents must also be considered absurd to include at least seven names on the ballot in order for it to be valid. This is tentless compulsion to have to elect politically unloving candidates. That is why I did not support this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report by my Labour colleague Richard Corbett as it promotes a set of key reforms to improve democracy, transparency and efficiency in the work of the European Parliament. The revision of the European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure includes among other things more transparency and greater safeguards in first-reading agreements, a ban on MEPs having second paid jobs as lobbyists, and strengthened sanctions for anyone making defamatory or xenophobic statements in plenary.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that the points touched are in line with my liberal view. I support the importance given to transparency and all the rules that have to be followed in case an individual has been signed in the transparency register. Transparency of the European Parliament’s activities is fundamental for the credibility of the institution. I believe that Members should enjoy the privileges and immunities only laid down in the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. In order to make the process more efficient, I support the idea of limiting the questions submitted by each Member State to a maximum of twenty questions over a period of three months. Finally, I think that there should not be split votes on compromise amendments.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the Corbett report on the overall review of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The Rules of Procedure contain the most detailed rules for voting, holding debates or submitting proposals in the European Parliament. The number of amendments to these Rules of Procedure tabled in plenary brought in some places only stylistic adjustments to the articles, but somewhere there were very significant changes. I agree that rules of the type of Rules of Procedure need to be reviewed regularly and ascertained whether their provisions are obsolete or whether the articles of the Rules of Procedure coincide with other superior rules. And although I did not agree with many of the amendments, I think that the positive changes outweighed, which is why I decided in the final vote to give my vote in the amended text.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Corbett report because I agree with the proposals put forward to improve the operating rules of the European Parliament. I would stress that the report seeks to bring Parliament's Rules of Procedure into line with the 'Better Lawmaking' work programme and to strengthen the links of institutional cooperation between the three institutions of the Union: Parliament, the Council and the Commission. I believe that the package of rules presented will serve to make the European Parliament an institution even more transparent, efficient, open and ready to react to its citizens.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - Due to the need to improve the functioning of the Rules of Procedure, to simplify and clarify all regulations and to protect Parliament from the politicanism that sabotages its work and influence as an important European institution, it is necessary to revise the Rules of Procedure. The holding of thematic sessions on topics of great interest in the functioning of the European Union will help to discuss more frequently on topics that interest us most. At least one such debate will have the right to report every MEPs club within Parliament. The revision of the Rules of Procedure excludes any financial interests of MEPs with regard to lobbying in the European Parliament and underlines the necessity of a detailed presentation of the statement of financial interests of the MEPs. Parliament must be familiar with the future recruitment and engagement of individual MPs. The changes needed for questions and the introduction of the 'ping-pong' method will allow easier communication between MPs and trustees, and written answers will reduce the excessive number of questions asked which serve individual MPs only as statistics. Restricting questions to 20 in three months will allow for a clearer and more constructive discussion, and unnecessary questions and comments will be avoided. The behaviour of MPs in Parliament makes an impression on citizens. It is therefore necessary to take a step in this direction and sanction every form of hate speech, racist or xenophobic speech.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. — The new regulation of the European Parliament, as it has been thought, reduces the freedoms of MEPs. I would have expected the reform of a document so important for the life of Parliament to happen with the widest possible debate and not with the usual agreement of the broad agreement. Instead, we are faced with a text that concentrates power in the hands of large political groups and even limits the intervention power of individual Members. Restrictive thresholds are imposed for tabling amendments, written statements, resolutions and motions. The possibility of requiring so-called “roll call votes” that is to publish how individual Members voted in Parliament is reduced. We at the M5S are fighting for institutions to respond to the citizens' demand for greater transparency. A radical change of course is needed to bring European citizens closer to the institutions. Change of course that must provide for new rules to limit the conflicts of interest of MPs themselves and not allow hiding their own vote. I therefore spoke out against this regulation.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the General Audit of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The functioning of the European Parliament must become more transparent, democratic and interactive. I therefore support the reform of the Rules of Procedure in order to streamline and simplify the internal work of Members and Parliament, thus enabling the European Parliament to perform its legislative, budgetary function and political control and consultation even more effectively and efficiently.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union, which for thousands of people fleeing war and hunger represents a promised land of prosperity and civilization, unfortunately still hides many skeletons in the closet. We cannot deny that some Member States are not really champions in respect of human rights. This House has many times been confronted about situations of violence within the Union itself, and here we have welcomed the cry of alarm of citizens who are harassed by their governments. As long as we still have to convince some states that shutting down televisions and newspapers, that raising walls and shooting at borders has nothing to do with the principles on which the European Union is founded, until all of this will still be on the agenda of the plenary, it will be necessary to monitor the human rights situation and make amends. It is not violence, repression and denial of rights that support, the pillar of a project that has given us and still guarantees us, thankfully, more than sixty years of peace. And that we should remind that to the many, too many political movements that incite hatred and violence. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, I do not understand what a reference is doing in a human rights report to the cancellation of the cooperation and verification mechanism in Romania and Bulgaria. The Cooperation and Verification Mechanism for Romania and Bulgaria has been and is a success, at least for Romania. Anti-corruption institutions and judicial institutions have been protected all the time by this mechanism, because there are many politicians who attack justice, attack anti-corruption prosecutors, individually attack prosecutors and judges and, once again, everything that means anticorruption. Why? Because they want not to be investigated, not to be convicted, they want to escape. That is why this mechanism is very useful, and he must stop only when he fulfills his task. It is a specific mechanism whereby Romania and Bulgaria, when they entered the European Union, made some promises - to continue the anti-corruption fight. Therefore, when these promises are kept, the mechanism may cease. Not until then. It can go in parallel with any other Rule of Law pact or mechanism that is spoken of in the European Parliament. If you'll allow me one last sentence, an election campaign has just ended in Romania and many or quite a lot of MPs who have attacked the anti-corruption bodies throughout the campaign have entered the Romanian Parliament.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I have been very hesitant whether to support or abstain from the report in question. In the end, I abstained, which is why I take the opportunity to explain why I made this decision. I personally consider the human rights agenda to be an extremely important agenda, and whole parts of that report are in the spirit of how I would agree with them. It is, for example, a question of protecting human rights in the world, fighting the death penalty, and so on. On the other hand, however, there are certain passages in that report that eventually led me to abstain. These are passages that relate to human rights within the European Union. When, in short, do I consider that in some cases the report is too invasive in relation to the sovereignty of individual Member States. I simply disagree with some points, such as the European Commission's push for a uniform adjustment for paternity, parental and maternity leave. I think these are things that are supposed to be adjusted by individual states on their own. And this is how I would find other things where we should respect the sovereignty of individual Member States and not interfere with their legal environment.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the rapporteur's work in this report, which includes many of the amendments tabled by my group on such relevant issues as migration and asylum or mass espionage on citizens. But it is also true that we lack more resounding in some areas, or, for example, references to the impact of austerity measures. I wanted to focus on a specific aspect of the human rights situation in the Union, specifically in one Member State. The Spanish State. The report called for all the fundamental rights of prisoners and prisoners to be guaranteed. However, the Spanish State is well below European standards due, inter alia, to its failure to comply with EU law. Framework Decision 2008/675 requires recognition of convictions served in other Member States. A rule that the Spanish Government took more than six years to transpose, and whose transposition attempted to conceal from the European Commission for a year and a half. It was thus trying to save time and continue to consolidate in Spanish courts a situation contrary to European standards and human rights. If the European standard is complied with, seven Basque prisoners should be released immediately, as stated in the report prepared by seven MEPs from three different groups in April this year. Article 6 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights provides for the right to freedom. It is time for the Union to activate all its mechanisms to guarantee this and other fundamental rights and that the Strasbourg Court does not have to come, as always, to restrain the Member States.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, it is a fact that human rights, as established by European Union regulations and law, should be subject to debate on the floor of the European Parliament. We should not become an exporter of fundamental human rights to all surrounding states, surrounding countries outside the European Union. We should have this discussion really on our soil. I have come to the conclusion that the report as a whole is sufficient, it is well written, even though it is indeed distorted on some issues. For me, it is important that the agenda of those fundamental human rights to our international policy is also linked. In order not to support regimes that undoubtedly fundamental human rights, as we recognise them, whether it is the right to life, the right to respect family private life or the right to dignity, do not observe. This, unfortunately, doesn't happen very often. We shouldn't be lecturing the world, but we should insist on basic human rights.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! While Article Two of the Charter of Fundamental Rights speaks clearly about the right to life, in this report we do not only have a word about the right of every person to give birth, but, moreover, there is not a word about the right of any man to give birth. For that, of course, we have a pretty glamorous verbal juggling about unspecified sexual laws. This report is a document of the decline of Europe, because those who make law by death have no future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I welcome this evaluation of the status of fundamental rights in the European Union. Based on the principles of compromise and subsidiarity and identifying the protection of fundamental rights and dignity as a priority, I am pleased to support the rapporteur’s findings. In establishing a more definitive framework in this sphere, we may hope that the vast range of rights which were identified will continue to be advanced. I also greatly appreciate Mr Nagy’s renewed efforts to recognise the promotion of rights for minorities as a keystone for future policy in this area.  I would also like to thank our President, Mr Schulz, for referring to the fundamental rights of a European and Irish citizen in Parliament yesterday evening when he called on the Egyptian authorities to release Ibrahim Halawa, who is celebrating his 21st birthday today in an Egyptian prison, without trial for four years for an offence he allegedly committed when he was a minor. So hopefully the Egyptian authorities will listen more to the Irish authorities, to the Department of Foreign Affairs, and to Mr Schulz, our President.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: in writing. — Today the European Parliament voted on a report concerning the situation of fundamental rights in the Member States of the Union. It is, in large part, a good report that underlines the importance of protecting the principles of expression and law. As for the writing on abortion, I believe that responsibility for health care policy belongs on a national level. In separate polls, I marked this view. Based on a holistic assessment, I chose to vote yes in the final vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ Contrary to common opinion on fundamental rights, the institutions and certain non-governmental organisations report that there are numerous violations within the EU of fundamental rights. I strongly argue that every EU citizen should see their rights respected regardless of gender, religion, sexual tendencies and race. The protection of rights also includes a topical issue such as migrants, to whom more commitment is needed by the European Union in order to provide them with adequate protection. Because of the importance of this issue and the way in which the report is concerned about dealing with some very topical and delicate points, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I think it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social (although the rapporteur tried to censor references to fundamental rights before voting in plenary). I think, however, that a good diagnosis is not enough: the Union must reverse its migration, economic and social policies if it is to curb this difficult situation.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The European Union is a community based on the principles of respect for human dignity, freedom and democracy, and the rule of law is the pillar of European liberal democracy and one of the fundamental principles of the EU, which derives from the constitutional traditions common to all EU Member States. The document emphasises that human dignity is an inviolable basis for all fundamental rights and that it should not be manipulated in any way. On the contrary, it must be respected and protected in all EU initiatives. Social inclusion, the situation of migrants and refugees, trafficking in human beings, women's rights and violence against women are also discussed. And although an attempt to address the challenges facing the EU in the areas listed is welcome, I cannot agree with some of the statements in the resolution contrary to my beliefs, so I abstained from voting.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 because I believe that we must constantly fight against all forms of discrimination that European citizens accept.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: This annual report contains no less than 138 paragraphs. As every year, there are several passages that testify to immigrationism pushed to the extreme. In particular, it encourages Member States to “allocate adequate resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants. The text also tackles freedom of expression. It is concerned about “the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet; recommends that Member States establish a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online; welcomes the Commission's presentation of a code of conduct on combating hate speech illegal online and calls for adherence to current and ongoing efforts to strengthen cooperation with the private sector and civil society.” Obviously, the report also places great emphasis on LGBTIQ propaganda and the promotion of abortion. I, of course, voted against this very politically correct report, revealing the ideology that animates European pseudo-elites.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am a strong advocate for ensuring fundamental rights for all, I do not believe further EU interference on this issue is the best way forward. National governments within Europe will always be the best way to enhance and protect rights without additional EU bureaucracy and unnecessary legislation. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I endorsed the conclusions of this report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Indeed, certain events have had a negative impact on the protection of fundamental rights, especially for certain groups of the population such as refugees, children and women. It is therefore important to recall here that these rights have no political affiliation and must be universally protected. However, they cannot be taken for granted in the light of the actions of some. We must therefore continue to promote respect for these rights in the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Insufficient protection of citizens and awareness of their rights under the Charter of Fundamental Rights can increase disappointment in the European project. In addition, terrorism, the migrant crisis and the economic crisis are precisely the factors that polarize our society. I therefore agree that the institutions, bodies and agencies of the Union and the Member States must ensure the protection of citizens' fundamental rights in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights when implementing Union law. The EU must continue to actively address not only legal and economic issues, but also human rights issues.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: This annual report, long and tedious, contains, as every year, several passages that testify to delusional immigrationism. In particular, it urges Member States to “allocate sufficient resources for the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants (§25). The text also addresses freedom of expression: it is concerned about “the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet; recommends that Member States introduce a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online; welcomes the Commission's submission of a code of hate speech on the Internet. on combating illegal hate speech online and calls for adherence to current and ongoing efforts to strengthen cooperation with the private sector and civil society” (§57). This is a blatant attempt to censor public discourse by assuming the right to define what would be “hate content”, that is, of course, what would be against the prevailing ideology. I naturally voted against this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report in particular because it represents the result of negotiating work that the S&D Group has provided in Parliament in order to defend amendments which focus on very important areas. These include respect for the rule of law, which is a fundamental principle for any democracy or migration issue, and the call on Member States to put in place policies to facilitate the integration of migrants into our society. It is also important to highlight the issue of the LGBTI community, which reminds us that all citizens are equal and cannot be discriminated against. Other important priorities were also raised in the amended report, including the need to strengthen efforts to end human trafficking networks and combat racism and violence against women.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: In writing. ‒ The protection of human rights is one of the principles behind the European Union, a constant objective guiding the action of the institutions committed every year to monitor the level of respect for fundamental rights and the soundness of the principles of the rule of law on the continent. The Nagy report, which I supported with my vote today, provides a complete picture of the situation within the European Union for 2015, highlighting the problems that have emerged in the different countries in these countries sectors. The text focuses, among the many issues concerned, on two particularly sensitive issues, those of integration and immigration. There is an increase in the phenomena of incitement to hatred towards migrants and refugees, an alarming reality that develops against a context of political parties and movements inclined to exploit xenophobic drives to increase one's electoral consensus. The report also focuses on an extremely worrying fact: at least 10,000 unaccompanied refugees and child migrants disappeared in the EU in 2015. The Union and the Member States must act as soon as possible with existing tools to trace missing children. Keeping migrants' families together and recording and identifying children can help prevent their disappearance.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which is carried out annually, aims to present the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and propose recommendations. In its visit to the Civil Liberties Committee, important changes have been made, such as removing the most problematic aspects and including many of our group's amendments, such as those relating to migration and asylum, the protection of whistleblowers, the assessment of counter-terrorism measures, condemning mass surveillance indiscriminate, etc. It is important to note that the report mentions aspects of corruption, racism and xenophobia, gender equality and violence against women, the rights of the Roma community, LGBT rights, as well as rights of children, other minorities, persons with disabilities, the elderly and digital rights . However, as a rapporteur for the EPP, we have not succeeded in making reference to how economic policy, especially austerity measures, have affected the fundamental rights of European citizenship. That is why a new attempt was made by tabling amendments at this plenary meeting. Since the majority were rejected, I voted abstention.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: I obviously opposed this report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015, as it is a concentrate of immigrationist propaganda and regulated violations of freedom of expression. Member States are therefore urged to establish legal and safe ways of immigration, even though migratory flooding has already weighed heavily on European populations, which are becoming increasingly vulnerable as public authorities prioritize the reception of foreign populations over indigenous peoples. Moreover, this report poses a real danger to the principle of freedom of expression, which is enshrined in the European Treaties, by wanting to force the Member States to put in place a procedure which I would call a real disconnection, since every citizen should be able to report the presence of so-called 'hateful' content. even as this criterion is most subjective. Finally, to the detriment of respect for the national prerogative, the Commission is appointed chief censorship body with the presentation of this “code of conduct on combating illegal hate speech online”.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this text which I think is fatious. The report mainly deals with the rights of illegal false refugees and LGBTI people, without doing anything in favour of the disastrous situation of the rights of European citizens, who are increasingly ignored and stomped on. I will continue to fight against this wrong European Union, which is hiding behind the politically correct so as not to face reality. That reality that shows how this Union is the real cause of the worsening living conditions of our people.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which is based on the need for the Union to promote the values of dignity and equality, which are their basis, and which do not admit any form of discrimination against any of its citizens. This report covers 40 commitments addressing key fundamental rights issues including the rule of law, women's rights and violence against them, children's rights, migration, social integration and inclusion, trafficking in human beings, xenophobia, freedom and security, rights of persons with disabilities, LGBTI rights, hate crimes, Roma rights and digital rights, among others.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which examines the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The European Parliament reiterates that human dignity is an inviolable basis for all fundamental rights and should not be subjected to any manipulation, respected and protected in all EU initiatives, and therefore calls for an increase in EU citizens' awareness of the natural dignity of all individuals in order to more humane and fairer societies. Secondly, Parliament condemns all forms of discrimination and violence against all people in the EU, because this is a direct violation of human dignity. The European Parliament calls on the Commission to adopt an anti-corruption strategy that includes effective measures. The EP also calls on the Member States to follow the recommendations in the Commission's anti-corruption report, and calls on them to strengthen police and judicial cooperation in the fight against corruption. To this end, calls on the Member States and the EU institutions to assist the rapid establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, providing it with adequate guarantees of independence and effectiveness.
