Parliament welcomes the Commission's initiatives and key actions to strengthen cooperation between Member States in the field of security, and the EU's effective response to terrorism and security threats in the European Union, and fully supports measures to enable effective security union. Parliament calls on Member States to cooperate fully with each other and to improve the exchange of information and exchange of information with Europol and other relevant EU agencies.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. — The situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 showed no significant progress, especially as regards minority rights. I would like to draw attention to the fact that minority communities continue to face obstacles to enforcing their linguistic rights in access to justice and other public services such as education, health and social services. Member States should make further efforts to remove disproportionate administrative and legislative barriers which could hinder linguistic diversity at European or national level. I would like to encourage the Commission to establish a policy standard for the protection of minorities in accordance with the Copenhagen criteria, which apply to both candidate states and Member States. It is necessary to exchange good practices for resolving minority problems and to apply best solutions throughout the European Union. I would like to encourage those Member States that have not yet done so to ratify as soon as possible the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities and the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages, who have ratified it and adhere to it. This also applies to candidate countries and countries with an association agreement. Member States must guarantee the right to use minority languages, and linguistic diversity within the Union must be protected. I propose to reinforce the Commission's plan for education and use of regional languages, as this will help tackle linguistic discrimination in the EU.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: In writing. ‒ Compared with today's challenges, the European Union must ensure the protection of fundamental rights in all its actions, as provided for in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. That is why I welcome a report that brings to attention the different cases in which human rights went into the background during 2015, leaving room for discrimination and xenophobia. The migration crisis, as well as acts of terrorism in some Member States, have accentuated the manifestations of these phenomena, putting the most vulnerable at risk. This is how many Member States responded to calls for help by erecting walls. This report, which I support, recalls the indispensability of fundamental principles, such as human rights, the rule of law and gender equality, on which the EU is founded.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. - Women's fundamental rights continue to be violated. I condemn all forms of violence against women and girls such as domestic violence, honour murder, forced marriage, human trafficking and female genital mutilation. Offenders need to be prosecuted and sanctioned, and EU authorities and national authorities need to strengthen cooperation, notably by exchanging good practices and improving the collection of comparable data on all forms of violence against women. I call on the EU to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union is a leader in the world for respect, promotion and protection of human and civil rights. Pillar of European culture, not just legal, they are the fundamental element of the EU's architecture and the inspiring principle of its action in the world. The vast socio-economic and political fallout resulting from this vision can be found in the entire Community legislation which protects individual rights, promotes the value of the individual and makes plurality of languages, ideas, faiths, opinions and habits a strong point rather than a weakness of the great common European home. Europe is one of the few realities in the world that has been able to safeguard minorities and avoid forced approvals while maintaining peace and variety within it. However, we are called to monitor and always do our best so that there are no exceptions or shortcomings to the implementation of our values. Some states that have more recently gone down the path of integration have important political formations within them which are indifferent, if not openly hostile, to the promotion and application of fundamental rights to all people. The return of nationalisms threatens many of the civil and social achievements achieved in seventy years of walking together: we work not to fall into the shadows of the past.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: This report calls on Member States to allocate adequate resources for the creation of legal routes for illegal migrants. At a time when the people of Europe are experiencing massive unemployment, increasing poverty and social inequality, it is really outrageous to see the European Union to give priority to the interests of illegal migrants rather than the interests of our fellow citizens. Moreover, the text undermines freedom of expression by calling for greater controls and penalties on Internet content. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. It is very important that human rights be respected within the European Union. This is particularly true at a time when the Union is facing unprecedented challenges. We cannot decently talk about respect for human rights in third countries if we do not do the same. The European Union has been built on common values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. We must do everything we can to ensure that these values are respected within the Union. The vote on this report allowed me to reiterate my position in favour of ratifying the Council of Europe's European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages. We must defend the right to use a minority language in order to protect our linguistic diversity.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 because the incitement of hatred by certain political forces is growing and increase feelings such as xenophobia and other forms of prejudice in important areas of the population. A situation heightened by the migration emergency, but also by terrorist attacks. The situation remains difficult and requires an effort on the part of the European Union to reiterate that we are a community based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, Rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. It is necessary for the European Union to put more proactive policies into the field, drawing up plans specifically aimed at promoting and awareness of rights.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a positive report. It includes strong references to whistleblower protection, condemns mass surveillance of the CIA, tackles corruption, contains progressive assessments of the refugee crisis and is strong on countering discrimination and protecting gender equality.  For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP strongly supports equal rights for all genders, races and sexualities. We also support the condemnation of crimes such as violence, child abuse and human trafficking. That being said, however, we reject the attempts to politicise this report in favour of EU charters, bodies and institutions. In particular, we reject the concerns in this report of the rise of Euroscepticism across Europe.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that human dignity is the inviolable foundation of all fundamental rights and should be respected and protected in all EU initiatives. I condemn all forms of discrimination and violence in the EU against all human beings, as it constitutes a direct violation of human dignity. Despite these inherent values enshrined in our Treaties and Charter of Fundamental Rights, violations still occur in the EU. I believe that in facing today’s challenges, the EU and Member States should uphold and enforce these values in every action they take, as the European Union is a community founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. I believe that it is essential to protect all fundamental rights and uphold the principles of the rule of law, but I could not vote in favour of this report as it contained references to abortion to which I cannot agree to.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. ‒ This year's report refers to Parliament's legislative INI calling for the establishment of a strategy and mechanism for the protection of EU fundamental rights without therefore delve, as has been the case over the years, into institutional matters. We welcome the introduction of a paragraph on corruption, the protection of migrants and the need to prevent abuse of hospitality funds and their fundamental rights and the part relating to the rights of children.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. It gives us a clear picture on the situation regarding the EU’s fundamental values – rule of law, human rights and democracy. I am personally glad that the resolution pays special attention to such key issues as violence against women, protection of children and rights for people with disabilities. We definitely should not lose these from our radar. Finally, I would like to highlight one part which is gaining in importance: it is on digital rights. Access to digital services together with privacy has become a challenge in recent years and we should reflect it properly.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are voting in favour of the report and emphasise that fundamental rights are universal, indivisible and always complementary and that the right balance must therefore be struck between the rights of all members of a rich and diverse society.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. This annual report is a positive attempt to highlight issues affecting millions of European citizens, with the aim of raising awareness of the relevant bodies and finding solutions. I think it contains positive elements especially after the vote in favour of our amendment on social rights in the final procedure in plenary, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: In writing. ‒ The annual own-initiative report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union does not, in any way, accept the criticalities of the socio-economic model which this European Union supports and represents. The report is also explicit the attack on those who do not share the “politically correct” thinking on issues concerning migrants and refugees. For these reasons my vote is down.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: In writing. ‒ As a primary European citizen, I welcome the report, confirming the full awareness that the Union is not only concerned, but also protects and guarantees human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, rule of law and respect for human rights. This essence, however, needs an overriding awareness by Europeans, which, in my view, is only possible by raising awareness of the deep sense of dignity from beginning to end of life. It also makes it necessary to strike a fair balance between the rights of everyone with the interests and duties of the community. Thus, strengthening the mechanisms of social inclusion and integration is a dynamic and multi-dimensional challenge achievable with better access to fundamental education, in order to enable weaning of a more human and open society, albeit firm in its values. Through the maturation of a conscious citizenship one can witness the hovering of fundamental values and, consequently, the resolution of the relative gaps regarding freedom and security. The most present shortcomings to date are found in the situation of prisons, trafficking in human beings, but more worrying in child poverty which increases the vicious cycle of disadvantage social.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: This annual report is a crucial exercise for the European Parliament, especially at a - I would say - critical time. 2015 was particularly difficult as regards fundamental rights: threats to the rule of law, terrorist attacks on security and freedom of expression, as well as difficulties in respecting the right to asylum. This report allows, on the one hand, an overall diagnosis of the human rights situation in the Union and, on the other hand, to identify the impact of the measures taken. However, unlike previous years, the diagnosis is in line with reality, the proposals put forward are consistent with the position of this Parliament and fundamental rights have not been used for political purposes. The portrait presented is not new, but reinforces the sense of apprehension. But above all, it must strengthen the urgency of Union action.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP strongly supports equal rights for all genders, races and sexualities. We also support the condemnation of crimes such as violence, child abuse and human trafficking. That being said, however, we reject the attempts to politicise this report in favour of EU charters, bodies and institutions. In particular, we reject the concerns in this report of the rise of Euroscepticism across Europe.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which addresses important issues on fundamental rights of the European Union, including the protection of human rights, integration and social inclusion, human trafficking, violence against women and children's rights.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ Respect for fundamental rights and freedoms is at the core of EU values and integration. We need to do more to fight discrimination and violence based on gender, ethnic origin, sexual orientation or religion across Europe. We need to protect in particular the most vulnerable, such as children.  I fully supported the report as it takes into account the rights of women victims of violence, the situation of refugees, in particular refugee women and unaccompanied minors, LGTBI people, minorities and people with disabilities. I also support more cooperation with industry to prevent and fight abuse, hate speech and radicalisation online, in respect of freedom of expression. These new challenges require the Member States to work together with mutual trust for a more efficient cross-border cooperation. We have the responsibility to stay vigilant and fight against any form of racism and xenophobia, to combat the rise of nationalism and populism and protect peace in Europe.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I think it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social (although the rapporteur tried to censor references to fundamental rights before voting in plenary). I think, however, that a good diagnosis is not enough: the Union must reverse its migration, economic and social policies if it is to curb this difficult situation.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: In addressing the current challenges, the EU and the Member States should act fully in line with the fundamental principles and values enshrined in the Treaties. In fact, the European Union is a community founded on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of people belonging to minorities. Compliance with these values must go hand in hand with external action not by the EU. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, because it reminds that, both in the management of internal crises and in relations with the rest of the world, the Union must contribute to the protection of rights fundamentals. In particular, I am thinking of issues essential to the lives of citizens, such as freedom of information, anti-corruption and anti-terrorism strategy, interreligious and intercultural dialogue and equal genre.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament. I welcome and consider the part of the report concerning national and linguistic minorities as a priority. I am particularly pleased that many parts of the amendments proposed by me on indigenous minorities have been included in the final version of the report, thereby strengthening the original text. However, I abstained from the final vote on the report because this political decision, which is not of legal relevance, has included a series of issues that fall within the competence of the Member States.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — I voted against the vote on the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Despite the fact that there are positive elements in the document, such as a call for action on human trafficking, support for the right of minorities, people with disabilities, women's rights or the eradication of poverty among older people, I have been very anxious about the ideological aspects of the report. The report interferes too far in matters whose regulation lies within the competence of the Member States. I believe that bringing ideological issues into the EU's system of protection of fundamental rights is a controversial thing. Effective protection of citizens' rights must be based on solutions and actions of a legal nature and devoid of ideological and world-view elements.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Fundamental rights in the European Union need to be always strengthened and safeguarded. Each and every Member State needs to implement policies and introduce new laws which ensure dignity for all. Malta has come a long way during the last three years, especially when it comes to LGBTI rights, with the introduction of civil union law, banning conversion therapy and the introduction of the gender identity bill. We need to continue fighting for the principles of equality while condemning all forms of discrimination. I am in favour of this report as we need to work towards a more socially inclusive Union which condemns any form of discrimination. As with all other votes, I voted against references to abortion.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I and my Conservative colleagues fully support fundamental rights and equality. However, a number of suggestions contained within this report go very far beyond the competences of the EU. For this reason I choose to abstain on this.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - Violence against women is a violation of fundamental rights affecting all levels of society, regardless of age, education, income, social position and country of origin or residence, and gender inequality and gender-based stereotypes increase the risk of violence and other forms of exploitation and hinders the full participation of women in all areas. Given that equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the EU and any discrimination based on gender is prohibited, I believe that in order to effectively combat gender-based violence, a change in attitude towards women and girls is necessary. In this context, I believe that the Commission should share Member States' best practices in addressing gender stereotypes, and Member States should do more to combat gender-based stereotypes that reproduce and strengthen gender roles in key in which such stereotypes are perpetuated.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — This own-initiative report focuses on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union in 2015, in particular the protection of fundamental rights and dignity, migration management, social integration and inclusion, freedom and security, trafficking in human beings and violence against women. Considering that, in the face of the challenges facing the Union, such as terrorism or migration flows, respect for fundamental rights deserves special attention, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP strongly supports equal rights for all genders, races and sexualities. We also support the condemnation of crimes such as violence, child abuse and human trafficking. That being said, however, we reject the attempts to politicise this report in favour of EU charters, bodies and institutions. In particular, we reject the concerns in this report of the rise of Euroscepticism across Europe.

name: Rachida DATI
text: I voted in favour of this report, which provides a comprehensive and balanced picture of the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The European Union is built on a foundation of common values that we must defend. As rapporteur for my political group on the state of prisons in Europe, it was particularly important to denounce the inhuman and degrading prison conditions in some Member States where prisons are too often overcrowded and are experiencing an explosive situation. It was also essential to stress in this report the need for better cooperation and exchange of information between Member States in the face of radicalisation and terrorism for a genuine Security Union, of course, with full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms. Similarly, I support the proposal for Member States to set up a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision, which was not of legal relevance, following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I believe that fundamental rights and civil liberties are important for social welfare and political and economic progress. In fact, I am opposed to any form of sexual discrimination, religious, gender and against disabled people, and I believe in a tolerant and free society.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on fundamental rights in the EU in 2015. This text, which addresses the main challenges related to fundamental rights in the EU in 2015, including migration, child protection and the online environment, is Parliament's response to the Commission's annual report on fundamental rights in the EU. Most recently, Parliament called for a European mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights to monitor each year the situation of these principles in the Member States, based on evidence, in an objective and non-discriminatory manner. Member States should also intensify their efforts to promote “European values, tolerance and sense of community, avoiding stigma”, in order to prevent radicalisation and violent extremism, while conducting positive information campaigns to help citizens see integration in a better way, affirms the text. The resolution deplores “the increasing level of hate speech within certain institutions, political parties and the media.” They call on the EU to set an example “by opposing hate speech within its institutions”.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. — The European Union ensures respect for the principles inherent in democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, both within and on the international stage. These values are enshrined in the Treaty and in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. However, violations of these rights occurred in Europe during 2015, primarily against migrants and refugees. They must be able to be welcomed under dignified conditions and enjoy the rights they have under international conventions. It is essential that the Union and its Member States help to promote European values of solidarity and integration. This is the full meaning of the European Pact in the field of fundamental rights that the European Parliament called for last October. The Commission must be able to challenge a Member State more systematically that does not respect our European values.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This 138-paragraph report, full of good feelings, addresses, inter alia, “hate speech” on the Internet, which should be more monitored and the immigration policy of the Member States: in particular, it would be appropriate to 'allocate adequate resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry' for migrants. We cannot support this liberticidal text under the guise of defending fundamental rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — The Annual Report on Fundamental Rights in 2015 summarizes the situation of pressing problems throughout the past year. The report contains a wide range of topics such as migration, the rights (of children, women, Roma, people with disabilities, in relation to citizenship), sexual health, trafficking in human beings, equality, the elderly, violence against women, LGBTI rights, etc. The positive elements are calls to action on human trafficking (in support of victims, people with disabilities, women's rights, rape, female genital mutilation and elderly poverty). However, some problematic points remain in the report, such as LGBTI rights, the call for inclusion in the Istanbul Convention and so on. For this reason, I abstained.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - Fundamental rights, human dignity, the rule of law, freedom and security must not be the scope of political contemplation, the auctioning of sociality and human sensitivity.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU 2015. This report is an annual exercise covering developments in the field of fundamental rights in EU Member States and contains suggestions for improvements. The EU should deal with all violations of fundamental rights, and it is important to my constituents in Wales that we do all we can to improve things both at home within the EU, and further afield.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which partly covers some points of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions, to which I contributed as shadow rapporteur. The cynical and ongoing application at EU and national level of austerity measures, which are still adopted as a benchmark economic approach, prevents effective institutional responses from being provided. 8 years after the start of the economic crisis, we continue to see the increased levels of poverty, the presence of exponential rates of unemployment and precariousness, with very high points among young people from the worst affected countries. This results in the impossibility of enjoying a truly free and dignified existence and the violation of fundamental rights, such as access to health care, to the protection of the rights of minors, disabled people, migrants and asylum seekers. The text makes clear reference to the responsibility of austerity policies. I hope that this awareness grab will result in a decisive reversal of course as soon as possible.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: The European Union is a community based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. The rule of law is the backbone of European liberal democracy and one of the founding principles of the EU stemming from the common constitutional traditions of the Member States. At least 3771 people died or have been reported missing in 2015 as they tried to reach a safe place in Europe, bringing the total deaths and missing persons to more than 30,000 in the last two decades, and terrorist acts represent one of the most serious violations of fundamental rights and freedoms. I would remind you that human dignity is the inviolable basis of all fundamental rights, that it should not be subjected to any kind of exploitation and that it must be respected and protected in all EU initiatives condemning all forms of discrimination and violence in the EU against all human beings, since that constitute a direct violation of human dignity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: as every year, there are several passages that testify to immigrationism pushed to the extreme. The text also tackles freedom of expression.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. — I welcome the report on the situation of fundamental rights for 2015, in particular the introduction of a paragraph on corruption, the protection of migrants, on the the need to prevent abuse of funds intended for reception. Equally shareable is the part of the report on the rights of children.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The recommendations in the field of freedoms, rights of refugees and migrants, freedom of movement, the right to privacy, the right to information, non-discrimination, equality between men and women, the rights of the child, the rights of persons with disability and the defence of social rights, among others, which we subscribe and claim. But well-meaning recommendations do not come. Concrete political measures must be taken to create the real and material conditions for their effective compliance. The strengthening and extension of public services; the right to health, education and culture; the right to employment and employment with rights; respect for the sovereignty of peoples, non-interference, international law and the UN Charter are some of the urgent and necessary measures that do not take place in this report. On the contrary, apart from the hollow evocation of the notorious 'fundamental rights in the European Union', the way indicated, explicitly or implicitly, is the strengthening of restrictive measures and limiting freedoms; it is the narrow, repressive and safeguarding vision of the ideal of democracy. What prevails is the usual restrictive and instrumental conception of human rights.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted no because I disagree.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question is based on the principles of decency and equality, and it is not possible to accept any form of discrimination against citizens of the Member States. The report focuses on the lack of humanitarian aid for refugees and their behaviour at the borders of the European Union. The report also focuses on the social exclusion of the Roma population, which has to face racism in several Member States as well as exclusion on the labour market.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report because once again we do not denounce the socio-economic model of this European Union which is the real cause of the deterioration of fundamental rights. The exaggerated presence of paragraphs dedicated to LGBTI people contributes to the negative vote.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - Fundamental rights, human dignity, the rule of law, freedom and security should not be the scope of political contemplation, the auctioning of sociality and human sensitivity, so I am voting against report A8-0345/2016 on the state of the fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which addresses fundamental issues and strongly condemns the lack of humanity shown at European borders. Social inclusion and integration of migrants and refugees and the granting of international protection in the host society is part of a dynamic and multi-dimensional process, in which respect for European values must be a priority. I support the call on Member States to apply integration policies as swiftly as possible and with adequate dedicated resources, and to develop them in cooperation with national institutions, local governments, schools, NGOs, as well as migrants and refugee communities. It is important to consider that access to education is one of the foundations for the integration of refugees. We will continue fighting for the principles of decency and equality, and will not accept any form of discrimination in Europe.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz—KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision which was not of legal relevance following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision, which was not of legal relevance, following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: In writing. ‒ In the context of this plenary session, the European Parliament officially presented the 2016 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar, two Yazid survivors of Isis sex slavery. The horror told by the words and looks of the two women underlined how the commitment to safeguarding human rights in the world must be a top priority for Europe and for each of us. With the approval of this report we reiterate the rejection and fight against any form of discrimination, any violence against the most fragile people to any physical, mental and sexual mortification. We deplore the atrocities that arise from any lack of respect for human rights and dignity. As Members of the S&D Group, in particular, we will continue to promote equality and social inclusion as inalienable rights of any human being.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: in writing. - The non-binding resolution addresses the biggest problems with regard to fundamental rights in the EU in 2015. I support the call for Member States to jointly stand up to the maintenance and strengthening of fundamental rights in the EU.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this non-legislative report. I strongly support equal rights for all genders, races and sexualities. I also support the condemnation of crimes such as violence, child abuse and human trafficking. That being said, however, I reject the attempts to politicise this report in favour of EU charters, bodies and institutions. In particular, I reject the concerns in this report of the rise of Euroscepticism across Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in  favour of this report which identifies key areas of concern in relation to the situation of fundamental rights. Against the backdrop of significant increases in hate crime, it is essential that efforts are made at EU, national and local level to counter extremism and promote respect for diversity. It is important that Member States work together and uphold solidarity by tackling areas of common interest to strengthen democracy and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: As every year, Parliament reports on the situation of human rights in the European Union, which is necessarily bad or in the process of becoming so bad. This report is especially an opportunity for intense pro-immigration propaganda or in favour of any minority, especially if it is noisy. There are rights that this type of report, the pinnacle of European politically correct, nevertheless never addresses: the right to freedom of expression of a dissenting opinion, particularly in matters of immigration, or in the moral field, any dissent being described by you as “hate speech”; the right to be taken into account, with respect and without respect stigma, the opinions of the peoples expressed by their votes; the right to protect its culture, way of life, customs and millennial values for every European people on its territory, the identity of Europe and its members does not limit itself to the “right of the manmist” that you so much love; the right to security, first of freedoms, constantly challenged by your policies, of which the attacks of recent months are the most terrible consequence. The culmination of your logic is that the majority of Europeans will soon have only one right: to suffer in silence.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which is carried out annually, aims to present the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and propose recommendations. In its visit to the Civil Liberties Committee, important changes have been made, such as removing the most problematic aspects and including many of our group's amendments, such as those relating to migration and asylum, the protection of whistleblowers, the assessment of counter-terrorism measures, condemning mass surveillance indiscriminate, etc. It is important to note that the report mentions aspects of corruption, racism and xenophobia, gender equality and violence against women, the rights of the Roma community, LGBT rights, as well as rights of children, other minorities, persons with disabilities, the elderly and digital rights . However, as a rapporteur for the EPP, we have not succeeded in making reference to how economic policy, especially austerity measures, have affected the fundamental rights of European citizenship. That is why a new attempt was made by tabling amendments at this plenary meeting. Since the majority were rejected, I voted abstention.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because it is essential to have a situation on respect for fundamental rights in the EU. The Charter of Fundamental Rights, a document of the same legal value as the Treaties, underlines their importance for the EU. The European Union is a community founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons among minorities. In the current global context, the EU and Member States should support and ensure compliance with these values in every action they take. In all actions taken by Member States and the EU, it is essential to respect fundamental rights and civil liberties, including respect for privacy and family life, the right to freedom and security, the right to the protection of personal data, the presumption of innocence and the right of defence, the right to an effective remedy and to a fair trial, freedom of expression and information, freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In the face of a Europe plagued by doubts and uncertainties, the European Union must endeavour to strengthen and guarantee the fundamental rights on which it has built itself. The own-initiative report by Jozsef Nagy places particular emphasis on the issues of freedom, security as well as those of minorities and people in great difficulty. The rise in populism and the increase in violence within the European territory reminded us that fundamental rights are at risk and that it was the responsibility of the European Parliament to enforce them. It is for this reason that I wanted to stand in favour of Jozsef Nagy's own-initiative report, as well as my parliamentary group, so that the rule of law remains the cornerstone of European democracy.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which is based on principles of decency and equality. It covers important questions such as those pertaining to: the rule of law; migration, integration and social inclusion; freedom and security; trafficking in human beings; combating discrimination, xenophobia, hate crime and hate speech; women’s rights and violence against women; children; rights of minorities; rights of people with disabilities; Roma rights; LGBTI rights; and citizenship. It is vital to continue fighting for principles of decency and equality and not to accept any form of discrimination against any of our citizens.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. — I supported this European Parliament's annual report on fundamental rights because it denounces the main issues encountered in 2015 and proposes public policy objectives. The draft initial report of the EPP rapporteur ignored certain fundamental rights or suggested problematic elements, particularly with regard to migration, minorities and social rights. In negotiations with the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs, our group managed to include the fact that the rights of women, the LGBTI community, Roma and unaccompanied minors must be protected, which I welcome. Finally, I welcome the fact that some amendments have been supported in plenary. These include sexual and reproductive rights, combating violence against transgender people, and the right to protection from exclusion and poverty.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The report on the human rights situation in the EU is made every year and aims to present the situation in the EU on the basis of human rights and, in addition, to make recommendations for improving the current situation. In addition to some positive elements contained in the report, there are many key weaknesses. The report makes no reference to the negative consequences of the crisis and the austerity measures that prevent access to fundamental rights, social rights and access to the basic human needs such as education and the health system. Furthermore, there is no mention of the need for the right to protection against poverty and social exclusion either. The absence of reference to social rights as an integral part of fundamental rights is important, as these are recognised by international and European conventions, but they generally escape the approach of the EU institutions on fundamental rights. These are some of the reasons that led us to vote against this report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with a broad cross-party majority of Members in the European Parliament, approved this report regarding the situation of Fundamental Rights in the EU in 2015. Recent developments in some EU Member States have had a negative impact on the protection of fundamental rights, in particular for vulnerable groups such as migrants, refugees, children and women. I believe we must act to scrutinise respect for and promotion of Fundamental rights across the Union. Democracy is a necessary condition for the rule of law, it is not sufficient to guarantee it. It is our obligation and our moral duty to guarantee that fundamental rights in the EU are protected.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz—KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision which was not of legal relevance following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. — I abstained on the vote on the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union in 2015, since some of the amendments adopted distort the report as measured in its initial drafting. The amendments of the extreme left adopted with the complicity of the Socialists and the extreme right do not reflect the reality of the facts but a certain conception of reality that we are held to be true. This is all the more deplorable given that the report provided a realistic diagnosis of the situation of vulnerable groups such as children, women, persons with disabilities and the elderly. The report also proposed an analysis of migration and integration in the Member States with due respect for the distinction between migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. However, I would like to point out that I do not share the recommendations concerning the promotion of regional and minority languages which run counter to our principle of indivisibility advocated by the French Constitution. Finally, I do not understand this obsession with wanting to impose a systematic gender assessment in all legislative proposals, whereas this does not make sense for purely technical texts such as, for example, the framework for the use of mercury.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Any form of discrimination against any of our citizens should not be accepted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the State of Fundamental Rights in the European Union in 2015 (2016/2009 (INI)), since the proposed document comprehensively outlines the biggest problems and the current situation on this issue. Human dignity is an inviolable basis of all fundamental rights and should be respected and protected in all EU initiatives. All forms of discrimination and violence in the EU should be condemned. The freedom of movement and residence of European citizens enshrined by the Treaties and guaranteed by the Free Movement Directive is one of the fundamental rights of European citizens. It is necessary to consider the possibility of establishing a whistleblower protection program and sources of information for journalists. The situation in prisons in some Member States is unsatisfactory. It is important to achieve social inclusion and integration of migrants and refugees who have been granted international protection that includes rights and obligations and whose integral parts are respect for the values on which the EU is built. Concerns are raised about reported cases of organised crime infiltration into the management of funds intended to accommodate migrants. It is necessary to support Member States in their efforts to prevent radicalisation and violent extremism. Attention needs to be paid due to increased racism and xenophobia in the form of afrophobia, bigotry towards Roma and Jews, Islamophobia and intolerance to migrants. Hate crime cases and hate speech need to be condemned particularly given the increasing presence of hate speech online.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — Driven by its willingness to urge Member States to release more funds for the reception of migrants, this report is still too full of ideology favourable to immigration, just as it seeks to halt freedom of expression under the pretext of combating hatred. I voted against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it takes into consideration recent developments concerning fundamental rights in several EU Member States. The current situation calls for a strong message that fundamental rights have to be protected and preserved. I am glad that it stresses the importance of full respect for the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality applying both to Member States and to the EU’s institutions based on a gradual approach, including both a preventative and corrective arm. Furthermore, I welcomed the special attention paid to children’s rights stressing the importance of the need for their highest protection. I find it crucial that the European Union does not forget that it has been built on respect for the rule of law and that it cannot take this cornerstone for granted.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Jozsef Nagy on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union during 2015, a text aimed at taking stock of the situation and challenges facing the EU in this area. The rapporteur, who was to cover topics as diverse and complex as the rule of law, the rights of children, minorities, women, the elderly, persons with disabilities and security, achieved a balanced outcome. The text also addresses the issue, rarely highlighted, of digital rights, including the protection of personal data and raising awareness of the dangers of the Internet among young people. It is important that the legislator adapts to technological developments; that is why I am mobilised on these issues in my work in the Committee on Culture. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the protection of fundamental rights in the Member States of the European Union. Covering topics as diverse as the rule of law, the rights of children, minorities, women, the elderly, persons with disabilities and security, the report strikes a certain balance. The report notes that, while the Charter of Fundamental Rights has become an integral part of the Treaties, violations of fundamental rights still occur in the EU and its Member States, demonstrating the continuing need to ensure that these rights are respected in our Member States. The text also focuses on the rise of Euroscepticism and the expression of violent political positions. A stronger citizen participation is required so that Europeans can express their concerns through democratic means, the only antidote to populism.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The report, which deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015, focuses on the migration and refugee crisis in a distorted light and calls for more rights for migrants and refugees in an undifferentiated way. The rapporteur calls for the creation of legal entry opportunities.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which identifies key areas of concern in relation to the situation of fundamental rights. Against a backdrop of significant increases in hate crime, it is essential that efforts are made at EU, national and local level to counter extremism and promote respect for diversity. It is important that Member States work together and uphold solidarity by tackling areas of common interest to strengthen democracy and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: in writing. - The 2015 Nagy report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union addresses a wide range of issues. Among them we find positive approaches, such as the fight against female genital mutilation or human smuggling. Unfortunately, on a number of issues, the report goes far beyond what should be classified as fundamental rights. Examples include the call for intercultural curricula in schools, the call for the introduction of the ideology of gender mainstreaming in “all policy areas” and the fight against “institutionalised racism” in school education. The Nagy report refuses any analysis of cultural and religious backgrounds in many human rights violations and assigns responsibility to men alone or to the institutionalized racism of society. Because of these blatant shortcomings, I rejected the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — I was sorry to have to abstain from the 2015 vote on the state of fundamental rights in the EU, but I did not believe that this document addresses the issue of human rights comprehensively. I disagree with how narrowly human rights are interpreted lately. Why aren't they talked about so much in relation to the conditions and salaries of supermarket cashiers or postal delivery services? Why is so little use of the term human rights in context with children whose parents can't afford to pay them lunches in school canteens? Moreover, it did not pass an amendment stating that it “condemns the fact that the economic crisis and austerity measures implemented to address it have seriously damaged basic social, civil and employment rights, inter alia, the right to access basic needs such as education, housing, health care and social security, as well as negative in some Member States impact on the general health of the population; therefore calls on the EU institutions and Member States to carry out ex-ante assessments on the impact on fundamental human rights for all policies and to ensure that sufficient resources available to ensure respect for fundamental rights, and to ensure the necessary minimum level of civil economic, cultural and social rights, with particular emphasis on the most vulnerable and socially disadvantaged groups”.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision, which was not of legal relevance, following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: in writing. - In principle, I support the report on the State of Fundamental Rights of the EU. Unfortunately, there are points in the text that I cannot support in this way. Claims in the field of family law interfere with the principle of subsidiarity and can therefore not be supported by me. I am also clearly opposed to a human right to abortion. For me, the protection of unborn life is in the foreground. That is why I abstained from the final vote.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as many of the amendments of the GUE/NGL group have been included in this report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and it includes many positive elements, which I strongly support, such as the possibility of setting up a whistleblower protection scheme or the urgent call for an effective anti-corruption strategy.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: In writing. ‒ Parliament's Annual Report on Fundamental Rights in the EU 2015 addresses key challenges in the field of human rights and this year in particular in the areas of migration, protection of minors and incitement to hatred. With this report, we affirmed the need for Member States to step up efforts to promote European values, tolerance and the sense of community without any stigmatization of minorities. We called on Member States to refrain from inciting fear and hatred of migrants and asylum seekers among their citizens in order to gain political advantages, and to carry out campaigns positive aimed at fostering a better approach by citizens to integration. Concerned by increasing levels of incitement to hatred by certain political parties, media and institutions, we also called on the European Union to act as an example in the fight against incitement to hatred within its institutions. I am happy that Parliament has already supplemented this recommendation by reforming its rules of procedure. These are issues that I am very close to my heart and which I have been fighting for a long time and that is why I welcomed this report and supported it in the House.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU contains fundamental rights and freedoms that are protected in the EU such as dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, rule of law, human rights and minority rights. Despite the fact that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has become a fully-fledged component of the EU treaties and the national legislation of the Member States, fundamental rights violations do occur in the EU and its Member States. Unfortunately, nowadays in the EU there is increasing racism, homophobia and xenophobia in the forms of Afrophobia, anti-Gypsyism, anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and anti-migrant sentiment. Furthermore, there is a growing presence of hate speech on the internet, from within certain institutions, political parties and media. Last but not least, in some Member States EU citizens have been disfranchised of their citizen/national voting rights in EU and national elections when they exercise their fundamental right to use a minority language in an election campaign. Therefore, I take the view that further efforts should be made towards a consistent and uniform implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, including through awareness-raising measures among practitioners and the general public, in order to guarantee that the rule of law and fundamental rights of European citizens are respected and promoted.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — The European Union was founded on principles of freedom, equality and democracy, the rule of law and the protection of human rights. Despite the fact that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has been incorporated into the EU treaties, there are still some situations of infringement of rights in some Member States. Parliament urges that vegan measures to protect fundamental rights and human dignity, the rule of law, integration and social inclusion, freedom and security, rights children, minorities, people with disabilities and the elderly, and focusing on combating discrimination, xenophobia, hate offences and incitement to hatred and violence against women. With the EU's objective in forming a more inclusive and cohesive society in mind, I am voting in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. As every year, there are several passages that testify to immigrationism pushed to the extreme. In particular, it encourages Member States to “allocate adequate resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants. The text also tackles freedom of expression. It is concerned about “the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet; recommends that Member States establish a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online; welcomes the Commission's presentation of a code of conduct on combating illegal hate speech in the EU. and invites us to join current and ongoing efforts to strengthen cooperation with the private sector and civil society.” I have no affinity for hate speech, but I denounce the use of this expression to criminalize any critical speech about mass immigration.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. — As every year, this text is full of immigrationist passages to the extreme. In particular, it encourages States to “allocate adequate resources to the establishment of legal and secure routes of entry”. It also urges Member States to put in place “a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online”. That is a direct encouragement to the disconnection, which I obviously condemn. I could only vote against this annual report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I think it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social (although the rapporteur tried to censor references to fundamental rights before voting in plenary). I think, however, that a good diagnosis is not enough: the Union must reverse its migration, economic and social policies if it is to curb this difficult situation.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. ‒ The Union has a decisive commitment to the respect and promotion of fundamental rights. For example, respect for these is one of the conditions for joining the Union. In addition, the Union, in its external action, must be based on the promotion of dignity and all other fundamental rights. This report addresses a number of current issues relating to fundamental rights within the Union. For example, it paid attention to refugees with special needs and children, including a number of measures aimed at protecting children from trafficking in persons and other kinds of abuse. The report does not obviate the increase in hate speech in recent times and in the face of which the Union should set an example to the rest of the world by fighting them in a real and effective way. My vote is favourable because the text will undoubtedly contribute to the protection of the rights of the most disadvantaged.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: in writing. - The 2015 Nagy report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union addresses a wide range of issues. Among them we find positive approaches, such as the fight against female genital mutilation or human smuggling. Unfortunately, on a number of issues, the report goes far beyond what should be classified as fundamental rights. It places a disproportionate emphasis on sexual rights and its alleged infringement and, in my view, shows too negative a picture of equality between men and women in the European Union. That is why I abstained from voting on the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I voted against. I do not agree with the call for Member States to enact registered partnerships or marriages for persons of the “LGBTI” group. Marriage legislation is a matter for individual member states, and the EU should not push member states into this kind of legislation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — The European Union today faces a number of challenges regarding the protection of fundamental rights, mostly in the areas of migration, integration and social inclusion, trafficking in human beings, fighting discrimination, hate crimes and speech, violence against women, child protection, minority rights, etc. While I believe violence against women is a violation of their fundamental rights and that we should all fight it together, I voted abstently given the gender ideology outlined in this report. It is completely inappropriate in the report on strengthening equality and promoting women's rights to introduce issues of gender ideology as well.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. — The European Union sees far beyond its borders, but often doesn't see what is happening at home. What are the reasons for this myopia? In my opinion, such are two: inability to see and unwillingness to see The failure to see the EU came across this year when it emerged that there was no EU institution that could independently and professionally identify problems in Hungary and Poland. Before candidate countries joined the EU, they had to meet the Copenhagen criteria. When a country has already joined the EU, it emerged that no one is looking at whether that country continues to meet these criteria. The EU treaties write that Member States combine common values, including human rights. If we weren't even interested in what was happening in the EU, it means that we are hypochonising and human rights are not our shared values. In Latvia, a large part of the population lives with a bizarre status — former citizens of the USSR, and they cannot vote in parliamentary, European Parliament or local elections for a quarter of a century. If this situation occurred in a non-EU country, the European Parliament would certainly adopt a condemning resolution. Because it is a member of the EU, there is silence. Because there is an unwritten law in the EU: you will not see my problems, but I will not see yours, but will show your principled principles in foreign affairs. This vicious circle needs to be torn. For the time being, let's not talk about actions, but we'll train at least to notice problems.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. ‒ In its basic documents, the EU declares itself to the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. I supported the report tabled, which assesses the implementation of fundamental rights in individual areas and policies. The report must serve as a basis for further action by the legislative and executive bodies of the Union and of the Member States, as well as of fundamental rights organisations, in order to take effective measures to address the deficiencies identified, including the necessary revision of legal standards.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, and because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text, on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU, is very far from our political line by being particularly immigrationist. In particular, it wishes to “allocate sufficient resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants (§25), which we oppose. On the other hand, it seems to be undermining freedom of expression by, for example, seeking to combat “the growing presence of hate speech on the internet” by introducing “a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online”. We criticize online hate speech, of course, but it is part of freedom of expression, a fundamental human right.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ The European Parliament report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 represents the European Parliament's ongoing commitment to the protection of fundamental rights and human dignity but also the firm willingness on the part of the European Union to protect these rights in its external relations. Finally, the proposal covers important and sensitive topics, encouraging confrontation and discussion on the rule of law, migration processes and the situation of women. In order to pursue these fundamental causes and values, I welcomed the proposal with a positive vote.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we addressed a report assessing the state of human rights in the EU for 2015. Basically, its entire content is somehow related to the theme of migration and refugees. The report details the damning phenomenon of human trafficking, we call for the need to provide migrants with access to quality medical care, integration and social inclusion, improving asylum proceedings and ensuring the protection of women and girls in particular from any form of violence. Combining families is another of necessities, of course. However, there I am completely devoid of consideration over the cause of mass migration and proposals for a long-term solution, which certainly does not call for Member States to support positively tuned campaigns explaining the need for integration of incoming refugees. That's why I abstained at the final vote.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. - This report deals with fundamental rights in the EU, which must be understood as rights inherent to all human beings, valid for all peoples and at all times. They therefore constitute inviolable, timeless and universal rights, and therefore they must always be protected and respected. Although this report does not cover all the situations that should be taken into account, it proposes a number of positive measures to protect and safeguard fundamental rights in the EU, including migration/asylum, gender equality and violence against women, corruption, discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, etc. I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. - I support the report by which the European Parliament will call for an end to incitement to hatred against migrants and refugees. Union countries should refrain from inciting among their citizens fear and hatred against migrants and asylum-seekers in order to obtain political revenues. The report perfectly summarizes the main concerns about fundamental rights in the Union in 2015, focusing on migration, child protection and the internet, as well as the right to free movement and access to abortion in case of life risk.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. - I am in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU 2015, because fundamental rights are universal and indivisible and it is necessary to ensure that the principles deriving from Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights are applied both in the European as well as in national legislation. The EU institutions are called upon to ensure a high level of protection of these rights in external relations. Finally, I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, because freedom of expression, information and the media is fundamental and inviolable in guaranteeing democracy and the rule of law.

name: Georg MAYER
text: in writing. - I was unable to support the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015, as the migration and refugee crisis in particular is presented in a positive light and more rights are required for migrants and refugees. The rapporteur also calls for the creation of legal entry opportunities and greater tolerance in intercultural and interreligious terms. Other negative aspects of the report were, on the one hand, the call for the legitimate recognition of sex change at Union level and the prohibition of medical examinations of intersex children, and, on the other hand, that schools should pay particular attention to homophobia in sport and young LGBTI people.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The report addresses the problems of a social, legal, political and economic nature faced by the most vulnerable groups of society in EU countries.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Each year, Parliament takes stock of the respect for fundamental rights in the European Union. The report contains positive elements on the rights of refugees and migrants and their social inclusion, the protection of whistleblowers, the assessment of terrorist measures and the state of emergency. It condemns mass surveillance and supports the right to oblivion, control and access to personal data. He even defends LGBTI rights, especially transgender and marriage for all. Even though the rapporteur is on the right. That being said, the report does not speak at any time about the impact of austerity policies on these fundamental rights. It is just if he admits that the Union's fight against poverty has not achieved its objectives. There is also nothing about environmental rights, when the European Commission constantly pollutes us with its GMOs and chemicals, aided by the big lobbies of Brussels. Here too, corruption and slippers will not be targeted. Under these conditions, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - This annual report does not differ from previous ones. It highlights the immigrationist policy desired by Europe to the detriment of Member States by encouraging Member States to allocate sufficient resources for the creation of safe and legal routes of entry for migrants. The regression of freedom of expression is also one of the recommendations of this report, which calls on Member States to set up a system of citizens' denunciation of hate speech on the internet and welcomes the presentation by the European Commission of a code of conduct on combating illegal hate speech online. Considering that only Member States must manage migration policies sovereignly, and considering that the fight against certain speeches is just another attempt to muzzle those who oppose the crazy immigrationist policy of the EU, I opposed this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union during 2015. Despite the fact that our values are enshrined in the Charter and in Article 2 of the Treaty, the European continent is not immune to gross violations of human rights. Each year the European Parliament observes this and this year's report is no exception. The rise of extremes poses a serious danger to our democracies and the drifts observed in some Member States are pushing the Union to act so that the Treaties are respected by all and at all times. In this regard, I would like to reiterate the need for continuous and objective monitoring of the respect by all Member States of the values that underpin European integration. With regard to the text before the vote, I chose to follow my group by rejecting most of the amendments proposed in plenary so as not to risk losing the comfortable majority obtained in the parliamentary committee and being able to send a strong signal from the European Parliament.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which urges to continue fighting for the principles of decency and equality and will not accept any form of discrimination against any of our citizens. However, I have never supported any references to abortion and women’s sexual and reproductive health and rights, which, in my opinion, are strictly a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — The draft resolution of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union is extremely thorough: it takes stock of the rights of women, children, minorities, persons with disabilities, the elderly, the Roma and the LGBTI . It addresses some issues that are particularly relevant and topical for human rights, such as migration, integration and social inclusion, trafficking in human beings and discrimination, xenophobia, hate crime and hate speech. Regarding migration, I consider it particularly important that the draft) states that the fundamental rights of migrants and refugees are violated in many cases at the external borders of the European Union and calls on Member States and EU institutions to ensure that border surveillance actions and asylum procedures respect for international and Union law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union; (b) calls for reception conditions that do not deprive people of their fundamental right to a worthy standard of living and physical and mental health, or comply with existing fundamental rights and asylum legislation; (c) calls on Member States to refrain from arousing fear and hatred among their citizens against migrants and asylum seekers in order to gain political advantage. I supported the adoption of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: This annual report contains no less than 138 paragraphs. As every year, there are several passages that testify to immigrationism pushed to the extreme. In particular, it encourages Member States to “allocate adequate resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants (§25). The text also tackles freedom of expression. It is concerned about “the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet; recommends that Member States establish a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online; welcomes the Commission's presentation of a code of conduct on combating illegal hate speech in the EU. and invites us to join current and ongoing efforts to strengthen cooperation with the private sector and civil society” (§57). Unfavourable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: This annual report contains no less than 138 paragraphs. As every year, there are several passages that testify to immigrationism pushed to the extreme. In particular, it encourages Member States to “allocate adequate resources to the creation of legal and safe routes of entry” for migrants (§25). The text also tackles freedom of expression.
