It is concerned about “the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet; recommends that Member States establish a simple procedure for citizens to report hate content online; welcomes the Commission's presentation of a code of conduct on combating hate speech illegal online and calls for adherence to current and ongoing efforts to strengthen cooperation with the private sector and civil society” (§57). This text is therefore absolutely unacceptable.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report, which identifies key areas of concern in relation to the situation of fundamental rights. Against the backdrop of significant increases in hate crime, it is essential that efforts are made at EU, national and local level to counter extremism and promote respect for diversity. It is important that Member States work together and uphold solidarity by tackling areas of common interest to strengthen democracy and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Indeed, the text maintains confusion between migrants and refugees. He thus participates in the call for illegal immigration already launched by the European Commission with its irresponsible policy of quotas for migrants. This highly unbalanced text considers that “immigration is part of the present and future of the European Union” or “a demographic opportunity”. I can't endorse him.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU was proclaimed in 2000 and became legally binding on the EU with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon in December 2009. I have voted for this report that enshrines certain political, social and economic rights for EU citizens and residents in EU law.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. - I supported Mr Nad's report because the European Union is a community based on values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law. I believe that Member States need to take more serious measures on the infringements of fundamental rights identified by reports from the European Commission, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), the Council of Europe and non-governmental organisations. I believe that raising values such as peace, equality, justice and respect for human rights among adolescents will strengthen their commitment to EU issues, allowing them to express their positions more democratically. Fundamental rights are universal, indivisible and always complemented. That is why not only the European institutions, but all actors at national level, must step up their efforts to protect them. I support the adoption of the necessary measures for the European Union's accession to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) in accordance with Opinion 2/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU, as this will increase the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms of EU citizens.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which actually provides a brief analysis of the state of the Union with regard to the situation of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, because I believe that current debates and social developments must not make us forget that we are a community based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law. In this respect, today's report recalls how important it is for Member States to respect these values in their work internally or externally. I also consider it appropriate to propose the report that the EU, through its Member States, ratify the Council of Europe Convention on the fight against trafficking in human beings, but also that the promotion and support through education of programmes against racism and discrimination has to be one of our priorities.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because, in particular, the migration and refugee crisis is being presented in a positive light and more rights are being demanded for migrants and refugees.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. The report focuses on the situation of fundamental rights in 2015, covering all possible areas, including migration, trafficking, women's rights, children, LGTB and digital rights.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. ‒ The countries of the Union should refrain from inciting among their citizens fear and hatred against migrants and asylum-seekers in order to obtain and maintain power. It is horrible to strip human beings of all dignity, with toxic behaviors reminiscent of the darkest historical times. Humiliation is increasing at an alarming rate in some institutions, political parties and the media, fueling the bonfires of fanaticism and extremism. Assuming our responsibility lies in the negligence of almost every European country to act Europe. When they have let solidarity between equals dilute, turning their backs on a human drama that has cost thousands of lives, and which history will eventually judge harshly. Human beings, children and adults, women and men deserve our firm rejection of violent extremism. And this is fought with education and culture.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - Human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, are the values on which the EU is founded. However, racism, discrimination, extremism and intolerance are today a major challenge for the European Union. The current complex crises and the widespread violations and abuses of human rights and fundamental freedoms require increasingly determined efforts by the EU. I voted in favour of the report, which sets out the main issues to be emphasised, which include: combating trafficking networks and traffickers, combating discrimination and prejudice against religion or belief, age, disability , sexual orientation or gender identity, combating violence against women, freedom of the media, communication and information, tackling violations of fundamental rights of migrants and refugees at the EU's external borders and social inclusion; and integration into the host society of those who enjoy international protection and the fight against child poverty.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. — The report is provocative hypocrisy. The EU selectively uses the protection of human rights as a pretext to justify its anti-grassroots policy and the civil governments of its Member States and to legitimise their imperialist interventions throughout the world, in Syria, in the wider region of South Africa. Mediterranean and B. Africa, where EU-US-NATO compete with other imperialist forces to control wealth sources, energy transport routes and exploit peoples. Under the convenient pretext of “combating terrorism” they deliberately use the term “radicalisation” distorted, to discredit the struggle of the working people against the capitalist system. They impose anti-communist laws, persecution of the KK and communist ideology on a number of EU countries, at the same time they pay honors and support the most reactionary forces, political descendants of the Nazis, against the peoples, such as Ukraine. They are aimed at restricting grassroots freedoms, targeting the working-grassroots movement and intimidation. The political representatives of the monopolies challenge the peoples by pretending to be the protector of human rights, while they are at the forefront of the crushing of grassroots freedoms, the suppression of trade union freedoms, the gigantic mechanisms of repression, the demolition of labour rights, the spread of poverty, poverty and misery.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe it has very well rebuilt the framework of fundamental rights of the European Union in 2015. This last year has been particularly difficult in respect of fundamental rights due to the radicalisation of violence, even terrorist violence, xenophobia and forms of discrimination that result in the rhetoric of incitement to hatred.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The protection of the fundamental rights of people is at the core of European values, together with solidarity and non-discrimination. I voted in favour of this report as I believe we must address the increasing challenges ahead of us with regard to tackling issues such as hate crime, hate speech, freedom and security, violence against women, minorities, or children, as well as protection against violation of digital rights. By granting the integrity of the fundamental rights of all EU citizens I believe we will be a step further and we will ease the discontent about Europe.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - This report on the state of fundamental rights in the EU in 2015 concerns me because it is not in line with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The report in many respects goes outside the Charter, which I cannot support because expanding the scope distracts attention from the essential. We must not take violations of fundamental rights lightly. Human dignity and integrity are inviolable. Therefore, in this sense, I welcome the condemnation of commercial surrogacy in Article 82, but I believe it is necessary to condemn and prohibit all forms of surrogate motherhood, not only commercial because it is evident from the practices of countries that have allowed altruistic surrogacy to open the way for commercialisation, and on After all, this practice can not be considered completely altruistic, but must be categorized as human trafficking. It saddened me that this report is very ideologically coloured, and especially in segments of children's rights. I find it inadmissible in the context of children's rights to talk about gender ideology and thus suppress gender differences from an early age and open up space for children to be manipulated. This is also opposed to the Convention on the Rights of the Child. If we are talking about fundamental rights, I think we need to follow the guidelines of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, which should be the starting point for this report, but this is not the case.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. — The EU and Member States must promote European values and protect all fundamental rights in all their activities when confronting today's challenges. There are several important messages in the report that is important to highlight. With regard to migrants and refugees, their social inclusion and integration in the host society is a very important process that requires concerted efforts of both refugees and migrants as well as Member States. The report condemns the lack of humanity shown at European borders where those fleeing war and persecution are shown no compassion but walls and barbed wire. Furthermore, it is important to stress that the refusal to provide life-saving sexual and reproductive health services, including abortion that saves the mother's life, constitutes a serious violation of human rights. In relation to the protection of LGBTI people, S&D has advocated strong condemnation of all forms of discrimination and violence based on gender orientation and gender identity. Unfortunately we also have to reiterate in this report that Roma continue to face bigotry and institutional racism and remind us that discrimination against Roma is unacceptable and harmful to European society. S&D will continue to fight for the principle of equality and will not accept any form of discrimination by any group of our citizens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Recommendations in the field of freedoms, rights of refugees and migrants, freedom of movement, the right to privacy, the right to information, non-discrimination, equality between men and women, the rights of the child, the rights of persons with disability and the defence of social rights, among others, which we subscribe to. Recommendations which, however, omit the real causes of the problems highlighted, on the one hand, and on the other, as in the case of the humanitarian refugee crisis, remove the degrading reality that the European Union has imposed on tens of thousands of human beings. The strengthening and extension of public services, such as access to health, access to education, access to information, the creation and enjoyment of universal and quality culture, the right to employment and employment with rights, are some of the urgent and necessary measures which do not take place in this report. On the other hand, the defense of the “rule of law” continues, as a tool of interference over sovereign states, imposing the model outlined in the treaties on each country, leaving no room for the implementation of its own models of development, in a demonstration that this is not possible in the straitjacket which is the EU. We voted against it.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. — The fight against discrimination and inequality of Europeans should constitute one of the essential pillars of the function of each Member of the European Parliament. I supported the report on the state of fundamental rights in 2015 because this document makes it clear to the European Commission that there is a need to present a new agenda. An agenda to which all relevant actors and representatives of citizens' rights will participate and which, taking into account the competencies of the Union Member States, will be able to ensure equal opportunities and rights for everyone. It is very conceivable that in Europe, for example, human trafficking and exploitation is still occurring, i.e. illegal activities, which are at the moment, unfortunately, even more stoking means of new communication technologies. I therefore supported the call for both the European Union and the Member States to ratify the Council of Europe Convention on Measures Against Trafficking in Persons and for the work of European agencies on this field to be supported. Member countries are currently seeing a growing trend of racism and xenophobia. So I also voted in favour of the provision that measures to promote equality for citizens should be incorporated into national policies as far as possible. I would very much like to see member countries as well as their lower level authorities support education on human rights and cultures. Education is a very effective means of preventing racism and intolerance. It needs to be used as much as possible.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. — The report broadly addresses the problems of immigration, children's rights, people with disabilities, human smuggling and violence against women. Nevertheless, due to the treatment of reproductive, sexual and abortion rights, I could not support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which reviews the situation of fundamental rights in the EU and addresses its main challenges in this regard. It highlights a number of recurring human rights violations that the EU must take into account. We need to take action to increase the protection of citizens, especially for children who are particularly vulnerable to online threats. We therefore call for strengthening the prerogatives and resources of Europol and Eurojust to combat paedophile networks, as well as awareness-raising campaigns and school curricula to teach children the potential risks associated with the Internet. We must continue to fight every day for a Europe that protects!

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The Union is a community based on respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, including the rights of minorities. In particular, the rule of law is the backbone of European liberal democracy and one of the founding principles of the Union, stemming from the constitutional traditions of the Member States. At the same time, human dignity - man as a value in itself - is the inviolable basis of all fundamental rights, which must not be subjected to any kind of exploitation and must be respected and protected in all EU initiatives. This report puts the right emphasis on the degree of compliance with the catalogues of fundamental rights enshrined in the European Union, establishing an accurate and satisfactory framework for the situation regarding respect for fair fundamental prerogatives last year and in the European universe. I therefore support this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP strongly supports equal rights for all genders, races and sexualities. We also support the condemnation of crimes such as violence, child abuse and human trafficking. That being said, however, we reject the attempts to politicise this report in favour of EU charters, bodies and institutions. In particular, we reject the concerns in this report of the rise of Euroscepticism across Europe.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Mr President, in recent years we have seen a rise in fundamental rights in some countries of the Union. That is why this diagnosis is important, but only if it implies effective measures in trying to counter this state of affairs, especially in relation to the rule of law, women's rights, LGBTI people and migration.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report. It is clear that human rights violations are abound. It is therefore important for us to establish a unified and inclusive system for registering irregularities. It is equally important to work actively inside the European Union in order to avoid the abovementioned violations. It is clear that, by voting, the European Parliament has shown that the protection of human rights remains one of the most important issues in the EU.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: The Charter of Fundamental Rights is an integral part of the European Treaties and the legislation of the Member States (with the exception of derogations granted to Poland, the United Kingdom and the Czech Republic). However, violations of its principles continue to occur in 2015, as stated in this report, for which I voted in favour. The rule of law is the backbone of European Democracy and a prerequisite for the protection of fundamental rights, so the Union 'Pact' on these matters should incorporate country-specific recommendations in order to facilitate its implementation process. Freedom of expression, social inclusion of migrants and refugees, human trafficking, poverty and child exclusion, discrimination against minorities or gender inequalities are some of the violations identified in the report and for which the EU needs to adopt effective solutions in order to accommodate joint solutions in their prevention and combat. Member States need to ensure that their legal systems comply with established European and international standards in order to ensure integration policies and effective measures against incitement to fear, hatred, radicalisation and extremism. The promotion of European values and the exchange of good practice are also fundamental.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the EU's Annual Report on the State of Fundamental Rights in 2015. The starting point for this is that all disputes concerning the annual report have been eliminated in advance. The report outlines the situation of fundamental rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, while it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social, I believe that it does not analyse or explain in sufficient depth the causes of fundamental rights (austerity policies which the Union must reverse, also its policies migratory, economic or social).

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not believe the EU should be getting involved in Member States’ civil liberty law.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which is based on principles of decency and equality. It covers important questions such as those pertaining to the rule of law, migration, integration and social inclusion, freedom and security, trafficking in human beings, combating discrimination, xenophobia, hate crime and hate speech, women’s rights and violence against women, children, rights of minorities, rights of people with disabilities, Roma rights, LGBTI rights, and citizenship. It is vital to continue fighting for principles of decency and equality and not to accept any form of discrimination against any of our citizens

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ As shadow rapporteur on this report, I was eager to highlight protection of the truly vulnerable (children, disabled people and some ethnic minorities). Unfortunately a moderate report became extreme, promoting so called ‘same sex marriage’ through backdoor means (recognition of civil status documents and tackling ‘homophobia’) and abortion (as if it were a woman’s right). As every doctor will show you abortion is not childcare and we need to seriously question a society which promotes sterile relationships when the crisis of our continent is too few babies being born. No European nation has a fertility rate to support a stable population. That is alarming, and must be addressed.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. — The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, democracy, the rule of law and freedom. Despite fundamentally implanted values at the very core of the European Union, we continue to witness a failure to respect fundamental values and preserve human dignity. Commission data indicate that 75 million people become a victim of some form of crime and for these reasons it is high time to act adequately and swiftly on this issue. I supported the European Parliament resolution believing that we will truly become a tolerant society by enabling equal rights for all. Migration is the biggest challenge at present, so it is necessary to promote intercultural and interfaith tolerance through sustained efforts and enhanced dialogue by engaging all stakeholders in society at all levels of government to bridge differences and reduce bigotry. Human dignity is the inviolable basis of all fundamental rights, it must be protected and respected. Citizens' education and intercultural dialogue improves citizens' understanding of the importance of social and political participation, while education on human rights raises their level of awareness of their own rights and teach them how to respect the rights of other persons.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The EU is a community based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. I think that the past year has seriously tested all these values and the ability of the international system to respond to situations of respect for fundamental human rights. Although the EU and its Member States made some progress in the area of fundamental rights in 2015, I would like to point out that in some areas of fundamental rights, we have failed as the EU. This is evidenced not only by the report submitted, but also by the various surveys and results for 2015, of which I would point to at least some. There are at least 3,771 people who have died or disappeared trying to reach a safe place in Europe, up to 75 million people fall victim to crime a year, terrorist attacks were one of the most serious forms of violations of fundamental rights and freedoms, among the most widespread forms of fundamental rights violations included trafficking in human beings for the purposes of sexual exploitation (70% of the identified victims of human trafficking in the EU are EU citizens). This is just a very brief suspension over some of the results, but I want to believe that we will be able to express greater satisfaction when assessing the fundamental rights situation in the EU for 2016.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. I agree that the protection of human rights and freedoms is at an all-time high in the EU, which cannot be considered a permanent condition, and the protection of human rights and freedoms must be daily strive. I consider an important step the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Prevention of Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence, although I do not think the EU should propose any new legislation. I also positively assess the fact that the report is dedicated to the problem of migration and social inclusion and integration of migrants, including the problem of hateful and xenophobic forays towards refugees. Among other things, the report is also dedicated to recognising the connection between women's sexual and reproductive health with a number of human rights; however, I cannot agree with the text of those provisions under which we must in a way to respect and protect the right of all women and girls to sexual and reproductive health and to place artificial interruption of pregnancy among vital essential services in the field of sexual and reproductive health. For these reasons I could not support the text of the report.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. — The European Union is a community based on values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, so the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union is extremely important. Every year, the report critically evaluates the human rights situation in various areas, from the rights of women, children, minorities, people with disabilities, the elderly, LGBTI rights, the rights of migrants and refugees, to discrimination in various areas, as well as rights related to the functioning of the rule of law, etc. At a time when we face rising inequality, poverty, still-high unemployment, spreading forms of precarious work, intolerance to minorities, laying wires and walls, shrinking social and labor rights, such reports are even more important as they highlight how much work is still ahead. But the key in this is that the report does not merely constitute dead letters on paper, but that its contents and especially recommendations are also taken into account in practice. Since I am firmly convinced that it is the duty of our society and thus the European Union as a whole to provide human rights and dignity to all parts of our society, I strongly support the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: ‒ Every year, the EP gives its opinion on compliance with fundamental rights in the EU. This year this was summarised in the Nagy report, which I voted for. The report states that there are still many opportunities to improve European policy on fundamental rights. The rapporteur initially tried to keep his report as limited as possible in order to avoid 'difficult' discussions on migration, security, women's rights and LGTB rights and a European approach to those countries that violate rights in this area. He wanted to confine himself to less controversial issues such as children's rights or combating discrimination based on age and disability. The PPE also recently voted against more progressive reports in the area of fundamental rights. The Greens have tabled 68 amendments with more stringent wording on many issues, such as migration and asylum, social rights, homeless people, discrimination, the fight against terrorism, the prison system, the Roma and other minorities. Approximately three-quarters of these amendments were adopted. So although we are improving the original report together with other political groups, the text adopted is somewhat less progressive than in previous years because the PPE and the Conservative ECR did not want to support recommendations on women's rights, socio-economic rights and LGTB rights.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: in writing. - The 2015 Nagy report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union addresses a wide range of issues. Among them we find positive approaches, such as the fight against female genital mutilation or human smuggling. Unfortunately, on a number of issues, the report goes far beyond what should be classified as fundamental rights. Examples include the call for intercultural curricula in schools, the call for the introduction of the ideology of gender mainstreaming in “all policy areas” and the fight against “institutionalised racism” in school education. The Nagy report refuses any analysis of cultural and religious backgrounds in many human rights violations and assigns responsibility to men alone or to the institutionalized racism of society. Because of these blatant shortcomings, I rejected the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. ‒ It is positive that the report points out that corruption and the mismanagement of public finances are also a violation of the fundamental rights of citizens of the European Union. In the future, we should focus more on these phenomena and work on a pan-European strategy to combat corruption, which contributes significantly to reducing citizens' confidence in the state and its institutions.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. It is not for the EU to define a catalogue of fundamental rights according to contemporary values and to enforce it all over the world. Human rights have grown on and in traditions. They are not arbitrarily changeable and elude the manipulative access of the legislator. In addition, the change in fundamental rights, which were once mere defensive rights and should be again today, is detrimental to a comprehensive justification. Asfa-Wossen Asserate says: “Occasionally, it has been mentioned how worrying it is on the character when you feel entitled to anything and actually to anything. The law is one of humanity's most exalted creations if it has not been revealed to it, but feeling entitled to it is one of the lowest states of mind. Everyone knows secretly that he has the right to kick his butt at best. Having silenced this knowledge is a sure sign of vulgarity. ”

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. — The European Commission, the Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA), the Council of Europe and the UN and NVOs point out in their reports that violations of fundamental rights occur in the European Union and Member States. The Charter of Fundamental Rights has become a full-fledged component of the Treaty, therefore it is necessary to protect them. The European Union is a community founded on the values of respect for human dignity, human rights, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and minority rights. Therefore, the EU and Member States need to support and implement these values in every activity with a view to increasing and maintaining mutual trust and countering threats. The most important security challenges the EU currently faces are the fight against terrorism and the refugee surge. In order for the EU to be ready to help the fight for human rights, it must first address the primary security issues of EU citizens, and for this reason I do not support this report.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Not only does corruption weaken Europe's economy, thereby lowering the welfare of citizens and citizens — according to the European Commission estimates two years ago, corruption per year causes some €120 billion of damage to the European economy — but by violating laws and abuse of power, it also leads to violations of human rights. Given that because of the very nature of corruption acts, which are generally covert and well planned, people often do not realize that their human rights are violated, it is therefore necessary to raise awareness of people in which cases their fundamental rights have been violated. As a society, we must have zero tolerance for corruption.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. The report contains both positive and negative reports. Some of the positive reports relate to refugees and the current framework for asylum, the massive violation of the rights of prisoners, increasing racism and xenophobia. However, the report makes no reference to the negative consequences of the crisis and the austerity measures preventing access to fundamental rights and access to basic human needs such as education and the health system. Furthermore, there is no mention of the need for the right to protection against poverty and social exclusion. References to the immediate establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office with special and exclusive powers and the proposal to give the Commission power to impose sanctions on Member States can also be included in the negative aspects of the report. For these reasons we have voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - Fundamental rights, human dignity, the rule of law, freedom and security must not be the scope of political contemplation, the auctioning of sociality and human sensitivity.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. — The part of the annual report on the situation of fundamental rights adopted by the European Parliament concerning national and linguistic minorities has become particularly strong, unlike previous years. The Fidesz—KDNP delegation therefore supported this political decision which was not of legal relevance following the EPP recommendation. At the same time, on a number of points, including those falling within the competence of the Member States, it voted against the text. It is of paramount importance that the reference to the best report on the protection of minorities in recent years, the Calmar Report of the Council of Europe, and the call for it to become part of EU law. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are human and fundamental rights which must be respected by the Union under the Treaty on European Union. It is therefore right to expect European decision-makers, especially the European Commission, to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way as part of fundamental rights.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which gives a comprehensive and fundamentally realistic picture of fundamental human rights in the Member States of the European Union. I think it is important that the summary gives due attention to the violations that threaten the most vulnerable groups in society, such as violence against women and children, discrimination against certain minorities, and various forms of hate speech. The report also addresses the responsibility of the Union and its Member States to face the new fundamental rights challenges and problems arising from the refugee crisis and the migration wave, as well as its relevance and relevance. At the same time, as an MEP representative of a Member State that is unfortunately perhaps the most seriously affected by official violations of the Member States — such as the rule of law, the demolition of democratic political rights, the illegal and inhuman treatment of refugees, the continuation of Roma and other minorities — I would have seen it justified to tougher condemn practices contrary to European standards at certain points in the report against general wording blurring the specific responsibility of the Member States.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. — The European Union is based on the values of respect for the dignity of the human person, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, as well as respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Any manifestation of discrimination or violence is a direct violation of all these principles. However, despite the passage of more than 70 years since the end of World War II, and almost 30 years since the fall of the Iron Curtain, the fundamental rights of Europeans continue to be violated and violated. This report addresses a great number of problems concerning citizens of the European Union. From protecting dignity, rule of law, freedom and security to inclusion and inclusion and on minority rights, discrimination, violence against women and hate speech ending. In particular, this latter issue should be of concern, because hate speech is intensifying among political forces, also via the Internet. Meanwhile, tackling discrimination, racism and xenophobia is crucial when it comes to ensuring that European values such as tolerance, diversity and mutual respect are respected.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. - The European Union is a community united in diversity, based on values of respect for democracy and the rule of law, human dignity, freedom, equality, human rights and the rights of minorities. As such, respect for fundamental rights is the essence of European construction, which makes it necessary to assess their situation at community level, taking into account evidence of numerous human rights violations in the EU (as reported by the Commission European, the Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), the Council of Europe, the UN and various NGOs. The situation in respect of fundamental rights in the EU brings to the attention of all interested parties the need to base all actions taken by the community and the Member States on the principles and values of the rule of law and democracy, rights fundamental and civil liberties. The impact assessments of all legislative proposals must also include aspects of fundamental rights and freedoms in the EU. In this context, the substantiation, operationalisation and implementation of sound policies and mechanisms anchored in the reality of the present and taking into account the dangers of the future, in terms of social inclusion and integration, access to education and training, freedom of expression, security and protection (of rights and integrity), is the key to ensuring fundamental rights in the EU.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - The European Union is based on a number of fundamental principles, including combating all forms of discrimination and respect for basic rights and freedoms. Unfortunately, in the context of the intensification of migration of non-EU people affected by wars and persecutions, there have also been a number of xenophobic attitudes towards these groups, but also towards other minorities on the territory of the Member States, for example towards the Roma minority. The European institutions must continue to promote social inclusion and integration of migrants and refugees into reception societies, based on respect for the rule of law, the principles of integration, freedom and security, supporting the fight against trafficking in human beings, discrimination, xenophobia, hate speech, violence against women and children. Member States should apply the principles of integrating these groups and ensure that the rights of minorities of all kinds, persons with disabilities, including Roma and sexual minorities are protected by close cooperation between national, local authorities, schools, NGOs and refugee communities. This document condemns discrimination against sexual minorities in some Member States and recommends adopting appropriate measures to protect them. I support the adoption of this report, which emerge the principles of decency and equality between our citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Human dignity is the inviolable foundation of all fundamental rights and should not be the subject of any use. It must be respected and protected in all EU initiatives. The citizens of the Union must be made aware of the inherent dignity of all human beings in order to achieve a more humane and just society. We condemn all forms of discrimination and violence committed within the Union against any human being, as they constitute a direct violation of human dignity.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The annual report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2015 outlines the issues and progress made in the enforcement of fundamental rights within the EU for 2015. The report covers a wide range of rights-related topics, such as, inter alia, the protection of fundamental rights and dignity, rule of law, women’s rights and violence against women, and LGBT rights. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is a crucial EU priority and necessity to follow up on the state of play of fundamental rights in the EU, and this cannot be successfully achieved without an appropriate assessment of such initiatives.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: In writing. ‒ I would like to concentrate my speech on the human rights situation of the Sahrawi people. As a European Union we must demand that the fundamental rights of the people of Western Sahara, including freedom of association, freedom of expression and the right of assembly be respected. We must also demand the release of all Sahrawi political prisoners and require access to the territories of Western Sahara for members of our Parliament, for independent observers, NGO and the press. The UN Minurso mission must be fully re-established in accordance with relevant UN resolutions.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. — Jozsef Nagy, A8-0345⁄2016 I support the Motion for a Resolution on the State of Fundamental Rights in the European Union in 2015. I agree with the majority of the proposed content of the proposal for a resolution and welcome the detailed analysis of fundamental rights in the European Union. In particular, I consider it necessary to strengthen security cooperation between Member States and provide an effective EU response to terrorism and security threats in the European Union. I also consider the correct efforts highlighted in the recently adopted European Border and Coast Guard Regulation for the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, which provides for a mandate to support search and rescue operations while guaranteeing fundamental rights. I also call on law enforcement authorities in the European Union to increase their efforts to combat criminal trafficking networks and their assistants, and to cooperate more intensively with each other, with a particular focus on crimes against children. The highlighting of these topics in the context of the State of Fundamental Rights in the European Union demonstrates the existence of institutional awareness of events that have negative implications for the lives of citizens of the European Union and underlines the willingness of the European Parliament to find a single solution for them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - The European Parliament issues a report on human rights in the European Union every year. This 2015 features a wide range of topics such as migration, general human rights, sexual health, people smuggling, equality, ageing population, violence against women, LGBT rights, etc. The report adopted by the LIBE committee this year is significantly less controversial than last year and contains numerous positive calls for human rights protection such as the call for action by the Union in cases of human trafficking and, in this regard, providing protection to victims, a call for protection of rights minority, people with disabilities, call for protection of women's rights in terms of strict conviction of rape and female genital mutilation and protection of the elderly population from poverty. But I can by no means agree with parts of the report calling for the protection of the rights of the LGBT population through legal institutions in a way that they are granted the right to marry because I hold firmly that marriage is solely a union of a woman and a man. So I voted abstentions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Because it is essential to protect all fundamental rights because the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union is fully incorporated in the Treaty and because there are violations of fundamental rights in the EU and Member States. The rule of law is the cornerstone of Europe's liberal democracy and one of the fundamental principles of the European Union. Migration is part of the EU's present and future and one of the biggest challenges of our time, demanding that the EU and member states take international humanitarian responsibility (according to statistics, at least 3771 migrants died in 2015 alone). Terrorism has also become part of the everyday life and is one of the worst violations of fundamental rights and freedoms, so Europe must have the right tools to protect citizens (attack on Charlie Hebdo, attempt to attack media freedom). Trafficking in human beings is also rising, which is a serious crime committed in organised crime circles - an interference with human dignity. It is also necessary to condemn any kind of discrimination and violence. It is necessary to fight discrimination, xenophobia, hate crimes and hate speech, trafficking in human beings, terrorism, violence and advocating for freedom and equality.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the situation of fundamental rights is a good attempt to describe the current situation in the European Union. Many of the important issues have been addressed which require immediate attention: for instance, the issues which national minorities are facing in the European Union, such as discrimination and obstacles to the enforcement of their rights. Unfortunately, problems related to stateless persons in the EU have not been included in the main text and I see this as a big mistake. While many of the issues mentioned in the report do apply to this group, it would have been a stronger statement to mention stateless persons explicitly and their lack of rights when it comes to European and local elections.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: in writing. - The 2015 Nagy report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union addresses a wide range of issues. Among them we find positive approaches, such as the fight against female genital mutilation or human smuggling. Unfortunately, on a number of issues, the report goes far beyond what should be classified as fundamental rights. Examples include the call for intercultural curricula in schools, the call for the introduction of the ideology of gender mainstreaming in “all policy areas” and the fight against “institutionalised racism” in school education. The Nagy report refuses any analysis of cultural and religious backgrounds in many human rights violations and assigns responsibility to men alone or to the institutionalized racism of society. Because of these blatant shortcomings, I rejected the report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. — I spoke in the sitting to denounce the contents of this report. First, a series of paragraphs call on Member States to better welcome migrants with, for example, a call “to allocate adequate resources to the creation of safe and legal routes of entry”. Secondly, I am concerned that this report contains references to the growing presence of hate speech on the Internet. Certainly they exist, but the opacity of the text and the debates leads me to think that the purpose of the text is above all to limit freedom of expression, so as to prevent political criticism from polluting the Brussels microcosm of our elites. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. — The annual report has a number of generalizations, which should be eliminated at this stage. The report is too broad, it talks about too many issues mixing things important with irrelevant. There is a serious risk of misinterpretations of it and that is why I voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. — Among other things, the report calls on Member States to 'refrain from arousing fear and hatred among their citizens against migrants and asylum seekers in order to gain political advantage. ' As a dedicated opposition to the Orbans regime, in addition to other important findings in the report, I supported the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which is carried out annually, aims to present the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and propose recommendations. In its visit to the Civil Liberties Committee, important changes have been made, such as removing the most problematic aspects and including many of our group's amendments, such as those relating to migration and asylum, the protection of whistleblowers, the assessment of counter-terrorism measures, condemning mass surveillance indiscriminate, etc. It is important to note that the report mentions aspects of corruption, racism and xenophobia, gender equality and violence against women, the rights of the Roma community, LGBT rights, as well as rights of children, other minorities, persons with disabilities, the elderly and digital rights . However, as a rapporteur for the EPP, we have not succeeded in making reference to how economic policy, especially austerity measures, have affected the fundamental rights of European citizenship. That is why a new attempt was made by tabling amendments at this plenary meeting. Since the majority were rejected, I voted abstention.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 because the report covers developments in the field of fundamental rights in the EU and Member States, suggesting improvements and recommendations. Many of our proposals were included, such as references on asylum and migration, economic and social rights, homeless people, non-discrimination, the fight against terrorism, the situation in prisons, Roma, LGTBI, stateless persons, etc.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing. - I call on the Member States to adopt strategies to ensure effective access to the labour market for people with disabilities; I regret that some EU funds for the integration of people with disabilities are still not fully used for this purpose; calls on the Commission to closely monitor the use of funds, and take action if necessary; I urge all Member States to carry out public education and awareness-raising campaigns that focus on children's rights to protection and promote positive, non-violent relations with children; strongly condemns the frequent harassment and rape in public places in the Union and believes that every woman and girl should feel safe and not be afraid of any form of sexual harassment in all public places.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. Petitions to Parliament serve as an important instrument for citizens to report alleged breaches of fundamental rights which they may have experienced in Member States where they reside. The report considers that citizens expect the Charter to ensure the protection of their fundamental rights by the institutions, bodies and agencies of the Union and by the Member States when they are implementing EU law. It equally underlines that a lack of protection and awareness of their rights under the Charter could aggravate citizens’ disenchantment with the European project. It urges the adoption of new legislation aimed at combating energy poverty and welcomes previous initiatives at any administrative level in the direction of guaranteeing universal access to energy. I voted in favour because I believe that a genuine reform of the European Citizens’ Initiative and the effective operation of this instrument could do much to improve the Union’s image.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. ‒ In this text, the European Chamber values the Council's work on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union in 2015. The document contains references to the protection of fundamental rights, ranging from recommendations under the rule of law to provisions on migration, integration and social inclusion; freedom and security; trafficking in persons; discrimination and xenophobia; hate crime and hate speech, violence against women, children's rights, disabled people, the elderly, minorities or rights in the digital environment. Particularly relevant is the need to promote the Charter and take action to raise awareness of it at the national level. This year, the text focuses on the analysis of hate crime, reiterating zero tolerance for the type of language that favours it and reiterating the need for national legislation to address this issue. To this end, it recommends that they be avoided, mainly on the Internet, as well as support at the community level its persecution and condemnation. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I think it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social (although the rapporteur tried to censor references to fundamental rights before voting in plenary). I think, however, that a good diagnosis is not enough: the Union must reverse its migration, economic and social policies if it is to curb this difficult situation.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which identifies key areas of concern in relation to the situation of fundamental rights. Against the backdrop of significant increases in hate crime, it is essential that efforts are made at EU, national and local level to counter extremism and promote respect for diversity. It is important that Member States work together and uphold solidarity by tackling areas of common interest to strengthen democracy and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the European Union is a community based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons who have become a minority belong.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This annual report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World (2015) and the EU's policy on this subject takes stock of the European Union's work in defending and promoting human rights by the European Union. The European Union has used human rights in particular this year, as in others, to justify external interference and interference in sovereign countries which then caused problems of respect and violation of human rights. Although it causes instability in the world, it does not proceed to its self-criticism. What moral does the European Union have when this report does not self-criticise human rights which are constantly violated within the borders of its Member States? It talks about the situation of refugees but says nothing about its causes and about the disastrous balance of European refugee policy. Of course, there are positive aspects in the report, for example the reference to the requirement for the closure of Guantanamo and some issues relating to the rights of women, people with disabilities, children and issues relating to the death penalty. However, this cannot in any way make us agree with the hypocrisy of the EU and the subjective and overriding way in which it looks at human rights.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: in writing. - I was unable to support the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015, as the migration and refugee crisis in particular is presented in a positive light and more rights are required for migrants and refugees. The rapporteur also calls for the creation of legal entry opportunities and greater tolerance in intercultural and interreligious terms. Other negative aspects of the report were, on the one hand, the call for the legitimate recognition of sex change at Union level and the prohibition of medical examinations of intersex children, and, on the other hand, that schools should pay particular attention to homophobia in sport and young LGBTI people.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — I am pleased with the adoption in 2015 of the EU's Second Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for 2015-2019, which comprehensively approaches the prevention and resolution of crises, and ensures more inclusion of human rights concerns to external aspects of EU policies. To this end, the plan enhances coherence between EU actions such as migration, trade, development cooperation or counter-terrorism. This step up by the Union is crucial at a point where public space for civil society is shrinking and we are dealing with more and more frequent attacks against human rights defenders and journalists in the world. In addition, the universality of democratic values is seriously challenged not only by authoritarian regimes, but also by terrorist groups, including such parapstate entities as, for example, the so-called Islamic State, which persecuted not only religious minorities but also many Muslims . However, this has implications later in the form of an increased wave of refugees to the EU, who hope to find their second, safer home with us. Consequently, with the essence of a comprehensive approach to promoting human rights compliance in the world, and being fully aware of the challenges facing the EU in this regard, I supported this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report, which identifies key areas of concern in relation to the situation of fundamental rights. Against a backdrop of significant increases in hate crime (particularly in the UK before, during and after the referendum) it is essential that efforts are made at EU, national and local level to counter extremism and promote respect for diversity. It is important that Member States work together and uphold solidarity by tackling areas of common interest to strengthen democracy and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that law enforcement agencies should increase efforts in combatting human trafficking. There have already been improvements but it is still being a major problem. Moreover, I am very concerned with the growing presence of hate speech and material on the internet, so I support the idea that Member States should put in place a simple procedure enabling members of the public to report the presence of hate content online. Thus, I also support the Commission’s announcement of the Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online. As a liberal, I believe in the importance of safeguarding sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the own-initiative report today, which takes account of the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. The report stresses that minorities that have lived in Europe for centuries, together with or alongside majority cultures, continue to face discrimination in the Union. The report considers that the solution to this problem lies in the need to establish minimum standards for the protection of the rights of minorities. Minority communities have specific needs and the full equality of these communities in all areas of economic, social, political and cultural life must be promoted. The report also encourages those Member States which have not yet done so to ratify without further delay the Framework Convention on the Protection of National Minorities and the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The rapporteur and my Slovak colleague József Nagy produced a very extensive report, which contains many good proposals. I am all the more sorry that the demand for so-called “safe artificial abortion” has come into it. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the observance of which should have been the subject of this annual report, does not know the right to abortion. Some time ago, the European Parliament passed a regulation that orders each cigarette box to be labelled with a risk warning. Abortion is certainly a greater intervention in the body of a woman than smoking a packet of cigarettes. Moreover, it poses a fatal threat to the emerging human life. The approved text, which refers to abortion as “safe,” so I consider it a manifestation of great hypocrisy, which I reject. I had to reject the report in principle.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — Fundamental rights are the building block of the European Union. Their active promotion is an essential element of us achieving freedom, security and democracy. Last year, from my point of view, has been quite successful in this area and we can see some concrete examples where the EU has tried to strengthen the fundamental rights of citizens. I mean, for example, new rules on procedural safeguards during criminal proceedings or the completion of data protection reform. It is essential that we continue to come up with new initiatives and work to ensure that every European citizen has equal access to their fundamental rights. However, I could not vote for this report because there are many points that go against my political beliefs. At the same time, I believe that the report goes beyond the competence of the EU.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I did not support the Annual Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The report has traditionally covered a broad set of topics, ranging from the rights of women, children, the elderly to the protection of fundamental rights in the light of technological, and especially digital progress. It contained many positive ideas, such as the fight against trafficking in human beings, the fight against violence against women, poverty, Roma inclusion, and the protection of the rights of people with disabilities. On the other hand, however, the report contained a number of topics that I could not support because they interfere with Member States' subsidiarity (e.g. family policy).

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Nagy report because I agree with the assessment of the situation of fundamental rights in the EU and because I share the proposals to improve their situation in the future. I stress that fundamental rights are universal, indivisible and always complementary, and a fair balance must be achieved between the rights of all in a different society. In this context, I would remind you that, in its relations with the rest of the world, the Union must contribute to the protection of fundamental rights. Finally, I would stress the condemnation of any kind of discrimination or violence on the grounds of gender, age, ethnic origin, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity or disability.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the annual report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015. The report refers to fundamental human rights and freedoms, taking into account the main aspects of today's social society: migration, integration and inclusion, security and counter-terrorism, human trafficking, hate crimes, violence against women, children, minorities, people with disabilities, the elderly persons, Roma rights and citizenship. Human dignity is inviolable and therefore it is necessary to respect and protect it. The report calls for raising awareness among EU citizens about the innate dignity of all persons in order to deliver a society with a greater level of sensitivity and inclusion. In addition to promoting tolerance, peace and security of European citizens, this report also protects those most vulnerable groups such as children, women, minorities, people with disabilities, the elderly and Roma. Hate speech is increasingly heard among political forces, and in large parts of the population there is a growing number of cases of xenophobia and other prejudices. This report will provide tools and mechanisms for reporting hate crimes which I believe is the basis for establishing a stable and democratic society of Europe.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the Fundamental Rights Situation in the European Union in 2015. At a time when there is a rise in Euroscepticism and the expression of extreme political beliefs, it is essential that the EU and Member States show even more understanding and efforts to ensure the fundamental rights of EU citizens, particularly vulnerable groups - children, women, the elderly, minorities.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate that there have been two committees, the Culture Committee and the Industry Committee on this report. This testifies, in my opinion, to a fair approach because the cultural and recreational industry is recognized the dual role of preserving cultural diversity and flying for development and, above all, occupation. We all remember the unhappy statement of a former minister, he was Italian yes, that with culture you do not eat. Today it is also Europe, if ever there was a need, that disproves that concept. Art and creativity are a source of wealth not only cultural, but also economic, deeply rooted in the territorial fabric in which they operate and from which the cultural and recreational industries draw inspiration , allowing traditions to be kept alive through innovation and creating profit. On all I mention the example of the fashion industry, where large industrial groups cooperate with small and medium-sized enterprises and crafts, which make their products valuable: a productive world that alone He certainly couldn't survive.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, in 2013 international trade in counterfeit and pirated products caused EUR 85 billion in damage in the European Union alone. Intellectual property rights have been put in place precisely to ensure that creative and inventive efforts are rewarded, respected and to encourage investment in new and efficient products. Let's not forget, creation is unique and copying it, repeating it in many other forms must be banned and must be punished. Creative and cultural industries create a bridge between art, culture, business and industry. European culture and art are based on 3 000 years of common cultural heritage. The cultural and creative industries promote cultural diversity and strengthen European identity. They also provide over 12 million jobs. The report promotes innovation, entrepreneurship in these cultural and creative sectors and improves access to finance and new creative models.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I would follow up on my colleague precisely by supporting copyright protection, which is contained in this report very consistently and in many paragraphs. For me, the protection of copyright is a fundamental policy of protecting intellectual property, because it brings investment, innovation to the field, means the development of jobs, employment is perfectly evident. I am very pleased that the 2014 directive has already brought a greater level of balanced concept of the relationship between author and user, that it has brought more transparency, but also competition between collective administrator. That's what I think is very important. We would still need cultural policy, support for cultural goods to be linked to cohesion policy. Unfortunately, this is not happening as a result of some imperfections in the general regulation. I think it is a great role for the next two and a half years to be able to change the setting of the current regulation for drawing aid in cohesion policy.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, the United Kingdom is a place where, thankfully, cultural and new technology businesses are able to thrive and grow. We see it all over the place, in Manchester, in London, and across our country. We have people at home with their own small businesses, and through that we have created jobs, we have created wealth, and we have created a spirit of business within those small businesses. But here in the European Union, for the past several years, we have seen new rules being created every day. And today, another report that either picks or chooses the winners that it wants to survive, or creates problems for those that are already in business. Many of those small businesses at home suffered the inequity of having to try and find ways of paying VAT in every country that we had. All I have said simply, time and time again to this place is: stop putting your hands into the problems of business; stay away. If you do, it will grow. Remove the regulations and allow small businesses to thrive in culture and in new technology.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I have always been a great admirer of all those who contribute to our creative and cultural treasury which we are so proud of in Europe. I was pleased to vote in favour of this comprehensive, articulate and forward—thinking report in the light of the rapporteur’s efforts to consolidate a long-term policy in this area. I have always advocated strongly for the creative potential of small and medium—sized enterprises, and, in reassessing the allocation of funds, for example, we may reinforce the potential which the cultural and creative industries host. Facilitating the interrelationship between SMEs and research, as well as the essential combination of creativity with entrepreneurialism, will prove truly fruitful in this domain. Measured investment and expertise in assessment will also provide the keystone for further innovation in this sphere. I think that Mr Ehler and Mr Morgano have done a very good job in this whole area and I thank them.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: in writing. — Today the European Parliament voted on a report on EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors. There is reason to have common rules on, for example, intellectual property law, which the report also underlined. At the same time, “uniform EU policy” must not mean rectified cultural policy. Issues of cultural policy are national competence and should not be decided at EU level. That is why in separate votes, I voted against, inter alia, EU joint cultural campaigns and an EU prize for the cultural sector, and I voted against the expansion of the EU's cultural policy budget. Overall, it is a report that addresses pressing issues, but there are also shortcomings and I therefore chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ The strong digitization that characterizes the present is increasing its range of involvement. Art and culture, in fact, are among the sectors that are most experiencing this aspect, with all the advantages and negative aspects that come with it. The aim of this report should, in fact, be to provide political indications for the development of European creative industries precisely in the light of the digitisation process. Personally I believe that the right way forward is to experiment with new innovative “business models”, not already existing, that focus more on the creators of the works, authors and performers and less about rights holders. That's why I decided to vote negatively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I was not able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains many positive points, it is a proposal that guarantees the participation of major economic actors. The development of cultural and creative industries depends on the fact that authors obtain fair remuneration for their work, but without this entailing any form of blocking the development of that industry and its services to the public. The report contains positive references to the inclusion of creators' rights, but it also guarantees the concentration of intellectual property rights through their financialization. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on a coherent EU policy for culture and creative industries. As Europe moves to the digital economy in the 21st century, traditional production processes are increasingly changing or displacing the cultural and creative sectors ('CCP'). The cultural and creative industry is based on cultural values, individual creativity and skills and has the potential to create prosperity and jobs on the basis of intellectual property value. Cultural and creative activities, among others, are based on the following sectors: architecture, archives and libraries, crafts, cultural heritage, design. Unlike other industries, the CCP has a dual value: it plays an essential role in preserving and supporting European cultural and linguistic diversity, strengthens the sense of European and regional identity, helps to transfer knowledge and values and preserves the tangible and intangible European heritage present and future generations. It is therefore strategically important to provide support for an innovative and research-oriented European CCP, as it can both preserve linguistic and cultural diversity, pluralism, and offer innovative and high-quality services, especially in the context of market fusion and globalisation. I voted in favour because I share the opinion of the rapporteurs that coordinated action at national, regional and local levels, as well as at EU level, is necessary to exploit the full potential of the sector.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors because I believe that measures must be taken to ensure that all parties involved are treated fairly in terms of pay.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: This report makes good observations but unfortunately seeks solutions at European level. Although it wants to put in place measures to preserve European know-how, the EU wants to use the development of these cultural and creative industries in favour of its “cultural diplomacy”, the digital single market. The report is also obsessed with the mobility of artists, a pretext for facilitated visa procedures for third countries and requires ever more funds, which makes no sense if the effectiveness of the programmes has not yet been demonstrated and the funds already available are not used wisely. Therefore, despite relevant findings on the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector, whether in terms of innovation, capacity for resilience or the protection of cultural heritage and European know-how, I regret the Europeist approaches developed there. That's why I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report tries to legislate on the culture and creative industries of every country within the EU with a ‘one-size-fits-all’ package. We have seen, time and time again, that this approach does not work. Member States are best placed to protect, preserve and promote their own culture; therefore, I voted against this resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text because I think it is more than necessary to look at the creative and cultural sectors. It is important to cultivate, support, promote and defend cultural content. This involves stimulating innovation in these sectors, increasing monitoring of them in order to provide them with appropriate solutions or improving access to finance. All of this will enable us to value 3,000 years of common cultural heritage that constitute the image of the European Union in the eyes of the world.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on a coherent EU policy for culture and creative industries. The cultural and creative industries (CCP) play a crucial role in Europe's reindustrialisation, stimulate growth and its strategic position can lead to the spread of innovation in other sectors such as tourism, retail and digital technology. I therefore agree that the EU can play a leading role in promoting a significant positive impact of creative sectors across Europe, as well as in supporting policies that promote its most unique assets, culture.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. — The aim of the report is to draw the legislators's attention to the fundamental difficulties and lack of resources in the cultural and creative sector and try to make proposals on this. The sector across Europe has a shortage of resources and a difficult rate of return, which in many cases discourages investors. The sector is seriously affected by the difficulties in enforcing patent and copyright due to the widespread use of digital platforms and Internet platforms. The report seeks to provide solutions to these problems, guarantee instruments and resources allocated under Horizon 2020. The rapporteur advocates not only the promotion of traditional handicraft professions, but also cultural activities related to fine arts and performers, primarily to folk art and thus to preserve culture. The rapporteur calls on the Commission and the Member States in a positive way to 'ensure the preservation of cultural heritage, cultural and linguistic diversity and traditional knowledge, as well as European and national, regional and local expertise. ' This means a new source and opportunity for Hungarian minorities beyond the borders, which obliges the Member States to help preserve cultural diversity by increasing the enforcement of rights related to minority language education and the use of minority languages.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — The report contains interesting, sometimes even very good points, particularly at the level of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector, but unfortunately it is tinged with Europeanism which would undermine the sovereignty of the Member States by wishing to implement an industrial policy at Union level and not of States. Just as the euro benefits only some countries and in fact suffer others, a European policy at the level of SMEs could serve some to favour others. I preferred to abstain on this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to develop a coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors. In particular, given the importance of the volume of employment represented by these sectors within the Union, framework conditions should be laid down to stimulate innovation and ensure the financing of different fields of activity. For example, the aim is to complete the establishment of a digital single market in order to fully benefit from what ICTs have to offer, but also to establish a system to promote R&D, European production of creative content and technological innovation in the media. This would facilitate the creation of competitive and creative services in the Union. In this regard, the report also encourages Member States to include these sectors in the Youth Employment Initiative in order to facilitate career development and training.
