Finally, it encourages the Commission to provide financial support for the achievement of these objectives through the various European programmes (such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus+ and Creative Europe) and the European Structural and Investment Funds set up for this purpose.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. ‒ In the 21st century the commitment to intelligent and sustainable growth cannot do without the valuable contribution that the cultural and creative industries can provide, for the realization of a more competitive and at the same time more inclusive economic system. The Ehler-Morgano report, which I supported in my vote, aims to set the way to permanently unlock the potential of the creative and cultural industries in Europe. The text identifies some measures to be taken, such as: collecting statistics and reliable data on the sector; fostering innovation and entrepreneurship by facilitating crossover; improving access to financing; supporting new commercial models and, above all, developing skills, such as commercial ones, which enable us to meet the changing needs of an environment increasingly affected by transition to the digital economy and from exceeding traditional value chains. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package, which deals with precarious contractual situations and ensures that fundamental social and working standards are met. Appropriate measures are needed to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, artists and rights holders receive fair compensation for their creations.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. ‒ This is a joint report by the ITRE and CULT committees on the challenges and possibilities facing creative and cultural industries in the Union. Among other issues, it highlights the need for active advocacy policies, access to finance, counter-piracy, better participation of perpetrators and creators in benefit-sharing, promoting cross-sectoral cooperation and mobility, improving the working conditions of workers in the sector and the gender, etc. I voted in favour of the report, because I believe that these aspects are necessary in order to lay the foundations for a specific policy that will enable the sector to be valued and sustainable growth in the Member States as a whole.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I supported this report on a coherent Union policy for the cultural and creative sectors. It is essential to call on the Commission to propose effective measures to combat online piracy, in particular to ensure that online services hosting content apply effective means to remove unlicensed content from their services and, once deleted, act to prevent such content from re-appearing. In addition, it calls for the promotion of “protocols on intellectual property assets” to facilitate the valuation of intellectual property rights, and invite the Commission and Member States to adopt the necessary mechanisms to increase the financial attractiveness of intellectual property rights and the recognition of their full value as assets.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I preferred to abstain from this report on the cultural and creative industries, on which I was shadow rapporteur for my group. I believe that the findings on the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector are right: whether in terms of innovation, capacity for resilience or the protection of European cultural heritage and know-how, cultural and creative industries must be properly supported. The whole text could be retained if it were to address the industrial policies of the Member States and not a Union-wide industrial policy. Unfortunately, as usual, the Union tends to want to grab the capacities of the Member States. This is also the case in the field of copyright, which is the basis of income of the creative and cultural industries and which the Commission seeks to regulate through a reform of the current directive, which is also likely to allow exceptions to copyright excessively. Other points are also questionable, such as this European-based obsession with mobility, or the desire to increase the European funds of the programmes concerned without even ensuring that they are properly managed.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: In writing. — Despite some appreciable passage, I do not agree with the proposal to focus decision-making on cultural issues in the hands of the Commission, because it would mean not respecting the cultural diversity of the various Member States, instead imposing a model dropped from above. For this reason I preferred to express myself with an abstention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries are not just one more industries. Of course, they are of crucial economic importance, generating more than 12 million jobs and more than 5% of the Union's GDP. But their value transcends mere figures: not only does our cultural legacy depend on them, but they constitute our cover letter to the world. Given the paradigm shift that digitalisation brings with it, it is necessary to equip them with the necessary tools for their development. As we called for in the report, for which I have been a socialist rapporteur in the ITRE Commission, there is an urgent need to strengthen its financial capacity, improving its perceptions as an attractive sector for investment, but also by enabling public funds, which have been severely diminished in these years of crisis. Combating counterfeiting and piracy and ensuring fair remuneration is urgently needed by tackling the transfer of value between creators and other actors in the value chain. And, of course, it is urgent to ensure the highest social and labor standards of its workers. Digitization cannot become synonymous with precariousness, but with development, opportunities and inclusion.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on a coherent policy in the EU's cultural and creative sectors. Culture, art and creativity are the real image of Europe and its wealth in the world. As Europe moves to the digital economy in the 21st century, cultural and creative industries are increasingly changing traditional production processes and traditional value chains. Today, the creation of quality content, the ability to innovate, tell, imagine, awaken emotions, has become our most precious material prima. It is necessary to develop, support, nurture and defend. Cultural and creative industries are an industry based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent, with the potential to create prosperity and jobs on the basis of intellectual property value. Cultural and creative activities are based on the following sectors: architecture, archives and libraries, handicrafts, audiovisual works (including films, television, video games and multimedia), cultural heritage, design, creativity-based luxury industry and fashion, festivals, music, performing arts, books and publishing, radio and fine arts. The roots and vitality of the European cultural and creative industries are the uniqueness of European culture and art, reflected in the common cultural heritage of 3 000 years ago.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values while at the same time contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is of particular importance. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: In writing. ‒ European culture and art represent 3 000 years of common cultural heritage. At a time of timid economic recovery, the cultural and creative industries are a potential “to unlock,” enhancing their significant impact in terms of sustainable growth and jobs. It is a dense network of SMEs and innovative start-ups directly linked to art, culture and creativity, which promote not only the preservation of our cultural heritage, but also generate value from intellectual property. I support this report, which underlines how concerted action at Community level is needed to achieve the full potential of the sector. Facilitating access to the market and European funds available to the cultural industry means supporting a sector providing jobs for more than 7% of the working population of the European Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. - I support this Report that recognises the cultural and creative industries (CCIs) traditionally based on cultural values and creativity as a strategic sector for job creation and sustainable development. The report supports cultural heritage and innovation and focused on several measures to achieve the sector's full potential, while highlighting the importance of education, skills and training.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — The findings on the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector are good, whether in terms of innovation, resilience capacity or the protection of European cultural heritage and know-how. The whole text could be retained if it were to address the industrial policies of the Member States, not an EU-wide industrial policy. So I abstained.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The report calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the creative and cultural sector (cultural and creative industries – CCI), and to provide funding for CCIs, in order to boost their competitiveness and to enable them to fulfil their potential in terms of creating quality jobs and growth. To achieve this goal, the report – while recognising the diverse nature of CCIs and, accordingly, of their specific funding and innovation needs – proposes a harmonised definition of CCIs on which statistical data should be based.  The report proposes the creation of a single EU-wide definition and statistics for the CCI. It seems contradictory because on the one hand the report admits European cultural richness and diversity, but on the other hand it proposes the creation of a definition that is necessarily reductive and debatable. The report also calls for the strengthening and completion of the European Digital Single Market which has many negative aspects. Despite the positive elements, this report overall seeks to reduce cultural diversity and treat the cultural sector as a commodity.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. ‒ In 21st century Europe, with the transition to the digital economy, ICCs (Cultural and Creative Industries) are progressively supplanting traditional production processes and chains of Traditional value. Today the production of quality content and the ability to innovate, to narrate, to imagine, to evoke emotions have become our most precious raw material: a material to be cultivated, supported, promote and defend. They preserve and promote European cultural and linguistic diversity, contribute to transmitting knowledge and values and safeguarding material and intangible heritage for the generations present and future and, at the same time, as the data clearly show, are an instrument of social cohesion, employment and growth. An organic approach to ICCs is key to supporting the revival of so many European companies, in Italy, Spain, Greece, France and other countries that have suffered the crisis.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: The purpose of this report is to recognize the role and potential of cultural and creative industries and to promote their development and outreach. These industries, which are difficult to relocate, provide jobs and contribute to the emergence of many innovations. That is why it is essential to put in place mechanisms to preserve European know-how while combating piracy and counterfeiting. The report also calls for the exclusion of the cultural and audiovisual services sectors from any agreement between the European Union and third countries. It is particularly regrettable that these protections do not benefit other strategic sectors such as agriculture, steel and automotive industries. However, we are opposed to the creation of a common industrial policy in this sector of activity. As usual, the European Union gives itself new prerogatives to the detriment of our national sovereignty. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - Cultural and creative industries are an important European Union sector based on a range of values such as creativity, artistic and cultural competences. Cultural industries generate jobs, having a positive impact on the economy, as well as added value for European cultural heritage. This segment includes cultural and creative contributions such as performing art, cultural heritage, artistic crafts, libraries and, last but not least, audiovisual. Given the importance of cultural and creative industries, a number of measures and efforts are needed to strengthen and support this area. This report proposes seven key policy areas, including: monitoring the development of the sector with a view to creating solutions tailored to the purpose of the ICC, addressing the evolution of skills needs and overcoming the skills deficit, collecting reliable statistics and data based on a comprehensive definition, with a view to raising awareness of the characteristics and needs of the sector. Cultural and creative industries play a key role in preserving cultural diversity, European heritage, pluralism, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report and trust that, through this instrument, the cultural and creative industries will enjoy of greater support.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. - The cultural and creative sectors in Europe represent a very significant potential in terms of innovation, growth and job creation. They provide more than 12 million jobs, or 7.5% of the Union's workforce. The cultural and creative sectors are very important in that they preserve European cultural and linguistic diversity but also because they contribute to Europe's competitiveness in the world. For this reason, the Union must have a long-term political, strategic and legal framework for these sectors. This strategy should both create incentives for innovation but must also protect them. Europe must become the world's leading power in terms of innovation and knowledge. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, which offers strong suggestions to the Commission for building a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries (ICC). As I have been able to express myself on this issue several times, the European Union needs to change direction, putting culture at the heart of its foreign policy. Ficting on cultural collaboration with its internal and external partners helps to revive the image of the Union and promote a world order based on peace, respect for human rights and understanding mutual. In this context, the ICCs represent a useful link element in the strategy for international cultural relations, between the constantly evolving ICT environment and the enhancement of a stronger European consciousness, creating a sense of belonging and mutual understanding between the citizens of the various member countries. To this end, the regulatory framework of copyright and intellectual property must be made consistent and harmonised, with ways capable of stimulating the use of new technologies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the proposed harmonisation of policies related to cultural and creative industries (CCIs). The report proposes the creation of a single EU-wide definition and statistics for CCIs. This is completely contradictory, since on the one hand the report admits European cultural richness and diversity, but on the other proposes the creation of a definition that is necessarily reductive and debatable.  The report as a whole views the cultural sector as a commodity rather than accepting its true value. For these reasons I voted against.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. We do not think that cultures in Europe would benefit from new EU measures and policies in this field. We believe that each Member State should have the right to decide independently on how to preserve and promote its culture.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that the Commission should develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the creative and cultural sector, and to provide adequate funding for cultural and creative industries (CCIs), in order to boost their competitiveness and to enable them to fulfil their potential in terms of creating quality jobs and growth. To achieve this ambitious goal, the report proposes a harmonised definition of CCIs on which statistical data should be based. The report also calls on the Commission to establish a balanced legal framework, including in the field of copyright, based on the specificities of the sector. It further recommends cross-sectorial cooperation to foster interaction between SMEs and research centres and universities, in order to better integrate creative with entrepreneurial education and to strengthen the business skills of creative entrepreneurs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to provide political indications for the development of the European cultural and creative industries, particularly in the light of the trend of strong digitisation, of initiatives to it is linked (e.g. content portability) and with a view to the announced modernisation of the legal framework for intellectual property rights (copyright). The approach is rather conventional, focusing on preserving existing business models, strongly oriented to the protection of rights holders, when necessary through measures above all restrictive and sanctioning; it focuses on a model of mass culture, essentially consumerist, where the treatment of the cultural product requires its commodification. Together with the M5S Europe delegation, I voted against it.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because, while the digital transition is indispensable today, it cannot go against the tide of the sustainability of a living culture that carries significant growth. In this sense, fair conditions must continue to be put in place to protect creators from the digital giants that constitute a monopoly. Indeed, while creative content is now increasingly accessible, creators' incomes have fallen considerably. In keeping with intellectual property and defending creators, it is unacceptable that platforms continue to capture much of the added value created by creative content.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Precarious working conditions and insecure forms of income are common practice in the creative industry sector, and that is why our House calls on the Commission to draw up an ambitious legislative package for artists and creative workers.  Sadly, women face the same barriers in these industries as in most others, which means a huge gender pay gap and an even bigger pension gap exist. Furthermore, there is a very high proportion of women who work in these industries, and more often than not they are declared as self-employed, facing serious challenges as mothers and working women.  Cultural and creative work requires the same commitment to fundamental social and labour standards on the part of the Commission and the Member States as in any other sectors, and this must also apply to negotiating mandates for trade agreements.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: In writing. ‒ The cultural and creative industries (ICC) bill EUR 547 billion in the European Union each year, which is approximately 4% of nominal GDP of the Union as a whole. I believe that the legal framework governing copyright and intellectual property should be revised and adapted to the challenges of the digital age. In particular, the report, for which I voted in favour, stresses that the European institutions should lay down rules recognising fair pay and adequate legal protection to all those involved in the creative process. This reform seems to me to be particularly urgent in certain areas, such as high fashion because counterfeits cause significant reductions in revenue to companies, resulting in job losses of work, in addition to the risks associated with protecting consumer health. I also believe that the Commission should develop funding and funds tailored to the cultural and creative industries in order to stimulate development and innovation in these areas. Finally, I am convinced that the European Union should increase the protection applicable to workers in the cultural and creative industries in the field of contracts, instruments of collective representation, social security social, health insurance and taxation in order to combat existing forms of precarious and facilitate the mobility of artists throughout the Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the report and underline that in the 21st century Europe, with the transition to the digital economy, the CCIs are increasingly replacing traditional manufacturing processes and traditional value chains. Today, the production of quality content, the ability to innovate, narrative, imagination, challenge emotions, have become our most valuable prima materia. We must therefore cultivate it, support it, promote it and defend it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - The report on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors is a positive attempt to adopt a common stance of the EU Member States on cultural issues, aimed at protecting and promoting European creative powers. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to outline an industrial policy for the cultural and creative industries, but the decision-making powers of the cultural sector to the European Commission. The report also contains shareable passages which are nevertheless clouded by decision-making centralisation that is not respectful of cultural diversity. Abstention vote.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: In writing. ‒ Our civilization has made a contribution not indifferent to the world's cultural heritage and so that we continue on the journey taken thousands of years ago, I am convinced in favour of report. Together with the indisputable cultural value, the strong footprint of inclusion and social cohesion should be added, and these essential elements lead to eminent consideration of industries cultural and creative by virtue of stimuli induced on innovation in other areas. Promoting creativity, to date, therefore implies a general increase in the psychic, social and economic well-being of the human being and therefore the establishment of a policy framework is made a priority Global, consistent and long-term industrial for ICCs in order to collect data, increase competitiveness and ability to deliver new quality jobs. Realizing what has been exposed so far will be possible through cross-sectoral cooperation to integrate creativity with effective entrepreneurial education. In addition, new forms of funding should be introduced for ICCs, which are predominantly SMEs, through public-private partnerships. I place extreme confidence in the role and activity carried out by the ICCs and I am very much awaiting the adoption of the policies promoted to promote their development since they are without positive effects in areas priorities to get out of the crisis gripping the EU.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: The cultural and creative industries (CCI) are characterised by their dual intrinsic value: they play a fundamental role in preserving and promoting Europe's cultural and linguistic diversity, reinforcing the sense of belonging to the European and regional identity, contribute to the transmission of knowledge and values and preserve Europe's cultural and intangible heritage for current and future generations. It is therefore strategically important to support innovative and research-oriented CCIs. In order to realise the full potential of the sector, concerted action is needed at national, regional and local level, but also at EU level, with the need: gathering reliable statistics and data on the sector; stimulating innovation and entrepreneurship in the cultural and creative sector; improving access to funding and develop skills, including business qualifications. CCIs play a key role in Europe's re-industrialisation, are a driver of growth and occupy a strategic position to unleash positive effects on innovation in other sectors such as tourism, retail trade and digital technologies. The EU must take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact of creative sectors across Europe by promoting their culture. I therefore support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because we need to create a legal framework that promotes and protects the innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries. The economic potential of this industry is enormous and it plays a crucial role in the reindustrialisation of the EU. The design of this regulatory framework should result in a fair and effective market that takes into account the interests of artists, creators and designers in the cultural and creative sectors, as well as platform operators and users.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. We do not think that cultures in Europe would benefit from new EU measures and policies in this field. We believe that each Member State should have the right to decide independently on how to preserve and promote its culture.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the text because the creative and cultural industries play a fundamental role in the re-industrialisation of Europe and are a driving factor in the development of Europe growth is strategically positioned to stimulate innovative fallout in other industrial sectors, such as tourism, retail and digital technologies. On these issues, the EU could take a leading role in promoting more the important positive effects that creative sectors have across Europe, including in order to encourage more and more policies in support of European culture.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains many positive points, it is a proposal that guarantees the participation of major economic actors. The development of cultural and creative industries depends on the fact that authors obtain fair remuneration for their work, but without this entailing any form of blocking the development of that industry and its services to the public. The report contains positive references to the inclusion of creators' rights, but it also guarantees the concentration of intellectual property rights through their financialization. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: In writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries are the sectors that rest on cultural values, creativity, individual skills and talent, which have the potential to create wealth and employment, generating value from intellectual property. Therefore it becomes strategically important to support innovative and research-oriented European ICCs, as they are able to preserve cultural and linguistic diversity, pluralism and the offer of innovative and high-quality services, especially in the context of the converged and globalized market. Although creative content consumption has never been higher, today the value gap at the expense of creators, has created an inefficient and unfair market and poses a health threat to long term of the creative and cultural sectors of the EU and for the success of the digital single market. I therefore welcomed this resolution, which calls on the Commission to identify legal solutions applicable to online services to overcome market distortion.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. - The strengths that define Europe in the world are: culture, art and creativity. In the 3000 years of cultural heritage, cultural and creative industries have marked the evolution of European civilizations. Supporting them, especially in a context of the transition to the digital economy, is becoming a strategic need, as they are aimed at preserving linguistic and cultural diversity, as well as ethnic pluralism. In addition to the economic impact generated by these industries, they are also a solid pillar in strengthening international partnerships. I voted in favour of these industries that play a key role in the reindustrialisation of Europe and which are a driver for economic growth. I believe that the European Union must take the leading role in promoting policies that support culture.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative industries (IFs) are industries based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent, and are able to create wealth and jobs through the creation of value based on intellectual property. They connect art, culture, business, technology. Further development of IFIs requires a comprehensive industrial strategy at European level. The European Parliament report calls on the Commission to establish a comprehensive and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sector and to include the development, promotion and financing of IFIs among its strategic objectives. There's a lot of potential in the sphere industries. It is also an important sector for the creation of jobs, which is why the creation of a legal framework that takes account of the specificities of the sector and provides room for further innovation.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report, which calls on the Commission to develop a coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the culture and creative industries and which calls on the EU to integrate the development, promotion and protection of the cultural and creative industries into its strategic objectives and general policy priorities. I believe that the cultural sector and the creative sector are industries based on the cultural values and creativity of the individual and the skills and talents that can generate income and create jobs. The protection of traditional manufacturing processes and traditional value chains during a time of progressive development in the digital economy sector is of particular importance. It should be noted that the Commission should pay particular attention to issues concerning the responsibility of online platforms, labour market conditions and attempts to increase the budget of the Creative Europe programme.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries have the potential to help to alleviate the current economic and employment difficulties in the European Union and promote inclusive and sustainable growth as well as innovation. I am in favour of this report, which deals with the precarious contractual situation in the cultural and creative industries and ensures respect for fundamental social and labour standards. We need to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and right holders receive fair remuneration for their works.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of this report which represents a supportive policy framework that can help cultural and creative industries deliver jobs and growth. I believe an EU policy framework for the cultural and creative industries must support, not burden, small business.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries are an important part of Europe's society and economy. The initiative opinion in several places highlights good initiatives and needs from which the industry would be deserved. However, we see it as problematic that tougher copyright law is seen as one of the most important tools for securing the future of the industry. For these reasons, the Swedish Green Delegation has chosen to abstain on the report on a uniform EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - It is common ground that women also face the same barriers in the cultural and creative industries as in other economic sectors, in particular as regards the gender pay and pension gap, access to finance, stereotypes, training and learning on throughout life. I believe that the huge potential of innovative and entrepreneurial women and the important role they play in the cultural and creative industries must be stimulated, and I therefore believe that all Member States must be encouraged to ensure adequate financial support and training, through promoting the exchange of best practices within the cultural and creative industries.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: This own-initiative report recommends to the European Commission the development of a comprehensive and coherent long-term strategic industrial framework for the cultural and creative sectors, and the provision of adequate funding to the cultural and creative industries (CCI). MEPs want to boost the competitiveness of these sectors so that they can express their potential for creating quality jobs and growth. To this end, the report proposes, inter alia, a harmonized definition of CCI on which statistical data should be based. It also calls for greater cooperation between SMEs and research centres and universities to promote the integration of innovations into the economy. Finally, the report proposes to diversify the tools and funds available to companies to encourage investment. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. We do not think that cultures in Europe would benefit from new EU measures and policies in this field. We believe that each Member State should have the right to decide independently on how to preserve and promote its culture.

name: Rachida DATI
text: I voted in favour of this report on a coherent European Union policy for the creative sector. With more than 12 million full-time jobs, the creative sector is undeniably an important part of the European economy. In order to further develop this sector, the Union and its Member States must ensure coherence in their support policies. This must be reflected in the adoption of a harmonized definition of the sector, as well as the development of a legislative framework addressing its most problematic challenges, for example, digitization and copyright issues.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values, while also contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I believe that Europe's cultural and creative industries (ICCs) are innovative and research-oriented. In the globalized market, ICCs have the potential to preserve cultural and linguistic diversity thereby safeguarding cultural heritage for future generations. In addition, ICCAs are promoters of economic growth and employment with 3 million companies and 12 million employees in the EU.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: One of the strengths of the European economy is its ability to create and innovate. The cultural and creative industries sector contributes 39% of the Union's GDP. It employs more people than the automotive industry and is highly competitive internationally. In order for the sector to continue to develop, it is essential that it receive adequate political and financial support. However, compared to other European industries, it has relatively few financial support instruments at its disposal. In order to remedy this imbalance, two guidelines need to be advocated. On the one hand, the establishment of a real industrial policy framework allowing for long-term support for culture. On the other hand, national policies that work in support of this European framework. Our legislation must also provide answers to the issues raised by the digital revolution. For example, copyright must be modernized to protect creators and empower hosts and intermediaries, thereby enabling everyone to enjoy the cultural offer in a fair and sustainable way. Finally, we should recall that preserving the vitality of European culture is essential to the intellectual dynamism of our societies and contributes to the definition of our identity.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. This report highlights some interesting elements about these industries, in particular that they are difficult to relocate and can play a driving role in reindustrialisation and in the revival of employment through training in manufacturing trades; that they are representative of European know-how abroad, especially since they are generally excluded from any agreement with third States. We also endorse the analysis of SMEs in the cultural sector. Nevertheless, we are not in favour of ever greater control of the Commission in this sector of activity, particularly in relation to the regulation of copyright. Moreover, the emphasis on the single market and the mobility of artists seems to pave the way for visa facilities for third-country nationals.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. Cultural and creative industries need support for their development and prosperity. The policies that the European Union is pursuing in this respect must be consistent, and this is why the initiative for such a report has been fully supported by me. I am also pleased with the final result achieved after some compromises and on the part of my political group. That is why I supported this report. Cultural and creative industries are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talents that have the potential to generate wealth and jobs by creating intellectual property value. Statistics show that 7.5% of the EU workforce is provided by those industries that have proven their growth in recent years. The report analyses the impact and potential of cultural and creative industries and calls for them to be included in the strategic objectives of the European Union as well as the common political priorities.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries are an important part of Europe's society and economy. The initiative opinion in several places highlights good initiatives and needs from which the industry would be deserving. However, we see it as problematic that tougher copyright law is seen as one of the most important tools for securing the future of the industry. For these reasons, the Swedish Green Delegation has chosen to abstain on the report on a uniform EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The fact is that the cultural institution has created jobs, leading to the creation of new business models aimed at digitizing cultural heritage, completing the digital single market, modernising educational processes, as well as fostering strong strategic links between cultural policy and common and productive resources. We must therefore cultivate, support, promote, defend culture, art and creativity.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the vote on this report as it did not address intellectual property rights effectively. The creative industries in Wales are an important sector for both culture and the economy and I do not feel this own-initiative report does enough to protect their interests.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative enterprises need a clear political framework to guide their development in the great digitisation process we are experiencing. The report in question was meant to give momentum to new business models and new models of culture and innovation, protecting the creators of the works, authors and performers and less to rights holders. In contrast, the conventional approach of preserving existing business models, strongly oriented to the protection of rights holders, and mass-culture models, consumerist and commodities , goes in the completely opposite direction. I voted negatively.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Cultural and creative industries are industries that are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent with the potential to generate wealth and employment through the creation of value from intellectual property. Therefore, in order to realise the full potential of the sector, concerted action is needed at national, regional and local level, but also at EU level. Gather reliable statistics and data on the basis of a comprehensive definition in order to raise awareness of the characteristics and needs of the sector, monitor developments in the sector in order to create purpose-suited CCI solutions, stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in the cultural and creative sector, facilitating cooperation with other sectors and policies (crossings), and improving access to finance, supporting new business models, are some of the recommended measures with which I agree.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The essence of this report is based on concepts that we do not endorse. There are aspects which do not give us disagreement, although they should be relativized in the general context of the report. The report proposes a definition of the Cultural and Creative Industries (ICC) according to which these “are based on cultural, creative, individual values, skills and talent, capable of creating wealth and employment through the valorisation of intellectual property. Architecture, archives and libraries, crafts, audiovisual (including cinema, television, video games and multimedia), cultural heritage, design, luxury industries oriented to creativity and fashion industry, festivals, music, performing arts, books and publishing, radio and visual arts'. Fundamentally, all areas of cultural activity that have been subject to commodification, and areas of commodity production to which we now intend to assign a “cultural” status. It is enough to look at our country and imagine the consequences that would have, in an already so degraded cultural framework, the classification of heritage, archives and libraries, of the arts in general in the universe of cultural industries, alongside fashion, jewellery, festivals and video games, competing with them in the “creation of wealth and employment through the valorization of intellectual property”. It would be a question of a commercialising concept of culture which is, in itself, reason to reject this report.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it examines the definition, potential and social and economic value of the cultural and creative industries. In particular, I agree with the Commission's request to develop a coherent industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sector, including the development and protection of ICCAs in strategic and priority objectives of the European Union.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - Coherent cultural and creative industries policy represents a strategic step towards creating new jobs, sustainable growth and promoting innovation and cultural heritage. Legislation in this area focuses on measures that will lead to the realisation of the full potential of the sector through clear and precise definitions. Member States should develop or introduce a legal and institutional framework for creative artistic activities in the case of contracts, social security, health insurance, direct and indirect taxation and compliance with European standards. The European Commission must respond to reducing the difference in value and will have to ensure that authors and creators and rightholders receive adequate compensation for their works.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain from the report because the issue of decision-making of cultural issues at the Commission cannot cooperate with respect for the cultural diversity of industries.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - Branches of culture and creativity are those sectors that are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent, having the potential to create wealth and jobs through the production of value from intellectual property. It is a fact that the cultural institution has created jobs, leading to the creation of new business models aimed at digitizing cultural heritage, completing the digital single market, modernising educational processes, as well as fostering strong strategic links between cultural policy and common and productive resources. We must therefore cultivate, support, promote, defend culture, art and creativity. I am therefore voting in favour of the report and the proposals of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on Culture and Education for a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with the precarious contractual situation in the cultural and creative industry and will ensure the respect for fundamental social and labour standards.  S&D had three main goals to insert in the report in order to have a coherent report: to complete the funding aspect of the cultural and creative industries; to strengthen the protection of authors and creators; and to introduce the social and labour dimension. All three goals were enhanced and included to the report by committee vote. The Commission is called to take the appropriate measures to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and right holders receive fair remuneration for their works.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. — The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services, and therefore as a member of the FIDESZE EPP delegation I voted in favour of the initiative.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ The European cultural and creative industry is a very important sector that provides more than 12 million full-time jobs EU-wide and creates approximately EUR 509 billion in value for the EU GDP. I support the report in calling on the Commission to develop and propose a comprehensive and coherent policy framework for the sector, to foster innovation and enable sufficient funding. An important part of this should be to increase the market access for SMEs and start-up businesses and to foster interaction between different market actors. The Commission should create a legal copyright framework that works for SMEs, creators, and right holders as piracy and counterfeiting is a serious concern for the innovation sector. The European cultural and creative industry has great potential in combating youth unemployment and promoting reindustrialisation and the Commission and Member States should include the CCIs in the EU Youth Employment Initiative and provide ways to facilitate entrepreneurship and training in this sector. To this end, the completion of the Digital Single Market should be a priority in order to fully seize the potential for growth and new jobs in this sector.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: In writing. ‒ I congratulate Mr Morgano, who has translated, in his work on the own-initiative report “A coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries”, the objectives and lines the S&D Group on the protection and development of one of the most strategic sectors for the growth, employment capacity and digital innovation of European companies. With our vote, today, we intend to support our commitment to safeguard and promote the development of cultural and creative industries, by betting on the enormous wealth of Europe's cultural heritage, on the extraordinary resources that small and medium-sized enterprises represent, and on the greater clarity and fairness that the social framework of workers in the sector has already demanded for some time.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EP resolution on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries (ICC) because I believe that businesses in this sector are a resource European and can promote growth and jobs in the EU and therefore can contribute decisively to the social and economic development of the EU and the Member States. Europe must be able to take full advantage of the new sources of intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth inherent in the cultural and creative industry. Investing in them could at one time enable the exploitation of their potential — still largely unexplored — and have a formidable impact in terms of growth creation and jobs, on the way of their social and economic impact in areas such as new business models, creativity and innovation, digitisation and skills creation. In the EU, cultural and creative industries employ more than 12 million workers full-time, representing 5.3% of the total EU GDP GVA, with much higher points in certain regions, where ICCAs contribute more than other sectors to young people's employment and have proved particularly resilient to the impact of the economic crisis. For all these reasons it is necessary for the ICC to be properly supported.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: in writing. — It is necessary to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term economic policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors in order to promote their competitiveness and exploit their employment and growth potential. In addition, cross-industry cooperation should be sought to promote interaction between small and medium-sized enterprises and research centres and universities.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. I do not think that cultures in Europe would benefit from new EU measures and policies in this field. I believe that each Member State should have the right to decide independently on how to preserve and promote its culture.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The creative economy across the UK employs nearly 3 million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. I voted in favour of this report which calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. — Parliament's resolution calls for a policy to support the cultural and creative industry at Union level. Indeed, the cultural and creative sectors are important in the different states of the Union and form an undeniable heritage that must be kept alive in order to avoid the museification or even the disappearance of certain crafts in particular. These sectors are also powerful vectors of our culture and our identity and values. Therefore, every people should be able to express themselves according to their own traditions. Innovations, especially digital ones, have revealed new talents, especially in France, a country that stands out particularly in video games and animated films. This report suggests positive avenues for work. However, the development of a coherent Union policy would therefore be very risky because it would tend to homogenize production and creations. This policy would necessarily be subject to the ideology of the EU: immigrationist, globalist, and even guilty of our traditions. Cultural diplomacy, a powerful tool for influencing people, is too important to transfer this competence to the Union, so I abstained on this Parliament resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. ‒ This is a joint report by the ITRE and CULT committees on the challenges and possibilities facing creative and cultural industries in the Union. Among other issues, it highlights the need for active advocacy policies, access to finance, counter-piracy, better participation of perpetrators and creators in benefit-sharing, promoting cross-sectoral cooperation and mobility, improving the working conditions of workers in the sector and the gender, etc. I voted in favour of the report, because I believe that these aspects are necessary in order to lay the foundations for a specific policy that will enable the sector to be valued and sustainable growth in the Member States as a whole.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as I believe that that the EU could take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe, and promote policies that champion Europe’s most unique asset: its culture. The creative economy across the UK employs nearly three million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is called on to act appropriately to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rights holders receive fair remuneration for their works.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to have a legal framework for businesses in the cultural and creative sector, adapted to the digital age and to encourage the collaboration of SMEs with university research centres. The report also plans to support the competitiveness of companies in the sector by facilitating access to finance, notably under the Juncker Plan for Strategic Investments.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. — Culture is the essential cement of our societies, but it is also a dynamic, growing industry: 12 million jobs and €509 billion in value added in the European Union's GDP. It is in this context that I supported this resolution, in order to affirm that the digital transition must be at the service of maintaining a living culture and a quality creation where the benefits are rightly shared. European artists, creators and cultural companies must be supported in this way, through the establishment of fair conditions in the face of digital giants. Today, creative content is increasingly accessible, distribution costs have fallen with technological change, yet creators have not seen their revenues increase in return. On the contrary, for some, these dropped dramatically. Much of the added value is captured by digital platforms that act as an intermediary between creators and consumers of cultural products. This is not acceptable. We need an ambitious European strategy that combines industry, culture and creation, which respects diversity and quality in the digital age and enables creators to live from their work.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries help to preserve and disseminate European knowledge and values, while also contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. These industries are particularly profound in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - Although Article 167 TFEU explicitly excludes harmonisation in the field of culture, noting that the EU's competences lie only to encourage cooperation between States and to complement their action to improve knowledge and disseminate culture and protection of cultural heritage, however, this report seeks to create a specific framework setting the conditions for the management of culture as yet another profitable industry. Even the individual positive references in the report regarding the need to boost funding in the fields of culture and creativity, support SMEs and tackle gender discrimination in the labour market are cancelled by the the ultimate goal set to serve the needs of the market and exploit the full potential of the cultural and creative industries as yet another tool for strengthening competitiveness. We have therefore voted against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that highlights how the EU can take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact of the cultural and creative sectors, particularly fostering policies that champion Europe’s most unique asset: its culture. All around the world, the cultural and creative sector (CCIs) are considered a major and growing part of the global economy. Its importance as a generator of jobs and wealth is increasingly recognised, particularly so in the EU. We need a comprehensive industrial strategy at the European level that will take all specific characteristics of cultural and creative industries into account, and will turn challenges like digitalisation and the review of copyright rules into new growth and job opportunities by creating a balanced legal framework. CCIs have a key role in reindustrialising Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors. There is no doubt that the cultural and creative industries are an exceptionally strong branch of the European economy, being a showcase and a mark of Europe in the world. They have great potential both to promote the growth, innovation and competitiveness of the European Union, but also to promote and cultivate our tradition and cultural diversity. It is therefore undoubtedly that they require specific support in order to develop unlimited, so I agree with the rapporteurs that it is necessary to create an industrial strategy at European level taking into account the specific characteristics of these industries as well as corresponding to their needs, including copyright law or digitisation. Furthermore, I would like to note that many of the companies operating in this industry are family companies and, in connection with their particular legal situation, they require a comprehensive approach, especially in relation to issues such as inheritance law.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, various works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values while at the same time contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ In this report the Commission is called to take the appropriate measures to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and right holders receive fair remuneration for their works. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the report Consistent EU Policy for Cultural and Creative Industries (2016/2072 (INI)), as culture and the creative sector are seen as a growing part of the world economy, extremely important for job creation. According to a study by the European Commission, the cultural and creative industries represent 11.2% of all private companies and 7.5% of all people employed in the economy. Cultural and creative industries comprise more than three million businesses with more than 12 million people working and generate 5.3% of Europe's total GDP. It is necessary to improve the investment environment and expand the range of financial instruments available to micro-enterprises and SMEs in the cultural and creative sectors through new and innovative funding programmes. The Commission should establish a comprehensive, consistent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors and integrate EU support for cultural and creative industries by adopting a comprehensive strategy. I support the establishment of a “European award for creative and cultural industries”.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — Good ideas in this report are wrong because, while I welcome the importance attached to the potential of SMEs in the cultural industry and their ability to protect culture and know-how, the question of sovereignty is indisputable for me. If this report were to address the industrial policies of the Member States rather than at the Union level, which he believes is the only competent one, it would gain my support. I abstained.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. — I supported this report because the cultural and creative sectors are extremely important for the European economy. Just mention that 3 million companies with a total of 12 million employees create them. The importance of this industry is also due to the fact that it is difficult to move existing jobs within its framework to other countries and to other continents. First of all, because they involve specific cultural competence and social experience. In addition, young people and women are more likely to be employed within these sectors, so social groups affected most by unemployment. If you look at the education structure of young people, they very often undertake education in these very areas, which means that we have the right capacity within the Union. Therefore, the lack of an EU strategy for this area of the economy is surprising. This means not only that there is a lack of vision for how to build up existing potential, but above all we do not think about how to use EU instruments and programmes to strengthen the industry in question and therefore create new and stable jobs. The best example of failure in this sector is that the European Strategic Investment Fund, which is one of the priorities of which is to support the cultural and creative industries, has not so far been granted any funding for the project from the sectors concerned.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because it calls for further development of a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sector (CCS) in terms of growth. I believe that the EU is in a strategic position to trigger innovative spillovers in other industrial sectors, such as tourism, retail, and digital technologies and that it can take a leading role in promoting the positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Christian Ehler and Mr Luigi Morgano on Union policy for the cultural and creative sector. The report calls for a genuine European industrial policy in favour of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular by drawing up an adequate definition of the sector. The creative and cultural industries are predominantly SMEs and are a source of employment and growth for the European economy. The aim of this initiative is to stimulate innovation and competitiveness of these industries by calling on the Commission to further finance these structures. As part of my duties as a member of the Committee on Culture, I give my special support to this text, which will serve as the basis for future European legislation. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the development of a comprehensive, coherent and long-term strategic industrial framework for the cultural and creative sector. In particular, the text calls for adequate funding to be provided to the cultural and creative industries (CCI). It encourages coherence in Member States' and Union policies, and recommends more interaction between SMEs, research centres and universities. Another recommendation of the report is to create a more conducive environment for investment and support mixed forms of financing, such as public-private partnerships, which are economically friendly and will boost the cultural sector.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The Commission should develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the cultural and creative industries and enable it to develop its potential for growth and quality jobs. It is underlined that the cultural and creative sectors, which are mainly composed of SMEs, operate in an ever-changing environment and therefore faces the challenge of developing new business models to design market-driven solutions and target new target groups. Searching for rightholders and non-transparent copyright legislation involves considerable administrative burdens, which is particularly burdensome for SMEs.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The creative economy across the UK employs nearly 3 million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, various works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values, while also contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since the report addresses the challenges that people working in the CCI (cultural and creative industries) face on a daily basis. The report will be of great help to the authors, musicians, moviemakers, designers or game-programmers to keep doing their job and encourage young and creative talents to follow their dreams in CCI by providing access to funding and social security.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. - I supported the report on EU policy on cultural and creative industries as I believe that a single strategy is needed to cover all components of the cultural and creative industries and become an action programme. The cultural and creative industries are an important sector for the European economy and the EU's internal market, which makes a great contribution to creating new jobs, which are mainly recruited by young people. Thanks to it, many small and medium-sized enterprises exist and operate. For this reason, I support the idea of establishing strategic policy and long-term commitments that will help reduce unemployment among young Europeans, new investment in science and digitisation, and to increase growth in the EU economy. I support the proposal to allocate more funding and funding through various European programmes to promote the industry.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: In writing. ‒ By approving the own-initiative report on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries (ICC), Parliament reiterated an important principle: culture, art, creativity have the potential to create wealth and employment and are an important and expanding part of the global economy, generating value from intellectual property. I think emphasizing the economic contribution that the cultural and creative industries generate is crucial, but it is even more so to remember that the cultural and creative industries are the industries that rely on cultural values, cultural diversity, individual and/or collective creativity, skills and talent and play an essential role also for the social development of the EU and its Member States. With this own-initiative report, which I supported in this House, we asked the European Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the ICCs, and the Union to include actual development, promotion and protection, and adequate funding of ICCAs among its strategic objectives and general priorities, in order to stimulate the competitiveness of these industries and enable them to realize the potential they have in terms of creating quality jobs and growth.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Indeed, the cultural and creative industries (CCIs) play an important role for the social and economic development of the EU and its Member States. CCIs on the one hand preserve and promote cultural and linguistic diversity by strengthening European, national, regional and local identities while on the other hand sustaining social cohesion and economic growth by promoting new business models, creativity and innovation, investment, digitalisation and skills building. In this context, I supported the resolution because the EU should develop a comprehensive and above all coherent long-term industrial policy framework for the CCIs. Moreover, I urge the EU to include the development, effective promotion and protection and adequate funding of CCIs in its strategic goals and overall priorities in order to boost their competitiveness and enable them to fulfil their potential in terms of creating quality jobs and growth.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative industries (ICCs) based on cultural values, creativity and talent have a strategic and important position for creating new jobs. In Europe, ICCs represent the uniqueness of culture and arts, promoting cultural and linguistic diversity, strengthening European identity, and transmitting heritage preservation principles. Not less, they also have the opportunity to become an instrument for promoting social cohesion. The report therefore calls on the Commission to create a global policy framework for the cultural and creative sector, increase the competitiveness of ICCs, providing adequate funding, and finding a unique definition. With the assurance that these policies will contribute to the promotion and protection of our cultural heritage, I am voting in favour of the report on coherent EU policy for cultural and creative inductions.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. — The economic weight, as well as in terms of employment, of the vast sector of creative and cultural industries is considerable. These are jobs, largely non-relocatable, which have a very important attraction for our younger generations. Every effort must be made to promote and develop this sector, to protect these creative and cultural industries against the threats of counterfeiting, smuggling, piracy, and to establish sustainable financing mechanisms through the consolidation of intellectual property rights, copyright, for example with regard to the cultural sector. I therefore supported this report, which proposes 'a coherent European Union policy for the cultural and creative sector'. With this one, we finally have on the table a roadmap, a number of concrete actions, which carry an ambitious vision for a proactive European strategy for the promotion and development of creative and cultural industries.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. — I have chosen abstention on this text. This report contains many interesting points: the recognition of the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector, the importance of copyright and the fight against counterfeiting, enhancing manufacturing employment and craftsmanship... Nevertheless, this constant desire to regulate and harmonise everything at Union level, while Member States have their own cultural or 'cultural diplomacy' policies, is highly detrimental. The result is a mixed impression of this text and the measures it proposes.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. ‒ The revision of intellectual property rules is a necessary evidence in the new digital environment, as the Commission itself has stressed, if cultural and creative work is decently paid and protected. However, it is necessary to ensure that copyright protection measures are not converted into a tax managed for the benefit of intermediaries and publishers or prevent the dissemination of creative and cultural works. The report seems unclear to me on these issues, and that is why I have preferred to abstain.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. — The report on coherent EU policy for the culture and creative sectors rightly emphasises that creativity, inspiration and imagination should be an integral part of the education process. In this context, it is important to provide greater support for the Member States for teachers so that they can effectively help young people develop creative and innovative skills. It is necessary to modernise teaching processes and to provide support for cooperation between schools in order to exchange the most effective methods and practices for stimulating creativity and innovation. The cultural sector and the creative sector is also of great importance for employment, especially young people. In this context, it is important to include this sector in the European programmes for jobs and growth, with a particular emphasis on professional development and training for workers in cultural and creative industries.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the importance of the cultural and creative industries and looks for ways to boost these sectors in the EU.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I voted against. I do not agree with the call for the Commission to develop a framework for cultural policy.
