Culture is supposed to be a matter for Member States and individual citizens. I don't agree with the idea of engaging the European Investment Bank in subsidizing culture.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — Cultural and creative industries are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent with the potential to create wealth and create jobs. They play a key role in preserving Europe's cultural and linguistic diversity, strengthening the sense of belonging, and contributing to the transfer of knowledge and safeguarding the material and intangible European heritage. By moving to a digital economy, cultural and creative industries are increasingly replacing traditional manufacturing processes and value chains in the EU. They are also a good tool for the social cohesion of the EU economy in terms of jobs, investment, growth and innovation and contribute significantly to European competitiveness globally. It is therefore of strategic importance to support innovative European cultural and creative industries facing research as they can preserve linguistic and cultural diversity, pluralism and offer innovative and high-quality services. I supported this report because I believe that cultural and creative industries have potential in terms of youth employment and that policy should be prioritised within the European Structural and Investment Funds, Horizon 2020 and the MFF as a whole.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries in Europe provide more than 12 million full-time jobs, which amounts to 7.5 % of the EU’s workforce, creating approximately EUR 509 billion in value added to GDP. Cultural and creative industries in the EU employ 2.5 times more people than automotive manufacturers and five times more than the chemical industry. The European Parliament called on the Commission to introduce an umbrella scheme that bridges the gap between R&D, European creative content production and technological innovation in the media field.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries are indisputable for our society, apart from economic, economic and financial benefits, a means of having a fundamental impact on youth education and education. In addition to promoting investment, research and the introduction of new modern technologies and trends, we must therefore not forget the promotion of cultural heritage in this area as an inspiration for the entire cultural and creative industries. It will help us preserve and build on everything good of our history while raising young people to respect history and true values.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, and because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. This report deals with the importance and potential of cultural and creative industries. It also aims to promote their development and outreach. The rapporteurs point out that these industries have the advantage of being difficult to relocate since they are often linked to specific cultural and historical competences, and that they can play a role in the reindustrialisation of Europe. It is therefore a matter of putting in place adequate measures to preserve European know-how. The report also reiterates Dominique Bilde's initiative to exclude the cultural and audiovisual services sectors from any agreement between the Union and third countries. On the other hand, it envisages an EU-wide industrial policy, which we are opposed to. That is why we cannot support this text.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries. This proposal can prove crucial not only in promoting a European identity but also in respecting the cultural and linguistic diversity that contribute to maintaining good relations with third countries. Moreover, the cultural and creative industry is a key development factor for the European Union and its Member States, at social level but also at economic level.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we voted on a report dealing with the EU's coherent policy for the cultural and creative sectors. I agree that it is a major sector that generates almost 39% of the Union's GDP and employment in this sector is steadily increasing, therefore this sector which creates incentives for innovation is necessary, support. However, I believe that the report does not adequately reflect the need for copyright reform in that direction to ensure balanced solutions between groups of industry representatives and consumers and creators, incentives small and medium-sized enterprises etc. I also disagree that there should be increased funding for the sector, with the help of the EFSI and other funds at a time when there are much more pressing problems in the EU to deal with. That's why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative sectors because I believe that the Cultural and Creativity Sectors (CCIs) have a dual value: firstly they play a key role in preserving and promoting European cultural and linguistic diversity; strengthen the sense of European and regional identity, contribute to the transmission of knowledge and values, but at the same time ensure the tangible and intangible European heritage for present and future generations. At the same time, they are a tool for social cohesion, through their significant contribution to the EU economy in terms of employment, investment, growth and innovation and contribute significantly to Europe's competitiveness on a global scale. Finally, it becomes strategically important to support innovative and research-oriented CSIs, as they are capable of preserving linguistic and cultural diversity, pluralism and the provision of innovative and high-quality services, especially in the context of a convergent and globalised market.

name: Georg MAYER
text: in writing. - The Commission should develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the cultural and creative industries and enable them to develop their potential to create growth and quality jobs. unfold. Stronger action will be tackled against product piracy (such as films). It is underlined that the cultural and creative sectors, which are mainly composed of SMEs, operate in an ever-changing environment and is therefore faced with the challenge of developing and developing new business models to develop and develop new business models in order to develop market-driven solutions and to address new target groups. Searches for rightholders and non-transparent copyright legislation involves considerable administrative burdens, which is particularly burdensome for SMEs. Partnerships with the education sector will be strengthened in order to provide better opportunities for marginalised communities in disadvantaged neighbourhoods. The cultural and creative industries play a crucial role in Europe's reindustrialisation. It can boost growth and drive innovation. This is particularly interesting for digital technology. In addition, aid to SMEs is very positive. That is why I supported the report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. — This report aims to support the cultural and creative sectors. Interesting. In addition to the contribution of these sectors to human intelligence, they represent five times more jobs than the chemical industry. Still, we have to agree on the covered trades. I do not believe that advertising actors and heritage protection policies, for example, can be put on the same level. Or even less undress Paul to dress up Jacques, when it is the European budget that abounds the Juncker fund. The report also supports the digital single market and a fuzzy European intellectual property right to be defined by the European Commission in its next directive. Finally, I am puzzled about the proposal to combat piracy, which seems to turn to a European Hadopi. This being said, the report is clearly committed to defending European know-how and promoting “excellence” crafts. It defends precarious workers in the cultural world and is unanimous on the “cultural exception” in agreements with third countries. Under these conditions, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. — This report makes a fairly interesting observation on the cultural and creative sector, recalling the necessary fight against counterfeiting and piracy, the introduction of measures to preserve European know-how, the exclusion of the cultural and audiovisual services sectors from any agreement between the Union and third countries (proposal carried by D. Bilde). However, even if the observation is correct, the solutions proposed in this report are much less so since they are only agreed at European level, whose non-homogeneity in the field of cultivation makes it impossible to implement them. I therefore abstained on this issue.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. — (NL) Twelve million people in Europe work in the cultural and creative sectors. That is 2.5 times more than in the European car industry. At the same time, this employment pool creates EUR 509 billion annually. In order to develop inclusive, sustainable and smart growth in Europe, we are therefore well committed to fully exploiting the potential of this full-fledged sector. The demand for the Commission in this report to develop an industrial policy that fully exploits the enormous potential of the cultural and creative sectors is therefore more than right. In addition to organising market-oriented training, an attractive investment climate must also be promoted, and research and development and the public — private cooperation should be promoted financially. Europe's cultural richness - from medieval architecture to contemporary cinema - is priceless. That is why it is also advisable to develop instruments that bring culture and education closer together. This will enable young people to prosper creative talents and promote active citizenship.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situation in the cultural and creative industry and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The report is calling on the Commission to take the appropriate measures to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and right holders receive fair remuneration for their works, which is essential

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — According to the conclusion of the joint draft resolution of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on Culture and Education, cultural and creative industries play a key role in Europe's reindustrialisation as a driver of growth, and thanks to their strategic position have a spill impact on innovation in other industrial sectors, such as tourism, retail and digital technologies. On this basis, he believes that the EU can play a leading role in raising awareness of the important positive impact of creative sectors across Europe and thus support policies that are the most unique value of Europe: its culture. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — This joint ITRE-CULT report by the EPP and Socialist elected representatives makes good observations but unfortunately seeks solutions at European level. These include recognizing the role and potential of cultural and creative industries, as well as taking action to foster their development and outreach. Abstention.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The assessment of the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector is correct: whether it be in terms of innovation, resilience capacity or the protection of European cultural heritage and know-how. The whole text could be retained if it were to address the industrial policies of the Member States, not a Union-wide industrial policy. That's why I abstain.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The creative economy across the UK employs nearly 3 million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is called on to act appropriately to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rights holders receive fair remuneration for their works. I therefore voted in favour of this report as I believe that that the EU could take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe, and promote policies that champion Europe’s most unique asset: its culture.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on a coherent Community policy for the cultural and creative sectors. The text recalls that culture and creation represent more than 12 million jobs in Europe with an added value of more than €500 billion. It formulates several proposals to support the cultural and creative sector, such as its better integration in training paths or aid for its digitization.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries represent industries based on cultural values, creativity, skills and talent that is likely to create jobs and wealth by generating value from intellectual property. I have voted for this report that will try to realise the full potential of cultural and creative industries through combined actions at national, regional and local level as well as EU level.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. - I gave my support to this resolution because I share the view that the EU does not make maximum use of the economic and social potential of cultural and creative industries (CTI). This sector represents a small part of the European and global economy and is a source of jobs and employment, especially in small and remote regions. In addition, it should be noted that the CTI provides the most jobs for young people and is one of the few sectors that have maintained their resilience in the context of the economic crisis. Yes, it is true that cultural policies are primarily the responsibility of national governments, but the EU has the task of complementing and supporting Member States' cultural actions. Unfortunately, we must find that caring for our cultural heritage remains in the background both in national and European contexts. Last but not least, we must note that the age of digital technologies gives us the incredible opportunity to digitize our cultural and historical heritage and preserve it for generations to come. For countries like Bulgaria this will give cause for self-confidence, as we will be able to show the world the Bulgarian life, culture and traditions. For this reason, I believe that ensuring funding for digitisation and online access to European cultural heritage must be a priority.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. - I voted for this report in thinking that before any customs, banking, common market union, we were a union of common values, and Europe is created on this common European culture, it is an area that would not have existed without the input of the genius who caused the throughout history, cultural revolutions that have changed the whole world. Culture is indeed our 'raw material', and we feel it every time we move away from the European space. This is the most important reason why I consider this report, on which it has been negotiated long, necessary, and proposals to encourage cultural and creative industries extremely welcome. Supporting coherent policies in the cultural and artistic space will boost creativity, guarantee more jobs for artists, whether they are consecrated or at the beginning of the road. In this respect, I welcome the proposal to promote, in all Member States, cooperation between art schools, vocational and technical education institutions, cultural and creative universities and enterprises. Last but not least, I voted for this report because it also addresses the issue of improving the role that public investment banks play in these sectors by making it easier to lend credit to cultural and artistic SMEs.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. — I supported the report highlighting the importance of the cultural and creative sector, which is the last sector with the lack of a framework strategy at EU level. The Commission and Member States should set up 'study laboratories, creative centres, cooperation spaces, networking programmes and cultural and creative clusters and networks in order to promote interaction between micro-enterprises, small, medium and large enterprises, and between non-profit organisations and commercial companies within cultural and creative sectors, traditional crafts, cultural heritage organisations, tourism, research centres, universities and investors. At the same time, it is crucial that the EU and its Member States retain the opportunity to protect and develop their cultural and audiovisual policies within their existing legal transcripts, standards and agreements, including UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of Diversity of Cultural Expressions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because, in particular, aid to small businesses is to be welcomed.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. Cultural and creative industries play an extremely important role in society, often being a mediator between different sectors and groups of society. It is therefore important to establish a comprehensive and long-term action plan for cultural and creative policies in order to contribute to their competitiveness.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - Branches of culture and creativity (CCIs) are those sectors that are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent, with the potential to create wealth and jobs through the production of value from intellectual property. The cultural and creative sector is seen as a major and growing part of the global economy. I voted in favour of the report, which focuses on various measures in order to fully exploit the potential of the CCI. To realise the full potential of the sector, concerted action is needed, at national, regional and local levels, but also at EU level. With regard to funding, emphasis is placed on new forms of financing, such as micro-credit or crowdfunding and the role to be played by the Commission and the Member States in promoting and improving the regulatory framework. Finally, as highlighted in the report, the EU could take a leading role in promoting the significant positive impact of creative sectors across Europe and also promote policies to defend Europe's most unique chapter: its culture.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. — The EU's interest in the cultural and creative sectors beyond pursuing the reproduction of sovereign urban values is also linked to the fact that they constitute - particularly in view of the difficulty of recovering from the crisis - a profitability area for monopolies, a basic condition for the which is the exploitation of industry workers. That is why the report notes with satisfaction that there are a number of young people highly skilled in atypical employment and not only does it not propose improving working conditions, but rather stresses the need to increase their mobility so that capital can find more easily cheap workforce, wherever and when he needs it. The report provocatively notes that creators need “entrepreneurship” in order to subordinate their creativity to profit, while its frequent references to the need to protect them are actually about the protection of intellectual property of business groups that exploit the product of their work. The Greek Communist Party voted against, stressing that the only solution that meets the needs of the creator and contemporary social needs for intellectual and cultural development is the abolition of capitalist property in the means of production and dissemination of art, so that the creator can be real owner of his thought and art.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which calls on the European Union to support artists in all aspects of their activities as well as European cultural enterprises. Cultural and creative industries in Europe generate more jobs and growth than other important sectors such as automotive and pharmaceutical industries. Culture, although not only to be appreciated from an economic perspective, represents 12 million jobs, or 7.5% of the Union's workforce, and EUR 509 billion of value added in GDP, or 5.3% of the Union's total value added. It was therefore important that this sector be taken into account in the policies of the European Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my fellow Members proposal because I agree with the assumption that the cultural and creative industries (ICCs) are an important and expanding part of the global economy, involving a wide range of segments, from architecture to artistic crafts, from audiovisual to show business, design to high-end industry, music and radio to publishing. In this respect, they act as a generator of employment and wealth with a positive impact on the economic system in terms of growth, employment, investment and innovation (aspects that strengthen cohesion social). They guarantee the safeguarding and promotion of cultural and linguistic peculiarities within the EU, while at the same time strengthening the sense of belonging to European and regional identity. They therefore constitute a flywheel of European values such as creativity, excellence, craftsmanship, and culture in the world. Given these premises, they agree that a standardised definition of ICCs should be received in order to carry out constant monitoring of the outputs and the desirability of training adequate for workers in the sector, on the dutiousness of copyright protection so that the ICC market is not deteriorated and the removal of barriers preventing access to the funding for the cultural and creative industries. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a member of the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection I supported this report, as I am confident that it is a step towards harmonisation of the sectors. The report calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the creative and cultural sector, and to provide adequate funding for CCIs, in order to boost their competitiveness and to enable them to fulfil their potential in terms of creating quality jobs and growth. To achieve this ambitious goal, the report proposes a harmonised definition of CCIs on which statistical data should be based.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported the Resolution on a consistent EU policy for cultural and creative industries, which highlights cross-sectoral cooperation to foster interaction between SMEs and research centres and universities to better integrate creative with entrepreneurial education and to strengthen business abilities of creative entrepreneurs. The resolution encourages Member States to build greater knowledge of cultural and creative industries in education and training programmes and to improve their training, learning and qualification systems. The Resolution calls for consideration of the possibility of establishing a mobility programme for “young innovators” to promote exchange and innovation in the field of culture and creativity; highlights the immense potential of women as innovators and entrepreneurs and the important role they play in the cultural and creative industries; encourages Member States to provide adequate financial support and training and stresses the importance of networking and exchange of best practices. It also encourages Member States to take initiatives such as a “cultural bonus” (e.g., the Italian government has made available €500 to 18-year-olds living in Italy which they can only spend on “cultural uplift activities” such as visiting museums, archaeological sites, etc.). The resolution stresses the importance of guaranteeing funding for the digitisation, preservation and internet accessibility of Europe's cultural heritage and stresses that women in the cultural and creative industries face the same obstacles as in other economic sectors.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: In writing. ‒ This report calls for the Commission to develop an ambitious legislative package on the cultural and creative industry, providing for funding to promote its development and precise measures to ensure compliance with fundamental social and working standards. The cultural and creative industries are a strategic sector for job creation and sustainable development. They defend and promote cultural heritage and encourage innovation. The Member States and the European Union, in particular the Commission, must focus on the full development of the potential of these undertakings, through the enhancement of education, training and skills. Equally important will be to ensure that value creators in the sector as authors, creators and actors receive fair remuneration for their work and that their contracts meet European standards related to social and health contributions and tax rules. Finally, in addition to direct funding from institutions, the new legislative framework will have to encourage other forms of financing, such as microcredit or crowdfunding. For these reasons, I wanted to support this report with my positive vote.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The cultural and creative industries in the EU employ two and a half times more people than in the production of cars and five times more people than in the chemical industry — they therefore play a key role in the social and economic development of the EU and its Member States and contribute to improving quality lives of citizens and are an important factor of inward investment. At their very heart are authors and performers and copyright protection is essential for the survival of these industries. It is the basis of the revenues of these industries and I therefore urge the Commission to find balanced legal solutions tailored to the digital age in copyright reform. It is also necessary to remove the wrong belief that investing in these industries is more risky compared to other types of enterprises. That is why I urge institutions to establish a comprehensive industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors and to encourage strengthening their competitiveness in order to achieve the potential for job creation and growth. A range of measures on contracts, collective representation opportunities, social and health insurance, direct and indirect taxation and compliance with European regulations are needed to improve artist mobility across the EU, and I therefore urge Member States to develop and/or implementation of legal and institutional frameworks for creative artistic activity.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. — (PT) The essence of this report is based on concepts that we do not endorse. There are aspects which do not give us disagreement, although they should be relativized in the general context of the report. The report proposes a definition of the Cultural and Creative Industries (ICC) according to which these “are based on cultural, creative, individual values, skills and talent, capable of creating wealth and employment through the valorisation of intellectual property. Architecture, archives and libraries, crafts, audiovisual (including cinema, television, video games and multimedia), cultural heritage, design, luxury industries oriented to creativity and fashion industry, festivals, music, performing arts, books and publishing, radio and visual arts'. Fundamentally, all areas of cultural activity that have been subject to commodification and areas of commodity production to which we now intend to give a “cultural” status. It is enough to look at our country and imagine the consequences that would have, in an already so degraded cultural framework, the classification of heritage, archives and libraries, of the arts in general in the universe of cultural industries, alongside fashion, jewellery, festivals and video games, competing with them in the “creation of wealth and employment through the valorization of intellectual property”. It would be a question of an embodiment concept of culture, which in itself is reason to reject this report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — I believe that the cultural and creative sectors need to be supported in Europe, as this is our shared heritage. Therefore, I am pleased to have been able to support a resolution that focuses on several measures to realise the full potential of this activity through the specific definition of cultural and creative industry. It stresses the importance of education, skills and training, its ability to create values from intellectual property, and proposes solutions to facilitate access to EU finances. I am pleased that this resolution also calls on Member States to establish a legal and institutional framework for creative arts activities in line with European standards.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative industries are based on cultural values, creativity of the individual and skills and talents that can generate income and create jobs through profit generation. More than 12 million people are employed in the cultural and creative sector industries (providing jobs 7.5% of the total employed people). Their value in terms of sales of goods and services reaches EUR 509 billion (5.3% of total gross added value in Europe). In 21st century Europe, marked by the transformation to the digital economy, the industries of the cultural sector and the creative sector are increasingly taking the place of traditional manufacturing processes and traditional value chains. The report focuses on, among others, the definition of social and economic value, impact, potential and the challenges facing the cultural and creative sector industries today. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Cultural and creative industries (IIC) generate a lot of jobs but are largely composed of SMEs, particularly vulnerable to copyright infringement. To encourage their development, I voted for the Commission to develop an effective strategy to make it easier for CCI to access European funds such as Horizon 2020 or Creative Europe. It is also important that CCI be better defined in order to establish a legal framework that would protect authors and intellectual property. We must support the creative sector, which is a growth driver and engine of the European cultural industry!

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The cultural and creative industries (CCI) are at the heart of a dual system consisting of large groups of innovative and competitive SMEs at international level and startups whose benefits for the economy and the promotion of employment are now unstoppable. However, they sometimes have more difficulties with regard to market access and financing. It is important to note that, in the European area, the CCIs are responsible for creating more than 12 million full-time jobs, representing 7.5% of the Union's workforce. It should also be noted that almost 39% of the Union's GDP is generated by them. This report calls on Member States to improve the investment environment and to extend the range of financial instruments available to micro-enterprises and SMEs in the cultural and creative sector through new and innovative financing schemes such as micro-credit, repayable contributions, collaborative financing, venture capital financing, start-up capital and venture capital. For the above, I support this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. We do not think that cultures in Europe would benefit from new EU measures and policies in this field. We believe that each Member State should have the right to decide independently on how to preserve and promote its culture.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - This report recognises the Cultural and Creative Industries (CCI), traditionally based on cultural values and creativity, as a strategic sector for job creation and sustainable growth, supporting cultural heritage and promoting innovation. The report focuses on several measures to realize the full potential of the sector through a concrete definition of the CCI. It highlights the importance of education and training, its ability to generate value from intellectual property and proposes solutions to facilitate access to EU funding and funds. S&D has introduced a new chapter on worker status in the cultural and creative sector, calling on Member States to develop or implement a legal and institutional framework for artistic and creative activity in terms of contracts, social security, health insurance, direct taxes and indirect and European compliance with standards. As far as funding is concerned, the emphasis is placed on new forms of financing: such as microcredits or crowdfunding, and on the role to be played by the Commission and the Member States in promoting and improving the regulatory framework.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Yesterday, the European Parliament positioned itself as a great advocate — and so much better — of the European cultural and creative industry. As the regulatory framework is changing rapidly, we have adopted a resolution that looks at the main themes of the Digital Single Market Strategy. Because the production of quality content, the ability to innovate, tell and create emotions are an invaluable raw material in Europe, it is important to cultivate it, support it, promote it and... above all, defend it. The text of the resolution therefore calls on the European Union to include the development, promotion, effective protection and adequate financing of the cultural and creative sectors in its strategic objectives and overall priorities. The adopted text also refers to “fair remuneration and legal protection” for all parties involved in the creative process and their works. But this is just an own-initiative report. The next important step on the strategy for a digital single market will take place on 15 December, with the publication of the electronic commerce report.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I abstained from voting on this report. It is clear that the text has been prepared inconsistently and is not complete. The wording contained in it can be interpreted and interpreted differently. I do not think it is possible to support a text whose inaccuracies could subsequently lead to undesirable consequences.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Cultural and Creative Industries (ICC) are based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent with the potential to generate wealth and employment through the creation of value from intellectual property. This report brings together considerations on the cultural and economic potential of the sector, indicating the pillars on which European Industrial Policy for CCIs should be based. The rapporteurs considered that, in order to realise the potential of the sector, concerted action at European, national, regional and local levels is necessary. Thus: identify characteristics and needs of the sector, monitor its evolution, stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship, facilitate cooperation and synergies with other sectors and policies, improve access to finance, support new business models, use existing financial instruments, to European level, developing skills and suppressing skills shortages are some of the measures listed by the rapporteurs, with which I agree. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that CCIs are essential in the 're-industrialisation' of Europe as an engine of strategic growth to boost innovation in other sectors. The EU must therefore promote the impact of this sector through policies that defend Europe's most unique good: its culture.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the EU's coherent policy for cultural and creative industries. The reason for this is that the report calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term economic policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors and to provide the industry with adequate financial resources. This will boost the competitiveness of the industry and increase its employment and growth potential.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains many positive points, it is a proposal that guarantees the participation of major economic actors. The development of cultural and creative industries depends on the fact that authors obtain fair remuneration for their work, but without this entailing any form of blocking the development of that industry and its services to the public. The report contains positive references to the inclusion of creators' rights, but it also guarantees the concentration of intellectual property rights through their financialization. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: In writing. ‒ The cultural and creative industries (ICCs) provide more than 12 million full-time jobs, corresponding to 7.5 percent of the European Union's workforce. They represent a strong growth sector that promotes innovation and helps alleviate the current economic and employment difficulties in the EU. There are still many challenges facing cultural and creative industries: the variety of definitions that makes it difficult to assess these activities precisely, the counterfeiting of protected goods by copyright and digital content piracy are just a few examples. I decided to express my support of the own-initiative report, which aims to highlight not only the great value and economic and social potential of this sector, but also the need for a European coherent long-term framework for its development.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I vote against all new EU law, I do not think individual cultures would benefit from an EU Culture Directive.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as I believe that that the EU could take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe, and promote policies that champion Europe’s most unique asset: its culture. The Creative Economy across the UK employs nearly three million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is called on to act appropriately to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rights holders receive fair remuneration for their works.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries have been changing significantly as digital technologies rise in recent periods, and therefore many researchers are increasingly dealing with this issue. It is pleasant to note that the cultural and creative industry, which has a turnover of EUR 535.9 billion and creates 7.1 million jobs, is among the sectors with the greatest entrepreneurial spirit and also develops other cross-cutting skills. Indeed, the fact that the cultural and creative industry is of great importance also shows that it employs two and a half times more people in the EU than car manufacturers and five times more than the chemical industry. What I am particularly pleased about is that the cultural and creative industries make a significant contribution to youth employment, more than any other sector. I am certainly among those people who disagree that investing in the cultural and creative industries is associated with a higher risk than other types of business. I am in favour of the fact that cultural and creative industries have played, and in the future, a key role in the reindustrialisation of Europe and will become essential for the stability and long-term competitiveness of the European economy. I supported the report because it focuses not only on the state of play, but it comes with interesting proposals and measures that can bring the sector more significantly to the forefront.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. — Europe is a great power for businesses in the cultural and creative industry: in 2014, exports of cultural goods amounted to more than €27 billion of European exports and fashion-related goods exceeded €200 billion. Europe is identified in many parts of the world with culture and historical heritage, which is why it is very important for the European Union to have a coherent policy in this area. The basis of this cultural and creative industry is Europe's cultural and linguistic diversity, the strength of regional identities and the experience of European history. Therefore, supporting cultural and linguistic diversity also means maintaining and reproducing the most important component of cultural and creative industries, and its social benefits can be quantified. It would be important for Member States to consider this diversity equally valuable and to be preserved.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: in writing. - The CCIs create wealth and jobs through the production of value from intellectual property. They account for 11.2% of private enterprises, 7.5% of employees and create 5.3% of total European GVA. However, in order to realise the full potential of the sector, concerted action is needed through various measures and policies such as promoting innovation, developing skills, improving access to finance and collecting reliable statistics, based on an integrated definition. The use of the existing 'European' toolkit is at the heart of the Motion for a Resolution and aims to develop a genuine and coherent industrial policy at EU level.

name: Bart STAES
text: — Cultural and creative industries are subject to significant changes as a result of the development of digital technology, the economic crisis and changes to the legislative framework. Reason for the EP to draw up a report on this. The Ehler/Morgano report was adopted by a large majority. I, too, voted in favour. The challenges facing the sectors — from music and audiovisual productions, to video games, architecture, fashion, modern art, radio, books about magazines and festivals are further reinforced by clear informative and legislative blockages in the areas of intellectual property rights and various tax regimes. In line with the Europe 2020 strategy for job creation, the aim is to ensure that creative sectors can contribute to employment across Europe. The reform of copyright legislation was one of the other driving forces behind this report, as was access to financial funds. The report calls on the European Commission to adopt an industrial policy approach for the creative sector and to encourage it more through promotion, subsidisation, but also through education and networks and platforms for cultural infrastructure. The report also calls for better protection of property rights and the fight against piracy.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. — The area of cultural policy must remain among the exclusive policies of the nation states. However, this does not mean that we cannot work together on topics and projects that present our common European culture and cultural heritage. In addition, the promotion of creative industries and mental work represents a significant investment in the future, when these sectors become more important in the context of the fourth industrial revolution.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: ‒ The creative and cultural sector in Flanders is very important. According to a study from the beginning of 2016 by the Flanders DC Knowledge Centre, this sector accounts for 2.7% of GNP and has more than 50,000 self-employed (or almost 13% of all self-employed in Flanders) and 70,000 employees. The N-VA supported this resolution, which makes recommendations on the development of a European policy on creative and cultural industries. Some elements, such as the creation of (yet) a new European award, were preferred to disappear from the resolution. But the balance is clearly positive.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - I rejected the European Parliament resolution on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries. The report is one of those that are completely superfluous. Culture is not a matter for the EU, it is not even a matter for the Federal Government in Germany. The report defines: “The cultural and creative industries encompass those sectors based on cultural values, cultural diversity, individual or collective creativity, skills and talent, and have the potential to promote innovation, prosperity and jobs through the creation of social and economic values in particular from intellectual property. These include the following industries that rely on cultural and creative input: architecture, archives and libraries, handicrafts, audiovisual media (including film, television, software and video games, and multimedia and music recordings), cultural heritage, design, creativity driven high quality goods industries and fashion , festivals, live music, the performing arts, books and publishing (newspapers and magazines), radio, visual arts and advertising. “This catchy definition is followed by all sorts of wishes and demands for the Commission, in particular the call for the Commission to “establish a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the Commission. “Culture and Creative Sector”. I can't imagine a better way to choke off the pitiful level of innovation and creativity in the EU.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. — The European Commission recognises the importance of the cultural and creative industries (CCIs) for the social and economic development of the Union, as well as its Member States. The EU needs to increase investment in new sources to guarantee smart, sustainable and inclusive development. In the cultural and creative industries, plenty of potential largely remains untapped. European cultural diplomacy, based on mutual respect for values and specificities, strengthens bilateral and multilateral relations between European and third countries, building bridges between societies through interpersonal contacts and cooperation in all cultural and creative areas and thus contributes to better mutual understanding, and at the same time acts as a driver of economic and social development. Cultural and creative industries (CCIs) create more than 12 million jobs and lies great potential for youth employment. I support this report since the cultural and creative industries (CCIs) are a driver of economic and social development and I believe that they play a huge role in presenting European values on the international political scene.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries. In today's age of digitisation, the existing cultural and creative industry has a great challenge to adapt to the significant developments we are witnessing in digitisation, while offering new opportunities for developing new business models and expanding the market. I therefore support the call from the report to the European Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors, while identifying specific indicators for monitoring and analysing cultural, economic and social impact.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - Although Article 167 TFEU explicitly precludes harmonisation in the field of culture, the report seeks to create a specific framework setting the conditions for the management of culture as yet another profitable industry, which, through the use of specific indicators to measure the economic impact, to be used to enhance the competitiveness of the Union. Even the individual positive references in the report regarding the need to boost funding in the fields of culture and creativity, to support SMEs and to tackle discrimination in the labour market, are canceled by the ultimate objective set for serving the needs of the market and exploiting the full potential of the cultural and creative industries as yet another tool to enhance competitiveness. The report promotes culture as an instrument of the foreign policy of the European External Action Service and calls for university-enterprises to cooperate in order to respond fully to the needs of large enterprises and the labour market. For the above reasons we have voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - The EU must respect and promote the cultural heritage of each Member State. It is hypocrisy on its part to claim that it promotes culture and creativity when it allows Member States to illegally own cultural and cultural goods in their museums from other Member States of the Union and from third countries.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, various works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values while at the same time contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative industries have the potential to contribute to alleviating the current economic and employment difficulties in the European Union, as well as promoting sustainable inclusive growth, as well as innovation. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the creative and cultural sectors in order to ensure that they are adequately funded, enhance their competitiveness and enable them to realise their potential in terms of creating quality jobs and economic growth. In this context, it is worth mentioning the need to raise awareness of young people in particular about career opportunities in craft and manufacturing professions linked to the cultural and creative sectors. Finally, it is extremely important to improve the investment environment and expand the range of financial instruments available to businesses, while supporting mixed financing ways, especially in the form of public-private partnerships. That's particularly important from the point of view of small and medium-sized

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. - The need for a synergistic, coherent and strategically integrated European policy for cultural and creative industries derives from a variety of reasons: the economic and social performance of the two industries, their strategic position in national economies, generating positive effects in other sectors of the national and European economy (tourism, trade, education, ICT, industry, etc.) and the major impact on human development in general. The digital age does not exclude the development of cultural and creative industries, but, on the contrary, contributes to their manifestation in various forms and degrees of complexity, by generating creative conditions and ecosystems. Policy in the field of cultural and creative industries must be based on different approaches to creativity (including cultural): from the perspective of the product created, from the perspective of the creative process and from the perspective of the creative person. Strategies for the development and financing of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries, strategies for implementing a legal and institutional framework on creative artistic activity (creative process), strategies and plans for training and development of creative skills. All this is possible through the development of stronger partnerships between cultural and creative industries, between social partners and providers of education and training, among all stakeholders within the respective industries.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. - The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that would address the precarious contractual situation in the cultural and creative industry and ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is invited to take appropriate measures to reduce the difference in value and to ensure that authors, creators, artists and rightholders receive fair remuneration for their works. I particularly welcome the inclusion in the report of the social dimension and I support this report by vote.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: The cultural and creative sectors play an important role in the reindustrialisation of Europe, act as a driving force for growth and are in a strategic position to trigger innovative redistributions in other sectors, such as tourism, retail trade and digital technologies. The European Union could play a leading role in highlighting the important positive effects of creative sectors throughout Europe, in promoting policies to support Europe's most valuable asset: its culture!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural and creative industries (CCIs) are, at the dawn of the 21st century, undergoing considerable change as a result of increased digital technologies, the economic crisis of the past several years, and considerable changes in the regulatory framework. It is therefore necessary to reflect those changes in EU policy-making and legislation. I agree with the need to focus on creative industries and their position in this dynamic environment. However, I do not agree with the extremely broad scope of the report which is in my opinion rather diluting the overall target. CCIs have different specifics than other ‘traditional’ industries, but the same regulatory framework has to apply in both cases. Therefore, I decided to support a number of deletions within this report and I voted in favour of the final text.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: ‒ The creative industries focus man's creativity and represent the new frontier of contemporary economic development. It is a productive dimension that generates innovation and, in the same way, is permeated by it. According to the latest figures from the European Commission, cultural and creative industries account for around 3% of EU gross domestic product and jobs. Despite these important numbers, this kind of companies still remains too widely undervalued, especially with regard to access to funds. I believe it is necessary, in this regard, for Member States to coordinate to reform the legislative context in which the cultural and creative industries operate and that policies and initiatives are defined for promote market access and investment. It is also crucial to recognise the high economic value of European excellence, such as design and fashion, which make our businesses famous all over the world.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. The report emphasises the support for innovative and research-oriented European cultural and creative industries that can ensure the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity and offer innovative and high-quality services. These include, for example, works of art, audiovisual products (films, television shows, video games), music, cultural heritage, festivals, etc. Creative and cultural industries contribute to the preservation and transfer of European knowledge and values, while also contributing to increasing employment, investment and competitiveness. Therefore, the future of creative and cultural industries is especially important. Creative industries are particularly stressed in the European R&D market. In many cases, due to low entry barriers, people who are unable to make other capital intensive investments can be at the forefront of a given area. This feature also provides opportunities for wider strata than before to participate in European innovation. Creativity is based on all forms of appearance of culture and art and should be an integral part of education. It is therefore particularly important to remind Member States to include artistic, musical, theatrical and cinema education in their school curricula, as they are key factors for deepening knowledge of cultural heritage, art practice and creativity.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on a consistent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. It is necessary to ensure competitiveness, allow the creation of quality jobs and the growth of the industry. The European Commission's communication entitled “Promoting cultural and creative sectors for growth and jobs in the EU” sees the key role of cultural and creative industries in the development of the Union as it promotes the cultural and linguistic diversity of Member States and strengthens its identity. Cultural and creative industries in Europe employ more than 12 million people full-time, which is 7.5% of the European Union's workforce, and industries that benefit from intellectual property rights bring almost 39% of the Union's GDP. Therefore, it is necessary to address the wrong belief that investment in cultural and creative industries is riskier compared to other companies and increase growth in the sector through the institutional emphasis of the European Union.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - I supported the report for several reasons. Worldwide, the cultural and creative industries are an essential and ever-growing area of the global economy. Its importance in creating new jobs and generating income can be seen more and more often, especially in the EU. But despite this, a common and realistic policy for this sector has not been developed so far. The report contains concrete proposals. A comprehensive strategy at European level is needed that takes into account all the specificities of the cultural industry. It is therefore very important to remind the EU Member States of the need to include theatre, music and film in the school curriculum, as this is a key factor in the development of knowledge of cultural heritage.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Cultural and creative content is often taken for granted, but behind them are millions of talented people who create a value measured in billions of euros on the market. The cultural and creative industry is very important for our societies and national economies and needs to be given the greatest possible support. Unfortunately, national governments very often, at least when it comes to Croatia, support exclusively grants from the budget and thus make one market very potent branch addicted to public finances. It's completely the wrong approach. The state needs to do more to protect the legal status of culturists and creatives and their copyright. They need to maximally facilitate business in the market instead of trying to subject strong individuals and creators to collective norms and satisfy tiny payments from the budget. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution to the European Parliament on a coherent EU policy for the cultural and creative industries. Culture, art and creativity create the image of Europe. In 21st century Europe, during the transition to the digital economy, the cultural and creative industry is increasingly replacing traditional production processes and traditional value chains. The cultural and creative industry is an industry based on cultural values and on the creativity, skills and talent of an individual and can create assets and jobs by creating value from intellectual property (European culture has over 3000 years history). Around the world, the cultural and creative industries are considered a large, growing part of the global economy and creating opportunities for new jobs. Nevertheless, a genuine and harmonised industrial policy at EU level has not yet been established, and a comprehensive industrial strategy is needed to be prepared. It would be necessary to define the concept of 'cultural and creative industry' for better performance. Through culture, good international cooperation can also be achieved. The cultural and creative industries play a key role in the re-industrialisation of Europe to drive growth and have a strategic position to create innovative external effects on other industrial sectors such as tourism, retail and digital technologies. Europe could play a leading role in this.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I will support any measures that will help to create a framework that fosters innovation and the development of the European cultural sector, which promotes cooperation and the exchange of good practices, with special emphasis on the correct financing that this sector needs in order to be able to develop successfully.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. — The findings on the potential of SMEs in the cultural and creative industries sector are good, whether in terms of innovation, resilience capacity or the protection of European cultural heritage and know-how. The whole text could be kept if it were to address the industrial policies of the Member States and not a Union-wide industrial policy, which prevents me from supporting it. I chose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. ‒ Culture, art and creativity: the world actually connects this image and these values to Europe. As the transition to the digital economy in 21st century Europe, IFAs are increasingly replacing traditional manufacturing processes and traditional value chains. The production of quality content, the ability to innovate, narrate, conceive and empower has become our most valuable resource. All this must be done, supported, encouraged and protected. I supported the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. ‒ This is a joint report by the ITRE and CULT committees on the challenges and possibilities facing creative and cultural industries in the Union. Among other issues, it highlights the need for active advocacy policies, access to finance, counter-piracy, better participation of perpetrators and creators in benefit-sharing, promoting cross-sectoral cooperation and mobility, improving the working conditions of workers in the sector and the gender, etc. I voted in favour of the report, because I believe that these aspects are necessary in order to lay the foundations for a specific policy that will enable the sector to be valued and sustainable growth in the Member States as a whole.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I decided to abstain on the report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries because the text of the report has been written in a way that allows different interpretations, the details of which may be of great importance. In general, the wording was not very precise.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing. — Cultural and creative industries are an industry based on cultural values, individual creativity, skills and talent, with the potential to create prosperity and jobs on the basis of intellectual property value. Cultural and creative activities are based on the following sectors: architecture, archives and libraries, handicrafts, audiovisual works (including films, television, video games and multimedia), cultural heritage, design, creativity-based luxury industry and fashion, festivals, music, performing arts, books and publishing, radio and fine arts. The development, improvement and development of infrastructure, which is essential to support the creative industries in Europe, must be encouraged and supported, in particular by ensuring the development of high-speed broadband in rural areas and remote regions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries. In 21st -century Europe, with the transition to the digital economy, cultural and creative industries are increasingly replacing traditional manufacturing processes and traditional value chains. All around the world, the cultural and creative sector is considered a major and growing part of the global economy. Its importance as a generator of jobs and wealth is increasingly recognised, particularly so in the EU. Moreover, culture, not only in its traditional forms, but also through cultural and creative industries, can play a crucial role in strengthening international partnerships.  I voted in favour because I believe that the support of CCIs should be made a policy priority within the ESIFs, Horizon 2020, and the MFF as a whole. In the Horizon 2020 research programme and the structural funds, potential synergies existing between EU policies should be fully exploited. This would make it possible to effectively use the funding available under EU programmes and reach the goals they were designed for.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to develop a coherent, comprehensive and long-term framework for the cultural and creative sectors, and to provide adequate financing to this industry, with the aim of increasing its competitiveness in order to enable it to achieve its full potential in creating quality jobs and to support economic growth. To achieve this ambitious goal, the report proposes to adopt a harmonized definition of the concept of cultural and creative industries that takes data as a basis. In addition, the Community Executive is requested to establish a weighted copyright legal framework that carefully reflects the specificities of this sector. It also recommends its cooperation with other sectors to improve the interaction between SMEs and universities, so that the educational branches of creation and entrepreneurship are better integrated. In particular, it calls on both Member States and the Commission to open up the range of financial instruments available to small businesses by supporting public/private consortia. Aware of the need to promote this sector at European level, I supported this proposal with my vote.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains many positive points, it is a proposal that guarantees the participation of major economic actors. The development of cultural and creative industries depends on the fact that authors obtain fair remuneration for their work, but without this entailing any form of blocking the development of that industry and its services to the public. The report contains positive references to the inclusion of creators' rights, but it also guarantees the concentration of intellectual property rights through their financialization. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The creative economy across the UK employs nearly three million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis. The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is called to act appropriately to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rights holders receive fair remuneration for their works. I therefore voted in favour of this report as I believe that that the EU could take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because European art and culture covers 3 000 years of common cultural heritage, conveying knowledge and values and contributing to protecting tangible and intangible evidence of the artificial and natural world for present and future generations.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: This own-initiative report is positive in many respects. It proposes to encourage public aid, avoiding their requalification as state aid, for cultural heritage, to facilitate access to European financing in the cultural and creative sectors, and to ensure safer working conditions for cultural workers. So many positive aspects I support. I also welcome the request to the Commission to adopt appropriate measures to facilitate the availability of attractive lawful offers to works, including cross-border. Easy access (and therefore at a reasonable price) to creations is indeed the only effective way to combat piracy, as profit becomes too little to accept the risk of illegality. It is a pity that this is not explicitly stated in the text. This would have avoided the long laïus on the fight against piracy seen solely from a repressive angle, whereas prevention is the safest way to protect oneselF. I also regret that nowhere mention is made of the possibility of setting up designations of origin to enhance our craftsmanship and ensure that it is the craftsmen who benefit from the economic benefits. So I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The development of the so-called Cultural and Creative Industries, with the usual mercantile logic, points to the fact that these are not a factor of promotion of cultural and linguistic diversity, but rather a factor of cultural homogenization, of menorization and dilution of peculiarities and cultural and linguistic specificities. This 'European identity' will, at most, be the identity of a certain concept of 'Europe', which has nothing to do with the diversity and broad dialogue that the best European cultural tradition has established with other cultures. It is significant that we speak here of 'European' and 'regional' identity, but not about national identities, which is an essential factor of European identity. In essence, this conceals the deliberate intention to go further and further in a process of commodification of all cultural production, consistent with a vision of society, which we reject, in which everything is reduced to commodity. The conceptions here about the place of culture in society and cultural industries in culture are reductive and unacceptable. In some cases, they seem to be tailored even to the interests of large companies in the audiovisual and fashion sector.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: in writing. - The Commission should develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for the cultural and creative sectors in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the cultural and creative industries and enable them to develop their potential to create growth and quality jobs. unfold. Stronger action will be tackled against product piracy (such as films). It is underlined that the cultural and creative sectors, which are mainly composed of SMEs, operate in an ever-changing environment and is therefore faced with the challenge of developing and developing new business models to develop and develop new business models in order to develop market-driven solutions and to address new target groups. Searches for rightholders and non-transparent copyright legislation involves considerable administrative burdens, which is particularly burdensome for SMEs. Partnerships with the education sector will be strengthened in order to provide better opportunities for marginalised communities in disadvantaged neighbourhoods. The cultural and creative industries play a crucial role in Europe's reindustrialisation. It can boost growth and drive innovation. This is particularly interesting for digital technology. In addition, aid to SMEs is very positive. That is why I supported the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The creative economy across the UK employs nearly 3 million people and it has been one of the most resilient sectors during the economic crisis, indeed growing whilst other sectors shrank.  The report calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative package that deals with precarious contractual situations in the cultural and creative industries and will ensure respect for fundamental social and labour standards. The Commission is called on to act appropriately to reduce the value gap and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rights holders receive fair remuneration for their works. I therefore voted in favour of this report as I believe that that the EU could take a leading role in promoting the important positive impact that the creative sectors have across Europe, and promote policies that champion Europe’s most unique asset: its culture.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that there is a need to work together on the creative industry and it is very important to constantly share knowledge and best practice between Member States. I believe that the Commission should strengthen measures on fighting online piracy. I believe that digital platforms are a good and efficient means to provide wider access to cultural and creative works and offer also great opportunities for the CCS to develop new business models. I support the partnership with education, because I believe that it can contribute to stimulating a stronger learning environment and better integrate the disadvantaged and marginalised communities. I agree with the adoption of policies aimed at increasing the level of cultural participation among EU citizens, because at the moment in many Member States it is still very low.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries, appreciating the constant attention of the rapporteur for the SME sector. The report draws attention to the fact that cultural and creative industries are at the heart of a dual and delicate ecosystem between large, internationally competitive groups, and innovative SMEs and start-ups that are constantly renewing the area, preserving and promoting diversity, create jobs, but are sometimes fragile, especially in terms of access to markets and finance. The rapporteur stresses that research on rightholders and non-transparent copyright rules represent administrative burdens involving high costs and considerable effort, especially for SMEs working on a cross-border basis, recommending that establish a common pan-European database with all available information on rightholders for each sector in order to facilitate the granting of rights. The rapporteur also points out that the EU should not only regard culture from the perspective of the internal market, competition or trade policy, but also as an element of Europe's cooperation and development policy, taking into account the specific characteristics of the EU's cultural spectrum.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution because I believe that an innovative European research and cultural and creative industry is important. Among other things, because it contributes to the preservation of linguistic and cultural diversity. But exploiting the full potential of the cultural and creative sector remains a major challenge. This is why coordination is needed at all levels, namely at national, regional, local, but also at EU level. In this regard, the resolution proposes a number of measures focusing on 7 key areas: − collection of reliable statistics and data based on a comprehensive definition to raise awareness of the characteristics and needs of the sector, − monitoring developments in the sector in order to generate effective solutions for the cultural and creative industries, − promoting innovation and entrepreneurship in the cultural and creative sectors by facilitating cooperation with other sectors and policies (exchanges), − improving access to finance, promoting new business models, − using the toolbox existing at European level, − developing skills, including entrepreneurial skills, − addressing changing skills needs and addressing skilled labour shortages. It is important to realise that the importance of the cultural and creative sector is growing — the industry already employs 7.5% of people across the European economy today.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — The increasing influence of globalisation and digitisation has an increasing influence on traditional cultural and creative sectors. Traditional industries are based on the talent, skills and values of European nations. I believe there is a need to preserve these skills, as well as cultural and linguistic cultural diversity. To achieve this goal, we need to adapt to the current conditions and start linking culture and creative sectors with modern technology and other sectors of the current economy. I am therefore voting in favour of this report because I think we need a coherent policy at EU level to deal with this area for the long term.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. — I welcome a joint report by the ITRE and CULT committees on coherent EU policy for the culture and creative sectors.
