It is our next step in realizing the key role of these sectors in the EU's social and economic development. The report duly defines the potential for generating growth and employment in cultural and creative industries, while highlighting their significant impact in areas such as new business models, creativity and innovation and digitalisation and development skills in this regard. Particular emphasis in the report is also on building high-quality sector data resources that will enable better building future policies, support innovation and education and providing adequate funding within the framework of EU cultural industry support programmes and creative industries. In accordance with the recommendations outlined in the report, I consider it necessary to identify specific indicators to monitor and analyze the cultural, economic and social impact of the cultural and creative sectors. In this context, I also consider it desirable to study and pinpoint alternative sources of data acquisition to complement and improve official statistics, given that complex business models are often used in cultural and creative industries that can challenge traditional forms of analysis and financing.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the report. The report calls on the European Commission to develop long-term policies for the cultural and creative industries, including by developing a common legal basis. The PVV believes that the Dutch legislator should be perfectly able to develop a long-term policy for the creative industry. Subordinating the Dutch parliament to another legally binding agreement is undesirable and contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. “I supported the draft report on a coherent EU policy in the field of cultural and creative industries. The cultural and creative industries provide around 12 million jobs, as well as significant added value to GDP. Many of the cultural enterprises belong to so-called small and medium-sized enterprises or creative start-ups. That is why this industry needs to be promoted. It is necessary to ensure the protection of the works of authors so that they have additional incentive to create new values. Action must be taken against the illegal copying of creative works, and there is also a need to develop a coherent strategy to ensure that the cultural and creative industries continue to innovate. Finally, it is also essential to properly identify the other obstacles facing this industry. It is he who helps maintain cultural traditions and values. And in this spirit, there were also challenges addressed by the report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Ehler/Morgano report because I agree with the European Commission's call for an ambitious legislative package. I would like to stress as a starting point the European Parliament's proposal for the definition of the cultural and creative industry, which should serve as a basis for future policies on this matter. Among other appeals, I would like to highlight the request to the Commission to deal with the precarious contractual situation of the cultural and creative industry by ensuring that fundamental social and labour standards are respected. The Commission is also invited to take appropriate measures to reduce disparities and ensure that authors, creators, performers and rightholders receive fair remuneration for their works.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the EU's consistent policy report for cultural and creative industries. I think cultural and creative industries are the basis for creating the country's wealth and creating new jobs. This report proposal will establish a coherent and long-term industrial policy framework for cultural and creative industries and will include the development, promotion and protection of cultural and creative industries into the EU's strategic objectives and general policy priorities. Cultural and creative industries play a key role in preserving European cultural and linguistic diversity, strengthening the sense of belonging to European and regional identity, contributing to the transfer of knowledge and values, and preserve material and intangible European heritage for today and future generations. At the same time, they are a concrete tool for social cohesion by contributing to the EU economy in terms of jobs, investment, growth and innovation, and contribute significantly to European competitiveness globally. It is of strategic importance to support innovative European cultural and creative industries facing research as they can preserve linguistic and cultural diversity, pluralism and offer innovative and high-quality services, especially in the context of a converging and globalised market.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. — The own-initiative report aims to provide political indications for the development of Europe's cultural and creative industries. This need arises in response to the strong trend towards digitization of the market and the legislative initiatives related to it, such as that on content portability and in view, also, of announced modernization of the legal framework for intellectual property rights (copyright). However, the document aims to preserve existing business models, strongly oriented towards the protection of rights holders, through above all restrictive and sanctioning measures. It sets its sights on a mass culture model, essentially consumerist. No attention is given to the rights of creators, interpreters and performers as we at the M5S have proposed with our amendments. The needs of small and medium-sized market participants are not taken into account, and the attempt is not made to open up to an evolution of intellectual property rights, so that the model of cultural production does not depend solely on such revenue. In the light of all these considerations, I voted against this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted for the EU's Coherent Policy Report for the Cultural and Creative Industries. I support the report as it calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive, coherent and long-term legal framework for the cultural and creative sectors and provide adequate resources to increase competitiveness to enable the cultural and creative industries to fulfil its potential in terms of creating quality jobs and further development.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, it is about women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. They continue to be discriminated against in Moldova, Ukraine, Georgia and other countries in the eastern area. Women are poorly represented in politics, as in public administration. They find it very difficult to find a job, especially women who have children. The rate of violence against women also does not decrease at all, it is relatively high, and these stereotypes persist: the differences between men and women and the role of women in society — in the sense that women are considered to play a subordinate role to men. In addition, women, Roma girls are discriminated against for this reason, ethnically, and also very important, do not get to school. They spend much less time on their own education and, as such, remain outside society, in the margins of society, and all these things will influence their lives, they do not find jobs. Now, what the Union can do is play a much more important role in solving these problems through different conditionalities compared to the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Marek JUREK
text: . — Destroyed by decades of power by the Soviet nations of Eastern Europe, the European Union today urges to guarantee all “health and sexual” services with “safe and legal abortion and sex education” at the forefront. If you don't want Putin to use such documents against the democratic endeavours of these nations, then finally stop writing them. Unless you just redact them for Putin.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I would first like to thank Mariya Gabriel, my friend and colleague, for doing a very good job in this report. In line with the PPE Group, I voted in favour of it given its crucial consideration of the status of women’s rights in the Eastern Partnership States. Encompassing security, peace, stability and prosperity as a priority, we would hope that this report’s recommendations will redefine the framework surrounding the rights of women. In light of the considerable difference in the status of said rights in these states, we must continue our efforts to champion this area as a great priority. In doing so, we may continue to advance the principles of equality, development and peace as a cornerstone of all current and future policy. I suppose it was appropriate that, while we were discussing this topic and voting on it today, just prior to it we had the privilege of presenting the Sakharov Prize to two wonderful, inspirational women who have gone through an awful lot, but are still there showing the invincibility of women and the human spirit.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: in writing. — Today the European Parliament voted on a report concerning equality in the countries of the so-called Eastern Partnership. In large parts, a good report underlining the importance of these countries continuing to work on the issue of equality between women and men. In separate votes, however, I highlighted the Christian Democrats' and my view that the national legislation of these countries in respect of health policy does not constitute a barrier to approaching the EU, as the text of the report in some parts claimed.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ The Eastern Partnership (OP) is based on respect for international law, the fundamental values of democracy and human rights, so the importance of the importance of democracy and human rights must not be forgotten gender equality and women's rights. Even today, the weight of social discrimination and gender stereotypes is felt. The aim of the report is to stabilize relations between the European Union and its eastern neighbourhood and the emancipation of women and their active participation in social, political and economic life is fundamental to the realisation of the ongoing changes. For these reasons I voted positively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I think it gives a good picture of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights, both individual and social (although the rapporteur tried to censor references to fundamental rights before voting in plenary). I think, however, that a good diagnosis is not enough: the Union must reverse its migration, economic and social policies if it is to curb this difficult situation.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on the motion for a European Parliament resolution on women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries. One of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy in order to ensure security, peace and stability is the stabilisation of the EU's neighbourhood. Women play an important role in achieving this goal. The majority of those affected by armed conflicts are women and children. For this reason, we need to assess and recognise the role that women play in conflict resolution and peace-building. I am convinced that it is important to involve women more in peace negotiations and political change processes and to understand that greater gender equality would contribute to achieving the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the European Neighbourhood Policy. However, I cannot agree with some of the measures provided for in the document to ensure women's rights and gender equality, and I have therefore voted against some of the proposals, but they have been adopted by a majority. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the whole document.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States because I believe that the European Union should impose more active issues relating to gender equality through the various tools available to it within the framework of the European Union. Neighbourhood Policy

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The EU's “Eastern Partnership” policy concerns six post-Soviet states: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. This report, as its title suggests, is reductive towards all women and is a clear interference by the European institutions in the institutional, political, economic and social systems of the targeted countries: communitization of victims, with a preference for women from ethnic minorities (Roma) or LGBTI, urging to the establishment of a quota policy for women's access to positions of responsibility, particularly in politics, interference in diplomatic choices in partnership countries, heavy emphasis on the right to family reunification for women with families in the European Union, urging to implement the recommendations of the Beijing platform so that every woman has access to her “reproductive rights” including contraception and abortion... Based on gender theory, it calls on states to punish “insults and stigma” towards LGBTI people in public space or in public services. As these terms are very vague, one can legitimize an infringement of freedom of expression in the end. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I strongly support women’s rights and welcome criticism of countries that are lagging behind with women’s rights legislation, this report at the same time calls for yet more EU legislation and yet more powers to be taken away from Member States.  I firmly believe that individual Member States are best placed to ensure that women’s rights are protected and enhanced, free from the burden of EU meddling. I voted to abstain on this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I expressed my support for this report on women's rights in Eastern Partnership States. I believe that the situation in this area needs to be improved in these countries. Despite the inclusion of women's rights in the respective constitutions of these States, gender stereotypes remain important, not only preventing women's greater participation in the labour market and political life, but also opening the door to social acceptance of gender-based violence and violence undeclared domestic workers. Therefore, it is necessary for these countries to take immediate measures to strengthen equality between men and women in society.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. For security, peace, stability and prosperity of all, one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy is the stabilisation of the EU's neighbourhood. The report highlights the crucial role played by women in the areas of conflict resolution, peace-building and resolution of the special situation arising from the conflict. I therefore agree with the need to pay attention to the obstacles to women's empowerment and how greater gender equality would contribute to achieving the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the European Neighbourhood.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: This report is a real insult to women, reducing them to eternal victim status. It is also a brutal interference in the policy of the States concerned, as well as a pro-communitarianism and immigration report. I voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Eastern Partnership countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine) to take more measures to improve the situation of women's rights there. Indeed, their situation remains alarming because, in many cases, their rights are not respected, whether in terms of health or in the judicial and economic framework. The efforts to be made by these countries must be aimed at three objectives. First, women's participation in decision-making processes must be improved through equitable access to power and the elimination of discriminatory practices in the political arena. Secondly, their participation in the economic sector should be promoted by putting an end to stereotypes and discrimination that prevent them from developing in the economic sector. Finally, of course, all forms of violence against them must be condemned and put an end to, inter alia, by establishing effective protection mechanisms.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: In writing. ‒ Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and Belarus are six Eastern States that have collaborated with the European Union for years in different areas within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The Mariya Gabriel report, which I supported today, analyses the status of women's rights in these countries, highlighting the discrepancies between the statements of principle, enshrined in the charts constitutional, and the actual level of equality that comes in them guaranteed. While adopting a general approach, the text effectively emphasizes the continuing of heavy economic and social obstacles, which not only prevent women from participating in decision-making processes and politicians, but they create substantial impediments for their free entry into the labor market. Staying stereotypes, discrimination and gender violence are also linked to the failure to protect women's health and reproductive rights. The European Union has a duty to strengthen its action in this area by making the most of the instruments made available by the ENP to demand a change in policies in the partnership countries Eastern. We need to focus on developing a more careful culture in promoting rights and exploiting women's potential to invest in the future.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, as the report focuses on measures in the Eastern Partnership States (EAP) to promote women's participation in decision-making processes, economic participation, the fight against violence against women, the role of women in peaceful conflict resolution, examples of good practices and Union support in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Gender equality is recognized as a cross-cutting issue in the ENP's strategic priorities for 2014-2020, we consider this report positive as it is necessary to mainstream and integrate gender issues into relations with EAP as well. The EAP launched in 2009 is signed by the Union, its Member States and the EAP: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. With this report, APAs must take concrete measures to overcome the many barriers women face in all spheres of society, including politics, care and education, as women are absent from power structures and remain predominantly active in low-wage sectors due to legal and structural barriers.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States. I am in favour of the establishment of mandatory quotas on the lists of candidates. Eastern Partnership States are also encouraged to ratify the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence against Women as soon as possible, as none of the countries concerned had ratified it, and authorities are called upon to implement national strategies to combat violence against women women and to closely monitor their effective implementation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — I obviously opposed this report, which is a concentrate of ideological poncifs in fact insulting all women, but also a typical example of manifest interference by the European institutions in the institutional, political, economic and social systems of the countries concerned. It is clearly based on the famous gender theory that gender stereotypes should be deconstructed from school (paras. 6, 22). Women are, in a scandalous way, communarized and thus reduced to their gender: 'poor, migrant women from ethnic minorities' (recital I), all potential conditions for victims of shinned victims such as a rosary. I also oppose this urge to the establishment of a quota policy for women's access to positions of responsibility, particularly in politics (apparently women are not able to raise themselves to these positions by themselves through their skills and merit). Finally, this report is outrageously immigrationist since it uses women's rights to justify additional migratory overwhelming, along with the right to family reunification for women with families in the EU.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: In writing. ‒ While I share the importance of women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States and the need to end violence against women, this report presents objective criticalities that prompted me to prefer a vote of abstention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the situation of women's rights in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and Belarus, all States of the Eastern Association. In these countries, de facto inequality exists and remains, even though equality between men and women is guaranteed. Economic changes in recent years have adversely affected the situation of women, and these States are therefore urged to improve the situation of women's rights, to take measures to increase equality between men and women and to combat domestic and gender-based violence, including sexual harassment and trafficking in human beings. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. For security, peace, stability and prosperity of all, one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy is the stabilisation of the EU's neighbourhood. Women play a crucial role in achieving this goal. The Eastern Partnership was established in 2009 as a joint initiative of the European Union, its Member States and six partner countries in Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus — Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. As the Eastern Partnership is based on commitments to the principles of international law, fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights, the importance of gender equality and women's rights cannot be forgotten. In the reporting of the strategic priorities of the European Neighbourhood Policy for 2014-2020, gender equality was highlighted as an issue of all areas to be addressed and integrated into all relevant activities. Gender equality is also mentioned as a “promising new area of cooperation” in the statement of the latest Eastern Partnership Summit, approved by the Riga Eastern Partnership Summit held in 2015. And indeed, the empowerment of women and their active participation in social, political and economic life is crucial to achieve the process of change.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. - Through my amendments, I have sought to emphasize the need for a better position of women in the labour market and the possibility of harmonizing private and business. Women are often the ones who neglect their education and work for the sake of the family and therefore it is necessary to strengthen the network of childcare institutions, but also care institutions for the elderly and the powerless women often take care of. I emphasized the importance of unions and various programs to strengthen the economic role of a woman. Amendments relating to LGBTI people are generally acceptable. It is important to condemn attacks and discrimination and require states to develop a strategic approach to combating discrimination against LGBTI people. A lot of us stressed people smuggling and prostitution. These are really burning problems. I also want to underline the importance of combating domestic violence through an organised approach through the training of police officers, medical staff, transparent court processes and the importance of safe houses. Domestic violence is not something a “woman deserves” or something that must be endure to keep the family together. It is imperative to empower women to report violence to the police. Also, care for women's sexual and reproductive health and the availability of modern means of contraception should be included in the report.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: This report makes interesting proposals concerning, inter alia, trafficking in women, violence against women and child labour in these States. On the other hand, it interferes far too much in the diplomatic fields of these states, urges the establishment of quotas for women in positions of responsibility, conceptualises the communitization of certain groups such as Roma or LGBTI women, and finally advocates some form of migration to the EU from these states. Therefore, I voted against this text.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because of how it highlighted many of the positive and negative aspects of the rights of women in Eastern Partnership states. It looked at the participation of women in decision-making processes, economic participation of women, combating violence against women, highlighting women’s role in peaceful resolution of conflicts, etc. It also highlighted the difficulties still facing women in these countries and the work that needs to be done in order to counteract this. The report remained quite progressive despite the split votes tabled which took away from some of the more progressive elements of it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: — Stabilization of its neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the EU foreign policy and European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. A crucial role in achieving that goal is played by women. The Eastern Partnership is based on respect for the principles of international law, the fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. importance of gender equality and women's rights. Despite both being recognized in the Constitutions and legal systems of all Eastern Partnership countries, social discrimination and gender stereotypes are still present which prevent greater inclusion of women in the labour market and political life and foster the continued social acceptance of domestic violence. There is therefore a need for greater involvement of women in peace negotiations and political transitions and an improvement in the position that women's rights and gender equality occupy in political priorities of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: The EU's Eastern Partnership policy concerns six post-Soviet states: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. This report represents a clear infringement of the European Union in the institutional, political, economic and social systems of the countries concerned. Admittedly, the text denounces all the violence against women, including trafficking in human beings for sexual exploitation or violence against women of all kinds. But this report sets out a typology of women to be defended as a priority, especially those from ethnic minorities or those from the LGBTI group. It is also called for the establishment of affirmative action policies for women in the countries concerned through a quota system and to promote family reunification. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - The Eastern Partnership is a joint initiative of the European Union, its Member States and six partner countries in Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus, based on a commitment to fundamental human rights, democracy, the rule of law, of great importance and respect for gender equality and women's rights. Thus, women's low participation in political structures of power, be they executive or parliamentary, was reported, mainly due to discriminatory practices and gender stereotypes. These types of associations of traits can limit the personal and professional development of women, hinder the potential of women, and also lead to various forms of discrimination in the labor market. Domestic violence is also a problem that a significant percentage of women face. Between 7% and 25% of women (by country) were victims of domestic violence. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that only by promoting gender equality and respecting fundamental human rights can we speak of a real and prosperous democracy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, because there are still deep criticalities in the field of equal rights for men and women. There are still thorny, unresolved issues, such as the blight of “trafficking,” involving thousands of women or the difficult plight of Roma women. Women's participation in political life is weak in Eastern Partnership countries. Profound institutional changes are still needed to combat discrimination and violence and promote political participation and visibility of women in Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on the participation of women in decision-making processes, economic participation of women, violence against women, women’s role in peaceful resolution of conflicts and examples of best practices and EU support in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy.  It considers that women still face significant barriers to participation in Eastern Partnership States (16% of elected MPs on average) and calls for them to take concrete steps to overcome the many barriers facing women in all areas of society including politics, care and education. Despite their higher levels of education in all Eastern Partnership countries, women are significantly and noticeably absent from the structures of power and remain active predominantly in low-paying sectors because of legal and structural barriers. Women also suffer from a gender pay gap that can be as wide as 50% in some sectors.  For highlighting these concerns, I voted in favour of the report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. UKIP agreed with the sentiments of the report which condemned sexual violence, rape, trafficking, child labour, the lack of rights for LGBTI and discrimination in these (non-EU) eastern European countries. However we could not support legitimising and expanding EU action on the international stage. The report called for gender quotas in politics; expansion of EU programmes and funding through Erasmus and Horizon2020 to these countries; and greater involvement of EU agencies in these countries. These issues should be addressed bilaterally between elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The report highlights the barriers to women’s empowerment and how greater gender equality would help reaching the Eastern Partnership (EaP) and European Neighbourhood (ENP) objectives. Women remain remarkably absent from the political structures of power, whilst in the economic field, despite the fact that women are generally more educated than men, the situation is also not very encouraging. The gender pay gap also remains an issue.  But the report also includes examples of good practices, relevant and successful projects to promote women’s rights and gender equality in the EaP states. I believe that gender equality is an area which would greatly benefit from a reinforced cooperation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership states. It is important that women’s rights and gender equality are put higher in the Eastern Partnership political priorities. I fully support these principles, but I could not vote in favour of this report as I cannot support abortion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: In writing. ‒ The emancipation of women and their active participation in social, political and economic life is fundamental to the realization of the ongoing changes, but the weight of the burden of the current change is still felt social discrimination and gender stereotypes. In the OP countries, in fact, the presence of women in the political structures of power (both executive and legislative) is still very little and it applies to business. In addition, those countries are identified as countries of origin or transit of human trafficking, where the majority of victims are women and children. Examples of good practice, relevant and successful projects for the promotion of women's rights and gender equality in the OP States are included in the report.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe we need to pay attention to women’s rights in the countries in our neighbourhood, countries with which we cooperate quite closely. I am also worried about the concerns raised in the text and would call on the countries to focus more on women’s issues. I would like to point out one issue here. Although I am convinced there is a case for having women participating more in political and economic life, it should not be pushed, as the resolution suggests, through instruments such as obligatory quotas.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: In writing. ‒ The stabilisation of Eastern European countries, their economic and social well-being are linked inderogably to the role of women, respect for their rights and dignity. Despite the fact that women are more educated than men on average, their presence in national representative bodies and in leadership roles still remains extremely limited in the States of the Eastern Partnership. Discrimination of women at work, persistence of stereotypes about their social roles, and the difference in pay between men and women continue to be worrying. Moreover, it is particularly alarming that the child labour phenomenon reported by the report in countries such as Georgia, Moldova and Azerbaijan is particularly alarming. And the current economic crisis is likely to worsen the situation and perpetuate the cycle of poverty and child exploitation. Europe can do much to stop this tragic phenomenon, especially through an effective neighbourhood policy and appropriate instruments of cooperation. For these reasons, I considered voting in favour of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are abstained from the report, which contains several ambiguous elements.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States. It is obvious that we must support any initiative aimed at protecting women's rights and equality. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: In writing. ‒ As a member of the delegations to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly and the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Association Committee, this report can only be proud of the work it has done, as well as spurring me as much as still needed. In fact, in March, the first meeting of the Euronest Women's Forum was held in March because of the necessary implementation of women's presence in decision-making processes, since moment we know how women are often excluded and hampered by it. Therefore, it is essential to introduce equal standards of access to power through the exchange of best practices with the countries of the partnership, in the light not only of the different cultural substrates that characterize them, but rather the profound economic changes undergone which make it a priority to strengthen economic participation with national plans. The role of women is, undoubtedly, crucial in ensuring peace given the involvement in humanitarian assistance, and the decisiveness of security, stability and prosperity. For this to come about, it is vital to review existing legislation to eradicate the abuse and violence of which women are victims.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on rights of women in the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: The Eastern Partnership, launched by the Prague Declaration (2009), is one of the main instruments of the European Neighbourhood Policy and pursues objectives of respect for international law and the values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. In this context, the area of cooperation for equality between men and women and the protection of women's rights is promising, in line with the Riga Declaration (2015). I welcome the fact that the principle of gender equality is enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of the six partner countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus, but I recall the way we still have to go in terms of women's participation in politics (only 14% of Ministers and 16% of Members ), in enterprises (10% in employers' organisations and 15% in trade unions) and pay justice (gap between 24% and 50%). I share the concern at the regrettable phenomenon of violence against women, particularly domestic violence. Their eradication is a civilizational imperative. I would stress the urgency of cooperation to combat trafficking in human beings (mostly women), considering the fact that these countries are used as origin or transit for this crime. I therefore support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report, although I am critical of a number of individual points. I welcome the fact that, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, we can influence the role of women and equality, and to combat violence against women and children. But demands for full access to abortion or mandatory quotas for the establishment of electoral lists go decisively too far.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. UKIP agreed with the sentiments of the report which condemned sexual violence, rape, trafficking, child labour, the lack of rights for LGBTI and discrimination in these (non-EU) eastern European countries. However we could not support legitimising and expanding EU action on the international stage. The report called for gender quotas in politics; expansion of EU programmes and funding through Erasmus and Horizon2020 to these countries; and greater involvement of EU agencies in these countries. These issues should be addressed bilaterally between elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Lara COMI
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because its main purpose is to highlight obstacles to women's emancipation and how greater gender equality could contribute the achievement of the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the ENP. Examples of good practice and successful projects to promote women's rights and gender equality in Eastern Partnership States are also included in the report. The subject of analysis is also the EU's support in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy, to which some recommendations are addressed in this regard. The report also assesses the situation of women in different areas, which are of paramount importance to the PPE Group: women's participation in decision-making processes, economic participation of women, violence against women, the role of women in peaceful resolution of conflicts.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which deals with the situation of women's rights in the six countries of the Union's Eastern Association, recognizes that although women's rights are formally recognized by all the constitutions of these states and gender equality is regarded as a strategic priority in the European Neighbourhood Policy, women continue to suffer discrimination and high rates of gender-based violence. It expresses concern at its low public representation and calls for concrete steps to overcome the barriers faced by women on a daily basis, such as the wage and pension gap that reached up to 50 per cent in some sectors. Despite her positive statements, the rapporteur on the right does not go far enough in terms of the recognition of sexual and reproductive rights for women. The text is also part of the European Neighbourhood Policy and its financial instruments, interference in the internal affairs of third countries and the promotion of regime change which I reject. For these reasons, despite your good intentions, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. - Neighbourhood stability is a major objective of the European Union's foreign policy, with a direct impact on the citizens of the bloc, who must enjoy security, peace, stability and prosperity. The Eastern Partnership was launched in 2009 as an initiative of the European Union and six partner countries from Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. This pact is based on respect for international law, the fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, but the importance of gender equality and women's rights must not be forgotten. Women's rights and gender equality are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all countries signatory to the Eastern Partnership. However, they are found less represented in high functions than men. Only 14% of the positions of ministers and 16% of the seats in Parliament are occupied by them. I voted for the promotion of women's rights and gender equality in all the Eastern Partnership Member States, but also for their ascension on the Union's list of political priorities.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — Stabilisation of EU neighbouring countries is one of the most important objectives of its foreign policy and European Neighbourhood Policy — one of the tools is the Eastern Partnership established in 2009. When the strategic priorities of the European Neighbourhood Policy were announced for years 2014-2020, emphasis was placed on gender equality as a cross-sectional issue. Gender equality was also considered a promising new area of cooperation in the declaration from the last Eastern Partnership summit. I share the stated position that women's empowerment and their active participation in social, political and economic life are in fact a prerequisite for change. Unfortunately, there are indications that social discrimination and the functioning of gender stereotypes are still common occurrences in countries that are signatory to the Eastern Partnership. The existence of stereotypes not only prevents more inclusion of women in the job market and participation in political life, but also paves the way for social acceptance of gender-based violence and non-reporting of domestic violence. The aim of the report is not only to enumerate shortcomings and mistakes in protecting women's rights, but also to highlight obstacles to strengthening their position, and to indicate that greater gender equality would help meet the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and European Neighbourhood Policy. On horizontal issues, I fully support the stated theses, but nevertheless, ideological and worldview records appear in the document which raise doubts. Accordingly, I abstained from voting on this document.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Each and every partner state needs to safeguard women’s rights and promote gender equality. The rapporteur identified that even though the countries do guarantee equality between women and men, de facto inequality still persists and thus the EU needs to impose more actively gender equality and gender mainstreaming through the many useful instruments of its Neighbourhood Policy. I voted in favour of this report as social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes are preventing greater inclusion of women in the labour market and participation in political decision-making processes. As in all other votes, I voted against any references to abortion.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support women’s rights across the European Union and I was therefore pleased to vote in favour of a report which covers a range of important issues.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - Many women in rural areas, who have no other possibilities, tend to accept low-paid jobs in agriculture, often without formal declarations and no social security rights whatsoever. I believe that the Eastern Partnership states must find the best solutions to eliminate gender inequalities in agriculture, which would certainly contribute to ensuring equal access to jobs for women and men, as well as pay equal for work of equal value.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — This own-initiative report examines the role of women in the objective of stabilizing the European Neighbourhood Policy. In particular, the report assesses the situation of women in a number of critical areas such as women's participation in decision-making processes, women's economic participation, violence against women, and the role of women in the peaceful resolution of conflicts. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. UKIP agreed with the sentiments of the report which condemned sexual violence, rape, trafficking, child labour, the lack of rights for LGBTI and discrimination in these (non-EU) eastern European countries. However we could not support legitimising and expanding EU action on the international stage. The report called for gender quotas in politics; expansion of EU programmes and funding through Erasmus and Horizon2020 to these countries; and greater involvement of EU agencies in these countries. These issues should be addressed bilaterally between elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in Eastern Partnership States. The Eastern Partnership, launched in 2009, is a joint initiative between the Union, its Member States and Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. Equality between women and men is one of the strategic priorities of the European Neighbourhood Policy for 2014-2020. In particular, I call on the partner countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus to ratify the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and to put in place national strategies. Finally, efforts must be made to increase the involvement of women in the peaceful resolution of conflicts and in decision-making processes.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because as a woman I believe that gender equality should be one of the main objectives promoted by the European Union's foreign policy in the countries of the European Union Eastern Partnership - in Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus. It is necessary to promote the role of women in the private and public sector of civil society, with zero tolerance of domestic violence and with support for equal opportunities in life professional, eliminating any form of discrimination against women.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: The Eastern Partnership aims to strengthen political association and economic integration between the Union and six Central European countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. This cooperation requires the sharing of fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights, but also gender equality. While the legal systems of the partnership countries enshrine women's rights, unfortunately, practices remain discriminatory. Women are underrepresented in the political sphere, with only 14% ministers and 16% parliamentarians, and in the economic sphere, the pay gap varies between 24 and 50% depending on the country concerned. Over the past five years, €103 million has been allocated to 121 projects and programmes to promote gender equality in the European neighbourhood, including €5 million for the Women in Business programme in Eastern Partnership countries. The Union must continue to promote gender equality among its partners. This implies, for example, technical assistance and sharing of good practices in the area of governance and public administration reform.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The text concerns six States: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. He draws inspiration from gender theory: it calls on states to punish “insults and stigma” towards LGBTI people in public space or in public services. It also calls for specific protection for a certain category of women: poor, migrant women, ethnic minority women. Some points, such as denunciation of trafficking in human beings, are positive. Nevertheless, we cannot endorse the unacceptable interference carried out by this text in the policies of sovereign States.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report for several reasons. Invitation for ratification of any international treaty is not the EU's business and therefore, in principle, I do not believe that we should do it here either (concerning the Istanbul Convention). We know that in the constitutions of the Eastern Partnership countries, women's rights and gender equality are well enshrined. In addition, the report calls for more traditionally male professions to be opened to women, which, for me, is not a proper step in the development of our society and I would not invite the Eastern Partnership countries to implement it, nor is the idea of quotas in political governance that is suggests that it would give women a greater level playing field — that for me is not the right approach. Of course, the report also offers some useful recommendations, which I cannot condemn, and looking for ways to eliminate gender stereotypes must be our goal.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - Combating violence against women, social discrimination and gender stereotypes continue to pose major challenges for the EU and its eastern neighbours. This report does not, however, aim to list the shortcomings and weaknesses in the protection of women's rights; it does not include the active participation of women in trade unions, the inclusion of Roma minors in education, and adopts policies for combating all forms of discrimination based on sexual orientation by supporting LGBTM and supporting an even greater link between partner countries and EU bodies and programmes, such as Horizon 2020, Creative Europe, COSME and Erasmus+. The report also calls for greater participation by women in peace negotiations and political transition processes.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: in writing. — The report as a whole is an important step in ensuring equal conditions. A strong contradiction is the issue of quota of female candidates and representatives. I think it is not the right path because it undermines the long-term work done by the public institutions. Such shortcuts do not guarantee a long-term egalitarian society but are merely a clingy supranational mechanism, a type of pox-policy that risks becoming counterproductive.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Women continue to be extremely absent from political power structures, both at the executive and parliamentary level, mainly because of discriminatory practices. Women account for an average of 14% of ministers and 16% of MEPs. In the economic field, despite the fact that women are generally better qualified than men, they represent 10% of the members of employers' organisations and 15% of trade union members. The gender pay gap is generally considerable, but there are significant discrepancies between the Eastern Partnership countries (between 24% and 50%), while horizontal and vertical segregation of the labour market is very sharp. Combating violence against women is a challenge shared by the EU and its eastern neighbours. Statistics on reported cases show that between 7% and 25% of women were victims of domestic violence, but most cases remain unreported. The report highlights the obstacles to the emancipation of women and how greater equality between men and women can contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the ENP.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The report states that equality between men and women is enshrined in the constitutions of the countries that form part of the so-called Eastern Partnership (EU Member States, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia and the Republic of Moldova) and their legal systems. All these countries have ratified most of the relevant international conventions in this area. Despite this, there are serious trampled on women's rights, which the report lists. The report calls for intensification of the fight against discrimination and the implementation of existing legislation; defends the role of education - kindergartens, pre-school, elementary, secondary and university education - accessible to all; stresses the need to set targets for the elimination of child labour; stresses the need to set targets for the elimination of child labour; stresses the need to combat gender-based domestic violence - sexual harassment, forced surrogate maternity, trafficking in human beings for the purpose of sexual exploitation, prostitution; calls for the specific protection of women and girls seeking asylum. Among other aspects that we support and value. But the report also contains less positive aspects, some omissions and aspects with which we disagree. It should be noted that nothing is said about the situation in Ukraine, the coup that the EU supported and the supportive fascist forces that have settled in the government of Ukraine and which have brought it back decades, in this area too.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. — This report focuses on the situation of women and their rights in the Eastern Partnership countries, including Armenia, Azerbaijan, Moldova, Ukraine, Belarus and Georgia. Despite the fact that women's rights are enshrined and protected in the individual constitutions of these countries, the reality is often different, and social and economic discrimination based on gender persists. Gender equality is an area for which strengthening cooperation between the European Union and the Eastern Partnership states would be of great benefit. Most of the problems are inherently common to the European Union and its eastern neighbours, and the aim of this report is to contribute to increasing the importance of women's rights and gender equality in the Eastern Partnership's political priorities ranking.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain from the report because, despite many positive points and a more than shareable purpose, there are still too important steps left and the report tries to fit in needlessly in the Russian-Ukrainian affair.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - Combating violence against women, social discrimination and gender stereotypes continue to pose major challenges for the EU and its eastern neighbours. However, this report does not aim to list the shortcomings and weaknesses in the protection of women's rights. On the contrary, it includes the active participation of women in trade unions, the inclusion of Roma minors in education, adopts policies to combat all forms of discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation by supporting LGBTM and advocating an even greater association between countries partners with EU institutions and programmes such as Horizon 2020, Creative Europe, COSME and Erasmus+. The report also calls for greater participation by women in peace negotiations and political transition processes. For the above reasons I am voting against the report and the proposals of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Even though women’s rights and gender equality are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all six Eastern Partnership countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine), social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes remain important and prevent greater inclusion of women in the labour market and participation in political decision-making processes. Also violence against women and the lack of sexual and reproductive health and rights remains a problem. The EU needs to impose more actively gender equality and gender mainstreaming through the many useful instruments of its Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. — The challenges facing Eastern Partnership countries in the area of women's rights are generally common to those faced by the European Union. In different proportions, the achievement of equality between men and women must be the subject of resolute efforts on both sides, in order to meet the foundations and objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the European Neighbourhood Policy for Security, Peace, Stability and Prosperity. The report strongly emphasizes the promotion of the wider participation of women in political life, including with a view to promoting democratic transitions. In addition, the report provides an overview of women's rights in different fields and proposes areas for closer cooperation, for example, in the fight against trafficking in human beings, including involving European agencies such as Europol. Finally, the report also calls for, in addition to the cross-cutting approach to gender equality, specific objectives be set within the framework of the Eastern Partnership, taking into account the principle of differentiation and within the framework of a quantified approach based on harmonised data collection and the use of the equality index of a kind developed by EIGE.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: in writing. - In cooperation with Eastern Partnership countries, it is important to strengthen gender equality.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. I agreed with the sentiments of the report which condemned sexual violence, rape, trafficking, child labour, the lack of rights for LGBTI and discrimination in these (non-EU) eastern European countries. However, I could not support legitimising and expanding EU action on the international stage. The report called for gender quotas in politics; expansion of EU programmes and funding through Erasmus and Horizon2020 to these countries; and greater involvement of EU agencies in these countries. These issues should be addressed bilaterally between elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: In writing. ‒ Under the Eastern Partnership, the issues related to gender discrimination come fully into the heritage of European law on which we must all work and seek continuously improve our performance. A short time ago, I dealt with just one particular aspect of this relentless political and social battle, namely the inclusion in full and equal rights of women in the labour market of agricultural sector. I voted in favour of this report because I think it correctly addresses the problem of gender stereotypes, which still block women by preventing them from accessing both management positions and they deserve both at pay in line with that of men. So let us deprive the whole of European society of a fundamental contribution to our business innovation and forget the promise of social equality and non-discrimination behind the Eastern Partnership and the European Union itself.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: This own-initiative report addresses the subject of women's rights in six states: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The report provides an alarmist assessment of the status of women in some countries, where women, but also children, are frequently trafficked by local mafias: surrogates, child labour, pimping... Faced with this truly worrying condition, some MEPs propose solutions that are not, by prioritizing the protection of LGBTI or Roma communities, calling for quotas for women in elected office or by proposing the right to family reunification for women with a family member in a State of the European Union. I have, of course, voted against this report, which denies all sovereignty.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, as the report focuses on measures in the Eastern Partnership States (EAP) to promote women's participation in decision-making processes, economic participation, the fight against violence against women, the role of women in peaceful conflict resolution, examples of good practices and Union support in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Gender equality is recognized as a cross-cutting issue in the ENP's strategic priorities for 2014-2020, we consider this report positive as it is necessary to mainstream and integrate gender issues into relations with EAP as well. The EAP launched in 2009 is signed by the Union, its Member States and the EAP: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. With this report, APAs must take concrete measures to overcome the many barriers women face in all spheres of society, including politics, care and education, as women are absent from power structures and remain predominantly active in low-wage sectors due to legal and structural barriers.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. - As rapporteur for the Committee on Social Affairs of the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, I voted for this report because we need to get involved in improving the market situation female work in these states. Firstly, we need to focus on gender equality as a common value seen from the EU-Eastern Partnership perspective. Secondly, concrete EU-EPA cooperation in the field is a priority to achieve the desired results. Most of the challenges are of the same nature for the EU and its eastern neighbours, but a political boost can help promote women's rights and gender equality within the political priorities of the Eastern Partnership. All EaP countries have developed strategies, programmes or action plans to improve the situation of women. The EU should help partners implement commitments in line with these strategies and national targets, as well as provide expertise to adjust labour legislation on gender equality and improve the participation of women in the labour market and in decision-making process.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states. Stabilisation of its neighbourhood is central to the European Union’s foreign policy; ensuring security, peace and prosperity and affirming women’s rights and freedoms is a vital part of this.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - We have voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Neighbourhood States. There are many positive references such as ensuring women's participation in trade unions, combating gender discrimination at work, emphasising the need for affordable childcare services and clear parental leave provisions , calls on authorities to strengthen the network of quality care facilities for the elderly and dependants, calls for equal access to education for all children, a special emphasis on the education of rural girls, and urges the intensification of actions against crime of human trafficking on the basis of the Scandinavian model. However, the text on some points is inspired by excessive interference in the internal affairs of other states with mandates for specific actions. For example, it promotes quotas. The report also disregards the fact that gender equality cannot be understood in the context of the neoliberal policies promoted by the EU in the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report that assesses the situation of Women’s rights in the six Eastern Partnership countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and Belarus, which are covered by the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes are still widespread across these countries, preventing greater inclusion of women in the labour market and participation in political decision-making processes. More worryingly, the high levels of violence against women and the lack of access to sexual and reproductive health remains challenging. Women’s Rights and gender equality issues must be kept on the political agenda.  We must do more to support grassroots women’s organisations and civil society, which are best positioned to reach out to local populations as well as help to raise awareness.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU needs to impose gender equality and gender mainstreaming more actively through the many useful instruments of its Neighbourhood Policy. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the Rights of Women in the Eastern Partnership States because I believe that in the countries concerned, in order to strengthen women's rights, it is also necessary to work towards general political and economic stability, in addition to respect human rights. The key points of this Report, which I voted for, are the importance of involving women in decision-making processes, engaging women in peace talks and political transitions, including women's involvement in economic life and certainly reducing violence against them. In the Member States of the Eastern Partnership, vertical and horizontal segregation in terms of jobs for women in the labour market remains deeply rooted in cultural and social norms, which needs to be worked on by raising the level of public awareness of the issue.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — While the report accurately denounces trafficking in women, violence against women and the problem of child labour, it is too many negative inclinations. In addition to the willingness of the European institutions to interfere are the communitisation of women and their reduction to the status of perpetual victims, as well as the defence of gender theory, so many factors weighing all their weight on the wrong side. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries. The Eastern Partnership is a European policy aimed at concluding agreements with countries such as Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The report calls for a better fight against discrimination in the economic sphere, since in some countries women have very little access to high-ranking positions. At the societal level, the text calls for strengthening efforts to combat violence against women. For a more effective approach, the report calls for the use of the European Neighbourhood Instrument to support civil society initiatives, which are best able to raise public awareness on these issues. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which aims to give women's rights and gender equality more importance in Eastern Partnership policies. The European Neighbourhood Policy aims to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. Women's rights must be fully part of the priorities of this framework. While these rights are well integrated into the Constitutions and legal systems of all partnership countries, social discrimination and gender stereotypes remain important. The text outlines several recommendations for achieving gender equality and strengthening women's rights in various areas.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report. Equal treatment of women in politics, economy and religion is the basis of an enlightened and humanist society and is therefore not negotiable. In the rapporteur's view, there is still a striking absence of women in the political power structures of the Eastern Partnership countries. I believe that the EU is going beyond its competences here and interferes with the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Stabilisation of its neighbourhood and ensuring security are the key tenets of EU foreign policy instruments. Peace, prosperity and affirming women’s rights and freedoms is a vital part of this. I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, as I support the initially good and important approach of Mrs Mariya Gabriel's draft report. Violence against women and domestic violence is a problem in the Eastern European countries that must be tackling offensively. However, the final report leaves this headline objective on many points and strikes areas that are definitely unrelated to the situation of women. I cannot and will not support this issue.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — I have decided to support the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States. While I believe that the Eastern Partnership States have so much important work ahead of them, I believe, however, that it is necessary to improve the situation for women's rights in the East partnerships, especially in connection with profound economic changes and economic uncertainty, which have had a negative impact on the economic situation of women and have led to shortcomings in their factual equality. In doing so, I condemn the use of sexual violence against women and girls as a weapon of war, including mass rape, sexual slavery, prostitution, persecution on the basis of belonging to a certain sex, including human trafficking, sex tourism, and I stress the need to fight enforced marriages as defined by the United Nations, including child marriages/ marriages at an early age, and I urge eastern neighbours to consistently oppose any form of exploitation and abuse of women through surrogacy.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since we share the same values with our Eastern European partners and therefore I am highly concerned when these values are not fully respected. Unreported domestic violence, under-representation of women in political life, and persistence of gender stereotypes are cross-cutting issues in all EaP states addressed in the present report.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. - I support the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. With regard to the participation of women in decision-making, it should be noted that the lack of women in the power structures of the Eastern Partnership countries is significant and tangible. I believe that there is a need to intensify the exchange of good practices in relation to the promotion of women's political participation in decentralised institutions and local authorities. Sustainable results are best achieved under the leadership of political parties, and therefore the key role of European political parties and their women's sections must be emphasised. I welcome the allocation of funds for initiatives related to combating violence against women and girls, ensuring longer-term access to effective services for victims and survivors. I call for deeper cooperation between the Eastern Partnership countries, on the one hand, and EU agencies and Member States' law enforcement authorities, on the other, in order to combat trafficking in human beings, which also ranks among the most profitable activities of organised crime, and in order to break down criminal networks.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. — I support the resolution prepared by Mariya Gabriel “Women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States”. As history teaches, the transformation of developing countries is carried out with the important complicity of women, but later, after prosperity, their rights are disregarded. Women's rights and equality are a significant issue of the European Union's social and economic policy. The non-discrimination claims therefore arise in third country agreements with the EU. It is important that women's rights are suitably high on the political agenda in our eastern neighbours, and work in this respect takes place in parallel with the implementation of policies on the economy or finance. The report highlights that, while all Eastern Partnership states have prepared strategies and plans to improve women's situation, their presence in public spaces and decision-making positions is very modest. There is also a prevalent “double load” model of women, who, after professional work, devote themselves to housework to a disproportionately greater degree than men. The report condemns the publicity of gender stereotypes in which a woman performs a subordinate role and which negatively affect women's educational paths and career paths. I also supported numerous references in the report on women's reproductive rights and the need for legislative affirmation action that would help change the situation.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: In writing. ‒ Since 2009 the Eastern Partnership aims to stabilise the neighbourhood of the European Union in order to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. I believe that gender equality and recognition of women's rights play a crucial role in achieving this objective and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report. Unfortunately, we have found that the situation in the field of women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries must be improved: women are significantly absent from power structures and Although they boast higher levels of education, they are mainly employed in low-remuneration sectors. We have therefore stressed the role of education in eliminating stereotypes around the role of women and eliminating discriminatory practices, highlighting the need for targeted support and tutoring for women entrepreneurs, who often do not have access to credit or business networks. Furthermore, we reiterated that the fight against violence against women is a challenge shared by the EU and the countries of its eastern neighbourhood, with particular attention to the need to create effective protection mechanisms for women engaged in the defence of human rights.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, the countries of the Eastern Partnership (EaP states) continue to be countries of origin, and in some cases transit and destination countries, for human trafficking of women and young girls. Alas, most of these women have been sexually exploited and have become victims of mass rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution and sex tourism. Therefore, I voted in favour because the EU should place the fight against human trafficking and sexual exploitation of women at the core of development cooperation with EaP states. Taking a broader perspective to protect human rights, particularly women’s rights, in EaP states, the EU should increase its support for female entrepreneurship, women’s empowerment and education.  Last but not least, I call on EaP states to protect women from human trafficking and sexual exploitation by increasing efforts to investigate and prosecute human/sex traffickers and by actively supporting NGOs that provide rehabilitation and social reintegration to victims.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — Gender equality is one of our strategic priorities for the period 2014-2020. According to statistics, women still have a small proportion of presence in political power structures; in the economic sphere, despite being more educated than men, they represent the 10 per cent of members of the governing bodies of entrepreneurs associations and 15 per cent of union members; the pay gap continues to be very high; and between 7 and 25 per cent of women was at least once a victim of domestic violence. The European Union now aims to create a stable situation in neighbouring countries, promoting security and peace, and women are an essential part of this process, which will only be achieved by making possible their emancipation. Women's rights and gender equality are recognized in the political and legal system of Eastern Partnership States, yet serious discrimination and stereotypes are evident that prevent the inclusion of woman in society and that encourage domestic violence. For these reasons, the purpose of the report is to list the obstacles to the emancipation of women and present a number of recommendations and good examples essential to achieving the objectives of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, dedicated to the issue of women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries, which is part of the true logic of partnership and cooperation ever closer between, on the one hand, the European Union and its Member States and, on the other hand, the countries of the Eastern Partnership — Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The challenges that these countries face in terms of women's rights are close to those we face in the European Union, in each of our Member States. There is, however, the challenge of human trafficking networks, a source of supply to modern slavers. We must therefore have a strategic vision and a clearer commitment that crosses all aspects, all policies of the Eastern Partnership, and making advancing women's rights a political priority in our dialogue with the countries of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. — Under the guise of good intentions or universal ideas (denouncing the sexual exploitation of women, combating violence against women, protecting women and their born or unborn children), this report is only a terrible Trojan horse for immigration, LGBT claims or the Roma issue.
