The ideology of gender is insinuated everywhere and gangrenes this text, moreover profoundly interfering with the policy of the targeted States. Finally, women are mentioned only under the prism of eternal victims, which is reductive or even totally insulting to them. I voted strongly against it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report is to assess women's rights in the Eastern European Association. I believe that the text is very positive in directly addressing issues that I find fundamental, such as the right to abortion and the prohibition of prostitution, as well as the need to introduce legislative measures to ensure women's equal access to the labour market. Nonetheless, some interference references and the fact that the Union itself is far from applying the standards defended here have led me to one abstention.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. ‒ The report highlights the importance of gender equality and women's rights as pillars for the achievement of the objectives of the Eastern Partnership, which was launched in 2009 and comprising the European Union, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. The text recalls that gender discrimination remains a considerable scourge in the Eastern Partnership countries. Thus, we still regret today the differences in access to the labour market or participation in political life. I vote in favour because we are facing equality between men and women, one of the principles which inspire European society and which will benefit from enhanced cooperation between the Union and the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, as I support the initially good and important approach of Mrs Mariya Gabriel's draft report. Violence against women and domestic violence is (not only) a problem in Eastern Europe's neighbouring countries that must be tackling offensively. However, the final report leaves this headline objective on many points and strikes areas that are definitely unrelated to the situation of women. I cannot and will not support this issue.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I do not agree with the call for countries in Eastern Europe to introduce quotas for women on candidate lists, nor do I agree with calls for special support programmes “for politicians and to activists”. Nor do I agree that “women's organisations” in Eastern European countries should be subsidised from the EU budget at the expense of our taxpayers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. — The Eastern Partnership was initiated by the Paris Declaration of 2009 as a joint initiative between the European Union, its Member States and six other countries. The key objective of the foreign policy of the European Union and the European Neighbourhood Policy is stabilisation to ensure peace, stability, security and prosperity. Although women's rights and gender equality are firmly enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all Member States of that partnership, social discrimination and various stereotypes prevent women from getting better into the labour market and their participation in political life. In voting on this report, I was abstained because of worldview provisions related to the right to life that I disagree with.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament considers the situation in the area of women’s rights in the Eastern Partnership countries to be in need of improvement. It points out that profound economic changes and economic uncertainty have had a negative effect on the economic situation of women, leading to shortcomings in their equality. Members called on the Eastern Partnership countries to overcome gaps in their anti-discrimination frameworks.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. — The Eastern Partnership States, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine, have women's rights enshrined in their legal systems. However, their rigorous implementation is problematic, as is in many countries of the Union. The rigorous promotion of women's rights and control over the exercise of this right must therefore become a self-evident daily part of all the policies of countries that respect the rule of law, democracy and human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - Referring to my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, I abstained in voting on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States because this report is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This text is an example of European policy and in particular the interference of the European institutions in the institutional, political, economic and social systems of third countries. The rapporteur hopes that member countries of the European Union's Eastern Partnership should introduce quotas for women's access to positions of responsibility, particularly in politics, with a preference for women from ethnic minorities (Roma) or LGBTI. We consider this report to be a real insult to women, reducing them to the status of victims. Finally, this is clearly a pro immigration and communitarianist report.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ The European Parliament's report on women's rights in Eastern Partnership States aims to highlight the need to consolidate equality between men and women in society today. In the Eastern Partnership area the situation of the female population proves particularly delicate, mainly due to the major changes affecting society and the situation economic uncertain. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which promotes more intensive use of legislation in combating discrimination and gender disparity.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we voted on a report looking at the assessment of women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. All member countries of this grouping have ratified most important international conventions in this area, but unfortunately women in the Eastern Partnership countries continue to suffer from social by discrimination. Neither equal access to employment applies here, nor equal pay for equal work between the sexes. The report specifically mentions the situation in Ukraine, where more than 1.5 million people have been forced displaced since the beginning of the conflict, but 2/3 of which represent women and children suffering impaired access to health care, housing and employment. I agree that it is necessary to combat the phenomenon of human trafficking, violence against women, to promote, in particular, the availability of education and services in the field of reproductive and sexual health. I therefore supported the report.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. - I am in favour of the resolution on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, because the stabilisation of neighbouring regions is one of the main objectives of the European foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) to ensure the security, peace, stability and prosperity and undoubtedly, for this to be implemented, the role of women is crucial. It is true that women remain largely absent from political structures, either at executive or parliamentary level, mainly because of discriminatory practices. Finally, combating violence against women is a common challenge for the EU and its eastern neighbours

name: Georg MAYER
text: in writing. - The rapporteur believes that there is still a striking absence of women in the political power structures of the Eastern Partnership countries, both in the executive and in Parliament, mainly due to discriminatory practices. The income gap between women and men is basically significant, although there are large differences in this respect between the countries of the Eastern Partnership. Horizontal and vertical segregation of the labour market plays a crucial role in this context. In rural areas, particularly in rural areas, women are ready to accept low-paid and unregistered employment offers, or they are engaged in self-employed entrepreneurial activities. Indeed, women represent a large proportion of entrepreneurs and business owners, but they face the same hurdles as in the EU, mainly due to the prevailing gender stereotypes and the sectors dominated by men. Equal treatment of women in politics, economy and religion is the basis of an enlightened and humanist society and is not negotiable. As the rapporteur interferes with the economic and political sovereignty of states in disregard of self-regulating processes in the labour market and generalises women in the Eastern Partnership countries in the Eastern Partnership, I abstained from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: This report focuses on women's rights in the countries in the so-called “eastern” neighbourhood of the European Union: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The EU maintains a policy of varying geometry, depending on its potential for interference, by supporting an “independent” press and there “pro-European opposition”. That said, the purpose of this report is to support the participation of women in the economic, social and political life of these countries, in order to further support the rule of law, democracy and equality. It supports the establishment of quotas in elections, the autonomous marital status of women (rights not related to the authorization of the husband) and sexual and reproductive rights. Only 50% of women on average have access to so-called modern contraceptive methods! He defends basic services for all. But of course, according to the report in Ukraine, everything is fine. I think the opposite. And the anti-Russian propaganda of this report is childish. In the end, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: This report on the partnership between the European Union and six post-Soviet states (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine) on women's rights is actually a stigma of women, reducing her to eternal victim status. It highlights the communitization of victims with an enhanced preference for women from ethnic minorities or LGBTI minorities, urges the States concerned to set up gender-based quotas and highlights the Union's immigrationist desires by emphasizing the right to family reunification. I therefore opposed this report, which is a total insult to women, without omitting that this is an umpteenth interference in the policies of sovereign states.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. — (NL) Although equality between men and women is enshrined by law in the countries of the Eastern Partnership, evidence is still provided on a daily basis that persistent male female stereotypes are common. Equality between men and women has actually deteriorated in recent years. Poorly paid jobs, gender-based violence and lack of access to sexual and reproductive rights for women are still discovering society. In recent years, the EU has provided €103 million in support to promote gender equality in the Eastern Partnership. This report takes stock of the situation. Countries are asked to set clear targets on gender equality and to make efforts to remove the obstacles preventing full economic and social participation of women. Worldwide, it has been shown that women in transition countries are often driving forces in securing peace, security and prosperity, thus raising society to the next level. That is why it is also appropriate to ensure equal access to high-quality training and equal representation at all levels of government in the neighbourhood.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - Eastern Partnership policy is one of the main priorities of the European Union's foreign policy and thus interferes with many areas of support and cooperation. The level of respect for human rights is one of the key priorities from the point of view of the Union and raising its level constitutes a conditio sine qua non and a necessity for deepening relations with the Eastern Partnership countries and their progress towards European integration. Women and girls represent valuable human capital in all of these countries. They generally achieve higher education, but this is not the correspondence of their subsequent social application. The representation of women in management positions remains very limited (only 10%) and women are often forced to work in positions that do not correspond to their professional qualifications or even in unregistered places. I believe that the Union must continue to maintain a decisive position as regards the empowerment of women in the Eastern Partnership countries, as well as condemning the violence that is present in society and, to some extent, quietly tolerated. This phenomenon has no place in modern democratic society.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Even though women’s rights and gender equality are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all six Eastern Partnership countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine), social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes remain important and prevent greater inclusion of women in the labour market and participation in political decision-making processes. Also violence against women remains a problem. However, I have never supported any references to abortion and women’s sexual and reproductive health and rights, which, in my opinion, are strictly a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — The constitutions and legal systems of all the countries of the Eastern Partnership launched in 2009 at the initiative of the Union and its Member States, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova, Armenia and Ukraine, encompass women's rights and gender equality. At the same time, social discrimination is significant, and gender stereotypes not only prevent women's involvement in the labour market and participation in political life, but also maintain social acceptance of gender-based and non-police domestic violence . Women are strikingly absent from positions of power, both in the executive and parliamentary branches, mainly thanks to discriminatory practices. The gender pay gap is particularly significant, ranging between 24% and 50%, while horizontal and vertical segregation of the labour market is critical. Women are therefore inclined to accept underpaid or undeclared jobs, particularly in rural areas. The report aims to highlight the obstacles to women's participation in society and how greater gender equality would help achieve the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the European Neighbourhood Policy. It also lists examples of best practices, relevant and successful projects promoting women's rights and gender equality in the Eastern Partnership countries. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — The EU's “Eastern Partnership” policy concerns six post-Soviet states: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The report is reductive towards all women, but also a clear interference by the European institutions in the institutional, political, economic and social systems of the target countries. It is based on gender theory (paras. 6, 22). It calls on states to punish “insults and stigma” towards LGBTI people in public space or in public services. Since the words “insults” and “stigma” are very vague, one can fear an infringement of freedom of expression in the end. Moreover, we cannot classify people according to their sexual practices. Finally, women are clearly communitized and reduced to their gender: 'poor, migrant women from ethnic minorities' (recital I). Ultimately, the report is condescending towards women, reducing them to the status of eternal victims. This is clearly a pro immigration and communitarianism report (migrants, LGBT, Roma). Vote against.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: This report is a real insult to women, reducing them to the status of eternal victims. On the other hand, I observe total interference in the policies of the States concerned. Finally, it is clearly a pro-immigration and communitarianism report (see passages concerning migrants or Roma). I am therefore voting against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on women's rights in the eastern part of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The text urges Eastern Partnership countries to take steps to strengthen gender equality, particularly in political responsibilities and the economic sector. It condemns domestic and sexual violence and their social acceptance. Finally, it highlights some good practices supported by international organizations, such as the “Women in Politics in Moldova” project or the Transcaucasian Women's Dialogue on Peace and Security.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In order to open the pathway to discussions of trade, human rights, economic strategy and travel agreements, amongst other issues, with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, the EU inaugurated the European Partnership on 7 May 2009. I have voted for this report that highlights the barriers to women’s empowerment.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this ambitious report, which makes an analysis of the situation of women in the Eastern Partnership countries, proposing solutions for improvement, and I welcome it, given that respect, promotion and guarantee of gender equality are part of the Union's goals European. The report rightly notes that violence against women continues to be significant in many of the Eastern Partnership countries and takes multiple forms, such as physical, emotional abuse, threats or sexual abuse. I welcome the fact that the report adopted today calls on partner countries to promote the political participation of women, to respect the principle of gender equality in terms of pay and promotion at work. I also consider it beneficial that all Eastern Partnership countries ratify the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence as soon as possible, and national authorities create strategies to combat violence against women and domestic violence in partnership with the EU violence against women and strictly monitor their application.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting here because equal treatment of women in politics, business and religion is the basis of an enlightened and humanist society and is not negotiable. The report interferes with the economic and political sovereignty of the state, in defiance of self-regulating processes in the labour market.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. The situation of women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries requires consistent attention and addressing political and human rights meetings with Eastern Partnership countries. However, social and economic discrimination against women is widespread enough in these countries and prevents women from participating in the labour market as well as in political life. Violence against women and lack of access to sexual health are also of concern. The EU can contribute to the development of this area, for example through the instruments of the Eastern Partnership Programme.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - As underlined in the Riga Declaration, gender equality is an area that would greatly benefit from enhanced cooperation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership States. Most of the challenges are common to the EU and its eastern neighbours. The aim of the report is to contribute to giving women's rights and gender equality a higher political priority in the Eastern Partnership countries. There is a need for direct action by Eastern Partnership countries to increase equality between women and men in society, including the adoption of national action plans and cooperation with international organisations and civil society bodies. in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, which calls on the Eastern Partnership countries to address shortcomings in their national frameworks to combat discrimination and to make greater use of legislation against sex discrimination in order to increase the degree of application of laws and stop the violation of women's rights in these countries. It also stresses the need for citizens' awareness campaigns and for institutional changes aimed at eliminating negative stereotypes affecting women and adversely affecting all sectors of their participation in society.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. — The resolution is used as another tool to exert diverse EU pressure on the Eastern Partnership countries in the context of the so-called ENP to promote the interests of the business groups served by the EU and the corresponding sections of the urban classes of these countries. Any references to the condemned phenomena of exploitation and violence against women are used as a cover. The report provocatively entrusts NGOs and “civil society organisations”, in other words employers, with the protection of women's rights, while in the name of “economic independence” it propagates “female entrepreneurship”, “social economy” and lending. as a way out to problems, hushing up their class exploitation. It considers... as supposedly “promotion of their rights” the increase of their participation in “administrative structures responsible for capital... economic reforms”, i.e. the promotion of anti-grassroots anti-labour measures and their emergence into “managerial positions”. All this has nothing to do with the concerns of the women of working grassroots families and not only are they far from their real needs but are opposed to them. That is why they must fight with a view to a society without capitalist exploitation, in which the conditions for tackling violence against women and resolving female inequality will be established.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because, in addition to highlighting the obstacles to the emancipation of women in the Eastern Partnership States, it provides examples of good practice which, in some of those countries, they led to the strengthening of gender equality. Without guarantee of women's rights, there are less security, peace, stability and prosperity, fundamental pillars of stabilising the eastern neighbourhood for the EU.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Stabilisation of its neighbourhood is one of the key objectives of the European Union’s foreign policy and of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) in order to ensure the security, peace, stability and prosperity of all. Women play a crucial role towards it. I voted in favour of this report as it assesses women’s situation in several areas which are of utmost importance for the EPP Group: the participation of women in decision-making processes; the economic participation of women; violence against women; women’s role in the peaceful resolution of conflicts. It gives examples of best practices in place in the EaP countries and outlines EU support/funding in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Several recommendations are sketched in all these fields to achieve gender equality and enhance women’s rights.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I cannot support the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. While this resolution builds its starting points on neighbourhood stabilisation as one of the key objectives of EU foreign policy and European neighbourhood policy in order to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity, and underlines the role of women (emphasis is on women's rights and equality gender in Eastern Partnership policy), however, does not specifically address the real problems of women in the Eastern Partnership countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine) and does not take measures to really improve their rights and positions. I take the view that this resolution should pay more attention to women who have certain powers and to carers, household workers and women with disabilities. D Member States should develop even stronger bilateral and multilateral ties with Eastern Partnership countries and actively participate in the transition, technical support and exchange of experiences. In this regard, I believe that Member States in close proximity to Eastern Partnership countries could play an important role in facilitating the formation of stronger links and in engaging other Member States in cooperation with the Eastern Partnership States.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: In writing. ‒ Stabilisation of its neighbourhood is one of the priorities of the European Union. The Eastern Partnership, initiated in 2009, is a joint initiative between the EU and six Eastern European and South Caucasus countries. Naturally, the gender dimension, as a principle of international law and the fundamental value of democracy, is also part of the commitments set out by this partnership. With this resolution we wanted to highlight how greater gender equality and support for women could contribute to achieving the objectives of the partnership itself. It is vital that partnership countries are committed more to strengthening equality between women and men through, for example, awareness campaigns about stereotypes that still affect broadly public life, or overcoming the too many gaps in their respective regulatory systems on the prevention of violence against women or discrimination based on sex. There is also a need for increased attention towards LGBTI people who are often discriminated against in public and official settings without any consequence for those committing such discriminatory actions. Much remains to be done and the EU can improve the situation of women in these countries thanks to the many tools useful in its neighbourhood policy, and for these reasons I supported this resolution.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. — The Eastern Partnership was established in 2009 under the Declaration of Prague as a joint initiative of the EU, its Member States and six partner countries in Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. When announcing the strategic priorities of the European Neighbourhood Policy for 2014-2020, gender equality was highlighted as a priority issue. Although women's rights and gender equality are firmly established in the constitutions and legal systems of all Member States of that partnership, de facto inequality persists. S&D specifically focused on the rights of LGBTI persons, on issues of sexual and reproductive health of women, on the need for stronger involvement of women in decision-making and economic policy implementation process as well as trade unions, on equal division of unpaid jobs, such as care and obligations in the household and on the fight against forced marriages. I call on the Eastern Partnership states to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women because none of those states have ratified it. The EU needs to impose gender equality more actively through many useful instruments of European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We follow many of the concerns raised in the report, particularly with regard to the imperative need to overcome gender inequalities. However, we believe that the report falls far short of analysing the causes of these inequalities and the ways needed to overcome them, particularly as regards the need for a break in right-wing and exploitation policies. There are, among other things, compulsory quota mechanisms to overcome the difference in women's participation in politics, a mechanism that we reject. It refers to the situation in Ukraine, without mentioning the EU's responsibilities in establishing a fascist regime. The report does not escape the usual approach to interference which so well characterizes the European Parliament. This justifies the exacerbation of the European Neighbourhood Policy and its role in supporting and financing initiatives that, of course, aim to contribute to political changes, of course, under the ideological framework of the EU, but also the use of the ENP for reforms in the Public Administration and the principles and policies of the States.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ We must recognise that the EU needs to impose gender equality and gender mainstreaming more actively through the many useful instruments of its Neighbourhood Policy. Even though women’s rights and gender equality are included within the constitutions and legal systems of all six Eastern Partnership countries of Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes remain prevalent, preventing greater inclusion of women in the labour market and participation in political decision-making processes.  Unfortunately, the discrimination and stereotypes also lead to violence against women and lack of sexual and reproductive health and rights. I am proud that the S&D Group worked together amongst others groups who managed to improve the very general draft by tabling amendments on: LGBTI persons’ rights; need for stronger involvement of women in economic decision making; access to micro-credits; the need for a change in stereotypes; support for equal sharing of unpaid work between men and women; the fight against forced (child) marriage; and combating violence against women. Although the six Eastern Partnership countries guarantee equality between women and men, de facto inequality persists in the areas the report highlights, stressing the importance of increased pressure towards gender equality and gender mainstreaming.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — As part of the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy, which aims to stabilize relations with its eastern neighbours, a partnership has been established with six Eastern European and Caucasus countries. This is based, inter alia, on respect for women's rights. However, we regret that social discrimination and gender stereotypes remain important in the countries affected by this partnership. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which refers to this tragic situation for women and makes several recommendations to improve their situation and encourage their participation in the economic and political sectors in the Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Stabilisation of the neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and, in particular, of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Women play a key role in this area. In view of the principle of differentiation of the ENP, it is important to point out that women's rights, as well as equality between people of different sexes, are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of the various Eastern Partnership countries. Unfortunately, there is still great social discrimination in this regard. These stereotypes not only prevent women from becoming more involved in the labour market and their participation in political life, but also maintain the social acceptance of the phenomenon of undeclared domestic violence. Statistics on reported cases show that between 7% and 25% of women (depending on the country) were victims of domestic violence, but most cases remain unreported. As I adequately reflect the above issues, I have been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. UKIP agreed with the sentiments of the report which condemned sexual violence, rape, trafficking, child labour, the lack of rights for LGBTI and discrimination in these (non-EU) eastern European countries. However we could not support legitimising and expanding EU action on the international stage. The report called for gender quotas in politics; expansion of EU programmes and funding through Erasmus and Horizon2020 to these countries; and greater involvement of EU agencies in these countries. These issues should be addressed bilaterally between elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Mr President, although the situation of women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and Belarus) has improved and they have committed themselves to ensuring equality between men and women, inequality persists. The Group of European Socialists has managed to improve the report by tabling amendments related to: the rights of LGBTI people, sexual and reproductive rights, the need for greater participation of women in economic decision-making and trade unions, access to microcredits, the need tackling stereotypes, support for the equitable sharing of unpaid work between men and women in care and domestic work, the fight against forced marriage and the fight against domestic violence, to highlight just a few.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on women's rights in Eastern Partnership States. The resolution, which highlights the many challenges that still require special attention in order to improve the situation in the field of women's rights, focuses on several main areas: women's participation in decision-making processes, women's economic participation, violence against women, roles played by women by women in the peaceful resolution of conflicts, examples of good practice and finally EU assistance in the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. In the context of profound economic changes and persistent conflicts in the region, particularly in Ukraine, it is important for the European Union to reiterate its support for the principles of international law and fundamental values, with particular emphasis on the promotion of women's rights in these Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report. This is an important report that sends a clear message to the Commission. Firstly, the report calls for the Commission to complete the gender impact assessment of readmission agreements with the Eastern Partnership countries. Another important call is to ensure women's rights, regardless of women's family and social status, such as women's access to visas. These requirements show that the European Parliament closely monitors the situation of women in the Eastern Partnership countries. At the same time, we want to encourage changes that could open up ways for these countries to get even closer to the EU.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Stabilisation of the neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). In order to ensure security, peace, stability and common prosperity, gender equality plays a crucial role in achieving this objective and should be integrated into all relevant policies. The Eastern Partnership emerged in 2009, with the Prague Declaration, as a joint initiative between the EU and six partner countries in Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus, based on a commitment to respect for the principles of international law and the fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and Human rights, as well as gender equality. However, there are still cases of discrimination creating barriers to the emancipation of women. The report calls for greater participation by women in peace negotiations and political transition processes as a key link in their social and political emancipation and participation. According to the Riga Declaration, strengthening cooperation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership will benefit efforts to achieve gender equality and women's rights, which have led me to support and vote in favour of this report.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. Stabilising their neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. Women play a crucial role in this. The report therefore aims to give greater importance to women's rights and gender equality in the policy of the Eastern Partnership. It contains recommendations in the areas of particular importance to the Group of the European People's Party. They are designed to promote gender equality and strengthen women's rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which deals with the situation of women's rights in the six countries of the Union's Eastern Association, recognizes that although women's rights are formally recognized by all the constitutions of these states and gender equality is regarded as a strategic priority in the European Neighbourhood Policy, women continue to suffer discrimination and high rates of gender-based violence. It expresses concern at its low public representation and calls for concrete steps to overcome the barriers faced by women on a daily basis, such as the wage and pension gap that reached up to 50 per cent in some sectors. Despite her positive statements, the rapporteur on the right does not go far enough in terms of the recognition of sexual and reproductive rights for women. The text is also part of the European Neighbourhood Policy and its financial instruments, interference in the internal affairs of third countries and the promotion of regime change which I reject. For these reasons, despite your good intentions, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report because I do wish to see women’s rights advanced, I just do not think that the EU should be doing it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states. Stabilisation of its Neighbourhood is central to the European Union’s Foreign Policy; ensuring security, peace and prosperity and affirming women’s rights and freedoms is a vital part of this.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ Women in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine face many difficulties, which are also plaguing European women, but to a much higher extent. Plus, their options to defend themselves are much more limited. That is why the EU helps them. I welcomed how the resolution adopted focuses on combating not only poverty or violence against women, but, above all, how it clearly mentions the crime of trafficking in human beings, to which many women, but also children from the Eastern Partnership countries suffer. The report also highlighted the unacceptable abuse of women to surrogacy, which is one form of human trafficking. And this practice should not only be pointed out, we are obliged to ban it! Not only the forced or commercial, but also the so-called altruistic. Because it tramples the dignity and fundamental human rights of both — surrogate mother and child. But the text here again seeks to impose gender ideology on non-EU countries, whether by pushing out the Istanbul Convention and so-called 'gender mainstreaming' or by combating so-called stereotypes. It also promotes the so-called “right to abortion” and easier access to contraception in the name of helping women of these countries. I do not think that this is the measures that these women and their families need from the EU. That is why I voted against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. — The Eastern Partnership established in 2009 represents a joint initiative of the Member States of the European Union and the six partner countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus, and is based, in accordance with the Declaration of Prague, on respect of the principles of international law and fundamental values including democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. When announcing the strategic priorities of cooperation for the period 2014-2020, gender equality was highlighted as a priority issue and defined as a new perspective area of cooperation. I supported the European Parliament resolution because I believe that the importance of gender equality and women's rights should not be suppressed into another row, but encompassed by relevant activities and put at the heart of policies. Fighting violence against women is also a key challenge we face. I would highlight the 5th Sustainable Development Goal, which calls for the eradication of all forms of violence against women and girls in the private and public sphere. It is precisely the empowerment of women and their active participation in social, political and economic life that is crucial for achieving the changes we strive for and accordingly it is necessary to promote and strengthen women's participation in political life and in leadership positions in order to raise awareness of the important role they play.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality between women and men is enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all Eastern Partnership countries. I regret that even though all Eastern Partnership countries have ratified most of the important international conventions in this area without reservation, women in some countries are still subject to social discrimination. While the rate of violations of women's rights varies substantially across the Eastern Partnership countries, we continue to see serious shortcomings in the incidence of violence against women, access to services and rights in the field of sexual and reproductive health (CFP), as well as other violations of rights. I supported the resolution because, as a woman, I consider gender equality irrespective of the country of origin to be one of the priorities of the European Union (EU). I believe that, in order to stabilise the neighbourhood of EU foreign policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), we will improve the situation of women's rights and improve their situation in the Eastern Partnership countries. I also believe that the Eastern Partnership countries will take immediate action to strengthen equality between women and men in society, including the adoption of national action plans and cooperation with international organisations and civil society stakeholders.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. — The European Parliament resolution on the rights of women in the Eastern Partnership countries addresses those problems that we also solve in the European Union, but at a completely different level. Women in these Eastern Partnership countries face much greater problems in the areas of economic dependency, unemployment, discriminatory conduct, lack of education, possibly problems with the alignment of family and professional life. First of all, it is about improving the political and economic situation in these countries. It is the very women who, in many cases, engage in civil society and effectively help with the necessary reforms. The report rightly emphasises the need for greater involvement of women in transformation processes. Where this involvement occurred, the results were very positive, such as in Moldova the UNDP project “Women in Politics”, which the report mentions. Despite all the pros of this resolution, I did not support it in the end, because I do not agree that the EP, through these parliamentary resolutions, invites Member States or third countries to greater availability of services to ensure reproductive and sexual health, which implies mainly a liberal approach to abortion.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The report underlines that overall political stability and respect for human rights are essential conditions for strengthening women's rights and improving their position in individual countries. Eastern Partnership countries should take immediate action to increase the equality of women and men in society, including by adopting national action plans and cooperation with international organisations and civil society stakeholders. They must also act towards resolving gaps in their anti-discrimination frameworks and to a greater extent apply legislation to combat discrimination on the basis of gender, taking into account international standards. This is very important, as the statistics reflect a very worrying situation. In Eastern Partnership countries, women held only 17 out of 136 senior ministries positions in 2015, their share among elected MPs in parliament averaged 16%, and only 17% of top positions were occupied in the civil service. It is also important that the report in several places also refers to the fight against trafficking in human beings, where women are most often victims. Cooperation between the Eastern Partnership countries, on the one hand, and the EU agencies and law enforcement agencies of the Member States, on the other, should be strengthened here. As I assess that the report contains very important aspects, I also supported it.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: in writing. - The emancipation of women and their active participation in social, political and economic life is crucial to the achievement of the objectives of the Eastern Partnership. However, in practice, social discrimination and gender stereotypes continue to pose major challenges, hindering women's greater integration into the labour market and their participation in the political life of these countries. In addition, they leave room for social acceptance of violence against women. The motion for a resolution is not intended to list the weaknesses, but includes examples of best practices to be adopted and recommendations to promote women's rights.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States, as I support the initially good and important approach of Mrs Mariya Gabriel's draft report. Violence against women and domestic violence is a problem in the Eastern European countries that must be tackling offensively. However, the final report leaves this headline objective on many points and strikes areas that are definitely unrelated to the situation of women. I cannot and will not support this issue.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. ‒ A high degree of respect for human and civil rights, including women's rights, is one of the indicators of the maturity of society. It is gratifying that we have seen progress in this area in the Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. - I rejected the European Parliament resolution on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. I think it's wrong to talk about special women's rights. How will these differ from human rights? Are there human rights for men and women? So men's rights and women's rights? How does the principle work then that all people are equal before the law when there are different rights? Laws must be general and the same for them to be good. The application of such laws alone will ensure that women are adequately protected.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. — The Eastern Partnership was launched in 2009, based on the principles of international law, fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. The 2015 Riga Declaration mentions gender equality as a promising new area of cooperation. It is important to emphasize that women's rights as well as gender equality are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all Eastern Partnership countries. But women still remain absent from political power structures largely because of discrimination. The report highlights a woman's key role in resolving conflicts and building peace. The report also calls for greater involvement of women in peace talks and political transitions. This report aims to highlight barriers to women's empowerment and to help achieve the objectives of the EAP and the ENP (European Neighbourhood Policy). Gender equality is an area that will greatly benefit from enhanced cooperation between the EU and Eastern Partnership countries. I fully support this Report as women's empowerment and their active participation in social, political and economic life is crucial in order to achieve a change in the process.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries. There are huge differences between Eastern Partnership countries on women's rights, but overall the level of violence against women is still relatively high. I support the report which considers the need to improve the situation on women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries, while also seeing as a necessary condition for strengthening women's rights in overall political stability, respect for human rights and economic stability affecting the economic situation women, which is often also the cause of lack of equality.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The report interferes too much in the internal affairs of other States with mandates for specific actions, for example the promotion of mandatory quotas on the electoral roll and the Nordic model for combating prostitution. Apart from our disagreement on quotas, for example, as such measures do not really solve the problem, the EU has no right to impose the policies it wants on other states. Equally serious is the fact that the report ignores the fact that the strengthening of women's rights and, by extension, gender equality cannot be understood in the context of the neoliberal policies promoted by the EU in the Eastern Partnership countries. Despite the individual positive references in the report, for example, to ensuring the participation of women in trade unions, combating discrimination at work, and a call for a strengthening of the network of quality care facilities for the elderly and dependants, these proposals it is not possible to coexist and strengthen them over time because of the other measures promoted by the EU, as is the case within the Union. That's why we abstained.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership states. As highlighted in the report, one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and neighbourhood policy is to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. Women really play a fundamental role in this. That is why I welcome the fact that regular reports to monitor developments in the neighbourhood will include gender equality. I also consider it right that the rapporteur notes that women's rights and gender equality are also enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of all countries in the Eastern Partnership, although they are still a serious problem of social discrimination and gender stereotypes. I think it is important to note that the Member States of the European Union also face similar problems, such as violence against women, low participation of women in decision-making processes and gender pay gap, EU Member States also need to make serious efforts in the situation. in order to improve it.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. — Equality of men and women has been enshrined in the constitutions and laws of all countries of the Eastern Partnership, namely Belarus, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia. All of these countries have also ratified the most important international conventions in the area. However, there is no doubt that it is difficult to talk in the Partnership countries about the actual equality of men and women. In power structures in Partnership states, women are conspicuously absent. Even if women succeed in embracing high-level political and decision-making positions, their abilities and competence are undermined, also in public. The same is the case for women's participation in the economy. Existing gender stereotypes and discriminatory practices prevent women from fully participating in the labor market and underlie gender pay differentiation, which is still extremely high. Another problem is violence against women, including human trafficking for sexual exploitation. Unfortunately, many crimes against women are not reported due to the prevailing consent in society for such behaviour. In the process of empowering and protecting women's fundamental rights in the countries of the Eastern Partnership, the European Union and its Member States should play an important role. However, it is not a question of calculating shortcomings and errors, but of highlighting obstacles to achieving these objectives and exchanging best practices, the implementation of which must take into account the specifics of each country.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. - In general, the situation of women in Europe is not appropriate to her role and importance in ensuring the sustainable development of society. Moreover, the European Institute for Gender Equality draws attention to the fact that the European Union is only halfway to a gender equality society. In this context, it is evident that women's rights in EaP countries are not respected either, with gender equality remaining a horizontal priority under the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) and the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI). In order to ensure respect for women's rights and improve their social and economic situation in those countries, there must be general political stability and the framework necessary to respect human rights in general. It is therefore necessary to urgently adopt specific measures to improve the situation of women in the EaP states, included in national action plans, resulting from cooperation with international organisations and civil society actors. EaP States also need to promote and support women's socio-economic and political participation and their leadership role, bearing in mind that they have a high level of labour market integration, playing an important role in conflict resolution and peacebuilding.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. — The report deals with the situation of women's rights in six Eastern Partnership States, which are covered by the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Although women's rights and gender equality are mentioned in the constitutions and legal systems in all these countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine), social, economic discrimination and gender stereotypes remain important issues. The EU must more actively impose gender equality and gender mainstreaming through the many useful instruments of its Neighbourhood Policy. For this reason, I support the document in question by vote.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text. As highlighted in the Riga Declaration, gender equality is an area that could benefit greatly from enhanced cooperation between the Union and the Eastern Partnership States. Most of the challenges are inherently common to the Union and its eastern European neighbours, and this report aims to contribute to making women's rights and gender equality a higher priority in Eastern Partnership policies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the rights of women in Eastern Partnership States (EaP) highlights the situation in the area of women’s rights in the EaP countries and points to the necessity for improvement. Particularly, the report highlights the profound economic changes and economic uncertainty that have had a negative effect on the economic situation of women, leading to the regression of female equality in these countries. I voted in favour of the report, which calls on the EaP countries to take immediate action to increase equality between women and men in society, including the adoption of national action plans and cooperation with international organisations and civil society stakeholders. The EU has the obligation to promote and enforce gender equality norms and women’s rights in its partner states, and I believe this report reinforces this objective.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: In writing. ‒ Parliament's action must be to draw attention to the fact that gender-crimes and sexual violence are classified in the Rome Statute as war crimes and against humanity. One of the objectives of the European institutions must be to devote more resources to combating all forms of violence against women (physical, sexual, psychological, economic), and among them it must not lack the modification of legal instruments to provide assistance to victims of violence. It is about effectively preventing and, with time, to eliminate violence against women and girls, by imposing appropriate penalties for those responsible. Parliament calls on, with this report, to ensure the effective defence of women also through the training of legal professionals, police officers and other staff dealing with notifications and of reports of acts of violence. Finally, we encourage the Eastern Partnership countries to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combat Violence Against Women as soon as possible, since none of the countries concerned have ratified it yet.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the Rights of Women in the Eastern Partnership States with regard to Articles 2 and 3. Treaties on European Union establishing gender equality as one of the foundations of the European Union. The Eastern Partnership is based on the principles of international law, which makes it necessary to integrate gender equality and women's rights as a supreme value at the foundations of this partnership. It is necessary to increase women's participation in the decision-making process, neutralize gender stereotypes that prevent women from entering the labour market, take adequate legal action to prevent and reduce violence against women and in the family. In line with the ongoing armed conflicts, it should also be borne in mind that women and children are the majority population affected by armed conflicts. For this reason, it is necessary to highlight the key role of women in conflict resolution, peace establishment and conflict-related emergencies. The report also calls for women to participate more actively in peace talks and political transition.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. — The Eastern Partnership was launched in 2009 as a joint initiative of the European Union, its Member States and six Eastern European countries and the countries of the South Caucasus — Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. This initiative is an integral part of the European Neighbourhood Policy. As a priority point in the European Union strategy in relation to these six countries, gender equality was emphasised, which was emphasised that it must be a guiding thread for all relevant activities within the partnership agreement. This report by the FEMM Committee underlines that while women's rights are institutionally and legally recognised in these countries, various stereotypes continue to prevail, and this leads to the prevention of greater participation of women in the labour market and participation in political life in general. While I wholeheartedly support the fight for women's rights, I cannot agree with those calls from the European Union that ask these countries to ratify the Istanbul Convention, punish those who offend or stigmatise people from the LGBT population, and seek the introduction of mandatory women's quotas for political candidates because I regard the same as an inadmissible violation of the sovereignty of nation-states. So I voted abstentions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I have supported the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. Stabilisation of neighbouring countries is one of the key objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and European Neighbourhood Policy to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all and women play an important role in this. The Eastern Partnership was established in 2009 on an EU initiative (it contains countries: Ukraine, Belarus, Azerbaijan, Moldova, Georgia and Armenia). Women are still neglected in these countries. They are poorly represented in political structural authorities, the gender pay gap is still vast and all too many times they are victims of violence or human trafficking. This report is not intended to list shortcomings and failures in the protection of women's rights, but to draw attention to the barriers to women's empowerment and how greater gender equality would help achieve the objectives of the Eastern Partnership and the European Neighbourhood Policy. Gender equality is an area where enhanced cooperation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries could make great progress.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Respect for women should exist not only at the level of values, but must also play an active role at the economic level in order to facilitate and improve their employment situation. Everyone should have access to studies and should respect the LGBT collective. I support this proposal so that the Commission also takes into account gender equality when it comes to agreements with Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. — This report is a real insult to women, reducing them to the status of victims who cannot take ownership of themselves. In addition, several paragraphs are of total interference in the policy of the States concerned, in order to force them to put in place some initiative proposed by a particular Member of the European Parliament. Finally, it is clearly a pro immigration and communitarist report aimed at giving migrants, LGBT, or Roma specific rights under the pretext that they belong to a particular community. I voted against this report with force.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. — It is necessary to work for women's equality in the Eastern Partnership States and we should discuss how best to contribute. Unfortunately, the report imposes provisions on third countries that may not encourage the promotion of women's rights according to their own patterns. It is necessary to act with extreme caution, which is why I abstained.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. — Stabilising its neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy and of the European Neighbourhood Policy in order to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity for all. Women play a fundamental role in this. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, as the report focuses on measures in the Eastern Partnership States (EAP) to promote women's participation in decision-making processes, economic participation, the fight against violence against women, the role of women in peaceful conflict resolution, examples of good practices and Union support in the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Gender equality is recognized as a cross-cutting issue in the ENP's strategic priorities for 2014-2020, we consider this report positive as it is necessary to mainstream and integrate gender issues into relations with EAP as well. The EAP launched in 2009 is signed by the Union, its Member States and the EAP: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. With this report, APAs must take concrete measures to overcome the many barriers women face in all spheres of society, including politics, care and education, as women are absent from power structures and remain predominantly active in low-wage sectors due to legal and structural barriers.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the rights of women in the Eastern Partnership (EaP) states because it clearly states that women still face significant barriers to equal participation in all areas of society. Eastern Partnership (EaP) states should take concrete steps to overcome the many barriers facing women in all areas of society, including politics, care and education. I urge the European Commission to act in several areas such as migration, anti-trafficking and family reunification procedures.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing. — I welcome the draft Council of Europe, which aims to identify what prevents women in the Eastern Partnership countries from getting to justice on an equal footing, and to help remove these obstacles.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the rights of women in the Eastern Partnership States. Stabilisation of its neighbourhood is one of the key objectives of the European Union’s foreign policy and of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) in order to ensure the security, peace, stability and prosperity of all. Women play a crucial role towards it.  The Eastern Partnership was launched in 2009 with the Prague Declaration, as a joint initiative between the EU, its Member States and six Eastern European and South Caucasus partner countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. Because the Eastern Partnership is based on the commitment to the principles of international law, fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, one should not forget the importance of gender equality and women rights. However, women remain remarkably absent from the political structures of power, be it in the executive or in the parliamentary branch, mainly due to discriminatory practices. I voted in favour because the report does not aim at listing the lacks and failures in protecting women’s rights but rather at highlighting the barriers to women’s empowerment and how greater gender equality would help reaching the EaP and ENP objectives.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. ‒ This self-initiative report draws attention to the delicate situation of women's rights in the Eastern Partnership region due to economic uncertainties. It emphasizes the urgency of taking measures to redirect this situation, including through appropriate national action plans, as well as through enhanced cooperation by the countries integrated into this Association, the institutions of the Union and its Member States in areas such as the fight against trafficking in human beings. It also emphasizes the need to share good practices and emphasizes the need to adopt a cross-cutting gender equality perspective within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. In support of the promotion of women's rights through all the mechanisms available to the Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which deals with the situation of women's rights in the six countries of the Union's Eastern Association, recognizes that although women's rights are formally recognized by all the constitutions of these states and gender equality is regarded as a strategic priority in the European Neighbourhood Policy, women continue to suffer discrimination and high rates of gender-based violence. It expresses concern at its low public representation and calls for concrete steps to overcome the barriers faced by women on a daily basis, such as the wage and pension gap that reached up to 50 per cent in some sectors. Despite her positive statements, the rapporteur on the right does not go far enough in terms of the recognition of sexual and reproductive rights for women. The text is also part of the European Neighbourhood Policy and its financial instruments, interference in the internal affairs of third countries and the promotion of regime change which I reject. For these reasons, despite your good intentions, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is of critical importance that EU cooperation with the Eastern Partnership states dismantles damaging gender stereotypes. Greater inclusion of women in the labour market, increased participation of women in political and public spheres, and expanding access to justice for those affected by gender-based violence will contribute to stability and increased economic prosperity in the Eastern Partnership states.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: — I voted in favour because women must have equal access to power and that women should be represented at all levels of government and decision-making in order to promote women's leadership.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The Eastern Partnership was launched in 2009, together with the Prague Declaration. It is a joint initiative between the EU, the Member States and Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova, and is based on commitments to the principles of international law and democracy. On the other hand, the Riga Declaration considers gender equality as a new area of cooperation. The report states that equality between men and women is enshrined in the constitutions of these countries and their legal systems; all these countries have ratified most international conventions. Despite this, there are serious violations of women's rights in these countries. Women's rights have no borders. However, these rights cannot be used to legitimize external interference interventions in the internal affairs of sovereign countries.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: in writing. - The rapporteur believes that there is still a striking absence of women in the political power structures of the Eastern Partnership countries, both in the executive and in Parliament, mainly due to discriminatory practices. The income gap between women and men is basically significant, although there are large differences in this respect between the countries of the Eastern Partnership. Horizontal and vertical segregation of the labour market plays a crucial role in this context. In rural areas, particularly in rural areas, women are ready to accept low-paid and unregistered employment offers, or they are engaged in self-employed entrepreneurial activities. Indeed, women represent a large proportion of entrepreneurs and business owners, but they face the same hurdles as in the EU, mainly due to the prevailing gender stereotypes and the sectors dominated by men. Equal treatment of women in politics, economy and religion is the basis of an enlightened and humanist society and is not negotiable. As the rapporteur interferes with the economic and political sovereignty of states in disregard of self-regulating processes in the labour market and generalises women in the Eastern Partnership countries in the Eastern Partnership, I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership States. In particular, this report aims to highlight obstacles to the emancipation of women and how greater gender equality could contribute to achieving the objectives of the partnership Eastern and ENP. Examples of good practice, relevant and successful projects for the promotion of women's rights and gender equality in Eastern Partnership States are also included.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which highlights the need to increase the participation of women in decision-making. I believe proper consideration must be given to the importance of empowering women in conflict resolution and peace-building in Ukraine. Women must take the lead in any post-conflict reconciliation mechanism that is set up. Women and girls must be involved in building vibrant democratic civil societies across Eastern Partnership countries, especially women who are leaders and role models in the social, cultural and political spheres. Programmes like Erasmus+ and Creative Europe can be key cultural diplomacy tools fostering inter-cultural dialogue and civic engagement, bringing women and girls together for the benefit of their societies.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I am a liberal woman and so this topic concerns me a lot. I agree with the fact that the situation of women’s rights in the Eastern Partnership states, still needs improvements. The situation of women has been negatively affected by the strong economic and changes and uncertainties, leading to a worsening of the battle for equality in particular in that area. Two fundamental preconditions to enhance women’s rights in the Eastern Partnership countries are an overall political stability and the respect for human rights. The Eastern Partnership countries should take immediate action to increase equality between women and men in society. This could be done by national action plans and cooperation with international organisations or other types of stakeholders. I would also like to stress the fact that women have often to bear the responsibility of elderly and dependent people, and that women with children usually find professional reintegration very difficult. A more equal sharing of care and domestic responsibilities between men and women may be a good precondition for women’s participation in the labour market.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted on the own-initiative report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. The rapporteur draws attention to the fact that women are predominantly active in low-wage sectors in all Eastern Partnership countries, despite their higher level of education. The report calls for women to be involved in the decision-making process and in the implementation of economic policies, promotion of business programs aimed at integrating and promoting women in companies and businesses, as well as local development projects aimed at economic capacity of women. The report also calls on the Eastern Partnership States to devote more resources to combating all forms of violence against women, including to modify legal instruments and to provide assistance to victims of violence.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - I understand the Eastern Partnership as an effort by the European Union to expand and strengthen the value environment inherent in Europe, where we can build on cultural, but also geographical proximity. A report by the FEMM committee could give Eastern Partnership states a certain compass on the road to improving women's status. Unfortunately, as in other reports from this committee, there have been demands for the legalisation of abortion, which go beyond the competence of the European Parliament. The statutory regulation of artificial termination of pregnancy is the exclusive competence of EU Member States. Moreover, if we know that there is no agreement between them on this issue today, then neither this House nor its committees simply have a mandate to make recommendations to our partners on this matter. With the exception of Azerbaijan, the countries of the Eastern Partnership have strong Christian roots, and such a report may have a negative impact on the perception of the EU as such and ultimately a deterioration in relations with each other.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. “I did not support the report on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries. Although all of these countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine) have women's rights and gender equality enshrined in their constitutional and legal order, real assertion of women in public and political life is still very difficult. The report calls for equal access to power, participation of women in anti-corruption programs, but also better access to microloans. However, the report also contains a number of problematic areas, including, in particular, calls for ratification of the Istanbul Convention by all these countries, as well as calls for mandatory quotas for political functions. As a long-term opponent of these artificial measures to achieve gender equality, as well as an opponent of the legal incompatibility and ideologisation of the Istanbul Convention, I decided to abstain from the final vote for these reasons.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: I voted in favour of the Gabriel report because I endorse the proposals to improve the situation of women in the Western Partnership States. It should be stressed that women's rights and gender equality are enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of the six Eastern Partnership countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Nevertheless, and despite this, social and economic discrimination and gender stereotypes continue to persist and prevent women from further inclusion in the labour market and political decision-making processes. I therefore support the call for equal access to power and women's representation at all levels of governance, and I would like to highlight the call for the exchange of best practice between the EU and its partners in promoting women's political participation.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support Mariya Gabriel's report especially because of the very sensitivity of this topic. Women are oppressed all over the world today and in many things. This year, the EP adopted a proposal for a resolution on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership, particularly taking into account gender equality as one of the main principles underlying the European Union. There is also the Convention on Fundamental Human Rights, but also other documents, rules, resolutions, drafts, etc. Neighbourhood stabilisation is one of the key objectives of the foreign policy of the European Union and the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) with the main task of ensuring security, peace, stability and prosperity. In this regard, we must not forget even the role of women. Women play a significant role in building peace around the world and have had it for a long time. The fact is that today they are often discriminated against, marginalized and oppressed. Because the Eastern Partnership (EAP) is one of the two main branches of the ENP based on the principles and laws of international law, the fundamental values of democracy, fundamental human rights, and we must not leave out the importance of gender equality and women's rights.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on Women's Rights in Eastern Partnership countries.
