The report assesses the position of women in various key areas and finds that Eastern Partnership countries are still lagging behind in integrating women, particularly those in the poorest and outermost areas and members of marginalised groups to equal access to power centres and equal representation of women at all levels of governance and decision-making. Therefore, I support projects and programmes financed by the European Neighbourhood Instrument aimed at women's organisations in the Eastern Partnership countries and contribute to raising awareness and addressing the problems faced by women in these regions.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the statements of vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Dear colleagues, I am very pleased to welcome President Juncker and Prime Minister Fico for the signing of the Joint Declaration on the EU's legislative priorities in 2017. This is the first time that our three institutions have agreed on a list of legislative procedures to be given preferential next year. Together we want to strive to make progress on the projects contained in the declaration next year, and if somehow, ideally, the projects will be completed. Finding an agreement between the three institutions was no easy task and required a great deal of compromise from all sides. The European Parliament has fought hard to include the deployment of workers and the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and tax evasion in the list of these priorities. Ultimately, we have stated, at least in the text, that progress on these issues is imperative. I would like to emphasise that this progress must be concrete and not just end in solemn declarations. In particular, the fight against tax evasion and the improvement of the Posting of Workers Directive are issues that directly affect the concerns of our citizens. Allow me to clarify some reservations about this statement at this point. Adopting such a declaration does not mean abandoning the prerogatives of the European Parliament in relation to legislative procedures, or that we hastily or hastily and without proper democratic control by our Parliament. It does not mean that work on the other projects not included in this declaration will stop or will not continue. On the contrary, a lot of work on important legislation is already is underway and will continue, as well as logically monitoring the proper implementation of the laws we have adopted. The aim of this Interinstitutional Agreement on better lawmaking is to make legislative procedures more transparent and efficient. The aim of the joint declaration, which is part of this agreement, is to reach agreement on where we need to deliver concrete results and what we can deliver realistically in the time ahead. That is what citizens expect: a Union that delivers concrete results and strives to make citizens' lives better where it is possible. That is why the three Presidents of the institutions — Mr Fico, Mr Juncker and myself — are signing this joint declaration. Ladies and gentlemen! We are opting for an agenda which, if signed here today, should indeed be given priority by all three institutions. This is a huge step forward. I would like to reiterate here that this has also been accepted by the Council for the first time. Our task now is to make this declaration a reality. We as Parliament are relying on the loyal cooperation of the three institutions — the Commission, Council and Parliament, as provided for in the Treaty. And we are betting on the constructive cooperation of the Presidencies of Malta and Estonia, which I hope will work with us in the same constructive way as the Slovak Presidency has done over the last six months. What I am particularly pleased about is the great presence, above all, by the Members who have been discussing the importance of this joint declaration over months. Wherever they are now, I wish all these colleagues all the best.

name: Robert FICO
text: Council. — I am very pleased to be here for such an important event, because it is, to some extent, an historic moment, because it is during our Slovak Presidency of the Council of Europe that we are signing the first agreement to the three institutions of the Union — Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the Commission — on the common main the legislative priorities of the Union for the following year. Excuse me for a personal comment, I do not need Members of the European Parliament to do this, but it seems to me that this is such a serious matter that they should have been sitting here. At least when signing such an agreement. I repeat, of course, I don't need their presence. I consider the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2017 as an important tool for increasing the efficiency and transparency of internal processes in the Union, especially in a sphere such as legislation. In addition, now full of Euroscepticism and criticism, it is also essential that the institutions work together, constructively and complementally. I consider its orientation towards the citizens of the European Union as the greatest contribution of this Joint Declaration. Initiatives identified as key, such as employment, social issues and security, are directly affected by them. Our next task will be to deliver tangible results on these topics and to present them clearly. That's what people expect, that's what they need. Of course, the essential prerequisite for success is the rigorous fulfillment of the priorities set. I believe that the regular evaluation of the implementation of our joint declaration will make a great contribution to this. Because countless targets have already been set and many documents signed, which often remained only on paper. By regularly monitoring the progress of the various initiatives set at the highest level, directly by the presidents of the three institutions, we will ensure that the Joint Declaration does not become just another such declaratory document. And I believe that as early as March, you and my Maltese colleague as President of the Council will be able to present the first concrete results of our joint work. Ladies and gentlemen, the declaration we are signing today demonstrates that we are interested in a different approach to solving problems within the Union. During the Slovak Presidency of the Council of the European Union, we have taken responsibly, respectfully and made every effort to bridge the critical period in which the European Union is located. I believe that the Bratislava Process has also made a significant contribution to the kick-start and implementation of the new procedures that the European Union currently needs. In this way, I would like to thank for the support of the other Member States, as well as the other EU institutions, and wish us all a lot of commitment, perseverance and a sense of belonging in our work together.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the European Commission. — Dear Mr President, Robert. This is an important moment. That is why I also understand that the capacity of the plenary is hardly enough to welcome here all those who have a first and priority interest in this agreement. I am glad that this agreement has been reached. The first time that the three Presidents of the three institutions have gathered together to establish our common guidelines for the next parliamentary year in the House. This is a good moment for the European Parliament.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr. Juncker. I would ask the two Members to join me in signing this document now. (The three Presidents signed the Joint Declaration)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the assessment of the Slovak Presidency (2016/2790 (RSP). I would like to point out that the Conference of Presidents has decided that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this item and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Robert FICO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. — Back in July, I spoke about the fact that Europeans today take the achievements of European integration as peace, travel without passports, the opportunity to pay with one currency or choose the country in which they want to live and work for granted. Worse, though, that many in Europe believe that this complete self-evident would exist without the European Union. And even that without the European Union, we could be significantly better off. Let us be the truth, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is in the most difficult crisis since its inception. However, it is not an external threat crisis; it is a crisis from the inside, expressed primarily by the mistrust of the people and the loss of authority of the European elites. The debate on the future of the Union has turned fundamentally during this year. Ask the European if he knows which country should join the European Union closest. He will tell you that he does not know, but that he knows very well which country should come out of the European union. Nowhere in the world, ladies and gentlemen, there is no grouping of countries even a little similar to the European Union. We've all taken the hardest path. On the one hand, we respect a number of national specificities. We hold on to our own national identities, but at the same time we have transferred a number of fundamental powers to joint administration. Today, we have a duty to return to the root. To ask ourselves whose powers and why the nation states have renounced in favour of the whole, and whether today we are not making a mistake precisely in moving away from these roots and paying attention to themes that are subordinate, irrelevant and, instead of joining together with common interests, divide Europe. With a unique project, ladies and gentlemen, which does not exist anywhere in the world, today we are reprehensibly gambling. To stop this gamble, let's just tell ourselves what our roots are in. They are in economic cooperation, they are in common security, they are in peace. Let us not, please, force people other than these fundamental topics, because if they do not identify with them and if they do not believe them, they will turn their back on the Union for good. The Slovak Republic took over in July this year the presidency with the ambition to respond to the situation. The first clear step forward was the Bratislava Summit, as it kicked off a long-delayed, absolutely necessary debate on how to make the Union better, safer and more efficient. What actually happened in the Union and what is happening in it today? What do we expect from the Union? How do we see her future? What did we fail at and why? And by discussing these issues, we started the so-called Bratislava process on 16 September, which is expected to culminate next March on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome. But part of the truth is also that, ladies and gentlemen, we are putting the Union at risk ourselves and often threatening it with the intra-political agendas of the Member States. For example, by holding referendums that are intra-politically motivated, but it is obvious that their results have a pan-European impact and suddenly become something that I could name as a problem for all of us. If this trend continues, the Union will be employed by internal policy in the Member States, we will be forced to seek steady solutions, compromise with our own principles, all at the expense of the credibility of the EU. If it were to continue this way, I believe that we will lack the political energy and, with it, the determination to tackle the fundamental problems facing the Union as a whole. I also want to call on European leaders here in the European Parliament to stop addressing their domestic agenda at the expense of the European Union. We all know well, but we don't want to admit it, that the referendum in the UK was a pure intra-political agenda that politicians failed to handle. We all know that the referendum in Italy was a pure intra-political agenda that has not been mastered. But the consequences of such decisions, for example in a possible referendum on whether or not Italy should remain in the euro area, would be absolutely catastrophic for the European Union and ideas. So once again, I call on European leaders to stop addressing their domestic agenda at the expense of all of us here in Europe. The current crisis in the Union we would should consider it a good impetus to take action leading to a more transparent Union. In turn, the current crisis of trust of our citizens represents an appropriate opportunity to create a more understandable and sincere communication bridge between the political elites and the European public. It is alarming that, according to recent surveys, up to 57% of young Europeans feel that they are marginalised and excluded from economic and social life as a result of the crisis in their country. We — political leaders — are here to give our people not only hope, but the certainty that we can tackle the crisis. That, despite the unpredictability of the external environment, we have control over our direction. In doing so, we must build on the strengths of our community. The European Union as a peaceful port, where peace, democracy, the rule of law, human rights, human dignity, freedom and solidarity are fundamental and timeless pillars of our coexistence. But also the European Union as a modern hub for digital progress and innovation. The European Union as a conscious driver in the fight against climate change. The European Union as the largest provider of development aid in the world. The European Union is strong and actionable only if it is united. The Bratislava Summit also reached this conclusion. The European 27 is committed to collectively overcome and overcome current and future challenges. However, the process of reflection, however necessary, is not sufficient in itself. Without action, even the most beautiful idea remains worthless. Therefore, the Bratislava Summit was not just about reflection, but about concrete steps towards making the European Union more understandable and, on the other hand, providing its citizens with a safe living space. And when I talk about security, I do not mean only external and internal security, the fight against terrorism, but also economic and social security, job security, income or climate and environmental security. These are all the areas that suffer the citizens of the Union the most. Not a game with the words we want to change in the Treaties on the European Union. Not an endless debate about whether we want more or less Europe. A citizen of the European Union wants an economically strong European Union. A Union based on investments that will contribute to economic growth and the creation of new jobs. When I stood before you in July, I said that if we wanted to have such a Union, we must make better use of the available financial instruments. Our ambition has come true. Today, thanks to the great cooperation of the Council and the European Parliament, we have the European Union budget for 2017, which is flexible, balanced and above all reflects our current priorities. That's very good news. After all, thanks to the budget adopted next year, for example, we will increase the resources to support economic growth and employment by 12%. We will also be better equipped to deal with migration and its causes, as well as to increase the security and border protection of the European Union. Citizens are also calling for new investment opportunities in the Union. I am therefore very pleased that the extension of the duration and financial capacity of the European Fund for Strategic Investments has moved closer to reality. By encouraging the use of public finances, we will give the necessary impetus to private investment that can bring new jobs. A citizen of the European Union also wants to have a job so that he can take care of himself and his loved ones without fear. Already today, the single market creates many new jobs and makes our daily lives easier. By completing the Digital Single Market, we can open up a large number of other opportunities. That is why I am delighted that we have managed to make significant progress on this agenda. For example, unjustified geographical blocking will perhaps soon become a thing of the past. We will help both consumers and sellers. Discrimination on grounds of nationality, residence or place of residence does not have its place in the Union. The free movement of European Union citizens must also apply to digital space in today's world. And this also applies when removing roaming charges. In addition, in order to exploit the full potential of the single market, we need an affordable one, a stable and sustainable supply of clean energy. We can be moved to this end by the Energy Union. Even during the last days of our Presidency, we are working together to move the Union further in this area as well. An ambitious and effective climate policy is also an integral part of the Energy Union. By ratifying the Paris Agreement, the European Union has confirmed the world leader in the fight against climate change. We have also sent an important message outwardly that when it comes to global challenges, we are able to take responsibility and work closely together. One such challenge is, of course, migration. We already know that the migration crisis is neither a seasonal nor a regional issue, but a global problem. And although our views on tackling it sometimes differ, a citizen of the European Union wants to know that we are able to offer constructive common action. I am pleased that we have shown in the last period that if we want to, we can also reach a consensus here and move this agenda forward. The European Border and Coast Guard, which, thanks to the rapid and effective cooperation of the European Parliament and the Council, started its activities on 6 October. The issue of responsibility and solidarity is also closely linked to migration. I know that these concepts have evoked diverse emotions in recent months. However, I believe that we all agree that every Member State must, without hesitation, give a helping hand if necessary. At the same time, however, I believe that we should take into account the real possibilities, capacities and capabilities of the individual Member States. And I am pleased that we have shown at a minimum in recent months that we are able to speak openly on this difficult subject. This is also the case with the Slovak Presidency's proposal concerning so-called effective solidarity. I hope that this concept will be one of the elements of the mosaic in the reform of the Common European Asylum System. However, we also have other challenges. In addition to protecting the external borders, we must ensure the functionality of Schengen, work closely with third countries, in particular transit countries and countries origin of migrants and eliminate the causes of migration. Progress on the creation of the European Fund for Sustainable Development should also help to do so. It aims, in particular, to address the root causes of migration by creating jobs, promoting investment and facilitating sustainable development in partner countries. Ladies and gentlemen, a citizen of the European Union wants to feel stability. In the current uncertain world, the Union should symbolise a fundamental foothold in the eyes of the citizen. In order to truly be a stable, safe and prosperous place to live, we need to have good relationships with neighbours as well as distant allies. And we need to be substantially more sovereign when it comes to some foreign policy topics. I will raise a question that can become a reality if, for example, an American adeministry changes its mind on sanctions against the Russian Federation, how we will replicate this stance. That's where it turns out whether or not we are truly sovereign in these views. Equally, we have a big problem if there is what the US administration suggests, and that is a very low presence, engagement in the European space. At the same time, I believe that we will successfully continue the concrete implementation of the Warsaw Declaration of EU and NATO Leaders on strengthening the strategic cooperation between the two organisations. Among other things, an effective enlargement policy leads to better resilience of the Union. It is this that is crucial to fostering transformation and consolidating stability in South-Eastern Europe. To this end, new chapters have been opened in the accession process with Montenegro and Serbia, and positive developments have also occurred when Bosnia and Herzegovina is registered as a member of the Union. It must be our interest that political and economic reforms continue to take place in all candidate countries that bring them closer to the Union and strengthen the rule of law. Free, fair and balanced trade based on reciprocity and mutual benefits is also crucial for the internal and external stability of the Union. Adoption of Agreement about free trade with Canada is an excellent example of this. This modern and ambitious agreement will not only strengthen the economic position of the Union, but will also open up new business opportunities for our citizens. Ladies and gentlemen, the only answer to the current wave of Euroscepticism is to approximate the sense, substance and real achievements of the European integration project through concrete results. Otherwise, we will open up space for different interpretations and speculation of truth to anti-European politicians. In this context, we probably have another major challenge coming from next spring — to ensure that the process of the UK's exit from the European Union is transparent with the full involvement of the Member States, and I will add, although these words have already raised criticism that negotiations must lead to conclusions that pays to remain a member state of the European Union. If negotiations show that it is not worth being a Member State of the European Union, the negative mood in Europe threatens to grow. And this must be avoided, because we can set an incredibly dangerous example to countries where Euroscepticism may be very strong. That is why the Slovak Presidency has made every effort to send a positive boost to the European public through its work and results. That's why we tried with all our strength to deliver tangible results that have an impact on the ordinary life of each of us. Our aim was not only to prevent further fragmentation in the Union, but also to reassure our citizens that the European Union is a project that has a future. I want to assure you that the responsibility we felt at the beginning of our Presidency that this same responsibility remained unchanged. I wish the incoming Maltese Presidency good luck and determination to fulfil its own priorities. I believe that the incoming Presidency will move us significantly forward in achieving our common objectives and, at the same time, I would also like to thank the Netherlands for its excellent cooperation within the trio.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the European Commission. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank our Slovak friends very warmly for a successful first presidency. In particular, I would like to congratulate Prime Minister Robert — finally, I am tutoie you because we are alone — and Ivan, who have been the workers' ankles of this presidency. Among the great achievements of the Slovak Presidency is the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Corps. One of the great achievements of this Presidency is the fact that we have been able to agree on the European directive on terrorism and on the systematic control of external borders. One of the major successes of its presidency will be the nearing completion directive on firearms, whose level of ambition is obviously below the Commission's more ambitious proposals, but this is a very real progress and I know how hard the Presidency has worked on it, just as it has done its best to ensure that we can agree on trade defence instruments. This is a great success of the Chair. For the rest, Mr President, I would have liked to debate, but since those with whom we could debate are absent — but I would like to thank the Members of Parliament who are present — I will have circulated my written speech.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: As you wish, Mr President of the Commission.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the European Commission, it is true that Slovakia took over the rotating presidency of the Council at a time that was particularly difficult, but the Slovak Presidency has not weakened, and it has been able to move forward on issues concerning our on behalf of my group, i would like to congratulate you on behalf of my group. Despite the reluctance of some Member States, a solid budget has been voted, with more than EUR 157 billion in commitments, a budget that we believe is still too minimalist, but most of which has been preserved, and on which we have been able to make improvements. Extended Juncker Plan, strengthened border security budget, increased youth guarantee, fight against tax evasion undertaken, posting of workers underway, modernization of trade defence instruments are a number of important advances. There is no growth without industry, and industry has also been at the heart of your presidency. It must continue to be, because it is the foundation of our current and future economy, and we need an ambitious industrial policy to safeguard our jobs and encourage innovation in new technologies. In this regard, carbon market reform is progressing, it will enable the development of low-carbon technologies to reduce the effects of climate change. The European Space Strategy is launched, it is a sector full of extraordinary possibilities in terms of applications and services. Defence too, where lines move to better cooperate at European level and involve each Member State in the defence effort. Finally, the railway sector: we have voted on a number of provisions in this framework to improve passenger transport, but it also means making our suppliers benefit European countries have made many advances in this area. Advances also in digital — you have said it very well — with clear commitments on ending roaming charges, while preserving investments. The quality of networks and access to the Internet remain major concerns for all Europeans. As far as energy is concerned, security of gas supply has been and will be a central topic of our discussions. Regional cooperation and the exchange of information must be improved, and European solidarity must be improved. I am also pleased that Slovakia has made it possible to continue and strengthen the work undertaken by the Dutch Presidency on access to innovative medicines for patients. I was pleased to see the fight against Alzheimer's and antibiotic resistance appear at the top of your agenda. In particular, the Slovak Presidency reiterated the central role of the vaccine as a preventive tool, particularly useful in preventing antibiotic abuse and the dangers it creates. I have only one little regret, but only a little personal regret: no agreement has yet been reached on the new regulation on veterinary medicinal products, it is a pity, because antibiotic resistance is still one of our priorities. I have accepted your call, your call for more community spirit, your call to fight against national selfishness. I hope that it will be heard, in any case thank you for all the concrete measures that you have been able to put in place and which — I hope — will be heard and understood by our fellow citizens, in order to fight against the demagogy of some who want to show that the European Union is not moving forward. In any case, thank you, the results are palpable and what I want is that we can communicate on what you have succeeded.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — You know best, Prime Minister, how much effort the last two governments under your leadership have devoted to preparing the Presidency. With how much tension we watched the referendum in the UK. Its results affected the functioning of the whole EU, but also influenced the programme of the Slovak Presidency. We can balance today. MEPs from various political groups, committees and different countries have appreciated that the results of the Slovak Presidency are very positive. Even today, it sounded. Prime Minister, please give our thanks to the entire team led by Ivan Korček, who was still sitting here and everyone remembers his face. Of course, also to the Ministers, the Secretary of State and the expert team. I must also highlight the political maturity, correctness and joint efforts of more than 90% of Slovak representatives in the European Parliament. Thank you, dear colleagues, that you also cared for the Slovak Presidency to be successful — this is how you behaved. At the Bratislava Summit in September, all prime ministers or presidents sent a clear message: that the European Union is the only alternative for each of them. This message has tremendous power. We managed to adopt the so-called Bratislava road map, which aims to bring Europe closer to its citizens. A great success is the rapid ratification of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. With the advent of a new administration in the US, we are all very pleased that the Paris Agreement is already an internationally valid document. We also managed to ratify the EU trade agreement with Canada (CETA). This agreement will serve as a model for many other agreements. In a record short time, the EU budget for next year was agreed. We found the agreement exactly on the anniversary of the tender revolution in Slovakia — on 17 November at 4:30 a.m. This day is also an international student day. That is why it is symbolic that on this day we managed to put EUR 500 million into the EU budget in support of young people's employment. European Socialists and Democrats fought for this project the beginning. Over three years, with this initiative, we have reduced the number of unemployed young people in the EU by 1.6 million. In Slovakia we have reduced youth unemployment by almost half with this project. Fighting tax evasion and fraud, migration crisis, helping third countries not to flee, combating terrorism, new Border and Coast Guard project, strong social agenda, safe and cheap energy, digital Europe, wholesale prices for roaming services, help farmers, jobs and growth in Europe... that is just part of the agenda that we have moved significantly forward by common forces during the Slovak Presidency. Dear colleagues, the Slovak Presidency is ending. The relay is taking over Malta. We continue on our journey together. The goal remains the same: for people in Europe to live better and safer.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — I, too, would like to express my compliments for the good organisation of the Presidency of the Slovak Republic in the Council of the European Union. It turned out that Slovakia coped with this task and responsibility with honour, especially thanks to the work of several young diplomats, many of whom have returned from abroad and helped to make our country more visible. They were behind the organisation of individual events and conferences within the Slovak Presidency. I think our thanks mainly to them, we should be able to express it adequately to them, I hope it will be right. Prime Minister Fico, I agree with you that political correctness, as you have said, is harmful and prevents us from naming things as they really are. One of the important issues that we must clearly name is the question of Turkey in relation to the European Union. We are more concerned about this issue. Since the coup attempt in Turkey in July, there have been a number of steps that must be clearly unacceptable to the European Union. We need to be able to express it. We should not be afraid to say more clearly that freedom of the media is one of the fundamental democratic values of our Community, and the verbal or physical attacks on journalists, the closing of entire editorial offices, the arrests of people in Turkey clearly contradicts this. Similarly, it is with the unmissable persecution of the Kurdish minority, what is happening in Turkey. The similarly stated introduction of the death penalty by President Erdogan needs to be clearly condemned. I regret that a number of leaders of the Union, too, in our Presidency, lack the courage to do so. However, concerns about the end of the agreement between the European Union and Turkey over the migration crisis or economic and economic benefits cannot be a measure of the declared rejection of political correctness. And this applies to relations with all countries that massively violate fundamental human rights. I am pleased that, in the European Parliament, my colleagues and I have expressed our position on the accession negotiations with Turkey, and we have called on the European Commission to have them, in the current situation, country froze. We must not be blackmailed by Turkey or President Erdogan. I believe that, above all, the closure of the so-called “migration flows to Europe” has resulted in a halt to the migration flows to Europe. The Balkan Road and the agreement with Turkey have already reduced the still low number of migrants who wanted to go to Europe. So let us throw away this fear, let us also express a clear no to Turkey.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would also like to thank the Prime Minister for all the efforts that the Slovak Presidency has made in order not just to make it a success, but to address the issues that are still pending. If I may just point out two issues that I remember from your statement, one is that the domestic political agenda should not prevail over EU-related and common EU interests and affairs. I think that this is very important, but I must say that it still prevails and we see it on a daily or weekly basis. We see it in the Council and we see it in the Council groups: issues are addressed and suddenly an issue of so-called national interest always prevails, whether it is a question of addressing the opening up of the markets in railways, whether it is digital or whatever it is. In this respect, I think that we need to return to the roots, which in fact show the ability to address the issues and find a common basis. The second issue is that you spoke about the EU being subtle. If I may just add, I think that we would like to see an EU that is a strong player and that we still need to contribute to this in a major way. You also referred to the American presidential elections. There is perhaps a bit of uncertainty. We don’t yet know what the policies will be. We have heard a lot of statements that create concern – I would wait for the policies – and, at the same time, threats are expressed from time to time by Russia. These two issues are an invitation to the European Union to be that strong player and to be able to address the issues that are not dependent on the Americans nor on the Russians. We are focusing on the trade agenda. Of course we know what happened with TPP – we do not yet know what will happen with TTIP – but we do not have to wait. On the one hand, we can negotiate with the other countries but, at the same time, the new administration will be put into place and we should set a positive agenda. We should be the ones co-setting, if not setting, the agenda. I do not think that we can be caught unprepared in this respect. Reference was also made to the migration crisis - sometimes too little and too slow, but we are progressing, I agree with you; but I do not think we can hide the fact that what is happening today in Turkey is completely unacceptable. This is a question of our values, and I think that we can hardly continue accession negotiations with Turkey unless we see a real shift in the direction in which Turkey is heading. At the same time, I am in favour of setting the conditions – as we have said in the European Parliament – and reopening the negotiations once, let us say, the situation has progressed in that country. Apart from what I have said, I think that values are key. I must say that we need to apply the same measure to everyone. I am glad that you have signed the agreement with Cuba but, at the same time, I would like to see future agreements that have the conditionality - if they provide concessions - that at the same time, there is real motivation and progress in the countries concerned. Prime Minister, in conclusion, I agree with a lot that you have said. I think that you have had a new experience and that on these issues that you have expressed, and some that I have added, we need recognition, champions in the Council to move beyond marginal – and sometimes very partial – national interest.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Prime Minister, President of the European Commission, historically the first Presidency of the Slovak Republic has come at a very difficult time. Although it looked like it would be forced to deal with the aftermath of David Cameron's irresponsible policies and Brexit, Slovaks managed much more than generally expected of them. In the context of Brexit, for example, they have managed to tame initial strong passions and largely calm the situation and relations with the UK. At the beginning of this half year, I presented the belief that this Presidency will see the European Union that the Visegrad Four countries are not enemies of Europe. I reiterate that we also want to live in peace and prosperity, but we have our political specifics and ask that it be respected. We are not non-solidarity, we are not irresponsible solitaires. We're not the ones who leave when times are mean. It is sad, but from a media point of view this presidency has been talked about especially because of scandals, but other aspects of a very complex period have not been addressed. Slovak diplomats managed to deal effectively with complicated problems compared to other presidencies and avoided internal political disputes. Thanks to considerable efforts, the Slovak side managed to ensure that farmers now have a chance for a transparent and commercial environment without unfair practices. I see this as a great achievement important for the future of the whole sector and for the sustainable development of the European Union. The Slovak Presidency has moved some important issues to denouement and has proved that even a small country can do much important work. Of course, I am far from agreeing with all the actions of this Presidency, especially in connection with the CETA and TTIP commercial treaties. I don't really consider it to be a chance or hope. It's the wrong concept of international trade that will fall upon our citizens. But at the same time, I believe it managed to dispel the initial panic that circulated in the couloirs before your presidency, Prime Minister. I want to reiterate at the moment, that countries from Central and Eastern Europe refuse to be taken as a second-category country, and I sincerely hope that the Slovak Presidency has proved to you, colleagues and colleagues, that we are not them. Finally, I would like to appreciate Prime Minister Fico, who managed to form a functional coalition for this presidency very quickly after the election, despite having health complications. Prime Minister, thank you for showing that we — like us, smaller countries — can be proud and can do a good job, and thank you also to your people who have been good allies in Europe Parliament in individual negotiations.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, I think you are right. Our citizens are expressing concern and mistrust towards the European Union when it is not frankly growing anger, and the referendum that took place in the United Kingdom at the outset of your presidency is the clearest demonstration of this. No wonder, of course, when a quarter of Europeans face the risk of poverty and social exclusion and many others say that they may be the next to have to go into the door. Many attribute all this to the European Union. Faced with that, you say, we need a new impetus, and you are right. But where was that new momentum during your presidency? I am still seeking to call into question an inept macroeconomic policy, which makes competition between workers with each other, a completely manic pursuit of free trade agreements and completely unreasonable budgetary austerity the key words of its policy. I am still looking for the beginnings, the impetus of a fiscal and social Europe, without which monetary union is doomed to failure. You were talking about a leading European Union in climate change, well that is no longer the case. Whereas in 2004, the European Union, which accounted for 30% of global GDP, invested more than half in renewable energy, today we still account for one-fifth of the world's GDP, but we account for only 17% of investment in renewables. We have become poor followers. From all this, of this fairer, more sustainable and more democratic Europe, I find no trace in the Bratislava process, which seems to be clinging to a Europe of defence as the solution to all evils. As for migration, I must acknowledge that during the Dutch Presidency, and then under the Presidency Slovak, the key words of migration policy have become “dismissal” and “keep at bay”. Of course, Prime Minister, it's not you. It is not you who said that you are not obliged to welcome all those at risk. It is not you, it is Mr Theo Francken, the Minister for Migration in Belgium, a minister Marine Le Pen would certainly not deny. However, I will repeat one of your quotes, which is that the idea that a multicultural Europe is a failure and that the natural integration of people who have a different way of life, thought, another culture and, above all, another religion, is not possible. Mr Fico, I tell you that if this multicultural Europe is impossible, then it is the European Union that is impossible, because the European Union, you see, it is a Union that has decided to make the motto 'unity in diversity'. The idea of the European Union is precisely to bring people living on a very small continent with different ways of thinking, lifestyles, languages and indeed religions. If you say that this society is impossible, it means that you even say that the European Union is impossible and with that we will never agree.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, on behalf of the EFD Group. Today we are discussing the Presidency of the Council of Slovakia. What luck — we might not have known anything else! The EU is in its biggest crisis, and this is actually the time when great action is needed, especially when it comes to regaining citizens' confidence. Mr Fico, however, the reputation precedes corruption. Your Presidency is overshadowed by EU financial scandals, for which you probably do not have to fear any consequences, because, like Mr Schulz, you are in the right party family, that of the Social Democrats. But that can't be exactly! These allegations must be clarified, at least half as closely as the accusations against UKIP or the Front National here. At least. It is dishonesty that we are applying double standards here. And that's exactly what makes people lose confidence. If you want to regain confidence if you want to promote more to the EU, then we should start here and, in particular, clarify these accusations that are being made to you.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to you colleagues and to the left-wing premier of Slovakia, who is a socialist and who is acting President of the Council, who has come here to make us the moral, right to him, who is not listening to me, I want to ask some things. First, why does Italy have to take in hundreds of thousands of illegal fake refugees every year and Slovakia doesn't? Why? Second, why does Slovakia receive much more money from Europe than it pours and instead Italy sends much more money to Brussels every year than it receives back? Italians have given Europe sixty billion euros more in the past decade than the money they received from Brussels. Then I make you a proposal, which is my proposal but also the proposal of millions of Italians. You take the illegal immigrants who landed in Italy because of the Renzi government and the European Union and we take our money back, because that money is needed for our earthquake-takers, for the our businesses, for our seniors who do not arrive at the end of the month. Italians are tired of the sermons and lies of this Europe, tired of being invaded by hordes of illegals, tired of having to pay for you. We don't want any more illegals in our country and especially we want our money back, all our money, right now.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Mr President, a six-month Presidency cannot be expected to find a solution to the EU's main issues, but it is to move forward in the right direction. Perhaps the most important issue in the Union is the migrant situation, in which Member States are best shared by the question of compulsory quotas. Prime Minister Fico has a strong opinion on this, Head of Government of Slovakia. In September, he declared that the mandatory refugee quota was dead. Well, if that is true, he is currently among us as a zombie, walking dead, because at the EU summit you stated that the existing resettlement programmes need to be accelerated and this week you are dealing with how to implement the principles of responsibility and solidarity. I hope that the responsibility also includes those who sent an invitation letter not to refugees, but to migrants in the hope of a better life, and solidarity includes not only the absurd 250 000 euros that should be paid for an unaccepted migrant, but also for example, in the case of Hungary, the EUR 500 million he has spent on protecting Schengen borders.

name: Robert FICO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. — I am very pleased that there is a majority view that the Slovak Presidency has produced concrete positive results for the Union over 6 months. And I believe that we have also managed to fulfill the slogan Good idea Slovakia. However, I would like to say that these results could not be achieved without the traditionally excellent cooperation with the European Parliament. And the European Parliament has been a difficult partner, and I therefore want to thank the European Parliament on behalf of the entire Slovak Presidency, and I would like to thank you personally, Mr President, dear Martin, for the cooperation that has been very correct and very open. Of course, it has often been very important to have the European Commission behind your back, and I think it will also be confirmed by the President of the European Commission if I say that our relations at the professional level have been, are and, I believe, will continue to be absolutely professional and in the interests of the matter. That is why I would like, because I know that without leadership, no institution works, to thank you directly, Jean-Claude, for the cooperation we felt throughout the Presidency, as well as your entire Commission. At the same time, I would like to wish my colleagues from Malta every success in taking over the Presidency's relay, and at the same time I believe that in their work, as well as in cooperation with you, the European Parliament, they will be served by the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2017, which we signed today. Once again, thank you very much to everyone for their contributions to the debate.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Prime Minister Fico. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. — The programme of the Slovak Presidency of the Council of the European Union was based on four main priorities. It was an economically strong Europe, a modern internal market, a sustainable migration and asylum policy and a globally engaged Europe. Wide-ranging decisions, such as the ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement or the CETA Trade Agreement, the fight against tax avoidance and the establishment of the European Union budget for 2017, were also included in the term of office of the Slovak Presidency of the Council of the European Union. The Presidency also called for changes to the Stability and Growth Pact. Not every point of this comprehensive programme has been convincingly implemented, although Slovakia can also be given a pioneering role in certain respects. The Presidency's programme was undermined by three principles. The first principle was to achieve concrete results, the second to prevent the fragmentation and fragmentation of the Member States of the European Union, and the third to restore citizens' confidence in the European project. The Slovak Presidency is facing major challenges at a time. After Brexit, it became clear that there must be a debate on the future of the Union, solutions to the ongoing migration crisis must be found and the integrity of the Schengen area must be restored. However, these problems cannot be resolved within a presidency.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. - I have a positive view of our Presidency overall. In Brussels, the deployment and work of our diplomats on many politically sensitive topics was certainly felt. From my point of view, this has been shown primarily on issues relating to the EU's external relations. I am pleased that the European Fund for Foreign Investment has been launched during our Presidency, the issue of visa liberalisation for Ukraine and Georgia has shifted, or active work on enlargement issues in the Western Balkans region. Here, many of our diplomats deserve real praise. The presidency has managed to tighten up a number of politically sensitive issues, such as the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and preparing to complete the 2017 Roaming Deal Agreement. This happened despite the turbulent situation in the Union and despite the events accompanying the Presidency at home. I am a little sorry that during our Presidency we did not take full advantage of the opportunity to communicate with the public on the fundamental issues and benefits of the European Union for Slovakia.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. — The Slovak Presidency (not only) has done a piece of honest work under the agenda of the IMCO Committee and I would like to thank Slovak colleagues for this. Although several unprecedented events have come to the forefront of political decision-making during the last half year in the EU, led by the decision of the citizens of Great Britain to appear from the Union, the presidency was also done within the framework of a so-called proper, possible not so visible, but no less important agenda. One of the stated priorities of the Presidency was to contribute to combating unfair trade practices in the food industry. Following the EP resolution on this topic, the Presidency in Bratislava held an international expert conference on how to strengthen the position of farmers in the food chain at which a number of delegates expressed their belief about the need to adopt European legislation. Not only the EP, but also a number of Member States invited the Commission to submit a proposal to straighten relations between producers, suppliers and food vendors. As rapporteur of the revision of the regulation on cooperation of supervisory authorities in the field of consumer protection, I also welcome that the Presidency has worked extensively to discuss this extensive regulation, and Slovak colleagues in the Council managed to gain support among the Member States for the proposal. Its adoption can substantially increase consumer protection in the internal market, which was, after all, one of the specific objectives of the SR under the historically first Presidency of that country.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. — Although this was Slovakia's first ever Presidency of the Council of the EU, it is important to acknowledge that this small country has handled this difficult challenge very well, and during a period of turbulent events in the world and in the Union itself. Among the biggest successes of the Slovak Presidency are the launch of the long-awaited European Border and Coast Guard, which aims to provide a more effective response from the Union to illegal immigration issues. Slovakia also managed to negotiate the EU budget for 2017 smoothly despite the resistance of some states, which threatened even to veto it. As a success, Bratislava can also sign the October 30 CETA agreement with Canada, which allowed it to be temporarily applied until ratified. For the Committee on Agriculture, which I chair, it is particularly important to adopt Council conclusions on unjust practices in the food supply chain, providing, inter alia, for the possibility of legislative action at Union level. In the European Parliament, we have called for such solutions for many years and now there is a real opportunity for action in this area. Referring to what the Slovak Presidency has failed to do, I think it has run out of greater determination in trying to bring Member States' positions in the area of refugees and migration policy closer together, which could raise new disputes in the future should the crisis escalate again.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The rotation of presidencies in the Council of the EU brings new challenges, new themes and momentum on the European political scene. Slovakia prepared for its presidency for a long time and responsibly. The programme was very ambitious, and when evaluating it, we can proudly say that the Slovak Presidency has done a piece of good, honest work for Europe. Under the guidance of the Minister for Finance, the 2017 budget was adopted with an increase in the Erasmus+ programme and the Youth Guarantee programme. Thanks to our efforts, the Paris Agreement on climate change has been ratified very quickly and successfully. Our success is also the conclusion of a trade agreement with Canada, with an important partner of the G7. More than 20 informal ministerial meetings and ministerial conferences have been organised under our Presidency. Bratislava, as well as other cities, also hosted almost 180 events at expert and working level. Many local governments, NGOs, schools, MEPs from Slovakia, who were present at presentations of various cultural, musical, theatre, exhibition, film or design projects. For the fact that Slovakia has been the centre of Europe for half a year, it is necessary to thank all those who have made the success of the Slovak Presidency.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - It is a pity that, during the debate on the Slovak Presidency, only a few Members were present in the Chamber during the speech of the Prime Minister. For I myself consider the Slovak Presidency a success, because we have managed what was expected of us: to broker agreements between the Member States in the Council of the EU and also between the Council and the European Parliament. It should also be realised that the most part of the Presidency's work is not seen by the public at all. Our people from the Permanent Representation in Brussels are behind it, with the Secretary of State Ivan Korčok in particular worthy of the great award. It is a pity that some of the irregularities concerning the accompanying events overshadowed what I consider essential: that Slovakia has managed to lead the main institution of the European Union competently and truly professionally. We may not yet have our own idea of what Europe should look like in the future, but we are very well versed in how it works today.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on the report on the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy by Josef Weidenholzer, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (2016/2219 (INI)) (A8-0355/2016).

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: rapporteur. — Mr President. Today is a very important day for human rights. We have awarded the Sakharov Prize to two great women, and now we are discussing the 2015 human rights report, which we will vote on tomorrow. Historians may refer to 2015 as a very crucial year. It was the year of the refugee crisis that sustainably challenged solidarity in Europe, and it was the year when Europe's dwindling role in foreign policy became increasingly apparent. It is not surprising that something has not really improved this year as far as the human rights situation is concerned. But I don't want to stop this fatalistic assessment. And because, especially in times of crisis, the foundations are supposed to be visible — and the foundation of the European Union, Europe, is democracy, the rule of law and human rights. The ECHR and the Charter of Fundamental Rights — these are the foundations, these are Europe's unique selling points. It is important that foreign policy makes this visible here too. The report therefore deals not only with the global human rights situation, but also, in particular, with the various instruments available to the EEAS. Like my predecessors Panzeri and Preda, I took a systematic approach. You do not want to list different occasions in different conflict zones. There is an annex to this, and we also have the very efficient instrument of urgent resolutions. I would therefore ask colleagues not to accept any amendments which call this principle into question again. It is a good thing that the Union is clearly committed to human rights. We have very important instruments: the European Union delegations, the human rights dialogues and the Special Representative for Human Rights. Stavros Lambrinidis has done an excellent job in 2015, as always, and he is a good, important ally of the European Parliament. Delegations are working very intensively, and we have always been able to see on missions the importance of human rights for the representatives of the Union. However, in the interests of the coherence and credibility of our human rights policy, it would be important for us to focus more on the increasing constraints of civil society. It's a great threat that spreads like a plague. The matter is simple: without strong civil society, there is no effective protection of human rights. It is therefore very important to strengthen this, as well as support for human rights activists who not only need legal advice, but also need to visit prisons and who should also be accompanied in court proceedings. The report also has substantive priorities. Migration and flight were particularly important — 2015 was very important in this context. We have also particularly addressed the issue of discrimination. What we have already stated in the Amsterdam Treaty: discrimination should be at the heart of our policy and should also be at the heart of human rights policy. It is of particular importance that there are consequences. Law enforcement and trade policy should be linked to human rights. The report has been debated very intensively. Experts and human rights organisations were called in. We had a total of 866amendments. I would like to thank the staff who have supported us in this. I am particularly grateful to the shadow rapporteurs for the constructive and pleasant working atmosphere.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur. As you know, we discuss our annual human rights reports twice a year, but if I look at the long list of debates we have had together in this Chamber over the last year, human rights have been at the centre of each and every European Parliament plenary. Even today, a few hours ago, we listened to our Sakharov Prize laureates, who I have just had the honour of meeting, saying that they look up to Europe as a symbol of humanity.  This is not simply an institutional duty that we fulfil. Our work on human rights lies at the core of our foreign policy. It defines our European Union and it defines who we are. Whatever we do concerns the real lives of real human beings. We do understand power politics and the great games of international affairs. Not only do we understand them, but we often play our part to shape them. But we never forget that everything we do is about real people. This is the European way in foreign policy. We are not naive and we are not cynical. In the global strategy we refer to principled pragmatism and that is our way. This will be even more important in the months and years to come. The decision by some countries to withdraw from the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court demonstrates that the pressure on the international system of global governance is going to be raised. There will be – there is already – a growing demand for a power that stands on the side of human rights. We are, more and more, an indispensable power – an indispensable power for human rights, for multilateralism, for a rules-based global order.  The report we are discussing today shows once again that all institutions of this Union stand on the same side. I am glad that you have shown your support not only for our Action Plan on Human Rights, but also for our Operation Sophia and for our new external investment plan. We agree on fundamentals, we agree on the vision, and we share the view that 2016 has been a very difficult year indeed for democracy and human rights. We are all convinced that there is no sustainable development without human rights, and there is no sustainable security without fundamental freedoms. This is what the global strategy calls resilience. Our states and our societies are strong only when democracy is strong, when the debate is free and open, when human rights are respected, when the space for participation is open and guaranteed, and participation itself is active and welcomed. Human rights abuses do not make a country more stable or more secure. On the contrary, they only make societies less resilient and weaken the legitimacy of institutions. This vision is already inspiring our actions in very concrete ways. Let me give a few examples. First, the report talks about our missions and operations and the link between security and human rights. The prevention of human rights abuses is indeed becoming a key focus, a key element for our work on security. The EU Action Plan on Human Rights says that our support for our partners’ security forces must always be consistent with the promotion of human rights. We are doing this in practice every single day, for instance also through my proposal of a European framework to support security sector reform. 2017 will be the year of a mid—term review for the Action Plan and we are already working on a daily basis to make it a meaningful review. Second, the report rightly focuses on civil society and the restrictions on freedom of expression. It is almost impossible to mention all the initiatives we have put in place to preserve and enlarge the space for pluralism and free debate. Some of you attended the annual EU—NGO Forum a few days ago in Brussels. You know our dialogue with civil society organisations is constant and intense, both in our region and worldwide. The EU4HumanRights campaign has raised awareness about human rights in Europe and beyond.  Let me thank in particular, as you did, our Special Representative Stavros Lambrinidis, who is here with me today, as he always is whenever we have these debates in this Chamber. His work is making a difference every single day for so many people and in particular for human rights activists and campaigners. You were talking about visits, dialogues and meetings – he is in strong and constant connection with me and with all our services and thus with many of you, and is our hand, our brain, our voice in handling difficult cases, in many cases with success and results of which we are proud. Thank you, Stavros. In 2016 the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights directly supported more than 250 human rights defenders and their families who were at risk because of their daily work.  On the third element, we are engaging constantly with our partners through dedicated human rights dialogues. I know that this is a delicate chapter of our work and I will start with the most delicate example. Yesterday in Brussels I met with Bruno Rodriguez, the Foreign Minister of Cuba. Our relationship with Cuba has entered a completely new phase and one of the first new steps we took was to start a dialogue on human rights. We have had two rounds of that – one in Europe and one in Havana – and I believe there is no other way to try to make a real difference than to engage constantly and tirelessly in trying to improve the situation on the ground, having frank and open discussions with our partners.  Finally, we are keeping human rights and the rights of women and children in particular at the core of peace talks and reconciliation processes. Syria is constantly on our minds, in these hours in particular as we are receiving terrible reports from the ground. Here I would like to take the opportunity in this debate to add my voice to that of the UN Secretary—General, who just a few hours ago underlined the obligation of all parties on the ground to protect civilians and abide by international humanitarian and human rights law, recalling that this is particularly the responsibility of the Syrian Government and its allies.  Those who perpetrate war crimes will be held accountable. The priority now, in these hours, is to protect civilians and guarantee them safe and monitored transit to a place of safety. We all know that it is also crucial – still in Syria, but in the future – to be working on protecting everyone’s rights through the transition, and in the transition, at the moment when a political process is finally put in place. But let me also mention a success story – as you did – and some positive examples: the peace deal in Colombia, an agreement for all the victims of conflicts that would provide a sound basis towards justice, reconciliation and reaching the truth. I am honoured that Juan Manuel Santos, the President of Columbia, was in Brussels with us yesterday on his first international visit after receiving the Nobel Peace Prize; together we launched the EU Trust Fund, precisely to accompany the implementation of the peace agreement in Colombia.  So let me conclude on a positive note. Yes, the situation of human rights in the word is very serious, but there are also success stories. Wherever things are moving in the right direction, the European Union is there, engaged directly through our funds, our delegations, our special representatives, dialogues and diplomacy. My message for you is the same one that I delivered to the NGOs a few days ago: we all need to be vigilant, we need to be critical where necessary, but we also need to amplify the success stories. We need to talk about the real people behind the numbers and beyond the budget lines. We need to show that the European Union is practically and concretely a force for human rights, a force for democracy and a force for good. We need our voice – your voice – to be heard on this too, more than ever.  (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur. Having also been rapporteur last year, I know that this is not an easy task. I would then like to emphasize the points contained in the opinion of the Committee on Development which I drafted this year. As you know, development, human rights and democracy are intrinsically linked, and I look forward to seeing these issues prominently in the report to be voted on tomorrow. Indeed, human rights, good governance, democracy and the rule of law are essential elements in eradicating poverty and inequality and, conversely, poverty and inequality endanger the enjoyment of human rights. In the Committee on Development, we welcomed the inclusion of a chapter on development in the 2015 Annual Report and hoped that it would become a constant practice. We also want to see a genuine synchronization between human rights and all our development cooperation, starting with the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. Human rights must, I believe, be a major cross-cutting element in achieving the goals of sustainable development. And I must also stress the paramount importance of Goal 16, aimed at guaranteeing peace, justice and integration in societies, since in the absence of peace, our development assistance cannot achieve its goals and respect for human rights cannot be ensured. Finally, as permanent rapporteur for policy coherence for development, I would like to stress the usefulness of this obligation under Article 208 of the Treaty for the realization of human rights.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. — Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, the Sakharov Prize is the soul of the European Parliament. It embodies the values on which the Union is founded: freedom, dignity, equality, respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy. It is a unique, effective and excellent instrument of policy coherence. I would like to thank all my colleagues for supporting the candidacy to which we have presented this award today, Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar. Thank you, to Nadia and Lamiya, for being shining lighthouses that illuminate the world. They are an example of resilience, which has not only inspired me, in my work as vice-president of the Sub-Commission on Human Rights, but all the people who fight for a fairer world. Nadia, you know that you have my unwaived commitment to bring your case to the International Criminal Court, because no crime against humanity must go unpunished. We, Europe, the world, need more Noadias, more Lamiyas. We need more Sakharov.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by thanking Mr Weidenholzer, who has succeeded in turning a flood of amendments and an original text into a consistent text, and which has been very open to cooperation with all shadow rapporteurs. The perspective of human rights cannot be observed in isolation or separately from other perspectives. It is of horizontal importance as a basis for all actions of the European Union. It is particularly important for all aspects of foreign policy, and for this reason too, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank you for your very good speech. We have a majority in this House that agrees that we cannot write a balanced report by picking out some examples of violations of human rights, whether by states or organisations. We have to describe our policy fundamentally, and we have succeeded in this case. We are also concerned about the increasing persecution of religions here in this House — including and especially my group — also about the persecution of Christian religions. This has been clearly demonstrated precisely in the attack on the Coptic Church. I should like to make one final comment, Mr President. Unfortunately, I was also as a (the President withdrew the speaker.)

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have witnessed this morning, with the awarding of the Sakharov Prize, how much work we still have to do. I would like to thank Mr Weidenholzer for his excellent work and I also welcome the commitment to the special representative Stavros Lambrinidis. This report must be seen as an important instrument for assessing European action in support of human rights and democracy and the report must be supportive to improve the our approach and adapt it to the specific areas of intervention. The annual report, due to the vastness of the topics covered, must necessarily use a thematic approach, without dwelling on individual newspaper cases but, at the same time, it must be able to provide clear indicators that can show where European action improved on the previous year and where the intended targets have not been met. With this report we need to be able to seriously assess the things we have done, especially with regard to certain areas, I think about trade agreements, and we need to use benchmarks and actions towards this direction precisely to build new visions regarding human rights. I think we have a lot to accomplish, to do, to do and we must do so by raising, substantially, the political level of our intervention on human rights. Our response must be to make Europe's citizens understand that less rights means less democracy and that cooperation with third countries in this field is also essential for us and for our future. We need to be consistent and ensure that human rights are respected both inside and outside the European Union and we must do so, this, with great energy, we must basically understand that human rights issue is an essential issue of all the policies of the European Union.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we are constantly reminded in this Parliament of the many atrocities and acts of human rights abuse that tragically occur throughout the world, such as in Aleppo right now as I speak. Only this morning, we heard the extremely moving testimonies of this year’s Sakharov laureates, Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar, from the Yazidi community. What they have experience under the brutal regime of ISIS is as evil an ideology as anybody could possibly imagine. These are personal stories, but they serve to illustrate the plight of millions of others who find themselves in similar circumstances across the globe.  Member States throughout the European Union each enjoy their own histories and historical trajectories of course. They have each move from autocracies in the past to democracy today, enshrining the rights of all over the few, and developing legal systems that have delivered equality before the law, albeit in very different timeframes. These are the principles that have delivered the civil and political freedoms and protections that we all enjoy today, along with many other economic and social rights. These are the values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and human rights, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, freedom of the press and expression. It is important that we recall that it is these fundamental values and other institutions that deliver the peace and prosperity we all see in Europe and the developed world today. It is also important that we continue to be a voice in advocating those values across other parts of the world, so we fully support the human rights report in the world as it is.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, today’s debate about human rights in the world comes at a time of growing pressure on the universality of human rights, from the banning and intimidation of civil society, to attacks on human rights defenders, journalists and bloggers, or restrictions on the free expression of LGBTIs, artists and those who demonstrate peacefully. The list is long and requires clear push-back that involves more leadership from Europe.  It is difficult to be proud of Europe when we watch Aleppo fall and bombardments by Russian and Assad’s planes being rewarded, when refugees fleeing this atrocious war are being fenced off, and international law and human rights are discarded when they get in the way of counterterrorism efforts or ‘managing’ migration. It is now more important than ever for us to stand unequivocally for the very values upon which our open societies are based and give meaning to those values globally. That means a more forceful and credible stance for the importance of and respect for human rights.  Young women, such as the Sakharov Prize winners who courageously fight the horrible violence caused by Daesh, have fled to Europe, but imagine the many, many, many who have spent years in refugee camps now, who have been married off with absolutely no perspective. What will we tell them? We cannot be complacent and must make sure that Europe remains a beacon of freedom, a safe haven for free thinkers and a meaningful representation of what universality of human rights is actually about. It is not only the right thing to do, but it is in our self-interest to offer perspectives for people who need them so desperately, such as in North Africa and the Middle East. I therefore urge you, as my final comment, to avoid deals like the one made with Turkey and now being copied with countries like Mali, in order to avoid a situation where the EU’s foreign policy becomes a mere instrument to manage migration without having a clear focus on the need to defend and protect human rights. That is what we should give much more attention to and prioritise in our foreign policy.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, I too would like to thank our rapporteur and his efforts to reconcile so many amendments. I am afraid, however, that the result will not be up to the challenges we should deal with in the field of human rights and their necessary universality, and how the European Union should act on this matter. I think we have never had such a long report. The longer it is, the more, there are contradictions, the less priorities are identified, and I'm sorry for that. I am particularly critical of the part that concerns migration. How can we unconditionally support readmission agreements, the Khartoum process or the Africa Trust Fund, when these agreements and procedures focus on countries where human rights are violated on a daily basis, as is the case in the Horn of Africa and the Middle East, and when these agreements are first and foremost decided on the basis of the number of those arriving to seek refuge on the soil of the European Union. What do the objectives of return policies, not sufficient, do in a human rights report? How does the flight forward in defence policy serve human rights? Moreover, despite the willingness not to target countries in particular, we still find the same obsessions dear to some in this Chamber and always the same forgotten. Not a word about the Gulf countries, not a word about Israel, even refusal to mention the States most concerned in Latin America. Thus, just yesterday, Guillermo Veldaño, a peasant trade unionist and defender of the right to water, was murdered in Colombia, where a quarter of Latin American human rights defenders and activists are murdered. So all this is not very satisfactory, and I want to reiterate once again my reservations on the appendix which lists a list of prisoners of consciousness. No, Madam High Representative, I do not share your optimism, I fear that all these contradictions... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. This year's Human Rights Report is both comprehensive and more progressive than before, in a number of important policy areas.
