Many thanks for this to the rapporteur, Mr Weidenholzer. Further demands can be found in the area of business and human rights in order to achieve greater legally binding obligations. Issues such as the use of armed drones, the fight against human trafficking and the protection of land rights also attracted more attention than in the past. Our report calls for coherence and continuity in human rights policy. With regard to the EU's refugee policy, however, we have to note that, both in 2015 and on an ongoing basis to this day, there is probably no policy area in which the EU failed so miserably because of this very requirement. Even in this parliamentary report, there was no majority criticism of the current outsourcing of European responsibility for the protection and care of refugees. The renunciation of a policy in accordance with human rights is to the detriment of those seeking help in Europe and is in stark contradiction with their own human rights. EU claims. Our report strongly calls for the fight against impunity. The International Criminal Court needs all our support in order to operate independently and efficiently. Now the governments of South Africa, Burundi and Gambia have decided to withdraw from the ICC. They are mainly concerned with exempting heads of state from prosecution — an extremely contradictory and unacceptable demand. It is to be welcomed that the President of Gambia is now considering withdrawing this decision. Finally, we have recently laid down stricter rules for the export of European goods that can be abused for torture or death penalty. But European rules alone are not enough. I therefore ask again to create a drive a comparable initiative on a global level.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as we discuss human rights, by virtue of my own Romany Gypsy heritage, I wish to highlight the issues facing our Roma Gypsy and Traveller communities. Anti-Gypsyism is a worrying global trend and has even been described to me by a leading human rights campaigner as the last acceptable face of racism today. The time has come to act beyond the usual platitudes and lip service; real action must be taken at Member State level. Every week, news reports highlight increasing attacks against our RGT communities, including murders taking place only last month. That is how serious the issue has become.  In my country, besides access to health care and education, there are many other issues facing our Gypsy and Traveller communities, not least the distinct shortage of both permanent and temporary stopping sites and a need for local authorities to live up to their legal obligations in this regard. Last year’s wicked changes to planning legislation, legally redefining the legal personality of a Traveller, would not have been allowed to happen to any other ethnic minority. Our government should hold their heads in shame.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the human rights situation in 2015, described in this report, has largely pointed out the shortcomings of European policy in this field. A number of programmatic documents, resolutions and treaties listed in this report condemn abuses in any form occurring in many corners of the world, but also across the European Union. Despite the legislative efforts made by competent international organisations, including European institutions and civil society, we cannot speak from year to year about a systematic and irreversible improvement in the human rights situation in the world. This shows that human rights mechanisms should be respected do not work as they should or have major deficiencies, particularly in the capacity for prevention and action. Human rights are a fluid concept, difficult to quantify and evaluate and often interpretable, especially out of bad will. I give you an example: respect for human rights is an area deeply linked to the justice system and education. In countries with corrupt and/or authoritarian regimes, these systems falsify human rights. Unfortunately, the European Union itself continues to have double standards in relations with countries where human rights are systematically violated. If these rights are just a “passe-partout” concept, at a declarative level, our role as a development vector will be neither recognised nor appreciated and ultimately will remain ineffective.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President! The global human rights situation — I would like to repeat here the question that Mrs Vergiat asked, because Mr Weidenholzer was not in the room right now: why are the Gulf States of Qatar and Saudi Arabia and Israel constantly excluded from these reports? I would like to mention one more thing: we are right to arouse the fact that the death penalty should be reintroduced in Turkey. But why do we allow the death penalty to be carried out on European soil? Why is it not pointed out that the US has a central office in Ramstein — that is, on German, on European soil — where people are killed by a mechanism via drones? The United States itself is giving 161 deaths. Human rights organizations speak of 1 100 people killed as collateral damage. Why do we not denounce this in the human rights reports and prevent European soil from executing death sentences?

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr President! I thank the rapporteur and his fellow co-rapporteurs for this difficult report. How does one document describe all human rights events for a whole year? This is an immensely difficult task, these more than 850amendments testify that we would like to accommodate all the other issues there. The year has been difficult due to human rights abuses, war, terrorism, violations of fundamental rights, particularly the right to live in different parts of the world, in particular the Middle East. Today we have awarded or awarded two women, two women Jasidas Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar with the Sakharov Prize: for freedom of thought, but also for determination to give testimony to the persecution of this nation. I would like to say that it is good that the report in Article 142 stresses the importance of the right to free religion as a human right and condemns any acts of violence or persecution for that reason. It's also good that the report in Article 148 notes that for years the most persecuted group in the world has been Christians. It's millions of persecuted and many who lose their lives. In Article 132, the report recalls that Parliament called and continues to call on members of the UN Security Council to recognize the crimes of Daesh on Christians, Jasids and other minorities as crimes against humanity, as crimes of genocide. Mr President! I think these are just some of the catalogue of these cases that we should be about... (The President answered the speaker's voice)

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate my colleague Josef Weidenholzer on the excellent work he has done with this very difficult report. The words of Nadia Murad and Lamiya Hayi Bashar resonate in this House still today and are a great responsibility for all of us. Last Saturday we commemorated World Human Rights Day. Sixty-eight years after member States joined the Universal Declaration. And sixty-eight years later, there's not very good news, I'm afraid. The Declaration remains painfully pending. This past year — 2016 — and 2015, which is the report addresses, have not been particularly good for human rights either. War crimes and crimes against humanity continue to occur and go unpunished. The International Criminal Tribunal, far from being strengthened, is being weakened because several countries were withdrawing from the Rome Statute. We are unable to enforce international humanitarian law, and attacks on hospitals, schools and humanitarian personnel are repeated every month. There is a virtually global trend towards greater repression against civil society, and humanitarian aid remains scarce and does not reach the whole world. But if there is something that will mark the Europe of 2015 is the refugee crisis. Never in history have there been so many refugees and displaced persons that we have not been able to care for. Europe, despite some efforts, has not been up to the top, mainly because of the responsibility of the Member States. Thousands of these refugees failed to survive. Thousands drowned in our Mediterranean Sea and yet, in spite of everything, and as we have heard here this morning, the European Union remains a reference for many people. A reference of justice and solidarity; a model for the world. That is why I am talking about responsibility, and that is why I say that this Parliament will continue to call on A Union that does not flucking its commitment to the defence of human rights and does so without complexes, before political and commercial interests jump above human dignity. Human rights must underpin our external and internal action, they must be the central element of our message. Only then can we be minimally effective in their defense. In conclusion, I would like to acknowledge Mr Lambrinidis's excellent work. A work often little known but that is a reference for many of us already. Congratulations and thank you. And yours too, Madam High Representative. Don't flagging. You're doing very well. You two make the European Union better.

name: Bas BELDER
text: — Paragraph 148 of the Weidenholzer report has not yet been ten words: 'true (Europe!) Christian refugees are regularly persecuted on religious grounds”. Behind these few words, however, lies a world of fear, of suffering, and of traumatic experiences. “I was more afraid in my German shelter than in Syria,” confesses, for example, a 29-year-old Christian refugee. Jihadists from his homeland formed his fellow inhabitants, whom he fled... Only a few weeks ago Open Doors Germany published his inquiry into 743 violations of justice against Christian refugees in German asylum shelters and another 10 against Jezidi s. “The tip of the iceberg”, emphasises the aid organization. Death threats, bodily harm, lewd behaviour towards women and girls are frequently mentioned. We are not talking about the verbal violence of Muslim radicals towards Christian asylum seekers such as “unclean infidels” who do not deserve a common roof over their heads, so they are not allowed to use common kitchens and showers. “Every day I am threatened”, says a Christian convert during an interview with the back to the camera. What should she, what should persecuted Eastern Christians think about freedom of faith, democratic rule of law in Europe? To all of us the answer!

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, over the last few years, violations of fundamental human rights have become systematic just across the EU’s borders, in countries that enjoyed being the EU’s partners, strategic partners, or even candidate countries just a while ago. In Russia, Azerbaijan or Turkey, for instance, the space of civil society has been shrinking, in some cases dramatically. Harassment, imprisonment, and disappearances of independent journalists, political opposition and human rights defenders have become everyday news. Just as one more faked election is on the news every few years.  In some countries like Belarus, things have been fixed for quite some time already when it comes to human rights. Cleansed and frozen. This is the current status of the civil society in Belarus. Once called the last dictator in Europe, Lukashenko can only celebrate today as the restrictive measures are removed. At the same time, globally, in the United Nations we observe another crisis of decision-making. In fact, the veto right has become a tool to defend dictatorships; a cover to make crimes against humanity close to legal. The immense propaganda and manipulation and false information on the top of all these, we are very close to having the cornerstones of the modern world order demolished.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, four thousand and five hundred killed in the Mediterranean when trying to reach our borders. Four thousand five hundred reasons why it is difficult for the European institutions to talk about human rights. Outsourcing our borders with shameful agreements such as that of the European Union/Turkey, looking away at the systematic violation of human rights by the Erdogan Government. Yesterday, more than two hundred HDP officials were arrested. Human rights as a strategy for commercial penetration into third countries of European multinationals. Austerity and debt as weapons of mass destruction of social rights in the peoples of southern Europe. Millions of people suffer energy poverty, which costs more than seven thousand people a year in countries like Spain. We have to end the hypocrisy of false rhetoric defending human rights. The best way to defend them is to practice them, ladies and gentlemen. What we have to do is, just that, practice them. (He agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — I listened carefully and I have to say that one question arises: do you really think it is intellectually, morally and politically right to mix budgetary policy, austerity, budgetary balances with the question of torture, lawlessness, religious persecution? Do you really think this is a policy to accomplish anything by throwing it all in one pot? Don't you mock the victims of genuine human rights abuses if you give such nonsense?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: answer from “blue card.” — Don't miss the truth, sir. Austerity policies have generated death, generated inequality in most of the peoples of southern Europe. In the 2015 report, UN Rapporteur John Paul Bohoslavsky speaks that austerity policies and memorandums signed with Greece have violated both European and international human rights law. Read the United Nations reports, Your Honor.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to come back to the question of the genocide of the Yazidis. Today Nadia Murad said that Daesh took their honour, and the European Parliament, with the award, has given it back. Lamiya Aji Bashar has said that the criminals must be brought to justice. I come back to the answer that Mrs Mogherini gave about 100 MEPs on 30 May on this issue, where we insisted that she act so that the EU recognises the treatment of Yazidis as genocide. Ms Mogherini, you made a long list of prerequisites for doing that. But my conviction – and I believe that Parliament is united on this – is that it is time for the EU to accelerate this process and to look for the possibility of calling it what we think it is: a genocide. This of course puts obligations on the EU to act on the grounds of the Genocide Convention. I really hope that you will look into this issue again.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. This year's annual report deals in a synthetic but organic way topics of considerable importance: we have managed to cover and highlight the most current and pressing issues on issues that can be defined transversal and on which we are called to intervene more concretely and effectively, including in compliance with and achieving the sustainable development goals set out in the 2030 Agenda. I particularly appreciated the parties concerning the defence and guarantee of the rights of indigenous peoples, therefore support for human rights defenders, the renewed commitment to the fight for the freedom of each, in an atmosphere of peace and solidarity. Then I would like to point out the part dedicated to Migrants, refugees, asylum seekers and internally displaced persons (IDPs), since it is a topic that, in my view, represents the greatest challenge of these times and on which the whole credibility of the European Union is played. Finally, my acclaim also goes to the part concerning Trade, business and human rights, a subject in depth covered in the corporate liability report, of which I was rapporteur, because, in my view, More attention should be paid to the policies adopted by multinationals on respect for human rights. Of course, focusing more on some issues does not mean to leave out those that have already been studied or to give less importance to others. In fact, when we talk about the safeguarding of human rights, we can distinguish different areas and aspects but, at the end of the day, the red thread that binds them all and which we must defend and promote remains one, that is to act with humanity. Now it remains only to be seen whether what we have promoted with words will be translated into equally laudable and effective actions.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is fun to see you debating human rights in an institution that harasses and persecutes those who have committed the crime of simply being Eurosceptics. Just a few hours ago, you voted for Richard Corbett's report, which will further restrict the freedom of expression of MEPs. Democracy is not just about slipping a bulletin into an urn, but is defined by the ability of a people to control their destiny. However, the loss of our legislative, budgetary, territorial and monetary sovereignty has accelerated the demoliquescence of democracy in the Member States of the European Union. How dare you talk about democracy, when you ratify free trade treaties such as the TAFTA on the backs of the people and impose quotas of migrants on them, without any consultation? How dare you talk about human rights, when you handed over Libya to Islamists by supporting the removal of Gaddafi, the same Islamists who are now imposing Sharia law and massacring religious minorities in the utmost indifference? How dare you talk about fundamental rights, when the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, paid a heartfelt tribute to Fidel Castro, who, I remind you, is responsible for the imprisonment and death of thousands of political opponents? Enough of this variable geometry indignation! Enough of this totalitarian Europe that should sweep outside its door before giving moral lessons to the whole world! (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Question “blue card”. — This is a curiosity. How dare you compare your feeling of being prosecuted in this House with the grave violations of human rights that we are talking about this afternoon? How dare you talk about your position, as if it were the same as those who suffer persecution and death? Are you not ashamed, dear colleague?

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Answer “blue card.” — The beginning of a dictatorship begins with the decisions you sometimes make, namely, to prevent any opposition from expressing itself. The harassment of Members of the Front National Group is totally outrageous. Yes, indeed, even sorry.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). — Mr President, this report is a manual of entertainment and production of laughter. I cannot say more lenient, at least respecting the rapporteur's trouble. To justify the classification, so as not to be accused for the umpteenth time as racist and populist. The report refers to freedom of thought, expression, conscience, faith and religion. But in Greece and Europe, if you declare a nationalist, you are described as a fascist. Are you saying you're a Christian? You're accused of Islamophobia. Are you asking for better conditions for your fellow countrymen? You're promoting racism. Are you talking about a nation? You don't show solidarity and you're a populist. The report talks about respect for democracy and elections. A terrible joke, considering the fierce reactions of the European political elite, blaming the British for the referendum and Brexit, the Americans for the Trump election and the citizens who support the nationalist movements. Different interpretation of democracy or hypocrisy? Finally, the report mentions the fight against discrimination. However, discrimination against nationalists from so-called democrats must be made in the context of the fight against discrimination... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, in its Global Strategy the EU has committed to act globally to address the root causes of conflict and poverty, and to promote human rights. In line with this commitment, this Annual Report reiterates that human rights remain a priority in our external policies, but they are increasingly under threat worldwide. At the hands of the authoritarian regimes, the space for civil society is shrinking, and violence against defenders is increasing. Individuals are persecuted for their faith, the Christians still being the most harassed religious community globally, in places like Iraq, Syria and Pakistan. In China, in a climate of fear, prominent rights defenders are harassed, tortured and go missing. Uyghur scholar, Ilham Tohti, remains in jail. Tibetans live in constant fear for their existence. Prominent lawyers in China, such as Jiang Tianyong, have gone missing in an ongoing widespread detention. Considering the current migration crisis in Europe, it is worth mentioning that the report distinguishes between migrants and refugees, in accordance with adequate legal procedures. Our report echoes our strong commitment to European values and universal human rights.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, this report is a diagnosis of the lives of men and women, children and the elderly, of concrete people persecuted, humiliated, wounded, drowned and killed — of people who needed protection and were on their own account and luck. People like us, or rather less fortunate than us, who have been and are victims of other men, groups, organizations and governments. This report is a symptom of what is worst in humanity, but it also shows us the evolution of what is most basic: the advancement of our rationality and which, in turn, shows the possibility of a more dignified world. I could list here some of the worst examples of disrespect for human rights, both inside and outside. But what is important for us to discuss here today is the centrality of human rights in the European Union's external policies. That is why, Commissioner, the effective implementation of the European Union Strategic Framework and the new action plan for human rights and democracy is urgently needed. We must give that signal clearly, show that the European Union's guidelines on human rights are a fight against all forms of discrimination. We believe in religious freedom, gender equality, the protection of the most vulnerable groups and respect for others. We still need a better and more coordinated way of receiving migrants, and for that we need to create legal instruments for asylum seekers. This is a hope that focuses on the recognition of the other and their freedom. This is what it means to be Europe.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: “I pay tribute to the victims of martial law in Poland. Every day of December carried new crimes at the time. Despite the report's demands, the European Union has trouble maintaining uniform standards in the human rights system, both internally and externally. This is the case best conducted for the third time, politically motivated debate about Poland.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: — Dear. The report on the situation, or more specifically, on human rights violations in the world, has been introduced in the European Parliament as a potentially powerful tool of our common foreign and security policy. If the Helsinki conference four decades ago, focusing the spotlights on human rights violators, opened the way for epochal change in the world, we must now self-critically conclude that when using this means of soft political power, we are lagging behind opportunities and expectations. Thus, even despite its large-scale scale, this report does not express the dramaticity of the moment in which our planet found itself. We refer to human rights when they are violated by others, we refuse to declare peace a fundamental value, we leave people alone when they are fearful of the present and the future. When it comes to the origins of crises, wars, human rights trampling, the European Union is caught up in its split, history and geostrategies. Therefore, our adverb generocity in the humanitarian field is not enough. Colleagues, we will have to talk about human rights more specifically, with reference to international and humanitarian law. We must be on the side of the weak and humiliated, not on the side of power and its abuse. Thank you very much.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: — Mr President, human rights are one of the two central points of the activities of the new Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres. In this context, the policy of the European Union in the area is very important to the United Nations. Despite the large scope of the report under discussion, it is missing some fundamental issues. There is no reference at the point migrants pointing to the European Union's efforts to pressure the rich oil states of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. It would be logical, after all, for refugees from Syria and Iraq, largely Sunnis, to be accepted by these contiguous states, whose resources are significantly higher than in the case of Lebanon, or Jordan. Throughout the report, I lack any technical mention of the United States of America. A number of states of the United States of America apply the death penalty, and among developed nations it is our strategic partner, exporter of democracy, that has the highest percentage of the population in prison. I believe that the European Parliament's action also contributes to the protection of the rights of the majority It is also the original population. Unfortunately, a colleague from Poland has left, there are also political prisoners, and they are not talked about here.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President! So we are talking about human rights in the world and the EU's role in this area. The EU is acting as a state and defender of human rights in the world. But the EU is not a state, and Mrs Mogherini is not, and she will not be. Your aim here is to set up and build a politically motivated human rights canon — a set of values that you are constructing. They even want to exaggerate abortion as a human right. Not only should it be unpunished or allowed, but it should be a human right. And even the Christian Democrats are taking part here, the so-called Christian Democrats. Speaking of which, Mrs Quisthoudt-Rowohl has just said that the Christian Democrats are particularly committed to protecting the Christian minorities in the world. I would remind you that yesterday I tabled an amendment on the agenda. I asked for a debate on the attacks against the Copts, against the Christian minority in Egypt, to be put on the agenda. The Christian Democrats abstained on this motion. Count Lambsdorff has agreed for the FDP, and the Christian Democrats have abstained. So much for that. We should stop pretending to be the model pupils in a special way with regard to respect for human rights, and perhaps we should rather touch our own noses and stop making rules to the whole world.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: — Mr President, we witnessed the presentation of the Sakharov Prize to two young Yazidi young people earlier, but how can we not see this European Parliament gesture as a tribute to the vice to virtue? Far from preventing massacres, you have encouraged the destruction or destabilization of secular states that protected the minority. I am thinking in particular of the many Christian communities, especially the Armenian church in Syria, once so well represented in Aleppo. A volunteer of SOS Christians of the East, who is on site, told us earlier that there were still about three square kilometers left in the hands of the al-Nusra front. These Islamists prevent civilians from reaching the liberated areas. Yet you have consistently supported these so-called rebels affiliated with al-Qaeda, Laurent Fabius going so far as to declare that they were doing, I quote “good work”. Aleppo will soon be completely liberated, but the provinces of Idlib and Rakka will have to be cleaned up. Now, surviving jihadists must be prevented from returning to Turkey and Europe, but we must also break the dangerous connections with their support from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, links revealed recently by Pierre Conesa for Saudi Arabia and Christian Chesnot and Georges Malbrunot for Qatar.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Mr President, giving a voice here to the victims today, I will focus on one of the biggest human rights violations I know, which is terrorism. Terrorism uses the most brutal violence against civilians, pursuing political, ideological or religious objectives. Terrorism attacks the essence of human rights, because they are the security and dignity of the individual. It destroys the supreme right, which is the right to live. I therefore believe that one of the priorities of the European Union's human rights policy in the world should be the fight against terrorism and promote the obligation of all States to protect and ensure the security of their people. The international community had to take full account of the rights of victims of terrorism, and one of the most important was the right to justice, with terrorists being tried by international tribunals for crimes against humanity. Impunity against any terrorism, whether religious, nationalist, ethnic or ideological is a grave violation of human rights. More than 300 crimes of the terrorist organization ETA are still unresolved. Terrorist crimes should not be prescribed, because they are against humanity. Today we have seen Nadia and Lamiya, two victims of Daesh terrorism who have seen their whole family die, have been rewarded with Sakharov. Those who have committed these atrocities have to pay for their crimes. We are the hope of their rights and all victims of terrorism.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: — Mr President, on the horizon of the year (hors micro) there is little hope for a better world in which peace dominate. War, violence and persecution dictate the agenda on many continents and cause thousands of people to leave their native places. 2015 was a year of extraordinary challenges for the European Union and the international community, amid instability and conflicts in the Middle East and regions of Asia and Africa, followed by the migrant crisis, as well as terrorist attacks against civilians. We are living in a paradox: states tend to become more and more repressive, because the fight against terror is an argument for mass surveillance, suppression or restriction of human rights, but on the other hand, this is why more and more people are fighting for their own. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Weidenholzer, on the drafted, balanced report, and I hope that it will contribute substantially to the protection and implementation of human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the right to development by peaceful means , placing human rights at the heart of the European Union's relations with all third countries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — In Turkey there are nearly 40 000 people in prisons and another 100 000 have lost their jobs. There are suspicious deaths every day, people disappear, nothing is known about them, and there are no investigations. Russia bombs civilians and hospitals in Syria. In Ukraine there are more than one million internally displaced people due to war and aggression. There are many political leaders in China who regard human rights as foreign infiltrators and, obviously, human rights activists shut down. There are 300 activists and lawyers arrested in China in 2015 alone. And we, here, what do we do? We close our eyes and continue to talk about bilateral treaties, financial aid, trade treaties, alliances with all these countries. If the Union has taken on foreign policies based on the rule of law, human rights and democracy, then let it put them into practice with these countries too.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President! We are debating human rights in the European Parliament today, and the extremists from the left and right are saying that we should not be able to do so. One of them say we hadn't achieved what can be achieved here in a class-struggle. The others claim that Europe should be a homogeneous national body and that any diversity is a problem. Of course, the European Union is not perfect. Everyone knows that, and we in the European Union know best. However, this report makes it clear. Respect for civil rights is the basis for human rights to be lived, that they are respected. We know that we too have problems with citizenship in the European Union. Is press freedom respected everywhere? No. The independence of the judiciary? No. Do we really guarantee pluralism, the protection of property everywhere as we want it? No. That is why it is also right that, within the European Union, we call on Member States such as Hungary and Poland not to go any further along the path they have taken. Because if we become implausible in the European Union, we will no longer be able to appear credibly outwardly against torture, no more against expulsion, no more against rape, no more against slavery, no more against extrajudicial executions, against all these terrible human rights violations. That's why it's so important. First civil rights fall, then human rights fall. We have to fight back the beginning. There are two concrete actions that we can take. We need to strengthen the mandate of the Fundamental Rights Agency in Vienna so that it can also identify maladministration in our Member States, and we must strengthen the mandate of Human Rights Commissioner Lambrinidis and his successors so that they become more visible and stronger in the institutional structure of the European Union. (The speaker is so agreed to answer two questions in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: the question posed by raising the blue card. — Mr., you are willing to criticise other countries — this is not the first time — but justice would require fairness to your own country. What could you say about the state of human rights in your own country? Does it present itself as perfectly as you would think of your voice?

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by raising a blue card. — What will you say about the fact that in your country children are prevented from speaking Polish if they come from broken marriages, and the Jugendamtu official finds it somehow inconvenient for control of the state administration. What will you say that in very many lands until now, school provisions of the Polish-German State Agreement are not exercised, which guaranteed German citizens of Polish origin the right to preserve their culture? Mr Fr, really, try for these human rights first and foremost at your place.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to two questions about the “blue card” procedure. — Well, I'm the last person to say that everything is perfect in Germany. In the context of the United Nations Universal Periodic Review, for example, prisons in Germany are sometimes criticised for failing to meet the standards that the United Nations expects. That's right, and you have to talk about it openly. We have another problem with the Polish language. This is a question of so-called minorities. The Danish minority in Germany is of course allowed to speak Danish at school. This is about: school lessons. Of course, Polish children in Germany are allowed to speak Polish. This is not an issue at all. Our Sorbian minority is also allowed to speak Sorbian at school and is taught accordingly. But we have open debates and good dialogue about this. We should do the same so that we can also be credible within the European Union if we are committed to global human rights to the outside world — and that is what this report is about.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Mr President. It is very good that a report be made on human rights violations in the world — in the rest of the world, of course, because as we all know in the European Union, human rights are not violated at all. But, come on, that in reality those who govern the European Union this human rights matter quite the same, or let's say it's a secondary thing. They do not suspend the association agreements with Israel or Morocco, despite crimes against the Palestinian and Saharawi people; weapons continue to be sold to Saudi Arabia, which is bombing Yemen; migrants are deported to Afghanistan; the agreement was signed with Turkey, to take care of refugees; and in exchange Europe is silent to the massacre of the Kurdish people and in the face of repression. And, of course, no touching multinationals. And that is why the binding treaty to curb human rights violations by large corporations under discussion in the European Union does not have the strong support of the European Union. Of course, we approve great reports, but they do not contain absolutely any of this.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, let me start by thanking our rapporteurs for their commitment in this annual report, which covers a wide range of issues of the utmost importance. I have in mind the advancement of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights, the very basics of the EU CFSP and other policies with an external dimension. The report points out attempts to shrink the space of civil society and limitations on freedoms of assembly or expression. It pays particular attention to women and children, as well as to new challenges like anti-microbacterial resistance and the right to health care, and EU human rights policies in this regard.  It stresses also that trade and human rights must go hand in hand. This is true. The report keeps a horizontal focus and, to my mind, this is one of its shortcomings. EU representatives act in specific countries. They need our support, and they do not see the point in avoiding naming those countries or those responsible for the atrocities in our annual report and it is not at all about naming and shaming. It is first of all, about the victims, people like Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar. It looks like we tend to care about the image and the prestige of dictators and human rights violators, trying not to upset them instead of speaking on behalf of those who are oppressed and denied their rights and freedoms. Finally, Venezuela, Cuba, Russia, Iran, China should be in our report.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the annual report reiterates Parliament’s call for the EU institutions and Member States to place human rights at the centre of our relations with all third countries, including strategic partners. But Parliament continues to be bluntly disregarded, and not just in Syria and Iraq, as Lamiya and Nadia today pointed out. Recent evidence of this is the European Council’s silence and the Commission’s perfunctory criticism over the recent arrest of Professor Merera Gudina, a prominent Oromo opposition leader, who is being tortured in Ethiopia and continues to be denied access to a lawyer. His crime was to speak at a public hearing hosted by me in this Parliament on the situation in Ethiopia with exiled Oromo athlete, Feyisa Lilesa, and Professor Berhanu Nega, said to be a terrorist by the real terrorist, the Ethiopian Government. The External Action Service and the Commission have yet to join the European Parliament’s President in demanding the immediate release of Professor Merera Gudina. The EU cannot be credible about human rights and the rule of law when it prepares to further finance, via the migration compact, the undemocratic regime in Ethiopia, which is already Africa’s top recipient of our development aid – a country under a state of emergency where thousands of peaceful protesters have been massacred, assassinated or languish in jails crowded with journalists and other prisoners of conscience. A country from which thousands have to flee as refugees and migrants – 88 000 this year alone – into war-ravaged Yemen according to UNHCR. How many Ethiopian citizens will have to die, and how close will Ethiopia have to come to civil war to end the EU’s complicity with this brutal and callous dictatorship?

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr President! We are debating today on the report on human rights and democracy in the world for 2015. It is very extensive and has more than fifty pages. I am pleased to note the transcript set out in point 148, where the European Parliament stresses that Christians now constitute a religious group that is most harassed and intimidated in most countries of the world, including Europe. This is a sad truth that we have been reminded many times in this House. Too bad so little has been done to improve the plight of Christians and prevent their persecution and killings. Despite the determination of Christians as the largest persecuted group in the world in the report, I note a huge asymmetry compared to those of other minorities. For example, so-called LGBTI sexual minorities are devoted to much more space, which is mentioned in points 124, 125, 126, among others. Both their wording and other records on so-called safe abortion make it possible for many MPs to vote against the whole report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Mr President, I am pleased to note that the report devotes a whole chapter to the situation of people with disabilities. On my initiative, a thorough examination of the effectiveness of projects relating to persons with disabilities has been included in the report, and NGOs representing people with disabilities should also be involved in the implementation of the projects under the 'nothing about us without us' principle. I am convinced that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities must be followed and more projects should be created to support disabled persons, the social integration of persons with disabilities at their place of residence. You don't have to talk, you have to act. We do not need democracy exports, but the strengthening of local communities. Local NGOs need to be involved, as they know exactly what is needed locally and can help ensure that the support is really delivered to the people for whom it is intended.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, the report contains much that is good and that we can support. Unfortunately the section on immigrants and refugees to some extent repeats failed ideas, insists on solutions that do not work and avoids touching the core problems. The report as usual calls for more legal channels to Europe for people of all skill levels, including the least qualified. I think this is irresponsible. Western Europe should have learned by now what happens when you import large numbers of people who do not have the skills that are needed in a post-industrial society. You get segregation, crime, religious radicalism and chaos. We cannot just manage the problem by, for example, relocating irregular migrants. We should focus more on reducing drastically the number of economic migrants who arrive and stay, by means of a more effective returns policy and external border control, tighter rules on family reunification, subsidiary protection, and so on.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, one more year we discussed the report on human rights and democracy in the world. One year, this is very special, as 2016 marks the 50th anniversary of the United Nations International Covenants on Civil and Political Rights and Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. The European Union is not only an economic community: it is also a community of values, principles, among which respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law occupy a central place and are also, in accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty, objectives of its external action. In this spirit, today we have delivered the Sakharov Awards for this year. And this morning in this House we heard the shocking testimony of two young victims of the disgusting Daesh. We are experiencing a certain regression in the world as far as human rights are concerned. Suffice it to think about the atrocities that are being committed daily in Syria. The Union's voice must therefore be more than ever unequivocal, especially when the voices of those who wrongly deny the universality of human rights are increasing and affirming that their respect is a matter of pure internal character that depends exclusively on the national sovereignty of each State. Therefore, the Union must continue to promote to the rest of the international community its respect and the defence of the dignity of the person, particularly now, when the cruel attacks of terrorism against the most basic rights are repeated. In this regard, I end my speech by strongly condemning, Mr President, the heinous attacks this weekend which have bloodied, among others, cities such as Cairo and Istanbul.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: — Mr President, this plenary session in Strasbourg is a good example of how the European Parliament deals with human rights. First, we handed over the Jesid women a respectful award, then we have on the agenda the forced workers of the cotton fields in Uzbekistan and the human rights abuses in the EU's Eastern Partnership Countries. This is a good example of human rights being on the agenda of the European Union. As someone said here, they are like a heart, and thankfully this heart is beating and the European Union is living because of these values. I would like to tackle two more things. As Mr Lambsdorff said, there are worrying developments within the EU in the development of the rule of law. It's true. Another issue is that EU member countries export arms to crisis areas. There needs to be change to these.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! Dear ladies! Rarely can one encounter such curiosal and cynical ideas as the fundamental rights report in the Union proposal to prevent neonatal mortality through easy access to so-called safe abortion. How can democracy even work if sophistry relegates public debate to such an intellectual and moral level.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Mr Lambrinidis, we are debating last year’s human rights situation, but just now at this moment Syrian Government soldiers are slaughtering civilians in Aleppo. A so-called solution there has been reached by trampling on all possible human rights and rules. The message we get today from Aleppo is that ‘might is making right’. The EU’s role, obviously, is not only to take care of the refugees, which we are doing, but its role is to prevent these tragedies from happening as far as possible, and resolve the crisis. We remain, unfortunately, divided and hesitant. Today’s Sakharov Prize Winners, Nadia and Lamiya, called once again to bring to justice those who have committed crimes against humanity. The EU’s role should be to initiate something to implement this. In the past six years the European Parliament has called, in three resolutions and two recommendations, to sanction individuals directly linked to the death of Sergei Magnitsky. Why has there been no action taken on this so far? The US, Canada and now my own country, Estonia, have enforced the Magnitsky list. By doing the same, the EU could possibly make a difference. What do we need? Last week, Mikhail Kasyanov said that the best way to help the Russian people – and that applies also to the Syrian people – is for the EU to stay true to its own values and principles, to implement them in deeds and not only in words. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: question “blue card”. — (FR) Mr Kelam, dear colleague, you have rightly referred to the winners of the Sakharov Prize, the two very courageous Yazidi women who have suffered from the actions of ISIS. But even if we must, of course, support them, do you not believe that you are still making a certain reduction by believing that Assad and Putin should finally be blamed for what they are doing in Aleppo? For let us not forget that they are fighting precisely ISIS, which persecuted these two women. Do you not believe, Mr. Kelam, that you should be nuanced?

name: Tunne KELAM
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for this question. I think this is a very risky approach, to differentiate between evils. There can be manifold evils. We think about Hitler or Stalin in the Second World War, and to ally with Stalin against Hitler brought about the slavery of East European nations for 50 years.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this morning Parliament gave its highest recognition for combating human rights, rewarding two extraordinary young women. Their story and testimony went into our hearts and confirmed to us how much violence and discrimination against women and girls have increased in recent years especially in war zones and under authoritarian regimes: exploitation, slavery, domestic violence and the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war, but not only because violence against women is also expresses in other forms, including harassment, bullying, intimidation and discrimination. Europe must remain a model for the coexistence of peoples and cultures in the world, Nadia and Lamiya reminded us in their adlocution. It is unacceptable that to date in many countries of the world, women still do not enjoy the same fundamental freedoms and economic, social, cultural, civil and political rights as men. Europe has the tools to promote democratic values in the world. What we are calling for is a greater ambition in policies to protect the rights and dignity of millions of women in the world, victims of all forms of violence and to pursue in our commitment to complaint and sanction against those responsible for genocides, crimes against humanity and war crimes, including crimes related to sexual violence.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. President, every society is free as free as its most vulnerable members are free. A stable society will find ways to protect such social groups and create circumstances in which they will contribute to its development. Members of minorities throughout history have significantly enriched Croatian society. But the evaluation of the minority contribution today is unfortunately only about material rights consumed by minority political representatives and a narrow circle of loyal people who push budget money through political blackmail. Such a misguided approach to valuing minorities has led to an absurd situation where minorities, despite a whole range of positive historical examples, are not viewed as those who enrich but unfairly consume something that doesn't belong to them. We must protect minority members. But, in the Croatian case, primarily from individuals who supposedly represent them, and in fact they fight over their backs only for their personal interest.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Mr President, our annual report makes a number of good recommendations, but I am afraid that we do not see a forest for trees. On page thirty-two of our report, we are talking about children's rights. But we do not bring peace of arms or answers to the children who perish in Aleppo today. Not even those who die there tomorrow. Why are they dying and whose fault? We're talking about human rights and their violations. So let's start acting at last and stop the greatest atrocities. Let's start with acts that should never have taken place in the twenty-first century. When we put the culprits into the equation, we figure out that we need to resuscitate the functioning of the UN Security Council. As long as the state responsible for violations of international humanitarian law holds veto power, we will only further afield helplessly to new atrocities. Russia and Assad must finally take responsibility for their actions. Eighty thousand people across an area of two times four kilometers are paralysed in a vicious circle of death. The set of human rights abuses in the world is the largest in decades. A solid backbone of international law, consistent inference of responsibility for its violations is condicio sine qua non even of our future existence.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, the narrative is that the EU can only be a genuine strategic actor if it embraces realpolitik and cynicism. It is a dangerous and false narrative and a false dilemma, whether in the context of the refugee crisis or relations with Turkey or with Russia, or security in northern and western Africa. Ultimately, the root causes of European insecurity lie in gross abuse of human rights and failing governance in our neighbourhood. We don’t need another endless debate about the trade-off between strategic interests and human rights. Indeed, instead, we need a more strategic approach to promoting human rights.  The EU must seize the initiative and formulate a positive agenda, such as pushing a new global architecture to manage migration flows and ensure the rights of refugees. In the same way, the EU pushed for R2B arms control, climate change, transitional justice and other issues. After the US elections, the EU may be the last global actor able and willing to fight for universal principles.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Mr President! Colleagues and Colleagues! One note and one polemic. I am very pleased that the report focuses on the key: religious freedom, protest against persecuted Christians, protection of refugee rights and the fight against human trafficking. This is the real barbaric scourge of the modern world. But the report and, above all, our discussion should avoid bias and here once more polemic with Mr Lambsdorff, who did not answer my and Mr Mark Jur's question. In Poland, which you so freely criticize, is very strong protection of national minorities: Germany in Poland has full school rights, its own schools, education and even parliamentary representation. Germany, by contrast, does not recognize the rights of national minorities at full length. So I invite you to Poland to learn the good patterns that you could use your homeland, and the whole of Europe.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: - Mr President! Today Saint Lucia is celebrated. In my native Sweden, she comes with candles during the darkest part of the darkest season. 1700 years ago Saint Lucia suffered the martyr death in Sicily. Yesterday, 25 other martyrs were buried in Cairo. They became victims of a persecution of Christians who bring the thoughts of the 4th century and the martyr Lucia. Mr President! Religious persecution is today one of the most common human rights crimes. I mention this because, together with other Members, I have suggested that the report we are discussing should more widely highlight religious freedom. Many of the amendments that we have tabled are now in this report, and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Weidenholzer, for very good work. At the same time, I would urge this House to always fully consider religious freedom as a central part of the concept of human rights. Or, as the UN special envoy for human rights says: Human rights without the perspective of religious freedom lack value. Let's agree on this, let's act on this, let's honor the martyrs of Cairo by always standing up for religious freedom. Thank you!

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, I want to first congratulate the rapporteur for this balanced and comprehensive report. Last Saturday was Human Rights Day, celebrating the dignity and worth of every human being. Today we heard the moving testimonies of the Sakharov Prize laureates and their extraordinary work for women affected by Isis’ campaign of sexual violence. But we have so much more to do. Today, there are reports in Aleppo of civilians being killed on the spot, mass detentions and bodies abandoned in the street. There have been serious human rights violations against Rohingya civilians, violations against civilians in occupied Kashmir, and similarly attacks against Coptic Christians in Egypt. It is a sad catalogue of suffering. We need to redouble our efforts to aid those who need it most and call for the perpetrators for those violations to be held to account in every possible forum. Human rights are not a matter of derogation, instead they should become the strongest pillars in all external policies and relations of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — Mr President, the protection of human rights is inconceivable without the protection of the social and economic rights of citizens. Three and a half years ago, together with other colleagues in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, we had the opportunity to vote on an important resolution stating that austerity is a violation of human rights and that is now crucial; we see it everywhere. We see austerity affecting Greece, affecting poor populations throughout the European Union and in this way we have a serious violation of human rights. In addition, there is one more issue in Greece: the thousands of refugees trapped in the Aegean islands at the moment are in a miserable condition. Their rights and human rights are also being violated, and that is why the relocation of these refugees from the Aegean islands to the European Union must begin. At the same time, the rights of the inhabitants of the Aegean islands are violated because these situations are there.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: — Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the rapporteur's work, which is never an easy exercise. Allow me to highlight four elements that I think are salient to the annual report. First, as the report highlights, the magnitude of migration flows has raised important human rights issues. The launch of Operation Sofia is a means of combating traffickers and thus protecting human rights. It is therefore crucial today that human rights remain a red line in our dialogue with third countries for joint management of migration, particularly in the context of the Valletta Action Plan. The second point I note in the report is the key role of European Union delegations. The role they have to play in contributing to the protection of human rights defenders, to initiate early alerts of deteriorating situations and following up on the recommendations of election observation missions. These expectations imply that sufficient human and financial capacities are allocated, and that delegations receive support from Member States' embassies. Thirdly, the fight against impunity and the role of the International Criminal Court. Yes, the European Union must remain firm on the Rome Statute. Nevertheless, I believe that we need a genuine strategy to promote membership of the ICC by States that have not yet signed or ratified its Statute, and thus broaden its regional scope, but we must also find a way to incorporate criticism from members constructively. Finally, I would like to mention the adoption of the 2016-2020 Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment. Today, the message we are sending is very strong. Let's get concrete results.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Mr President, I wish to begin by welcoming the quality of this report and by regretting the morally miserable and intellectually primary way in which the extremist forces represented in this Parliament address the issue of human rights, as has been evident throughout this debate. This report strictly highlights the main problems facing the world in the field of human rights. Unfortunately, these are experiencing worrying setbacks in various regions and the European Union must redouble its efforts to counteract these same setbacks. It is true that some progress has been made, for example with regard to the increasing conditioning of the European Union's trade agreements with third countries to respect for human rights. I am referring, for example, to the application of the generalised scheme of trade preferences and the multiplication of impact studies on the external investments of the European Union. The new action plan for human rights and democracy has very positive aspects and the instrument for democracy and human rights remains fundamental, but they are timid advances. Wars and terrorism, the situation of migrants and refugees, trafficking in human beings, the criminalization of fundamental freedoms, the persecution of minorities, the repression of human rights defenders, contempt for indigenous peoples, disregard for women's rights an extremely dangerous scenario and from the outset they are almost always interconnected phenomena.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: — The European Union wants to export human rights and democracy. This really is a high-value export fact, but the paradox is that a demographically dying Europe wants to advise the world on how to thrive. What entitles us to do this, I ask. If we want to respect human rights, we need people to apply to. The European Union has a dangerously low birth rate of 1.58 child per woman; 50 years from now, countries with critically low birth rates, such as Poland, Portugal or my own country Slovakia, will stand on the brink of collapse. Why, then, we don't support natural marriage and traditional families already now. This report does not at all favour marriages and families, which are the key to prosperity in the world. On the contrary, many paragraphs are devoted to promoting childless relationships and the sterility or abortion of children. Isn't it strange exporting a “kill your kids and you'll live better” culture? The European Union's strategy and development aid should support families and family entrepreneurship, as they help stable and prosperous democracies.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to shed light on this very important subject by a concrete example. I have been in Iraq, the Mosul region in recent days, and I know how much Mrs Mogherini is committed to this region and to normalising the situation. So I would like to say three sentences about the human rights situation. Nothing else can be done until security is guaranteed from a human rights point of view. Nothing is worth talking about until we can put opposing people at a negotiating table. Hundreds of thousands of refugees want to return home, but there's no hope yet. There are three things to help Europe: water, electricity, education. That's how easy I ask you to say, it's completely different to do it. One must be noted, and I would very much like to draw attention to this. Millions of people will leave Iraq if we don't help them. Either we help or they come.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, today, when human rights are under threat worldwide, when more and more people are fleeing from war and armed conflicts, and when there are more than 250 million children alone living in countries affected by conflict, many of them forcibly displaced, coherent and strong EU action is ever more important in order to support the development of long-term sustainable solutions in areas of conflict and oppression. This is why I believe that the report rightly points out the need to mainstream our human rights and democracy support actions across all policies with an external dimension, such as development, migration, trade and neighbourhood policy. A more focused, systematic and coordinated use of our human rights instruments is thus essential. But just as essential is that the EU increase its credibility worldwide and lead by example in the area of democracy, human rights and respect for minorities.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that the situation of human rights in the world today is dire. As we speak, the Assad regime is destroying what is left of besieged Aleppo, reportedly massacring thousands of civilians. Our thoughts and actions are with those suffering right now. We must also stand up and fight for the release of human rights defenders and political prisoners around the world. Sadly, human rights defender Nabeel Rajab, seen here, is still in prison, whilst the Bahraini Government reviews his tweets. The European Union, you, High Representative, must demand his immediate release. In Iran, UK-Iranian citizen Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been imprisoned for unknown charges, separated from her baby daughter and her husband, Richard. The UK Government and EU diplomats must do more to secure her release. Together with my colleagues I will continue to do what I can to ensure she comes home safely. And colleagues, I would urge all of you to take part in the annual Amnesty International ‘Write for Rights’ campaign for the release of political prisoners.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: — The Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World extensively reflects that 2015 was a year of serious human rights and democracy challenges. Unstoppable military conflicts, increasing authoritarianism, shrinking civil society, restricting freedom of speech and media, increasing discrimination and hate language. In the context of this complex international situation, I find the actions taken by the European Union to protect human rights and democracy to be successful and adequate. However, I believe that the European Union can respond more effectively to the many human rights challenges if it uses the broad set of instruments at its disposal in a targeted and coordinated manner.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: – Mr President, I took the floor to propose to Ms Mogherini a very specific idea on the ongoing talks on Cyprus: please support the right and the obligation of the two leaders in Cyprus to propose their own suggestion on the issue of safety and guarantees. In case we face a new collapse, the leaders representing the Cypriots should respond accordingly and in common line, and they should respond because they represent the Cypriots, no one else supports them to do so. One final thing, try to establish in Cyprus an important European institution. Institutions, as you know, provide more safety than armies, not to say the opposite: that armies provide uncertainty, unsafety, rather than safety.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Vice-President, Mr Lambrinidis. Is the situation of human rights and democracy in the world worse than ever before? No. But what is true is that the problems and violations of human rights in any corner of the world have never been so visible to this European Parliament as now. We saw it yesterday, and this morning too, with the utterly moving testimony of two young Yazidis brutally tortured and raped. But it is not enough for the European Union to recognize them with the Sakharov Prize. The European Union must also be able to develop a common foreign and security and defence policy capable of ensuring the defeat of Daesh's cruelty. Political defeat, military defeat, but also moral defeat, avoiding impunity for perpetrators of human rights violations. But that moral defeat also requires that we link this debate with yesterday's debate, which shows that fundamental rights and human rights are also declining in the European Union: violations of the rights against women, and not just their sexual and reproductive health rights; violations of religious, ethnic minorities and their sexual orientation; violations of the rights of persons subject to the public authorities in the prison system. It was imperative to ratify the European Convention on Human Rights. And it is also imperative that we say loud and clear that Europe is not enough to be an area free from the death penalty. This has to be the house of human rights. A moral reference.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2015 has also been a difficult year, there have been a number of human rights violations and democracy has suffered in many parts of the world. Restrictions on non-governmental organizations, serious human rights violations against activists, and attacks on journalists and bloggers have been recorded in many countries. The Lisbon Treaty has strengthened the European Union's commitment on the international stage, but much more needs to be done to ensure fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, principles of equality and solidarity. The terror threat, which hit Europe hard first in Paris and then in Brussels, has also put a strain on our system. The annual report underlines the need to balance security needs with respect for civil liberties. Today, more than ever, the construction of a European area of rights that is genuinely inclusive in its complexity and not uniquely geographical must be a priority in the agenda of the Community institutions and Member States.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, very briefly, just to say that I fully share the views of most of you. All of your observations will obviously inform our constant daily work and also including some suggestions that were more focused on precise elements or files we are working on, from the individual cases to the big crisis zones. Some of you, I think Mr Panzeri said that human rights are a fundamental component of every single policy of the European Union. This is exactly my commitment. It is also my institutional responsibility regarding the external policies of the European Union: trying to make sure that human rights are at the centre of whatever we do, be it security, development, be it trade, be it all the external policies we run. Let me also underline that I share very much what some of you said: this also requires a policy coherence in our internal policies. This goes beyond my institutional responsibilities, but this is at the core of my political worries. The more we are consistent with human rights, respect and promotion inside our borders, the more we are credible and also powerful in ensuring human rights are protected and promoted outside of the Union. As many of you remembered and recalled, we are a community of values and not only a community of people or policies. I would really plead for you to use, at least in this Chamber, appropriate language. I have heard words today that hurt me very much, especially after having heard this morning the testimony of two girls who have shown incredible courage, not only for what they have lived through, but also for sharing this experience with others, reliving their experiences in such a painful way. Hearing in this room words like ‘imported people’ as if people could be traded or imported or exported, I think it is really something we should pay attention to, especially in this room, to honour the community of values that you all represent in this Chamber. Work continues with our special representative, with Stavros, every single day, on all the various files. I am sure that we will continue to work together in this respect with the role of the European Parliament at the centre of our daily work and the European Union will continue to be, at least externally, and I hope also internally, very strongly, the most active, the most dedicated, the most committed promoter and defender of human rights in the world. Because we see all the limits of our work; we see the limits of our results: a lot of frustration sometimes, but still we continue. But if you look around in the world, you realise that we are the most committed, the most dedicated, the most convinced promoters of human rights all over the world, and I will continue, together with you, to be strongly committed to this.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: rapporteur. — Mr President. I would like to thank all my fellow Members very warmly for discussing a wide range of issues in their speeches, which I was unable to deal with due to lack of time. I would particularly like to thank the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, for making it clear that human rights violations do not make countries safer, but rather the opposite is true that wherever human rights, democracy and the rule of law are not respected, there is a major security shortcoming emerges. This is a very important statement, which should of course also be taken into account in everyday politics. I would like to briefly highlight three points: law enforcement has been mentioned, and I believe that an instrument is only good if it has teeth. In this sense, we must do a great deal to improve these instruments. It's also good if we see new developments. We have dealt with drones here in this report. This is something completely new, where violations of human rights can suddenly occur almost outside the normal legal framework, where machines take responsibility. This is something we haven't actually known so far. We have also dealt with these aspects in great detail, such as freedom of expression on the Internet, hate speech. Here too, you should be more active. Of course, we have been talking about human rights violations in the EU in response to some colleagues who are no longer here. I would like to remind you all that you yourself voted on the Fundamental Rights Report yesterday, which is exactly what you criticised later. Let me say briefly: we should consider how we can reform this human rights report. He would have to be more timely, he would have to become leaner and more precise, and he would have to better communicate with the allow the Commission. The role of the Human Rights Commissioner is essential here. Finally, let me just say one thing: when we have been talking about human rights for so long today, we should also think of the people of Aleppo who are now experiencing horrible things in these minutes.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - Human rights represent one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is built. It must therefore actively speak out against any violations of them. It's true both inward and externally. Therefore, the European diplomatic service needs to be even more strongly involved in these activities in the future. Cases of human rights violations should also be taken into account more strongly when building economic and trade relations between the European Union and its Member States with third countries. Their protection is particularly important from the point of view of the various vulnerable groups of the population. Whether it's women, children, minorities, seniors, but, for example, handicapped people, who are unfortunately often forgotten. Each of them is specific in terms of their rights and needs in this area. In ensuring them, various organisations play an irreplaceable role within a functioning civil society. These should therefore not be questioned, which we are unfortunately witnessing today also on the domestic political scene. On the contrary, they need to be helped and work to strengthen their independence.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. —A few days after Human Rights Day, we are discussing today in this House the Union's efforts to promote respect for human rights around the world. Our priorities have focused on such important issues as freedom of expression and association, freedom of conscience, the abolition of the death penalty and the fight against torture, among others, and we must continue to fight with an ambitious strategy that places human rights at the centre of the Union's relations agenda with the rest of the countries. There are numerous human rights violations that occur every day in the world, but today I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the imperative situation of the Saharawi people in Western Sahara. Together with many colleagues, we have tabled an amendment highlighting the unquestionable lack of respect for fundamental rights in these occupied territories and the release of political prisoners. We want a lasting solution to the conflict in Western Sahara rooted in the Saharawi people's right to self-determination, in accordance with United Nations resolutions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — Promoting and protecting human rights and democratic values are threatened worldwide, and regardless of the progress made during 2015, there are still serious problems hampering freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion and freedom of assembly and association. It is necessary to prevent repressive laws that negatively affect civil society and strengthen foreign and security policies based on democracy and the rule of law. In this context, the action of the international community is inevitably coordinated, because only in this way can high standards of human dignity, equality and solidarity be achieved. Moreover, I believe that the European Union and the Member States need to fully implement the measures established by the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy and push for UN reforms. The refugee crisis and tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea make it clear that greater contribution from all actors globally is needed.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. — As every year, we discuss the state of compliance with human rights in the world. At the same time, we rarely see when the Union itself contributes to their infringement outside its territory. This is the case with private military and security enterprises coming from her area. Some EU member states are among the largest exporters of military and protection services. These entities operate in a grey area of responsibility. The Union has excluded their operation from the provisions of the Service Directive, and its representatives are quite arrogantly opposed at the UN to draw up an international convention that would introduce legal regulations and restrictions on their activities. Claims that existing soft law acts, which are legally non-binding, such as the Montreux document or the Code of Adaptation of Private Security Service Providers, are not only ridiculous, but are already compromising the EU internationally. The European External Action Service plays an inglorious role in this regard. I therefore expect that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy will revise this position so that EU actors do not violate human rights outside the EU and the EU does not block the adoption of international regulations that seek to take private action military enterprises and protection in the international legal framework.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - The European Union cannot succumb to its ambition to remain the flagbearer of human rights and democracy in the world. This requires the coherence and credibility of the Union's external and internal policies more than ever in the face of the latest global challenges, particularly the refugee crisis. The credibility, in particular, in our migration policy, which has recently been disrupted internally by the governments of some EU Member States through inhumane, degrading, discriminatory treatment of refugees. A very thorough and important report by colleague Weidenholzer confronts us with dramatic facts from this point of view, but avoids naming specific Member States.
