As a Hungarian politician and a democrat, I cannot dispense with this, because today, unfortunately, the Orbán Government is the most shameful European example of systematic violations of refugee rights. It is the government that relocates refugees who are still stranded in the country to more humiliating conditions than ever before, to a tent camp that is unsuitable for winter stays. The regime under which a court can classify as a terrorist under the new anti-terrorism law and ten years (!) sentences a Syrian refugee to prison, who protested with speakers and rock throwing against the wall or barbed wire built on the Hungarian border, without personal injury. This is part of the overall picture of the human rights situation in Europe today, and I think it represents a serious internal challenge for the EU as a democratic community of values.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. — At present, human rights are strongly threatened not only at EU level, but also at global level, either by authoritarian regimes or by the actions of entities limiting the space of civil society, or even by the attitudes and behaviors of people in general that bring affecting fundamental freedoms and human rights. EU policy in this regard, based on promoting the principles of its creation, must not only be synergistically integrated into all its policies (development policy, common security and defence policy, enlargement policy, migration policy, etc.), but also coherent to internal and external level. Also, in order to increase the effectiveness of the EU in protecting and promoting human rights and democratic principles around the world, EU policy in this area must take into account the essence of the EU's annual reports, addressed critically and constructively, by highlighting not only achievements, but also challenges, constraints and even threats. Moreover, it is absolutely necessary to define and implement a system to monitor the assessment of progress made, including in the implementation of the action plan at Member State level, based on dialogues and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Elmar Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy (Article 36 TEU) (2016/2036 (INI)) (A8-0360/2016).

name: Elmar BROK
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, High Representative, dear Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to echo the last word of the previous rapporteur: in these hours the light is coming out in Aleppo — with much, much suffering and death. We have to recognise that attempts to achieve a peaceful solution have failed, and in the end Europe was no longer there, because I believe we have a decisive weakness. Not that Mrs Mogherini is doing the wrong job here, but if you don't have a stick, the carrot won't help with that either. That is why I believe that we need to make an appropriate mix, and what you have proposed in your Global Strategy, what has been decided by the Council of Foreign Affairs, which will be decided in the European Council the day after tomorrow, shows that we are crucial in the field of foreign, security and, above all, defence policy. need to move forward. We see that flight movements that concern us have something to do with a war that we cannot make a sufficient contribution to ending it decisively and early. We see that military violations of international law are being perpetrated in Europe, as in Kiev. We see that traffickers are causing incredible suffering on the coasts, which leads to many deaths in the Mediterranean. We see the development problems in Africa that bring insecurity, war and flight. I believe that we must also see that both Russia's conduct in violation of international law and statements in the American election campaign also lead to uncertainties as to whether NATO's collective defence still has full credibility. We must work to ensure that it has full credibility, because we need a security guarantee for our Member States, and that has to do with NATO. But this also shows that we need to develop our own skills to strengthen NATO, or if NATO does not work to have something of your own. For both reasons, we have to do this ourselves, and I believe that this must proceed accordingly. Nor can we make a difference in many parts between internal and external security when we come to the issue of terrorism, for example. I believe that many things intertwine and that, for these reasons, too, we need to overcome the passivity that we have sometimes had. The fact is that 70% or more of European citizens agree on an issue that more Europe needs to come — namely in foreign, security and distribution policy. I believe that sometimes the apparatuses in the national capitals block, but not the citizens who want more security. I believe that it is important for the reason that we finally come to the fact that there is a mentality in the Member States, that we need to have better common diplomacy, that the European Member States must act more together here and not a race between the foreign ministers, who will first compete with the foreign ministers. his flight somewhere, but it needs to be spoken with one voice to move diplomacy forward. We need development. If I have a sensible development policy, not only in the classical sense of development policy as we understand it, but better living conditions in other countries, particularly in Africa, also in view of the demographic factor. This includes a different trade policy. This means that there must be an integrated approach in many areas and no longer the distribution between two different subjects. I believe that only then can the problems be solved. Only then peace is possible. We must recognise that development provides security, but that even with stability, social justice, democracy and the rule of law, we are once again stabilising and advancing development can provide a sustainable development that is necessary. I believe that we need all the military conditions for this too. We need skills in foreign and security policy, and that is why we need to realise that our Member States are spending EUR 200 billion on defence, with a moderate result. Here we need the synergy effects in the areas of headquarters, command lines, cooperation, pooling and sharing, procurement, research and development. I believe that there is an urgent need for us to move forward in this area in order to be able to deliver accordingly. I hope that this development and this willingness, which has developed over the past six months, will play a role in the European Council on Thursday, that we will take decisive steps forward in the relevant preparatory work that you too, Mrs Mogherini, will make us take decisive steps to ensure that Europe gives its citizens the feeling that to provide security. Lack of security is what makes Europe insecure. Because of the fears — this is what drives the populists. Let us democrats produce security, based on human rights and development.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Thank you Mr President, but first of all, Elmar, thank you for this report but also thank you for all the work we have done in these two years. Thank you for the wisdom, the competence, the passion you put into everything you do and also into this excellent report. Thank you also for this debate, the third Article 36 debate we have had this year, and as you know we are supposed to have at least two Article 36 debates per year and we went further – this I believe is proof of the fact that we need to work more together on this, but also the intensity and the quality of our cooperation in this field. So thank you also for that, and thank you because your report follows not just the structure of the global strategy but also the spirit of the strategy. This report’s message on the European Union as, I quote, ‘the largest economic power, the most generous donor of humanitarian and development assistance, and the front-runner in global multilateral diplomacy’, end quote, is exactly what we need in these times. To be a little bit more self-confident or at least aware of the instruments we have. The report describes a European Union that is a superpower, a diplomatic superpower, but I’m glad that we are finally starting to realise our potential and our strength. It is so important that European institutions pass coherent messages in these complicated times, because we all see the challenges, we all see the threats, we also see the limits, but we must never forget our strengths. We must never forget that as a true Union we are a global player and our unity holds the key to the security of our citizens, as you just said, and also of our partners. And since I’ve presented the global strategy on foreign and security policy, our work for a stronger Union has moved on very concretely and very fast. So today I would like to update you on our main actions starting with those on security and defence that I will present on Thursday, two days from now, to the European Council, to our Heads of State and Government. When I presented this strategy I said that the implementation would have to begin in a matter of weeks and not in a matter of years, and by the end of this week exactly this package on security and defence will be presented. I will present it to the European Council to give its endorsement to it but also its orientations on this defence package. It is a package based on three main ideas and three main documents. First idea and documents. Our Union can be made more secure through our external action, and this is the sense of the global strategy and its implementation plan on security and defence, that was already endorsed by the Foreign and Defence Ministers in November. Second, we need a stronger defence industry and to achieve this goal with the European Commission we have put forward a European defence action plan. Third, we need stronger cooperation with our partners and with this in mind the European Union has signed an unprecedented joint declaration with NATO. This package includes a number of concrete actions to make our defence spending more efficient and effective, to improve our rapid response to crises, for the joint planning and conduct of our missions, and for Member States to explore the possibility of a permanent structured cooperation on defence matters. We need to address our citizens’ needs, not with endless ideological debates but with concrete decisions, so we are moving fast and with concrete steps towards a real European Union of security and defence. But implementation of the global strategy is not simply about defence. Greater integration on security cannot be and should not be a substitute for greater integration in other fields. I want to be very clear on this. We need much more in different fields of our policies for what relates my institutional competences, the second strand of implementation of the global strategy relates to the resilience of states and societies in our region and to an integrated approach to conflicts and crises. We are working now on a set of targeted actions to address the whole cycle of conflict and crisis, and on a joint communication on resilience to be presented by next spring. In the meantime, the strategy is already impacting on our new policy proposals: we have just discussed now the link between human rights and resilience, and how we are putting human rights at the centre of all our foreign policies. Moreover, last month we presented our proposal for a new consensus on development which is 100% consistent with the approach of the strategy: for the first time ever, all European institutions can agree on a shared development policy, one common policy on development for the Parliament, the Commission, the Council and each and every national government. If we finally manage to make full use of our different European and national instruments and at the same time to act as one single force, then our potential truly has no parallel in the world. Implementation of the strategy also includes the revision of our sectoral and geographical strategies and a renewed and joint attention on public diplomacy. But let me just focus on two other strands of implementation before I conclude. One is the link between our internal and external policies, starting from migration. Our external work on migration, in particular with the migration compacts, but not only, is proceeding along these lines and I will present the second progress report on the five migration compacts at the European Council on Thursday. Last but not least, the work on global governance. It is extremely important and I know I can count on this Chamber to work hand-in-hand on this. Just yesterday my friend António Guterres was sworn in as the new Secretary-General of the United Nations. Our cooperation with Ban Ki-moon already has been really impressive and I would like to thank him for this. On all the current crises, from Syria to Libya, to the work we are doing in these very minutes and hours on Aleppo, trying to guarantee the protection of civilians, all the current crises, all the work we do and also on all the global issues from sustainable development to climate change, the European Union and the United Nations are natural partners and we are working together on a daily basis. António’s mandate will provide us with an even greater opportunity to strengthen and reform the system of global governance. We are entering a phase of change for the United Nations, this is an opportunity for our European Union to be more and more present inside the UN system with a more effective coordination among Member States, and I think I can count on this Chamber to support this approach as well. The last few years, despite all the crises and all the difficulties inside the United Nations, we have also managed to show the incredible potential of a more cooperative global governance, from the deal on Iran’s nuclear programme to the Quartet report on the Middle East, from the Paris Agreement on climate change to the sustainable development goals, the international community has delivered on many of the challenges it has faced. The European Union has the duty and the interest to keep a reformed United Nations at the core of the international system, and I know on this we can work together with this Parliament. So let me also thank you, Elmar, for your constant leadership, for your constant wisdom, for your constant passion in the work you have done as the chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee. I know this is your last CFSP report as the AFET chair, but I count personally on your commitment to a stronger European Union, to continue to support the work we are doing to make the European Union our Union, a stronger actor as a force for multilateralism, for peace, for cooperation as a principled and responsible superpower.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the ambitious report prepared by Mr Elmar Brok, whose message is clear: we want a more present, more assertive, but above all more efficient Europe. It is time to focus on areas where we can make a difference, and respect for human rights and democracy must remain more than ever at the heart of our external policies. Here are a few things that I think are essential: first of all, enlargement. It must not be forgotten that this is the best instrument of stability on the European continent. Europe's reaction to the various crises and to the rise of populism must be openness, not retreat. I am thinking in particular of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a country for which I am rapporteur. We must do everything we can to ensure the future of the country within the Union. Secondly, our crisis management capabilities in the neighbourhood, be it east with Ukraine or south with Syria or Libya. The report points out that the European Union is a diplomatic superpower, which is true, in theory, but we must be more present. That is why, I believe, the Union can do more to resolve the Syrian conflict rather than just a humanitarian actor. Another point I would like to highlight is the issue of strategic partners of which India is a part. For this tool to be a real asset of our foreign policy, it must be redesigned and revitalized. Finally comes the Europe of defence. I hope that the Heads of State will give a strategic impetus to the defence on Thursday, with clear guidance on the way forward. We need more commitment on the part of the Member States, more cooperation and, above all, to equip us with real civilian and military capabilities. Preparatory action on defence research, which my group has very much supported, or the defence action plan presented by the Commission, are major steps forward. To get a place at the big table, the Union needs two things: strategic autonomy and a deterrent capacity.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I will start by thanking Elmar Brok for his excellent report. It is a real piece of work, a real legacy to the European Parliament and foreign affairs, security and defence. We are now in a period of unprecedented challenges for foreign policy, and with the election of Donald Trump in the USA, we also have ahead of us a situation of unprecedented uncertainty. This is happening at a time when we are confronted with multiple wars and, among other things, terrorism, migration, and the imperialistic attitude of Russia and its propaganda. I should also mention equally its direct threat to the free and fair elections in some new Member States and beyond. This gives even more importance to the role of the EU on the global scene. It is an opportunity, but also a challenge. We have to prove that we are capable of playing a leading role and a resolute one. We will be marginalised, and other global actors will prevail over us if we fail. In order to be influential, we need first and foremost unity and full support for the High Representative and the global strategy. This is the only way we can make use of our leverage. The other important consequence following the elections of the new American president is that we also have uncertainty as to how the USA will now interpret their role in NATO. This requires an even larger importance in the current international context. Also, from this point of view, we should take the opportunity to intensify the role of EU Member States within NATO, and to enhance the process of a joint EU-NATO agenda as was done after the NATO summit in Warsaw. This agenda must be based on complementarity, cooperation, coordination at the highest level of interoperability of our forces in the interest of collective defence.  I very much welcome the steps already taken by the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, and I only hope that this is just the starting point of much more consistent cooperation. It goes without saying that, in order to achieve these goals, we need to urgently strengthen and restructure our defence investments; not spending, but investments. I fear a simple coordination of investments is not enough. We have until today relied mostly on NATO and particularly on the USA. Now, the time has come to clearly identify our challenges and our needs and to take all the necessary actions in that direction while, at the same time, being proactive in the relations with the future challenges. I will conclude by saying that pooling and sharing has proved to be just close to nothing. We have to act for the security needs of all 27 Member States today and in the future.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Self-criticism would adorn the European Union, especially with regard to its failing Middle East policy. However, paragraph 48 of the Brok report lacks any trace of this. Unilateral criticism is once again ventilated towards Israel, and the EU itself remains out of control. Because what is the case? The EU violates both international law and the Interim Agreement between Israel and the Palestinians of 1995 (Oslo II) by financing Palestinian construction and infrastructure projects in the C area of the West Bank without any coordination with the relevant Israeli authorities. The security of the Jewish state is also at stake: geopolitical talk. This European Union policy, together with Brussels political action against the Jewish presence in Judea and Samaria, as well as the 2013 guidelines and the 2015 product labelling, disqualifies the EU as a party or even a peacekeeper in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. A fiasco!

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I give my full support to the Brok report and to the work of Elmar Brok, not only concerning this report, but also his whole commitment to European integration in this Parliament and outside. We should put our money where our mouths are, and that means that we can’t just have declarations and no means. We should have this option of 2% GNP for our defence. This is also the NATO commitment. We should strengthen European defence, of course. The best thing would be inside NATO as the European pillar. Since Kennedy it has been an issue that we should have it, and we should now really create it. However, if the United States and the European members of NATO do not agree, then Europe has to have its own options. It cannot be stagnant. Of course we have to have joint procurement and joint research and development. Let me be clear: Russia should know that we defend our Union and our values, and that is with hard power and with soft power. We should under-promise and over-deliver, and we should go forward together. Again, European defence – and I limit myself to this issue – is key.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. The praise of the EU as a generous donor of development aid and humanitarian aid in the report conceals an important fact: 60% of development aid funds go directly back to European companies and organisations. Mr Brok, sensible development aid, sustainable development aid looks different! Criticism of the practice of arms exports is also in vain, as the EU remains one of the largest arms dealers in the world. In fact, there are regulations, but arms are unrebated, death is exported, especially to the countries of the Middle East. It is cynical when the people who want to flee to Europe before death by these weapons are increasingly prevented from doing what drives them on even more dangerous routes. Legal escape routes are now almost completely closed. It is an abuse to use development aid to better defend against protection seekers. Borders are being raised before the borders — see Tunisia, Libya, the Sahel. Yes, that too is a kind of enlargement policy. Is this also a human rights policy that has always been invoked in the debate before? These connections are not found in the report, because there is only one route here: more armament, more money for the arms industry and arms research, the fusion of internal and external security, and not least aggressive refugee defence. For a long time they wrote on the flags that the EU wanted to create a ring of friends around it. This approach has completely failed. What we have is a ring of fire! When will the right consequences be drawn from this? That would mean: a fundamental change of policy, and not more and more of the wrong.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this is one of the yearly occasions when we should be able to talk about our global vision and our responses at the global scale. Nevertheless, I’m going to concentrate on a few more specific issues since this is not the first, and probably won’t be the last document dealing with our global strategy and its implementation. First of all, let me thank the rapporteur for the exemplary work which as usual he put into the report, both in the draft and in the negotiations. We are glad to be able to be part of many of the compromises. The report rightly highlights the possibility and the wish and even, to some degree, the fact that Europe could be a diplomatic superpower. It is something that we should all strive for, and we agree that this is the goal, but there are quite a few steps along the way until we fully reach that potential. Just to mention one single example: the EU has more diplomatic representations around the globe than any of the Member States, but nevertheless so far we have been unable to pool even our consular functions. So the blocks that come are usually not from the other institutions, not from the European Parliament and not from the Council, but from the Member States. A diplomatic superpower should not speak with many different voices. We can only become a diplomatic superpower if we remain committed to an integrated and common foreign policy. For that we need to convince our Member States as well. Secondly, I would like to mention the claims that we need significant defence capability development. We agree that we need to have power in order to be able to keep and foster peace around the world. That also requires power, we fully agree with that. We also agree that we are not there yet. We need further developments in this field. However, what we’re slightly worried about is the militarisation of foreign policy: that is something which needs to be avoided, and it needs to be avoided because a military policy cannot dictate the needs of diplomacy. Last but not least, as the Vice President has already mentioned, the development policy needs to be an integrated one, fully agreed between all the institutions. This is something that requires primacy to be given to development and not to security.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, well, as you all pat yourselves on the back for creating a combined EU army, I for one am becoming increasingly concerned. With great military power comes great responsibility. While the EU describes itself as a diplomatic superpower, it is nothing of the kind. You only need to look at the mess the EU has created in Turkey to see that this institution does not have the experience or the maturity to be a superpower. And with a superpower army must come a superpower defence budget. My question is who is going to pay? As part of Brexit the British people voted to return the UK armed forces intact, free of the EU army. So I would be loath to see one penny of British taxpayers’ money being used to fund the EU’s new defence agenda. That is why I am calling for the UK to be exempt from all new spending in this area. The British people demand it.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the enthusiastic tone in which the situation of a Europe which has decided, according to this report, to be a protagonist, I would say that dictate world politics, clashes with a somewhat different reality. A reality that sees, for example, a situation totally changed in the international relationship between the great powers, when even a simple immobiliarist, a person who has made himself, who himself is always busy with business, real estate, but which obviously has a great sense, he understood that the fight against terrorism, because here we say that a strong, muscular, European defence policy is needed to fight terrorism and pretend not to know that the golden way to fight terrorism and beat terrorism — Aleppo teaches — is to seek a policy of agreement, of coexistence with that other power World military that is able to fight against terrorism, which fights terrorism and above all beats terrorism, while Europe is good at making words, defending rights human, but so weak that we can't even rip up the trafficking of poor human people across the Mediterranean, as we have repeatedly come to denounce. But let's come to defense policy. On this policy, let's say that making rhetoric about the fledgling European army is problematic, since it appears a bit of a compromise, a middle ground, a European army that doesn't have enough men and endowments to fight an eventual war, it doesn't even have the necessary structure. And then we wonder what the real aims of this European army are. The first is to complete the disarmament of individual states and to complete the robbery of sovereignty and also an economic robbery, given the high cost: 500 million a year I am certainly not for something that serves no use, I'm not certain few. The second, the second aspect, the second goal even worse. In the original text of the resolution of 22 November on European defence policy, it reads that “the army entrusted to the European Defence Agency should work in concert with NATO on various operations, including those concerning immigration.” It is easy to assume that the European military could, for example, dedicate itself to rescuing migrants arriving by sea on our shores, to help the big traffickers. Given that the EU's policy so far has been to turn us into an open-air refugee camp, we Italians, Greece, and so on, soldiers would be reduced to completing the work. This is not what Europe needs, to fight terrorism seriously, put an end to this idiotic and irresponsible cold war policy against Russia, which is indispensable to eradicate the terrorism.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). — Madam President, it is a fact that the European Union faces many challenges and threats. However, in order to implement a common foreign and defence and security policy, it is essential that it meets the needs of the Member States and does not satisfy the expediency and the anchorages of the European Union's leading circle. The two main threats currently facing the European Union are terrorism and the invasion of illegal immigrants. But both of them have come from erroneous interventions by the European Union in internal conflicts of neighbouring countries, usually supported by the wrong side. This must stop happening in the future. In order to control migratory flows, which many terrorists also carry in the European Union, safe areas must be created in the neighbouring countries of the crisis country, hot spots must be created there and aid for refugees there. The European Union's commercial and agricultural policy towards third countries must not be directed against the interests of the inhabitants of the countries of the European Union by creating unfair competition. The defence of the European Union must continue to be based on NATO, 22 of the 28 countries of which are Member States of the European Union. The European Union must not replace NATO. Moreover, the threats it receives are not so strong as to justify an excessive increase in its military capabilities. Finally, countries which do not meet the Copenhagen criteria and create problems should not be called upon to integrate into enlargement.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President! Mrs High Representative, thank you for your presentation. I would like to reassure you on one point: I don't think it's time to give any farewell speeches on Elmar Brok yet. This will also make its voice heard independently of a function and, I believe that we will continue to support our policy here to the best of its ability. You mentioned that we have a summit at the end of this week where we will also talk about security and defence. I would imagine that the occasion will perhaps be asked what has been implemented since the summits of December 2013 or even June 2015. I think we have some catching up on there. I'll name one keyword: security of supply. This is a decision, and we have not made any progress. I would really like you to take up these decisions and also remind the Member States that they did so. But it also takes progress on your part. You will be asked how to implement the defence package. I would therefore like more courage from the Commission if Member States appear to make the derogation the rule and make unjustified use of Articles 3, 4 and 6. I really want clear guidelines on your part to prevent you from simply stealing out of this defence internal market. Keyword certification in the military sector: In the civilian sector, why not in this area? Surely an area where we could save money. I am also chairman of the delegation for relations with the Pan-African Parliament. In relations with Africa, we can make very specific differences in the way we treat countries, such as Ghana and Gabon, on current occasions. Both actually have a change of government, only in Gabon does the president accept not. Therefore, it should become visible how we act differently there. And in Gambia, the president changed his mind. Here too, we should show concretely what it means to support the democratic will of the peoples and what reactions we will have if a President who has been voted out does not accept this. This is very effective on the part of the Union, especially with regard to individual states.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Madam President, Fukuyama was wrong. History did not end because the present brought back power politics to the international system, forcing the EU to readapt to this old type of politics. Elmar Brok’s report, being very complex and therefore comprehensive, an appropriate legacy I should say, compels us to be selective in the topics we address. Consequently, I intend to address only two issues. The first is the popular support the EU is getting from its citizens. That support is indispensable for the functioning and future of our Union, and the truth is that sometimes our adversaries communicate better with our citizens then we manage to do. But it is due to the easiness with which confusion and manipulation percolate in an environment with many alternative sources of information. Paradoxically, the more sources of information we have, the less informed we are. And that is in part from the support provided to the eurosceptic parties on the extreme right and extreme left of the political spectrum. But it is partly due to our own making, to our strong belief, not always warranted, that the European citizens believe and follow automatically the EU leaders, and to the over-bureaucratisation of the EU’s relations with its citizens. And here I have a parenthesis to point to the new regulation concerning visitors here in this Parliament. The second issue is the expected revision of the current arrangements regulating world trade today. Already TTIP is on ice and the TTP contemplates total scrapping. If that happens it will challenge the EU’s initial raison d’être, questioning its first achievement, namely its common commercial policy. Imagine all those long decades of tough negotiations to provide the current institutional and legal platform for world trade becoming irrelevant or facing the perspective of becoming irrelevant overnight. Where would that leave the EU? What would that mean to the EU power status?

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! The future of European cooperation depends on mutual and solidarity, partnership cooperation of our countries, but also on respect for European nations. This report contains very important wording, for example, on the importance and sadly sad perspective of the commitment of thousands of young European Muslims to the forces of the Islamic State Caliphate or wording on the increasing Russian expansion on east of Europe. But the conclusions are fatally stereotypical — more power for the integrated EU institutions, unfortunately this fateful tone of disregard, aggression, exclusion in relation to Europeans who remain in opposition, in an empowered opposition to the European Union authorities or to the governments that eat they support. Please, one thing is clear: the sooner the European establishment learns to respect those millions of Europeans who disagree with its policies, the more bad news in the future we will avoid.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: — Thank you Chairman, Reverend Mrs. Mogherini. Today in this hall we listened to the tragic story of the winners of the Sakharov Prize. I don't know what we were thinking about, each of our own. I asked myself the question of how much responsibility we should take on me, so that the countries that were their homeland were scattered. Our responsibility is great. Therefore, I do not support the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy, for the following reasons: the concept of a common policy in the security area builds on a linear increase in defence budgets and on an armed race, defines a common enemy, advocates deepening the Cold War, on the propaganda of the opposite side wants to answer with the same, absurd methods. We are talking about the principle of three D: Diplomacy, Developement, Defence, but we pay attention to the latter and neglect the possibilities and obligations of European diplomacy. Peace and security can be ensured through the search for common interests, respect for international law and policy accountability in all countries of the European Union that are members of NATO or not.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Madam President, this is a report based on a securitarian and militaristic perspective which, moreover, reaches conclusions without analysis of the causes, because something will have to see that our neighbourhood is burning with military intervention, destabilization using extremist groups, or breaking consensus and agreements. It increases all military capabilities, but not to seek a non-aggressive deterrence, nor an independent European Union. It assumes transatlantic visions, that is, that America remains our guardian. It holds the Warsaw Summit; a global NATO that seems to compete with the UN, increasingly aggressive with our East neighbourhood. He continues to bet on unilateral sanctions. In Syria, for example, Aleppo has been released. I do not know whether the European Union has learned that it has to talk to the Syrian Government as well. This common foreign and security policy leads to further conflict, increase military expenditure, and to a discouraged European Union that still does not understand geopolitical changes and remains subordinate to the interests of the global power.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini. The horrific events in Aleppo show us how little we play a role. The fact that we do not play a role in this brutal military drama at the moment, however, is also due to the fact that we as Europeans did not use our opportunities together before, than there could have been any other than military solutions. Against the backdrop of this Aleppo menetekel, speaking of a superpower Europe seems almost absurd to me. With this sounds like loss of reality. But I would also like to warn against this hollow arrogance because I believe that this is not what the European citizens expect. Indeed, European citizens expect us to deliver in the area of external and internal security. yeah! But I do not believe that they are keen on Europe striving for a superpower role and interfering throughout the world. I believe what they want is for us to stick to the peaceful orientation of our Union. If Elmar Brok tries to thinker this rhetorically by talking about the diplomatic superpower, it's well meant, but I don't think it helps anything. As long as the Member States, as long as the national capitals do not have the political will to speak with one voice, as long as we can make plans and resonate words as much as we want. Mr Jurek, I must also say this in your direction to the right: to stand as a pole here and pretend that Europe is virtually raping the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe by trying to develop a common security, that is already a strong piece! Who is supposed to stand up for you in solidarity anyway? Do you think Mr. Trump will do that? I don't think that's possible. You cannot make yourself a casper in the European Parliament by denying reality. But, Mrs Mogherini, we cannot try to overcome weakness with rhetorical Bramar-based. If the army chiefs have identified 300 pooling and sharing projects and only 19 have been tackled so far at all, then we know what concrete needs to be worked on.

name: Petr MACH
text: — Ladies and gentlemen, in a moment you are about to vote, and I quote: “The European Union is the greatest success in history.” I think the European Union is a big mistake and just another pretentious effort at central management of our entire continent. You are about to vote down, and I quote: “The European Union is the greatest economic power.” To me, the reshuffling of bureaucracy has stopped economic growth across Europe and brought some countries to the brink of state bankruptcy. You are about to vote, and I quote: “The European Union brings peace, prosperity and stability.” I think European diplomacy has sparked a civil war in Ukraine and the European Union's migration policy has brought to Europe only instability, terror and one million illegal migrants. You are about to vote down the creation of the European Union Army, the European Union Military Command, the Defence Council and the Military Planning Unit. I, seeing and observing the chaos five years ago the actions of some states caused the European Union in Libya, seeing how the diplomacy of the European Union caused a disturbance in Ukraine, when I see, as you downvoted the countries of central europe in terms of migration quotas, so simply from the idea of a european army, frost runs down my back. So I will vote against it and I urge you, vote against this report Mr Brok as well.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Madam President, long live President Brok, transformed into Santa Claus! I know him rather as Father Fouettard, against those who dare to tell the truth, the villains populists who love the people. We must welcome the list of very appropriate good intentions on this Christmas holiday: peace, democracy, human rights and, for this, European defence under the European tree. The reality is that a foreign and defence policy would require European sovereignty. This cannot exist, because there is no real sincere convergence of interests. Let's look, for example, at what is called the Franco-German couple. With each partnership, French interests are drowned in Germanic politics, presented as a European policy. I could give examples, I do not have time. The reality is that behind the void of the discourse of European values lies the reality of the new imperialism, of this hegemonic will which has already cost Europe so much. It is called economic war or imposed foreign policy, but it is always the same arrogance, the same contempt for other peoples, the same brutal domination. The reality is that behind the so-called common policy there is also the action of opaque influence groups, relays of powerful oligarchies and criminal groups that make up both, such as the Soros Foundation, which prepared Mrs Merkel's migration policy. John Paul II prophesied the close end of totalitarian liberalism, after that of totalitarian collectivism. This will be the end of your Europe. People are already expressing their revolt and that is why President Juncker no longer wants to consult them. Let us betray the peoples of Europe, in the name of democracy and human rights! That's your policy. It is time to build a Europe of cooperation and nations with respect for the freedom of peoples, but for that we must get out of your Europe totalitarian. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Question about the procedure of the 'blue card'. — Mr Schaffhauser, did I just understand correctly that Jean-Claude Juncker is undermining human rights while Mr Putin defends them?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: The answer “blue card”. — I do believe that thanks to the intervention of Russia — and in this way I am just saying what the bishop of Aleppo also says — we have been able to restore law, justice, respect for minorities that existed before, especially for Christian minorities, who lived much better before today, and that as a result of that intervention, we have managed to restore some stability, we hope, for the future.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). — Madam President, the report is a basis for plans for new imperialist wars, for the profit plans of the Euro-unifying monopolies. The White Paper on defence, the European Defence Semester and their defence fund, the support of Athena-type programmes for more expeditionary bodies are some of the means of promoting these European Union projects, either independently or complementary to the THERE IT IS. The European Defence Union, the Euroarmy, the Euroheadquarters based on the European Union's global strategy do not remove — on the contrary, they confirm the strong competition within the European Union and as a whole. But the very expensive bill will again be paid by the peoples with new massacres, border changes, and fugees. The Greek government is implicating our country in all this, while provocatively photographed and coloured on the islands with golden savites, oil the criminal Nazi Golden Dawn. Here and now fight against the imperialist plans of the European Union, NATO and the United States and governments, so that people do not spill their blood for the interests of the monopolies!

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: — Madam President, High Representative, I have always considered that the function you are carrying out is a task that is almost impossible, given the scale of the task and the difficulty of the challenges. But I must say that, in the difficulty, there is also the difficulty of enduring a lot of things that you have to hear today in this chamber. Freedom of expression sometimes leads to aberrations or even lies, and I salute your courage to hold until the end of this session. I have no doubt about the professionalism and dedication of many people, starting with yourself, who serve, I was going to say under the European flag, be it in the external missions in our delegations and in the external action service in Brussels. These people are professional, they are dedicated to the cause. However, I must say that I continue to doubt a part of this system and foreign policy which, by wanting to do everything everywhere, with all the instruments at our disposal, fails to make the European Union sufficiently audible. Unfortunately, we are still lacking — and this is largely the responsibility of the Member States, of course — of this hierarchy of priorities that would make the European Union truly weigh where it should weigh, and as a matter of priority in our nearby environment. I am very concerned that the European Union is losing its environment, from Ukraine to Syria, Libya and the Horn of Africa. These are places where we have conducted a lot of missions, where we have deployed a lot of staff, where we spent a lot of money, and we lose those places, we are no longer audible, we are no longer determinant, if we have never been. This is a matter to question the sense of priorities we must have and the concentration of the resources we need to invest, perhaps in a number of areas smaller, but where our action will be truly decisive. Our credibility is first played out in our close environment, so I will ask you, for the coming year, to put the package on issues that are really in our environment and which weigh on our stability. I am thinking in particular of the action you are taking, which I hope will be decisive, especially for Tunisia, which is an essential link in the chain of stability — or instability — that prevails around Europe. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), a blue-card question. — (GR) Thank you for accepting my speech. If I understood correctly, you said that the possibility of free expression leads to extreme views. Do I understand correctly that you are opposed to freedom of expression or not?

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: answer “blue card”. — I think, sir, that you have had a translation problem. I said precisely that freedom of expression in this chamber has led to outrances and lies, and if you want an example of a lie that I could hear this afternoon, I heard a Member, not very far from where you are located, say that thanks to the actions of Mr. Putin and Mr. Assad in Aleppo, ISIS had been destroyed. I ask these people to withdraw a lie; ISIS is not present in Aleppo. There are Syrian opposition groups, which are armed groups, perhaps terrorist groups, that is possible, but there is no Islamic State in Aleppo. That's the kind of lie you can hear. It is freedom of expression, but it is nonetheless a factual and objective lie.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to applaud the High Representative’s work on security and defence. The common set of proposals, approved last week, to implement the EU-NATO joint declaration represents important steps forward. Member States must have more ambition and sign up to a systematic effort to fill the EU’s foreign security and defence policy with a greater sense of purpose and urgency. Many EU countries have become inward-looking and suspicious of European projects; this creates the tendency to respond to events rather than to shape them. A stronger, more robust policy is needed to promote a stable and prosperous neighbourhood. Developing a new technology, or upgrading a military infrastructure, is a long-term process. That is why countries must start immediately, without wasting more time. We also need to strengthen the capacities of our neighbours and partners, because the security of our neighbours is also our security. If Europe is to remain safe and secure, defence cooperation among Member States and through partnership must become the norm.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! I would like to remind you that in the 1950s Europeans already started a company to establish a European defence community. This failed at the time, and since then we have lived very well under the protection of NATO. It is a dangerous game that we are suddenly beginning to supplement this protection of NATO with something of our own now, at a time when military protection and military strength are undoubtedly more necessary than in the last two decades, and when external threats are increasing. The European Member States of NATO are already struggling to meet their alliance obligations. If we now send a signal to the new US president that Europeans have their own defence community, a European Defence Union — then he can only see it as an invitation to reduce the US alliance's commitments to extend the US's strength to other problematic regions of the world. focus. I think we're going a fundamentally wrong way here. We should get involved in NATO to drive forward joint efforts there. Joint arms procurement projects and the like are taking place without further ado. There is no need to create a double structure here.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, against the background of the latest news on US President-elect Trump making Rex Tillerson the Secretary of State, it is very timely to speak about EU-US relations in the context of world security. The development of good relations between the European Union and the USA has been a decades-long process. We are allies and work together in trying to find solutions to various crises around the world, with the aim of promoting peace, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Even today, we are closely working together in trying to bring an end to the war in Syria and defeat ISIS and the terror they spread. We also have the same point of view when it comes to Russian aggression in Ukraine and Georgia.  We need to ensure that this good relationship between the EU and the United States continues, and again I come to the point that the European Union must do more for its own security and defence. For starters, the EU Member States need to set the goal of spending 2% of their GDP on defence, as the NATO members have done, and cooperation between the EU and NATO must be deepened.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, here we go again: it is another uncritical report, another unrelenting push for the militarisation of Europe at all levels. A coordinated EU security and defence policy through to an EU army will not make our citizens any safer, in fact the militarisation of the EU is nothing more than a vanity project by Commissioners and larger Member States. The calls for increased military funding for Member States to meet NATO capacity goals and the call for the EU to combine its soft power with hard power are ludicrous. It is a promotion of an EU arms industry while social expenditure is being simultaneously slashed. We are all well-versed in the history of Europe to know what happened the last time that Europe became extremely militarised. Will the only difference now be that this time the guns will be pointing outwards instead of in? May I also conclude by stating that reports like this are further evidence of the contempt for neutral Member States by many in this Parliament and the European institutions.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President! We live in a new age and we have new security policy challenges — wars in our local area, terrorist attacks that strike in our midst. And as long as terror struck in any country far over there, then the notes in our newspapers were small. Now it strikes in our midst, and fear grabs hold of us, and also the desire to act. But most of the terrorists are born and raised in our midst, and what did we do wrong? Friends are no longer friends, and enemies can suddenly become friends. The fight against the great common enemy, that is climate impact, can basically be lost with a new president of the United States. It doesn't look bright. Guns we ourselves have sold to previously peaceful and kindly minded states end up in the wrong hands. They are used against our friends and maybe against ourselves, but we keep selling. EU member states act. We're raising our defense appropriations, we're working on anti-radicalisation, and hopefully we're also doing better risk assessments before new weapons get permission to be sold. I agree with the rapporteur that we need better cooperation and coordination between Member States. So far I think we all agree. What we have a different picture of, on the other hand, is what way we solve the problems very best. Many in this House want us to move towards an increasingly common military — becoming a superpower. That, in breach of the regulatory framework, we should use EU funds for a variety of military purposes, and in addition to defence research. The report talks about the EU's military capability, despite the fact that today we do not have such a model because it is the military capabilities of the Member States. And not everyone actually wants to go in that direction either. Increased flexibility is requested by EU financial rules and I interpret it as saying that other things, such as aid, will be used to cover military action. Countries are asked to put two percent of GDP on defence, etc. There is a lot that is good in the report, but there are also a lot of issues, or writes, which I as green and swedish can't get behind. Thank you!

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President! So we are now discussing the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report regrets that the performance of the common defence policy is not properly communicated and calls for better emphasise merits. Have you perhaps thought, Mr Brok — your report — that people have understood very well what you are writing here and understand exactly the policy that you are conveying but want to have a different policy and not other words that you describe? Then I read that propaganda is about to be done. The EU and the Member States should be called upon to make propaganda — counter-propaganda, of course. But propaganda remains propaganda. In a free society, it is the task of journalists and the media to research and disseminate information, and in a free society it is precisely not the task of the States to form public opinion. Democracy becomes absolutely meaningless if the state uses propaganda to form the opinion of its citizens. Maybe you should think about it. I think people have understood well what this is about. I think people are simply opposed to politics, and dealing with this with propaganda is useless.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate Mr Brok on his report. It is a complete and realistic text about our main challenges and threats, about the instruments we have to deal with them. The current uncertain international landscape requires a more active and cohesive foreign policy of the Union, which defends our interests and values, committed to multilateralism and the defence of the universality of human rights. Moreover, we need to act in the face of the gradual deterioration of our security environment. The circle of instability surrounding the Union in the neighbourhood area; the terrorist threat, particularly in Daesh; the revisionist attitudes of some countries, as well as the possible withdrawal of the United States, are elements that compel us to deepen our common foreign policy and in particular its security dimension and, in particular, its security dimension and defense. In this regard, I welcome the priority given to strengthening this policy in Mr Brok's document. There will never be a Union foreign policy without a genuine common security and defence policy. We must be ambitious in its implementation, as are the Council conclusions of last November and the recent Commission proposals. But also pragmatic, particularly in a context of fiscal consolidation, as is known. Finally, I do not want to conclude without remembering the humanitarian tragedy that Aleppo is experiencing. The parties need to sit back to negotiate and there is a political agreement for the Syrian conflict. But today, the most urgent thing is to alleviate the humanitarian tragedy that is going on there, and there too the Union can make an important contribution.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: — Mr President, it is extremely difficult to predict the future at the moment geopolitically. What is certain is only that we need deeper integration and defence cooperation, such as joint procurement and standards, but above all we need to maximise the Union's diplomacy and crisis management. Gotta avoid false rhetoric. There has often been talk of the European military here, and I understand that it is not at all. The issue is cooperation. You also have to avoid unnecessary provocation in relation to Russia. I also think it's particularly important that when it's uncertain what's going on in the United States, transatlantic relations emphasize value-based cooperation with the U.S. It is an absolutely important and important message for the United States as well. Mr President, what is new about this is that the EU no longer focuses on security and defence policy only on external operations, but attention is moving closer to the Union's own borders and regions. With the implementation of this global strategy, we have to answer and face the question of how ultimately the European Union will bear responsibility for protecting the Union, including through military means. This response needs to be achieved, and I agree with the High Representative, if the European Union is unanimous, if it used all the tools we have, we would really be a huge force to bring about good change in the world.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, due to the political changes that engulfed the world in 2016, there is a growing voice of disoriented elites living in their own world and less listening and understanding voters. This report is a great example of this rift between elites and ordinary people. The rapporteur asks us to disregard national interests and put European ones first. He calls national interests narrow-minded and outdated. The only thing that is outdated here is a romantic supponational model that aims to create a European superpower in which everyone primarily feels Europeans and puts the interests of the European Union first. National identities and nation-states are a European reality, because the vast majority of citizens put them first. It is the citizens who wonder what kind of Europe they want, and they almost unanimously refuse further political integration. Those whose own political agenda is ahead of the will of the citizens, not those who fight for national interests, have been rejected in more and more states.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I have to say that the concept of cooperation amongst EU Member States is ridiculous when you only have to look at the frequent incursions. Only yesterday there was another Spanish naval incursion into Gibraltarian waters. I have a consistent wariness of the development of EU common defence and foreign affairs. This place consistently talks about supporting and cooperating with NATO. I call it undermining and replacing. Why would we give up a tried and tested alliance system in NATO in the name of an EU experiment? My belief is no better expressed than in this report. Although Member States make a spending commitment to NATO of 2% of GDP, most do not, and it is only through accounting trickery that my own country does. The development of EU military ambitions directly challenges the neutral stance of Sweden, the Republic of Ireland and Austria. If the EU will not comprehend that, your ambitions for ever closer union at all levels are eventually bound to fail, but of course you will only blame someone else when that eventuality happens.

name: David McALLISTER
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that the European Union's common foreign and security policy should necessarily be based on the three major English-language Ds: diplomacy, development and defence. On diplomacy, we agree that the European Union should continue to focus its policy on conflict resolution and international consensus. As the largest trading power in the world, our word as the European Union has weight. Second: development. I think paragraph 40 of the report makes it particularly clear that we Europeans must tackle the root causes of instability and inevitable migration, such as poverty, economic inequality of opportunity, armed conflict, poor governance and climate change. This can only be achieved if we strengthen democratic institutions and civil society, and thus the resilience of unstable states. Thirdly, Defence. A lot has been said about defence. I believe that the European Union's common security and defence policy needs to be further strengthened. The High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, is on the right track here. Only by strengthening our civilian and military capacities will we be able to respond comprehensively to crises, strengthen the resilience of our partners and protect Europe. In short, this report makes it clear why it is imperative that the European Union should assume more responsibility in the common foreign and security policy, as citizens expect from us. I am particularly grateful to our rapporteur, Elmar Brok.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: — Dear colleagues! Dear Mrs Mogherini! I think the main question that needs to be answered is whether the countries of the European Union really want a common foreign and defence policy. The problem is that in many cases the answer is still “no.” Member States still want to live in their own world and do not want to lose sovereignty. The bad news for these countries is that the world is changing and Europe's influence in the world is rapidly falling for a variety of reasons, whether in terms of population size, economy size, military. It's neither bad nor good - it's a reality, but Europeans and politicians still see Europe as the centre of the world who can dictate its rules to other countries and regions of the world. That's not the case anymore, and practitioners who encounter foreign affairs every day can only confirm this. It's good if an old man still feels that he is young and strong, but much worse is if he continues to act like a young one. But he also has his own strengths, such as experience and patience. The number of instruments of influence in European foreign policy is very limited. We still have strengths: technology, education, a capacious internal market, influence in international organisations, opportunity to finance projects, etc., but Europe is unfortunately losing its influence with every step. The question is how quickly Europe will lose its positions to other superpowers, and where the new point of equilibrium will ultimately be. That, I think, is the main point of this report.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, the CFSP and CSDP have received a bad press in my country, the UK, where it is wrongly suggested that it will inevitably lead to an EU standing army aimed at undermining NATO; Mr Carver is completely wrong on this. I take a more nuanced approach and I have always seen a complementary role for cooperation in foreign policy and defence at EU level. It was with this in mind that delivered CFSP’s origins after all, in so-called political cooperation in the 1986 European Single Act, as agreed by the then-UK Prime Minister, one Mrs Thatcher. For instance, EUNAVFOR ATALANTA’s success has proved that there is a defence role for the EU that combines soft and hard power, without undermining NATO, Mr Carver, whilst the sanctions regime employed against Iran has illustrated that a CFSP common position can leverage our individual Member States’ positions. As Britain sadly leaves the European Union, I believe that foreign security policy will be one of the key areas that we must remain plugged into. In possession of one of the world’s most effective armed forces, being one of the P5 on the Security Council and a nuclear power, the UK has a lot to offer the EU, particularly as our shared interests will remain the same post-Brexit. As a member of NATO, the Berlin Plus Agreement will allow Britain to easily contribute to any future CFDP missions and I hope that during the Brexit negotiations, the EU 27 will see sense in finding a more formalised structured CFSP role for Britain, given its close links to the continent and the ongoing common security interests. The UK, for instance, could bring more to the table by way of military assets in exchange, during the negotiations, for concessions elsewhere, such as better access to the Single Market.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, Mr Brok’s report is an excellent one, integrating very well both old and new challenges because, first of all, this report is about implementation, which is often the weakest link in our system. I would remind us of the message in the previous report, by Mr Paşcu: ‘Europe is no longer in control of its security environment and has lost the luxury of choosing the time and place of action’. What we need, it says, is ‘crisis prevention and crisis resolution’. Aleppo is unfortunately a symbol of failed crisis-resolution, with a devastating moral and political price. This report also addresses the new front of security policy, that is, how to counter misinformation and propaganda. I think it is very important that we call for the EU institutions and Member States to finally and clearly acknowledge that the ongoing information warfare is not only an external EU issue, but also an internal one. Because propaganda and misinformation result in election outcomes, that is, a real change of power. One of my calls is also to establish an automated information-sharing system in the EU.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini. The global strategy you have presented must be the framework for European foreign and security policy, and this should be implemented step by stage. I only call Africa. You also mentioned this: a continent that we have long neglected. Clean energy for all, programmes for young people, these are examples of how we can then mitigate other problems, such as migration. For Africa, I always recommend that we cooperate with China, because they are very present on this continent. As President of the European Movement, I know how much South-East Europe is waiting for signals that we are fulfilling our promises. They feel neglected, so you have to give signals again and again that they belong to us. You mentioned Antonio Guterres our old friend. Indeed, even more so, great commitment to the UN is required. We need a new agenda for the world that can really compensate for these imbalances. This is the second time we have been discussing safety here in a short time. There is no question that citizens expect the European Union to be able to organise security. I would encourage you to continue with your timetable and not be impressed by all the anti-Europeans who have said so horrible and wrong here. It is really in the interests of the citizens that we create synergies and that we enable ourselves as the EU to truly establish security and peace. That's why I think we are world power in many areas, but in this area, we are just a dwarf, and that needs to change. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I have just heard that you are fully behind European defence policy. I would remind you that in 1999 it was your party that, together with the Greens, once waged and supported the war in Kosovo, in disregard of international law. I would, of course, ask you whether, in the future, the European Defence Army will ensure that international law is respected, because European air forces are currently operating in the airspace there, in contravention of international law and the sovereignty of the state of Syria. Should this become EU policy in the future?

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — This cannot become EU policy. Anyone looking at Article 2 of the Lisbon Treaty will see that the EU can only carry out military missions on behalf of the international community, the UN. And that is exactly the difference with the Member States of the EU. You know them that take military action — very often for good purposes, but sometimes for dubious purposes. I hope that a European peace policy will respect international law and not abuse international law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, the European Union is well founded on the merit of the solidarity of its Member States. The Common Foreign and Security Policy has been established to protect all the countries of the Union. In recent times Greece has been facing obvious challenges from both Turkey and Albania. In particular, Mr Erdogan now disputes the Lausanne Treaty, disputes Greece's sovereign rights in the Aegean islands, Turkish militants violate Greek airspace, exert enormous pressure and to all this the Greek people do not see a satisfactory response on the part of the European Union. The European Union remains dormant. He doesn't really grind the sultan's teeth. It does not tell him that he needs to be put together and that his challenges against Greece do not pass. Turkey must therefore understand that it cannot continue in this direction, but in that we need the determination of the European Union. It is a fact that Greece has the potential to deal with Turkey, but it also needs the support of the European Union. To demonstrate in practice that Community solidarity exists!

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the High Representative and thank Elmar Brok for a very well prepared report. Our foreign and security policies need to be more results-oriented. We have to lead a credible and efficient policy which matches the expectations of our citizens. The EU should strengthen its international position and assume more responsibility for our security. Strength is in our unity; building trust between the Member States is the way to have a common and integrated approach to our external policies, be it trade, security or development. The global strategy and security strategy is a step forward. The upcoming revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is an opportunity to allocate appropriate resources for their implementation. The EU needs to show that the value invested in these policies is paying back. We should start taking more responsibility in our neighbourhood. We can feel the effects of migration, terrorism and attacks on international order and values. Our global aspirations start and end in our backyard. We should be more attentive to the developments in our eastern and southern neighbourhoods. We should invest in security, stability and development in these regions. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue Card question. - Honourable Member, you mentioned the necessities that have not yet arisen, so that we need a genuine European common security and foreign policy. However, do you see a new challenge in finding each other between the President-elect and the existing Russian President — otherwise it seems to the detriment of Europe. Do you see a new challenge in this?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: blue-card answer. – Well I think that we should take care of our security in a more responsible way. Whatever the President-elect of the United States and Mr Putin in Moscow are saying or planning, we should be responsible to ourselves.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: Mr President, the European Union is at a decisive moment in its history, and it is not only in the economic and social sphere, also in the field of common defence and security, where there are old and new challenges, it must make an urgent choice between reacting or resignating itself. Because if the European Union has lost influence in the world, it is also due to the fact that it cannot assert itself as a guarantor of security in its geographical area and of peace and stability in its neighbourhood. This report correctly identifies the main cause for this failure, which is an uncoordinated and fragmented reaction to common threats and risks. The diagnosis is not new. The European Union has always faced this insufficiency, but we must not forget that the main design that was at its origin was the need to guarantee peace on a war-torn continent. It is therefore in the spirit of the European project that the European Union should assume once and for all as a power capable of preventing, dissuading and protecting. In this era of hybrid and cross-border conflicts and threats guaranteeing peace and security in Europe means guaranteeing peace and security outside walls. It is not enough to perform just a mediating function. It is true that it has experienced some successes, such as the dialogue between Serbia and Kosovo and Iran's nuclear agreement, but in the face of the tragedy in Syria, in the face of the situation in Libya and the Sahel, we see that this is clearly insufficient and that the development of European defence capabilities, with the corresponding increase in investment. This could lead to a permanent self-defence structure and, where appropriate, to a permanent European Union headquarters for civilian and military missions and operations under the Common Security and Defence Policy, provided that it is in liaison with NATO structures.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, High Representative, first of all, allow me to congratulate my fellow Member Brok on this report. Today, the Union is facing diverse challenges in foreign policy and security policy. These include conflicts in the Middle East, civil wars and population growth in the African continent combined, but also terrorism, cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings or radicalisation. These are all problems that have a direct impact on the Union, on the security of our citizens. Protecting our external borders is essential in this context. We must strengthen our common defence policy, cooperation and capacities. In order to effectively protect the Union from external challenges, our external borders. But this alone is not enough if we do not try to remedy the root causes that put such pressure on our borders. With proper development policy and well-targeted support, we can promote peace and stability. So we can prevent mass migration or instability and radicalisation. We all know that we feel more and more that there is no freedom without security. But we can only guarantee security within the Union if we have a sufficiently strong and firm foreign and security policy.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation of instability and uncertainty that the European Union is facing, characterized by recent events which have highlighted signs of a political crisis in act, I think deserves an articulated and structured response, living up to the global challenges to be faced in the near future, in a long period of time. The report on the implementation of foreign and security policy, also recalling the report on the overall strategy presented in this House in July by the High Representative, aims to relaunch and strengthening in operational terms those principles and values of the European Union, thanks to which we have been able to build a peaceful society. Moreover, Russia's behavior, which repeatedly violated international law deliberately, and the uncertainty arising from the election of the new President of the United States give Europe a central role of management and intervention for respect for international law and humanitarian law. The European Union is the frontrunner of world multilateral diplomacy, but today, with the deepening of the crisis and the obvious difficulty of action by the United Nations, caused by cross-vetoes, we must take awareness of the need to strengthen the European role, laying the foundation for a purposeful impulse, combining soft power with hard power. Stronger and more common military capabilities and consequently a more active and effective role in conflict resolution and peacebuilding are key elements in enabling the European Union to respond fully to today's crises and I am convinced that you, Mrs Mogherini and we with you, today more than yesterday, can achieve a great result for the European Union in this field.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, we are debating today Mr Brok’s report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. It is in my view a good, compact and comprehensive report. It mentions a number of proposals and visions which, in the majority, I truly share. For example, the commitment to a strong EU security and defence policy, or a call to deliver an EU White Book on defence in 2017. To face the unbearable situation in Syria, the top priority is the reform of the Security Council. We have to concentrate all of the EU’s and Member States’ diplomatic forces to reform the Security Council. We need to remove the veto concerning mass atrocities. The international security and humanitarian mechanisms seem to be paralysed. We are obliged to make them work again and do we need to do it now.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
