text: – Madam President, I apologise for being absent during part of this debate: tonight the EPP Group is selecting its candidate to become the next President of the European Parliament, so I had to be there. Colleagues, the European Union is surrounded by serious conflicts including the war going on in Ukraine, the annexation of Crimea, parts of Georgia being occupied by Russia, and other conflicts both hot and frozen. We in the Baltics are threatened by Russia on an almost everyday basis. The EU faces multifaceted challenges, including terrorism, cybersecurity, misinformation, human trafficking and radicalisation and growing populism. The external and internal threats are intertwined more and more. We believe that EU external action needs to be based on three pillars, the three ‘D’s of defence, development and diplomacy, though being aware that the level of the CFSP is only around EUR 320 million. We understand that in order to safeguard its interests, protect its citizens and promote other values worldwide, the EU requires the full engagement of the Member States and the coherent use of policies from our external policies toolbox. Finally, my gratitude and admiration goes to Elmar Brok, the draftsman of this report and the long-standing chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of this House: thank you, Elmar.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen. The European Union's responsibility in the world does not start or end at the external border of the European Union. We need to be much more aware than in the past of our shared responsibility as a global player. The strength of our neighbors is our strength, and the weakness of our neighbors would also be our weakness. I would therefore like to thank Elmar Brok for the many concrete recommendations contained in his report on the many and complex cross-border challenges in our neighbourhood, how we tackle them, ensure the security of our citizens and support the European Union in the three pillars of external action, Diplomacy, development and defence — more effective, efficient, better, and thus more credible and stronger. There is no lack of decisions, there is no lack of proposals, but there is a lack of political will to implement what we have recognised as necessary and correct. Unfortunately, the blocking unanimity still inhibits our clout and our ability to act and react. Unfortunately, the Member States of the Union still deny the necessary budget and competences. Unfortunately, Member States are raising, researching and investing primarily coexist rather than with each other, and unfortunately growing populism and nationalism are weakening our credibility and capacity to act on a daily basis. Let's turn this state off and do what we decide!

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Madam President, Madam High Representative, the fact is that Europe is in a precarious situation and faces great external and internal challenges, and is also surrounded by an arc of instability that is a bit overflowing either through terrorism or through migration. Unfortunately, we have an example of Russia that violates the sovereignty of neighboring countries and which threatens global and world peace. The report by our colleague, Mr. Elmar Brok, directly identifies three key challenges and perspectives in thinking in common foreign and security policy. We really find ourselves at the crossroads as far as defense policy is concerned. One direction is to maintain strong ties with the United States through NATO and within NATO. Another direction is the development of standalone defense capacities, independent of the United States, especially after Trump's victory in the presidential election. I believe that the third reason is the most important - the future of defence of the European Union is precisely an independent security architecture built on cooperation and coordination of Member States, strengthening interoperability of military capacities, as well as defining key objectives of foreign and defence policy towards unstable European neighbourhood. In the wake of these challenges, it is essential to strengthen the status and position of the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy and to work towards harmonisation of Member States' foreign policies. This requires deeper integration, but we must bear in mind that only by strengthening the close cooperation of all foreign policy actors can we achieve that these goals are indeed achieved. I thank Mr. Brock once again.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while we celebrated the 25 years of the Maastricht Treaty a few days ago, it is still necessary, today, to recall that the common foreign security policy is one of the pillars of what Europe is today. On the other hand, in the face of the rise of populism, let us not tired of telling the truth: no Member State can tackle the challenges we face alone. The coherent and effective implementation of the CFSP is an imperative. In this sense, allow me to highlight three elements. Firstly — and this is one of my deepest beliefs — the Union must continue to invest even more in mediation, preventive diplomacy and conflict prevention. I am convinced that this is an area where the Union has a net added value. As such, the conflict in the Middle East must be the subject of permanent mobilization. This is our neighbourhood, and we know the effects of permanent instability in this region. Secondly, I stress the missions EUCAP Sahel and EUBAM Libya, which must be provided with the necessary human and financial resources to ensure the security of Europeans and the stability of the Union. The Sahel is a key region, where the risk of connecting insecure areas is significant. Finally, the Union must participate in strengthening the capacities of regional and subregional organizations, particularly in Africa, to address security challenges, but also to encourage our partners to tackle the sources of conflict and instability.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Mr President, in the context of the crisis in East Ukraine, full implementation of the Minsk Agreement can bring the political solution, and everyone seems to agree on this. The Russian side has a lot of work to do in this regard, but let us not forget the obligations imposed on the Ukrainian government. They undertook to provide a special status for Eastern Ukrainian territories while preserving the sovereignty and territorial unity of Ukraine at some point in the settlement — of course, discussing when the time should come. I think we say little about this issue and sometimes pretend that the Minsk Agreement only imposes tasks on Russia. Without respect for and safeguarding the rights of minorities living in Ukraine, this country will not be stable, which is in the interests of both the European Union and Russia. Ensuring minority rights has always been a guarantee of long-term stability.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is now surrounded by an arc of instability, since much of the Middle East and North Africa are overwhelmed by ethnic-religious conflicts conflicts resulting in direct and serious consequences for the safety and well-being of European citizens. This internal and external crisis must also be an opportunity for the Union to improve its functioning and cooperation. We need to strengthen the Union's foreign and defence policy. Member States must have more ambitions in the field of common security, and the long process of the process which will have to lead to a single European defence system, where cooperation between States must be started. members must become the norm. And I agree with President Juncker's proposal to create a European Defence Fund that will boost research and innovation. Ongoing defence research activities must be an important preparatory action in view of a European programme funded by the European Union under the next framework multiannual financial.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, nowadays the European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges including conflict zones, state collapse, terrorism, hybrid states, cyber- and energy insecurity. Unfortunately all these challenges have direct and serious consequences for the security and wellbeing of EU citizens. For that reason, EU citizens see an effective common foreign and security policy as a priority area on action for the EU where extensive cooperation can bring most valuable contributions.  In that regard I call on both EU institutions and Member States to work together in a common and truly coordinated effort in order to develop a strong, coherent common foreign and security policy. It is important to note that a strong and coherent CFSP is achievable only if democratic reforms are being implemented and Member States start to speak with one voice and act together.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, some of you referred during the debate to a simple truth which is that individually our Member States are losing influence. Some of you expressed it in a different way: there is nothing we can do alone as single Member States, no matter how big or small we are. Some of you questioned if together we are losing influence; maybe compared to a century ago, probably yes. But also some underlined that in the current geopolitical situation we actually have some space that is opening up for the European Union to act as a security provider, as a guarantor for a rules-based global order that we can use if we are up to the task. Which means that, while individually we are losing influence, together as Europeans we can regain that sovereignty that as Member States we are losing.  This is why to me it resonates really strangely to hear, also in this Chamber, some of you referring to the fact that having a common foreign and security policy is a way of losing sovereignty. It is actually the only way to regain sovereignty in the world of today, acting as Europeans, and this was very clear when we had our Treaties adopted. But, if our strength is our unity, we have to be aware of the power we can exercise. Sometimes I wonder who we believe the European Union is. I give you news: the European Union is each and every one of you, and especially you that are sitting in a European institution. You are a European institution yourself. So whenever we say, whenever you say, some of you say in this room, that the European Union is weak, you are saying to yourself that you are weak, and maybe you can do something about that. I see the European Union through the eyes of our partners, and I see that they see the European Union as a superpower today. What I see from the inside of the European Union is that we do not even realise the power we have; and if you do not realise the power you have, then yes, you are powerless, because you do not use it. If you do not believe in yourself who should believe in yourself? Who should believe in you? This is the basic rule that you teach to your teenagers, daughters and sons, when they reach 13, 14 years old, no? I am not yet there but I am practising. If you do not believe in your capabilities and your capacity, in your tools, if you do not believe in yourself, how can you claim others should believe in you? So at the same time you are saying the European Union is weak, and on the other hand you are saying - sometimes the same ones of you - we should act as a superpower. Well, the two do not stand together. Either we believe in what we can do and we do it, and we implement the decisions we take - or I wonder what you are doing in this room. Sometimes I do.  This to say that we have the tools, economic tools, diplomatic tools, that nobody else in the world has. We should also have the security and defence tools that could complement our soft power. There is a unique mix, the European way of doing security, which is a mix of mediation, conflict prevention, work on poverty eradication, on human rights, on governance - which is also part of security nowadays. And also the hard power means that sometimes we need to enforce some decisions or to simply allow humanitarian aid into place.  This unique mix, this European way of doing security, is something that the world is desperately looking for and that we would have, if we managed to develop the political will. I hope in two days from now the Heads of State or Government will put that political will behind the implementation plan on security and defence.  Because this is what we need in this moment, to complete our toolbox, together with the soft power instruments, the EUR 20 billion every year we invest in Africa - EUR 20 billion every year - are we not a superpower? Who else in the world invests EUR 20 billion every year in the African continent? So we need to complement this with some instruments of hard power that together Member States can shape. It is not a matter of a European army. I have repeated it I do not know how many times, I will continue to repeat this: Member States have one set of forces, they can use it for European missions, for NATO missions, for UN peacekeeping missions, for national purposes. But we need to work on the output of our defence investments because it is true that we invest 50% of what the Americans spend on defence, but the output of our investment in defence is 15% of what the Americans get as an output. That gap to me is what we have to work on today. We can also work on all the rest but today it is the economy of scale, it is coordination, it is cooperation that we need, including on the industrial basis of research. Let me say one last word on Syria - two last words, one on Syria. Some of you said that we cannot only be a humanitarian player. Believe me, being the humanitarian player that has more credibility and more determination than all the others on the ground - because we have been the ones trying to allow with our resources, with our work on the ground, with our offices in Gaza and in Damascus, trying to allow humanitarian aid to get into places; sometimes we have managed, sometimes we failed - but being the credible and committed humanitarian player on the ground in Syria gives us the space and the credibility to be also a political player, most of all with the Syrians and with the regional players. This is what we are doing. This is what we are doing every day, and when I say this I mean this is what we are doing every hour, especially in these hours, we are trying to protect the civilians in Aleppo. This means that we are trying to reach out to all those that have an influence on the ground in this moment, to try and protect the civilians. Every single life counts. The problem is - and some of you mentioned that - the world is in such bad shape today that the big question is not: ‘How powerful is the European Union and how come we are not managing to stop the war?’ The point is: ‘Who in the global system of today has the power to enforce humanitarian and international law?’ The point is that the system of international rules is broken and we have to find effective ways of enforcing the international and humanitarian law. This is an effort the European Union has to make and can make. We will never manage alone, even if we are a superpower, we will never manage alone, because yes, we are not managing today in these hours to do as much as we would like to do for the people of Aleppo and elsewhere, but the same goes for our friends in the United States, our friends in the United Nations, our friends in the G5. Are we all powerless? I do not believe so. I do not believe so, but as it is true that we have a lot of power if we realise how to use it, it is also true that we need to work with others to find the solution to the crisis. This is also the European way and we will continue, we will continue to try and save every single life, protect every single person, in Aleppo but not only there. One last thing: some of you mentioned the fact that we need to have priorities. To me the priorities are two and are very clear. One is our region, and our region goes from the east of Europe to the Sahel. Second is investing our potential, our work, on the areas, on the files, where we can make a difference, and not others. Sometimes this is the case for places that are far away and where we have a direct interest in investing in security and stability. But we have to analyse case-by-case where it is us that can make the difference, and where it is us that can contribute but maybe one step back.  And this is an exercise I believe we are making now, with a strong focus on Africa because Africa is our neighbour, is demographically growing as we all know, is a security but also an economic challenge for all of us and also an opportunity, and this is why I believe next year will be really an African year for us, not only because we have the summit with Africa but also because we are looking at ways in which we can invest in security, in economic development, in digital, in energy, in human rights and governance, in all sectors far beyond the migration-only angle. That is important, but it is not the only angle for our relation with Africa. Last but not least, as I have spent too many words on Elmar in the beginning, I was reminded that this is not the time for farewell, so I will not say anything now. (Applause)

name: Elmar BROK
text: rapporteur. — (DE) Madam President, dear Federica. We should indeed approach with more self-confidence. We have all the potential to play a role in our interests. I can only agree that we can regain our sovereignty. Through Europe, because the nation states are too weak for this, we can regain sovereignty for our peoples. I think that is a very crucial motive for doing this. We are not just dealing with NATO, but — as the references to Africa and other issues show — we need to develop our own capabilities, regardless of what happens to collective defence in Europe. We can only take this forward together by developing skills here, for example in Africa policy, which has to do with traditional development policy, but also with good governance, with a different trade policy. Rather, we have to recognise that we need to summarise instruments that we have been handling separately so far and which have therefore not taken effect. I also believe that we must be able to move forward with a coalition of the willing, which is offered by the permanent structured cooperation. Not everyone has to join. Article 42 (7) also states that non-NATO members only need to participate in accordance with their constitutional circumstances and that this is not an overcoming of national constitutional competences. That's why we have a lot of room here. The fact is that the Secretary General of NATO said that Europe needs to develop capabilities so that it is also effective for NATO. Having a European Union with armies where 80% of the cost is overhead cost is money thrown out. We are wasting taxpayers' money on our division and lack of cooperation! That is why we should act together and move forward accordingly. I believe that some good-willers who still have their NATO have concerns that may be able to overcome them. But I have to say one thing: we are not going to be told by those on the far right and on the far left who have their campaigns financed by Putin's supporters or even Putin money. To advocate and promote our policies is not propaganda. Mrs von Storch, you are pursuing a policy that is against the interests of our citizens and is delivering to us those who are not well with Europe. We don't need Putin friends as counselors.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. — Mrs Brok's report on the implementation of the Union's common foreign and security policy is the first substantial step forward towards genuine European integration in a sector as sensitive as that of foreign affairs. Article 36 TEU gives us the tools to act with a strong implementation of the common security policy. And that was precisely our intention, to lay the basis today for the Council to approve the High Representative's initiative and, on the basis of Parliament's opinion, to transpose our resolution next Thursday. It is an opportunity not to be missed: I believe that a recovery of European sovereignty is improcrastinable which the Member States no longer have the strength to grasp. We need finally to be able to speak with one voice even in foreign policy. The challenges that lie ahead require us very strongly.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Our Common Foreign and Defence Policy has been in the making for decades and is long overdue. One of its main objectives is maintaining security and stability near the borders of the European Union, and sometimes even behind those borders, as instability in our region can have repercussions on the Union. Another thing that would significantly contribute to stability behind our borders would be the creation of a Kurdish state. According to different estimates, there are 25 to 30 million Kurds in Turkey, Syria, Iran and Iraq alone, and millions of Kurdish refugees elsewhere. The Kurdish people have their own identity and form the world’s largest group without its own state. The creation of such a state would help stabilise the region.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. — To the disadvantage, the situation around the European Union is changing. Large areas of North Africa and the Middle East are engulfed by war, and terrorist groups are increasingly infiltrating Europe. Other threats are also emerging, such as war in eastern Ukraine and attacks in cyberspace. We must therefore increase the EU's responsibility for our shared security. I know there is no chance of a joint European military, but we can take action in the EU that would improve our security more effectively. I see three such pragmatic endeavors. First, there would be a common permanent headquarters in the European Union to conduct civil-military operations. Secondly, the Union must respond more quickly to threats by using its combat groups for joint missions and operations. Finally, thirdly, a ring-fenced fund should be created in the EU, from which a common security and defence policy would be financed. I think these actions would enhance the European Union's defence and security capacity.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the recommendation by Maria Arena, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement (16384/1/2010 – C7—0097/2011 – 2010/0323(NLE)) (A8—0332/2016), and – the report by Maria Arena, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement (2016/2226(INI)) (A8—0330/2016).

name: Maria ARENA
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, the European Parliament is invited to give its approval on the protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, in order to extend the provisions of that Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. Ratification of the Textile Protocol will lead to the inclusion of textiles in the partnership and cooperation agreement concluded between the country and the European Union in 1999. The provisions provided for under the heading 'trade of goods' of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement would therefore apply equally to textiles. This Title provides for the granting of most-favoured-nation status on a reciprocal basis, trade free of quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, a safeguard clause and prohibitions or restrictions on imports, exports or goods in transit. are justified by public morality, public interest or public health. It is following an interim report that was adopted by the European Parliament in 2011 that we are here today, which reserves its consent to improving the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, particularly on the issues of child and forced labour in the context of the annual cotton harvest. Following the adoption of the report, a dialogue was established with Uzbekistan, through which annual hearings were held, including the participation of several actors, including civil society, the Uzbek authorities and European and international institutions. Close cooperation has also been undertaken between Uzbekistan and the International Labour Organization in order to assess actions undertaken to eradicate child and forced labour in the context of harvesting annual cotton. The ILO conducted a cotton harvest monitoring mission for the first time in 2013, which was repeated in 2014, 2015 and 2016. The 2015 final report of the ILO monitoring mission, which took place between 14 September and 31 October 2015, showed that child labour had been virtually eradicated during the harvest of cotton. Public authorities have put in place various measures to eliminate child labour, including the organization of after-school daycare facilities, fines for offenders, empowerment of parents, teachers and farmers. Only a few isolated cases have been identified. The ILO therefore affirmed that child labour was indeed sporadic and socially unacceptable. This position has been reaffirmed by the latest ILO support. His report will be official early next year, but we already have the conclusions of this report, which actually confirm what happened in 2015. Unfortunately, the same statements could not be made on the issue of forced labour. Since the assessment in this regard is more sensitive, ILO has identified several indicators of forced labour, related to abusive working conditions and the recruitment process. The Uzbek authorities have made several commitments to progressively abolish forced labour by adults, including the establishment of a permanent feedback mechanism to respond to public grievances, the organization of awareness-raising campaigns and the establishment of programmes for the evaluation and implementation of international conventions in the field of human rights. material. Parliament therefore fully supports the work carried out by the ILO to permanently abolish forced labour in Uzbekistan. The efforts of the Uzbek authorities should be encouraged. That is why we propose to give consent with, of course, a resolution that says simply to the uzbek government that if the work that has been done so far could not continue, we would take a much harder attitude here in the European Parliament on the whole agreement between the Union and the uzbek authorities.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the textile protocol that we are debating today will extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to bilateral trade in cotton and textiles. As you well know, this is an issue that has been on your agenda since 2011.  The aim of the textile protocol is to facilitate EU exports to Uzbekistan in the textile and clothing sector. It will grant a legal basis for the Most Favoured Nation treatment to EU textile and clothing exports to Uzbekistan. Therefore, it is in our interest to conclude such a protocol with Uzbekistan. The Commission is well aware of the concerns that has been raised with regard to the need for Uzbekistan to continue addressing the challenges in the cotton sector. It is true, there have been lots of concerns. But as the rapporteur said, and I would like to thank the rapporteur Ms Arena for her work on this. According to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), Uzbekistan has made significant progress since the last resolution of 2011 in this House; particularly as regards eliminating the use of child labour from cotton harvests. I also want to commend Uzbekistan’s cooperation with the ILO, including on the issue of forced labour. Moreover, I am also happy that the Commission services have been able to facilitate the contacts between Uzbekistan and the ILO. We have been discussing these matters regularly with the Uzbek authorities and have also been closely cooperating with the External Action Service and our EU Delegation in Tashkent throughout the process.  The ILO’s committee on experts report from last year’s harvest was very positive about the achievements in the area of child labour and also welcomed progress in the area of forced labour, while noting that there are some remaining challenges. The ILO’s preliminary assessment of this year’s harvest, which ended just a month ago, continues on the positive note from last year. A substantial information campaign on the fight against child labour and forced adult labour has been conducted. This is work in progress for the coming years, going in the right direction. I can confirm that the Commission will very closely monitor and actively support this important process with the objective of ensuring that the issues related to the recruitment processes in Uzbekistan’s cotton manufacturing are addressed in an effective, lasting and sustainable way.  Furthermore, the Commission has been supporting financially the monitoring mechanism put in place by the ILO through an ongoing contract with the World Bank of EUR 5 million.  Moreover, we are ready to support Uzbekistan’s economic diversification efforts via our development cooperation assistance programme to Uzbekistan, in which rural development is a focal sector. The total amount of that programme is EUR 168 million for the period 2014-2020. Finally, a few words on EU-Uzbekistan’s trade relations: given the very low bilateral trade flows today, there is room to boost trade relations. I am convinced that a good business climate and respect for the rule of law are essential conditions to develop bilateral trade and investment relations. To this end, we are encouraging the Uzbek government to pursue the necessary reforms. The EU fully supports Uzbekistan’s accession to the World Trade Organisation. This would also enhance bilateral trade relations and facilitate EU investment in the country. It would also be in line with the momentum currently existing in the Central Asia region. Let me reiterate: Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Kazakhstan have recently joined the WTO, and Turkmenistan has recently announced its interest in WTO membership. So that is all positive news.

name: Elmar BROK
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. Thank you very much. The Committee on Foreign Affairs supports the approval. We believe that progress has been made since 2011, both in the area of child labour and in the area of forced labour — as the Commissioner has just outlined. Then we also need to make a signal that it will be rewarded for doing this. At the same time, we should also remember that it is possible to partially suspend the implementation of the PCA, as provided for in Articles 2 and 95, if it again goes in the wrong direction. In any case, we should support the work of the ILO in the monitoring process and also the World Bank with its projects to modernise agriculture in Uzbekistan. I believe that these are important ways to get closer to respecting democracy and human rights. For this reason, we would recommend to come to a concept here.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, in 2011 the Parliament made a really historic vote. It was the first time after the Lisbon Treaty that this Parliament, which now has to say ‘yes’ or ‘no’ in consent procedures, blocked the textile protocol with Uzbekistan, because of child labour and forced labour to a degree that is simply unacceptable. There was horrendous abuse of children and adults for the main export product: our clothes and other textiles. Since then there have been lots of improvements. The government has started to work with the International Labour Organisation in the Decent Work Country Programme. In October 2016, the ILO Convention on Freedom of Association was ratified. Nevertheless, huge problems still persist. It is right that child labour has decreased and is now not socially acceptable anymore, but we have plenty of reports from independent civil society organisations which say that forced labour is still there in an amount which simply does not make the glass half-full. In that sense, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) side, we were also pushing for having put in good cooperation with rapporteur Arena from Committee on International Trade (INTA) to have a resolution, and this resolution has some very important points in it. Nevertheless, in the end I had to withdraw my name from the consent procedure because I simply could not say yes to giving consent. I will also ask tomorrow for a postponement of the vote until the final reports from the International Labour Organisation and the independent civil society organisations are there, because they have been working and the harvest only stopped a couple of weeks ago, so we do not have the final reports yet. It was a debate we had at the beginning of our negotiations in the Parliament, and we cannot have that vote now. Hopefully, I will get support from my colleagues tomorrow for that because, as I said, the glass is unfortunately not yet half-full.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. In December 2011, Parliament rejected approval of the extension of the EU-Uzbekistan Agreement to include textile products and made its approval conditional on Uzbekistan's ability to make significant progress in the elimination of forced and child labour within the framework of the annual cotton harvest. This measure was right and important, and it has meant that we now see a different situation than it was five years ago. The 2015 ILO report shows that there is practically no child labour during cotton harvesting. The ILO also confirms that child labour, if any, occurs only sporadically and has become socially unacceptable in Uzbekistan. In recent years, the authorities have committed themselves to taking far-reaching measures, including the gradual abolition of forced labour by adults. This resolution commends the efforts of the Uzbek Government. At the same time, she also points out that the sudden death of Islam Karimov and the election of Shawkat Mirsiyev as the new president must not jeopardise the initiated process of improvement. With our approval, we follow the reasoning of our 2011 report. Uzbekistan has implemented the calls for tangible and profound changes. The European Parliament, with its approval tomorrow, should encourage Uzbekistan to continue along this path. Finally, we are also sending an important signal not only to Uzbekistan, but also to other countries that it is worthwhile to continuously improve the human rights situation. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Arena, for the very good cooperation we have had.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Maria Arena for the very comprehensive and very good report she is discussing with us here today. The topic of cotton production is particularly important to me. I am shadow rapporteur on Parliament's report on the EU flagship initiative for the clothing industry, which the Commission has been working on for some time. Many think of Bangladesh seamstresses and the collapse of Rana Plaza when it comes to supply chain traceability and fair clothing. Ever since I have dealt with supply chains in the textile sector, I have been emphasining a fact that is being forgotten. Textile production begins in the cotton fields. According to the International Labour Organisation, about 60% of child labour is in agriculture — mostly in the cotton fields. That is why I am very pleased that legislation is now in force in Uzbekistan which prohibits child labour and that, as a result of these rules, child labour has been almost completely eliminated. However, I am somewhat concerned that forced labour will continue to be used in the cotton fields in 2016, including public sector employees and students. For example, I support the rapporteur in calling on the Uzbek President to introduce a new human rights paradigm and to end the ongoing forced and child labour during cotton harvesting completely without delay. This should be done in close cooperation with and under the supervision of the International Labour Organisation. I am particularly positive that the Trade Union Confederation of Uzbekistan joined the International Trade Union Confederation as an associate member in October 2015. Only where trade unions function and where there is the freedom to unite into a trade union can a good way to decent working conditions and the Protection of workers' rights. I remain on the subject and will definitely include cotton production in the report on the EU flagship initiative in the clothing industry, and I hope that, in the case of Uzbekistan, as the European Parliament, we will continue to be in close contact with the Commission in order to continue the situation on the ground. improve.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, Parliament said in the 2011 report that we will reform the textile agreement when we can state that access to the ILO has been secured to observe the working conditions and, above all, the working conditions in the country with regard to child and forced labour. This has happened. The ILO has reported on the issue at regular intervals, and a 2015 report found that child labour had been effectively completely eliminated. I believe it is essential and important that if we have insisted that the International Labour Organisation ILO goes and observes and has done this work freely there and reported to us on it, we also trust this reporting and on the other hand respect the decision we took in this regard in the year in 2011. In other words, it is worth noting with satisfaction the developments in Uzbekistan. Of course, there is still work left in the case of forced labour, and it is also very important for child labour to continue monitoring so that positive development can be secured even in the future and ensure zero tolerance in this area. But it is also good to remember that in the new democracies — not always these old ones — things do not happen in any moment, and in my view, by renewing this agreement, we can give our own approval to the work that has been done in Uzbekistan up to now. In the 2011 report, we did not call for a complete resolution of the situation, but for a significant development, which I believe will be met when the child labour problem is overcome or has been virtually completely eliminated in this five-year period. Human rights issues must be taken seriously, but I also think this is a place of thanks for the good work done to Uzbekistan there, and I would also like to thank our rapporteur, Maria Arena, for a good, balanced report.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I am very surprised at our approach in the European Parliament, because I cannot confirm the progress that has just been mentioned here. On the contrary, I have evidence in my hand that forced labour continues to be carried out systematically at national level. It is an official and signed letter from the District Attorney of the Chad region, which says that for this year's harvest all public employees, medical staff, teachers and students by decree of the national government — not a local government, but the national government of Uzbekistan — moved to the harvest have been. The penalties for non-compliance are job loss or loss of place. Why don't we wait for the 2016 harvest report before we vote? Why do we ignore the independent organisations that tell us that, although progress has been made in child labour, it has not been abolished by any means and that forced labour is still being carried out on a very large scale? Yes, the Uzbek Government has made progress because of our pressure here from Europe, but it has far from meeting the standards we have set for approval.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, Mr Buchner is right to say right now that the situation in Uzbekistan is certainly not yet what we would like for the people of the country. We rightly called in the 2011 resolution that there should not be a completely clear world in Uzbekistan, but that we would like to see clearly visible improvements. The much better conditions exist in Uzbekistan. Not all the problems have been solved, but it is precisely here in the Committee on External Trade, which was also attended by representatives of the ILO, the International Labour Organisation, who has made a clear reference to the intensive improvements made in recent years. According to the International Labour Organisation, there has been no systematic child labour since 2014. According to this report, child labour has become very rare and is now also heavily condemned in social terms. Awareness-raising campaigns in schools have also contributed to this. At least significant improvements have also been made in the area of forced labour, even though there is still clear potential for improvement. But what bosts me the most is that we put a lot of pressure. We have told the Commission what we expect from the Commission. We have repeatedly said this to the Uzbek Government, and we should now take the next step. We should confirm this agreement tomorrow. However, we should tell the Uzbek Government in all our discussions that this cannot be the end of development, but only an intermediate step. Our group will continue to examine this very intensively and critically in the coming months and years, and if necessary, we will also take back the criteria.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today ends the long work carried out in recent years by the European Parliament, in close cooperation with the International Labour Organisation, for extend the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Uzbekistan to trade in textile products. I am proud to have followed what we can see as a positive case for cooperation between the European Union and a third country for the S&D Group in the Foreign Affairs Committee. of human rights through our trade policy. Thanks to pressure from the European Parliament, with the gradual opening of the Uzbek authorities from 2013, in fact, the serious problem of child labour has been essentially eliminated in relatively little time, while significant strides forward, although not yet sufficient, were made against the use of forced labour. We are talking about a strategic country in the region, where major transformations are underway. I am referring in particular to the presidential elections last December 4, the first of the history of the young republic, elections from which emerged the winner so, it must be said, not surprising the former first Minister Mirziyoyev. We wish him well for good work, trusting that he continues the path taken towards greater openness and cooperation with the ILO and the European Union in the agricultural sector, but not only. In fact, much still remains to be done in various fundamental fields, from respect for human rights to the rule of law, pluralism to freedom of the press, issues on which we will remain vigilant. However, with the consensus that we will vote tomorrow, Parliament wants to give a positive signal, encouragement to the Uzbek government to show that the European Union intends to work with third countries in a relationship of partnership and not imposition of their own rules, remembering, though, that if you were to take steps back on the child or forced labour we will reserve to suspend the agreement.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: — I remember well the resolution adopted by the European Parliament five years ago — 2011 — and our criticism against Uzbekistan regarding the use of forced and child labour in the harvesting of cotton. Today, the situation in Uzbekistan is qualitatively different: the country has made significant progress in abandoning child labour. Monitoring by the European Parliament and the European Commission, the conclusions of the International Labour Organisation testify to the benefit of Uzbekistan: child labour has ceased. Why do we want to ignore these facts? Why are we aiming to diminish these reforms and the progress achieved? True, the problem of forced labour has not been fully resolved, student work has remained, but Uzbekistan is determined to continue reforms. Let us acknowledge and support. All the more so that it is in the interest of the European Union to promote trade between the European Union and Uzbekistan, recognising the importance of the textile industry for the economy of Uzbekistan, considering the European Union's acceptance of Uzbekistan's membership of the World Trade Organisation, taking into account all this, tomorrow we should support the for the textile protocol.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, Central Asia is of geostrategic importance to the EU and our partners in the region fully depend on the trade agreements with the EU. It is worth mentioning that in 2015 trade between the EU and Uzbekistan was worth about EUR 1.8 billion. Partnership and cooperation agreements are non-preferential and ensure most-favoured-nation treatment prohibiting quantitative restrictions in bilateral trade.  Uzbekistan has been waiting for the extension of the provisions of its PCA to bilateral trade in textiles since 2011. There was an important reason for this, but now we can see the improvement in the cotton production sector regarding forced and child labour. A dialogue involving stakeholders, civil society, Uzbek authorities, European and international institutions, has been established and the recommendations from Parliament’s interim report of 2011 have been fulfilled.  Moreover in 2014 Uzbekistan became the first Central Asian country to agree to a decent work country programme with the ILO, the extension of which should be signed in 2017. With all this in force, I believe that we can fully support and give consent to the textile protocol and the accompanying resolution.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, first I would like to express my appreciation of Ms Arena’s constructive approach to this file. As a shadow rapporteur for the EU Central Asia strategy revision, I am glad that we are increasing our work in the region and that our communications channels with our partners in the region are open. I believe we need a tailor-made approach in engaging with each of the five countries.  The centrality of Uzbekistan in Central Asia is undisputed. We should stand ready to engage with the new political leadership in Tashkent and extend our expertise when needed to support the reform process in the country in order to achieve better governance, strengthening of the rule of law and democratic reforms.  This file concerns the textile industry and comments on the way forward with Uzbekistan. We are seeing positive signs from the Uzbek Government in tackling the cotton harvest related programmes. Significant progress has been achieved since 2011. Child labour has been effectively eradicated due to joint work of the ILO and the Uzbek Government. Our recommendations are being taken on board; therefore we the support the extension of the PCA to the trade in textiles.  However, we should remain critical where needed, in particular in the case of forced labour. Here we need to actively engage with the government to achieve eradication of forced labour. It is an ongoing process in which the European Union can and should be instrumental.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Repeatedly in this room, but also in European capitals, voices of criticism are heard over free trade agreements, about services. This wave is sweeping through Europe, and it's actually hard to see why. The protocol we are talking about today, the agreement we are talking about today, is the best evidence of how good civilizational effects can be achieved in countries where there are situations that are unacceptable by civilisation and European culture. Such undoubtedly include forced labor or — even worse — child labor. How could we affect our partner if we weren't operating a trade with him? How could we be affected if we didn't have a trade agreement with him? How could we be affected if we couldn't apply this instrument in the form of a protocol? Today we have such a condition that we can largely enjoy that the employment of children in Uzbekistan has ended, even if there are some marginal individual cases. Tomorrow we will, I hope, be glad that also forced labor will fade in this country. This is all we have thanks to free trade agreements and we need to develop them with the whole world.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Thank you, Mr President, for giving me the floor. In my capacity as a member of the Central Asia delegation, I have travelled to Uzbekistan many times and has only been there again in recent weeks. Yes, of course, this country has had to look forward on its difficult path to independence. Of course, every hand was needed there — including the hands of children. But I think Uzbekistan has taken a crucial, very important path in recent years, has really fought against child labour in an unprecedented way, and is very, very well there today. I think we should give this country a chance now. The opportunity to sell cotton on the market, but above all to sell finished textile products, that is, to get a decent added value from cotton. The country deserves this opportunity, and if I look around a little bit where else clothes — and unfortunately also on what terms — are produced in the world, then Uzbekistan has the chance to be a country that is now leading by example to others. So I think this is a good protocol, and we should agree to it tomorrow.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Mr. President, it is an undoubted fact that Uzbekistan has made serious and significant progress in the last few years. With this resolution, with this decision, we will not reward Uzbekistan for these moves, but first of all we will open the possibility for Uzbekistan to establish lasting competitive and concrete relations with the Member States of the European Union. And this message is extremely important. We want Uzbekistan as a partner, we see the great progress that have been made in recent years, we want to encourage them to continue such steps towards strengthening the values that the European Union has in their society and of course we want to say: we will seriously follow our friends, our friends we will seriously support, but also say when we disagree with them.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members for this debate. I think most of us agree that, even if the situation is far from perfect, Uzbekistan has made a lot of progress in this area and this is also confirmed by the ILO - not only this preliminary report, but it has been a trend for several years now. There is of course no time to be complacent, we need to continue to monitor this, to work with the ILO, to work with Uzbekistan so that this good development continues. The Commission will monitor this very closely and support the progress, and is happy to engage with the European Parliament, throughout this process.  I also think, and some of you mentioned it, that this renewed cooperation and trade with Uzbekistan will give us a positive impact on other aspects of bilateral cooperation not only in the areas of trade and development cooperation, but also of course when it comes to labour rights and human rights, where a lot needs to be done - but this can open a new platform for dialogue with them.  Also I want to say that the textile protocol, from a trade point of view, is also very much in the interest of the European Union because it provides legal certainty for our exporters in that sector. So for all these reasons the Commission hopes, and I hope also, that you will vote in favour of this tomorrow morning. Again my thanks to the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for the work that you have been doing.

name: Maria ARENA
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, thank you Commissioner, thank you to the shadow rapporteurs who have worked on this issue. It is proof that there is a way to trade and trade that makes the relationship and relations between our States much fairer. I commend the work of everyone, of course the Commission, the ILO, Parliament and all those who have contributed to ensuring progress in Uzbekistan. All trade agreements should be of that order to work effectively for the well-being of everyone. It is true, Mr Buchner, who is no longer there, Mrs Lunacek, who is no longer there, everything is not perfect. Nobody said that everything was perfect, and that is why we opted to join this consent a resolution which clearly states to the Uzbek authorities that this is the beginning of something today, that we must continue to work on the transformation of the productive apparatus, on the diversification of the economic fabric, on improving working conditions. All this must be continued, and we have said that, if it were not, if the Uzbek authorities stopped the process, we would activate Articles 2 and 95 for the suspension of the agreement. Mrs Lunacek, I am surprised to see the request to postpone the decision, because the timing had been decided, it was decided with all the political groups to say that this year we would make this decision. Indeed, relationships of trust are not established in one way, relationships of trust are also established when one gives something. It was important, in the context of our relationship with Uzbekistan, to be able to give something after the efforts that have been made. We have committed ourselves to doing so this year and we will make that commitment, I hope, tomorrow.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, 14 December 2016.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, on the accession of Ecuador by Helmut Scholz, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (07620/2016 — C8-0463/2016 — 2016/0092 (NLE)) (A8-0362/2016).

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. We must now ratify the EU trade agreement with Ecuador. As permanent rapporteur for the Trade Committee for Ecuador, I have been able to closely monitor the long process of developing trade relations between the European Commission and the Government of Ecuador. This includes the agreement now before us with Ecuador and the accession of the Andean region to the regional agreement with Colombia and Peru, which has thus been negotiated in special negotiations. I sympathled the withdrawal of Ecuador from the negotiations and welcomed the country's alternative proposal for a cooperation agreement. Ecuador insisted first of all to launch the fight against poverty, for the constitutional anchoring of human, social and environmental standards, and an independent, catching-up and at the same time more sustainable economic policy and development. This is in view of the challenge that Ecuador has the US dollar as its currency to date and thus has only to a limited extent monetary and fiscal governance to changing global economic conditions. Nevertheless, the first conditions have been created to put economic cooperation with other countries on a new basis, including interesting projects with other Latin American countries. In 2010, as the European Parliament, we welcomed by a large majority the fascinating logic of the Yasuni-ITT project. The question already moves: what are we doing here to open up such new economic and, at the same time, growth-critical ideas, real economic support and lasting prospects in all of our interests? Commissioner, I am still firmly convinced that the Commission's reluctance to this new agreement at the time was a mistake. We are in our negotiation schemes, our instruments and mechanisms still too deadlocked despite trade for all. I would be delighted if you could assure me today to consider the alternative and more development-oriented approach of Ecuador. This is because the agreement with the states of the region needs to be revised and improved in the coming years — especially when it comes to social changes, such as the peace process in Colombia, which continues to be a sensitive and graceful structure of the region. trade and economic relations on the part of the EU, but also with neighbouring countries. Many smallholder farmers in Colombia have already lost their livelihoods as a result of the double competition from the agreements with the US and the EU. This, however, should now be avoided by a forward-looking, partnership-based fair trade policy for Ecuador. Similar could be said for mining activities, as they endanger the habitat and traditional lives of indigenous people, as well as the environment, all of which are protected by Ecuador's modern constitution. No selfish pressure should be created by EU companies. As the European Parliament, in our accompanying resolution, we made a statement by the Government of Ecuador on maintaining and strengthening social and environmental progress under the Correa Government on the condition of our agreement and on further progress in strengthening democratic standards and their practical implementation. pooked. Ecuador submitted a comprehensive document in the summer of 2016 which I can only recommend reading to all my colleagues. The forthcoming elections will decide on a possible continuation of modern and progressive policies. Allow me to say this context: if the agreement were not reached on 1 January, those political forces would be called Failures that want to turn the social and environmental wheel backwards. Let us talk today about the conditions, the additions to this agreement. I look forward to the debate today.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the accession of Ecuador to the Columbia-Peru Agreement is a milestone in our relations. This agreement builds on our strong political, historical, cultural and trade links with Ecuador, and it boosts the possibility for deepening them further. We need to recognise the courage and the strong will of Ecuador. It is a major step for that country – the most ambitious and comprehensive free trade agreement, and the first free trade agreement that Ecuador negotiates with a developed partner.  The agreement reflects Ecuador’s clear determination to pursue the road of modernisation and reform of its economy, to diversify and to integrate into the global economy and international value chains. And to reach this, Ecuador has taken determined action and addressed trade irritants and prepared for accession. Some of these decisions have not been easy, and we need to give credit to Ecuador for taking them. Ecuador is now joining its neighbours, Colombia and Peru, and enjoying a privileged trade relationship with us – with the same rights and the same obligations.  Throughout this agreement, the EU is also supporting regional integration in Latin America. We have shown continued commitment towards a stronger partnership with Latin America, through the conclusion of ambitious trade and development agreements with all countries in the region. I am pleased to see that there has been strong support, both in the Council and Parliament, for the rapid accession of Ecuador. Both institutions have shown the political will to get the job done in time. And with this vote today, the institutions will have made provisional application before the end of the year possible. As the rapporteur said, it is very important to keep that deadline so that we avoid a gap between the end of the current trade preferences and the provisional application, which would have meant major trade disruption with Ecuador. By boosting export opportunities for Ecuador, we also respond to the country’s need to relaunch its economy after the terrible earthquake it suffered in April. With the constructive work done with Ecuador and the confidence built between both sides – and notably over the past six months – I trust we will continue to work with Ecuador to ensure that the agreement is implemented and will bring new opportunities for more trade flows in both directions. I also wish to inform you – because I know this is of importance to many of the Members of this House – that the work on the Regulation covering bilateral safeguard and the stabilisation mechanisms for bananas is a separate track: we are not only making progress, but it has been resolved in a trialogue, and I would like to thank the Members of Parliament and the Slovak Presidency for making that possible. Thank you very much, Mr Scholz, for your hard work on this as rapporteur. Thank you to the shadow rapporteurs, and to all of you for your attention and, hopefully, a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Commisarin Malmström. This is one minute for the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Mr Brok, who is also a special expert on the Andes.

name: Elmar BROK
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. We will discuss this in more detail in the Andean Pact, Mr Wieland, but that is a different story. I am pleased to say that the Committee on Foreign Affairs supports the present. We believe that this is also an important step towards regional development and that closer cooperation in the economic and trade sectors will be possible here. We would like to point out, however, that we are also monitoring the progress of the development of liberties and fundamental rights in this country. There have always been certain concerns here too, and we should also mention in this context that the question of values cannot be completely disregarded here either. This is already an important matter for us in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. For this reason, we support the necessary developments here, but we will also monitor this. That is not only the case in Uzbekistan, we say that in Ecuador.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, on 11 November the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to the Multiparty Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed. Personally, I am very pleased that Ecuador has finally decided to join the Agreement, as it contributes to strengthening ties between the Andean countries and also strengthens the European Union's position in the region. At the end of 2014, Ecuador ceased to benefit from the GSP+ advantages, and Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, worked quickly to draft a Regulation — which expires on 31 December — which would prevent the loss of trade preferences while negotiations on the Agreement were concluded, which would be caused significant damage to companies in both Ecuador and the European Union. I would like to congratulate the Commission, the Council and, in a very special way, the rapporteur, Mr Scholz, on the speed with which we have worked to be able to vote within the scheduled timetable. I would also like to stress that it is very good news that political agreement has been reached today on the safeguard clause, in order to prevent this Agreement from damagging the banana sector in several European peripheral regions. This Agreement is beneficial to both parties, will create a stable environment for European and Ecuadorian traders investors and will contribute to the intensification of trade flows and increased investment for mutual benefit, as is already happening with Colombia and Peru.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Indeed, the European Parliament has been closely monitoring the process of Ecuador's accession to the agreement with Colombia and Peru. As you recall, we adopted a resolution on this subject here in November 2015, there was an ad hoc delegation to Ecuador in March 2016, and we also had an intensive exchange of views with Ecuador's Minister of Trade, so that this is an example of how the European Parliament will support participation opportunities. to ensure that what we agreed together — a value-based trade policy — is implemented. It is clear, of course, that, as in the case of Colombia and Peru, Parliament's activities have put some aspects of democratic, environmental and labour law improvements on the track. At the time, we called for an appropriate declaration, a roadmap, from Colombia and Peru, and similarly now also received a plan from Ecuador to improve the situation in the labour and environmental fields. We will, of course, continue to support this accordingly. By the way, there are many positive elements. For example, Ecuador also has a momentum in fair trade, which we also want to promote very strongly, a separate action plan to support smallholder farmers in the area of fair trade, be it flowers or fruit. In this respect, a number of positive developments have emergered. The third point: I think the work is only just beginning. Even if we decide tomorrow that accession can take place, then we must of course monitor the implementation. I firmly believe that negotiation is one side of the coin, but perhaps the most important side is the implementation of agreements. And this must be take place in a very cooperative, dialogue-based process so that we can work in partnership with the issues of freedom of expression, workers' rights and environmental standards to be for the benefit of people. And as far as our banana producers are concerned, in fact, today in the trilogue we got a solution so that the whole picture is round and we can probably agree with a clear conscience tomorrow.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to express my group's agreement with Ecuador's incorporation into the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, which must incorporate the guarantee measures included in the safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for European bananas. Without them, the future of a fundamental industry for several European outermost regions, such as the Canary Islands, is committed. The proposed measures, such as early warning, automatic activation of the stabilisation mechanism, a report on its operation in 2019 — open to possible compensation — the possibility of extending this mechanism beyond 2020, and a permanent assessment of the banana market and the state of the sector to identify problems and to act accordingly, are sufficient to scare away the only uncertainty associated with this Agreement. That is why I welcome the agreement reached today, which we will discuss and vote later. Otherwise, I think this addition is good news. To begin with, it consolidates stability, improves the situation of fundamental rights and provides social and environmental guarantees to the development it will promote throughout the area. Secondly, it benefits many citizens of these countries who live there and those who have become new Europeans. In the Basque Country, for example, the Ecuadorian colony is the largest of those that group the nationals of other states who have decided to build society and country there, with us. Finally, the Agreement will unite the European Union to this positive effect and must work together in the consolidation of our presence and influence in a region of America that has been looking forward to the Asia-Pacific area for years. Finally, I stress that activating this Agreement is urgent so that Ecuador can better cope with the pernicious effects of three circumstances: the decline in oil prices, appreciation of the dollar and the depreciation of neighboring currencies, with the effects that this has had on the Ecuadorian economy, whose exports have fallen by 30 per cent; the earthquake in April, which produced nearly 30 000 victims and damages whose reparation will require investing an amount equivalent to 3 per cent of Ecuadorian GDP; the progression of the income of the country, which has passed this strip. Therefore, we support all these... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, by the European Parliament's mobilisation in favour of the outermost regions, we succeeded in this trilogue this afternoon in achieving progress in the protection of bananas in the ORs, and I would like to thank all those who contributed to this: Members of Parliament in particular the rapporteur, the Council and also, of course, the European Commission, which has taken its full part. But also agree that the right method would have been to incorporate these requests very upstream. Remember, in the sugar agreement with Vietnam, for La Réunion, we had to act also at the last moment, in a context that has become very tense and threatening. That is why, Commissioner, I believe that the time has come to meet around a table, Members of the ORs and yourself, to outline a trade policy that can take into account the interests of the ORs on the basis of Article 340.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the free trade agreement we signed with Colombia and Peru in 2012 will be extended to Ecuador after the vote of this Parliament. 2016 was a very tough year for this small South American country, the oil price collapse of more than 60 percent, the revaluation of the dollar, the devaluation of other South American currencies have had a strong impact on the economy and exports, which dropped by 29 percent. Added to this crisis was the April 16 earthquake that caused three billion dollars in damage. The agreement with Ecuador provides for a gradual and asymmetrical lowering of customs duties and, in my view, is a good measure to help this country at a difficult time and strengthen its economic structure. But my only concerns remain two: I am pleased, on the one hand, the agreement reached today on the issue of competition between Ecuadorian banana producers and European banana producers, in particular Canary Islands, which were in danger of being crushed by Ecuadorian production which we remember, in some cases, does not meet European quality standards. It will now be necessary to consider whether the agreement reached today protects European farmers enough. Secondly, my concern is about respect for ILO conventions and freedom of association in Ecuador, because although the Charter Treaty claims to promote these rights, in fact a ITUC report denounces many obstacles related to freedom of association and organization, in particular barriers to the founding of trade unions, the system of the single union in certain areas and the limits of collective agreements. If the Commission is in any case able to solve these issues, this agreement could become a good example of how the Union's trade policy can work for the well-being of all.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, I had already had the opportunity to talk to you about the Havana Charter, and I will repeat myself again. The post-war Havana Charter was drafted to achieve a world of free trade and peace. For this, there was balanced exchanges. Surpluses had to be condemned, like deficits. It was therefore necessary to balance in order to offer fair trade. So yes to targeted support for economies in difficulty, yes to upgrading these economies, yes, finally, openness and regional partnership, yes to this perhaps wider openness, but on the condition that we are in a free trade that is effectively regulated. I think this is very important if we want trade to rhyme with peace and not economic war.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Mr President, Commissioner. If this debate had occurred a few hours ago, my words would be quite different. I would tell you that in commercial agreements the bill is always paid by the agricultural sector, which I think, too. And I would also tell them that bananas had been abandoned and that it was only important to move forward with the agreement with Ecuador and not the safeguard clause or the banana stabilization mechanism. But fortunately — and I have to express my thanks to everyone and, fundamentally, to the Commissioner, who has been involved in this matter — we have managed to reach an agreement and compromise at the last minute. An agreement that will be accompanied by the agreement we signed today. That is, we are going to move forward with the clause; a clause that, of course, significantly improves clauses that we have had so far. Faced with the lack of transparency and information, in the face of inaction when there were breaches or in the face of uncertainty, today we establish measures with this clause which are very important. Early warning when 80% is reached is essential, such as improving statistics with the obligation to make them public, or assessing the system, or seeing whether there has been a deterioration of the same system — conducting an examination involving the Member States, but also the sector, which is an essential part of it. or regular meetings with the same sector, or Commission action when 100 per cent volume is being reached. I think that if we add impact assessments to that, we have a good deal. The banana sector is always under threat, but today it is a little safer, and that's good for everyone.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner. Yes, Peru and Colombia already have the trade agreement, which is already in force, and now Ecuador is coming to it. I would like to remind you that in 2015 Parliament adopted a resolution in which we made demands that we agree to Ecuador's accession at all. These core requirements are about the inclusion of binding sustainability chapters, which are very important to us. It is about human rights, it is about ILO labour standards, it is about multilateral environmental agreements. We really have to insist that they will be respected. Unfortunately, we now hear from the NGOs and also from human rights activists that not everything is working out as well in Ecuador as we imagine. Human rights abuses occur again and again. It also happens that there are problems with the right to freedom of assembly and that trade unions cannot establish themselves either. So here we see a big problem. However, it is also unfortunate that the implementation of this sustainability chapter in Peru and Colombia is not yet working like this. Here too, we need to do more. I am of the opinion that we do not just need negotiations to be concluded, and then what is written on paper will fit. Once we have concluded the agreement, we must insist that it will then be complied with. Here I clearly believe that we need to impose sanctions against infringements, that we must also have a monitoring system, monitoring systems — so that we can comply with all these important human rights. I urge the governments of Ecuador and Peru to take the commitments and commitments seriously, and also to honour them, so that this trade agreement has a positive effect on the population, so that there are human rights and labour rights, which can also be achieved. really complies.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of giving consent to the protocol permitting the accession of Ecuador to this trade agreement. In general, it will increase the EU presence in South America and, most importantly, it will improve our trade relations in the region.  This agreement will complete the regional dimensions of the Andean countries, which are now linked to the European Union. Also, the accession of Ecuador should bring more integration among the three partners. We can see that Ecuador is still benefiting, until the end of this year, from preferential access to the EU markets for its goods. If you look at Ecuador and the global picture, this was reported in the resolution of November 2015, which confirms the progress made by Ecuador in many areas, although some outstanding issues remain, such as complete press freedom.  So it is a process and we have to be encourage this process. The conclusion of this process, with the provisional entry into force of the protocol, will create a more stable economic relationship, founded on the provisions of this agreement.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the reduction in customs tariffs upon entry into the Community market, provided for in the trade agreements concluded between the European Union and the banana-producing countries of South and Central America, could have adverse consequences both on the European market and on the balance already fragile socio-economic conditions in the outermost regions. This agreement with Ecuador, the world's largest exporter of bananas, poses a direct threat to the Community's cleanest banana sector in the world. This tariff dismantling, which will soon reach EUR 75 per tonne on South American bananas entering the European market, goes further than the concessions made by the Commission to the WTO in 2009. Despite the slight improvements — which I welcome — that were made to the text during today's trilogue on the stabilisation mechanism for bananas scheduled until 2009, I cannot resolve to give a blank seing to this agreement, and I am convinced that... (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Fernando RUAS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the trade agreement whose negotiations were concluded in 2010 is already in force between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Peru and Colombia, on the other, since March and August 2013 respectively, and has proved mutually advantageous to the two parts. It is now intended that Ecuador, as a member country of the same Andean community, will also be an integral part of this agreement, to which Bolivia can also be added. However, adding to its economic and social vulnerability, the country was hit by an earthquake last April.
