I am, however, in favour of this country's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and the Andean Community, not for short-term reasons or as a response to natural cataclysms, but because this agreement will enable the country to continue its path towards economic, social, labour and environmental growth and development. more sustained and geared towards the real interests of citizens, while at the same time intensifying its relations with our continent, which thus has the opportunity to strengthen its political, economic and financial weight in this area of the globe with which we have strong historical, cultural and Diplomatic. However, it should be borne in mind that Ecuador is the largest exporter of bananas in the world, so its accession to the agreement could have a significant impact on Community producers located in the European outermost regions. I therefore believe it is essential that, in parallel, the amendments to Regulation 19 and 20/2013 on the application to Ecuador of the safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for imports of bananas into European territory, which have been agreed today, should be swiftly adopted.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ecuador is facing a serious crisis in which the oil price collapse of more than 60% has resulted in a 30% contraction in imports but more importantly, the country has yet to rebuild the damage of a terrible earthquake, in which more than 360 people died and which left three billion dollars worth of damage. We need to strengthen a truly unstable economic system at the moment. Accessing the trade agreement which the Union has already signed with Colombia and Peru would be a vital opportunity for development for Ecuador, a sustainable and economic development which must be necessarily related to social and democratic development. Opening up to the trade agreement must be an opportunity for negotiated dialogue and supervision also on sensitive issues, such as freedom of the press, a sore button in a country which in three years has started more than 900 proceedings against opposition journalists. The European Parliament then supports the agreement, but it absolutely constrains it to respect workers' rights, as well as freedom of expression and information.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Mr. President, I would like to clearly support this agreement because, simply speaking, we will have a chance to talk less about poverty, problems in countries with which we want to have partnerships and good relations. Ecuador is one of those examples. Maybe it was in its own way and Uzbekistan was a little earlier, but these are models, these are ways that in this aula we will talk less about the problems in the world, how we will talk less about poverty and humanitarian aid that we give. This is a great example in which Europe shows its will and openness, and after all its economic strength — why not say that? — especially because a deal has also been reached here with European banana producers. In this context, I think this is a praiseworthy agreement and I expect of course that the Commission will meet all the expectations of Parliament.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ecuador's entry into the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru is certainly an important step in our relations and for the future of the country, but I must point out that the serious situation of the Ecuadoran bananas working in the small fazenda and who are forbidden the right to associate freely at level sectoral. I myself recently went to Quito and met some of the representatives of the ASTAC union, the same ones that many of us had already met in Brussels and who illustrated the situation there on the camp in Ecuador. Thousands are bananas working in hundreds of small fazendas of Ecuador, threatened with death because they demanded respect for human rights and better working conditions. We can't afford another blank check hoping for a miracle, but we need to be careful. Commissioner, the European Union must demand the freedom of association of Ecuadoran bananas before the trade agreement is active.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you and thank you all for your support for this agreement. It is true that this agreement has the potential to go far beyond trade, as many of you mentioned. We have become partners with Ecuador and have radically upgraded the nature of our bilateral relationship and our coinciding visions for sustainable development. This is because both of us are committed to a comprehensive vision of sustainable and inclusive development and the improvement of human rights. There is work to be done here in Ecuador – absolutely – but with this agreement we create a platform to discuss and support Ecuador, as well as to make sure that the benefits of the agreement will really be distributed across Ecuadorian society in an inclusive way. Ecuador is committed to complying with core labour standards and international environmental agreements. I am looking forward to working together with Ecuador in order to create positive dynamics and to make the agreement successful for economic operators, consumers, citizens and civil society in the larger sense. I hope that the European Parliament will not only support the agreement tomorrow, but also – as many of you said – during its implementation phase. That is the most important thing. I hope that when you have had the possibility to study the details of the agreement in the trilogue on bananas and the safeguard mechanism, you will be assured to see that your concerns have been taken into account. The Commission will monitor this and its implementation. We look forward to continuing to work with the European Parliament on this. If you allow me Mr President, and as this is my last appearance this year in the plenary, may I wish you, Mr President, and the Members of this House a Merry Christmas.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Commissioner Malmström. I warmly reciprocate your Christmas wishes. I hope that you will also have the opportunity to recover and come to your senses a little between the years. I look forward to seeing each other again in the New Year.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: rapporteur. — Thank you, Mr President, I can only fully endorse this. I too wish the Commissioner some relaxing days over Christmas holidays and the turn of the year. I would also like to thank all the other colleagues for their intensive cooperation on this agreement — over the years. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteur from the Green Group, Mrs Keller, who has just been elected to her group as chairman of the group and is therefore unable to take part in this debate. I would therefore like to make two more comments: with all the understanding of colleagues who do not agree with this agreement, because it does not give up the principle of free trade logic, because the balance of power threatens to undermine progressive development, because many things are becoming more complicated and not easier, I would just like to stress that that I support the Government of Ecuador in the context of today's historical and current developments in South America. As has already been said, our Parliament and its Trade Committee have a responsibility to continuously evaluate the economic and socio-environmental impact of the agreement over the next few years. If deemed necessary, we will also call for appropriate changes to the agreement. With regard to trade cooperation with Ecuador, as with all other agreements, the European Parliament will not lay its responsibility with ratification, but will actively monitor its implementation in its daily lives. In the Trade Committee, we have also created the appropriate structures there together with the monitoring groups. One more thought from the debate now: I believe that when we are discussing jobs in EU banana-producing regions and areas, safeguard agreements — good that we have managed the trilogue — but that also means that we are also talking about it have to think about what this means for jobs, for production in the third countries concerned. So how do we jointly create agreements that enable fair trade, social, environmental and human rights standards and thus make a joint contribution to development? Not only do we have to turn our doors, we also need to look there, and it is a shared responsibility to shape this task responsibly in the future. Thank you, and I hope that a great many Members will agree tomorrow.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 December 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. — Once again, international agreements benefit large and harm the small. US multinationals (Chiquita and Dole) will this time be the big beneficiaries, since their production is much more competitive than that of small Latin American producers and much less sustainable than that of European producers. It should be remembered that the United States denounced the Union for exempting ACP countries from tariffs, triggering a war in Arbitration Courts that ended with this agreement, which Ecuador, the largest exporter of bananas in the world, is now joining. In this regard, we must highlight the classification of banana cultivation in the Canary Islands and other peripheral areas of Europe as sensitive crops, since the high standards which the Union imposes on its producers in social and environmental matters has nothing to do with the minimums with which it is grown in many industrial farms in the Canary Islands and other peripheral areas of Europe. South America. For this reason, we will require the Commission to activate safeguard and stabilise mechanisms to prevent any harassment of our local production, which directly work more than 30 000 European citizens.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on CAP instruments for reducing price volatility on agricultural markets by Angélique Delahaye, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (2016/2034 (INI)) (A8-0339/2016).

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, their bureau, the political advisers and, of course, the secretariat, for their work and the preparation of this vote in plenary. This is my first report as a European parliamentarian and it is an honour for me to have been rapporteur on this text long awaited by European farmers. In the face of the violence of the crisis and the desperation of the agricultural world, it was indeed urgent to address the issue of volatility. The elected representatives of the European peoples cannot remain silent when agriculture dies. The ambition of my mandate as a Member of the European Parliament was to bring solutions first to European farmers. As we know, among farmers Europe is seen more as a source of problems than as a solution. It is very logical that we, as Members of Parliament, have the responsibility to provide answers. Tomorrow, this Parliament will be an opportunity to show European farmers that Europe is useful to them and that MEPs are aware of their situation. No, we're not above ground. No, we are not disconnected from realities. No, we do not passively accept the decline in European agriculture. On the contrary, we have an ongoing relationship with the agricultural world, to which I belong, like other Members here. We are aware of the disaster that threatens us. Yes, we are aware of farmers' suicides on a daily basis. Yes, we know the despair of farmers. Yes, we are outraged that people working to feed their fellow citizens die in general indifference. I did not come to Parliament to cross my arms and to witness, powerless, the death of our agriculture. That is not my view of politics. I'm here to fight, fight for agriculture, because, yes, ladies and gentlemen, it is a real fight to fight. It is in this spirit that I propose to you the vote on my report on the tools of the CAP to combat price volatility. My aim is simple: to get the Commission to make proposals to combat price volatility. The main areas of my report are the following: strengthening contractualisation between the various actors in the food chain, the orientation of the CAP towards risk management tools, the creation of price observatories and strengthening existing ones to make markets more transparent and, finally, the improvement of the tools of the food chain. crisis management to respond more quickly and effectively to emergencies experienced by farmers. These guidelines have been widely supported by my fellow Members of the Committee on Agriculture. Once again, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the spirit of conciliation and respect in which we have reached these compromises. At this moment, the adoption of this report coincides with an alignment of planets. Indeed, the report of the Task Force submitted to the European Commission on agricultural markets, published on 14 November, comes to the same conclusions as ours. The report on price volatility adopted by the Committee of the Regions last week makes the same proposals. This is an opportunity to bring the voice of Parliament loud and loud. It is, once again, a great honour for me, a farmer, to have been rapporteur on such an important subject at a moment like this. On reading the two reports, I would like to propose the following two plenary amendments, for which I count on your support. The first on setting up a legislative framework to combat unfair trading practices, the second on the prevalence of the CAP over competition law European Union, both of which are sources of price volatility. So they have a full place in this report. Finally, last week, President Juncker and you, Commissioner, announced the adoption, before the end of 2017, of a communication on the future of the common agricultural policy. We can only look forward to seeing the Commission finally get to work on this issue. I wish, perhaps ambitious, but not unrealistic, that this report can serve as a basis for reflection on the Commission's forthcoming proposals with a view to the next policy for 2020. I am happy and proud to be part of this leading European project. I therefore count on you, ladies and gentlemen, to support my report tomorrow so that it will weigh on the Commission's future proposals. The most important part of the work is ahead of us, the harder remains to be done.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish first of all to thank Ms Delahaye and the shadow rapporteurs for all the work that they have done in producing this report, as well as Mr Ali for the opinion provided on behalf of the Committee on Budgets. I would like to congratulate you, Ms Delahaye, on achieving your first parliamentary report.  This report comes at a very good time, when the Commission is preparing a communication for adoption next year on the modernisation and simplification of the CAP, as announced by President Juncker at the Agricultural Outlook conference last week. I have identified three principles which I believe should guide the new CAP: market resilience, more sustainable agricultural production and progress on generational renewal. The issues that are raised in this report go to the heart of the debate about the future of the CAP by asking how best to deal with risks and crises in agriculture and reflecting on the whole range of public policy instruments that are currently available. I want to assure Ms Delahaye that we will fight together for farmers’ livelihoods and that we are on the same political page in this regard.  I fully agree with the central thesis of this report that we need to maintain sustainable agricultural production in Europe, and for this we need to seek efficient ways to ensure farmers can cope with risks and crises. We all know that risks and crises are inherent in agricultural production, and farmers have consistently demonstrated resilience in the face of adversity. Despite this resilience in the market orientation of the CAP, there continues to be clear justification for a formal public intervention, either at the level of the Member States or of the European Union, in order to support our farmers. Several interventions by farmers and stakeholders at last week’s European Union Agricultural Outlook conference demonstrated the importance of this message.  The report quite rightly acknowledges that the CAP has evolved over time and in line with the needs of European farmers and society, and in response to the challenges of the day. However, during the past two years we have experienced particular difficulties in the dairy, pig—meat and fruit and vegetable sectors in particular. Thankfully, we are now seeing a recovery in those markets, not least as a consequence of the robust actions that have been taken by the European Commission. In response to the crisis in various sectors, we have deployed virtually the full toolkit that is available under the Common Market Organisation and mobilised in excess of EUR 1.5 billion extra resources. If we take the example of the mill sector, as many as 24 regulations have been adopted between September 2014 and September 2016. These measures adopted included the opening, extension and enhancement of private storage aid schemes, the extension of public intervention periods and fixed price ceilings, the granting of targeted aid for our livestock farmers, the authorisation of collective agreements on the planning of milk production, and even the introduction of a milk production reduction scheme. We will also remember that we managed to find synergies between the migration and agricultural policies to make sure that milk is distributed to school children in Syria.  There are also other instruments available to help market actors to become more resilient and sustainable by their own means. I am referring here to the significant progress in market transparency that has been made over the past two years, with dashboards being developed for the main agricultural products, and observatories being established for milk, pigmeat, beef and veal to give market signals to our farmers and our agribusinesses. Building on the work of the Milk Market Observatory, these have been a good success in terms of providing accurate and timely information to all of our operators so that they can make market-led and good decisions. The experience has also raised some questions, of course, about the effectiveness of the toolkit available. Our responsibility as policymakers is to create an adequate framework to help the farming sector to successfully deal with risks and crises by enhancing its resilience.  In my view, there are a number of questions we need to ask ourselves: do the existing tools allow us to act where needed, and to do so quickly enough? Should farmers have greater built-in measures to help them in times of crisis on the basis of a risk management approach? And do producers and processors have the ability to diversify their markets, or to find new markets in times of market loss? These are questions, perhaps, that indicate to us the existing tools are not perfect. So we have to continually look at the variety of instruments at our disposal in order to try and improve them. One of those ways is through the provision of a basic income support in order to help farmers within an effective safety net. This will continue as an essential element of any new CAP through a system of direct payments, something which Ms Delahaye’s report calls for. You will by now be familiar with report of the Agri-Market Taskforce whose recommendations have been well received. Several of these recommendations, for instance those on market transparency, the improved functioning of producer organisations, as well as risk management, go hand in hand with the concerns that have been expressed in this report. I welcome and look forward to the hearing which the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development will hold next month on the Agri-Market Taskforce report. The recommendations contained in Ms Delahaye’s report will form part of the debate on the future of the CAP, particularly in relation to the adequacy of the existing risk and crisis management tools. In addressing the adequacy and use of these tools, we should consider any obstacles which prevent or discourage their use.  This report, then, is a valuable contribution to the debate and I acknowledge the emphasis which the report places on the importance of a common policy. In this context of preparing a new CAP which aims to modernise and simplify the policy, I can assure the House that my services will examine this report very carefully and ensure that appropriate account is taken of it and its recommendations.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, Commissioner Hogan, dear colleagues, the volatile prices in the agricultural market can have a strong negative impact on the food security of consumers, incomes of farmers and the well-being of entire countries. This volatility can be caused by a combination of the economic and natural factors and can be intensified by the broad political and legislative environment and speculation on agricultural products. In order to overcome the negative consequences of the price volatility in this important sector of the economy, some measures could be introduced as follows: firstly, rural development programmes should be used more broadly to contribute towards insurance, mutual funds and income stabilisation schemes for farmers. Secondly, improving synergies between the CAP and other EU policies, in particular regarding energy, water supply, land use, biodiversity and ecosystems, as well as development of remote and mountainous areas. Thirdly, the creation of a system to protect the farmers’ incomes through the use of risk management tools. And last but not least, better monitoring the significant price volatility of agricultural products by improving the European food price monitoring tools and using the information to make an adequate and timely response.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. Indeed, price volatility is one of the very central problems that farmers face, and the more we remove market instruments from the CAP, such as quotas, the greater the logical risk of volatility. We have seen this very clearly in recent months and years. Looking ahead, it is relatively easy to predict that volatility will not decrease in the markets, but will increase. That is why I agree with you, Commissioner, that we need instruments to combat this volatility. One instrument — you mentioned it too — could be insurance and mutual funds. Indeed, we already have instruments in the second pillar of the common agricultural policy in the common agricultural policy today. I come from a country and a region where there is probably the highest density of insurance contracts in the European Union. If I look at the complexity, the difficulty of the rules we have created, the bureaucracy that we have created, it sometimes gets bad for me. We spend hundreds of millions a year to support insurance contracts, and at the same time very often harvest non-acceptance by farmers. I agree with you, Commissioner, that we need to look at the instruments we have and look at where they can be improved, where they can be debureaucratised and where they can be made more easily accessible.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner for his willingness and also thank Mr Delahaye for his willingness to confront us in these weeks of work. Volatility in prices for agricultural products is one of the main causes of the dramatic situation in which European agriculture is facing, and the forecasts are not reassuring. Globalisation, instability and sophistication of agricultural markets, increasing variability in supply due to climate instability, increased health risks and the fragile balance of Food supply chain will continue to adversely affect farmers' exposure to price volatility. It is necessary to adopt a more impactful policy, with targeted instruments to ensure sustainable agricultural production, accompanied by fair and remunerative prices able to mitigate the negative effects on farmers exposure to price volatility. It is useful to highlight that while the European Union reduces strategic support for agriculture, its competitors on the world market, the United States, Brazil, China, introduce public financial support significant and growing to develop new risk policy models and to provide tools that can protect their farmers from the negative effects of price volatility. If we want to protect our agriculture we need to change the traditional approach. The negotiating power of producers must be strengthened in the food supply chain by means of standard, transparent, balanced and collectively negotiated written contracts in order to counter trade practices unfair, promote competitiveness and ensure the stability of incomes. In order to protect agricultural enterprises in a market-oriented CAP, it is necessary to further develop the instruments for managing climate, health and economic risk, instruments Income stabilization, individual provision mechanisms, mutual funds and income stabilization instruments. More needs to be done in terms of raising awareness and training as regards existing risk management tools. I call on the Commission to adopt, in close cooperation with national authorities and farmers' associations, a plan to raise awareness of available risk management instruments within the framework of the second pillar of the CAP. Countercyclical aid is a real novelty of the motion for a resolution we are debating, they intervene in support of farmers' income when unfavourable vintages compress their income and are a key and innovative instrument for European policy which, I hope, the European Commission will be able to assess adequately, providing greater flexibility in annual budgets or financial mechanisms in able to allow the European farmer to receive the difference between an objective price and the price actually received from the market. Access to credit for farmers must also be facilitated, greater use of financial instruments should be encouraged, possibly through the intervention of the EIB, which could participate in the development of a credit guarantee mechanism for European farmers. European farmers can no longer wait, nor continue to pay for prolonged periods of low prices. The time has come to defend European farmers against price volatility, strengthening their role in the food supply chain to ensure they receive the right compensation for their products.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being with us. I have been in this Parliament since 2009. Not so long, compared to some of you, but it seems longer sometimes and I cannot remember any point during this time when we have not been talking about at least one sector of agriculture being in crisis. Price volatility has a big impact on agriculture, and it can lend itself to exacerbating these crises. As an industry, it is very difficult to take collective action to hedge or insure against the effects of volatility. The agricultural industry is made up of a myriad of players. Unlike many other strategic industries, it does not have the structure to act together.  Traditionally, the CAP has attempted to deal with this problem by market intervention measures and, as CAP has been reformed, more emphasis and more budget has been given to direct payments to support farmers’ decoupled incomes, in some way trying to use that as a mechanism for riding volatility. But has this worked? I suggest not, as we have these continuing crises. This report lays out a number of tools that can be used, but frankly, I do not see that any of them are new. Price intervention – not new; crisis reserve – not new; risk management tools and mutual funds in pillar 2 – that is not new, and the encouragement of producer organisations is not new either. That is not because we are all very dull people who cannot think of new things; it is because we really have tried most of the options available to us. These already exist. The report calls on further development of these tools and this is welcome, but what else can we do? There is no level playing field as Member States have huge flexibility in how they apply pillar 2 support, but I do not think we should take that flexibility away. They also have huge differences in how much pillar 2 support they actually get. In order to redress these imbalances, the answer is not necessarily more money as suggested in a number of places in this report, but perhaps a complete review and reallocation of the CAP funding based on today’s data and designed to tackle today’s problems, including price volatility. If we continue to work on a historic basis, we will be doing European agriculture a disservice, giving no incentive to move forward. My group believes that the best way to help farmers ride the rollercoaster of price volatility is to increase their efficiency and encourage their profitability.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. — Madam President, 30 years ago, during our studies, we were taught that agricultural products are subject to far the greatest instability. I can understand that it was 30, 40, 50, 100 years ago, but still I can't understand how today we still have to talk about it. Today, when we have all the knowledge, when we have all the possible mechanisms at our disposal, we are still talking about the same topic that we all learned together 30 years ago, at least those who are engaged in economics or agriculture. So what I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, is the fact that we have to do more for our agriculture, do much, much more. And let's not forget that countries such as the United States of America, such as China or Brazil, have decided to seriously invest in agriculture. With the choice of Mr. Trump seeking to commit primarily to his state, at least so he says, one can expect U.S. policy to be even more focused toward supporting industry and agriculture in America. Therefore, we will have and how to discuss in the coming years, if we do not support our agriculture. But there is not only a question of us within the European Union, that is, us at the level of the European Union, but I want to talk about the Member States, but I also want to talk about regional and local authorities, about all the mechanisms that are available to us because we are not only at our disposal mechanisms that you manage. Mr. Commissioner, or the European Commission. There are a lot of mechanisms and a lot of tools at our disposal. And that's why I want to talk about the problems we face at this point when we're talking about the need to protect our agriculture and especially when we're talking about what's been offered right now by Ms. Rapporteur, which is a new amendment that wants to speak clearly about unfair trading practices. From field to trade we have too much dishonesty towards our farmers and therefore I invite you to really do everything to ensure that our agriculture gets the right protection.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the fundamental reason for the volatility in agricultural markets is the globalisation of our food supply, and allowing speculation on world commodity markets to dictate prices to the detriment of the primary producer. Using financial instruments in CAP for managing price risks, rather than reducing and addressing the causes of price volatility, ignores the reality. The financialisation of our food supply, where you have highly organised financial institutions with access to information exerting control over fragmented producers, the level of support they get and therefore food supply, is another step along the road of locking farmers into a treadmill of debt and below—cost production. It is the normalisation of a form of slavery for the farmers.  Farmers themselves have to realise that the best long-term solution to price volatility would be product diversification, and for them to focus on what the market required and not to buy into the spin of the vested interests and to engage in a race to the bottom for the benefits of multinationals. Trade agreements such as CETA, TTIP and Mercosur further increase problems by exposing farmers on both sides of the Atlantic to increased pressures that they simply cannot bear. When we hear of the positives, we hear about positives for the agri-food industry. This does not necessarily mean positives for the farmer. Whether these trade agreements will bring difficulties in a financial sense or in a mental health sense because of extra competition, it is not going to be worth it. On basic income we need that, not just in farming but in a lot of different sectors. Mechanisation will make sure of that.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Climate change, globalisation, market instability, unfair business practices are just a few of the causes of price fluctuations that we will face in the future. Under these conditions, we must strive for the smallest farms, especially families, to remain, because they ensure the creation of jobs in remote regions and support rural viability. As you know, direct payments are a predicted and fixed share of farm income, which is especially important in times of crisis. Direct payments allow the farmer to plan this part of the income, the farmer knows exactly when and how much, what payments will receive, but the current unevenness in direct payments distorts the market. I regret that the report did not take into account the fundamental remark of the Committee on Budgets that, in order to ensure a level playing field in the Single Market and the sustainable use of agricultural resources at European Union level, it is necessary to harmonise direct payments between Member States. Production costs are similar across Europe. Is it not time to show that the European Union is solidarity and equally appreciates the work of every farmer, no matter where he works? Another important proposal is the education of farmers. Avoiding crises, it is important to educate farmers how to avoid, reduce the impact of crises, how to properly choose measures and not waste resources, but to ensure sustainable farming.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, volatility is a fact of life in farming and we have seen this work to positive effect quite recently. The sugar beet price is going up; all the surplus beet that farmers produce in the UK this season will be paid for at the full price. Next year there is going to be a higher price. For milk, the price is going up. It does work that way around. In October farmers sowed a wheat crop. In that month they had the opportunity to sell that crop for GBP 130 a tonne for the following November, 13 months later. They had that opportunity because of a futures market.  They could also, by using a futures market, have bought an option to have sold their crop for GBP 130 per tonne; that would cost them GBP 7 per tonne. In other words, they were guaranteed a rock bottom price of GBP 123 per tonne. If the price was higher than that they could take it. But futures depend on speculation: one-third speculators, one-third producers, and one-third users of the commodity; it has to be in that ratio. But the EU, through its MiFID legislation, is trying to get rid of the speculators. It is trying to de-speculate. If you de-speculate the futures market then you do not have a futures market and so the farmers cannot benefit.  Things sort themselves out. The potato futures market collapsed 20 or 30 years ago because it was over-speculated; this can happen. Of course we have another tool and the Commissioner did mention it: the annual farm payment, whatever you like to call it. In poor years, well, this is your prop – what you lean on. In good years, it is a chance to re-invest in your business. So the combination of futures markets and the single farm payment should keep most farmers going along pretty nicely. Remember, farmers are businessmen, they are in there to take risks and make a good profit. They are not the employees of the state working on nationalised land.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the profession of the farmer is a trade made of passion, effort, sacrifice and mastery and these palaces, unfortunately, have not yet learned to respect this craft. Respect for agricultural activity cannot and should not be an electoral slogan, but must materialise within the acts of these European buildings, it must materialise within the CAP, it must materialize in the rules on the internal market. In the name, unfortunately, of the free market you have disintegrated our agriculture. Not to govern imports, rather the invasions of cheap and low-quality product, we step on the efforts of our farmers, efforts of heroes farmers who guard the environment, sow the produced, they irrigate it, treat it, collect it, store it and try to market it. Think that then in the end they have to do the math — it's absurd, if we think that just this year growing one hectare of rice means getting four quintals of rice, it means getting two hundred euros and spending it One hundred and ninety, it means having an assumed margin, potential of two euros, two euros and fifty, three euros per fifty. We reflect, reflect colleagues, and most importantly act before it's too late.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Madam President, farmers across the European Union deplore the fact that their incomes are falling and the areas exploited are diminishing sharply. During this time, production costs have increased considerably, leading to higher prices, with a hard impact to bear both for agricultural producers and consumers. Under these circumstances, price volatility is extremely severe in the agricultural sector, which is vulnerable to fluctuations in domestic and foreign markets, global consumption trends and climate change. Agricultural producers are hard to manage these effects, and national public authorities unfortunately do not use effective tools to regulate imbalances on markets. I therefore consider that it is necessary to strengthen the process of setting up and development of producer organisations and associations in the agricultural sectors, in order to create their own production, processing, storage and sales capacities. The negotiating power must also be increased when establishing medium-term and long-term contracts, as well as facilitating the supply of supermarkets in what we call the short supply chain. At European Union level, it is important to set up a forecasting unit, which forecasts sector production and market absorption capacities, so that farmers can effectively link their demand with supply. The development of mutual funds in agriculture and production insurance instruments is a real support for farmers to prevent price volatility, but also to combat damage in this sector.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the collapse in prices for many agricultural products, accompanied by the extreme volatility which has led to increasing fluctuations in recent years, Unpredictable and unfortunately, often, downward prices themselves, it is posing serious risks to the sustainability of a sector vital to the European economy such as the agri-food sector. If price volatility is a phenomenon that has always characterised agricultural markets, the current size, and even more those that can be achieved in perspective, require effort common in order to ensure agricultural production that can respond to the global challenge of food security while ensuring stable and adequate incomes for our farmers. The measures envisaged in the last reform of the common agricultural policy to counter market variability have proved insufficient, as demonstrated by the crisis affecting the sector dairy. Among other things, the introduction of a complex bureaucratic fulfillment facility has effectively mortified the potential these instruments might have in protecting European agricultural enterprises from risks of market. The fact that the Income Stabilization Tool, considered one of the most innovative instruments introduced since the last reform, has only been applied in three countries of the Union confirms the need to take action at most soon, in order to make the current measures simpler, more effective, more efficient, as well as more usable by all Member States. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur Angélique Delahaye for the text we are preparing to vote on, which is an excellent starting point, offering important ideas not only in the short term, with interventions that may be included already in the framework of the omnibus package, but also in the long term, opening a more detailed reflection on the use of aid countercyclical protection of farmers' incomes, with a view to complementarity between initiatives aimed at managing risks and market crises on the one hand.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Our agricultural policy is more and more market-oriented. Farmers want to be able to keep their own pants. Give them the possibilities for that. Hardworking agricultural entrepreneurs must be given the tools for fair market operation along the entire chain. That is why it is extremely important for the legislator to clarify the existing possibilities for farmers and gardeners to be able to organise themselves. So they can together make a fist in the chain. Unlike large companies, individual farmers and gardeners do not have an army of lawyers to see where opportunities lie between the complex rules. In addition, farmers and gardeners should have more opportunities to cover business risks such as low prices or bad weather conditions. The next step is for Member States to ensure that these risk instruments work well and that farmers and gardeners can actually use them. I have also tabled amendments to this end. Simple, clear and clear rules ensure that the market offers a fair outcome for everyone. We must all continue to strive for that.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, less than a month ago we saw the publication of the Agricultural Markets Task Force report on enhancing the position of farmers in the supply chain. That report correctly cited farmers as the main shock—absorbers in volatile markets. Now before Parliament we have a report that denies exactly that.  The control by corporate market forces over agricultural prices is the main source of volatility, yet this report would see the problem being the solution: mutual funds, private insurance schemes and increased competitiveness on third markets are all cited as tools to stabilise farming incomes and reduce farm debt. Farmers, who are price takers and not price makers, stand to be swallowed up by a system that pushes private institutions to deal with the agricultural crisis. I believe that if we support this report we will be doing a huge disservice to our farmers and to the communities that depend on them.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Madam President! We have always been able to live on the farms with certain price fluctuations if we make profits on average over the years. But now we are dealing with volatile markets that we can no longer accept. We need to talk about the causes now. Climate change and associated crop fluctuations have already been addressed — that is, resilient farming methods. But we also need to talk about how our markets work. We need to talk about how we can reconcile supply and demand. I am convinced that our aggressive export strategy is doing a lot of damage here. Unreliable third markets are part of the problem. Food speculation is playing into this. In 2009, 2010, the food was withdrawn from the market and then placed it back on the market after the price increase with the large business. And biofuels are still playing into the hands of speculation. If we oppose this only risk management, insurance instruments, where the little money of the second pillar goes into, then insurance will ultimately win, but certainly not the farmers.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, thank you Commissioner for your presence. First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Angélique Delahaye for this report on this subject of volatility. Four years ago, when we were preparing for the reform of the CAP, the thought that had the wind was to say that there would be no crisis anymore, because all world prices were in an upward trend. Not many of us were calling for tools, and it is clear that you were very happy, Commissioner, to be able to use the few that have been made available to you. They don't go far enough, we know today. So, as has been said, we need to use the omnibus to perfect copying and giving farmers market management tools. Volatility is first of all the fruit of obscurantism. Volatility affects both the upstream and downstream of agriculture, and ultimately the farmer, because he is isolated, is the victim of it. We must therefore resolutely not only find tools, but also to support farmers in a better organisation, give them contracts which, over the course of time, will guarantee them an opportunity, an income, and which will allow industrialists to have a guarantee of supply, because we always talk about crises when they are in the world. the farmer's detriment, but in the recent past we have experienced crises that were at the detrients of the downstream, and downstream will be happy to have contracts that ensure it over the long term. The question must be asked, Commissioner, as to why in most European countries producer organisations are not stronger.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: — Madam President, I will try to be original in this debate, first of all to say that, in the light of the situation where agricultural aid does not take account of the economic reality of farmers at all, in view of the fact that the Commission obviously remains in a budgetary shackle in which it must evolve, which the Council overtakes, the image of Antonio Maspes — whose memory I recall, who was a seven-time track cyclist and who was the surplace specialist; he stayed once 32 minutes in a world championship before winning the final by surplacing — Parliament, and Mrs Delahaye's report, is undoubtedly a flash in the grisaille, thanks in particular to Nicolas Caputo, who was able to obtain compromises that make the countercyclical aids finally on the carpet. It is true that countercyclical aid allows farmers to take account of the economic reality of farmers, in order to help them in the best and the most just. But, of course, this poses a difficulty — indeed, I am speaking under the supervision of Jean Arthuis, who will speak after me — it poses a budgetary problem, because of course, there is no question of talking in annuities at the level of the agricultural budget, since countercyclical aid can be different from year to year. But they are interesting, Madam President, these countercyclical aid, and I would like the Commissioner to tell us his opinion on the idea of having countercyclical aid in the future.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: — Madam President, I too wish to welcome Mrs Delahaye's proposals, particularly the establishment of insurance systems. Anxiety and despair affect the peasant world and more particularly the breeders. The changes in the CAP have eliminated regulatory instruments on the promise of dynamic and lucrative exports. In this new context, production volumes have increased, while the decline of some external markets has precipitated the fall in prices. As a result, many milk and meat producers sell at a loss. We are measuring the urgency of providing intelligent protection tools to prevent and resolve crisis situations. The angelism of the Union cannot make trade self-disarmament a dogma and make agriculture the adjustment variable in free trade agreements. The same applies to competition law and the prohibition of cartels. Let us be pragmatic and dare to establish European mechanisms for balancing supply and demand without excessive nostalgia for quotas. I think it is appropriate to entrust the associations comprising producers, the PDOs, to regulate according to the level of prices the volumes delivered on the basis of commitments defined at European level. Commissioner, it is time for Europe to get out of its always cheaper obsession and finally reconcile producers and consumers.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Madam President, this report tries to seek instruments in the CAP to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets, but forgets that price volatility is a consequence of the CAP itself, which, when it prioritizes exports, liberalises agricultural markets, deregulates production and destroys any possibility of allowing a decent income for farmers and farmers through the prices of their products. The proposals made in this report do not go beyond instruments for managing the crisis and risks and, moreover, they intend to finance some of these instruments by transferring part of the money that farmers and farmers receive today to other sectors such as insurance companies. This seems totally unacceptable to us. But, in fact, if you want to reduce volatility, Mr Hogan, the Commission, the Council and Parliament must implement a public common agricultural policy that prioritizes the internal market, which equip itself with the necessary tools to regulate the production of markets, which balances supply and demand and equip the sector. a serious collective bargaining framework, allowing minimum price agreements covering production costs and remunerating labour in all sectors, and which, in addition, give back to agrarian organisations — which farmers and farmers have endowed themselves — their negotiating role.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: — First of all, congratulations to my colleague Delahaya on an excellent prepared report, for cooperation with the Commission on this acute problem. Unfair practices in the food chain are certainly one of the key problems we face today, and ultimately bring profits to speculators and hard times to honest, working farmers. Therefore, I propose that we also write in Europe on products or it is fair trade. It is not enough to talk about fair shops only about coffee coming from other continents, let's also ask ourselves if European products, when, I do not know, milk is bought at 19 cents, 20 cents or any other product, according to the principle of fair trade. Another important message from this report is that farmers also need to connect and act more efficiently and thus also place a better position in this particular market. Most likely, in the future Common Agricultural Policy, it will be necessary to devote more resources to these actions than we have today. I also put a lot on what the Commissioner has already said, that we need to support young farmers. These young farmers will bring new grips into agriculture as well as to market these agricultural products, they will create new opportunities for rural jobs, use modern technologies, digital platforms, and also establish smart villages — smart villages — where emerging new jobs. We have to conclude a partnership between the farmer and the consumer, and that's when all of us struggles will go.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the crisis in recent years has highlighted all the limits of the common agricultural policy and, in particular, its inability to deal with effective systems price volatility, allowing farmers to face the price swing. The result was that many companies, too many companies were forced to shut down. At this moment we know what priorities are to be changed, no longer sufficient emergency measures, one-off, it is necessary to create a stable system to protect our farmers, it is necessary to favour aggregation in order to have greater bargaining power towards large distribution. Favouring producer organizations is not enough, we have to affect the dimensional growth of OPs. In order to cope with price volatility and greater income stability, farmers must have access to facilitated financial instruments, in this the EIB should play a key role. The system of credit for agriculture must be facilitated, farmers must be able to rely on a banking system that grants loans, gives value to land, so that they can initiate investments, reforms structural and technological innovation that allow farmers to finally face the crisis.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, increased price volatility since 2007 has changed the rules of the game. Farmers are often confronted with a volatility which becomes problematic, where price movements are large and unpredictable. In addition, the current fragmentation of the agricultural sector brings some actors to the chain that abuse their market power and create unfair trading practices.  Unfortunately, during these periods of falling prices, farmers represent the main shock absorber for the entire industry and see their margins shrink rapidly. In this context, I firmly believe in a fairer functioning of the food supply chain. We must pay attention to the process by which food is produced, processed, transported and sold to the consumers. It is crucial to reinforce the weak bargaining position of farmers and change the role of the producer organisation and cooperatives.  Let me conclude by expressing that we must invest even further in the potential of the instrument to deal with price volatility. Farmers do deserve to get a fair price for their products.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Madam President, as is rightly said, volatility is a complex process with many causes. However, we should not mix these causes, because otherwise we are applying the wrong instruments to combat this volatility. The fever can be caused by a virus or a bacterium. Treatment to be efficient always implies a correct diagnosis. In this case, I fear that climate randomness is deliberately blending with financial speculation and price manipulation by large multinationals and large distribution. To seek to impute climate change the greatest cause of increasing price volatility is to seek to impose or accentuate an increasingly market-oriented reform of the CAP and further aggravate the causes of this instability. Naturally, this is not about the stability of farmers. What is at stake here is the definitive abandonment of a logic of direct income support — this, yes, stable — by an income insurance logic, copying the North American model. Price volatility is combated with public regulatory instruments rather than financial instruments.

name: Norbert LINS
text: — Commissioner, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I can only join many of the previous speakers. However, I expressly do not share the view of the Greens that the European Union would pursue an aggressive export strategy, but the European Union is pursuing a moderate export strategy, and this can help to ensure that we are not only dependent on a market, not just on our own market, but also on our home market. can also generate better value creation in other markets. No, we need to strengthen the position of farmers in the food chain. So far, they are clearly the weakest link in the chain. Price volatility in markets is nothing unusual. The agricultural sector is particularly vulnerable to extreme fluctuations for various economic, natural and political reasons. At the moment, the majority of market partners and food retailers do not recognise and assume responsibility for domestic agriculture. Unfair trade practices, however, must not be easily tolerated. There is a need for action in the form of a legislative text to strengthen the bargaining power of farmers. The aim is to create a safe living and working basis for those who produce safe and high-quality food every day — namely farmers.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, I also congratulate you on this report, and I have a special thanks to Mr Nicola Caputo, who has really done a great deal of work on the socialist proposals that are largely reflected in this material. And not only our political group, but also many committees could make very important, valuable contributions. It's clearer than day: farmers are almost crazy about extreme price fluctuations, perhaps more afraid of this than the many challenges of the weather. And I think that if this Parliament can contribute with this report so that they can live their lives in a more stable price environment, we have already done a great deal towards food security and food security, which is, by the way, the unforgotten objective of the common agricultural policy. I feel that the CAP would remain extremely fragile without the instruments that have been set up here, and I would also recommend that these measures be called agricultural stabilisers.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, the report is strategic in that it points to a range of possible ways to tackle the volatility of agricultural prices, at a time when it is clear that we have insufficient resources to deal with it. The crisis in the dairy sector that we have witnessed over the last two and a half years, mentioned here by the Commissioner, is proof of this. If we do not strengthen the resources, we will put at serious risk the sustainability of agricultural activity in Europe, especially in areas where it contributes most to the establishment of the population, such as the Azores. Here, the consequences of agricultural crises can have an impact amplified by the outermost nature, including increased production costs, and the weight of agriculture in the local economy. We therefore call for specific indicators for the outermost regions to be taken into account in order to trigger measures in the event of crisis in the agricultural sector in order to guarantee a sustainable level of income for farmers in these regions.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, price volatility in agricultural products markets is one of the causes of uncertainty of farmers and affects their ability to produce and create jobs. Pressed by high production costs due to volatility of materials and energy prices, depending on developments in the global market, are unprotected from most of the risks of production, and previous measures and funds from the agriculture budget do not seem sufficient to mitigate these risks successfully. The income they need to guarantee a decent life is disappearing. This discourages their investment in modernisation, innovation, prevents young farmers from entering the business and generational restoration of rural spaces. Family farms are the most vulnerable link in the food supply chain. That is why legislation at European level should suppress unfair trade practices and set legal frameworks for implementing measures such as collective contracting of longer contract deadlines, stable prices of agricultural products, reasonable payment deadlines and other conditions related to production, and aimed at balanced distribution of production risks along the entire food supply chain.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank all the people that responded to this very important debate. As you know, the common agricultural policy that was agreed in 2013 by the co-legislators reiterated in support of the market orientation of that policy. This is what the Council and the European Parliament decided, and, in any policy which is dependent on the market, price volatility is an inevitable feature. The last two years have tested the adequacy or otherwise of the measures, and we need – as several speakers have said here this evening – to work together to ensure that farmers are provided with the appropriate tools to deal with price volatility, and we need to learn and look at the market experience of the past two years in relation to what tools we require.  In my opening remarks, I said that we must work at removing obstacles to the use of these market tools in the present CAP. If, as Mr Dorfmann or Mr De Castro suggest, it is because of red tape, then we must make the policy simpler. Simplification is something that I very much support, and I will do everything possible to reduce red tape in the agricultural sector, as I am already doing.  Of course it may also be – as Ms Girling said – that we have used all the tools that are available. If that is the case, we need collectively to be more imaginative and see if there are other proposals that we can make in this regard. Next year’s communication provides an opportunity for this House and for the Council, and I am committed to working constructively with all stakeholders to help our farmers in this regard.  A number of speakers have referred to the need to ensure sustainable production, and I want to agree with Mr Ropė when he identifies small farmers as being central to the future of sustainable agricultural production and sustainable rural communities in Europe. We need to ensure that farmers, who are our boots on the ground in the context of implementing environment and climate action, continue to be the custodians of our policy in our rural areas, and also the custodians of our rural environment.  Mr De Castro also referred to the need to remove obstacles to such tools as the Income Stabilisation Mechanism, and you and all Members of the House will get an opportunity to assist me in a proposal in this regard in the Omnibus Regulation which is coming before the House in 2017. So I urge you to adopt this regulation, as Mr Dantin noted, to help farmers to get easier access to the income stabilisation tool and to get easier access to credit through the reforms that I am making and the changes in the financial instruments.  Despite any differences which may exist in this House and between our respective institutions, there is clear agreement across the board on the need to strengthen the position of farmers in the food chain and to tackle the issue of unfair trading practices. I agree with what Mr Tarabella said in this regard. I would also remind the House that the Council adopted Council conclusions yesterday, which, along with the overwhelming vote of this Parliament, are making a very important statement and contribution towards the need for the Commission to come forward with proposals in the work programme of 2017 to try to deal with this issue of the position of the farmer in the food chain.  I should also say that, despite the support that farmers get from the European Union and our national governments to co-finance programmes, most farmers would like to get their income from the market. That means having access to the market, and getting a fair return from the market. So we need fair trade, not always free trade, and farmers are benefitting from well negotiated free trade agreements and access to third—country markets. We are making good progress in this regard, and I am confident that this trend will continue. We cannot continue to have farmers’ production in storage at the expense of the European Union taxpayer all the time. We have to find outlets for that, internally and externally.  In terms of achieving a fair return, I welcome the report of the Agricultural Markets Task Force. The Commission is currently considering those recommendations very carefully, and this will inform the proposal I will make in 2017. I would like to remind Mr Serrão Santos, that farmers in the Azores under the POSEI scheme are getting at up to EUR 250 extra per cow in the dairy sector if they wish to utilise that, in addition to voluntary coupled support from the Portuguese Government. These are instruments that are already available and which are being utilised by your regional government and your national government in Portugal in order to assist your dairy farmers.  Finally, I would like once again to express my appreciation to Ms Delahaye and the shadow rapporteurs for the work done in producing this report. This will serve as very important information and recommendations to me in the context of the work programme for 2017 and the legislative proposals and measures that we will bring forward in the context of the position of the farmer in the food chain.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, for those who are still in the Chamber, I would like to tell Mr Flanagan that I share his view on the consequences of globalisation, just as I share Mr Agnew's view on the role and place of farmers as entrepreneurs and not in as employees of a central government. Much has been said in this Chamber, but we are at the stage of observation, and this report which we co-built with the rapporteurs and all the groups, for those who wished to participate, goes further. I hope that is what we will remember. In any case, Mr Hogan, I intend to look very closely at the proposals you will make to us and thank you for taking into account the proposals that will be voted on by this Parliament, like this report.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. — The economic situation of European farms is unfortunately quite far from stabilising. This is largely due to the peculiarities of this sector, which like no other is dependent on natural factors, and these are difficult to predict. Adding to this are the issues of changes in international turnover and demand in the local market. This all affects a lot of price volatility, which has negative consequences for both food producers and consumers. Therefore, we need effective measures that will lead to a maximum reduction in price fluctuations. I share the rapporteur's view that the risk management support currently offered by the CAP under the second pillar is insufficient. Risk management instruments must be revised and, where appropriate, expanded. It is also necessary to strive for as much market transparency as possible. The overarching objective of these measures should be to guarantee a decent level of income for farmers and to create a stable market for goods for consumers.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: in writing. — The persistently difficult situation on agricultural markets is now causing massive distortions. I welcome this landmark parliamentary resolution, which makes securing farm income the highest priority. Farmers must finally be able to calculate again and earn an income from the price of the product. At the moment, we see a pure profit maximization of the retail groups and their lobby. One example is the steadily rising milk price in Europe, which is not passed on to farmers, or only months, is passed on to farmers. The total sell-off and undercutting competition at the expense of farmers must finally come to an end. Concrete measures to strengthen agricultural organisations, the establishment of European agricultural price observatories and the creation of a new legislative framework that will put the safeguards of the common agricultural policy on competition law can restore the position of farmers in the food chain be strengthened. I therefore call on the European Commission to deliver the proposals quickly and unbureaucratically to put an end to price dumping. This parliamentary resolution is a strong sign of support for family farms. We are with all our strength behind the farmers. Quality food has its price. Price dumping, on the other hand, is only a door opener for mass production and standard food!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. — The EU is the world's largest importer and exporter of agri-food products. However, the possibilities of using the CAP rural development programmes to strengthen the systems of insurance, mutual funds and farm income stabilisation have not produced the desired results. Moreover, the liberalisation of markets by abolishing customs duties from third countries creates problems both for agricultural production and for European farmers. At the same time, the EU's refusal to lift sanctions against Russia has affected farmers in the European South and beyond. Particularly for Greece, the problems in the rural world are inflated because of the tax policy imposed by the troika. The increase in the tax on agricultural oil, the annihilation of subsidies and the confiscation of the few subsidies from the government have led to an impasse on my country's farmers. The austerity policy undermines investment, modernisation and discourages young people from engaging in the agricultural sector. Finally, there must be a strengthening of the instruments to support agricultural incomes in areas affected by serious natural disasters.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. — It is increasingly clear that instruments under the second pillar of the CAP are not sufficient to combat the volatility of agricultural prices. Regarding the current CAP instruments, the latest available data show that they have been used by twelve Member States to counter price volatility. In total, EUR 2.7 billion of public expenditure was allocated (of which EUR 1.7 billion comes from rural development funds). Unfortunately, although they have increased compared to the funds allocated to the previous CAP system, this expenditure still accounts for only 0.4% of CAP expenditure and less than 2% of expenditure under the second pillar. The European Commission should, in the forthcoming reform of the CAP, pay particular attention to market instruments and ensure consistent and decent incomes for farmers.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - The farm market has always been characterised by instability and price changes. In recent years, due to the rapidly occurring major changes in demand, presentation and prices, this has become a structural feature of agriculture at European, but also at global level. There are many reasons for this. Climate change and pests in agriculture have a negative impact on agricultural production, which directly affects prices. Therefore, the responsibility of the European Union in contributing to the provision of food safety in Europe must be increased. European farmers, especially from newly acceded countries, as well as from Lithuania, are increasingly exposed to risks independent of them. The EU should therefore increase its aid to farmers in these countries. The EU should guarantee stability in the agricultural sector, as price volatility causes a high level of uncertainty among producers and consumers. At low prices, manufacturers see risks to their profits and investment capacities, while high food prices cause difficulties in acquiring basic foods, which leads to a crisis situation. It is necessary to provide Member States with additional tools and guarantee aid in terms of crop, animal and plant bans, investment funds and a new income stabilisation mechanism. In this way, it will be possible to eliminate the established instability in the agricultural sector.
